  <i>jo</i>) into <i>go</i>, III. 33; for creating the remarkable 'ghost-word' <i>gofysshe</i>, III.
  584; and a few similar curiosities. But I found it worth while to collate it throughout; and
  readings from it are marked 'Ed.' The later black-letter copies are mere reproductions of it.</p>
<p>§ <a id="stro27"></a>27. <span class="sc">The Present Edition.</span> The present edition has
  the great advantage of being founded upon Cl. and Cp., neither of which have been previously made
  use of, though they are the two best. Bell's text is founded upon the Harleian MSS. numbered 1239,
  2280, and 3943, in separate fragments; hence the text is neither uniform nor very good. Morris's
  text is much better, being founded upon H. (closely related to Cl. and Cp.), with a few
  corrections from other unnamed sources.</p>
<p>Thanks to the prints provided by the Chaucer Society, I have been able to produce a text which,
  I trust, leaves but little to be desired. I point out some of the passages which now appear in a
  correct form for the first time, as may be seen by comparison with the editions by Morris and
  Bell, which I denote by M. and B.</p>
<p>I. 136; <i>derre</i>, dearer; M. B. dere (no rime). 285. <i>meninge</i>, i. e. intention;
  <i>and so in</i> l. 289; M. B. mevynge. 388. M. B. insert a semicolon after <i>arten</i>. 465.
  <i>fownes</i> (see note);  M. B. fantasye (line too long). 470 <i>felle</i>, fell, pl. adj.; M. B.
  fille, i. e. fell (verb). 590. <i>no comfort</i>; M. comfort; B. eny comfort. 786.
  <i>Ticius</i> (see note); M. Syciphus; B. Siciphus. 896. <i>Thee oughte</i>; M. To oght (no
  sense); B. The oght (will not scan). 1026. See note; put as a question in M. B.; B. even inserts
  <i>not</i> before <i>to done</i>. 1050. <i>me asterte</i>; M. may sterte; B. me stert
  (better).</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="pagelxxvii">{lxxvii}</span></div>
<p>II. 41. <i>seyde</i>, i. e. if that they seyde; M. B. seyinge (will not scan). 138.
  <i>were</i> (would there be); M. B. is. 180. <i>wight</i>; M. B. knyght (but see l. 177). 808.
  <i>looth</i>; M. B. leve. 834. <i>Ye</i>; M. B. The. 1596. <i>For for</i>; M. B. For.</p>
<p>III. 17. <i>Comeveden</i> (see note); M. Comeneden; B. Commodious. <i>him</i>; M. B. hem. 33.
  <i>io</i> (= <i>jo</i>); M. B. go. 49. M. B. omit <i>gladnes</i>. 572. <i>Yow thurfte</i>; M. Thow
  thruste; B. Yow durst. 584. <i>goosish</i>; M. goofish; B. gofisshe. 674. M. Thei voide
  [<i>present</i>], dronke [<i>past</i>], and traveres drawe [<i>present</i>] anon; B. They voyded,
  and drunk, and travars drew anone. Really, <i>dronke</i> and <i>drawe</i> are both past
  participles; see note. 725. <i>Cipris</i>; M. Cyphes; B. Ciphis. 1231. <i>Bitrent and wryth</i>,
  i. e. winds about and wreathes itself; M. Bytrent and writhe is; B. Bitrent and writhen is.
  <i>Wryth</i> is short for <i>writheth</i>; not a pp. 1453. <i>bore</i>, i. e. hole; M. boure;
  B. bowre. 1764. <i>to-hepe</i>, i. e. together; M. B. to kepe.</p>
<p>IV. 538. <i>kyth</i>; M. B. right (no sense). 696. <i>thing is</i>; M. B. thynges is.  818.
  <i>martyre</i>; M. B. matere (neither sense nor rime).</p>
<p>V. 49. <i>helpen</i>; M. B. holpen. 469. <i>howve</i>; M. B. howen. 583. <i>in my</i>; M. B.
  omit <i>my</i>. 927. <i>wight</i>; M. B. with. 1208. <i>trustinge</i>; M. B. trusten (against
  grammar). 1266. <i>bet</i>; M. B. beste. 1335, 6. <i>wyte The teres</i>, i. e. blame the
  tears; M. B. wite With teres. 1386. <i>Commeve</i>; M. Com in to; B. Can meven. 1467. <i>She</i>;
  M. B. So. 1791. <i>pace</i>; M. B. space (see note).</p>
<p>It is curious to find that such remarkable words as <i>commeveden</i>, <i>io</i>,
  <i>voidee</i>, <i>goosish</i>, <i>to-hepe</i>, appear in no Chaucerian glossary; they are only
  found in the MSS., being ignored in the editions.</p>
<p>A large number of lines are now, for the first time, spelt with forms that comply with grammar
  and enable the lines to be scanned. For example, M. and B. actually give <i>wente</i> and
  <i>wonte</i> in V. 546, instead of <i>went</i> and <i>wont</i>; <i>knotles</i> for
  <i>knotteles</i> in V. 769, &amp;c.</p>
<p>I have also, for the first time, numbered the lines and stanzas correctly. In M., Books III.
  and IV. are both misnumbered, causing much trouble in reference. Dr. Furnivall's print of the
  Campsall MS. omits I. 890-6; and his print of MS. Harl. 3943 counts in the Latin lines here
  printed at p. <a href="#page404" class="pginternal">404</a>.</p>
<p>§ <a id="stro28"></a>28. It is worth notice that Troilus contains about fifty lines <span class="pagenum" id="pagelxxviii">{lxxviii}</span>in which the first foot consists of a single
  syllable. Examples in Book I are<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p>That | the hot-e fyr of lov' him brende: 490.</p>
<p>Lov' | ayeins the which who-so defendeth: 603.</p>
<p>Twen | ty winter that his lady wiste: 811.</p>
<p>Wer' | it for my suster, al thy sorwe: 860.</p>
<p>Next | the foule netle, rough and thikke: 948.</p>
<p>Now | Pandar', I can no mor-e seye: 1051.</p>
<p>Al | derfirst his purpos for to winne: 1069.</p>
</div>
<p>So also II. 369, 677, 934, 1034, 1623 (and probably 1687); III. 412, 526, 662, 855 (perhaps
  1552), 1570; IV. 176, 601, 716, 842, 1328, 1676; V. 67 (perhaps 311), 334, 402, 802, 823, 825,
  831, 880, 887, 949, 950, 1083, 1094, 1151, 1379, 1446, 1454, 1468, 1524.</p>
<p>It thus appears that deficient lines of this character are by no means confined to the poems in
  'heroic verse,' but occur in stanzas as well. Compare the Parlement of Foules, 445, 569.</p>
<p>§ <a id="stro29"></a>29. <span class="sc">Proverbs.</span> Troilus contains a considerable
  number of proverbs and proverbial phrases or similes. See, e. g., I. 257, 300, 631, 638, 694,
  708, 731, 740, 946-952, 960, 964, 1002, 1024; II. 343, 398, 403, 585, 784, 804, 807, 861, 867,
  1022, 1030, 1041, 1238, 1245, 1332, 1335, 1380, 1387, 1553, 1745; III. 35, 198, 294, 308, 329,
  405, 526, 711, 764, 775, 859, 861, 931, 1625, 1633; IV. 184, 415, 421, 460, 588, 595, 622, 728,
  836, 1098, 1105, 1374, 1456, 1584; V. 484, 505, 784, 899, 971, 1174, 1265, 1433.</p>
<p>§ <a id="stro30"></a>30. A translation of the first two books of Troilus into Latin verse, by
  Sir Francis Kinaston, was printed at Oxford in 1635. The volume also contains a few notes, but I
  do not find in them anything of value. The author tries to reproduce the English stanza, as
  thus<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Dolorem Troili duplicem narrare,</p>
<p>Qui Priami Regis Trojae fuit gnatus,</p>
<p>Vt primùm illi contigit amare,</p>
<p>Vt miser, felix, et infortunatus</p>
<p>Erat, decessum ante sum conatus.</p>
<p>Tisiphone, fer opem recensere</p>
<p>Hos versus, qui, dum scribo, visi flere.'</p>
</div>
<p>For myself, I prefer the English.</p>
<p class="sp5">§ <a id="stro31"></a>31. Hazlitt's Handbook to Popular Literature records the
  following title:—'A Paraphrase vpon the 3 first bookes of Chaucer's Troilus and Cressida.
  Translated into modern English ... by J[onathan] S[idnam]. About 1630. Folio; 70 leaves; in 7-line
  stanzas.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="pagelxxix">{lxxix}</span></div>
<h1 class="sp3 ac" style="margin-bottom:4.7ex;"> <span class="x-larger">ERRATA AND
  ADDENDA.</span></h1>
<p class="ac">I. BOETHIUS.</p>
<p>P. 8, Book I, met. 4, l. 8. <i>For</i> thonder-light <i>a better reading is</i> thonder-leit;
  see p. xliii, and the note (p. 422).</p>
<p>P. 10; foot-notes, l. 10. <i>Read</i>: C. vnplitable; A. inplitable.</p>
<p>P. 26, Book II, met. 1, l. 11. <i>For</i> proeueth <i>read</i> proeveth.</p>
<p>P. 29, Book II, pr. 3, l. 3. <i>Delete the comma after</i> wherwith.</p>
<p>P. 48, Book II, pr. 7, l. 86. <i>For</i> thas <i>read</i> that.</p>
<p>P. 50, Book II, pr. 8, l. 17. <i>For</i> windinge <i>read</i> windy. See pp. xlii, 434.</p>
<p>P. 58, Book III, pr. 3, l. 68. <i>For</i> all <i>read</i> al.</p>
<p>P. 62, l. 4. Counted as l. 10; it is really l. 9.</p>
<p>P. 63, Book III, pr. 5, l. 41. <i>For</i> of <i>read</i> <i>of</i> (in italics).</p>
<p>P. 74, Book III, pr. 10, l. 6. <i>For</i> has <i>read</i> hast.</p>
<p>P. 111. The side-number 215 is one line too high.</p>
<p>P. 122, Book IV, met. 6, l. 24. Delete the square brackets; see pp. xlii, xliii.</p>
<p class="sp3">P. 124, Book IV, pr. 7, l. 61. MS. C. <i>has</i> confirme; <i>and</i> MS. A.
  <i>has</i> conferme. <i>But the right reading must be</i> conforme; <i>for the</i> Latin <i>text
  has</i> conformandae.</p>
<p class="ac">II. TROILUS.</p>
<p>P. 159, Book I, 204. <i>For</i> cast <i>read</i> caste.</p>
<p>P. 160, Book I, 217. The alternative reading is better; see note, p. 463.</p>
<p>P. 160, Book I, 239. <i>For</i> yet <i>read</i> yit (for the rhyme).</p>
<p>P. 162, Book I, 284. <i>For</i> neuer <i>read</i> never.</p>
<p>P. 163, Book, I, 309. <i>For</i> Troylus <i>read</i> Troilus.</p>
<p>P. 163, Book I, 310. <i>For</i> thyng <i>read</i> thing.</p>
<p>P. 165, Book I, 401. <i>Alter</i> ! <i>to</i> ?</p>
<p>P. 166, Book I, 406. <i>For</i> thurst <i>read</i> thurste.</p>
<p>P. 166, Book I, 420. <i>For</i> deye <i>read</i> dye (for the rhyme).</p>
<p>P. 171, Book I, 570. <i>For</i> euery <i>read</i> every.</p>
<p>P. 172, Book I, 621. <i>For</i> Troylus <i>read</i> Troilus (as elsewhere).</p>
<p>P. 173, Book I, 626. Delete the comma after 'fare.'</p>
<p>P. 174, Book I, 656. <i>For</i> y <i>read</i> I.</p>
<p>P. 174, Book I, 657. <i>Insert</i> ' <i>at the beginning</i>.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="pagelxxx">{lxxx}</span></div>
<p>P. 181, Book I, 879. <i>For</i> the <i>read</i> thee.</p>
<p>P. 192, Book II, 113. <i>Delete</i> ' <i>at the end</i>.</p>
<p>P. 194, Book II, 170. <i>Insert</i> ' <i>at the beginning</i>.</p>
<p>P. 205, Book II, 529. <i>For</i> penaunc <i>read</i> penaunce.</p>
<p>P. 208, Book II, 628. <i>For</i> swych <i>read</i> swich.</p>
<p>P. 229, Book II, 1294. <i>Insert</i> ' <i>at the beginning</i>.</p>
<p>P. 234, Book II, 1461. <i>For</i> streyt <i>read</i> streght, <i>as in</i> MS. H.</p>
<p>P. 260, Book III, 522. <i>Delete the comma after</i> laft.</p>
<p>P. 260, Book III, 535. <i>For</i> made <i>read</i> mad <i>or</i> maad.</p>
<p>P. 261, Book III, 558. <i>For</i> lengere <i>read</i> lenger.</p>
<p>P. 264, Book III, 662. <i>For</i> thondre <i>read</i> thonder.</p>
<p>P. 271, Book III, 885. <i>For</i> ringe <i>read</i> ring.</p>
<p>P. 282, Book III, 1219. <i>For</i> sweet <i>read</i> swete.</p>
<p>P. 312, Book IV, 318. <i>For</i> to the peyne <i>read</i> to my peyne.</p>
<p>P. 390, Book V, 1039. <i>For</i> she <i>read</i> he. Cf. note, p. 499; and p. lx, l. 3.</p>
<p>P. 431, note to Prose 5, 35; l. 3. <i>Delete</i> for which I find <i>no</i> authority. (In
  fact, <i>postremo</i> is the reading given by Peiper, from <i>one</i> MS. only; most MSS. have
  <i>postremae</i>, the reading given by Obbarius, who does not recognise the reading
  <i>postremo</i>).</p>
<p>P. 463. Note to I, 217. <i>Add</i>—So too in Barbour's Bruce, i. 582: 'Bot oft failyeis
  the fulis thocht.'</p>
<p>P. 479, last line; and p. 480, first line. <i>For</i> represents the Pers. and Arab.
  <i>dū’lkarnayn</i>, lit. two-horned; from Pers. <i>dū</i>, two, and
  <i>karn</i>, horn—<i>read</i> represents the Arab, <i>zū’lkarnayn</i>, lit.
  two-horned; from Arab. <i>zū</i>, lord of, <i>hence</i>, possessing, and the dual form of
  <i>karn</i>, horn.</p>
<p>Notes to I. 948, 951; II. 36, 1335; III. 1219. Dr. Köppel has shewn (in Archiv für das Studium
  der neueren Sprachen, xc. 150, that Chaucer here quotes from Alanus de Insulis, Liber Parabolarum
  (as printed in Migne, Cursus Patrologicus, vol. ccx). The passages are<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p>Fragrantes uicina rosas urtica perurit (col. 582).</p>
<p class="stanza">Post noctem sperare diem, post nubila solem;</p>
<p style="margin-left:0.70em">Post lacrimas risus laetitiamque potes (583).</p>
<p class="stanza">Mille uiae ducunt homines per saecula Romam (591).</p>
<p class="stanza">De nuce fit corylus, de glande fit ardua quercus (583).</p>
<p class="stanza">Dulcius haerescunt humano mella palato,</p>
<p style="margin-left:0.70em">Si malus hoc ipsum mordeat ante sapor (592).</p>
</div>
<p>P. 498, Note to V, 806. <i>Add</i>—L. 813 is due to Dares; see p. lxiv, note.</p>
<p class="sp5">P. 499, Note to V, 1039, l. 6. <i>For</i> the rest is Chaucer's addition
  <i>read</i> the statement that she gave it to Diomede is due to Benoît; see p. lxii. Again, just
  below, <i>read</i> The incidents of the 'broche' and 'pensel' are also due to the same; see p. <a href="#pagelxii" class="pginternal">lxii</a>.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page1">{1}</span></div>
<h1 class="sp4 ac" style="margin-bottom:4.7ex;"> <span class="x-larger">BOETHIUS DE CONSOLATIONE
  PHILOSOPHIE.</span></h1>
<h2 class="sp3 ac" style="margin-bottom:2.1ex;"> <span class="larger">BOOK I.</span></h2>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre I.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Carmina qui quondam studio florente peregi.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Allas! I, weping, am constreined to biginnen vers of sorowful</p>
<p>matere, that whylom in florisching studie made delitable ditees.</p>
<p>For lo! <a href="#BIMINL3" id="BIMIL3" class="pginternal">rendinge</a> Muses of poetes endyten to me thinges to
    be</p>
<p>writen; and drery vers of wrecchednesse weten my face with</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">verray teres. At the leeste, no drede ne mighte overcomen tho</p>
<p>Muses, that they ne weren felawes, and folweden my wey, <i><a href="#BIMINL6" id="BIMIL6" class="pginternal">that is</a></i></p>
<p><a href="#BIMINL6" class="pginternal">to seyn</a><i>, whan I was exyled</i>; they that weren glorie of my
    youthe,</p>
<p>whylom weleful and grene, comforten now the sorowful <a href="#BIMINL8" id="BIMIL8" class="pginternal">werdes</a> of</p>
<p>me, olde man. For elde is comen unwarly upon me, hasted by</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the harmes that I have, and sorow hath comaunded his age to be</p>
<p>in me. Heres hore ben shad overtymeliche upon myn heved,</p>
<p>and the <a href="#BIMINL12" id="BIMIL12" class="pginternal">slake</a> skin trembleth upon myn empted body.
    Thilke</p>
<p>deeth of men is weleful that ne cometh not in yeres that ben</p>
<p><a href="#BIMINL13" id="BIMIL13" class="pginternal">swete</a>, but cometh to wrecches, often <a href="#BIMINL14" id="BIMIL14" class="pginternal">y-cleped</a>.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">15</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">Allas! allas! with how deef an ere deeth, cruel, torneth awey</p>
<p>fro wrecches, and <a href="#BIMINL16" id="BIMIL16" class="pginternal">naiteth</a> to closen wepinge eyen! Whyl
    Fortune,</p>
<p>unfeithful, favorede me with <a href="#BIMINL17" id="BIMIL17" class="pginternal">lighte</a> goodes, the sorowful
    houre,</p>
<p><i>that is to seyn, the deeth</i>, hadde almost dreynt myn heved. <a href="#BIMINL18" id="BIMIL18" class="pginternal">But</a></p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page2">{2}</span><a href="#BIMINL18" class="pginternal">now</a>, for Fortune cloudy
    hath chaunged hir deceyvable chere to</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">me-ward, myn unpitous lyf draweth a-long unagreable dwellinges</p>
<p><i>in me</i>. O ye, my frendes, what or wherto avauntede ye me to</p>
<p>ben weleful? for he that hath fallen stood nat <a href="#BIMINL22" id="BIMIL22" class="pginternal">in
    stedefast</a></p>
<p><a href="#BIMINL22" class="pginternal">degree</a>.</p>
</div>
<p>C. = MS. Ii. 3. 21, Cambridge; A. = MS. Addit. 10340 (Brit. Mus.). <i>The text follows</i> C.
  <i>mainly</i>. Ed. = Printed edition (1532), <i>quoted occasionally</i>.</p>
<p class="sp3">1, 2. <i>Imperfect in</i> C. 6. C. foleweden; A. folweden. 8. C. sorful; A.
  sorouful. // C. wierdes, <i>glossed</i> fata; A. werdes. 11. C. arn; A. ben. 12. C. of; A. upon.
  // C. emptyd; A. emty. 16. C. nayteth; A. Ed. naieth. 17. A. <i>glosses</i> lighte <i>by</i> sc.
  temporels. // C. sorwful; A. sorouful. 19. C. deceyuable; A. disceyuable. 20. C. vnpietous; A.
  vnpitouse. 22. C. stidefast; A. stedfast. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose I.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Hec dum mecum tacitus ipse reputarem.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Whyle that I stille recordede thise thinges with my-self, and</p>
<p><a href="#BIPINL2" id="BIPIL2" class="pginternal">markede</a> my weeply compleynte with office of pointel, I
    saw,</p>
<p>stondinge aboven the heighte of myn heved, a woman of ful greet</p>
<p>reverence by semblaunt, hir eyen brenninge and cleer-seinge over</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the comune might of men; with a lyfly colour, and with swich</p>
<p>vigour and strengthe that it ne mighte nat ben <a href="#BIPINL6" id="BIPIL6" class="pginternal">empted</a>; al
    were it</p>
<p>so that she was ful of so greet age, that men ne wolde nat trowen,</p>
<p>in no manere, that she were of oure elde. The stature of hir was</p>
<p>of a <a href="#BIPINL9" id="BIPIL9" class="pginternal">doutous</a> Iugement; for som-tyme she constreinede and
    shronk</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">hir-selven lyk to the comune mesure of men, and sum-tyme it</p>
<p>semede that she touchede the hevene with the heighte of hir</p>
<p>heved; and whan she <a href="#BIPINL12" id="BIPIL12" class="pginternal">heef</a> hir heved hyer, she percede
    the</p>
<p>selve hevene, <a href="#BIPINL13" id="BIPIL13" class="pginternal">so that</a> the sighte of men looking was in
    ydel. Hir</p>
<p>clothes weren maked of right <a href="#BIPINL14" id="BIPIL14" class="pginternal">delye</a> thredes and subtil
    crafte, of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">perdurable matere; the whiche clothes she hadde woven with hir</p>
<p>owene hondes, as I knew wel after by hir-self, declaringe and</p>
<p>shewinge to me the beautee; the whiche clothes a derknesse of a</p>
<p>forleten and dispysed elde hadde dusked and derked, <a href="#BIPINL18" id="BIPIL18" class="pginternal">as it is
    wont</a></p>
<p>to derken bi-smokede images.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">20</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">In the nethereste hem or bordure of thise clothes men redden,</p>
<p>y-woven in, <a href="#BIPINL21" id="BIPIL21" class="pginternal">a Grekissh P</a>, <i>that signifyeth the lyf
    Actif</i>; and aboven</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page3">{3}</span>that lettre, in the heyeste bordure, <a href="#BIPINL21" class="pginternal">a Grekissh T</a>, <i>that signifyeth</i></p>
<p><i>the lyf Contemplatif</i>. And bi-twixen these two lettres ther weren</p>
<p>seyn degrees, nobly y-wroght in manere of laddres; by whiche</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">degrees men mighten climben fro the nethereste lettre to the</p>
<p>uppereste. Natheles, handes of some men hadde <a href="#BIPINL26" id="BIPIL26" class="pginternal">corven</a>
    that cloth</p>
<p>by violence and by strengthe; and everiche man of hem hadde</p>
<p>born awey swiche peces as he mighte geten. And forsothe, this</p>
<p>forseide woman bar smale bokes in hir right hand, and in hir left</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">hand she bar a ceptre.</p>
<p class="stanza">And whan she say thise poetical Muses aprochen aboute my</p>
<p>bed, and endytinge wordes to my wepinges, she was a litel</p>
<p>amoved, and glowede with <a href="#BIPINL33" id="BIPIL33" class="pginternal">cruel</a> eyen. 'Who,' quod she,
    'hath</p>
<p>suffred aprochen to this syke man <a href="#BIPINL34" id="BIPIL34" class="pginternal">thise comune
    strompetes</a> of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">swich a place that men clepen the theatre? The whiche nat</p>
<p>only ne asswagen nat hise sorwes with none remedies, but they</p>
<p>wolden feden and norisshen hem with swete venim. Forsothe,</p>
<p>thise ben tho that with thornes and prikkinges of talents or</p>
<p>affecciouns, whiche that ne ben <a href="#BIPINL39" id="BIPIL39" class="pginternal">no-thing fructefyinge</a>
    nor</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">profitable, destroyen the corn plentevous of fruites of resoun;</p>
<p>for they <a href="#BIPINL41" id="BIPIL41" class="pginternal">holden</a> the hertes of men in usage, but they ne
    delivere</p>
<p>nat folk fro maladye. But if ye Muses hadden withdrawen fro</p>
<p>me, with your flateryes, any uncunninge and unprofitable man, as</p>
<p>men ben wont to finde comunly amonges the poeple, I wolde</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">wene suffre the lasse grevously; <a href="#BIPINL45" id="BIPIL45" class="pginternal">for-why</a>,
    in swiche an unprofitable</p>
<p>man, myn ententes ne weren no-thing endamaged. But ye withdrawen</p>
<p><a href="#BIPINL47" id="BIPIL47" class="pginternal">me</a> this man, that hath be norisshed in the studies
    or</p>
<p>scoles of Eleaticis and of Achademicis <i>in Grece</i>. But goth now</p>
<p>rather awey, <a href="#BIPINL49" id="BIPIL49" class="pginternal">ye mermaidenes</a>, whiche that ben swete til
    it be at</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIPINL49" class="pginternal">the laste</a>, and suffreth this man to be cured and heled
    by myne</p>
<p>Muses,' <i>that is to seyn, by noteful sciences</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza">And thus this companye of Muses y-blamed casten wrothly the</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page4">{4}</span>chere dounward to the erthe; and, shewinge by
    reednesse hir</p>
<p>shame, they passeden sorowfully the threshfold.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">55</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">And I, of whom the sighte, <a href="#BIPINL55" id="BIPIL55" class="pginternal">plounged</a>
    in teres, was derked so</p>
<p>that I ne mighte not knowen what that womman was, of so</p>
<p>imperial auctoritee, I wex al abaisshed and astoned, and caste my</p>
<p>sighte doun to the erthe, and bigan stille for to abyde what she</p>
<p>wolde don afterward. Tho com she <a href="#BIPINL59" id="BIPIL59" class="pginternal">ner</a>, and sette hir doun
    up-on</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the uttereste corner of my bed; and she, biholdinge my chere,</p>
<p>that was cast to the erthe, hevy and grevous of wepinge, compleinede,</p>
<p>with thise wordes that I shal seyen, the perturbacioun</p>
<p>of my thought.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. I.</span> 1. C. While that; A. In the mene while that. 2. C.
  sawh; A. sawe. 3. C. heyhte; A. heyȝt. // C. gret; A. greet. 5. C. myht; A. myȝt. 6.
  C. vygor; A. vigoure. // C. myhte; A. myȝt. // C. emted; A. emptid. 7. C. gret; A. greet
  (<i>and so often</i>). 9. C. dowtows; A. doutous (<i>and so</i> ow <i>for</i> ou <i>often</i>).
  10. C. lyk; A. lyche. 11. C. heyhte; A. heyȝte (<i>and so elsewhere</i>). 12. C. hef; A.
  heued; Ed. houe. 14. C. riht (<i>and so</i> h <i>for</i> gh <i>often</i>). 16. C. knewh; A. knewe.
  17. C. dirknesse; A. derkenes. 19. <i>Both</i> dyrken. // C. the smokede; A. bysmoked. 21. A. in
  swiche; C. <i>om.</i> swiche. C. <i>glosses</i> P <i>by</i> practik. // C. syngnifieth; A.
  signifieth. 22. C. <i>glosses</i> T <i>by</i> theorik. // C. singnifieth; A. signifieth. 23. C.
  by-twixen; A. by-twene. 24. C. nobely; A. nobly. 25. C. clymbyn (<i>and so</i> -yn <i>for</i> -en
  <i>constantly</i>). // C. Ed. nethereste; A. nethemast. 26. C. Ed. vppereste; A. ouermast 31. C.
  say; A. sauȝ. 33. C. amoued; A. ameued. // C. cruwel; A. cruel. 34. C. sike; A. seek. // C.
  the; A. thise (Lat. <i>has</i>). 37. C. noryssyn; A. norysche. // C. hym; A. hem. 39. C.
  fructefiynge; A. frutefiyng. 40. C. corn; A. cornes (Lat. <i>segetem</i>). 41. C. <i>om.</i> the.
  // C. <i>om.</i> ne. 42. C. maledye; A. maladye. 44. C. poeple; A. peple. 45. C. greuosly; A.
  greuously (<i>and so often</i> os <i>for</i> ous <i>in</i> C.). 48. C. schooles; A. scoles. 53. C.
  downward; A. adounward. // C. <i>om.</i> and. // C. rednesse; A. redenesse. 54. C. sorwfully. //
  C. thresshfold; A. threschefolde. 55. C. dyrked; A. derked. 57. C. wax; A. wex. // C. cast; A.
  caste. 58. C. down to; A. adoune in-to. 59. C. ner; A. nere. 61. C. compleyde; A. compleinede. 63.
  C. thowht; A. thouȝt. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre II.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Heu quam precipiti mersa profundo.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>'Allas! how the thought of man, dreint in over-throwinge</p>
<p>deepnesse, dulleth, and forleteth his propre cleernesse, <a href="#BIMIINL2" id="BIMIIL2" class="pginternal">mintinge</a></p>
<p>to goon in-to foreine derknesses, as ofte as his anoyous bisinesse</p>
<p>wexeth with-oute mesure, that is driven to and fro with worldly</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">windes! This man, that whylom was free, to whom the hevene</p>
<p>was open and knowen, and was wont to goon in heveneliche</p>
<p>pathes, and saugh the lightnesse of the rede sonne, and saugh the</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIINL8" id="BIMIIL8" class="pginternal">sterres of the colde mone</a>, and whiche sterre in hevene
    useth</p>
<p>wandering <a href="#BIMIINL9" id="BIMIIL9" class="pginternal">recourses</a>, <a href="#BIMIINL9" class="pginternal">y-flit</a> by
    dyverse speres—<a href="#BIMIINL9" class="pginternal">this man</a>, overcomer,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">hadde comprehended al this by noumbre <i>of acountinge in</i></p>
<p><i>astronomye</i>. And over this, he was wont to seken the causes</p>
<p>whennes the souning windes moeven and bisien the smothe water</p>
<p>of the see; and what spirit torneth the stable hevene; and why</p>
<p>the sterre aryseth out of the rede eest, to fallen in the westrene</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">wawes; and what atempreth the lusty houres of the firste somer</p>
<p>sesoun, that <a href="#BIMIINL16" id="BIMIIL16" class="pginternal">highteth</a> and apparaileth the erthe with
    rosene flowres;</p>
<p>and who maketh that plentevouse autompne, in fulle yeres, <a href="#BIMIINL17" id="BIMIIL17" class="pginternal">fleteth</a></p>
<p>with hevy grapes. And eek this man was wont to telle the</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page5">{5}</span>dyverse causes of nature that weren y-hidde.
    Allas! now lyeth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">he <a href="#BIMIINL20" id="BIMIIL20" class="pginternal">empted</a> of light of his thought; and
    his nekke is pressed with</p>
<p>hevy cheynes; and bereth his chere enclyned adoun for the grete</p>
<p>weighte, and is constreined to looken on the <a href="#BIMIINL22" id="BIMIIL22" class="pginternal">fool</a>
    erthe!</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. II.</span> 3. C. dyrk-; A. derk-. 4. C. wordely; A. worldly
  (Lat. <i>terrenis</i>). 5. C. Ed. whilom; A. sumtyme. 7. C. lythnesse; A. lyȝtnesse. 10. C.
  comprendyd; A. Ed. comprehendid. 11. C. seken; A. seche. 14. C. est; A. eest. 15. C. fyrst; A.
  fyrste. 17. A. that; C. the. // C. autompne; A. autumpne. 19. C. I-hydde; A. yhidde. // C. lith;
  A. lieth. 20. A. emptid; C. emted. 22. C. the fool; Ed. the fole; A. foule (Lat. <i>stolidam</i>).
  </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose II.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Set medicine, inquit, tempus est.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>But tyme is now,' quod she, 'of medicine more than of</p>
<p>compleinte.' Forsothe than she, entendinge to me-ward with alle</p>
<p>the lookinge of hir eyen, seide:—'Art nat thou he,' quod she,</p>
<p>'that whylom y-norisshed with my milk, and fostered with myne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">metes, were escaped and comen to corage of a parfit man?</p>
<p>Certes, I yaf thee swiche <a href="#BIPIINL6" id="BIPIIL6" class="pginternal">armures</a> that, yif thou
    thy-self ne</p>
<p>haddest first cast hem a-wey, they shulden han defended thee</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIINL8" id="BIPIIL8" class="pginternal">in sikernesse</a> that may nat ben over-comen. Knowest thou
    me</p>
<p>nat? Why art thou stille? Is it for shame or for astoninge?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">It were me lever that it were for shame; but it semeth me that</p>
<p>astoninge hath oppressed thee.' And whan she say me nat only</p>
<p>stille, but with-outen office of tunge and al doumb, she leide hir</p>
<p>hand softely upon my brest, and seide: 'Here nis no peril,' quod</p>
<p>she; 'he is fallen into a <a href="#BIPIINL14" id="BIPIIL14" class="pginternal">litargie</a>, whiche that is a
    comune sykenes</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to hertes that ben deceived. He hath a litel foryeten him-self,</p>
<p>but certes he shal lightly remembren him-self, yif so be that he</p>
<p>hath knowen me or now; and that he may so don, I wil wypen a</p>
<p>litel his eyen, that ben derked by the cloude of mortal thinges.'</p>
<p>Thise wordes seide she, and with the lappe of hir garment, <a href="#BIPIINL19" id="BIPIIL19" class="pginternal">y-plyted</a></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">in a frounce, she dryede myn eyen, that weren fulle of the wawes</p>
<p>of my wepinges.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. II.</span> 4. C. Ed. whilom; A. sumtyme. // C. noryssed; A.
  I-norschide. 5. C. escaped; A. ascaped. 8. C. Knowestow; A. Knowest thou. 9. C. artow; A. art
  thou. // C. it is; A. Ed. is it. // C. asthonynge (<i>but</i> astonynge <i>below</i>). 14. C.
  litarge; A. litargie. // C. sykenesse; A. sekenes. 15. C. desseyued; A. desceiued. 16. C.
  remenbren; A. reme<i>m</i>bren. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre III.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Tunc me discussa liquerunt nocte tenebre.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Thus, whan that night was <a href="#BIMIIINL1" id="BIMIIIL1" class="pginternal">discussed</a> and chased
    a-wey,</p>
<p>derknesses forleften me, and to myn eyen repeirede ayein hir</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page6">{6}</span>firste strengthe. And, right by ensaumple as the
    sonne is hid</p>
<p>whan the sterres ben <a href="#BIMIIINL4" id="BIMIIIL4" class="pginternal">clustred</a> (<i>that is to seyn,
    whan sterres ben</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>covered with cloudes</i>) by a swifte winde that highte <a href="#BIMIIINL5" id="BIMIIIL5" class="pginternal">Chorus</a>, and</p>
<p>that the firmament stant derked by wete <a href="#BIMIIINL6" id="BIMIIIL6" class="pginternal">ploungy</a>
    cloudes, and</p>
<p>that the sterres nat apperen up-on hevene, so that the night</p>
<p>semeth sprad up-on erthe: yif thanne the wind that highte <a href="#BIMIIINL8" id="BIMIIIL8" class="pginternal">Borias</a>,</p>
<p>y-sent out of the <a href="#BIMIIINL9" id="BIMIIIL9" class="pginternal">caves</a> of the contree of Trace,
    beteth this night</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">(<i>that is to seyn, chaseth it a-wey</i>), and descovereth the closed day:</p>
<p>than shyneth Phebus <a href="#BIMIIINL11" id="BIMIIIL11" class="pginternal">y-shaken</a> with sodein light, and
    smyteth</p>
<p>with his bemes in mervelinge eyen.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. III.</span> 1. C. descussed; A. discussed. 2. C. dirk-; A.
  derk-. // C. <i>om.</i> ayein. 3. C. fyrst; A. firste. 5. C. heyhte; A. hyȝt. 6. C. dirked;
  A. derked. 8. C. hyhte; A. hyȝt. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose III.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Haud aliter tristicie nebulis dissolutis.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Right so, and non other wyse, the cloudes of sorwe dissolved</p>
<p>and don a-wey, I <a href="#BIPIIINL2" id="BIPIIIL2" class="pginternal">took</a> hevene, and receivede minde to
    knowen the</p>
<p>face of my fysicien; so that I sette myn eyen on hir, and fastnede</p>
<p>my lookinge. I <a href="#BIPIIINL4" id="BIPIIIL4" class="pginternal">beholde</a> my norice Philosophie, in whos
    houses</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I hadde conversed and haunted fro my youthe; and I seide thus.</p>
<p>'O thou maistresse of alle vertues, descended from the soverein</p>
<p>sete, why artow comen in-to this solitarie place of myn exil?</p>
<p>Artow comen for thou art maked coupable with me of false</p>
<p>blames?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">10</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'O,' quod she, 'my <a href="#BIPIIINL10" id="BIPIIIL10" class="pginternal">norry</a>,
    sholde I forsaken thee now, and</p>
<p>sholde I nat <a href="#BIPIIINL11" id="BIPIIIL11" class="pginternal">parten</a> with thee, by comune travaile,
    the charge</p>
<p>that thou hast suffred for envie of my name? Certes, it nere</p>
<p>not leveful ne sittinge thing to Philosophie, to leten with-outen</p>
<p>companye the wey of him that is innocent. Sholde I thanne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIPIIINL15" id="BIPIIIL15" class="pginternal">redoute my blame</a>, and agrysen as
    though ther were bifallen a</p>
<p>newe thing? <a href="#BIPIIINL16" id="BIPIIIL16" class="pginternal"><i>quasi diceret, non</i></a>. For trowestow
    that Philosophie</p>
<p>be now alderfirst assailed in perils by folk of wikkede maneres?</p>
<p>Have I nat striven with ful greet stryf, in olde tyme, bifore the</p>
<p>age of my Plato, ayeines the foolhardinesse of folye? And eek,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the same <a href="#BIPIIINL19" id="BIPIIIL19" class="pginternal">Plato</a> livinge, his maister
    Socrates deservede victorie of</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page7">{7}</span>unrightful deeth in my presence. The heritage of
    which Socrates—<i>the</i></p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIINL21" id="BIPIIIL21" class="pginternal">heritage</a> <i>is to seyn the doctrine of the whiche
    Socrates in his</i></p>
<p><i>opinioun of Felicitee, that I clepe welefulnesse</i>—whan that the</p>
<p>poeple of Epicuriens and Stoiciens and many othre enforceden</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">hem to go ravisshe everich man for his part—<i>that is to seyn,</i></p>
<p><i>that everich of hem wolde drawen to the defence of his opinioun the</i></p>
<p><i>wordes of Socrates</i>—they, as in partie of hir preye, to-drowen me,</p>
<p>cryinge and debatinge ther-ayeins, and corven and to-renten my</p>
<p>clothes that I hadde woven with myn handes; and with tho</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">cloutes that they hadden araced out of my clothes they wenten</p>
<p>awey, weninge that I hadde gon with hem everydel.</p>
<p class="stanza">In whiche <i>Epicuriens and Stoiciens</i>, for as moche as ther semede</p>
<p>some traces or steppes of myn habite, the folye of men, weninge</p>
<p>tho <i>Epicuriens and Stoiciens</i> my famuleres, perverted (<i>sc. persequendo</i>)</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">some through the errour of the wikkede or uncunninge</p>
<p>multitude of hem. <i>This is to seyn that, for they semede philosophres,</i></p>
<p><i>they weren pursued to the deeth and slayn.</i> So yif thou hast nat</p>
<p>knowen the exilinge of <a href="#BIPIIINL38" id="BIPIIIL38" class="pginternal">Anaxogore</a>, ne the
    enpoysoninge of</p>
<p>Socrates, ne the tourments of <a href="#BIPIIINL39" id="BIPIIIL39" class="pginternal">Zeno</a>, for they weren
    straungeres:</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">yit mightestow han knowen the <a href="#BIPIIINL40" id="BIPIIIL40" class="pginternal">Senecciens</a> and the <a href="#BIPIIINL40" class="pginternal">Canios</a> and</p>
<p>the <a href="#BIPIIINL41" id="BIPIIIL41" class="pginternal">Sorans</a>, of whiche folk the renoun is neither
    over-olde ne</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIINL42" id="BIPIIIL42" class="pginternal">unsolempne</a> The whiche men, no-thing elles ne
    broughte hem to</p>
<p>the deeth but only for they weren enfourmed of myne maneres,</p>
<p>and semeden most unlyke to the studies of wikkede folk. And</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">forthy thou oughtest nat to wondren though that I, in the bittre</p>
<p>see of this lyf, be fordriven with tempestes blowinge aboute, in</p>
<p>the whiche tempestes this is my most purpos, <i>that is to seyn</i>, to</p>
<p>displesen to wikkede men. Of whiche shrewes, al be the ost</p>
<p>never so greet, <a href="#BIPIIINL49" id="BIPIIIL49" class="pginternal">it is to dispyse</a>; for it nis
    governed with no leder</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of resoun, but it is ravisshed only by fletinge errour folyly and</p>
<p>lightly. And if they som-tyme, makinge an ost ayeins us, assaile</p>
<p>us as strenger, our leder draweth to-gidere hise richesses in-to his</p>
<p>tour, and they ben <a href="#BIPIIINL53" id="BIPIIIL53" class="pginternal">ententif</a> aboute <a href="#BIPIIINL53" class="pginternal">sarpulers</a> or sachels unprofitable</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page8">{8}</span>for to taken. But we that ben heye aboven, siker
    fro alle</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">tumulte and wode noise, warnestored and enclosed in swich a</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIINL56" id="BIPIIIL56" class="pginternal">palis</a>, whider as that chateringe or anoyinge folye
    ne may nat</p>
<p>atayne, we scorne swiche ravineres and henteres of fouleste</p>
<p>thinges.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. III.</span> 3. C. fesissien; A. fyciscien; Ed. phisycien. //
  C. fastnede; A. festned. 4. Lat. <i>respicio</i>. 6. C. vertuus; A. vertues. 7. C. artow; A. art
  thou. 13. A. <i>om.</i> thing. 14. C. compaygnie; A. compaignie. 16. C. trowestow; A. trowest
  thou. 20. C. desseruede; A. deserued. 21. C. eritage; A. heritage. 25. C. rauysse; A. rauische.
  26. C. deffence; A. defence. 30. C. arraced; A. arased. 31. C. <i>om.</i> I. 33. C. or; A. and.
  34. A. familers. 36. A. <i>om.</i> that. 38. C. <i>om. 1st</i> of. 40. C. myhtestow; A.
  myȝtest thou. // C. Senecciens; A. Senectiens; Ed. Senecas. 43. C. enformyd; A. vnfourmed.
  44. C. vnlyk; A. vnlyke. 48. C. oost, <i>glossed</i> i. acies. 50. C. rauyssed; A. rauysched. //
  C. folyly, i. sine consilio. 52. A. hys rycchesse. 53. C. sarpuleris; A. sarpulers. 55. C.
  tumolte; A. tumulte. // A. stored. 56. C. palis; A. palays (Lat. <i>uallo</i>). // C. <i>om.</i>
  that. // C. anoyenge; A. anoying. 57 C. atayne; A. attayne. // C. schorne; A. scorne. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre IV.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quisquis composito serenus euo.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Who-so it be that is cleer of vertu, sad, and wel ordinat of</p>
<p>livinge, that hath put under foot the proude werdes and looketh</p>
<p>upright up-on <a href="#BIMIVNL3" id="BIMIVL3" class="pginternal">either fortune</a>, he may holde his chere
    undiscomfited.</p>
<p>The rage ne the manaces of the see, commoevinge or</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">chasinge upward <a href="#BIMIVNL5" id="BIMIVL5" class="pginternal">hete</a> fro the botme, ne
    shal not moeve that</p>
<p>man; ne the unstable mountaigne that highte <a href="#BIMIVNL6" id="BIMIVL6" class="pginternal">Vesevus</a>,
    that</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIVNL7" id="BIMIVL7" class="pginternal">wrytheth</a> out through his brokene chiminees smokinge
    fyres. Ne</p>
<p>the wey of <a href="#BIMIVNL8" id="BIMIVL8" class="pginternal">thonder-light</a>, that is wont to smyten heye
    toures, ne</p>
<p>shal nat moeve that man. Wher-to thanne, o wrecches, drede ye</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">tirauntes that ben wode and felonous with-oute any strengthe?</p>
<p>Hope after no-thing, ne drede nat; and so shaltow desarmen</p>
<p>the ire of thilke unmighty tiraunt. But who-so that, quakinge,</p>
<p>dredeth or desireth thing that nis nat <a href="#BIMIVNL13" id="BIMIVL13" class="pginternal">stable of his
    right</a>, that</p>
<p>man that so doth hath cast awey his sheld and is remoeved fro</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">his place, and enlaceth him in the cheyne with the which he may</p>
<p>ben drawen.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. IV.</span> 2. C. leuynge; A. lyuyng. // <i>Both</i> wierdes;
  C. <i>has the gloss</i> fata. 3. C. may his cheere holde vndescounfited; A. may holde hys chiere
  vndiscomfited. 4. C. manesses; A. manace (Lat. <i>minae</i>). 5. hete (Lat. <i>aestum</i>). 6. C.
  hihte; A. hyȝt. 7. Ed. writheth; C. writith; A. wircheth (Lat. <i>torquet</i>). // A.
  chemineys. 9. C. Whar-; A. Wher-. 10. C. felonos; A. felownes. 11. C. deseruien; A. desarmen; Ed.
  disarmen. 14. C. remwed; A. remoeued. 15. A. <i>om.</i> the <i>before</i> which. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose IV.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Sentisne, inquit, hec.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>'Felestow,' quod she, 'thise thinges, and entren they aught in</p>
<p>thy corage? <a href="#BIPIVNL2" id="BIPIVL2" class="pginternal">Artow lyke</a> an asse to the harpe? Why
    wepestow,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page9">{9}</span><a href="#BIPIVNL3" id="BIPIVL3" class="pginternal">why spillestow
    teres</a>? Yif thou abydest after help of thy leche,</p>
<p>thee bihoveth discovere thy wounde.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">5</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">Tho I, that hadde gadered strengthe in my corage, answerede</p>
<p>and seide: 'And nedeth it yit,' quod I, 'of rehersinge or of</p>
<p>amonicioun; and sheweth it nat y-nough <a href="#BIPIVNL7" id="BIPIVL7" class="pginternal">by him-self</a> the
    sharpnesse</p>
<p>of Fortune, that wexeth wood ayeins me? Ne moeveth it</p>
<p>nat thee to seen the face or the manere of this place (<i>i. prisoun</i>)?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Is this the librarie whiche that thou haddest chosen for a right</p>
<p>certein sete to thee in myn hous, ther-as thou desputedest ofte</p>
<p>with me of the sciences of thinges touchinge divinitee and touchinge</p>
<p>mankinde? Was thanne myn habite swich as it is now?</p>
<p>Was than my face or my chere swiche as now (<i>quasi diceret, non</i>),</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">whan I soughte with thee secrets of nature, whan thou <a href="#BIPIVNL15" id="BIPIVL15" class="pginternal">enformedest</a></p>
<p>my maneres and the resoun of alle my lyf to the ensaumple of</p>
<p>the <a href="#BIPIVNL17" id="BIPIVL17" class="pginternal">ordre of hevene</a>? Is nat this the guerdoun that I
    referre to</p>
<p>thee, to whom I have be obeisaunt? Certes, thou <a href="#BIPIVNL18" id="BIPIVL18" class="pginternal">confermedest</a>,</p>
<p>by the <a href="#BIPIVNL19" id="BIPIVL19" class="pginternal">mouth of Plato</a>, this sentence, <i>that is to
    seyn</i>, that comune</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thinges or comunalitees weren blisful, yif they that hadden studied</p>
<p>al fully to wisdom governeden thilke thinges, or elles yif it so</p>
<p>bifille that the governoures of comunalitees studieden to geten</p>
<p>wisdom.</p>
<p class="stanza">Thou seidest eek, by the mouth of <a href="#BIPIVNL24" id="BIPIVL24" class="pginternal">the same
    Plato</a>, that it was</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">a necessarie <a href="#BIPIVNL25" id="BIPIVL25" class="pginternal">cause</a>, <a href="#BIPIVNL25" class="pginternal">wyse</a> men to taken and desire the governaunce</p>
<p>of comune thinges, for that the governements of citees, y-left</p>
<p>in the handes of <a href="#BIPIVNL27" id="BIPIVL27" class="pginternal">felonous tormentours citizenes</a>, ne
    sholde nat</p>
<p>bringe in pestilence and destruccioun to gode folk. And therfor</p>
<p>I, folwinge thilke auctoritee (<i>sc. Platonis</i>), desired to putten forth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">in execucioun and in acte of comune administracioun thilke</p>
<p>thinges that I hadde lerned of thee among my secree resting-whyles.</p>
<p>Thou, and god that putte thee in the thoughtes of wyse</p>
<p>folk, ben <a href="#BIPIVNL33" id="BIPIVL33" class="pginternal">knowinge with me</a>, that no-thing ne broughte
    me to</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page10">{10}</span>maistrie or dignitee, but the comune studie of
    alle goodnesse.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And ther-of comth it that bi-twixen wikked folk and me han ben</p>
<p>grevous <a href="#BIPIVNL36" id="BIPIVL36" class="pginternal">discordes</a>, that ne mighten ben relesed by
    preyeres; for</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVNL37" id="BIPIVL37" class="pginternal">this libertee</a> hath the freedom of conscience, that the
    wratthe of</p>
<p>more mighty folk hath alwey ben despysed of me for savacioun of</p>
<p>right.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">40</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">How ofte have I resisted and withstonde thilke man that highte</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVNL41" id="BIPIVL41" class="pginternal">Conigaste</a>, that made alwey assautes ayeins <a href="#BIPIVNL41" class="pginternal">the prospre fortunes</a> of</p>
<p>pore feble folk? How ofte eek have I put of or cast out him,</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVNL43" id="BIPIVL43" class="pginternal">Trigwille</a>, provost of the kinges hous, bothe of the
    wronges that he</p>
<p>hadde bigunne to don, and eek fully performed? How ofte have</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I covered and defended by the <a href="#BIPIVNL45" id="BIPIVL45" class="pginternal">auctoritee</a>
    of me, put ayeins perils—</p>
<p><i>that is to seyn, put myn auctoritee in peril for</i>—the wrecched</p>
<p>pore folk, that the covetyse of straungeres unpunished tourmenteden</p>
<p>alwey with miseyses and grevaunces out of noumbre? Never man</p>
<p>ne drow me yit fro right to wronge. Whan I say the fortunes and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the richesses of the poeple of the provinces ben harmed or</p>
<p>amenused, outher by privee ravynes or by comune tributes or</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVNL52" id="BIPIVL52" class="pginternal">cariages</a>, as sory was I as they that suffreden the
    harm.</p>
<p class="stanza"><b>Glossa.</b> <i>Whan that Theodoric, the king of Gothes, in a dere</i></p>
<p><i>yere, hadde hise gerneres ful of corn, and comaundede that no man</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>ne sholde byen no corn til his corn were sold, and that at a grevous</i></p>
<p><i>dere prys, Boece withstood that ordinaunce, and over-com it, knowinge</i></p>
<p><i>al this the king him-self.</i></p>
<p class="stanza"><b>Textus.</b> Whan it was in the soure hungry tyme, ther was</p>
<p>establisshed or cryed grevous and <a href="#BIPIVNL59" id="BIPIVL59" class="pginternal">inplitable
    coempcioun</a>, that men</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">sayen wel it sholde greetly turmenten and endamagen al the</p>
<p>province of <a href="#BIPIVNL61" id="BIPIVL61" class="pginternal">Campaigne</a>, I took stryf ayeins the <a href="#BIPIVNL61" class="pginternal">provost</a> of the pretorie</p>
<p>for comune profit. And, the king knowinge of it, I overcom</p>
<p>it, so that the coempcioun ne was not axed ne took effect.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page11">{11}</span>[<b><a href="#BIPIVNL64" id="BIPIVL64" class="pginternal">Glossa.</a></b>] <i>Coempcioun, that is to seyn, comune achat or bying</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>to-gidere, that were establisshed up-on the poeple by swiche a
    manere</i></p>
<p><i>imposicioun, as who-so boughte a busshel corn, he moste yeve the king</i></p>
<p><i>the fifte part.</i></p>
<p class="stanza">[<b>Textus.</b>] <a href="#BIPIVNL68" id="BIPIVL68" class="pginternal">Paulin</a>, a counseiller
    of Rome, the richesses of the</p>
<p>whiche Paulin the <a href="#BIPIVNL69" id="BIPIVL69" class="pginternal">houndes</a> of the palays, <i>that is to
    seyn, the officeres</i>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">wolden han devoured by hope and covetise, yit drow I him out of</p>
<p>the Iowes (<i>sc. faucibus</i>) of hem that gapeden. And for as moche</p>
<p>as the peyne of the accusacioun aiuged biforn ne sholde nat</p>
<p>sodeinly henten ne punisshen wrongfully <a href="#BIPIVNL73" id="BIPIVL73" class="pginternal">Albin</a>, a
    counseiller of</p>
<p>Rome, I putte me ayeins the hates and indignaciouns of the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">accusor <a href="#BIPIVNL75" id="BIPIVL75" class="pginternal">Ciprian</a>. Is it nat thanne
    y-nough y-seyn, that I have</p>
<p>purchased grete discordes ayeins my-self? But I oughte be the</p>
<p>more assured ayeins alle othre folk (<i>s. Romayns</i>), that for the love</p>
<p>of rightwisnesse I ne reserved never no-thing to my-self <a href="#BIPIVNL78" id="BIPIVL78" class="pginternal">to hem-ward</a></p>
<p>of the kinges halle, <i>sc. officers</i>, by the whiche I were the more</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">siker. But thorugh tho same accusers accusinge, I am condempned.</p>
<p>Of the noumbir of the whiche accusers oon <a href="#BIPIVNL81" id="BIPIVL81" class="pginternal">Basilius</a>,</p>
<p>that whylom was chased out of the kinges service, is now <a href="#BIPIVNL82" id="BIPIVL82" class="pginternal">compelled</a></p>
<p>in accusinge of my name, <a href="#BIPIVNL82" class="pginternal">for nede of foreine moneye</a>.</p>
<p>Also <a href="#BIPIVNL84" id="BIPIVL84" class="pginternal">Opilion</a> and Gaudencius han accused me, al be it
    so that the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">85</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Iustice regal hadde whylom demed hem bothe to go in-to exil for</p>
<p>hir trecheryes and fraudes withoute noumbir. To whiche Iugement</p>
<p>they nolden nat obeye, but defendeden hem by the sikernesse</p>
<p>of holy houses, <i>that is to seyn, fledden into seintuaries</i>; and</p>
<p>whan this was <a href="#BIPIVNL89" id="BIPIVL89" class="pginternal">aperceived</a> to the king, he comaundede,
    that but</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">they voidede the citee of Ravenne by certein day assigned, that</p>
<p>men sholde merken hem on the forheved with an hoot yren and</p>
<p>chasen hem out of the toune. Now what thing, semeth thee,</p>
<p>mighte ben <a href="#BIPIVNL93" id="BIPIVL93" class="pginternal">lykned</a> to this crueltee? For certes, thilke
    same day</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page12">{12}</span>was received the accusinge of my name by thilke
    same accusers.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIPIVNL95" id="BIPIVL95" class="pginternal">What may ben seid her-to?</a> (<i>quasi
    diceret, nichil</i>). Hath my</p>
<p>studie and my cunninge deserved thus; or elles the forseide dampnacioun</p>
<p><i>of me</i>, made that hem rightful accusers or no? (<i>quasi</i></p>
<p><i>diceret, non</i>). Was not Fortune ashamed of this? Certes, al</p>
<p>hadde nat Fortune ben ashamed that innocence was accused, yit</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">oughte she han had shame of the filthe of myne accusours.</p>
<p class="stanza">But, <a href="#BIPIVNL101" id="BIPIVL101" class="pginternal">axestow in somme</a>, of what gilt I
    am accused, men seyn</p>
<p>that I wolde save the companye of the senatours. And desirest</p>
<p>thou to heren in what manere? I am accused that I sholde han</p>
<p>destourbed the accuser to beren lettres, by whiche he sholde han</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">maked the senatoures gilty ayeins the kinges real maiestee. O</p>
<p>maistresse, what demestow of this? Shal I <a href="#BIPIVNL106" id="BIPIVL106" class="pginternal">forsake</a>
    this blame,</p>
<p>that I ne be no shame to thee? (<i>quasi diceret, non</i>). Certes, I have</p>
<p>wold it, <i>that is to seyn, the savacioun of the senat</i>, ne I shal never</p>
<p>leten to wilne it, <a href="#BIPIVNL109" id="BIPIVL109" class="pginternal">and that I confesse</a> and am
    aknowe; but the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">entente of the accuser to be destourbed shal cese. For shal I</p>
<p>clepe it thanne a felonie or a sinne that I have desired the</p>
<p>savacioun of the ordre of the senat? (<i>quasi diceret, dubito quid</i>).</p>
<p>And certes yit hadde thilke same senat don <a href="#BIPIVNL113" id="BIPIVL113" class="pginternal">by me</a>,
    thorugh hir</p>
<p>decrets and hir Iugements, as though it were a sinne or a felonie;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>that is to seyn, to wilne the savacioun of hem</i> (<i>sc. senatus</i>).
    But</p>
<p>folye, that lyeth alwey to him-self, may not chaunge the merite</p>
<p>of thinges. Ne I trowe nat, by the Iugement of <a href="#BIPIVNL117" id="BIPIVL117" class="pginternal">Socrates</a>, that</p>
<p>it were leveful to me to hyde the sothe, ne assente to lesinges.</p>
<p>But certes, how so ever it be of this, I putte it to gessen or</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">120</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIPIVNL120" id="BIPIVL120" class="pginternal">preisen</a> to the Iugement of thee and of
    wyse folk. Of whiche</p>
<p>thing al the ordinaunce and the sothe, for as moche as folk that</p>
<p>ben to comen after our dayes shullen knowen it, I have put it</p>
<p>in scripture and in remembraunce. For touching the lettres falsly</p>
<p>maked, by whiche lettres I am accused to han hoped the fredom</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of Rome, what aperteneth me to speke ther-of? Of whiche</p>
<p>lettres the fraude hadde ben shewed apertly, yif I hadde had</p>
<p>libertee for to han used and ben at the confessioun of myne</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page13">{13}</span>accusours, the whiche thing in alle nedes hath
    greet strengthe.</p>
<p>For what other fredom may men hopen? Certes, I wolde that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">som other fredom mighte ben hoped. I wolde thanne han</p>
<p>answered by the wordes of a man that highte <a href="#BIPIVNL131" id="BIPIVL131" class="pginternal">Canius</a>;
    for whan</p>
<p>he was accused by Gaius Cesar, <a href="#BIPIVNL132" id="BIPIVL132" class="pginternal">Germeynes sone</a>, that
    he</p>
<p>(<i>Canius</i>) was knowinge and consentinge of a coniuracioun</p>
<p>y-maked ayeins him (<i>sc. Gaius</i>), this Canius answerede thus:</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">135</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">"Yif I hadde wist it, thou haddest nat wist it." In which thing</p>
<p>sorwe hath nat so dulled my wit, that I pleyne only that shrewede</p>
<p>folk aparailen felonies ayeins vertu; but I wondre greetly how</p>
<p>that they may performe thinges that they hadde hoped for to</p>
<p>don. For-why, to wilne shrewednesse, that comth peraventure</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of oure defaute; but it is lyk a monstre and a mervaille, how</p>
<p>that, in the present sighte of god, may ben acheved and performed</p>
<p>swiche thinges as every felonous man hath conceived in his</p>
<p>thought ayeins innocents. For which thing oon of thy <a href="#BIPIVNL143" id="BIPIVL143" class="pginternal">famileres</a></p>
<p>nat unskilfully axed thus: "Yif god is, whennes comen wikkede</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">145</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thinges? And yif god ne is, whennes comen gode thinges?"</p>
<p>But al hadde it ben leveful that felonous folk, that now desiren</p>
<p>the blood and the deeth of alle gode men and eek of alle the</p>
<p>senat, han wilned to gon destroyen me, whom they han seyen</p>
<p>alwey batailen and defenden gode men and eek al the senat,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">150</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">yit had I nat desserved of the faderes, <i>that is to seyn, of the</i></p>
<p><i>senatoures</i>, that they sholden wilne my destruccioun.</p>
<p class="stanza">Thou remembrest wel, as I gesse, that whan I wolde doon or</p>
<p>seyen any thing, thou thyself, alwey present, rewledest me. At</p>
<p>the city of <a href="#BIPIVNL154" id="BIPIVL154" class="pginternal">Verone</a>, whan that the king, gredy of
    comune slaughter,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">155</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">caste him to transporten up al the ordre of the senat the gilt of</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVNL156" id="BIPIVL156" class="pginternal">his real maiestee</a>, of the whiche gilt that Albin was
    accused, with</p>
<p>how gret sikernesse of peril to me defendede I al the senat!</p>
<p>Thou wost wel that I seye sooth, ne I ne avauntede me never</p>
<p>in preysinge of my-self. For alwey, whan any wight receiveth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">160</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">precious renoun in avauntinge him-self of his werkes, he amenuseth</p>
<p>the secree of his conscience. But now thou mayst wel seen to</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page14">{14}</span>what ende I am comen for myne innocence; I
    receive peyne</p>
<p>of fals felonye for guerdon of verray vertu. And what open</p>
<p>confessioun of felonye hadde ever Iuges so acordaunt in crueltee,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">165</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>that is to seyn, as myn accusinge hath</i>, that either errour of mannes</p>
<p>wit or elles condicioun of Fortune, that is uncertein to alle mortal</p>
<p>folk, ne <a href="#BIPIVNL167" id="BIPIVL167" class="pginternal">submittede</a> some of hem, <i>that is to seyn,
    that it ne enclynede</i></p>
<p><i>som Iuge to han pitee or compassioun</i>? For al-thogh I hadde ben</p>
<p>accused that I wolde brenne holy houses, and strangle preestes</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">170</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">with wikkede swerde, or that I hadde greythed deeth to al gode</p>
<p>men, algates the sentence sholde han punisshed me, <a href="#BIPIVNL171" id="BIPIVL171" class="pginternal">present</a>,</p>
<p>confessed, or convict. But now I am remewed fro the citee <i>of</i></p>
<p><i>Rome</i> almost <a href="#BIPIVNL173" id="BIPIVL173" class="pginternal">fyve hundred thousand pas</a>, I am
    with-oute defence</p>
<p>dampned to proscripcioun and to the deeth, for the studie and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">175</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">bountees that I have doon to the senat. But O, wel ben they</p>
<p>worthy of merite (<a href="#BIPIVNL176" id="BIPIVL176" class="pginternal"><i>as who seith, nay</i></a>), ther
    mighte never yit non</p>
<p>of hem be convict of swiche a blame as myne is! Of whiche</p>
<p>trespas, myne accusours sayen ful wel the dignitee; the whiche</p>
<p>dignitee, for they wolden derken it with medeling of som felonye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">180</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">they baren me on hand, and lyeden, that I hadde polut and</p>
<p>defouled my conscience with <a href="#BIPIVNL181" id="BIPIVL181" class="pginternal">sacrilege</a>, for coveitise
    of dignitee.</p>
<p>And certes, thou thy-self, that are plaunted in me, chacedest</p>
<p>out of the sege of my corage al coveitise of mortal thinges; ne</p>
<p>sacrilege hadde no leve to han a place in me biforn thyne eyen.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">185</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For thou droppedest every day in myne eres and in my thought</p>
<p>thilke comaundement of <a href="#BIPIVNL186" id="BIPIVL186" class="pginternal">Pictagoras</a>, <i>that is to
    seyn</i>, men shal</p>
<p>serve to godde, <i>and not to goddes</i>. Ne it was nat convenient,</p>
<p><i>ne no nede</i>, to taken help of the foulest spirites; <a href="#BIPIVNL188" id="BIPIVL188" class="pginternal">I</a>, that thou</p>
<p>hast ordeined and set in swiche excellence that thou makedest</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">190</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">me lyk to god. And over this, the <a href="#BIPIVNL190" id="BIPIVL190" class="pginternal">right
    clene</a> secree chaumbre</p>
<p>of myne hous, <i>that is to seyn, my wyf</i>, and the companye of</p>
<p>myn honest freendes, and my wyves fader, as wel holy as worthy</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page15">{15}</span>to ben reverenced <a href="#BIPIVNL193" id="BIPIVL193" class="pginternal">thorugh</a> his owne dedes, defenden me from</p>
<p>alle suspecioun of swich blame. But O malice! For they that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">195</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">accusen me taken of thee, <i>Philosophie</i>, <a href="#BIPIVNL195" id="BIPIVL195" class="pginternal">feith</a> of so gret blame!</p>
<p>For they trowen that I have had affinitee to malefice <i>or enchauntement</i>,</p>
<p>by-cause that I am replenisshed and fulfilled with thy</p>
<p>techinges, and enformed of thy maneres. And thus <a href="#BIPIVNL198" id="BIPIVL198" class="pginternal">it
    suffiseth</a></p>
<p>not only, that thy reverence ne availe me not, but-yif that thou,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">200</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of thy free wille, rather be blemished with myn offencioun. But</p>
<p>certes, to the harmes that I have, ther bitydeth yit this</p>
<p>encrees of harm, that the gessinge and the Iugement of moche</p>
<p>folk ne looken no-thing to the desertes of thinges, but only</p>
<p>to the aventure of fortune; and iugen that only swiche thinges</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">205</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ben purveyed of god, whiche that temporel welefulnesse commendeth.</p>
<p class="stanza"><b>Glose.</b> <i>As thus: that, yif a wight have prosperitee, he is a</i></p>
<p><i>good man and worthy to han that prosperitee; and who-so hath</i></p>
<p><i>adversitee, he is a wikked man, and god hath forsake him, and</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">210</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>he is worthy to han that adversitee. This is the opinioun of some</i></p>
<p><i>folk.</i></p>
<p class="stanza">And ther-of comth that <a href="#BIPIVNL212" id="BIPIVL212" class="pginternal">good gessinge</a>,
    first of alle thing, forsaketh</p>
<p>wrecches: certes, it greveth me to thinke right now the</p>
<p>dyverse sentences that the poeple seith of me. And thus moche</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">215</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I seye, that the laste <a href="#BIPIVNL215" id="BIPIVL215" class="pginternal">charge</a> of
    contrarious fortune is this: that,</p>
<p>whan that any blame is leyd upon a caitif, men wenen that he</p>
<p>hath deserved that he suffreth. And I, that am put awey fro</p>
<p>gode men, and despoiled of dignitees, and defouled of my name</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVNL219" id="BIPIVL219" class="pginternal">by gessinge</a>, have suffred torment for my gode dedes.
    Certes,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">220</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">me semeth that I see the felonous covines of wikked men</p>
<p>habounden in Ioye and in gladnesse. And I see that every</p>
<p>lorel shapeth him to finde out newe fraudes for to accuse gode</p>
<p>folk. And I see that gode men beth overthrowen <a href="#BIPIVNL223" id="BIPIVL223" class="pginternal">for
    drede</a></p>
<p>of my peril; and every luxurious tourmentour dar doon alle</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">225</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">felonye unpunisshed and ben excited therto by yiftes; and</p>
<p>innocents ne ben not only despoiled of sikernesse but of defence;</p>
<p>and therfore me list to cryen <i>to god</i> in this wyse:—</p>
</div>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page16">{16}</span></div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. IV.</span> 1. C. Felistow; A. Felest thou. 2. A. Art thou. //
  C. wepistow; A. wepest thou. 3. A. spillest thou. 9. C. sen; A. seen. 11. A. sege (<i>for</i>
  sete). 12. <i>So</i> A.; C. deuynyte. // C. <i>om. 2nd</i> touchinge. 13. C. <i>om.</i> it is. 14.
  C. om. <i>quasi ... non</i>. 17. <i>After</i> this, C. <i>has</i> nonne; A. <i>has</i> ironice. //
  C. gerdou<i>n</i>s; A. gerdou<i>n</i> (Lat. <i>praemia</i>). 18. C. conformedest (Lat.
  <i>sanxisti</i>); see note. 19. C. Mowht; A. mouthe. 20. A. comunabletes. 22. A. studieden in
  grete wisdomes. 25. C. whise; A. wyse. 26. A. of comune citees (Lat. <i>urbium</i>). 27. C.
  citesenes; A. citizenis. 29. A. folowynge. // C. autorite; A. auctoritee. 30. C. excussioun(!); A.
  execusioun. 32. C. whise; A. wise. 33. A. knowen; C. <i>has the gloss</i> concij (= conscii). 34.
  C. dignete; A. dignite. // C. <i>om.</i> the. 36. <i>So</i> A.; C. descordes. // <i>Above</i>
  preyeres, C. <i>has</i> i. est inexorabiles. 37. A. <i>om. 2nd</i> the. 38. C. sauacioun; A.
  saluacioun. 40. C. recisted. // C. hyhte; A. hyȝt. 41. C. Ed. prosp<i>er</i>e; A.
  p<i>ro</i>pre. 42. A. poure. // C. fookk; A. folke. 45. C. deffended; A. defended. // C. autorite;
  A. auctorite. 47. C. vnpunyssed; A. -nysched. 49. C. ne drowh; A. drowe. 50. A. rychesse. // C.
  <i>om. 2nd</i> the. 51. A. eyther (<i>for</i> outher). // C. pryuey; A. priue. // C. Raueynes; A.
  rauynes. 54. C. yer; A. yere. 55. C. A. solde. 58. C. sowr<i>e</i>; A. soure (Lat. <i>acerbae
  famis tempore</i>). 59. A. establissed; C. estabelissed. // C. vnplitable; A. inplitable (Lat.
  <i>inexplicabilis</i>). 61. Ed. Campayne; C. A. Compaygne. 64. <i>The gloss</i> (Coempcioun ...
  part) <i>is misplaced in both</i> MSS., <i>so as to precede</i> Whan it was (58). 65. C.
  estabelissed. // A. <i>om.</i> the. 66. C. imposiscioun. // C. bossel; A. busshel. 68. <i>So</i>
  A.; C. consoler (!). // A. rychesse. 69. C. palysse; A. palays. 70. C. drowh; A. drowe. 71. sc.
  faucibus <i>from</i> A. 73. C. punisse; A. punischen. // C. conseyler. 75. A. yseyne. 77. A.
  asseured. 78. <i>After</i> no-thing, C. <i>adds</i> i. affinite. 79. C. <i>om. 2nd</i> the. 81. A.
  <i>om. 2nd</i> the. 82, 85. C. whilom; A. somtyme. 84. C. caudencius (<i>wrongly</i>). 88. C.
  sentuarye; A. seyntuaries. 89. C. <i>om.</i> was. 90. C. assingned; A. assigned. 91. C. me (=
  men); A. men. // C. marke; A. merken. 92. A. <i>om.</i> the. // C. <i>om.</i> thee. 93. C.
  crwelte. 94. C. resseyued. 98. C. asshamyd; A. asshamed. 99. C. whas. 101. A. axest thou. 102. C.
  desires. 104. C. destorbed; A. distourbed. 106. C. mayst<i>er</i>esse; A. meistresse.  A. demest
  thou. 109. C. <i>om.</i> that. 109. C. I am; A. Ed. <i>om.</i> I. 110. C. destorbed. 111. A. a
  felonie than. 114. C. and (<i>for</i> or). 119. C. A. put. 120. C. whise. 122. C. shellen; A.
  schollen (<i>better</i> shullen). 123. A. <i>om. 2nd</i> in.  C. thowchinge. 125. C. <i>om.</i> Of
  whiche lettres. 129. C. <i>om.</i> what. // C. hoepen. 133. C. <i>om.</i> Canius. 136. C. sorw.

<h3> <span class="sc">Metre V.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>O stelliferi conditor orbis.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>O thou maker of the <a href="#BIMVNL1" id="BIMVL1" class="pginternal">whele</a> that bereth the sterres, which
    that</p>
<p>art y-fastned to thy perdurable chayer, and tornest the hevene</p>
<p>with a ravisshing <a href="#BIMVNL3" id="BIMVL3" class="pginternal">sweigh</a>, and constreinest the sterres to
    suffren</p>
<p>thy lawe; so that the mone som-tyme shyning with hir <a href="#BIMVNL4" id="BIMVL4" class="pginternal">ful
    hornes</a>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">meting with alle the bemes of the sonne hir brother, hydeth the</p>
<p>sterres that ben lesse; and somtyme, whan the mone, pale with</p>
<p>hir <a href="#BIMVNL7" id="BIMVL7" class="pginternal">derke hornes</a>, approcheth the sonne, leseth hir
    lightes; and</p>
<p>that the eve-sterre Hesperus, whiche that in the firste tyme of</p>
<p>the night bringeth forth hir colde arysinges, <a href="#BIMVNL9" id="BIMVL9" class="pginternal">cometh eft
    ayein</a></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">hir used cours, and is pale <i>by the morwe</i> at the rysing of the</p>
<p>sonne, and is thanne cleped Lucifer. Thou <a href="#BIMVNL11" id="BIMVL11" class="pginternal">restreinest</a>
    the day</p>
<p>by shorter dwelling, in the tyme of colde winter that maketh</p>
<p>the leves to falle. Thou dividest the <a href="#BIMVNL13" id="BIMVL13" class="pginternal">swifte tydes</a> of
    the night,</p>
<p>whan the hote somer is comen. Thy might atempreth the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">variaunts sesons of the yere; so that Zephirus the deboneir</p>
<p>wind bringeth ayein, <i>in the first somer sesoun</i>, the leves that</p>
<p>the wind that highte Boreas hath reft awey <i>in autumpne, that</i></p>
<p><i>is to seyn, in the laste ende of somer</i>; and the sedes that the</p>
<p>sterre that highte <a href="#BIMVNL19" id="BIMVL19" class="pginternal">Arcturus</a> saw, ben waxen heye cornes
    whan the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">sterre <a href="#BIMVNL20" id="BIMVL20" class="pginternal">Sirius</a> eschaufeth hem. Ther nis
    no-thing unbounde from</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVNL21" id="BIMVL21" class="pginternal">his olde lawe</a>, ne forleteth the werke of his propre
    estat.</p>
<p class="stanza">O thou governour, governinge alle thinges by certein ende, why</p>
<p>refusestow only to governe the werkes of men by dewe manere?</p>
<p>Why suffrest thou that slydinge fortune torneth so grete entrechaunginges</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of thinges, so that anoyous peyne, that sholde dewely</p>
<p>punisshe felouns, punissheth innocents? And folk of wikkede</p>
<p>maneres sitten in heye chayres, and anoyinge folk treden, and</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page17">{17}</span>that unrightfully, <a href="#BIMVNL28" id="BIMVL28" class="pginternal">on</a> the nekkes of holy men? And vertu cler-shyninge</p>
<p>naturelly is hid in <a href="#BIMVNL29" id="BIMVL29" class="pginternal">derke derkenesses</a>, and the
    rightful</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">man bereth the blame and the peyne of the feloun. Ne forsweringe</p>
<p>ne the fraude, <a href="#BIMVNL31" id="BIMVL31" class="pginternal">covered and kembd</a> with a fals colour,</p>
<p>ne anoyeth nat to shrewes; the whiche shrewes, whan hem list</p>
<p>to usen hir strengthe, they reioysen hem to putten under hem</p>
<p>the sovereyne kinges, whiche that poeple with-outen noumbre</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">dreden.</p>
<p class="stanza">O thou, what so ever thou be that knittest alle bondes of</p>
<p>thinges, loke on thise wrecchede <a href="#BIMVNL37" id="BIMVL37" class="pginternal">erthes</a>; we men that ben
    nat</p>
<p>a foule party, but a fayr party of so grete a werk, we ben</p>
<p>tormented in this see of fortune. Thou governour, withdraw</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and restreyne the ravisshinge flodes, and fastne and ferme thise</p>
<p>erthes stable with thilke <a href="#BIMVNL41" id="BIMVL41" class="pginternal">bonde</a>, with whiche thou
    governest the</p>
<p>hevene that is so large.'</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. V.</span> 1. C. whel; A. whele. 3. C. Rauessyng; A. rauyssyng.
  // C. sweyh; A. sweigh; Ed. sweygh. 4. C. wyt (<i>for</i> with). 6. A. lasse. // C. wan
  (<i>for</i> whan). 9. C. est; A. eft (Lat. <i>iterum</i>). // A. aȝeynes. 10. C. <i>om.</i>
  the <i>after</i> at. 13. C. falle; A. to falle. // C. swift; A. swifte. 14. C. wan (<i>for</i>
  whan). 15. C. sesoun (<i>wrongly</i>); A. sesons. 17. C. hihte; A. hyȝt. // C. borias. 19.
  C. hihte; A. hyȝt. // C. sawgh; A. saw. // C. hyye; A. hey. // C. wan. 20. C. eschaufed; A.
  eschaufeth; (Lat. <i>urat</i>). // C. fram. 21. C. the werke; A. hym. 23. C. refowsestow; A.
  refusest thou. // C. dwwe; A. dewe. 24. C. suffres. // C. so; A. to. // A. vtter; (<i>for</i>

  heiȝe (Lat. <i>celsos</i>). // C. chayres; A. chaiers. 28. C. oon (<i>read</i> on); A. in.
  29. A. clere and shynyng (Lat. <i>clara</i>). 30. A. Ne the forsweryng. 32. C. weche (<i>for</i>

  <i>bef.</i> werk. 39. C. this; A. the. // C. withdrawh. 40. C. restryne; A. restreyne. // C. thei
