  (<i>better?</i>) </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose V.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Hic ubi continuato dolore delatraui.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Whan I hadde, with a continuel sorwe, sobbed or <a href="#BIPVNL1" id="BIPVL1" class="pginternal">borken
    out</a></p>
<p>thise thinges, she with hir chere pesible, and no-thing amoeved</p>
<p>with my compleintes, seide thus: 'Whan I say thee,' quod she,</p>
<p>'sorweful and wepinge, I wiste anon that thou were a wrecche</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and exiled; but I wiste never how fer thyne exile was, yif thy</p>
<p>tale ne hadde shewed it to me. But certes, al be thou fer fro thy</p>
<p>contree, thou nart nat put out of it; but thou hast failed of thy</p>
<p>weye and gon amis. And yif thou hast lever for to wene that</p>
<p>thou be put out of thy contree, than hast thou put out thy-self</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">rather than any other wight hath. For no wight but thy-self ne</p>
<p>mighte never han don that to thee. For yif thou remembre of</p>
<p>what contree thou art born, it nis nat governed by emperours, ne</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page18">{18}</span>by governement of multitude, as weren the
    contrees of hem of</p>
<p>Athenes; but <a href="#BIPVNL14" id="BIPVL14" class="pginternal">oo lord and oo king</a>, <i>and that is god,
    that is lord of</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>thy contree</i>, whiche that reioyseth him of the dwelling of hise</p>
<p>citezenes, and nat for to putte hem in exil; of the whiche lorde</p>
<p>it is a soverayne fredom to be governed by the brydel of him and</p>
<p>obeye to his Iustice. Hastow foryeten thilke right olde lawe of thy</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVNL18" id="BIPVL18" class="pginternal">citee</a>, in the whiche citee it is ordeined and
    establisshed, that for</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">what wight that hath lever founden ther-in his sete or his hous than</p>
<p>elles-wher, he may nat be exiled by no right from that place? For</p>
<p>who-so that is contened in-with the <a href="#BIPVNL22" id="BIPVL22" class="pginternal">palis</a> and the clos
    of thilke citee,</p>
<p>ther nis no drede that he may deserve to ben exiled. But who-so</p>
<p>that leteth the wil for to enhabite there, he forleteth also to deserve</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to ben citezein of thilke citee. So that I sey, that the <a href="#BIPVNL25" id="BIPVL25" class="pginternal">face</a> of this</p>
<p>place ne moveth me nat so mochel as thyne owne face. Ne I</p>
<p>axe nat rather the walles of thy librarie, aparayled and wrought</p>
<p>with yvory and with glas, than after the sete of thy thought. In</p>
<p>whiche I putte nat whylom bokes, but I putte that that maketh</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">bokes worthy of prys or precious, that is to seyn, the sentence of</p>
<p>my bokes. And certeinly of thy desertes, bistowed <a href="#BIPVNL31" id="BIPVL31" class="pginternal">in
    comune</a></p>
<p><a href="#BIPVNL31" class="pginternal">good</a>, thou hast seid sooth, but after the multitude of thy gode</p>
<p>dedes, thou hast seid fewe; and of the honestee or of the falsnesse</p>
<p>of <a href="#BIPVNL34" id="BIPVL34" class="pginternal">thinges that ben aposed</a> ayeins thee, thou hast
    remembred</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thinges that ben knowen to alle folk. And of the felonyes and</p>
<p>fraudes of thyne accusours, it semeth thee have y-touched it forsothe</p>
<p>rightfully and shortly, al mighten tho same thinges betere</p>
<p>and more plentivousely ben couth in the mouthe of the poeple</p>
<p>that knoweth al this.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">40</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">Thou hast eek blamed gretly and compleined of the wrongful</p>
<p>dede of the senat. And thou hast sorwed for my blame, and thou</p>
<p>hast wopen for the damage of thy renoun that is apayred; and thy</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page19">{19}</span>laste sorwe eschaufede ayeins fortune, and
    compleinest that guerdouns</p>
<p>ne ben nat evenliche yolden to the desertes of folk. And</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">in the latere ende of <a href="#BIPVNL45" id="BIPVL45" class="pginternal">thy wode Muse</a>, thou
    preyedest that thilke</p>
<p>pees that governeth the hevene sholde governe the erthe. But</p>
<p>for that manye tribulaciouns of affecciouns han assailed thee, and</p>
<p>sorwe and ire and wepinge to-drawen thee dyversely; as thou art</p>
<p>now feble of thought, mightier remedies ne shullen nat yit touchen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thee, for whiche we wol usen somdel lighter medicines: so that</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVNL51" id="BIPVL51" class="pginternal">thilke passiouns</a> that ben woxen harde in swellinge, by
    perturbaciouns</p>
<p>flowing in-to thy thought, mowen wexen esy and softe,</p>
<p>to receiven the strengthe of a more mighty and more egre</p>
<p>medicine, <a href="#BIPVNL54" id="BIPVL54" class="pginternal">by an esier touchinge</a>.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. V.</span> 1. C. <i>om.</i> a. // C. borken (= barked); A.
  broken (Lat. <i>delatraui</i>). 2. A. peisible. 4. C. soruful; A. sorweful. // C. wrechche; A.
  wrecche. 6. C. nadde; A. ne hadde. // A. to me; C. <i>om.</i> to. 8. C. wey; A. weye. 11. C.
  remenbre; A. remembre. 13. C. <i>om.</i> hem of. 16. C. cytesenis; A. citezenis. C. put; A. putte.
  17. C. brydul; A. bridel. 18. C. hasthow; A. hast thou. 19. C. weche. 20. C. whyht; A.
  wyȝt. 21. C. wer; A. where. 22. C. contyned; A. contened. // C. palys; A. paleis (Lat.
  <i>uallo</i>). 23. C. desserue. 25. C. cytesein; A. Citezein. // C. face, <i>glossed</i> i. manere
  (Lat. <i>facies</i>). 26. C. moueth; A. amoeueth. 27. A. Ne I ne axe. // C. wrowht; A.
  wrouȝt. 29. C. put; A. putte (<i>twice</i>). // C. whilom; A. somtyme. 30. C. presyous. 32.
  C. seyde; A. seid. 33. A. vnhonestee (<i>wrongly</i>). 34. A. Ed. opposed. // C. remenbryd. 36. C.
  Acusours. // C. I-twoched (<i>for</i> I-towched); A. I-touched. 38: C. mowhth; A. mouthe. 42. A.
  wepen. 43. C. A. gerdouns; Ed. guerdons. 44. C. <i>om.</i> nat. 45. C. later<i>e</i>; A.
  l<i>att</i>re. // C. <i>glosses</i> wode <i>by</i> s. seuientis. 52. A.
  p<i>er</i>turbac<i>i</i>ou<i>n</i> folowyng (<i>wrongly</i>). </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre VI.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Cum Phebi radiis graue<br>
  Cancri sidus inestuat.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Whan that the hevy sterre of the Cancre eschaufeth by the</p>
<p>bemes of Phebus, <i>that is to seyn, whan that Phebus the sonne is</i></p>
<p><i><a href="#BIMVINL2" id="BIMVIL2" class="pginternal">in the signe of the Cancre</a></i>, who-so yeveth thanne
    largely hise sedes</p>
<p>to the feldes that refusen to receiven hem, <a href="#BIMVINL4" id="BIMVIL4" class="pginternal">lat him gon</a>,
    bigyled of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">trust that he hadde to his corn, to acorns of okes. Yif thou wolt</p>
<p>gadre violettes, ne go thou not to the purpur wode <a href="#BIMVINL6" id="BIMVIL6" class="pginternal">whan the
    feld</a>,</p>
<p>chirkinge, agryseth of colde by the felnesse of the winde that highte</p>
<p>Aquilon. Yif thou desirest or wolt usen grapes, ne seke thou nat,</p>
<p>with a glotonous hond, to streyne and presse the stalkes of the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">vine in the ferst somer sesoun; for Bachus, the god of wyne, hath</p>
<p>rather yeven hise yiftes to autumpne, <i>the later ende of somer</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza">God tokneth and assigneth the tymes, ablinge hem to hir</p>
<p>propres offices; ne he ne suffreth nat the stoundes whiche that</p>
<p>him-self hath devyded and constreyned to ben y-medled to-gidere.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIMVINL15" id="BIMVIL15" class="pginternal">And forthy</a> he that forleteth certein
    ordinaunce of doinge by over-throwinge</p>
<p>wey, he ne hath no glade issue or ende of his werkes.</p>
</div>
<p><span class="sc">Me. VI.</span> 1. C. ca<i>n</i>kyr; A. Ed. cancre. 2. C. beemes; A. beme (Lat.
  <i>radiis</i>). 3. C. cankyr; A. Ed. Cancre. 4. C. feeldes. // C. Reseyue; A. receiuen. // C.
  <i>glosses</i> hem <i>by</i> s. corn. 5. C. Accornes of Okes; A. acorns or okes. // C. wolt; A.
  wilt. 6. C. gadery; A. gadre. // C. feeld; A. felde. 7. C. felnesses; A. felnesse. // C. hyhte; A.
  hyȝt. 9. C. stryne; A. streyne. 11. C. later; A. latter. 13. C. propres; A. propre. 16. C.
  issw; A. issue. </p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page20">{20}</span></div>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose VI.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Primum igitur paterisne me pauculis rogacionibus.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>First woltow suffre me to touche and assaye the estat of thy</p>
<p>thought by a fewe demaundes, so that I may understonde what</p>
<p>be the manere of thy curacioun?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Axe me,' quod I, 'at thy wille, what thou wolt, and I shal</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">answere.'</p>
<p class="stanza">Tho seide she thus: 'Whether wenestow,' quod she, 'that</p>
<p>this world be governed by foolish happes and fortunous, or</p>
<p>elles that ther be in it any governement of resoun?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod I, 'I ne trowe nat in no manere, that so</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">certein thinges sholde be moeved by <a href="#BIPVINL10" id="BIPVIL10" class="pginternal">fortunous fortune</a>; but I</p>
<p>wot wel that god, maker and mayster, is governour of his werk.</p>
<p>Ne never nas yit day that mighte putte me out of the sothnesse</p>
<p>of that sentence.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'So is it,' quod she; 'for <a href="#BIPVINL14" id="BIPVIL14" class="pginternal">the same thing
    songe thou</a> a litel</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">her-biforn, and biweyledest and biweptest, that only men weren</p>
<p>put out of the cure of god. For of alle other thinges thou</p>
<p>ne doutedest nat that they nere governed by resoun. But <a href="#BIPVINL17" id="BIPVIL17" class="pginternal">owh!</a></p>
<p>(<i>i. pape!</i>) I wondre gretly, certes, <a href="#BIPVINL18" id="BIPVIL18" class="pginternal">why that
    thou</a> art syk, sin</p>
<p>that thou art put in so holsom a sentence. But lat us seken</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">depper; I coniecte that ther lakketh <a href="#BIPVINL20" id="BIPVIL20" class="pginternal">I not
    nere what</a>. But</p>
<p>sey me this: sin that thou ne doutest nat that this world be</p>
<p>governed by god, <a href="#BIPVINL22" id="BIPVIL22" class="pginternal">with whiche governailes</a> takestow hede
    that</p>
<p>it is governed?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Unnethe,' quod I, 'knowe I the sentence of thy questioun;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">so that I ne may nat yit answeren to thy demaundes.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'I nas nat deceived,' quod she, 'that ther ne faileth somwhat,</p>
<p>by whiche the maladye of thy perturbacioun is crept into</p>
<p>thy thought, so as <a href="#BIPVINL28" id="BIPVIL28" class="pginternal">the strengthe</a> of the palis chyning
    is open.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page21">{21}</span>But sey me this: remembrest thou what is the
    ende of thinges,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and whider that the entencioun of alle kinde tendeth?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'I have herd it told som-tyme,' quod I; 'but drerinesse hath</p>
<p>dulled my memorie.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod she, 'thou wost wel whennes that alle thinges</p>
<p>ben comen and procedeth?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">35</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'I wot wel,' quod I, and answerede, that 'god is beginning</p>
<p>of al.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'And how may this be,' quod she, 'that, sin thou knowest</p>
<p>the beginning of thinges, that thou ne knowest nat what is the</p>
<p>ende of thinges? But swiche ben the customes of perturbaciouns,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and this power they han, that they may moeve a</p>
<p>man out of his place, <i>that is to seyn, fro the stablenes and perfeccioun</i></p>
<p><i>of his knowinge</i>; but, certes, <a href="#BIPVINL42" id="BIPVIL42" class="pginternal">they may nat al</a>
    arace</p>
<p>him, ne aliene him in al. But I wolde that thou woldest</p>
<p>answere to this: remembrestow that thou art a man?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">45</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Why sholde I nat remembre that?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Maystow nat telle me thanne,' quod she, 'what thing is a man?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Axestow me nat,' quod I, 'whether that I be a resonable</p>
<p>mortal beest? I woot wel, and I confesse wel that I am it.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Wistestow never yit that thou were any other thing?' quod</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">she.</p>
<p class="stanza">'No,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Now woot I,' quod she, 'other cause of thy maladye, and</p>
<p>that right grete. Thou hast left for to knowen thy-self, what</p>
<p>thou art; thorugh whiche I have pleynly founden the cause of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thy maladye, <a href="#BIPVINL55" id="BIPVIL55" class="pginternal">or elles the entree</a> of
    recoveringe of thyn hele.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVINL56" id="BIPVIL56" class="pginternal">For-why, for</a> thou art confounded with foryeting of
    thy-self, <a href="#BIPVINL56" class="pginternal">for-thy</a></p>
<p>sorwestow that thou art exiled of thy propre goodes. And</p>
<p>for thou ne wost what is the ende of thinges, for-thy demestow</p>
<p>that felonous and wikked men ben mighty and weleful. And</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page22">{22}</span>for thou hast foryeten by whiche
    governements the world is</p>
<p>governed, for-thy wenestow that thise mutaciouns of fortune</p>
<p>fleten with-oute governour. Thise ben grete causes not only</p>
<p>to maladye, but, certes, grete causes to deeth. But I thanke</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVINL64" id="BIPVIL64" class="pginternal">the auctor and the maker of hele</a>, that nature hath not
    al</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">forleten thee. I have grete <a href="#BIPVINL65" id="BIPVIL65" class="pginternal">norisshinges</a>
    of thyn hele, and that</p>
<p>is, the sothe sentence of governaunce of the worlde; that thou</p>
<p>bilevest that the governinge of it nis nat subiect ne underput</p>
<p>to the folie of thise happes aventurous, but to the resoun of</p>
<p>god. And ther-for doute thee no-thing; for of this litel spark</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thyn hete of lyf shal shyne.</p>
<p class="stanza">But for as moche as it is nat tyme yit of <a href="#BIPVINL71" id="BIPVIL71" class="pginternal">faster</a> remedies, and</p>
<p>the nature of thoughtes deceived is this, that as ofte as they</p>
<p>casten awey sothe opiniouns, they clothen hem in false opiniouns,</p>
<p>of which false opiniouns the derkenesse of perturbacioun wexeth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">up, that confoundeth the verray insighte: and that derkenesse</p>
<p>shal I assaye som-what <a href="#BIPVINL76" id="BIPVIL76" class="pginternal">to maken thinne and wayk</a> by
    lighte</p>
<p>and <a href="#BIPVINL77" id="BIPVIL77" class="pginternal">meneliche</a> remedies; so that, after that the
    derkenesse of</p>
<p>deceivinge desiringes is don awey, thou mowe knowe the shyninge</p>
<p>of verray light.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. VI.</span> 1. C. woltow; A. wolt thou. // C. estat; A. stat.
  6. C. wheyther. // C. weenesthow; A. wenest thou. 8. A. <i>ins.</i> wenest thou <i>after</i>
  elles. 9. A. <i>om. 2nd</i> I. 11. C. his; A. this (Lat. <i>suo</i>). 12. C. put; A. putte. 14. C.
  lytul; A. lytel. 17. C. dowtedest, A. doutest. // C. owh; A. how; Ed. ough. 18. C. syk; A. seek.
  19. C. sin that; A. sithen. // A. in-to (<i>for</i> in). 20. A. <i>om.</i> ner<i>e</i>. 21. C.
  syn; A. sithen. 22. A. takest thou. 23. C. <i>om.</i> it. 25. C. <i>om.</i> nat. // A. demaunde
  (Lat. <i>inquisita</i>). 26. C. desseyued. 27. C. of thi; A. <i>om.</i> thi. 28. C. palys chynyng;
  A. paleys schynyng (Lat. <i>hiante ualli robore</i>). 29. C. remenbres. // A. <i>adds</i> thi
  <i>bef.</i> thinges; <i>and om.</i> and. 30. C. entensyn. 34. A. p<i>ro</i>ceded. 35. A. is the.
  37. C. syn; A. sithen. 39. A. endyng. 42. C. arrace; A. arace. 44. C. Remenbresthow; A. remembrest
  thou. 45. C. remenbre. 46. C. Maysthow; A. Maiste thou. // C. thinge. 47. C. Axestow me nat; A.
  Axest not me. // C. wheither. // A. <i>om.</i> I <i>after</i> that. 48. A. best mortel. 49. C.
  Wystesthow; A. Wistest thou. 54. C. fwonde; A. knowen. 56. C. confwndyd. 57. C. sorwistow; A.
  sorwest thou. 58. C. domesthow; A. demest. 59. A. <i>om.</i> And. 60. C. ast foryeeten. // C.
  gou<i>er</i>nement; A. gouernementz (Lat. <i>gubernaculis</i>). 61. A. wenest thou. 63. C. thi
  deth; A. (<i>rightly</i>) <i>om.</i> thi. 64. C. alle; A. al. 65. A. <i>ins.</i> and <i>before</i>
  I have. 67. A. subgit. // C. -putte; A. -put. 68. C. Auentros; A. auenturouses; Ed. auenturous. //
  C. <i>om.</i> to. 69. C. lytul; A. litel. 70. A. heet. 71. C. meche (= moche). 72. C. desseyued;
  A. disseiued. 74. C. dirkenesse; A. derknesse. // C. perturba (!). // C. wexit. 78. C. A.
  desseyuynge. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre VII.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Nubibus atris.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>The sterres, covered with blake cloudes, ne mowen <a href="#BIMVIINL1" id="BIMVIIL1" class="pginternal">yeten</a></p>
<p>a-doun no light. Yif the <a href="#BIMVIINL2" id="BIMVIIL2" class="pginternal">trouble</a> wind that hight
    Auster, turning</p>
<p>and walwinge the see, <a href="#BIMVIINL3" id="BIMVIIL3" class="pginternal">medleth the hete</a>, <i>that is to
    seyn,</i></p>
<p><i>the boyling up from the botme</i>; the wawes, that whylom weren</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIMVIINL5" id="BIMVIIL5" class="pginternal">clere as glas</a> and lyke to the faire
    clere dayes, <a href="#BIMVIINL5" class="pginternal">withstande</a> anon</p>
<p>the sightes of men by the filthe and ordure that is resolved.</p>
<p>And the fletinge streem, that <a href="#BIMVIINL7" id="BIMVIIL7" class="pginternal">royleth</a> doun dyversly
    fro heye</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page23">{23}</span>mountaignes, is arested and resisted ofte tyme
    by the encountringe</p>
<p>of a stoon that is departed and fallen from som roche.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">10</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">And for-thy, yif thou wolt loken and demen sooth with cleer</p>
<p>light, and <a href="#BIMVIINL11" id="BIMVIIL11" class="pginternal">holden</a> the wey with a right path, <a href="#BIMVIINL11" class="pginternal">weyve</a> thou Ioye,</p>
<p>dryf fro thee drede, fleme thou hope, ne lat no sorwe aproche;</p>
<p><i>that is to seyn, lat non of thise four passiouns over-comen thee</i></p>
<p><i>or blende thee</i>. For cloudy and derke is thilke thought, and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">bounde with brydles, where-as thise thinges regnen.'</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. VII.</span> 1. C. Ed. yeten; A. geten. 2. C. A. wynde. 4. C.
  Ed. whilom; A. somtyme. 5. C. lyk; A. lyke. // C. cleer<i>e</i> dayes and brihte; A. bryȝt
  dayes. // C. withstand; A. withstant. 7. C. hy; A. heyȝe. 9. C. fram. 14. C. A. dirke. 15.
  C. were (<i>for</i> where). // C. reygnen; A. regnen. </p>
<p class="sp5 ac"><b>Explicit Liber Primus.</b></p>
<h2 class="sp3 ac" style="margin-bottom:2.1ex;"> <span class="larger">BOOK II.</span></h2>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose I.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Postea paulisper conticuit.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>After this she stinte a litel; and, after that she hadde gadered</p>
<p>by atempre stillenesse myn attencioun, she seide thus: (<i>As who</i></p>
<p><i>mighte seyn thus: After thise thinges she stinte a litel; and whan</i></p>
<p><i>she aperceived by atempre stillenesse that I was ententif to herkene</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>hir, she bigan to speke in this wyse</i>): 'Yif I,' quod she, 'have</p>
<p>understonden and knowen outrely the causes and the habit of</p>
<p>thy maladye, thou languissest and art defeted for desyr and</p>
<p>talent of thy rather fortune. She, that ilke Fortune only, that</p>
<p>is chaunged, as thou feynest, to thee-ward, hath perverted the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">cleernesse and the estat of thy corage. I understonde the</p>
<p>fele-folde colours and deceites of thilke merveilous monstre</p>
<p>Fortune, and how she useth ful flateringe familaritee with hem</p>
<p>that she enforceth <a href="#BIIPINL13" id="BIIPIL13" class="pginternal">to bigyle</a>; so longe, til that she
    confounde</p>
<p>with unsufferable sorwe hem that she hath left in despeyr unpurveyed.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And yif thou remembrest wel the kinde, the maneres,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page24">{24}</span>and the desert of thilke Fortune, thou shalt wel
    knowe that,</p>
<p>as in hir, thou never ne haddest ne hast y-lost any fair thing.</p>
<p>But, as I trowe, I shal nat gretly travailen to do thee remembren</p>
<p>on thise thinges. For thou were wont to hurtelen and despysen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">hir, with manly wordes, whan she was blaundissinge and present,</p>
<p>and pursewedest hir with sentences that were drawen out of myn</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPINL22" id="BIIPIL22" class="pginternal">entree</a>, <i>that is to seyn, out of myn
    informacioun</i>. But no sodein</p>
<p>mutacioun ne bitydeth nat with-oute a manere chaunginge of</p>
<p>corages; and so is it befallen that thou art a litel departed</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">fro the pees of thy thought.</p>
<p class="stanza">But now is tyme that thou drinke and ataste some softe and</p>
<p>delitable thinges; so that, whan they ben entred with-in thee,</p>
<p>it mowe maken wey to strengere drinkes of medicynes. <a href="#BIIPINL28" id="BIIPIL28" class="pginternal">Com</a></p>
<p>now forth therfore the suasioun of swetenesse rethorien, whiche</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that goth only the right wey, whyl she forsaketh nat myne estatuts.</p>
<p>And with Rhetorice com forth Musice, a damisel of our hous,</p>
<p>that singeth now lighter <a href="#BIIPINL32" id="BIIPIL32" class="pginternal">moedes</a> <i>or prolaciouns</i>,
    now hevyer.</p>
<p>What eyleth thee, man? What is it that hath cast thee in-to</p>
<p>morninge and in-to wepinge? I trowe that thou hast seyn</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">som newe thing and uncouth. Thou wenest that <a href="#BIIPINL35" id="BIIPIL35" class="pginternal">Fortune</a> be</p>
<p>chaunged ayein thee; but thou wenest wrong, yif thou that</p>
<p>wene. Alwey tho ben hir maneres; she hath rather kept, as</p>
<p>to thee-ward, hir propre stablenesse in the chaunginge of hir-self.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Right swich was she whan she flatered thee, and deceived</p>
<p>thee with unleveful lykinges of fals welefulnesse. Thou</p>
<p>hast now knowen and ataynt the doutous or double visage of</p>
<p>thilke blinde goddesse Fortune. She, that yit covereth hir and</p>
<p>wimpleth hir to other folk, hath shewed hir every-del to thee.</p>
<p>Yif thou aprovest hir and thenkest that she is good, use hir</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIIPINL45" id="BIIPIL45" class="pginternal">maneres</a> and pleyne thee nat. And yif
    thou agrysest hir false</p>
<p>trecherye, despyse and cast awey hir that pleyeth so harmfully;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page25">{25}</span>for she, that is now cause of so muche sorwe to
    thee, sholde</p>
<p>ben cause to thee of pees and of Ioye. <a href="#BIIPINL48" id="BIIPIL48" class="pginternal">She hath
    forsaken</a></p>
<p>thee, forsothe; the whiche that never man may ben siker that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">she ne shal forsake him.</p>
<p class="stanza"><b><a href="#BIIPINL51" id="BIIPIL51" class="pginternal">Glose.</a></b> <i>But natheles, some
    bokes han the text thus</i>: For sothe,</p>
<p>she hath forsaken thee, ne ther nis no man siker that she ne</p>
<p>hath nat forsaken.</p>
<p class="stanza">Holdestow than thilke welefulnesse precious to thee that shal</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">passen? And is present Fortune dereworthe to thee, which that</p>
<p>nis nat feithful for to dwelle; and, whan she goth awey, that</p>
<p>she bringeth a wight in sorwe? For sin she may nat ben withholden</p>
<p>at a mannes wille, she maketh him a wrecche whan she</p>
<p>departeth fro him. What other thing is flittinge Fortune but a</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">maner shewinge of wrecchednesse that is to comen? Ne it ne</p>
<p>suffyseth nat only to loken on thinge that is present biforn the</p>
<p>eyen of a man. But wisdom loketh and amesureth the ende</p>
<p>of thinges; and the same chaunginge from oon in-to an-other,</p>
<p><i>that is to seyn, from adversitee in-to prosperitee</i>, maketh that the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">manaces of Fortune ne ben nat for to dreden, ne the flateringes</p>
<p>of hir to ben desired. Thus, at the laste, it bihoveth thee to</p>
<p>suffren with evene wille in pacience al that is don in-with the</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPINL68" id="BIIPIL68" class="pginternal">floor</a> of Fortune, <i>that is to seyn, in this
    world</i>, sin thou hast</p>
<p>ones put thy nekke under the yok of hir. For yif thou wolt</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">wryten a lawe of wendinge and of dwellinge to Fortune, whiche</p>
<p>that thou hast chosen frely to ben thy lady, artow nat wrongful</p>
<p>in that, and makest Fortune wroth and aspere by thyn inpatience,</p>
<p>and yit thou mayst nat chaunge hir?</p>
<p class="stanza">Yif thou committest and bitakest thy sailes to the winde, thou</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">shall be shoven, not thider that thou woldest, but whider that the</p>
<p>wind shoveth thee. Yif thou castest thy sedes in-to the feldes,</p>
<p>thou sholdest han in minde that the yeres ben, <a href="#BIIPINL77" id="BIIPIL77" class="pginternal">amonges</a>, other-whyle</p>
<p>plentevous and other-whyle bareyne. Thou hast bitaken</p>
<p>thy-self to the governaunce of Fortune, and for-thy it bihoveth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page26">{26}</span>thee to ben obeisaunt to the
    maneres of thy lady. Enforcest</p>
<p>thou thee to aresten or withholden the swiftnesse and the sweigh</p>
<p>of hir turninge whele? O thou fool of alle mortal fooles, if</p>
<p>Fortune bigan to dwelle stable, she <a href="#BIIPINL83" id="BIIPIL83" class="pginternal">cesede</a> thanne to
    ben</p>
<p>Fortune!</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. I.</span> 1. C. lytul; A. litel; (<i>and so below</i>). // A.
  she; C. I (<i>wrongly</i>). 2. C. atencioun. 4. C. aperseyuyd; A. aperceiued. 5. C. here; A. hire.
  // C. whise. 6. A. vtterly. 7. C. maledye. // A. talent and desijr. 9. C. changed; A. chaunged.
  10. A. astat. 11. C. feelefold; A. felefolde. // A. colo<i>ur</i>. // C. meruayles; A.
  merueillous. 14. C. onsufferabele; A. vnsuffreable. // C. dyspeyr; A. despeir. 15. C. remenbrest.
  16. A. <i>om.</i> that. 17. C. thinge. 18. C. remenbr<i>e</i>; A. remembren. 19. C. on; A. of. //
  C. hurtelyn; A. hurtlen. 20. C. wan. // C. <i>om.</i> was. 21. C. purswedest; A. pursewedest. 24.
  A. departed a litel. 26. C. ataast; A. atast. 29. C. suacyou<i>n</i>; A. suasiou<i>n</i>. 30. C.
  estatutes; A. estatutz. 31. A. damoisel. 32. C. A. moedes (Lat. <i>modos</i>). // C. probasyons;
  A. prolaciouns. 36. C. weenes. 38. C. stabylnesse; A. stablenes. // C. <i>ins.</i> standeth
  <i>bef.</i> in. // C. chau<i>n</i>nynge. 40. C. desseyued; A. desseiued. // C. vnlefful; A.
  vnleueful. 42. C. coueryht. 43. C. hat (<i>for</i> hath). 44. C. thinkest; A. thenkest. // C. god;
  A. goode. 48. A. to the cause. 53. C. forsake; A. forsaken. 54. C. holdestow; A. holdest thou. //
  C. p<i>re</i>syes; A. p<i>re</i>ciouse. 56. C. feythfulle; A. feithful. 57. C. whitholden. 62. A.
  <i>om.</i> a. // A. mesureth. 63. C. fram. 64. C. in-to; A. to. 65. C. manesses; A. manaces. 67.
  C. wit. 68. C. syn; A. sythen. 69. C. welt; A. wilt; Ed. wolt. 71. C. artow; A. art thou. 75. C.
  thedyr; A. thider. // C. whedyr. 76. C. A. wynde. // C. in-to; A. in. // C. feeldes. 77. A.
  <i>om.</i> amonges. 78. C. barayne. 81. C. sweyȝ; A. sweyes (Lat. <i>impetum</i>). 82. C.
  wheel; A. whele. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre I.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Hec cum superba uerterit uices dextra.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Whan Fortune with a proud right hand hath torned hir</p>
<p>chaunginge stoundes, she fareth lyk the maneres of the boilinge</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMINL3" id="BIIMIL3" class="pginternal">Eurype</a>. <b>Glosa.</b> <i>Eurype is an arm of the see
    that ebbeth and</i></p>
<p><i>floweth; and som-tyme the streem is on o syde, and som-tyme on</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>the other.</i> <b>Text.</b> She, cruel Fortune, casteth adoun kinges</p>
<p>that whylom weren y-drad; and she, deceivable, enhaunseth up</p>
<p>the humble chere of him that is discomfited. Ne she neither</p>
<p>hereth ne rekketh of wrecchede wepinges; and she is <a href="#BIIMINL8" id="BIIMIL8" class="pginternal">so
    hard</a></p>
<p>that she <a href="#BIIMINL9" id="BIIMIL9" class="pginternal">laugheth</a> and scorneth the wepinges of hem, the
    whiche</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">she hath maked wepe with hir free wille. Thus she pleyeth,</p>
<p>and thus she proeueth hir strengthes; and sheweth a greet wonder</p>
<p>to alle hir servauntes, yif that a wight is seyn weleful, and over-throwe</p>
<p>in an houre.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. I.</span> 3. C. A. Eurippe (<i>twice</i>); Ed. Eurype. 5. C.
  the; A. that. 6. C. whilom; A. somtyme. // C. enhanseth; A. enhau<i>n</i>seth. 7. C. vmble; A.
  humble. // C. descounfited; A. discomfited. // C. Ne; A. and. 9. C. lyssheth; A. lauȝeth;
  Ed. laugheth (Lat. <i>ridet</i>.) 11. A. p<i>re</i>ueth. // A. strengthe (Lat. <i>uires</i>). //
  C. A. grete. 12. C. whiht; A. wyȝt. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose II.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Vellem autem pauca tecum.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Certes, I wolde pleten with thee a fewe thinges, usinge the</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIINL1" id="BIIPIIL1" class="pginternal">wordes of Fortune</a>; tak hede now thy-self, yif that she
    axeth</p>
<p>right. "O thou man, wher-fore makest thou me gilty by thyne</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIINL4" id="BIIPIIL4" class="pginternal">every-dayes</a> pleyninges? What wrong have I don thee?
    What</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">goodes have I bireft thee that weren thyne? Stryf or plete</p>
<p>with me, bifore what Iuge that thou wolt, of the possessioun</p>
<p>of richesses or of dignitees. And yif thou mayst shewen me</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page27">{27}</span>that ever any mortal man hath received any of
    tho thinges to</p>
<p>ben hise in propre, than wol I graunte frely that alle thilke</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thinges weren thyne whiche that thou axest. Whan that nature</p>
<p>broughte thee forth out of thy moder wombe, I receyved thee</p>
<p>naked and nedy of alle thinges, and I norisshede thee with my</p>
<p>richesses, and was redy and ententif through my favour to</p>
<p>susteyne thee; and that maketh thee now inpacient ayeins me;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and I envirounde thee with alle the aboundance and shyninge</p>
<p>of alle goodes that ben in my right. Now it lyketh me to</p>
<p>with-drawen my hand; thou hast had grace as he that hath</p>
<p>used of foreine goodes: thou hast no right to pleyne thee, as</p>
<p>though thou haddest outrely for-lorn alle thy thinges. Why</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">pleynest thou thanne? I have done thee no wrong. Richesses,</p>
<p>honours, and swiche other thinges ben of my right. My servauntes</p>
<p>knowen me for hir lady; they comen with me, and departen</p>
<p>whan I wende. I dar wel affermen hardily, that yif tho thinges,</p>
<p>of which thou pleynest that thou hast forlorn, hadde ben thyne,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thou ne haddest not lorn hem. Shal I thanne only ben defended</p>
<p>to usen my right?</p>
<p class="stanza">Certes, it is leveful to the hevene to make clere dayes, and,</p>
<p>after that, to coveren tho same dayes with derke nightes. The</p>
<p>yeer hath eek leve to apparailen the visage of the erthe, now</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">with floures and now with fruit, and to confounden hem som-tyme</p>
<p>with reynes and with coldes. The see hath eek his right</p>
<p>to ben som-tyme calme and blaundishing with smothe water,</p>
<p>and som-tyme to ben horrible with wawes and with tempestes.</p>
<p>But the covetise of men, that may nat ben stanched, shal it</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">binde me to ben stedefast, sin that stedefastnesse is uncouth</p>
<p>to my maneres? Swich is my strengthe, and this pley I pleye</p>
<p>continuely. <a href="#BIIPIINL37" id="BIIPIIL37" class="pginternal">I torne</a> the whirlinge wheel with the
    torning cercle;</p>
<p>I am glad to chaungen the lowest to the heyest, and the heyest</p>
<p>to the lowest. <a href="#BIIPIINL39" id="BIIPIIL39" class="pginternal">Worth up</a>, if thou wolt, so it be by
    this lawe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page28">{28}</span>that thou ne holde nat that I do
    thee wronge thogh thou</p>
<p>descende adoun, whan the resoun of my pley axeth it.</p>
<p class="stanza">Wistest thou nat how <a href="#BIIPIINL42" id="BIIPIIL42" class="pginternal">Cresus</a>, the king
    of Lydiens, of whiche</p>
<p>king Cyrus was ful sore agast a litel biforn, that this rewliche</p>
<p>Cresus was caught of Cyrus and lad to the fyr to ben brent,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">but that a rayn descendede doun fro hevene that rescowede</p>
<p>him? And is it out of thy minde how that Paulus, consul of</p>
<p>Rome, whan he hadde taken the king of <a href="#BIIPIINL47" id="BIIPIIL47" class="pginternal">Perciens</a>, weep
    pitously</p>
<p>for the captivitee of the self kinge? What other thing biwailen</p>
<p>the cryinges of tragedies but only the dedes of Fortune, that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">with an unwar stroke overtorneth realmes of grete nobley?</p>
<p><b>Glose.</b> <i><a href="#BIIPIINL51" id="BIIPIIL51" class="pginternal">Tragedie</a> is to seyn, a ditee of a
    prosperitee for a tyme,</i></p>
<p><i>that endeth in wrecchednesse.</i></p>
<p class="stanza">Lernedest nat thou <i><a href="#BIIPIINL53" id="BIIPIIL53" class="pginternal">in Greke</a></i>,
    whan thou were yonge, that</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIINL54" id="BIIPIIL54" class="pginternal">in the entree</a>, <i>or in the celere</i>, of Iupiter,
    ther ben couched two</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">tonnes; that on is ful of good, that other is ful of harm? What</p>
<p>right hast thou to pleyne, yif thou hast taken more plentevously</p>
<p>of the goode syde, <i>that is to seyn, of my richesses and prosperites</i>;</p>
<p>and what eek if I ne be nat al departed fro thee? What eek</p>
<p>yif my mutabilitee yiveth thee rightful cause of hope to han yit</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">beter thinges? Natheles dismaye thee nat in thy thought; and</p>
<p>thou that art put in the comune <a href="#BIIPIINL61" id="BIIPIIL61" class="pginternal">realme</a> of alle, ne
    desyre nat to</p>
<p>liven by thyn only propre right.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. II.</span> 3. C. makes; A. makest. 4. A. wronges (Lat.
  <i>iniuriam</i>). 5. C. pleten; A. plete (Lat. <i>contende</i>). 8. C. reseyued. // C. tho; A.
  these. 9. C. thykke; A. thilke. 11. C. browht; A. brouȝt. // C. resseyued. 12. A. al thing.
  // C. noryssede; A. norysshed. 13. C. fauor; A. fauo<i>ur</i>. 19. A. vtterly lorn. 20. C.
  pleynes. 25. C. I shal; A. Shal I. // C. deffendyd. 28. C. coeueryn; A. keuere (<i>better</i>
  coveren). // C. dirk; A. derke. 29. C. apayrelyn; A. apparaile. 30. C. frut; A. fruyt. 32. C.
  kalm; A. calme. // C. blawndyssynge; A. blaundyshing. 33. C. <i>om. 2nd</i> with. 35. C.
  stidefast; A. stedfast. <i>So</i> stide(sted-)fastnesse. 41. C. dessende. // A. dou<i>n</i>. // A.
  <i>om.</i> the. 42. C. wistesthow; A. Wost thou (Lat. <i>Nesciebas</i>). // A. <i>om.</i> the. 44.
  C. kawth; A. cauȝt. 45. C. dessendede; A. descended. 48. C. kapteuite; A. captiuitee. // C.
  thinge; A. thinges. 49. C. cryenges; A. criinges. 50. A. the realmes; C. <i>om.</i> the. // C.
  noblye; A. nobley. 54. A. seler. // C. cowched; A. couched (Lat. <i>iacere</i>). 56. C. hasthow.
  57. A. rycchesse. 58. A. <i>om.</i> be <i>and</i> al. 59. C. yeueth; A. ȝiueth. 60. A.
  desmaye. 61. A. <i>om.</i> the. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre II.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Si quantas rapidis flatibus incitus.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Though Plentee, <i>that is goddesse of richesses</i>, <a href="#BIIMIINL1" id="BIIMIIL1" class="pginternal">hielde</a> adoun</p>
<p>with ful horn, and withdraweth nat hir hand, as many richesses</p>
<p>as the see torneth upward sandes whan it is moeved with</p>
<p>ravisshinge blastes, or elles as many richesses as ther shynen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">brighte sterres on hevene on the sterry nightes; yit, for al</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page29">{29}</span>that, mankinde nolde not cese to wepe wrecchede
    pleyntes.</p>
<p>And al be it so that god receyveth gladly hir preyers, and</p>
<p>yiveth them (<a href="#BIIMIINL8" id="BIIMIIL8" class="pginternal">as fool-large</a>) moche gold, and aparaileth
    coveitous</p>
<p>men with noble or clere honours: yit semeth hem haven y-geten</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">no-thing, but alwey hir cruel ravyne, devouringe al that they</p>
<p>han geten, sheweth other <a href="#BIIMIINL11" id="BIIMIIL11" class="pginternal">gapinges</a>; <i>that is to
    seyn, gapen and</i></p>
<p><i>desyren yit after mo richesses</i>. What brydles mighten withholden,</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMIINL13" id="BIIMIIL13" class="pginternal">to any certein ende</a>, the desordenee covetise of men,
    whan,</p>
<p>ever the rather that it fleteth in large yiftes, the more ay brenneth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">in hem the thurst of havinge? Certes he that, quakinge and</p>
<p>dredful, weneth him-selven nedy, he ne liveth never-more riche."</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. II.</span> 1. A. rycche. // <i>Both</i> hielde; Ed. hylde. 2.
  A. recches(!). 4. C. rauyssynge. // A. rycches. 5. A. nyȝt (Lat. <i>noctibus</i>). 6. C.
  plentes; A. pleyntes. 7. C. resseyueth. // C. preyres; A. p<i>ra</i>yers. 8. C. A. yeueth. // A.
  ful (<i>for</i> fool). 9. A. folk (<i>for</i> men). 10. C. thinge; A. thing. // C. crewel. 12. A.
  rycchesse. 15. A. threst. 16. C. leueth; A. lyueth. // A. -mo. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose III.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Hiis igitur si pro se tecum Fortuna loqueretur.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Therfor, yif that Fortune spake with thee for hir-self in this</p>
<p>manere, for-sothe thou ne haddest nat what thou mightest answere.</p>
<p>And, if thou hast any-thing wherwith, thou mayest rightfully defenden</p>
<p>thy compleint, it behoveth thee to shewen it; and I wol</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">yeven thee space to tellen it.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certeynly,' quod I thanne, 'thise beth faire thinges, and</p>
<p>enointed with hony swetenesse of rethorike and musike; and</p>
<p>only whyl they ben herd they ben delicious. But to wrecches is</p>
<p>a depper felinge of harm; <i>this is to seyn, that wrecches felen the</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>harmes that they suffren more grevously than the remedies or the</i></p>
<p><i>delites of thise wordes mowen gladen or comforten hem</i>; so that,</p>
<p>whan thise thinges stinten for to soune in eres, the sorwe that is</p>
<p>inset greveth the thought.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Right so is it,' quod she. 'For thise ne ben yit none remedies</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of thy maladye; but they ben a maner norisshinges of thy sorwe,</p>
<p>yit rebel ayein thy curacioun.  For whan that tyme is, I shal</p>
<p>moeve swiche thinges that percen hem-self depe. But natheles,</p>
<p>that thou shalt not wilne to leten thy-self a wrecche, hast thou</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page30">{30}</span>foryeten the noumber and the manere of thy
    welefulnesse? I</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">holde me stille, how that the soverayne men of the citee token</p>
<p>thee in cure and kepinge, whan thou were orphelin of fader and</p>
<p>moder, and were chosen in affinitee of <a href="#BIIPIIINL22" id="BIIPIIIL22" class="pginternal">princes</a> of
    the citee; and</p>
<p>thou bigunne rather to be <a href="#BIIPIIINL23" id="BIIPIIIL23" class="pginternal">leef</a> and dere than forto
    ben a neighbour;</p>
<p>the whiche thing is the most precious kinde of any propinquitee</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">or alyaunce that may ben. Who is it that ne seide tho</p>
<p>that thou were right weleful, with so grete a nobleye of thy fadres-in-lawe,</p>
<p>and with the chastitee of thy wyf, and with the oportunitee</p>
<p>and noblesse of thy masculin children, <i>that is to seyn, thy sones</i>?</p>
<p>And over al this—me list to passen the comune thinges—how</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thou haddest in thy youthe dignitees that weren werned to olde</p>
<p>men. But it delyteth me to comen now to the singuler uphepinge</p>
<p>of thy welefulnesse. Yif any fruit of mortal thinges may han any</p>
<p>weighte or prys of welefulnesse, mightest thou ever foryeten, for</p>
<p>any charge of harm that mighte bifalle, the remembraunce of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thilke day that thou saye thy two sones maked conseileres, and</p>
<p>y-lad to-gedere fro thyn house under so greet assemblee of</p>
<p>senatoures and under the blythenesse of poeple; and whan thou</p>
<p>saye hem set in the court in here chayeres of dignitees? Thou,</p>
<p>rethorien or pronouncere of kinges preysinges, deservedest glorie</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of wit and of eloquence, <a href="#BIIPIIINL40" id="BIIPIIIL40" class="pginternal">whan thou</a>,
    sittinge bitwene thy two sones,</p>
<p>conseileres, in the place that highte Circo, fulfuldest the abydinge</p>
<p>of the multitude of poeple that was sprad abouten thee, with so large</p>
<p>preysinge and laude, as men singen in victories. Tho yave thou</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIINL43" id="BIIPIIIL43" class="pginternal">wordes</a> to Fortune, as I trowe, <i>that is to seyn,
    tho feffedest thou</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>Fortune with glosinge wordes and deceivedest hir</i>, whan she acoyede</p>
<p>thee and norisshede thee as hir owne delyces. Thou bere away of</p>
<p>Fortune a yifte, <i>that is to seyn, swiche guerdoun</i>, that she never yaf</p>
<p>to <a href="#BIIPIIINL48" id="BIIPIIIL48" class="pginternal">privee</a> man. Wilt thou therfor leye a rekeninge
    with Fortune?</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page31">{31}</span>She hath now twinkled first upon thee with a
    wikkede eye. Yif</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thou considere the noumbre and the manere of thy blisses and</p>
<p>of thy sorwes, thou mayst nat forsaken that thou art yit blisful.</p>
<p>For if thou therfor wenest thy-self nat weleful, for thinges that</p>
<p>tho semeden ioyful ben passed, ther nis nat why thou sholdest wene</p>
<p>thy-self a wrecche; for thinges that semen now sorye passen also.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">55</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><a href="#BIIPIIINL55" id="BIIPIIIL55" class="pginternal">Art thou</a> now comen first, a
    sodein gest, in-to the shadwe or</p>
<p>tabernacle of this lyf; or trowest thou that any stedefastnesse be</p>
<p>in mannes thinges, whan ofte a swift houre dissolveth the same</p>
<p>man; <i>that is to seyn, whan the soule departeth fro the body</i>? For,</p>
<p>al-though that selde is ther any feith that fortunous thinges wolen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">dwellen, yit natheles the <a href="#BIIPIIINL60" id="BIIPIIIL60" class="pginternal">laste day</a>
    of a mannes lyf is a manere</p>
<p>deeth to Fortune, <a href="#BIIPIIINL61" id="BIIPIIIL61" class="pginternal">and also</a> to thilke that hath
    dwelt. And therfor,</p>
<p>what, wenestow, <a href="#BIIPIIINL62" id="BIIPIIIL62" class="pginternal">thar [thee] recche, yif thou</a>
    forlete hir in deyinge,</p>
<p>or elles that she, <i>Fortune</i>, forlete thee in fleeinge awey?</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. III.</span> 2. A. <i>om.</i> nat. 4. A. tellen (<i>for</i>
  defenden). 6. C. bet (<i>for</i> beth); A. ben. 8. C. delysyos; A. deliciouse. 15. C. maledye. //
  C. noryssynges; A. norissinges. // C. sorwes; A. sorwe (Lat. <i>doloris</i>). 17. C. swych; A.
  swiche. 20. C. souerane; A. souerayn. 23. C. begunne; A. bygunne. 24. C. neysshebo<i>ur</i>; A.
  neyȝbo<i>ur</i>. // C. presyous. 26. A. <i>om.</i> tho that. // A. nere (<i>for</i> were).
  // C. fadyris. 27. C. castete; A. chastite. 29. C. lyste; A. lyst. // C. the; A. of. 30. A.
  thought (<i>for</i> youthe); Ed. youthe. 32. C. wel-; A. wele-. // C. frute; A. fruyt. 36. C. A
  semble; A. Ed. assemble. 37. C. peeple; A. poeple. 39. C. des-; A. de-. 40. C. bitwyen; A. bytwix;
  Ed. bytwene. 41. C. hihte; A. hyȝt. // C. A. Ed. <i>all insert</i> and <i>before</i>
  fulfuldest; <i>I omit it, because it obscures the sense</i>. 42. A. <i>om.</i> the <i>and</i> so.
  44. C. to; A. of. 45. <i>So</i> Ed.; C. A. desseiuedest. 46. C. noryssede; A. norsshed; Ed.
  norisshed. // A. hast had (<i>for</i> bere away). // C. bar. 47. C. A. gerdoun; Ed. guerdon. 48.
  C. lye; A. leye; Ed. laye (Lat. <i>ponere</i>). 49. C. <i>om.</i> a. 50. C. blysse
  (<i>wrongly</i>); A. Ed. blisses. 51. C. art; A. Ed. nart. // C. blysse-; A. blys-. 53. C. the; A.
  tho (Lat. <i>tunc</i>). 57. C. dyssoluede; A. Ed. dissolueth. 59. C. al that thowgh; A. Ed.
  although that. // Ed. selde; C. ȝelde (= zelde); A. yelde (= ȝelde); Lat.
  <i>rara</i>. // C. fortune; A. Ed. fortunous. 62: C. weenestow; A. wenest thou. // C. dar; A.
  thar. // <i>I supply</i> thee. // C. recke; A. recche. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre III.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Cum polo Phebus roseis quadrigis.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Whan Phebus, the sonne, biginneth to spreden his cleernesse</p>
<p>with rosene chariettes, thanne the sterre, y-dimmed, paleth hir</p>
<p>whyte cheres, by the flambes of the sonne that overcometh the</p>
<p>sterre-light. <i>This is to seyn, whan the sonne is risen, the dey-sterre</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>wexeth pale, and leseth hir light for the grete brightnesse of the</i></p>
<p><i>sonne.</i></p>
<p class="stanza">Whan the wode wexeth rody of rosene floures, in the first somer</p>
<p>sesoun, thorugh the brethe of the winde Zephirus that wexeth</p>
<p>warm, yif the cloudy wind Auster blowe felliche, than goth awey</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIIMIIINL10" id="BIIMIIIL10" class="pginternal">the fairenesse</a> of thornes.</p>
<p class="stanza">Ofte the see is cleer and calm withoute moevinge flodes; and</p>
<p>ofte the horrible wind Aquilon moeveth boilinge tempestes and</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMIIINL13" id="BIIMIIIL13" class="pginternal">over-whelveth</a> the see.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page32">{32}</span>Yif the forme of this worlde is
    so selde stable, and yif it turneth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">by so many entrechaunginges, wolt thou thanne trusten in the</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMIIINL16" id="BIIMIIIL16" class="pginternal">tomblinge</a> fortunes of men? Wolt thou trowen on
    flittinge goodes?</p>
<p>It is certein and establisshed by lawe perdurable, that no-thing that</p>
<p>is engendred <a href="#BIIMIIINL18" id="BIIMIIIL18" class="pginternal">nis</a> stedefast ne stable.'</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. III.</span> 1. C. hyr; A. Ed. his. 2. C. palyt. 3. A. flamus.
  7. C. rosyn; A. rosene. 9. C. A. wynde. 10. C. thornesse. 11. C. floedes. 13. Ed. -whelueth; C.
  -welueeth; A. -whelweth. 14. Ed. selde; C. ȝeelde (= zeelde); A. <i>om.</i> (Lat.
  <i>rara</i>). 15. C. wolthow; A. Ed. wilt thou. 16. C. towmblynge; Ed. tomblyng; A. trublynge
  (Lat. <i>caducis</i>). // C. wolthow; A. Ed. wilt thou. // C. Ed. on; A. in. // C. flettynge; A.
  flittyng. 17. C. is it; A. It is. // C. A. establyssed; Ed. establysshed. // C. thinge; A. thing.
  18. C. estable; A. stable. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose IV.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Tunc ego, uera, inquam, commemoras.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Thanne seide I thus: 'O norice of alle vertues, thou seist ful</p>
<p>sooth; ne I ne may nat forsake the right swifte cours of my</p>
<p>prosperitee; <i>that is to seyn, that prosperitee <a href="#BIIPIVNL3" id="BIIPIVL3" class="pginternal">ne be
    comen</a> to me</i></p>
<p><i>wonder swiftly and sone</i>. But this is a thing that greetly smerteth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">me whan it remembreth me. <a href="#BIIPIVNL5" id="BIIPIVL5" class="pginternal">For in alle</a>
    adversitee of fortune,</p>
<p>the most unsely kinde of contrarious fortune is to han ben</p>
<p>weleful.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#BIIPIVNL8" id="BIIPIVL8" class="pginternal">'But that thou,'</a> quod she, 'abyest thus
    the torment of thy</p>
<p>false opinioun, that mayst thou nat rightfully blamen ne aretten</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to thinges: <i>as who seith, for thou hast yit many habundaunces of</i></p>
<p><i>thinges</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza"><b>Text.</b> <a href="#BIIPIVNL12" id="BIIPIVL12" class="pginternal">For al be it</a> so that the
    ydel name of aventurous</p>
<p>welefulnesse moeveth thee now, it is leveful that thou rekne with</p>
<p>me of how manye grete thinges thou hast yit plentee. And</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">therfor, yif that thilke thing that thou haddest for most precious</p>
<p>in al thy richesse of fortune be kept to thee yit, by the grace of</p>
<p>god, unwemmed and undefouled, mayst thou thanne pleyne</p>
<p>rightfully upon the meschef of Fortune, sin thou hast yit thy</p>
<p>beste thinges? Certes, yit liveth in good point thilke precious</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">honour of mankinde, <a href="#BIIPIVNL20" id="BIIPIVL20" class="pginternal">Symacus</a>, thy wyves
    fader, which that is</p>
<p>a man maked alle of sapience and of vertu; the whiche man</p>
<p>thou woldest byen redely with the prys of thyn owne lyf. He</p>
<p>biwayleth the wronges that men don to thee, and nat for him-self;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page33">{33}</span>for he liveth in sikernesse of any sentences put
    ayeins him. And</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">yit liveth <a href="#BIIPIVNL25" id="BIIPIVL25" class="pginternal">thy wyf</a>, that is atempre of
    wit, and passinge other</p>
<p>wimmen in clennesse of chastetee; and for I wol closen shortely</p>
<p>hir bountees, she is lyk to hir fader.  I telle thee wel, that she</p>
<p>liveth looth of this lyf, and kepeth to thee only hir goost; and is</p>
<p>al maat and overcomen by wepinge and sorwe for desyr of thee,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">in the whiche thing only I moot graunten that thy welefulnesse is</p>
<p>amenused. What shal I seyn eek of thy <a href="#BIIPIVNL31" id="BIIPIVL31" class="pginternal">two sones,
    conseilours</a>,</p>
<p>of whiche, as of children of hir age, ther shyneth the lyknesse of</p>
<p>the wit of hir fader or of hir elder fader? And sin the sovereyn</p>
<p>cure of alle mortel folk is to saven hir owen lyves, O how weleful</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">art thou, yif thou knowe thy goodes! For yit ben ther</p>
<p>thinges dwelled to thee-ward, that no man douteth that they ne</p>
<p>ben more dereworthe to thee than thyn owen lyf. And for-thy</p>
<p>drye thy teres, for yit nis nat everich fortune al hateful to thee-ward,</p>
<p>ne over greet tempest hath nat yit fallen upon thee, whan</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that <a href="#BIIPIVNL40" id="BIIPIVL40" class="pginternal">thyn ancres</a> cleven faste, that
    neither wolen suffren the</p>
<p>counfort of this tyme present ne the hope of tyme cominge to</p>
<p>passen ne to faylen.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'And I preye,' quod I, 'that faste moten they halden; for</p>
<p>whyles that they halden, how-so-ever that thinges ben, I shal wel</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">fleten forth and escapen; but thou mayst wel seen how grete</p>
<p>aparayles and aray that me lakketh, that ben passed away fro</p>
<p>me.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'I have som-what avaunsed and forthered thee,' quod she, 'yif</p>
<p>that thou anoye nat or forthinke nat of al thy fortune: <i>as who</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>seith, I have som-what comforted thee, so that thou tempest thee nat</i></p>
<p><i>thus with al thy fortune, sin thou hast yit thy beste thinges</i>. But</p>
<p>I may nat suffren <a href="#BIIPIVNL52" id="BIIPIVL52" class="pginternal">thy delices</a>, that pleynest so
    wepinge and</p>
<p>anguissous, for that ther lakketh som-what to thy welefulnesse.</p>
<p>For what man is so sad or of so parfit welefulnesse, that he ne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">stryveth and pleyneth on som halve ayen the qualitee of his</p>
<p>estat? For-why ful <a href="#BIIPIVNL56" id="BIIPIVL56" class="pginternal">anguissous</a> thing is the
    condicioun of mannes</p>
<p>goodes; for either it cometh nat al-togider to a wight, or elles it</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page34">{34}</span>last nat perpetuel. For sum man hath grete
    richesses, but he is</p>
<p>ashamed of his ungentel linage; and som is renowned of noblesse</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of kinrede, but he is enclosed in so grete anguisshe of nede</p>
<p>of thinges, that him were lever that he were unknowe. And</p>
<p>som man haboundeth both in richesse and noblesse, but yit he</p>
<p>bewaileth his chaste lyf, for he ne hath no wyf. And som man is</p>
<p>wel and selily y-maried, but he hath no children, and norissheth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">his richesses to the eyres of strange folkes. And som man is</p>
<p>gladed with children, but he wepeth ful sory for the trespas of</p>
<p>his sone or of his doughter. And for this ther ne acordeth no</p>
<p>wight lightly to the condicioun of his fortune; <a href="#BIIPIVNL68" id="BIIPIVL68" class="pginternal">for
    alwey</a> to every</p>
<p>man ther is in som-what that, unassayed, he ne wot nat; or elles</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">he dredeth that he hath assayed. And adde this also, that every</p>
<p>weleful man hath a ful delicat felinge; so that, but-yif alle thinges</p>
<p>bifalle at his owne wil, for he is impacient, or is nat used to han</p>
<p>non adversitee, anon he is throwen adoun for every litel thing.</p>
<p>And ful litel thinges ben tho that withdrawen the somme or the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">perfeccioun of blisfulnesse fro hem that ben most fortunat. How</p>
<p>many men, trowest thou, wolden demen hem-self to ben almost in</p>
<p>hevene, yif they mighten atayne to the leest party of the remnaunt</p>
<p>of thy fortune? This same place that thou clepest exil, is</p>
<p>contree to hem that enhabiten heer, and forthy <a href="#BIIPIVNL79" id="BIIPIVL79" class="pginternal">nothing
    [is]</a></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">wrecched but whan thou wenest it: <i>as who seith, thou thy-self, ne</i></p>
<p><i>no wight elles, nis a wrecche, but whan he weneth him-self a wrecche</i></p>
<p><i>by reputacioun of his corage</i>. And ayeinward, alle fortune is blisful</p>
<p>to a man by the <a href="#BIIPIVNL83" id="BIIPIVL83" class="pginternal">agreabletee</a> or by the egalitee of
    him that</p>
<p>suffreth it.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">85</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">What man is that, that is so weleful, that nolde changen his</p>
<p>estat whan he hath lost pacience? The <a href="#BIIPIVNL86" id="BIIPIVL86" class="pginternal">swetnesse</a> of
    mannes</p>
<p>welefulnesse is sprayned with many biternesses; the whiche welefulnesse,</p>
<p>al-though it seme swete and ioyful to hem that useth it,</p>
<p>yit may it nat ben <a href="#BIIPIVNL89" id="BIIPIVL89" class="pginternal">with-holden</a> that it ne goth away
    whan it wole.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page35">{35}</span>Thanne is it wel sene, how
    wrecched is the blisfulnesse of mortal</p>
<p>thinges, that neither it dureth perpetuel with hem that every</p>
<p>fortune receiven agreablely or egaly, ne it delyteth nat in al to</p>
<p>hem that ben anguissous. O ye mortal folk, what seke ye thanne</p>
<p>blisfulnesse out of your-self, whiche that is put in your-self?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Errour and folye confoundeth yow.</p>
<p class="stanza">I shal shewe thee shortely the poynt of sovereyne blisfulnesse.</p>
<p>Is ther any-thing more precious to thee than thy-self? Thou</p>
<p>wolt answere, "nay." Thanne, yif it so be that thou art mighty</p>
<p>over thy-self, <i>that is to seyn, by tranquillitee of thy sowle</i>, than hast</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thou thing in thy power that thou noldest never lesen, ne Fortune</p>
<p>ne may nat beneme it thee. And that thou mayst knowe that</p>
<p>blisfulnesse ne may nat standen in thinges that ben fortunous</p>
<p>and temporel, now understonde and gader it to-gidere thus:</p>
<p>Yif blisfulnesse be the sovereyn good of nature that liveth by</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">resoun, ne thilke thing nis nat sovereyn good that may be taken</p>
<p>awey in any wyse, (for more worthy thing and more digne is</p>
<p>thilke thing that may nat ben taken awey); than <a href="#BIIPIVNL107" id="BIIPIVL107" class="pginternal">sheweth it wel</a>,</p>
<p>that the unstablenesse of fortune may nat atayne to receiven</p>
<p>verray blisfulnesse. And yit more-over: what man that this</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">toumbling welefulnesse ledeth, <a href="#BIIPIVNL110" id="BIIPIVL110" class="pginternal">either he
    woot</a> that it is chaungeable,</p>
<p>or elles he woot it nat. And yif he woot it nat, what blisful</p>
<p>fortune may ther be in the blindnesse of ignorance? And yif he</p>
<p>woot that it is chaungeable, he moot alwey ben adrad that he ne</p>
<p>lese that thing that he ne doubteth nat but that he may lesen it;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>as who seith, he mot ben alwey agast, <a href="#BIIPIVNL115" id="BIIPIVL115" class="pginternal">lest he lese that</a> he wot wel he</i></p>
<p><i>may lese it</i>. For which, the continuel dreed that he hath ne</p>
<p>suffreth him nat to ben weleful. Or yif he lese it, he weneth to</p>
<p>be dispysed and forleten. Certes eek, that is a ful litel good that</p>
<p>is born with evene herte whan it is lost; <i><a href="#BIIPIVNL119" id="BIIPIVL119" class="pginternal">that is
    to seyn, that men</a></i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">120</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>do no more fors of the <a href="#BIIPIVNL120" id="BIIPIVL120" class="pginternal">lost</a> than
    of the havinge</i>. And for as moche</p>
<p>as thou thy-self art he, to whom it hath ben shewed and proved</p>
<p>by ful manye demonstraciouns, as I wot wel, that the sowles of</p>
<p>men ne mowe nat deyen in no wyse; and eek sin it is cleer and</p>
<p>certein, that fortunous welefulnesse endeth by the deeth of the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page36">{36}</span>body; it may nat ben douted that,
    yif that deeth may take awey</p>
<p>blisfulnesse, that alle the kinde of mortal thinges ne descendeth</p>
<p>in-to wrecchednesse by the ende of the deeth. And sin we knowen</p>
<p>wel, that many a man hath sought the fruit of blisfulnesse nat</p>
<p>only with suffringe of deeth, but eek with suffringe of peynes and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">tormentes; how mighte than this present lyf maken men blisful,</p>
<p>sin that, whan thilke selve lyf is ended, it ne <a href="#BIIPIVNL131" id="BIIPIVL131" class="pginternal">maketh</a> folk no</p>
<p>wrecches?</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. IV.</span> 1. C. vertuus; A. vertues. 4. C. <i>om.</i> a. 6.
  C. vnȝely (= vnzely); A. Ed. vnsely. 8. A. abaist (!). // C. tormentz; A. to<i>ur</i>ment
  (Lat. <i>supplicium</i>). 10. C. -daunce; A. Ed. -daunces. 13. C. leefful; A. leueful. 15. C.
  thinge; A. thing. 19. C. leueth; A. lyueth. 21. C. <i>om. 2nd</i> of. 24. C. leueth; A. liueth.
  29. C. maad; A. maat; Ed. mate. 30. C. thinge; A. thing. 31. C. amenyssed; A. Ed. amenused. 32. C.
  lyke-; A. lyk-. 33. A. Ed. eldefadir. 35. A. But (<i>for</i> For). 36. <i>So</i> C. Ed.; A.
  dwelly<i>n</i>g. // A. -wardes. 40. A. cliue. 42. A. fallen. 43. A. holden. 44. C. A. halden. 45.
  C. mayste. 49. A. forthenke. 52. C. delites (?); A. Ed. delices (Lat. <i>delicias</i>). 55. C. Ed.
  and; A. or. 57. A. <i>om.</i> nat. 58. A. lasteth. // A. p<i>er</i>petuely. // A. rycchesse. 59.
  A. renomed. 60. anguisshe of] A. angre for. 63. Ed. chaste; C. caste; A. chast. 64. C. zelyly; A.
  Ed. selily. // C. hat. // C. noriseth; A. norissheth. 66. C. A. sory; Ed. sore. 69. A. is in mest
  som-what. 71. A. wel (<i>for</i> ful). 72. Ed. is; C. A. <i>om.</i> 77. A. remenaunt. 79. <i>I
  supply</i> is; Lat. nihil <i>est</i> miserum. 80. C. ho; A. who. 81. A. no (<i>for</i> a). 83. C.
  egreablete; A. agreablete. 86. C. what (!); A. whan. // C. lost; A. lorn. 87. C. sprayngd (!); A.

  92. C. resseyuen; A. receyuen. 100, 106. C. thinge; A. thing. 101. A. bynyme. 102. A. <i>om.</i>
  ne. 107. C. take; A. taken. 108. C. resseyuen; A. receyue. 110. A. <i>om.</i> it. 115. C. list; A.
  lest. 116. A. <i>om.</i> it. 118. A. forleten hit. 120. C. A. lost; Ed. losse. // C. meche
