<h3> <span class="sc">Metre IV.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quisquis uolet perennem Cautus ponere sedem.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>What maner man, stable and war, that wole founden him</p>
<p>a perdurable sete, and ne wole nat ben cast down with the loude</p>
<p>blastes of the wind Eurus; and wole despyse the see, manasinge</p>
<p>with flodes; lat him eschewen to bilde on the cop of the mountaigne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">or in the moiste sandes. For the felle wind Auster</p>
<p>tormenteth the cop of the mountaigne with all his strengthes;</p>
<p>and the <a href="#BIIMIVNL7" id="BIIMIVL7" class="pginternal">lause</a> sandes refusen to beren the hevy
    wighte.</p>
<p class="stanza">And <a href="#BIIMIVNL8" id="BIIMIVL8" class="pginternal">forthy, if thou</a> wolt fleen the
    perilous aventure, <i>that is to</i></p>
<p><i>seyn, of the worlde</i>; have minde certeinly to ficchen thyn hous of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">a merye site in a lowe stoon. For al-though the wind, troubling</p>
<p>the see, thondre with over-throwinges, thou that art put in quiete,</p>
<p>and <a href="#BIIMIVNL12" id="BIIMIVL12" class="pginternal">weleful</a> by strengthe of thy palis, shalt leden a
    cleer age,</p>
<p>scorninge the woodnesses and the ires of the eyr.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. IV.</span> 1. C. waar. 7. Ed. lose; A. lowe see(!); (Lat.
  <i>solutae</i>). // A. weyȝte. 10. C. lowh; A. Ed. lowe. 12. C. A. palys (Lat.
  <i>ualli</i>). </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose V.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Set cum rationum iam in te.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>But for as moche as the norisshinges of my resouns descenden</p>
<p>now in-to thee, I trowe it were tyme to usen a litel strenger</p>
<p>medicynes. Now understond heer, al were it so that the yiftes of</p>
<p>Fortune ne were nat brutel ne transitorie, what is ther in hem</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page37">{37}</span>that may be thyn in any tyme, or
    elles that it nis foul, yif that it</p>
<p>be considered and loked perfitly? Richesses, ben they precious</p>
<p>by the nature of hem-self, or elles by the nature of thee? What is</p>
<p>most worth of richesses? Is it nat gold or might of moneye</p>
<p>assembled? Certes, thilke gold and thilke moneye shyneth and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">yeveth betere renoun <a href="#BIIPVNL10" id="BIIPVL10" class="pginternal">to hem that despenden
    it</a> thanne to thilke</p>
<p>folk that <a href="#BIIPVNL11" id="BIIPVL11" class="pginternal">mokeren it</a>; for avarice maketh alwey
    mokereres to ben</p>
<p>hated, and largesse maketh folk cleer of renoun. For sin that</p>
<p>swich thing as is transferred fram o man to another ne may nat</p>
<p>dwellen with no man; certes, thanne is thilke moneye precious</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">whan it is translated into other folk and <a href="#BIIPVNL15" id="BIIPVL15" class="pginternal">stenteth to ben had</a>, by</p>
<p>usage of <a href="#BIIPVNL16" id="BIIPVL16" class="pginternal">large</a> yevinge <i>of him that hath yeven
    it</i>. And also: yif</p>
<p>that al the moneye that is over-al in the worlde were gadered</p>
<p>toward o man, it sholde maken alle other men to ben nedy <a href="#BIIPVNL18" id="BIIPVL18" class="pginternal">as of that</a>.</p>
<p>And certes <a href="#BIIPVNL19" id="BIIPVL19" class="pginternal">a voys al hool</a>, <i>that is to seyn,
    with-oute amenusinge</i>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">fulfilleth to-gidere the hering of moche folk; but certes, youre</p>
<p>richesses ne mowen nat passen in-to moche folke with-oute</p>
<p>amenusinge. And whan they ben apassed, nedes they maken</p>
<p>hem pore that for-gon the richesses.</p>
<p class="stanza">O! streite and nedy clepe I this richesse, sin that many folk</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ne may nat han it al, ne al may it nat comen to o man with-outen</p>
<p>povertee of alle other folk! And the shyninge of gemmes, <i>that</i></p>
<p><i>I clepe precious stones</i>, draweth it nat the eyen of folk to hem-ward,</p>
<p><i>that is to seyn, for the beautee</i>? But certes, yif ther were</p>
<p>beautee or bountee in the shyninge of stones, thilke cleernesse is</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of the stones hem-self, and nat of men; for whiche I wondre</p>
<p>gretly that men mervailen on swiche thinges. For-why, what</p>
<p>thing is it, that <a href="#BIIPVNL32" id="BIIPVL32" class="pginternal">yif it wanteth</a> moeving and Ioynture
    of sowle and</p>
<p>body, that by right mighte semen a fair creature to him that hath</p>
<p>a sowle of resoun? For al be it so that gemmes drawen to hem-self</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">a litel <a href="#BIIPVNL35" id="BIIPVL35" class="pginternal">of the laste</a> beautee of the
    world, through the entente of</p>
<p>hir creatour and <a href="#BIIPVNL36" id="BIIPVL36" class="pginternal">through the distinccioun</a> of hem-self;
    yit, for as</p>
<p>mochel as they ben put under youre excellence, they ne han nat</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page38">{38}</span>deserved by no wey that ye sholden mervailen on
    hem. And</p>
<p>the beautee of feldes, delyteth it nat mochel un-to yow?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">40</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><i>Boece.</i> '<a href="#BIIPVNL40" id="BIIPVL40" class="pginternal">Why sholde it nat</a>
    delyten us, sin that it is a right fair</p>
<p>porcioun of the right faire werke, <i>that is to seyn, of this world</i>?</p>
<p>And right so ben we gladed som-tyme of the face of the see</p>
<p>whan it is cleer; and also mervailen we on the hevene and on the</p>
<p>sterres, and on the sonne and on the mone.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">45</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><i>Philosophye.</i> 'Aperteneth,' quod she, 'any of thilke thinges
    to</p>
<p>thee? Why darst thou glorifyen thee in the shyninge of any</p>
<p>swiche thinges? Art thou distingwed and embelised by the</p>
<p>springinge floures of the first somer sesoun, or swelleth thy</p>
<p>plentee in the fruites of somer? Why art thou ravisshed with</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ydel Ioyes? Why embracest thou straunge goodes as they weren</p>
<p>thyne? Fortune ne shal never maken that swiche thinges ben</p>
<p>thyne, that nature of thinges hath maked foreine fro thee. Sooth</p>
<p>is that, with-outen doute, the frutes of the erthe owen to ben to</p>
<p>the norissinge of bestes. And yif thou wolt fulfille thy nede after</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that it suffyseth to nature, than is it no nede that thou seke after</p>
<p>the superfluitee of fortune. For with ful fewe things and with ful</p>
<p>litel thinges nature halt hir apayed; and yif thou wolt achoken</p>
<p>the fulfillinge of nature with superfluitees, certes, thilke thinges</p>
<p>that thou wolt thresten or pouren in-to nature shullen ben unioyful</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to thee, or elles anoyous. Wenest thou eek that it be a fair</p>
<p>thing to shyne with dyverse clothinge? Of whiche clothinge yif</p>
<p>the beautee be agreeable to loken up-on, I wol mervailen on the</p>
<p>nature of the matere of thilke clothes, or elles on the werkman</p>
<p>that wroughte hem. But also a long route of meynee, maketh</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that a blisful man? The whiche servants, yif they ben vicious of</p>
<p>condiciouns, it is a great charge and a distruccioun to the hous,</p>
<p>and a greet enemy to the lord him-self. And yif they ben goode</p>
<p>men, how shal straunge or foreine goodnesse ben put in the</p>
<p>noumbre of thy richesse? So that, by all these forseide thinges,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">it is clearly y-shewed, that never oon of thilke thinges that thou</p>
<p>acountedest for thyne goodes nas nat thy good. In the whiche</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page39">{39}</span>thinges, yif ther be no beautee to ben desyred,
    why sholdest thou</p>
<p>ben sory yif thou lese hem, or why sholdest thou reioysen thee</p>
<p>to holden hem? For yif they ben faire of hir owne kinde, what</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">aperteneth that to thee? For al so wel sholden they han ben</p>
<p>faire by hem-selve, though they weren departed fram alle thyne</p>
<p>richesses. Forwhy faire ne precious ne weren they nat, for that</p>
<p>they comen among thy richesses; but, for they semeden faire and</p>
<p>precious, ther-for thou haddest lever rekne hem amonges thy</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">richesses.</p>
<p class="stanza">But what desirest thou of Fortune with so grete a noise, and</p>
<p>with so grete a fare? I trowe thou seke to dryve awey nede with</p>
<p>habundaunce of thinges; but certes, it torneth to you al in the</p>
<p>contrarie. Forwhy certes, it nedeth of ful manye helpinges to</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">85</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">kepen the diversitee of precious <a href="#BIIPVNL85" id="BIIPVL85" class="pginternal">ostelments</a>. And sooth it is,</p>
<p>that of manye thinges han they nede that manye thinges han; and</p>
<p>ayeinward, of litel nedeth hem that mesuren hir fille after the nede</p>
<p>of kinde, and nat after the outrage of coveityse. Is it thanne so,</p>
<p>that ye men ne han no proper good y-set in you, for which</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ye moten seken outward youre goodes in foreine and <a href="#BIIPVNL90" id="BIIPVL90" class="pginternal">subgit</a></p>
<p>thinges? So is thanne the condicioun of thinges torned up-so-down,</p>
<p>that a man, that is a devyne <a href="#BIIPVNL92" id="BIIPVL92" class="pginternal">beest</a> by merite of his
    resoun,</p>
<p>thinketh that him-self nis neither faire ne noble, but-yif it be</p>
<p>thorugh possessioun of ostelments that ne han no sowles. And</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">certes, al other thinges ben apayed of hir owne beautee; but ye</p>
<p>men, that ben semblable to god by your resonable thought,</p>
<p>desiren to aparailen your excellent kinde <a href="#BIIPVNL97" id="BIIPVL97" class="pginternal">of the
    lowest</a> thinges;</p>
<p>ne ye understonden nat how greet a wrong ye don to your</p>
<p>creatour. For he wolde that mankinde were most worthy and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">noble of any othre erthely thinges; and ye threste adoun your</p>
<p>dignitees benethe the lowest thinges. For <a href="#BIIPVNL101" id="BIIPVL101" class="pginternal">yif that
    al</a> the good of</p>
<p>every thinge be more precious than is thilke thing whos that</p>
<p>the good is: sin ye demen that the fouleste thinges ben youre</p>
<p>goodes, thanne submitten ye and putten your-selven under tho</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">fouleste thinges by your estimacioun; <a href="#BIIPVNL105" id="BIIPVL105" class="pginternal">and
    certes</a>, this tydeth nat</p>
<p>with-oute youre desertes. For certes, swiche is the condicioun of</p>
<p>alle mankinde, that only whan it hath knowinge of it-selve, than</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page40">{40}</span>passeth it in noblesse alle other thinges; and
    whan it forleteth the</p>
<p>knowinge of it-self, than is it brought binethen alle beestes. For-why</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">al other livinge beestes han of kinde to knowe nat hem-self;</p>
<p>but whan that men leten the knowinge of hemself, <a href="#BIIPVNL111" id="BIIPVL111" class="pginternal">it
    cometh</a> hem</p>
<p>of vice. But how brode sheweth the errour and the folye of yow</p>
<p>men, that wenen that any thing may ben aparailed with straunge</p>
<p>aparailements! But for sothe that may nat ben doon. For yif</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">a wight shyneth with thinges that ben put to him, <i>as thus, if</i></p>
<p><i>thilke thinges shynen with which a man is aparailed</i>, certes, thilke</p>
<p>thinges ben comended and preysed with which he is aparailed;</p>
<p>but natheles, the thing that is covered and wrapped under that</p>
<p>dwelleth in his filthe.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">120</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">And I denye that thilke thing be good that anoyeth him that</p>
<p>hath it. <a href="#BIIPVNL121" id="BIIPVL121" class="pginternal">Gabbe I of this?</a>. Thou wolt seye "nay."
    Certes,</p>
<p>richesses han anoyed ful ofte hem that han tho richesses; sin that</p>
<p>every wikked shrewe, (and for his wikkednesse the more gredy</p>
<p>after other folkes richesses, wher-so ever it be in any place, be it</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">gold or precious stones), <a href="#BIIPVNL125" id="BIIPVL125" class="pginternal">weneth</a> him
    only most worthy that hath</p>
<p>hem. Thou thanne, that so bisy dredest now the swerd and now</p>
<p>the spere, yif thou haddest entred in the path of this lyf a voide</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVNL128" id="BIIPVL128" class="pginternal">wayferinge</a> man, than woldest thou singe beforn the
    theef; <i>as</i></p>
<p><i>who seith, a pore man, that berth no richesse on him by the weye,</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>may boldely <a href="#BIIPVNL130" id="BIIPVL130" class="pginternal">singe</a> biforn theves,
    for he hath nat wherof to ben</i></p>
<p><i>robbed</i>. O precious and right cleer is the blisfulnesse of mortal</p>
<p>richesses, that, whan thou hast geten it, than hast thou lorn thy</p>
<p>sikernesse!</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. V.</span> 1. C. A. noryssinges; Ed. norisshynges. // C. dess-;
  A. desc-. 6. A. Richesse. 8. A. worthi. // A. rycchesse. // C. <i>om.</i> it. 15. C. stenteth; A.

  thise rycchesses. 25. A. <i>om. 1st</i> ne. 27. A. in-to. 28. C. beautes; A. Ed. beaute. // C.
  But; A. For. 29. A. <i>om.</i> the. 31. C. gretely; A. gretly. 32. C. Ioyngture; A. ioynture. 33.
  C. myht; A. myȝt. 35. C. last; A. laste. 36. C. <i>om.</i> and. 38. C. A. desserued. // A.
  shullen. 41. C. ryhte; A ryȝt. 46. C. darsthow; A. darst thou. 47. C. Arthow; A. Art thou.
  49. A. <i>om.</i> the. // C. fructes; A. fruytes. // C. arthow. // C. rauyssed; A. rauyshed. 52.

  accou<i>m</i>ptedest. 75. A. as (<i>for</i> al-so). 77, 78, 80. A. rycchesse. 90. A. outwardes.
  98. A. ne ye ne, &amp;c. 100. A. Ed. erthely; C. wordly. 103. C. tho; A. the. // C. A. foulest.

<h3> <span class="sc">Metre V.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Felix nimium prior etas.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Blisful was the first age of men! They helden hem apayed</p>
<p>with the metes that the trewe feldes broughten forth. They</p>
<p>ne distroyede nor deceivede nat hem-self with outrage. They</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page41">{41}</span>weren wont lightly to slaken hir hunger at even
    with acornes</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of okes. <a href="#BIIMVNL5" id="BIIMVL5" class="pginternal">They ne coude</a> nat medly the yifte
    of Bachus to the</p>
<p>cleer hony; <i>that is to seyn, they coude make no <a href="#BIIMVNL6" id="BIIMVL6" class="pginternal">piment</a> nor clarree</i>;</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVNL7" id="BIIMVL7" class="pginternal">ne they coude</a> nat medle the brighte fleeses of the
    contree of</p>
<p>Seriens with the venim of Tyrie; <i>this is to seyn, they coude nat</i></p>
<p><i>deyen whyte fleeses of Serien contree with the blode of a maner</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>shelfisshe that men finden in Tyrie, with whiche blood men deyen</i></p>
<p><i>purpur</i>. They slepen hoolsom slepes up-on the gras, and</p>
<p>dronken of the renninge wateres; and layen under the shadwes</p>
<p>of the heye pyn-trees. Ne no <a href="#BIIMVNL13" id="BIIMVL13" class="pginternal">gest ne straungere</a> ne
    carf yit</p>
<p>the heye see with ores or with shippes; ne they ne hadde seyn</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">yit none newe strondes, to leden marchaundyse in-to dyverse</p>
<p>contrees. Tho weren the cruel clariouns ful hust and ful stille,</p>
<p>ne blood y-shad by egre hate ne hadde nat deyed yit <a href="#BIIMVNL17" id="BIIMVL17" class="pginternal">armures</a>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVNL18" id="BIIMVL18" class="pginternal">For wher-to</a> or which woodnesse of enemys wolde first
    moeven</p>
<p>armes, whan they seyen cruel woundes, ne none medes be of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">blood y-shad?</p>
<p class="stanza">I wolde that oure tymes sholde torne ayein to the olde</p>
<p>maneres! <a href="#BIIMVNL22" id="BIIMVL22" class="pginternal">But the anguissous</a> love of havinge brenneth
    in folk</p>
<p>more cruely than the fyr of the mountaigne Ethna, <i>that ay brenneth</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVNL24" id="BIIMVL24" class="pginternal">Allas!</a> what was he that first dalf up the gobetes or
    the weightes</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of gold covered under erthe, and the precious stones that wolden</p>
<p>han ben hid? <a href="#BIIMVNL26" id="BIIMVL26" class="pginternal">He dalf</a> up precious perils. <i>That is to
    seyn, that</i></p>
<p><i>he that hem first up dalf, he dalf up a precious peril; for-why for</i></p>
<p><i>the preciousnesse of swiche thinge, hath many man ben in peril.</i></p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. V.</span> 2. Ed. feldes; C. feeldes; A. erthes. 3. C.
  desseyuyd; A. desceyued. 4. C. accornes; A. acornes. 6. C. nor; Ed. or; A. of. 7. C. fleezes; A.
  flies; Ed. fleces. 8. A. siriens (Lat. <i>Serum</i>). 9. C. flezes; A. flies; Ed. fleces. // C.
  syryen; A. sirien; Ed. Syrien. 10. C. shylle-; A. Ed. shel-. 13. A. <i>om. 3rd</i> ne. // C.
  karue; A. karf; Ed. carfe. 16. C. crwel (<i>and so again below</i>). // C. Ed. hust; A. whist. 17.
  A. y-shed. // A. armurers (!). 18. C. wer to. 19. C. say; A. seien. 22. C. angwissos; A.
  anguissous. 23. C. <i>om. 2nd</i> the. // A. Ed. of Ethna; C. <i>om.</i> of. // A. euer
  (<i>for</i> ay). 27. C. <i>om. 2nd</i> he. 28. A. <i>om.</i> thinge. // A. ben; C. be. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose VI.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quid autem de dignitatibus.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>But what shal I seye of dignitees and of powers, the whiche</p>
<p>ye men, that neither knowen verray dignitee ne verray power,</p>
<p>areysen hem as heye as the hevene? The whiche dignitees and</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page42">{42}</span>powers, yif they comen to any wikked man, they
    don as grete</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">damages and destrucciouns as doth the flaumbe of the mountaigne</p>
<p>Ethna, whan the flaumbe walweth up; ne no deluge ne doth so</p>
<p>cruel harmes. Certes, thee remembreth wel, as I trowe, that</p>
<p>thilke dignitee that men clepen <a href="#BIIPVINL8" id="BIIPVIL8" class="pginternal">the imperie of
    consulers</a>, the</p>
<p>whiche that whylom was biginninge of fredom, youre eldres</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">coveiteden to han don away that dignitee, for the pryde of the</p>
<p>consulers. And right for the same pryde your eldres, biforn that</p>
<p>tyme, hadden don awey, out of the citee of Rome, the kinges</p>
<p>name; <i>that is to seyn, they nolde han no lenger no king</i>. But</p>
<p>now, yif so be that dignitees and powers be yeven to goode men,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the whiche thing is ful selde, what agreable thing is ther in tho</p>
<p>dignitees or powers but only the goodnesse of folkes that usen</p>
<p>hem? And therfor it is thus, that honour ne comth nat to vertu</p>
<p>for cause of dignitee, but ayeinward honour comth to dignitee for</p>
<p>cause of vertu. But whiche is thilke youre dereworthe power,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that is so cleer and <a href="#BIIPVINL20" id="BIIPVIL20" class="pginternal">so requerable</a>? O
    ye ertheliche bestes,</p>
<p>considere ye nat over which thinge that it semeth that ye han</p>
<p>power? Now yif thou saye a mous amonges other mys, that</p>
<p>chalaunged to him-self-ward right and power over alle other mys,</p>
<p>how greet scorn woldest thou han of it! <b>Glosa.</b> <i>So fareth it by</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>men; the body hath power over the body.</i> For yif thou loke wel</p>
<p>up-on the body of a wight, what thing shall thou finde more</p>
<p>freele than is mankinde; the whiche men wel ofte ben slayn with</p>
<p>bytinge of smale flyes, or elles with the entringe of crepinge</p>
<p>wormes <a href="#BIIPVINL29" id="BIIPVIL29" class="pginternal">in-to the privetees of mannes body</a>? But wher
    shal man</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">finden any man that may exercen or haunten any right up-on</p>
<p>another man, but only up-on his body, or elles up-on thinges</p>
<p>that ben lowere than the body, <a href="#BIIPVINL32" id="BIIPVIL32" class="pginternal">the whiche I clepe</a>
    fortunous</p>
<p>possessiouns? Mayst thou ever have any comaundement over</p>
<p>a free corage? Mayst thou remuen fro the estat of his propre</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">reste <a href="#BIIPVINL35" id="BIIPVIL35" class="pginternal">a thought</a> that is clyvinge
    to-gidere in him-self by stedefast</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page43">{43}</span>resoun? As whylom a tyraunt wende to confounde
    <a href="#BIIPVINL36" id="BIIPVIL36" class="pginternal">a free man</a></p>
<p>of corage, and wende to constreyne him by torment, to maken</p>
<p>him discoveren and acusen folk that wisten of a coniuracioun,</p>
<p><i>which I clepe a confederacie</i>, that was cast ayeins this tyraunt;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">but this free man boot of his owne tonge and caste it in the</p>
<p>visage of thilke wode tyraunt; so that the torments that this</p>
<p>tyraunt wende to han maked matere of crueltee, this wyse man</p>
<p>maked it matere of vertu.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#BIIPVINL44" id="BIIPVIL44" class="pginternal">But what</a> thing is it that a man may
    don to another man, that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">he ne may receyven the same thing of othre folk in him-self:</p>
<p><i>or thus, what may a man don to folk, that folk ne may don him the</i></p>
<p><i>same?</i> I have herd told of <a href="#BIIPVINL47" id="BIIPVIL47" class="pginternal">Busirides</a>, that was
    wont to sleen his</p>
<p>gestes that herberweden in his hous; and he was sleyn him-self</p>
<p>of Ercules that was his gest. <a href="#BIIPVINL49" id="BIIPVIL49" class="pginternal">Regulus</a> hadde taken in
    bataile</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">many men of Affrike and cast hem in-to feteres; but sone after</p>
<p>he moste yeve his handes to ben bounde with the cheynes of</p>
<p>hem that he hadde whylom overcomen. Wenest thou thanne</p>
<p>that he be mighty, that hath no power to don a thing, that othre</p>
<p>ne may don in him that he doth in othre? And yit more-over,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">yif it so were that thise dignitees or poweres hadden any propre</p>
<p>or natural goodnesse in hem-self, never nolden they comen to</p>
<p>shrewes. For contrarious thinges ne ben nat wont to ben</p>
<p>y-felawshiped to-gidere. Nature refuseth that contrarious thinges</p>
<p>ben y-ioigned. And so, as I am in certein that right wikked folk</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">han dignitees ofte tyme, than sheweth it wel that dignitees and</p>
<p>powers ne ben nat goode of hir owne kinde; sin that they suffren</p>
<p>hem-self to cleven or ioinen hem to shrewes. And certes, the</p>
<p>same thing <a href="#BIIPVINL63" id="BIIPVIL63" class="pginternal">may I</a> most digneliche iugen and seyn of
    alle the</p>
<p>yiftes of fortune that most plentevously comen to shrewes; of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the whiche yiftes, I trowe that it oughte ben considered, that no</p>
<p>man douteth that he nis strong in whom he seeth strengthe; and</p>
<p>in whom that swiftnesse is, sooth it is that he is swift. Also</p>
<p>musike maketh musiciens, and phisike maketh phisiciens, and</p>
<p>rethorike rethoriens. For-why the nature of every thing maketh</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">his propretee, ne it is nat entremedled with the effects of the</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page44">{44}</span>contrarious thinges; and, <a href="#BIIPVINL71" id="BIIPVIL71" class="pginternal">as of wil</a>, it chaseth out thinges that</p>
<p>ben to it contrarie. But certes, richesse may not restreyne</p>
<p>avarice unstaunched; ne power ne maketh nat a man mighty</p>
<p>over him-self, whiche that vicious lustes holden destreyned with</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">cheynes that ne mowen nat be unbounden. And dignitees that</p>
<p>ben yeven to shrewede folk nat only ne maketh hem nat digne,</p>
<p>but it sheweth rather al openly that they ben unworthy and</p>
<p>undigne. And why is it thus? Certes, for ye han Ioye to clepen</p>
<p>thinges with false names that beren hem alle in the contrarie;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the whiche names ben ful ofte <a href="#BIIPVINL80" id="BIIPVIL80" class="pginternal">reproeved</a> by the effecte of the</p>
<p>same thinges; so that thise ilke richesses ne oughten nat by</p>
<p>right to ben cleped richesses; ne swich power ne oughte nat</p>
<p>ben cleped power; ne swich dignitee ne oughte nat ben cleped</p>
<p>dignitee.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">85</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">And at the laste, I may conclude the same thing of alle the</p>
<p>yiftes of Fortune, in which ther nis nothing to ben desired, ne</p>
<p>that hath in him-self naturel bountee, as it is ful wel y-sene. For</p>
<p>neither they ne ioignen hem nat alwey to goode men, ne maken</p>
<p>hem alwey goode to whom that they ben y-ioigned.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. VI.</span> 1. A. seyne. 2. A. <i>om.</i> ye. 5. C. flawmbe; A.
  fla<i>m</i>me (<i>twice</i>). 6. A. <i>ins.</i> wit (!) <i>bef.</i> walweth. 7. C. crwel. // C.
  remenbryth. 8. A. thilke; C. thikke. // A. emperie; C. Imp<i>er</i>iye. 11. A. conseilers. 13. A.
  kyng; C. kynge. 15. Ed. selde; C. A. zelde. // C. A. Ed. thinges; <i>read</i> thing (Lat. <i>quid
  placet</i>). 19. A. <i>om.</i> thilke. 22. C. musȝ; A. myse; Ed. myce. 23. C. mysȝ;
  A. myse; Ed. myce. 26. C. shalthow. 27. A. mannes kynde. // A. whiche ben ful ofte slayn. 29. A.
  mennes bodyes. 33. C. Maysthow. 34. C. Maysthow remwen. 35. A. cleuyng. // C. stidefast; A.
  stedfast. 40. Ed. caste; C. A. cast. 42. C. crwelte. 45. C. resseyuen; A. receyue. 48. A.
  herburghden. 52. C. <i>om.</i> he. // C. whylom; A. somtyme. // C. weenesthow. 53. C. thinge; A.
  thing. 54. A. <i>om. 1st</i> in. // A. to (<i>for 2nd</i> in). 63. Ed. I (<i>after</i> may); C. A.
  <i>omit</i>. 67. C. <i>om.</i> it. 68. <i>So</i> A.; C. musuciens, phisissiens. 70. A.
  effect<i>is</i>; C. effect. // A. <i>om.</i> the. 72. C. A. to it ben. 73. A. <i>om. 2nd</i> ne.
  81, 82. A. rycchesse (<i>twice</i>). 82, 83. A. whiche (<i>for</i> swich; <i>twice</i>). 87. C.
  I-seene; A. sene. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre VI.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Nouimus quantas dederit ruinas.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>We han wel knowen how many grete harmes and destrucciouns</p>
<p>weren don <i>by the emperor <a href="#BIIMVINL2" id="BIIMVIL2" class="pginternal">Nero</a></i>. He leet brenne
    the citee of</p>
<p>Rome, and made sleen the senatoures. And he, cruel, whylom</p>
<p>slew <a href="#BIIMVINL4" id="BIIMVIL4" class="pginternal">his brother</a>; and he was maked moist with the
    blood of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">his moder; <i>that is to seyn, he leet sleen and slitten the body of</i></p>
<p><i>his moder, to seen wher he was conceived</i>; and he loked on every</p>
<p>halve up-on her colde dede body, ne no tere ne wette his face, but</p>
<p><i>he was so hard-herted that</i> he mighte ben <a href="#BIIMVINL8" id="BIIMVIL8" class="pginternal">domes-man</a> or Iuge of</p>
<p>hir dede beautee. And natheles, yit governede this <i>Nero</i> by</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ceptre alle the poeples that Phebus the sonne may seen, cominge</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page45">{45}</span>from his outereste arysinge til he hyde his
    bemes under the</p>
<p>wawes; <i>that is to seyn, he governed alle the poeples by ceptre imperial</i></p>
<p><i>that the sonne goth aboute, from est to west</i>. And eek <i>this</i></p>
<p><i>Nero governed by ceptre</i> alle the poeples that ben under the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">colde sterres that highten <a href="#BIIMVINL15" id="BIIMVIL15" class="pginternal">"septem
    triones"</a>; <i>this is to seyn, he</i></p>
<p><i>governede alle the poeples that ben under the party of the north</i>.</p>
<p>And eek <i>Nero governed</i> alle the poeples that the violent wind</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVINL18" id="BIIMVIL18" class="pginternal">Nothus</a> scorkleth, and baketh the brenning sandes by
    his drye</p>
<p>hete; <i>that is to seyn, alle the poeples in the south</i>. But yit ne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">mighte nat al his hye power torne the woodnesse of this wikked</p>
<p>Nero. <a href="#BIIMVINL21" id="BIIMVIL21" class="pginternal">Allas!</a> it is a grevous fortune, as ofte as
    wikked swerd</p>
<p>is ioigned to cruel venim; <i>that is to seyn, venimous crueltee to</i></p>
<p><i>lordshippe</i>.'</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. VI.</span> 2. C. let; A. letee (!). 3. C. crwel. // C. whylom;
  A. somtyme. 5. C. lette (<i>wrongly</i>); A. let. 6. C. conseyued; A. conceiued. 7. A. half. // C.
  wecte; A. wette. 9. A. ȝitte neuertheles. 11. A. hidde. 12. C. sceptre; A. ceptre. 15. C.
  vii. tyryones (<i>sic</i>); A. the seuene triones; Ed. the Septentrions. 16. A. parties. 18. C.
  Ed. scorklith; A. scorchith. 19-21. A. <i>om.</i> But yit ... Nero; Ed. <i>retains it,
  omitting</i> hye. // <i>For</i> Allas ... it is, A. <i>has</i>—But ne how greuous fortune
  is; C. <i>om.</i> a <i>bef.</i> greuous, <i>but</i> Ed. <i>retains it</i>.  C. <i>repeats</i> it
  is. 22. C. crwel; crwelte. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose VII.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Tum ego, scis, inquam.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Thanne seyde I thus: 'Thou wost wel thy-self that the coveitise</p>
<p>of mortal thinges ne hadde never lordshipe of me; but</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIINL3" id="BIIPVIIL3" class="pginternal">I have wel desired</a> matere of thinges to done, <i>as
    who seith, I</i></p>
<p><i>desire to han matere of governaunce over comunalitees</i>, for vertu,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">stille, ne sholde nat elden;' <i>that is to seyn, that [him] leste
    that,</i></p>
<p><i>or he wex olde, his vertu, that lay now ful stille, ne should nat</i></p>
<p><i>perisshe unexercised in governaunce of comune; for which men</i></p>
<p><i>mighten speken or wryten of his goode governement</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza"><i>Philosophye.</i> 'For sothe,' quod she, 'and that is a thing that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">may <a href="#BIIPVIINL10" id="BIIPVIIL10" class="pginternal">drawen to governaunce</a> swiche
    hertes as ben worthy and</p>
<p>noble of hir nature; but natheles, it may nat drawen or tollen</p>
<p>swiche hertes as ben y-brought to the fulle perfeccioun of vertu,</p>
<p>that is to seyn, coveitise of glorie and renoun to han wel administred</p>
<p>the comune thinges or don gode desertes to profit of the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">comune. For see now and considere, how litel and how voide of</p>
<p>alle prys is thilke glorie. Certein thing is, as thou hast lerned by</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page46">{46}</span>the demonstracioun of astronomye, that al the
    environinge of the</p>
<p>erthe aboute ne halt nat but the resoun of <a href="#BIIPVIINL18" id="BIIPVIIL18" class="pginternal">a
    prikke</a> at regard of the</p>
<p>greetnesse of hevene; that is to seyn, that yif ther were maked</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">comparisoun of the erthe to the greetnesse of hevene, men wolden</p>
<p>iugen in al, that the erthe ne helde no space. Of the whiche litel</p>
<p>regioun of this worlde, the ferthe partye is enhabited with livinge</p>
<p>bestes that we knowen, as thou thyself hast y-lerned by <a href="#BIIPVIINL23" id="BIIPVIIL23" class="pginternal">Tholomee</a></p>
<p>that proveth it. And yif thou haddest with-drawen and abated in</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thy thought fro thilke ferthe partye as moche space as the see and</p>
<p>the mareys contenen and over-goon, and as moche space as the</p>
<p>regioun of droughte over-streccheth, <i>that is to seyn, sandes and</i></p>
<p><i>desertes</i>, <a href="#BIIPVIINL28" id="BIIPVIIL28" class="pginternal">wel unnethe</a> sholde ther dwellen a
    right streit place to</p>
<p>the habitacioun of men. And ye thanne, that ben environed and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">closed with-in the leste prikke of thilke prikke, thinken ye to</p>
<p>manifesten your renoun and don youre name to ben born forth?</p>
<p>But your glorie, that is so narwe and so streite y-throngen in-to so</p>
<p>litel boundes, how mochel coveiteth it in largesse and in greet</p>
<p>doinge? <a href="#BIIPVIINL34" id="BIIPVIIL34" class="pginternal">And also sette</a> this there-to: that many a
    nacioun,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">dyverse of tonge and of maneres and eek of resoun of hir livinge,</p>
<p>ben enhabited in the clos of thilke litel habitacle; to the whiche</p>
<p>naciouns, what for difficultee of weyes and what for dyversitee of</p>
<p>langages, and what for <a href="#BIIPVIINL38" id="BIIPVIIL38" class="pginternal">defaute</a> of unusage and
    entrecomuninge of</p>
<p>marchaundise, nat only the names of singuler men ne may nat</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">strecchen, but eek the fame of citees ne may nat strecchen. At</p>
<p>the laste, certes, in the tyme of <a href="#BIIPVIINL41" id="BIIPVIIL41" class="pginternal">Marcus Tullius</a>,
    as him-self writ in</p>
<p>his book, that the renoun of the comune of Rome ne hadde nat</p>
<p>yit passed ne cloumben over the mountaigne that highte <a href="#BIIPVIINL43" id="BIIPVIIL43" class="pginternal">Caucasus</a>;</p>
<p>and yit was, thilke tyme, Rome wel waxen and greetly redouted of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the <a href="#BIIPVIINL45" id="BIIPVIIL45" class="pginternal">Parthes</a> and eek of other folk
    enhabitinge aboute. Seestow</p>
<p>nat thanne how streit and how compressed is thilke glorie that ye</p>
<p>travailen aboute to shewe and to multiplye? May thanne the</p>
<p>glorie of a singuler Romaine strecchen thider as the fame of the</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page47">{47}</span>name of Rome may nat climben ne passen? And eek,
    seestow nat</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that the maneres of dyverse folk and eek hir lawes ben discordaunt</p>
<p>among hem-self; so that thilke thing that som men</p>
<p>iugen worthy of preysinge, other folk iugen that it is worthy of</p>
<p>torment? And ther-of comth it that, though a man delyte him in</p>
<p>preysinge of his renoun, he may nat in no wyse bringen forth ne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">spreden his name to many maner poeples. There-for every man</p>
<p>oughte to ben apayed of his glorie that is publisshed among his</p>
<p>owne neighbours; and thilke noble renoun shal ben restreyned</p>
<p>within the boundes of o manere folke. But how many a man,</p>
<p>that was ful noble in his tyme, <a href="#BIIPVIINL59" id="BIIPVIIL59" class="pginternal">hath the wrecched</a>
    and nedy</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">foryetinge of wryteres put out of minde and don awey! Al be</p>
<p>it so that, certes, thilke wrytinges profiten litel; the whiche</p>
<p>wrytinges long and derk elde doth awey, bothe hem and eek hir</p>
<p>autours. But ye men semen to geten yow a perdurabletee, whan</p>
<p>ye thenken that, in tyme to-cominge, your fame shal lasten. But</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">natheles, yif thou wolt maken comparisoun to the endeles spaces</p>
<p>of eternitee, what thing hast thou by whiche thou mayst reioysen</p>
<p>thee of long lastinge of thy name? For yif ther were maked comparisoun</p>
<p>of the abydinge of a moment to ten thousand winter,</p>
<p>for as mochel as bothe the spaces ben <a href="#BIIPVIINL69" id="BIIPVIIL69" class="pginternal">ended</a>, yit
    hath the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">moment som porcioun of it, al-though it litel be. But natheles,</p>
<p>thilke selve noumbre of yeres, and eek as many yeres as</p>
<p>ther-to may be multiplyed, ne may nat, certes, ben comparisoned</p>
<p>to the perdurabletee that is <a href="#BIIPVIINL73" id="BIIPVIIL73" class="pginternal">endeles</a>; for of
    thinges that han ende</p>
<p>may be maked comparisoun, but of thinges that ben with-outen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ende, to thinges that han ende, may be maked no comparisoun.</p>
<p>And forthy is it that, al-though renoun, of as long tyme as ever</p>
<p>thee list to thinken, <a href="#BIIPVIINL77" id="BIIPVIIL77" class="pginternal">were thought</a> to the regard
    of eternitee, that</p>
<p>is unstaunchable and infinit, it ne sholde nat only semen litel, but</p>
<p>pleynliche right naught. But ye men, certes, ne conne don</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">nothing a-right, but-yif it be for the audience of poeple and for</p>
<p>ydel rumours; and ye forsaken the grete worthinesse of conscience</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page48">{48}</span>and of vertu, and ye seken your guerdouns of the
    smale wordes of</p>
<p>straunge folk.</p>
<p class="stanza">Have now heer and understonde, in the lightnesse of swich</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">85</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">pryde and veine glorie, how a man scornede festivaly and merily</p>
<p>swich vanitee. Whylom ther was a man that hadde assayed</p>
<p>with stryvinge wordes another man, the whiche, nat for usage of</p>
<p>verray vertu but for proud veine glorie, had taken up-on him</p>
<p>falsly the name of a philosophre. <a href="#BIIPVIINL89" id="BIIPVIIL89" class="pginternal">This rather man</a>.
    <i>that I spak</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>of</i> thoughte he wolde assaye, wher he, thilke, were a philosophre</p>
<p>or no; that is to seyn, yif that he wolde han suffred lightly in</p>
<p>pacience the wronges that weren don un-to him. This feynede</p>
<p>philosophre took pacience a litel whyle, and, whan he hadde</p>
<p>received wordes of outrage, he, as in stryvinge ayein and reioysinge</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of him-self, <a href="#BIIPVIINL95" id="BIIPVIIL95" class="pginternal">seyde</a> at the laste
    right thus: "understondest</p>
<p>thou nat that I am a philosophre?" That other man answerde</p>
<p>ayein ful bytingly, and seyde: "I hadde wel understonden it, yif</p>
<p>thou haddest holden thy tonge stille." But what is it to thise</p>
<p>noble worthy men (for, certes, of swiche folke speke I) that seken</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">glorie with vertu? What is it?' quod she; 'what atteyneth fame</p>
<p>to swiche folk, whan the body is resolved by the deeth at the</p>
<p>laste? For yif it so be that men dyen in al, <i>that is to seyn, body</i></p>
<p><i>and sowle</i>, the whiche thing our resoun defendeth us to bileven,</p>
<p>thanne is ther no glorie in no wyse. <i>For what sholde thilke glorie</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>ben</i>, whan he, of whom thilke glorie is seyd to be, nis right naught</p>
<p>in no wyse? And yif the sowle, whiche that hath in it-self science</p>
<p>of goode werkes, unbounden fro the prison of the erthe, wendeth</p>
<p>frely to the hevene, <a href="#BIIPVIINL108" id="BIIPVIIL108" class="pginternal">despyseth it</a> nat thanne
    alle erthely occupacioun;</p>
<p>and, being in hevene, reioyseth that it is exempt fro alle</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">erthely thinges? <i>As who seith, thanne rekketh the sowle of no</i></p>
<p><i>glorie of renoun of this world.</i></p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. VII.</span> 4. A. desired. 5. <i>I supply</i> him (<i>to make
  sense</i>). // Ed. leste; C. A. list. 6. A. wex; C. wax. 7. C. p<i>er</i>ise; A. perisshe. // Ed.
  vnexercysed; C. A. vnexcercised. 17. A. <i>om. 1st</i> the. // C. <i>om.</i> of. 21. A. that erthe
  helde. 26. A. and mareys. // C. spaces (<i>for</i> space). 28. C. vel; A. wel. 32. C. narwh; A.
  narwe. 36. A. cloos. 37. C. deficulte; A. difficulte. // C. deficulte (<i>repeated</i>); A. Ed.
  diuersite. 38. A. <i>om.</i> and <i>after</i> vnusage. 39. Ed. synguler; C. A. syngler. // A.
  <i>om.</i> nat (<i>bef. 1st</i> strecchen). 41. C. marchus; A. Marcus. // Ed. Tullius; C. A.
  Tulius. // C. writ; A. writeth. 43. C. <i>om.</i> yit. // A. hyȝt. 44. C. thikke; A. thilk.
  // A. wexen. 45. C. sestow; A. Sest thou. 48. Ed. synguler; C. singler; A. singlere. // A.
  strecchen; C. strechchen. 49. C. seysthow; A. sest thou; Ed. seest thou. 51. C. thinge; A. thing.
  56. A. paied. // Ed. publysshed; C. publyssed; A. puplissed. 57. A. neyȝbores; Ed.

  weer<i>e</i> he; A. where he; Ed. wheder he. 91. A. <i>om.</i> that. 94. C. resseyuyd; A.

  102. A. <i>om.</i> it. 103. C. deffendeth; A. defendith. 105. A. for (<i>for</i> whan). 107. C.
  <i>glosses</i> erthe <i>by</i> i. corporis. 108. C. <i>glosses</i> it <i>by</i> i. anima. 110,
  111. A. <i>om.</i> As who ... this world. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre VII.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quicunque solam mente praecipiti petit.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Who-so that, <a href="#BIIMVIINL1" id="BIIMVIIL1" class="pginternal">with overthrowinge thought</a>, only seketh
    glorie of</p>
<p>fame, and weneth that it be sovereyn good: lat him loken up-on</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page49">{49}</span>the brode <a href="#BIIMVIINL3" id="BIIMVIIL3" class="pginternal">shewinge</a> contrees of hevene, and up-on the streite site</p>
<p>of this erthe; and he shal ben ashamed of the encrees of his</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">name, that may nat fulfille the litel compas <i>of the erthe</i>. O!</p>
<p>what coveiten proude folk to liften up hir nekkes in ydel in the</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIINL7" id="BIIMVIIL7" class="pginternal">dedly</a> yok <i>of this worlde</i>? For al-though that
    renoun y-sprad,</p>
<p>passinge to <a href="#BIIMVIINL8" id="BIIMVIIL8" class="pginternal">ferne</a> poeples, goth by dyverse tonges;
    and al-though</p>
<p>that grete houses or kinredes shynen with clere titles of honours;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">yit, natheles, deeth despyseth alle heye glorie of fame: and deeth</p>
<p>wrappeth to-gidere the heye hevedes and the lowe, and maketh</p>
<p>egal and evene the heyeste to the loweste. Wher wonen now the</p>
<p>bones of trewe <a href="#BIIMVIINL13" id="BIIMVIIL13" class="pginternal">Fabricius</a>? What is now <a href="#BIIMVIINL13" class="pginternal">Brutus</a>, or stierne</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIINL14" id="BIIMVIIL14" class="pginternal">Catoun</a>? The thinne fame, yit lastinge, of hir ydel
    names, is</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">marked with a fewe lettres; but al-though that we han knowen</p>
<p>the faire wordes of the fames of hem, it is nat yeven to knowe</p>
<p>hem that ben dede and consumpte. <a href="#BIIMVIINL17" id="BIIMVIIL17" class="pginternal">Liggeth</a> thanne
    stille, al</p>
<p>outrely unknowable; ne fame ne maketh yow nat knowe. And</p>
<p>yif ye wene to liven the longer for winde of your mortal name,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">whan o <a href="#BIIMVIINL20" id="BIIMVIIL20" class="pginternal">cruel</a> day shal ravisshe yow,
    <a href="#BIIMVIINL20" class="pginternal">thanne is</a> the seconde deeth</p>
<p>dwellinge un-to yow.' <b>Glose.</b> <i>The first deeth he clepeth heer the</i></p>
<p><i>departinge of the body and the sowle; and the seconde deeth he</i></p>
<p><i>clepeth, as heer, the stintinge of the renoun of fame.</i></p>
</div>
<p class="sp3">3. C. cyte (<i>for</i> site); A. sete (<i>error for</i> site; Lat. <i>situm</i>).
  6. A. liften vpon hire nekkes in ydel and dedely. 7. A. <i>om.</i> that. 9. A. <i>om.</i> that. //
  C. cler; A. clere. 13. A. stiern; Ed. sterne. 17. A. Ed. consumpt. 18. A. vtterly. 21. Ed. to
  (<i>for</i> un-to); A. in. // A. Ed. the; C. <i>om.</i> (<i>after</i> heer). </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose VIII.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Set ne me inexorabile contra fortunam.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>'But for as mochel as thou shalt nat wenen', quod she, 'that I</p>
<p>bere <a href="#BIIPVIIINL2" id="BIIPVIIIL2" class="pginternal">untretable</a> bataile ayeins fortune, yit
    som-tyme it bifalleth that</p>
<p>she, deceyvable, deserveth to han right good thank of men; and</p>
<p>that is, whan she hir-self opneth, and whan she descovereth hir</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">frount, and sheweth hir maneres. Peraventure yit understondest</p>
<p>thou nat that I shal seye. It is a wonder that I desire to telle,</p>
<p>and forthy unnethe may I <a href="#BIIPVIIINL7" id="BIIPVIIIL7" class="pginternal">unpleyten</a> my sentence
    with wordes; for</p>
<p>I deme that contrarious Fortune profiteth more to men than</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page50">{50}</span>Fortune debonaire. For alwey, whan Fortune
    semeth debonaire,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">than she lyeth falsly in bihetinge the hope of welefulnesse; but</p>
<p>forsothe contrarious Fortune is alwey soothfast, whan she sheweth</p>
<p>hir-self unstable thorugh hir chaunginge. The amiable Fortune</p>
<p>deceyveth folk; the contrarie Fortune techeth. The amiable</p>
<p>Fortune bindeth with the beautee of false goodes the hertes of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">folk that usen hem; the contrarie Fortune unbindeth hem by the</p>
<p>knowinge of freele welefulnesse. The amiable Fortune mayst</p>
<p>thou seen alwey <a href="#BIIPVIIINL17" id="BIIPVIIIL17" class="pginternal">windinge</a> and flowinge, and ever
    misknowinge of</p>
<p>hir-self; the contrarie Fortune is atempre and restreyned, and wys</p>
<p>thorugh exercise of hir adversitee. At the laste, amiable Fortune</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">with hir flateringes draweth miswandringe men fro the sovereyne</p>
<p>good; the contrarious Fortune ledeth ofte folk ayein to soothfast</p>
<p>goodes, and haleth hem ayein as with an hooke. Wenest thou</p>
<p>thanne that thou oughtest to leten this a litel thing, that this <a href="#BIIPVIIINL23" id="BIIPVIIIL23" class="pginternal">aspre</a></p>
<p>and horrible Fortune hath discovered to thee the thoughtes of thy</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">trewe freendes? For-why this ilke Fortune hath departed and uncovered</p>
<p>to thee bothe the certein visages and eek the doutous</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIINL26" id="BIIPVIIIL26" class="pginternal">visages</a> of thy felawes. Whan she departed awey
    fro thee, she</p>
<p>took awey hir freendes, and lafte thee thyne freendes. Now whan</p>
<p>thou were riche and weleful, as thee semede, with how mochel</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">woldest thou han bought the fulle knowinge of this, <i>that is to seyn,</i></p>
<p><i>the knowinge of thy verray freendes</i>? Now pleyne thee nat thanne</p>
<p>of richesse y-lorn, sin thou hast founden the moste precious kinde</p>
<p>of richesses, that is to seyn, thy verray freendes.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. VIII.</span> A. <i>omits to end of</i> bk. iii. pr. 1. 3. C.
  desseyuable. // C. desserueth. 7. <i>So</i> C.; Ed. vnplyten. 13. C. desseyueth. 17. C. maysthow.
  30. C. woldesthow. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre VIII.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quod mundus stabili fide.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p><a href="#BIIMVIIINL1" id="BIIMVIIIL1" class="pginternal">That the world with stable feith</a> varieth acordable
    chaunginges;</p>
<p>that the contrarious qualitee of elements holden among hem-self</p>
<p>aliaunce perdurable; that Phebus the sonne with his goldene</p>
<p>chariet bringeth forth the rosene day; that the mone hath commaundement</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">over the nightes, which nightes Hesperus the eve-sterre</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIIINL6" id="BIIMVIIIL6" class="pginternal">hath brought</a>; that the see, <a href="#BIIMVIIINL6" class="pginternal">greedy to flowen</a>, constreyneth</p>
<p>with a certein <a href="#BIIMVIIINL7" id="BIIMVIIIL7" class="pginternal">ende</a> hise flodes, so that it is nat
    leveful to strecche</p>
<p>hise brode <a href="#BIIMVIIINL8" id="BIIMVIIIL8" class="pginternal">termes or boundes</a> up-on the erthes,
    <i>that is to seyn, to</i></p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page51">{51}</span><i>covere al the erthe</i>:—al this
    acordaunce of thinges is bounden with</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIIMVIIINL10" id="BIIMVIIIL10" class="pginternal">Love</a>, that governeth erthe and
    see, and hath also commaundements</p>
<p>to the hevenes. And yif this Love <a href="#BIIMVIIINL11" id="BIIMVIIIL11" class="pginternal">slakede</a> the
    brydeles,</p>
<p>alle thinges that now loven hem to-gederes wolden maken a bataile</p>
<p>continuely, and stryven to fordoon the fasoun of this worlde, the</p>
<p>whiche they now leden in acordable feith by faire moevinges.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">This Love halt to-gideres poeples ioigned with an holy bond, and</p>
<p>knitteth sacrement of mariages of chaste loves; and Love endyteth</p>
<p>lawes to trewe felawes. O! weleful were mankinde, yif thilke</p>
<p>Love that governeth hevene governed youre corages!'</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. VIII.</span> 6. C. hat. 7. C. lueful; Ed. leful. 8. erthes;
  Lat. <i>terris</i>. </p>
<p class="sp5 ac"><b>Explicit Liber secundus.</b></p>
<h2 class="sp3 ac" style="margin-bottom:2.1ex;"> <span class="larger">BOOK III.</span></h2>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose I.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Iam cantum illa finierat.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>By this she hadde ended hir song, whan the sweetnesse of hir</p>
<p>ditee hadde thorugh-perced me that was desirous of herkninge,</p>
<p>and I astoned hadde yit <a href="#BIIIPINL3" id="BIIIPIL3" class="pginternal">streighte</a> myn eres, <i>that is
    to seyn, to</i></p>
<p><i>herkne the bet what she wolde seye</i>; so that a litel here-after I</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">seyde thus: 'O thou that art sovereyn comfort of anguissous</p>
<p>corages, <a href="#BIIIPINL6" id="BIIIPIL6" class="pginternal">so</a> thou hast remounted and norisshed me with
    the</p>
<p>weighte of thy sentences and with delyt of thy singinge; so that</p>
<p>I trowe nat now that I be <a href="#BIIIPINL8" id="BIIIPIL8" class="pginternal">unparigal</a> to the strokes of
    Fortune:</p>
<p><i>as who seyth, I dar wel now suffren al the assautes of Fortune, and</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>wel defende me fro hir</i>. And tho remedies whiche that thou</p>
<p>seydest her-biforn weren right sharpe, <a href="#BIIIPINL11" id="BIIIPIL11" class="pginternal">nat only that</a>
    I am nat</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPINL12" id="BIIIPIL12" class="pginternal">a-grisen</a> of hem now, but I, desirous of heringe, axe
    gretely to</p>
<p>heren the remedies.'</p>
<p class="stanza">Than seyde she thus: 'That felede I ful wel,' quod she, 'whan</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that thou, ententif and stille, <a href="#BIIIPINL15" id="BIIIPIL15" class="pginternal">ravisshedest</a> my wordes; and I</p>
<p>abood til that thou haddest swich habite of thy thought as thou</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page52">{52}</span>hast now; or elles til that I my-self hadde
    maked to thee the</p>
<p>same habit, which that is a more verray thing. And certes, the</p>
<p>remenaunt of thinges that ben yit to seye ben swiche, that first</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">whan men tasten hem they ben bytinge, but whan they ben</p>
<p>receyved withinne a wight, than ben they swete. But for thou</p>
<p>seyst that thou art so desirous to herkne hem, with how gret</p>
<p>brenninge woldest thou glowen, yif thou wistest whider I wol</p>
<p>leden thee!'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">25</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Whider is that?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'To thilke verray welefulnesse,' quod she, 'of whiche thyn herte</p>
<p>dremeth; but for as moche as thy sighte is ocupied and distorbed</p>
<p>by imaginacioun <i>of erthely thinges</i>, thou mayst nat yit seen thilke</p>
<p>selve welefulnesse.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">30</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Do,' quod I, 'and shewe me what is thilke verray welefulnesse,</p>
<p>I preye thee, with-oute taryinge.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'That wole I gladly don,' quod she, '<a href="#BIIIPINL32" id="BIIIPIL32" class="pginternal">for
    the cause of thee</a>;</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPINL33" id="BIIIPIL33" class="pginternal">but I wol</a> first marken thee by wordes and I wol
    enforcen me to</p>
<p>enformen thee thilke <i>false</i> cause <i>of blisfulnesse</i> that thou more</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">knowest; so that, whan thou hast fully bi-holden thilke false</p>
<p>goodes, and torned thyn eyen to that other syde, thou mowe knowe</p>
<p>the cleernesse of verray blisfulnesse.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. I.</span> 3. C. streyhte; Ed. streyght. 5. C angwissos. 7. C.
  weyhte; Ed. weight. // C. sentenses; Ed. sentences. 8. C. vnparygal; Ed. vnperegall. 10. C.
  deffende; Ed. defende. 11. C. hir-; Ed. here-. 12. C. desiros; Ed. desyrous. 17. C. Ed. had. 21.
  C. resseyued. 22. C. wit; Ed. with. 23. C. woldesthow; Ed. woldest thou. 26. C. thynge (!); Ed.
  thyn; Lat. <i>tuus</i>. 28. C. herthely; Ed. erthly. 31. C. tarynge; Ed. taryeng; Lat.
  <i>cunctatione</i>. 33. C. the (<i>for</i> thee); Ed. <i>om.</i> </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre I.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Qui serere ingenuum uolet agrum.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Who-so wole sowe a feeld plentivous, lat him first delivere it fro</p>
<p>thornes, and kerve asunder with his <a href="#BIIIMINL2" id="BIIIMIL2" class="pginternal">hook</a> the busshes
    and the</p>
<p>fern, so that the corn may comen hevy of eres and of greynes.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMINL4" id="BIIIMIL4" class="pginternal">Hony</a> is the more swete, yif mouthes han first tasted
    savoures that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ben wikkid. The sterres shynen more agreably whan the wind</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMINL6" id="BIIIMIL6" class="pginternal">Nothus</a> leteth his <a href="#BIIIMINL6" class="pginternal">ploungy</a>
    blastes; and after that Lucifer the</p>
<p>day-sterre hath chased awey the derke night, the day the fairere</p>
<p>ledeth the rosene hors <i>of the sonne</i>. And right so thou, bi-holdinge</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page53">{53}</span>first the false goodes, <a href="#BIIIMINL9" id="BIIIMIL9" class="pginternal">bigin</a> to with-drawen thy nekke</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">fro the yok <i>of erthely affecciouns</i>; and after-ward the verray goodes</p>
<p>shollen entren in-to thy corage.'</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. I.</span> 1. A. of (<i>for</i> fro). 2. A. bushes; Ed.
  busshes; C. bosses. 3. C. heres; A. eres. 5. A. wikke. // C. agreablely. 7. C. dirke; A. derke. 8.
  A. <i>om.</i> And. 10. C. verre; A. verrey. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose II.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Tunc defixo paullulum uisu.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Tho fastnede she a litel the sighte of hir eyen, and with-drow</p>
<p>hir right as it were in-to the <a href="#BIIIPIINL2" id="BIIIPIIL2" class="pginternal">streite sete</a> of hir
    thought; and bigan</p>
<p>to speke right thus: 'Alle the <a href="#BIIIPIINL3" id="BIIIPIIL3" class="pginternal">cures</a>,' quod she, 'of
    mortal folk,</p>
<p>whiche that travaylen hem in many maner studies, goon certes by</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">diverse weyes, but natheles they enforcen hem alle to comen only</p>
<p>to oon ende of blisfulnesse. And blisfulnesse is swiche a good,</p>
<p>that who-so that hath geten it, he ne may, <a href="#BIIIPIINL7" id="BIIIPIIL7" class="pginternal">over
    that</a>, no-thing</p>
<p>more desyre. And this thing is forsothe the <a href="#BIIIPIINL8" id="BIIIPIIL8" class="pginternal">sovereyn
    good</a> that</p>
<p>conteyneth in him-self alle maner goodes; to the whiche good yif</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ther failede any thing, it mighte nat ben cleped sovereyn good:</p>
<p>for thanne were ther som good, <a href="#BIIIPIINL11" id="BIIIPIIL11" class="pginternal">out of this ilke
    sovereyn good</a>, that</p>
<p>mighte ben desired. Now is it cleer and certein thanne, that</p>
<p>blisfulnesse is a parfit estat by the congregacioun of alle goodes;</p>
<p>the whiche blisfulnesse, as I have seyd, alle mortal folk enforcen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">hem to geten by diverse weyes. For-why the coveitise of verray</p>
<p>good is naturelly y-plaunted in the hertes of men; but the miswandringe</p>
<p>errour mis-ledeth hem in-to false goodes. Of the</p>
<p>whiche men, som of hem wenen that sovereyn good be to liven</p>
<p>with-oute nede of any thing, and travaylen hem to be haboundaunt</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of richesses. And som other men demen that sovereyn good be,</p>
<p>for to ben right digne of reverence; and enforcen hem to ben</p>
<p>reverenced among hir neighbours by the honours that they han</p>
<p>y-geten. And some folk ther ben that holden, that right heigh</p>
<p>power be sovereyn good, and enforcen hem for to regnen, or elles</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to ioignen hem to hem that regnen. And it semeth to some other</p>
<p>folk, that noblesse of renoun be the sovereyn good; and hasten</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page54">{54}</span>hem to geten glorious name by the arts of werre
    and of pees.</p>
<p>And many folk <a href="#BIIIPIINL28" id="BIIIPIIL28" class="pginternal">mesuren</a> and gessen that sovereyn
    good be Ioye</p>
<p>and gladnesse, and wenen that it be right blisful thing to ploungen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">hem in voluptuous delyt. And ther ben folk that entrechaungen</p>
<p>the causes and the endes of thise forseyde goodes, as they that</p>
<p>desiren richesses to han power and delytes; or elles they desiren</p>
<p>power for to han moneye, or for cause of renoun. In thise thinges,</p>
<p>and in swiche othre thinges, <a href="#BIIIPIINL34" id="BIIIPIIL34" class="pginternal">is torned</a> alle the
    entencioun of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">desiringes and of werkes of men; as thus: noblesse and favour</p>
<p>of people, whiche that yeveth to men, as it semeth hem, a maner</p>
<p>cleernesse of renoun; and wyf and children, that men desiren for</p>
<p>cause of delyt and of <a href="#BIIIPIINL38" id="BIIIPIIL38" class="pginternal">merinesse</a>. But forsothe,
    frendes ne sholden</p>
<p>nat be rekned a-mong the godes of fortune, but of vertu; for it is</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">a ful holy maner thing. Alle thise othre thinges, forsothe, ben</p>
<p>taken for cause of power or elles for cause of delyt.</p>
<p class="stanza">Certes, now am I redy to referren the goodes of the body to</p>
<p>thise forseide thinges aboven; for it semeth that strengthe and</p>
<p>gretnesse of body yeven power and worthinesse, and that beautee</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and swiftnesse yeven noblesses and glorie of renoun; and hele of</p>
<p>body semeth yeven delyt. In alle thise thinges it semeth only</p>
<p>that blisfulnesse is desired. For-why thilke thing that every man</p>
<p>desireth most over alle thinges, he demeth that it be the sovereyn</p>
<p>good; but I have defyned that blisfulnesse is the sovereyn good;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIIIPIINL50" id="BIIIPIIL50" class="pginternal">for which</a> every wight demeth, that
    thilke estat that he desireth</p>
<p>over alle thinges, that it be blisfulnesse.</p>
<p class="stanza">Now hast thou thanne biforn thyn eyen almest al the purposed</p>
<p>forme of the welefulnesse of man-kinde, that is to seyn, richesses,</p>
<p>honours, power, and glorie, and delyts. The whiche delyt only</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">considerede <a href="#BIIIPIINL55" id="BIIIPIIL55" class="pginternal">Epicurus</a>, and iuged and
    establisshed that delyt is</p>
<p>the sovereyn good; for as moche as alle othre thinges, as him</p>
<p>thoughte, <a href="#BIIIPIINL57" id="BIIIPIIL57" class="pginternal">bi-refte</a> awey Ioye and mirthe fram the
    herte. But I</p>
<p>retorne ayein to the <a href="#BIIIPIINL58" id="BIIIPIIL58" class="pginternal">studies</a> of men, of whiche men
    the corage</p>
<p>alwey reherseth and seketh the sovereyn good, <a href="#BIIIPIINL59" id="BIIIPIIL59" class="pginternal">al be
    it</a> so that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">it be with a derked memorie; but he <a href="#BIIIPIINL60" id="BIIIPIIL60" class="pginternal">not</a> by whiche path, right</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page55">{55}</span>as a dronken man not nat by whiche path he may
    retorne him to</p>
<p>his hous. Semeth it thanne that folk folyen and erren that</p>
<p>enforcen hem to have nede of nothing? Certes, ther nis non other</p>
<p>thing that may so wel performe blisfulnesse, as an estat plentivous</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of alle goodes, that ne hath nede of non other thing, but that is</p>
<p>suffisaunt of himself unto him-self. And folyen swiche folk thanne,</p>
<p>that wenen that thilke thing <a href="#BIIIPIINL67" id="BIIIPIIL67" class="pginternal">that is right good, that
    it</a> be eek right</p>
<p>worthy of honour and of reverence? Certes, nay. For that thing</p>
<p>nis neither foul ne worthy to ben despised, that wel neigh al the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">entencioun of mortal folk travaylen for to geten it. And power,</p>
<p>oughte nat that eek to ben rekened amonges goodes? What</p>
<p>elles? For it is nat to wene that thilke thing, that is most worthy</p>
<p>of alle thinges, be feble and with-oute strengthe. And cleernesse</p>
<p>of renoun, oughte that to ben despised? Certes, ther may no</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">man <a href="#BIIIPIINL75" id="BIIIPIIL75" class="pginternal">forsake</a>, that al thing that is
    right excellent and noble, that it ne</p>
<p>semeth to ben right cleer and renomed. For certes, it nedeth nat</p>
<p>to seye, that blisfulnesse <a href="#BIIIPIINL77" id="BIIIPIIL77" class="pginternal">be [nat] anguissous</a> ne
    drery, ne subgit to</p>
<p>grevaunces ne to sorwes, sin that in right litel thinges folk seken</p>
<p>to have and to usen that may delyten hem. Certes, thise ben</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the thinges that men wolen and desiren to geten. And for this</p>
<p>cause desiren they richesses, dignitees, regnes, glorie, and delices.</p>
<p>For therby wenen they to han suffisaunce, honour, power, renoun,</p>
<p>and gladnesse. <a href="#BIIIPIINL83" id="BIIIPIIL83" class="pginternal">Than is it good</a>, that men seken
    thus by so many</p>
<p>diverse studies. In whiche desyr it may lightly ben shewed how</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">85</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">gret is the strengthe of nature; for how so that men han diverse</p>
<p>sentences and discordinge, algates men acorden alle in <a href="#BIIIPIINL86" id="BIIIPIIL86" class="pginternal">lovinge</a> the</p>
<p>ende of good.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. II.</span> 2. C. cyte; A. sete; Lat. <i>sedem</i>. 5. C.
  enforsen; A. enforced; Ed. enforcen. 6. A. <i>om.</i> And blisfulnesse. 10. A. <i>om.</i> cleped.
  14. C. enforsen; A. enforcen. 18. A. is (<i>for</i> be). 20. C. ben; A. be. 22. C. nesshebors; A.
  neyghbours. 23. A. halden. // C. heyh; A. heyȝe; Ed. hye. 24: A. to b (<i>for</i> be). 28.
  C. by (<i>for</i> be); A. Ed. be. 29. A. <i>om.</i> thing. 32. A. rycchesse. 35. A. <i>om. 1st</i>
  of. // C. fauor; A. fauo<i>ur</i>. 36. A. <i>om.</i> to men <i>and</i> hem. 38. A. shollen. 39. A.
  Ed. the; C. tho. 45. C. sweft-; A. swifte-. 49. C. deffyned; A. Ed. diffined. 52. A. <i>om.</i>
  thy eyen; C. thy (<i>for</i> thyn); Ed. thyn. // A. almost. 55. A. <i>om.</i> and <i>bef.</i>
  iuged. // C. A. establyssed; Ed. establysshed. 59. A. <i>ins.</i> of <i>after</i> good
  (<i>wrongly</i>). 60. C. dirkyd; A. derke; Ed. dyrked. // A. <i>om.</i> but he ... path. // C.
  paath (<i>twice</i>). 62. C. foleyen; A. folyen. 65. C. A. <i>ins.</i> it <i>bef.</i> is; Ed.
  <i>om.</i> 66. C. A. foleyen; Ed. folyen. 69. C. wel neyh; Ed. wel nygh; A. <i>om.</i> // C. alle;
  A. Ed. al. 77. <i>I supply</i> nat. // C. angwyssos. // C. subgyd; A. subgit. 81. A. rycches. 86.
  C. allegates; A. algates. // A. lyuynge (!). </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre II.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quantas rerum flectat habenas.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>It lyketh me to shewe, by subtil song, with <a href="#BIIIMIINL1" id="BIIIMIIL1" class="pginternal">slakke</a>
    and delitable</p>
<p>soun of strenges, how that Nature, mighty, <a href="#BIIIMIINL2" id="BIIIMIIL2" class="pginternal">enclineth and
    flitteth</a></p>
<p>the governements of thinges, and by whiche lawes she, <a href="#BIIIMIINL3" id="BIIIMIIL3" class="pginternal">purveyable</a>,</p>
<p>kepeth the grete world; and how she, bindinge, restreyneth alle</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thinges by a bonde that may nat ben unbounde. Al be it so that</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page56">{56}</span>the lyouns <a href="#BIIIMIINL6" id="BIIIMIIL6" class="pginternal">of the contre of Pene</a> beren the faire chaynes, and</p>
<p>taken metes of the handes of folk that yeven it hem, and dreden</p>
<p>hir <a href="#BIIIMIINL8" id="BIIIMIIL8" class="pginternal">sturdy</a> maystres of whiche they ben wont to
    suffren betinges:</p>
<p>yif that hir horrible mouthes ben be-bled, <i>that is to seyn, of bestes</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>devoured</i>, hir corage of time passed, that hath ben ydel and rested,</p>
<p>repeyreth ayein; and they roren grevously and remembren on hir</p>
<p>nature, and slaken hir nekkes fram hir chaynes unbounde; and</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIINL13" id="BIIIMIIL13" class="pginternal">hir mayster</a>, first to-torn with blody tooth,
    assayeth the wode</p>
<p>wrathes of hem; <i>this is to seyn, they freten hir mayster</i>. And the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIIIMIINL15" id="BIIIMIIL15" class="pginternal">iangelinge</a> brid that singeth on the
    heye braunches, <i>that is to seyn,</i></p>
<p><i>in the wode</i>, and after is enclosed in a streyt cage: al-though that</p>
<p>the <a href="#BIIIMIINL17" id="BIIIMIIL17" class="pginternal">pleyinge bisinesse</a> of men yeveth hem honiede
    drinkes and</p>
<p>large metes with swete studie, yit natheles, yif thilke brid, skippinge</p>
<p>out of hir streyte cage, seeth the <a href="#BIIIMIINL19" id="BIIIMIIL19" class="pginternal">agreables</a>
    shadewes of the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">wodes, she defouleth with hir feet hir metes y-shad, and seketh</p>
<p>mourninge only the wode; and twitereth, desiringe the wode, with</p>
<p>hir swete vois. The yerde of a tree, that is haled a-doun by</p>
<p>mighty strengthe, boweth redily the crop a-doun: but yif that the</p>
<p>hand of him that it bente lat it gon ayein, anon the crop loketh</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">up-right to hevene. The sonne Phebus, that falleth at even in</p>
<p>the westrene wawes, retorneth ayein eftsones his carte, <a href="#BIIIMIINL26" id="BIIIMIIL26" class="pginternal">by privee</a></p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIINL26" class="pginternal">path</a>, ther-as it is wont aryse. <a href="#BIIIMIINL27" id="BIIIMIIL27" class="pginternal">Alle thinges</a> seken ayein to hir</p>
<p>propre cours, and alle thinges reioysen hem of hir retorninge ayein</p>
<p>to hir nature. Ne non ordinaunce nis bitaken to thinges, but that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that hath ioyned the endinge to the beginninge, and hath maked</p>
<p>the cours of it-self stable, <i>that it chaungeth nat from his propre</i></p>
<p><i>kinde</i>.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. II.</span> 3. A. <i>om.</i> the. 8. A. <i>om.</i> betinges. 9.
  C. horyble. 11. A. that (<i>for 1st</i> and). 13. A. to-teren. 15. A. Iangland. // A. this (<i>for
  2nd</i> that). 16. A. inclosed. // C. streyht; A. streit. 17. C. pleynynge; A. pleiyng; Lat.
  <i>ludens</i>. 19. A. Ed. agreable. 24. C. bent; A. bente. 27. A. in-to (<i>for</i> to). 30. C.
  hat; A. hath. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose III.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Vos quoque, o terrena animalia.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Certes also ye men, that ben ertheliche <a href="#BIIIPIIINL1" id="BIIIPIIIL1" class="pginternal">beestes</a>,
    dremen alwey</p>
<p>youre beginninge, al-though it be with a thinne imaginacioun;</p>
<p>and by a maner thoughte, al be it nat cleerly ne parfitly, ye loken</p>
<p>fram a-fer to thilke verray fyn of blisfulnesse; and ther-fore naturel</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page57">{57}</span>entencioun ledeth you to thilke
    verray good, but many maner</p>
<p>errours mis-torneth you ther-fro. Consider now yif that by thilke</p>
<p>thinges, by whiche a man weneth to geten him blisfulnesse, yif</p>
<p>that he may comen to thilke ende that he weneth to come by</p>
<p>nature. For yif that moneye or honours, or thise other forseyde</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thinges bringen to men swich a thing that no good ne fayle hem</p>
<p>ne semeth fayle, certes than wole I graunte that they ben maked</p>
<p>blisful by thilke thinges that they han geten. But yif so be that</p>
<p>thilke thinges ne mowen nat performen that they bi-heten, and</p>
<p>that ther be defaute of manye goodes, sheweth it nat thanne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">cleerly that <a href="#BIIIPIIINL15" id="BIIIPIIIL15" class="pginternal">fals beautee</a> of
    blisfulnesse is knowen and ateint in</p>
<p>thilke thinges? First and forward thou thy-self, that haddest</p>
<p>habundaunces of richesses nat long agon, <a href="#BIIIPIIINL17" id="BIIIPIIIL17" class="pginternal">I axe</a>
    yif that, in the</p>
<p>habundaunce of alle thilke richesses, thou were never anguissous</p>
<p>or sory in thy corage of any wrong or grevaunce that bi-tidde thee</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">on any syde?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod I, 'it ne remembreth me nat that evere I was</p>
<p>so free of my thought that I ne was alwey in anguissh of</p>
<p>som-what.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'And was nat that,' quod she, 'for that <a href="#BIIIPIIINL24" id="BIIIPIIIL24" class="pginternal">thee lakked</a> som-what</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that thou noldest nat han lakked, or elles thou haddest that thou</p>
<p>noldest nat han had?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Right so is it,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne desiredest thou the presence of that oon and the</p>
<p>absence of that other?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">30</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'I graunte wel,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Forsothe,' quod she, 'than nedeth ther som-what that every</p>
<p>man desireth?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Ye, ther nedeth,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod she, 'and he that hath lakke or nede of aught</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">nis nat in every wey suffisaunt to himself?'</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#BIIIPIIINL36" id="BIIIPIIIL36" class="pginternal">'No,'</a> quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'And thou,' quod she, 'in al the plentee of thy richesses haddest</p>
<p>thilke lakke of suffisaunse?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'What elles?' quod I.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">40</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Thanne may nat richesses <a href="#BIIIPIIINL40" id="BIIIPIIIL40" class="pginternal">maken</a> that a man nis nedy, ne that</p>
<p>he be suffisaunt to him-self; and that was it that they <a href="#BIIIPIIINL41" id="BIIIPIIIL41" class="pginternal">bi-highten</a>,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page58">{58}</span>as it semeth. And eek certes I trowe, that this
    be gretly to</p>
<p>considere, that moneye ne hath nat in his owne kinde that it</p>
<p>ne may ben bi-nomen of hem that han it, maugre hem?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">45</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'I bi-knowe it wel,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Why sholdest thou nat bi-knowen it,' quod she, 'whan every</p>
<p>day the strenger folk bi-nemen it fro the febler, maugre hem?</p>
<p>For whennes comen elles alle thise <a href="#BIIIPIIINL48" id="BIIIPIIIL48" class="pginternal">foreyne</a>
    compleyntes or</p>
<p>quereles of pletinges, but for that men axen ayein here moneye</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that hath ben bi-nomen hem by force or by gyle, and alwey</p>
<p>maugre hem?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Right so is it,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Than,' quod she, 'hath a man nede to seken him foreyne</p>
<p>helpe by whiche he may defende his moneye?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">55</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Who may sey nay?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod she; 'and him nedede non help, yif he ne hadde</p>
<p>no moneye that he mighte lese?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'That is douteles,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Than is this thinge torned in-to the contrarye,' quod she.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'For richesses, that men wenen sholde make suffisaunce, they</p>
<p>maken a man rather han nede of foreyne help! Which is</p>
<p>the manere or the gyse,' quod she, 'that richesse may dryve awey</p>
