<p>nede? Riche folk, may they neither han hunger ne thurst?</p>
<p>Thise riche men, may they fele no cold on hir limes on winter?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But thou wolt answeren, that riche men han y-now wher-with they</p>
<p>may staunchen hir hunger, slaken hir thurst, and don a-wey cold.</p>
<p>In this wyse may nede be counforted by richesses; but certes,</p>
<p>nede ne may nat all outrely ben don a-wey. For though this nede,</p>
<p>that is alwey gapinge and gredy, <a href="#BIIIPIIINL69" id="BIIIPIIIL69" class="pginternal">be fulfild</a> with
    richesses, and axe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">any thing, yit dwelleth thanne a nede that mighte be fulfild. I</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIINL71" id="BIIIPIIIL71" class="pginternal">holde me stille, and telle nat</a> how that litel
    thing suffiseth to</p>
<p>nature; but certes to avarice y-nough ne suffiseth no-thing. For</p>
<p>sin that richesses ne may nat al don awey nede, but richesses</p>
<p>maken nede, <a href="#BIIIPIIINL74" id="BIIIPIIIL74" class="pginternal">what may it thanne be</a>, that ye wenen
    that richesses</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">mowen yeven you suffisaunce?</p>
</div>
<p><span class="sc">Pr. III.</span> 2. A. <i>om.</i> youre biginninge. 15. C. ataynt; A. a-teint.
  24. A. that (<i>for</i> And). // A. <i>om.</i> nat that ... for. // A. thou lakkedest; Ed. the
  lacked. 34. A. a wyȝt (<i>for</i> aught). 35. C. suffysaunte; A. suffisaunt. 37, 40. A.
  rycchesse. 46. C. sholdesthow. 47. A. bynymen. // C. febeler<i>e</i>; A. febler. 50. C. <i>om.</i>
  hem. 54. C. deffende. 56. A. nedith. 60. A. rycchesse. 63. A. threst. 64. C. the; A. thei. 65. A.
  y-nouȝ. 66. A. threst. 68. C. <i>om.</i> nat. // C. vtrely; A. outerly. 69, 70. C. fulfyd;
  A. fulfilled (<i>twice</i>). 72. C. aueryce; A. auarice. 73. C. rychesse (<i>1st time only</i>);
  A. rychesse (<i>twice</i>). // C. alwey; A. awey. </p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page59">{59}</span></div>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre III.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quamvis fluente diues auri gurgite.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Al were it so that a riche coveytous man hadde a <a href="#BIIIMIIINL1" id="BIIIMIIIL1" class="pginternal">river</a> fletinge</p>
<p>al of gold, <a href="#BIIIMIIINL2" id="BIIIMIIIL2" class="pginternal">yit sholde it never</a> staunchen his
    coveitise; and though</p>
<p>he hadde his nekke y-charged with precious stones of the <a href="#BIIIMIIINL3" id="BIIIMIIIL3" class="pginternal">rede</a></p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIIINL3" class="pginternal">see</a>, and though he do ere his feldes plentivous with an
    hundred</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">oxen, never ne shal his bytinge bisinesse for-leten him whyl he</p>
<p>liveth, ne the lighte richesses ne sholle nat beren him companye</p>
<p>whan he is ded.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. III.</span> 1. A. <i>om. 2nd</i> a. 2. A. couetise. 4. A.
  erye. // C. feeldes. 6. C. leuith; A. lyueth. // C. shol; A. shal. // C. A. compaignie. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose IV.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Set dignitates.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>But dignitees, to whom they ben comen, maken they him</p>
<p>honorable and reverent? Han they nat so gret strengthe, that</p>
<p>they may putte vertues in the hertes of folk that usen the lordshipes</p>
<p>of hem? Or elles may they don a-wey the vyces? Certes, they</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ne be nat wont to don awey wikkednesse, but they ben wont</p>
<p>rather to shewen wikkednesse. And ther-of comth it that I have</p>
<p>right grete desdeyn, that dignitees ben yeven ofte to wikked</p>
<p>men; for which thing Catullus cleped <i>a consul of Rome, that</i></p>
<p><i>highte</i> Nonius, <a href="#BIIIPIVNL9" id="BIIIPIVL9" class="pginternal">"postum"</a> or <a href="#BIIIPIVNL9" class="pginternal">"boch"</a>; <i>as who seyth, he cleped him</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>a congregacioun of vyces in his brest, as a postum is ful of
    corupcioun</i>,</p>
<p>al were this Nonius set in a chayre of dignitee. Seest thou nat</p>
<p>thanne how gret vilenye dignitees don to wikked men? Certes,</p>
<p>unworthinesse of wikked men sholde be the lasse y-sene, yif they</p>
<p>nere renomed of none honours. <a href="#BIIIPIVNL14" id="BIIIPIVL14" class="pginternal">Certes, thou</a> thyself
    ne mightest</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">nat ben brought with as manye perils as thou mightest suffren</p>
<p>that thou woldest beren the magistrat with <a href="#BIIIPIVNL16" id="BIIIPIVL16" class="pginternal">Decorat</a>; <i>that is to</i></p>
<p><i>seyn, that for no peril that mighte befallen thee by offence of the king</i></p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page60">{60}</span><i>Theodorike, thou noldest nat be felawe in
    governaunce with Decorat</i>;</p>
<p>whan thou saye that he hadde wikked corage of a likerous shrewe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and of an accuser. Ne I ne may nat, for swiche honours, iugen</p>
<p>hem worthy of reverence, that I deme and holde unworthy to han</p>
<p>thilke same honours. Now yif thou saye a man that were fulfild</p>
<p>of wisdom, certes, thou ne mightest nat deme that he were unworthy</p>
<p>to the honour, or elles to the wisdom of which he is</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">fulfild?'—'No,' quod I.—'Certes, dignitees,' quod she,
    'apertienen</p>
<p>proprely to vertu; and vertu transporteth dignitee anon to</p>
<p>thilke man to which she hir-self is conioigned. And for as moche</p>
<p>as honours of poeple ne may nat maken folk digne of honour, it</p>
<p>is wel seyn cleerly that they ne han no propre beautee of dignitee.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And yit men oughten taken more heed in this. For yif it so be</p>
<p>that a wikked wight be so mochel the foulere and the more out-cast,</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIVNL32" id="BIIIPIVL32" class="pginternal">that he is despysed</a> of most folk, so as dignitee
    ne may nat</p>
<p>maken shrewes digne of reverence, the which shrewes dignitee</p>
<p>sheweth to moche folk, thanne maketh dignitee shrewes rather so</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">moche more despysed than preysed; and forsothe <a href="#BIIIPIVNL35" id="BIIIPIVL35" class="pginternal">nat unpunisshed</a>:</p>
<p><i>that is for to seyn, that shrewes revengen hem ayeinward</i></p>
<p><i>up-on dignitees</i>; for they yilden ayein to dignitees as gret guerdoun,</p>
<p>whan they bi-spotten and defoulen dignitees with hir</p>
<p>vilenye. And for as mochel as thou mowe knowe that thilke</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">verray reverence ne may nat <a href="#BIIIPIVNL40" id="BIIIPIVL40" class="pginternal">comen by</a>
    thise shadewy transitorie</p>
<p>dignitees, undirstond now thus: yif that a man hadde used and</p>
<p>had <a href="#BIIIPIVNL42" id="BIIIPIVL42" class="pginternal">many maner</a> dignitees of consules, and were
    comen peraventure</p>
<p>amonge straunge naciouns, sholde thilke honour maken</p>
<p>him worshipful and redouted of straunge folk? Certes, yif that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">honour of poeple were a naturel yift to dignitees, it ne mighte</p>
<p>never cesen nowher amonges no maner folk <a href="#BIIIPIVNL46" id="BIIIPIVL46" class="pginternal">to don his
    office</a>,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page61">{61}</span>right as fyr in every contree ne stinteth nat to
    eschaufen and to</p>
<p>ben hoot. But for as moche as for to ben holden honourable or</p>
<p>reverent ne cometh nat to folk of hir propre strengthe of nature,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">but only of the false opinioun of folk, <i>that is to seyn, <a href="#BIIIPIVNL50" id="BIIIPIVL50" class="pginternal">that wenen</a></i></p>
<p><i>that dignitees maken folk digne of honour</i>; anon therfore whan</p>
<p>that they comen ther-as folk ne knowen nat thilke dignitees, hir</p>
<p>honours vanisshen awey, and that anon. But that is amonges</p>
<p>straunge folk, mayst thou seyn; but amonges hem ther they</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">weren born, ne duren nat thilke dignitees alwey? Certes, the</p>
<p>dignitee of the <a href="#BIIIPIVNL56" id="BIIIPIVL56" class="pginternal">provostrie</a> of Rome was whylom a
    gret power;</p>
<p>now is it nothing but an ydel name, and the <a href="#BIIIPIVNL57" id="BIIIPIVL57" class="pginternal">rente</a>
    of the senatorie</p>
<p>a gret charge. And yif a wight whylom hadde <a href="#BIIIPIVNL58" id="BIIIPIVL58" class="pginternal">the
    office</a> to taken</p>
<p>hede to the vitailes of the poeple, as of corn and other thinges, he</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">was holden amonges grete; but what thing is now more out-cast</p>
<p>thanne thilke provostrie? And, as I have seyd a litel her-biforn,</p>
<p>that thilke thing that hath no propre beautee of him-self receiveth</p>
<p>som-tyme prys and shyninge, and som-tyme leseth it by the</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIVNL64" id="BIIIPIVL64" class="pginternal">opinioun of usaunces</a>. Now yif that dignitees
    thanne ne mowen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">nat maken folk digne of reverence, and yif that dignitees wexen</p>
<p>foule <a href="#BIIIPIVNL66" id="BIIIPIVL66" class="pginternal">of hir wille</a> by the filthe of shrewes, and
    yif that dignitees</p>
<p>lesen hir shyninge by chaunginge of tymes, and yif they wexen</p>
<p>foule by estimacioun of poeple: <a href="#BIIIPIVNL68" id="BIIIPIVL68" class="pginternal">what is it</a> that
    they han in hem-self</p>
<p>of beautee that oughte ben desired? <i>as who seyth, non</i>;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thanne ne mowen they yeven no beautee of dignitee to non other.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. IV.</span> 2. C. honorable, <i>glossed</i> ironice. 3. C.
  lordshippys; A. lordshipes. 5. A. <i>om.</i> ne. // A. wikkednesses (<i>twice</i>); Lat.
  <i>nequitiam</i>. 6. C. <i>om.</i> to <i>bef.</i> shewen. 7. C. desdaign; A. desdeyne. 9. C.
  nomyus; A. nonius. // Ed. postome. 11. C. nomyus. // C. <i>om.</i> a. // C. Sesthow. 12. C.
  fylonye; A. vylenye; Ed. vylonies; Lat. <i>dedecus</i>. 16. C. Ed. the; A. thi. // A. magistrat;
  C. magestrat. 17. A. by the offence; C. by offense; Ed. by offence. 19. Ed. saw. // C. lykoros; A.
  likerous. 22. Ed. sawe. 25. A. Ed. quod she; C. <i>om.</i> 29. C. they, <i>glossed</i>, s. honurs.
  30. A. more; C. mor. // C. <i>om.</i> it. 30-5. A. For if it so be that he that is most out-cast
  that most folk dispisen. or as dignite ne may nat maken shrewes worthi of no reuerences. than
  maketh dignites shrewes more dispised than preised. the whiche shrewes dignit (<i>sic</i>)
  scheweth to moche folk. and forsothe not vnpunissed; Ed. for if a wight be in so muche the more
  outcast, that he is dispysed of moste folke, so as dignyte ne may not maken shrewes worthy of no
  reuerence, than maketh dignite shrewes rather dispysed tha<i>n</i> praysed, the whiche shrewes
  dignite sheweth to moche folk. And forsothe not vnpunisshed. 38. C. A. gerdoun; Ed. guerdons. //
  C. by-spetten; A. byspotten; Lat. <i>commaculant</i>. 40. C. thyse shadwye; A. the shadewy. 41. A.
  this (<i>for</i> thus). 47. A. enchaufen. 50. C. <i>om.</i> that <i>bef.</i> wenen. 53. C.
  vanesshen; A. vanissen. 54. C. maysthow. // A. but; C. Ed. ne. 56, 58. C. whylom; A. som-tyme
  (<i>twice</i>). 57. C. <i>om.</i> the <i>bef.</i> senatorie. 59. A. and what other; Ed. and of
  other. 62. C. resseyueth; A. resceyueth. 66. C. felthe; A. filthe. // C. <i>om.</i> that
  <i>after</i> yif (<i>3rd time only</i>). 70. C. dignete. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre IV.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quamvis se, Tyrio superbus ostro.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Al be it so that the proude Nero, with alle his wode luxurie,</p>
<p>kembde him and aparailede him with faire purpres of <a href="#BIIIMIVNL2" id="BIIIMIVL2" class="pginternal">Tirie</a>,</p>
<p>and with whyte perles, algates yit <a href="#BIIIMIVNL3" id="BIIIMIVL3" class="pginternal">throf</a> he hateful
    to alle folk:</p>
<p><i>this is to seyn, that al was he behated of alle folk</i>. Yit this</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">wikked <i>Nero hadde gret lordship, and</i> yaf whylom to the</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page62">{62}</span><a href="#BIIIMIVNL6" id="BIIIMIVL6" class="pginternal">reverents</a> senatours the <a href="#BIIIMIVNL6" class="pginternal">unworshipful</a> setes of
    dignitees. <i>Unworshipful</i></p>
<p><i>setes he clepeth here, for that Nero, that was so wikked, yaf</i></p>
<p><i>tho dignitees.</i> Who-so wolde thanne resonably wenen, that blisfulnesse</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">were in swiche honours as ben yeven by vicious shrewes?</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. IV.</span> 2. A. kembed; apparailed. 5. C. lorshippe; A.
  lordship. // C. Ed. whylom; A. som-tyme. 6. C. reuerentz; Ed. reuerent; A. dredeful; Lat.
  <i>uerendis</i>. 8. A. tho; C. Ed. the. // A. <i>om.</i> so. 10. C. vysios; A. vicious. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose V.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>An vero regna regumque familiaritas.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>But <a href="#BIIIPVNL1" id="BIIIPVL1" class="pginternal">regnes</a> and <a href="#BIIIPVNL1" class="pginternal">familiaritees</a>
    of kinges, may they maken a</p>
<p>man to ben mighty? <a href="#BIIIPVNL2" id="BIIIPVL2" class="pginternal">How elles, whan</a> hir blisfulnesse
    dureth</p>
<p>perpetuely? But certes, the olde age of tyme passed, and eek</p>
<p>of present tyme now, is ful of ensaumples how that <a href="#BIIIPVNL4" id="BIIIPVL4" class="pginternal">kinges
    ben</a></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIIIPVNL4" class="pginternal">chaunged</a> in-to wrecchednesse out of hir welefulnesse.
    O! a</p>
<p>noble thing and a cleer thing is power, that is nat founden</p>
<p>mighty to kepen it-self! And yif that power of reaumes be</p>
<p>auctour and maker of blisfulnesse, yif thilke power lakketh on</p>
<p>any syde, amenuseth it nat thilke blisfulnesse and bringeth in</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">wrecchednesse? But yit, al be it so that the reaumes of mankinde</p>
<p>strecchen brode, yit mot ther nede ben moche folk, over</p>
<p>whiche that every king ne hath no lordshipe ne comaundement.</p>
<p>And certes, <a href="#BIIIPVNL13" id="BIIIPVL13" class="pginternal">up-on thilke syde that</a> power faileth,
    which that</p>
<p>maketh folk blisful, right on that same syde <a href="#BIIIPVNL14" id="BIIIPVL14" class="pginternal">noun-power</a> entreth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">under-nethe, that maketh hem wrecches; in this manere thanne</p>
<p>moten kinges han more porcioun of wrecchednesse than of</p>
<p>welefulnesse. <a href="#BIIIPVNL17" id="BIIIPVL17" class="pginternal">A tyraunt</a>, <i>that was king of
    Sisile</i>, that hadde</p>
<p>assayed the peril of his estat, shewede by similitude the dredes</p>
<p>of reaumes by gastnesse of a swerd that heng over the heved</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>of his familier</i>. What thing is thanne this power, that may nat</p>
<p>don awey the bytinges of bisinesse, ne eschewe the prikkes of</p>
<p>drede? And certes, yit wolden they liven in sikernesse, but</p>
<p>they may nat; and yit they glorifye hem in hir power. Holdest</p>
<p>thou thanne that thilke man be mighty, that thou seest that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">he wolde don that he may nat don? And holdest thou thanne</p>
<p>him a mighty man, that hath envirownede his sydes with men</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page63">{63}</span>of armes or <a href="#BIIIPVNL27" id="BIIIPVL27" class="pginternal">seriaunts</a>, and dredeth more hem that he maketh</p>
<p>agast than they dreden him, and that is put in the handes of</p>
<p>his servaunts for he sholde seme mighty?  But of familieres</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">or servaunts of kinges <a href="#BIIIPVNL30" id="BIIIPVL30" class="pginternal">what</a> sholde I
    telle thee anything, sin</p>
<p>that I myself have shewed thee that reaumes hem-self ben</p>
<p>ful of gret feblesse? The whiche familieres, certes, the ryal</p>
<p>power of kinges, <a href="#BIIIPVNL33" id="BIIIPVL33" class="pginternal">in hool</a> estat and in estat abated,
    ful ofte</p>
<p>throweth adown. <a href="#BIIIPVNL34" id="BIIIPVL34" class="pginternal">Nero</a> constreynede Senek, his
    familier and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">his mayster, to chesen on what deeth he wolde deyen. <a href="#BIIIPVNL35" id="BIIIPVL35" class="pginternal">Antonius</a></p>
<p>comaundede that knightes slowen with hir swerdes Papinian</p>
<p><i>his familier</i>, which Papinian hadde ben longe tyme ful mighty</p>
<p>amonges hem of the court. And yit, certes, they wolden bothe</p>
<p>han renounced hir power; of whiche two <a href="#BIIIPVNL39" id="BIIIPVL39" class="pginternal">Senek</a>
    enforcede him</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to yeven to Nero his richesses, and also to han gon in-to</p>
<p>solitarie exil. <a href="#BIIIPVNL41" id="BIIIPVL41" class="pginternal">But whan</a> the grete weighte, <i>that
    is to seyn</i>, of</p>
<p><i>lordes power or of fortune</i>, draweth hem that shullen falle,</p>
<p>neither of hem ne mighte do that he wolde. What thing is</p>
<p>thanne thilke power, that though men han it, yit they ben agast;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and whanne thou woldest han it, thou nart nat siker; and</p>
<p>yif thou woldest forleten it, thou mayst nat eschuen it? But</p>
<p>whether swiche men ben frendes at nede, as ben conseyled by</p>
<p>fortune and nat by vertu? Certes, <a href="#BIIIPVNL48" id="BIIIPVL48" class="pginternal">swiche folk</a> as
    weleful</p>
<p>fortune maketh freendes, contrarious fortune maketh hem</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">enemys. And what <a href="#BIIIPVNL50" id="BIIIPVL50" class="pginternal">pestilence</a> is more
    mighty for to anoye a</p>
<p>wight than a familier enemy?</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. V.</span> 3. C. perpetualy; A. perpetuely. 7. A. realmes. 8.
  C. auctor; A. auctour. 10. A. realmes (<i>om.</i> the). 11. C. node (<i>for</i> nede). 12. C.
  lorshipe. 14. C. A. nou<i>n</i>power. 19. A. realmes. 20. C. famyler. 23. A. yit; C. yif. 24. C.
  seyst; A. seest; Lat. <i>uideas</i>. 27. A. seruauntes. // A. <i>om.</i> hem. 31. A. realmes. 32.
  A. feblenesse. // A. real; Ed. royal. 34. C. hyr famyler (<i>sic</i>); A. his familier. 37. C.
  famyler; A. familier. // C. that hadde; A. <i>om.</i> that. 41. C. solutarie; A. solitarie. 42. C.
  sholen; Ed. shullen; A. sholden; Lat. <i>ruituros</i>. 44. C. yit; Ed. yet; A. that. 47. C.
  wheyther. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre V.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Qui se uolet esse potentem.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Who-so wol be mighty, he mot daunten his cruel <a href="#BIIIMVNL1" id="BIIIMVL1" class="pginternal">corage</a>,</p>
<p>ne putte nat his nekke, overcomen, under the foule reynes of</p>
<p>lecherye. For al-be-it so that thy lordshipe strecche so fer,</p>
<p>that the contree of Inde quaketh at thy comaundements or at</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thy lawes, and that the last <i>ile in the see, that hight</i> <a href="#BIIIMVNL5" id="BIIIMVL5" class="pginternal">Tyle</a>,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page64">{64}</span>be thral to thee, yit, yif thou mayst nat putten
    awey thy foule</p>
<p>derke desyrs, and dryven out fro thee wrecched complaintes,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">8</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">certes, it nis no power that thou hast.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. V.</span> 1. C. wole; Ed. wol; A. wolde. 4. C. thath (!). //
  A. contre Inde. // A. comaundement. 5. A. leest (<i>for</i> last); Lat. <i>ultima</i>. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose VI.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Gloria uero quam fallax saepe.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>But glorie, how deceivable and how foul is it ofte! For</p>
<p>which thing nat unskilfully a tragedien, <i>that is to seyn, a maker</i></p>
<p><i>of ditees that highten <a href="#BIIIPVINL3" id="BIIIPVIL3" class="pginternal">tragedies</a></i>, cryde and
    seide: "<a href="#BIIIPVINL3" class="pginternal">O glorie</a>,</p>
<p>glorie," quod he, "thou art nothing elles to thousandes of folkes</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">but a greet sweller of eres!" For manye han had ful greet</p>
<p>renoun by the false opinioun of the poeple, and what thing</p>
<p>may ben thought fouler than swiche preysinge? For thilke folk</p>
<p>that ben preysed falsly, they moten nedes han shame of hir</p>
<p>preysinges. And yif that folk han geten hem thonk or preysinge</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">by hir desertes, what thing hath thilke prys eched or</p>
<p>encresed to the conscience of wyse folk, that mesuren hir good,</p>
<p>nat by the rumour of the poeple, but by the soothfastnesse of</p>
<p>conscience? And yif it seme a fair thing, a man to han</p>
<p>encresed and spred his name, than folweth it that it is demed</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to ben a foul thing, yif it ne be y-sprad and encresed. But,</p>
<p>as I seyde a litel her-biforn that, sin ther mot nedes ben many</p>
<p>folk, to whiche folk the renoun of a man ne may nat comen,</p>
<p>it befalleth that he, that thou wenest be glorious and renomed,</p>
<p>semeth in the nexte partie of the erthes to ben with-oute glorie</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and with-oute renoun.</p>
<p class="stanza">And certes, amonges thise thinges I ne trowe nat that the</p>
<p>prys and grace of the poeple nis neither worthy to ben</p>
<p>remembred, ne cometh of wyse Iugement, ne is ferme perdurably.</p>
<p>But now, of this name of <a href="#BIIIPVINL24" id="BIIIPVIL24" class="pginternal">gentilesse</a>, what man is
    it</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that ne may wel seen how veyn and how flittinge a thing it</p>
<p>is? For yif the name of gentilesse be referred to renoun and</p>
<p>cleernesse of linage, thanne is gentil name but a foreine thing,</p>
<p><i>that is to seyn, to hem that glorifyen hem of hir linage</i>. For it</p>
<p>semeth that gentilesse be a maner preysinge that comth of the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page65">{65}</span>deserte of ancestres. And yif
    preysinge maketh gentilesse,</p>
<p>thanne moten they nedes be gentil that ben preysed. For</p>
<p>which thing it folweth, that yif thou ne have no gentilesse of</p>
<p>thy-self, <i>that is to seyn, preyse that comth of thy deserte</i>, foreine</p>
<p>gentilesse ne maketh thee nat gentil. But certes, yif ther be</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">any good in gentilesse, I trowe it be al-only this, that it semeth</p>
<p>as that a maner necessitee be imposed to gentil men, for that</p>
<p>they ne sholden nat outrayen or forliven fro the virtues of hir</p>
<p>noble kinrede.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. VI.</span> 4. A. Ed. he; C. she (!). 6. A. <i>om.</i> the
  <i>bef.</i> poeple. 9. C. of (<i>for</i> or). 15. A. ne encresed. 19. A. parties of the erthe;
  Lat. <i>parte terrarum</i>. 23. C. remenbred. 24, 26, 29. C. gentellesse; A. gentilesse. 26. C.
  refferred. 30. A. decert; Ed. desert<i>es</i>. 32. A. folweth; C. folueth. 36. C. inposed. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre VI.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Omne hominum genus in terris.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Al the linage of men that ben in erthe ben of semblable</p>
<p>birthe. On allone is fader of thinges. On allone ministreth</p>
<p>alle thinges. He yaf to the sonne hise bemes; he yaf to the</p>
<p>mone hir hornes. He yaf the men to the erthe; he yaf the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">sterres to the hevene. He encloseth with membres the soules</p>
<p>that comen fro his hye sete. Thanne comen alle mortal folk</p>
<p>of noble sede; why noisen ye or bosten of youre eldres? For</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMVINL8" id="BIIIMVIL8" class="pginternal">yif thou loke your</a> biginninge, and god your auctor
    and your</p>
<p>maker, thanne nis ther no <a href="#BIIIMVINL9" id="BIIIMVIL9" class="pginternal">forlived</a> wight, but-yif he
    norisshe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">his corage un-to vyces, and forlete his propre burthe.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. VI.</span> 4. A. Ed. hir hornes; C. hyse hornes. 5. C.
  menbrys. 8. Ed. ye loke; Lat. <i>spectes</i>. // A. thy (<i>for 1st</i> your); Lat. <i>uestra</i>.
  </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose VII.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quid autem de corporis uoluptatibus.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>But what shal I seye of <a href="#BIIIPVIINL1" id="BIIIPVIIL1" class="pginternal">delices</a> of body, of whiche
    delices the</p>
<p>desiringes ben ful of anguissh, and the fulfillinges of hem ben ful</p>
<p>of penaunce? How greet syknesse and how grete sorwes unsufferable,</p>
<p>right as a maner fruit of wikkednesse, ben thilke delices</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">wont to bringen to the bodies of folk that usen hem! Of whiche</p>
<p>delices I not what Ioye may ben had of hir moevinge. But this</p>
<p>wot I wel, that who-so-ever wole remembren him of hise luxures,</p>
<p>he shal wel understonde that the issues of delices ben sorwful</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page66">{66}</span>and sorye. And yif thilke delices mowen maken
    folk blisful,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">than by the same cause moten thise bestes ben cleped blisful;</p>
<p>of whiche bestes al the entencioun hasteth to fulfille hir bodily</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVIINL12" id="BIIIPVIIL12" class="pginternal">Iolitee</a>. And the gladnesse of wyf and children
    were an honest</p>
<p>thing, but it hath ben seyd that it is over muchel ayeins kinde,</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVIINL14" id="BIIIPVIIL14" class="pginternal">that children</a> han ben founden tormentours to hir
    fadres, I not</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">how manye: of whiche children how <a href="#BIIIPVIINL15" id="BIIIPVIIL15" class="pginternal">bytinge</a> is every condicioun,</p>
<p>it nedeth nat to tellen it thee, that hast <a href="#BIIIPVIINL16" id="BIIIPVIIL16" class="pginternal">or</a>
    this tyme assayed</p>
<p>it, and art yit now anguissous. In this approve I the sentence</p>
<p>of my disciple <a href="#BIIIPVIINL18" id="BIIIPVIIL18" class="pginternal">Euripidis</a>, that seyde, that "he
    that hath no</p>
<p>children is weleful by infortune."</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. VII.</span> 12. A. <i>om.</i> an. 15. A. Ed. euery; C.
  eu<i>er</i>e. 18. Ed. Euripidis; C. Eurydyppys; A. Euridippus; Lat. <i>Euripidis</i> (gen.). </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre VII.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Habet omnis hoc uoluptas.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Every delyt hath this, that it anguissheth hem with prikkes</p>
<p>that usen it. It resembleth to thise flyinge flyes that we clepen</p>
<p>been, that, after that he hath shad hise agreable honies, <a href="#BIIIMVIINL3" id="BIIIMVIIL3" class="pginternal">he fleeth</a></p>
<p>awey, and stingeth the hertes, of hem that ben y-smite, with</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">bytinge overlonge holdinge.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. VII.</span> 1. C. A. anguisseth. 3. C. <i>om. 2nd</i> that. //
  A. the bee (<i>for</i> he). </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose VIII.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Nihil igitur dubium est.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Now is it no doute thanne <a href="#BIIIPVIIINL1" id="BIIIPVIIIL1" class="pginternal">that thise weyes</a> ne
    ben a maner</p>
<p>misledinges to blisfulnesse, ne that they ne mowe nat leden</p>
<p>folk thider as they biheten to leden hem. But with how grete</p>
<p>harmes thise forseyde weyes ben enlaced, I shal shewe thee</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">shortly. For-why yif thou enforcest thee to asemble moneye,</p>
<p>thou most bireven him his moneye that hath it. And yif</p>
<p>thou wolt shynen with dignitees, thou most bisechen and</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVIIINL8" id="BIIIPVIIIL8" class="pginternal">supplien</a> hem that yeven tho dignitees. And yif
    thou coveitest</p>
<p>by honour to gon biforn other folk, thou shalt defoule thy-self</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thorugh humblesse of axinge. Yif thou desirest power, thou</p>
<p>shalt by <a href="#BIIIPVIIINL11" id="BIIIPVIIIL11" class="pginternal">awaytes</a> of thy subgits anoyously ben
    cast under manye</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page67">{67}</span>periles. Axest thou glorie? Thou shalt ben so <a href="#BIIIPVIIINL12" id="BIIIPVIIIL12" class="pginternal">destrat</a> by aspre</p>
<p>thinges that thou shalt forgoon sikernesse. And yif thou wolt</p>
<p>leden thy lyf in delices, every wight shal despisen thee and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">forleten thee, as thou that art thral to thing that is right foul</p>
<p>and <a href="#BIIIPVIIINL16" id="BIIIPVIIIL16" class="pginternal">brotel</a>; that is to seyn, servaunt to thy
    body. Now is it</p>
<p>thanne wel seen, how litel and how brotel possessioun they</p>
<p>coveiten, that putten the goodes of the body aboven hir owne</p>
<p>resoun. For mayst thou sormounten thise olifaunts in gretnesse</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">or weight of body? Or mayst thou ben stronger than the bole?</p>
<p>Mayst thou ben swifter than the tygre? Bihold the spaces and</p>
<p>the stablenesse and the swifte cours of the hevene, and stint</p>
<p>som-tyme to wondren on foule thinges; the which hevene, certes,</p>
<p>nis nat rather for thise thinges to ben wondred up-on, than for</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the resoun by which it is governed. But the shyning of thy</p>
<p>forme, <i>that is to seyn, the beautee of thy body</i>, how swiftly passinge</p>
<p>is it, and how transitorie; certes, it is more flittinge than the</p>
<p>mutabilitee of flowers of the <a href="#BIIIPVIIINL28" id="BIIIPVIIIL28" class="pginternal">somer-sesoun</a>.
    For so <a href="#BIIIPVIIINL28" class="pginternal">Aristotle</a></p>
<p>telleth, that yif that men hadden eyen of a beest that highte</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">lynx, so that the lokinge of folk mighte percen thorugh the</p>
<p>thinges that with-stonden it, who-so loked thanne in the entrailes</p>
<p>of the body of Alcibiades, that was ful fayr in the superfice</p>
<p>with-oute, it shold seme right foul. And forthy, yif thou semest</p>
<p>fayr, thy nature maketh nat that, but the desceivaunce of the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">feblesse of the eyen that loken. But preyse the goodes of the</p>
<p>body as mochel as ever thee list; so that thou knowe algates</p>
<p>that, what-so it be, <i>that is to seyn, of the goodes of thy body</i>,</p>
<p>which that thou wondrest up-on, may ben destroyed or dissolved</p>
<p>by the hete of a fevere of three dayes. Of alle whiche forseyde</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thinges I may reducen this shortly in a somme, that thise worldly</p>
<p>goodes, whiche that ne mowen nat yeven that they biheten, ne</p>
<p>ben nat parfit by the congregacioun of alle goodes; that they</p>
<p>ne ben nat weyes ne pathes that bringen men to blisfulnesse,</p>
<p>ne maken men to ben blisful.</p>
</div>
<p><span class="sc">Pr. VIII.</span> 9. C. shal. 10. A. by (<i>for</i> thorugh). 11. C. be
  (<i>for</i> by). // A. vndir many; C. Ed. vndyr by many; Lat. <i>periculis subiacebis</i>. 12. C.
  A. destrat; Ed. distracte. 16. C. brwtel (<i>for</i> brotel; <i>1st time</i>). 19. A. mayst thou;
  C. maysthow. 20. C. weyhty (!). 32. C. in superfyce (<i>om.</i> the). 34. A. desceiuaunce of the;
  Ed. disceyuaunce of; C. deceyuable or (!). 37. A. the goodes of thi; Ed. the goodes of the; C.
  godes of the. 40. A. Ed. a somme; C. <i>om.</i> a. //  C. wordly. 42. C. ne ne ben. // A. Ed. by
  the; C. <i>om.</i> the. 43. C. man (<i>for</i> men; <i>1st time</i>). </p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page68">{68}</span></div>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre VIII.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Eheu! quae miseros tramite deuios.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Allas! which folye and which ignoraunce misledeth wandringe</p>
<p>wrecches fro the path of verray goode!</p>
<p class="stanza">Certes, ye ne seken no gold in grene trees, ne ye ne gaderen</p>
<p>nat precious stones in the vynes, ne ye ne hyden nat your</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIIIMVIIINL5" id="BIIIMVIIIL5" class="pginternal">ginnes</a> in the hye mountaignes to
    cacchen fish of whiche ye</p>
<p>may maken riche festes. And yif yow lyketh to hunte to roes,</p>
<p>ye ne gon nat to the fordes of the water that highte <a href="#BIIIMVIIINL7" id="BIIIMVIIIL7" class="pginternal">Tyrene</a>.</p>
<p>And over this, men knowen wel the crykes and the cavernes</p>
<p>of the see y-hid in the flodes, and knowen eek which water</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">is most plentivous of whyte perles, and knowen which water</p>
<p>haboundeth most of rede purpre, <i>that is to seyn, of a maner</i></p>
<p><i>shelle-fish with which men dyen purpre</i>; and knowen which</p>
<p>strondes habounden most with tendre fisshes, or of sharpe fisshes</p>
<p>that highten <a href="#BIIIMVIIINL14" id="BIIIMVIIIL14" class="pginternal">echines</a>. But folk suffren
    hem-self to ben so blinde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that hem ne reccheth nat to knowe where thilke goodes ben</p>
<p>y-hid whiche that they coveiten, but ploungen hem in erthe</p>
<p>and seken there thilke good that sormounteth the hevene that</p>
<p>bereth the sterres. What preyere may I maken that be digne</p>
<p>to the nyce thoughtes of men? But I preye that they coveiten</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">richesse and honours, so that, whan they han geten tho false</p>
<p>goodes with greet travaile, that ther-by they mowe knowen the</p>
<p>verray goodes.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. VIII.</span> 4. A. <i>om.</i> nat. 5. C. hyye mountaygnes; A.
  heyȝe mountaignes. // C. kachche; A. kachen; Ed. catchen (= cacchen). 6. C. honte; A. Ed.
  hunte. // C. rooes; Ed. roes; A. roos. 8. A. crikes; Ed. crekes; C. brykes; Lat. <i>recessus</i>.
  9. A. Ed. in the; C. <i>om.</i> the. 14. Ed. Echines; C. A. echynnys. 15. C. rechcheth; A.
  recchith. // C. weer<i>e</i> (<i>for</i> where). </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose IX.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Hactenus mendacis formam.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>It suffyseth that I have shewed hider-to the forme of false</p>
<p>welefulnesse, so that, yif thou loke now cleerly, the order of</p>
<p>myn entencioun requireth from hennes-forth to shewen thee the</p>
<p>verray welefulnesse.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">5</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page69">{69}</span>'For sothe,' quod I, 'I see
    wel now that suffisaunce may nat</p>
<p>comen by richesses, ne power by reames, ne reverence by</p>
<p>dignitees, ne gentilesse by glorie, ne Ioye by delices.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'And hast thou wel knowen the causes,' quod she, 'why it is?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes, me semeth,' quod I, 'that I see hem right as though</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">it were <a href="#BIIIPIXNL10" id="BIIIPIXL10" class="pginternal">thorugh a litel clifte</a>; but
    me were levere knowen hem</p>
<p>more openly of thee.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod she, 'the resoun is al redy. For thilke thing</p>
<p>that simply is o thing, with-outen any devisioun, the errour</p>
<p>and folye of mankinde departeth and devydeth it, and <a href="#BIIIPIXNL14" id="BIIIPIXL14" class="pginternal">misledeth</a></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">it and transporteth from verray and parfit good to goodes that</p>
<p>ben false and unparfit. But sey me this. <a href="#BIIIPIXNL16" id="BIIIPIXL16" class="pginternal">Wenest
    thou</a> that</p>
<p>he, that hath nede of power, that him ne lakketh no-thing?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Nay,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod she, 'thou seyst a-right. For yif so be that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ther is a thing, that in any partye be febler of power, certes,</p>
<p>as in that, it mot nedes ben nedy of foreine help.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Right so is it,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Suffisaunce and power ben thanne of o kinde?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'So semeth it,' quod I.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">25</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'And demest thou,' quod she, 'that a thing that is of this</p>
<p>manere, <i>that is to seyn, suffisaunt and mighty</i>, oughte ben</p>
<p>despysed, or elles that it be right digne of reverence aboven</p>
<p>alle thinges?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod I, 'it nis no doute, that it is right worthy to</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ben reverenced.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Lat us,' quod she, 'adden thanne reverence to suffisaunce</p>
<p>and to power, so that we demen that thise three thinges ben</p>
<p>al o thing.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod I, 'lat us adden it, yif we wolen graunten the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">sothe.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'What demest thou thanne?' quod she; 'is that a derk thing</p>
<p>and nat noble, <i>that is suffisaunt, reverent, and mighty</i>, or elles that</p>
<p>it is right noble and right cleer by celebritee of renoun? <a href="#BIIIPIXNL38" id="BIIIPIXL38" class="pginternal">Consider</a></p>
<p>thanne,' quod she, 'as we han graunted her-biforn, that he that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page70">{70}</span>ne hath nede of no-thing, and is
    most mighty and most digne</p>
<p>of honour, yif him nedeth any cleernesse of renoun, which</p>
<p>cleernesse he mighte nat graunten of him-self, so that, for lakke</p>
<p>of thilke cleernesse, he mighte seme the febeler on any syde</p>
<p>or the more out-cast?' <b>Glose.</b> <i>This is to seyn, nay; for who-so</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>that is suffisaunt, mighty, and reverent, cleernesse of renoun
    folweth</i></p>
<p><i>of the forseyde thinges; he hath it al redy of his suffisaunce.</i></p>
<p class="stanza"><i>Boece.</i> 'I may nat,' quod I, 'denye it; but I mot graunte</p>
<p>as it is, that this thing be right celebrable by cleernesse of renoun</p>
<p>and noblesse.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">50</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Thanne folweth it,' quod she, 'that we adden cleernesse of</p>
<p>renoun to the three forseyde thinges, so that ther ne be amonges</p>
<p>hem no difference?'</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#BIIIPIXNL53" id="BIIIPIXL53" class="pginternal">'This is a consequence,'</a> quod
    I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'This thing thanne,' quod she, 'that ne hath nede of no</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">foreine thing, and that may don alle thinges by hise strengthes,</p>
<p>and that is noble and honourable, nis nat that a mery thing</p>
<p>and a Ioyful?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'But whennes,' quod I, 'that any sorwe mighte comen to this</p>
<p>thing that is swiche, certes, I may nat thinke.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">60</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Thanne moten we graunte,' quod she, 'that this thing be</p>
<p>ful of gladnesse, yif the forseyde thinges ben sothe; and certes,</p>
<p>also mote we graunten that suffisaunce, power, noblesse, reverence,</p>
<p>and gladnesse ben only dyverse by names, but hir substaunce</p>
<p>hath no diversitee.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">65</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'It mot needly been so,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thilke thing thanne,' quod she, 'that is oon and simple</p>
<p>in his nature, the wikkednesse of men departeth it and devydeth</p>
<p>it; and whan they enforcen hem to geten partye of a thing</p>
<p>that ne hath no part, <a href="#BIIIPIXNL69" id="BIIIPIXL69" class="pginternal">they ne geten hem</a> neither
    thilke partye that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">nis non, ne the thing al hool that they ne desire nat.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'In which manere?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thilke man,' quod she, 'that secheth richesses to fleen</p>
<p>povertee, he ne travaileth him nat for to gete power; for he</p>
<p>hath levere ben derk and vyl; and eek withdraweth from</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">him-self many naturel delyts, for he nolde lese the moneye that</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page71">{71}</span>he hath assembled. But certes, in this manere he
    ne geteth</p>
<p>him nat suffisaunce <a href="#BIIIPIXNL77" id="BIIIPIXL77" class="pginternal">that power forleteth</a>, and that
    molestie</p>
<p>prikketh, and that filthe maketh out-cast, and that derkenesse</p>
<p>hydeth. And certes, he that desireth only power, he wasteth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and scatereth richesse, and despyseth delyts, and eek honour</p>
<p>that is with-oute power, ne he ne preyseth glorie no-thing.</p>
<p>Certes, thus seest thou wel, that manye thinges faylen to him;</p>
<p>for he hath som-tyme defaute of many necessitees, and many</p>
<p>anguisshes byten him; and whan he ne may nat don tho defautes</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">85</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">a-wey, he forleteth to ben mighty, and that is the thing that</p>
<p>he most desireth. And right thus may I maken semblable</p>
<p>resouns of honours, and of glorie, and of delyts. For so as</p>
<p>every of thise forseyde thinges is the same that thise other</p>
<p>thinges ben, <i>that is to seyn, al oon thing</i>, who-so that ever</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">seketh to geten that oon of thise, and nat that other, he ne</p>
<p>geteth nat that he desireth.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><i>Boece.</i> 'What seyst thou thanne, yif that a man coveiteth</p>
<p>to geten alle thise thinges to-gider?'</p>
<p class="stanza"><i>Philosophie.</i> 'Certes,' quod she, 'I wolde seye, that he wolde</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">geten him sovereyn blisfulnesse; but <a href="#BIIIPIXNL95" id="BIIIPIXL95" class="pginternal">that shal he nat finde</a> in</p>
<p>tho thinges that I have shewed, that ne mowen nat yeven that</p>
<p>they beheten.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes, no,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne,' quod she, 'ne sholden men nat by no wey seken</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">blisfulnesse in swiche thinges as men wene that they ne mowen</p>
<p>yeven but o thing senglely of alle that men seken.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'I graunte wel,' quod I; 'ne no sother thing ne may ben</p>
<p>sayd.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Now hast thou thanne,' quod she, 'the forme and the causes</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of false welefulnesse. Now torne and flitte the eyen of thy</p>
<p>thought; for ther shalt thou sen anon thilke verray blisfulnesse</p>
<p>that I have bihight thee.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod I, 'it is cleer and open, thogh it were to</p>
<p>a blinde man; and that shewedest thou me ful wel a litel her-biforn,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">whan thou enforcedest thee to shewe me the causes</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page72">{72}</span>of the false blisfulnesse. For but-yif I be
    bigyled, thanne</p>
<p>is thilke the verray blisfulnesse parfit, that parfitly maketh a</p>
<p>man suffisaunt, mighty, honourable, noble, and ful of gladnesse.</p>
<p>And, for thou shalt wel knowe that I have wel understonden</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thise thinges with-in my herte, I knowe wel that thilke blisfulnesse,</p>
<p>that may verrayly yeven oon of the forseyde thinges, sin</p>
<p>they ben al oon, I knowe, douteles, that thilke thing is the</p>
<p>fulle blisfulnesse.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><i>Philosophie.</i> 'O my <a href="#BIIIPIXNL119" id="BIIIPIXL119" class="pginternal">norie</a>,'
    quod she, 'by this opinioun I</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">120</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">seye that thou art blisful, yif thou putte this ther-to that I</p>
<p>shal seyn.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'What is that?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Trowest thou that ther be any thing in thise erthely mortal</p>
<p>toumbling thinges that may bringen this estat?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">125</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Certes,' quod I, 'I trowe it naught; and thou hast shewed</p>
<p>me wel that over thilke good ther nis no-thing more to ben</p>
<p>desired.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thise thinges thanne,' quod she, '<i>that is to sey, erthely</i></p>
<p><i>suffisaunce and power and swiche thinges</i>, either they semen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">lykenesses of verray good, or elles it semeth that they yeve to</p>
<p>mortal folk a maner of goodes that ne ben nat parfit; but thilke</p>
<p>good that is verray and parfit, that may they nat yeven.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'I acorde me wel,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne,' quod she, 'for as mochel as thou hast knowen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">135</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">which is thilke verray blisfulnesse, and eek whiche thilke thinges</p>
<p>ben <a href="#BIIIPIXNL136" id="BIIIPIXL136" class="pginternal">that lyen</a> falsly blisfulnesse, <i>that is to
    seyn, that by deceite</i></p>
<p><i>semen verray goodes</i>, now behoveth thee to knowe whennes and</p>
<p>where thou mowe seke thilke verray blisfulnesse.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod I, 'that desire I greetly, and have abiden longe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">tyme to herknen it.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'But for as moche,' quod she, 'as it lyketh to my disciple</p>
<p>Plato, in his book of <a href="#BIIIPIXNL142" id="BIIIPIXL142" class="pginternal">"in Timeo,"</a> that in right
    litel thinges men</p>
<p>sholden bisechen the help of god, what iugest thou that be now</p>
<p>to done, so that we may deserve to finde the sete of thilke</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">145</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">verray good?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod I, 'I deme that we shollen clepen the fader</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page73">{73}</span>of alle goodes; for with-outen him nis ther
    no-thing founden</p>
<p>a-right.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thou seyst a-right,' quod she; and bigan anon to singen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">150</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">right thus:—</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. IX.</span> 5. A. <i>om.</i> sothe <i>and 2nd</i> I. 6. A.
  richesse. // A. Ed. realmes. 8. A. hast thou; C.hasthow. // A. cause; Lat. <i>caussas</i>. 16. A.
  inparfit. // C. Wenesthow. 20. A. fieble; C. Ed. febler; Lat. <i>imbecillioris ualentiae</i>. 21.
  C. mot; Ed. mote; A. most. 25. C. demesthow. 29. A. nis (<i>twice</i>). 36. C. demesthow. // Ed.
  derke; C. dyrk; A. dirke. 38. A. of (<i>for</i> by). 53. A. And this (<i>for</i> This). // C.
  consequens; Ed. consequence; A. consequente <i>or</i> consequence. 54. C. hat (<i>for</i> hath).
  // A. no nede. 58. Ed. whence; A. wenest (!); Lat. <i>unde</i>. 72. A. rychesse. 74. Ed. derke; C.
  dyrk; A. dirk. 75. C. delices (<i>or</i> delites); A. delitz; Ed. delytes. 77. Ed. molestie; C. A.
  moleste; Lat. <i>molestia</i>. 78. A. derknesse; C. dyrkenesse. 80. C. schatereth. // C. delytz;
  A. delices (<i>or</i> delites). 83. C. Ed. defaute; A. faute. 84. Ed. anguysshes; A. anguysses; C.
  angwyssos. 86. A. semblable; C. semlable. 90. C. oothr<i>e</i>. 92. C. seysthow. 101. C. A.
  senglely. 104. C. hasthow. 106. C. shalthow. 109. A. <i>om.</i> ful wel. 115. C. Ed. that thilke;
  A. <i>om.</i> that. 118. A. the fulle of (<i>wrongly</i>). 119. C. norye; A. nurry. 130. A.
  likenesse; Lat. <i>imagines</i>. 141. A. disciple; C. dissipule. 142. C. in tymeo; A. in thimeo;
  Lat. <i>uti in Timaeo Platoni</i>. 143. C. byshechen. // A. <i>om.</i> now. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre IX.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>O qui perpetua mundum ratione gubernas.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>'O thou fader, creator of hevene and of erthes, that governest</p>
<p>this world by perdurable resoun, that comaundest the tymes to</p>
<p>gon from <a href="#BIIIMIXNL3" id="BIIIMIXL3" class="pginternal">sin that age hadde beginninge</a>; thou that
    dwellest</p>
<p>thy-self ay stedefast and stable, and yevest alle othre thinges</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to ben moeved; ne foreine causes <a href="#BIIIMIXNL5" id="BIIIMIXL5" class="pginternal">necesseden</a> thee never to</p>
<p>compoune werk of <a href="#BIIIMIXNL6" id="BIIIMIXL6" class="pginternal">floteringe matere</a>, but only the
    forme of</p>
<p>soverein good y-set with-in thee with-oute envye, <i>that moevede</i></p>
<p><i>thee freely</i>. Thou that art alder-fayrest, <a href="#BIIIMIXNL8" id="BIIIMIXL8" class="pginternal">beringe</a> the faire world</p>
<p>in thy thought, formedest this world to the lyknesse semblable</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of that faire world in thy thought. Thou drawest al thing of</p>
<p>thy soverein ensaumpler, and comaundest that this world,</p>
<p>parfitliche y-maked, have freely and absolut his parfit parties.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIXNL13" id="BIIIMIXL13" class="pginternal">Thou bindest</a> the elements by noumbres
    proporcionables, that</p>
<p>the <a href="#BIIIMIXNL14" id="BIIIMIXL14" class="pginternal">colde</a> thinges mowen acorden with the hote
    thinges, and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the drye thinges with the moiste thinges; that the fyr, that</p>
<p>is purest, ne flee nat over hye, ne that the hevinesse ne drawe</p>
<p>nat adoun over-lowe the erthes that ben plounged in the wateres.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIXNL18" id="BIIIMIXL18" class="pginternal">Thou knittest</a> to-gider the mene sowle of treble
    kinde, moevinge</p>
<p>alle thinges, and devydest it by membres acordinge; and whan</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">it is thus devyded, it hath asembled a moevinge in-to two</p>
<p>roundes; it goth to torne ayein to him-self, and envirouneth a</p>
<p>ful deep thought, and torneth the hevene by semblable image.</p>
<p>Thou by evene-lyke causes enhansest the sowles and the lasse</p>
<p>lyves, and, ablinge hem heye by lighte <a href="#BIIIMIXNL24" id="BIIIMIXL24" class="pginternal">cartes</a>,
    thou sowest hem</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">in-to hevene and in-to erthe; and whan they ben converted to</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page74">{74}</span>thee by thy benigne lawe, thou makest hem
    retorne ayein to</p>
<p>thee by ayein-ledinge fyr.</p>
<p class="stanza">O fader, yive thou to the thought to styen up in-to thy streite</p>
<p>sete, and graunte him to enviroune the welle of good; and, the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">lighte y-founde, graunte him to fichen the clere sightes of his</p>
<p>corage in thee. And scater thou and to-breke thou the weightes</p>
<p>and the cloudes of erthely hevinesse, and shyne thou by thy</p>
<p>brightnesse. For thou art cleernesse; thou art peysible reste</p>
<p>to debonaire folk; thou thy-self art biginninge, <a href="#BIIIMIXNL34" id="BIIIMIXL34" class="pginternal">berer</a>, leder, path,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and terme; to loke on thee, that is our ende.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. IX.</span> 3. A. for to gon. // C. from sin that; A. from tyme
  that; Ed. syth that. 7. A. <i>om.</i> thee <i>after</i> with-in. 10. A. alle thinges. 11. A.
  comaundedist. 12. C. <i>om.</i> and absolut. 13. A. Ed. proporcionables; C. porcionables. 16. A.
  fleye (<i>for</i> flee). // A. Ed. drawe; C. drawen. 18. C. <i>glosses</i> sowle <i>by</i> anima
  mundi. 19. C. menbres. 20. C. in to two; A. in two; Ed. in to. 22. C. tornet; A. tournith. 24. C.
  Ed. sowest; A. sewest. 26. A. Ed. benigne; C. bygynnynge (!). 28. A. thi thouȝt
  (<i>wrongly</i>); C. <i>has the gloss</i>: s. boecii. // A. thi streite; Ed. thy strayte; C. the
  streite. 29. A. <i>om.</i> him. // C. enuerowne; A. enuiroune. 31. A. <i>om. 2nd</i> thou. 33. A.
  <i>om.</i> reste. 34. C. paath. 35. A. <i>om.</i> that. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose X.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quoniam igitur quae sit imperfecti.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>For as moche thanne as thou hast seyn, which is the forme</p>
<p>of good that nis nat parfit, and which is the forme of good that</p>
<p>is parfit, now trowe I that it were good to shewe in what this</p>
<p>perfeccioun of blisfulnesse is set. And in this thing, I trowe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that we sholden first enquere for to witen, yif that any swiche</p>
<p>maner good as thilke good that thou has diffinisshed a litel</p>
<p>heer-biforn, <i>that is to seyn, soverein good</i>, may ben founde in the</p>
<p>nature of thinges; for that <a href="#BIIIPXNL8" id="BIIIPXL8" class="pginternal">veyn</a> imaginacioun of
    thought ne</p>
<p>deceyve us nat, and putte us out of the sothfastnesse of thilke</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thing that is summitted unto us. But it may nat ben deneyed</p>
<p>that thilke <a href="#BIIIPXNL11" id="BIIIPXL11" class="pginternal">good ne is</a>, and that it <a href="#BIIIPXNL11" class="pginternal">nis right as</a> welle of alle</p>
<p>goodes. For al thing that is cleped inparfit <a href="#BIIIPXNL12" id="BIIIPXL12" class="pginternal">is
    proeved</a> inparfit</p>
<p>by the amenusinge of perfeccioun or of thing that is parfit.</p>
<p>And ther-of comth it, that <a href="#BIIIPXNL14" id="BIIIPXL14" class="pginternal">in every thing general</a>,
    yif that men</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">sen any-thing that is inparfit, certes, in thilke general ther mot</p>
<p>ben som-thing that is parfit; for yif so be that perfeccioun is</p>
<p>don awey, men may nat thinke ne seye fro whennes thilke</p>
<p>thing is that is cleped inparfit. For the nature of thinges ne</p>
<p>took nat hir beginninge of thinges amenused and inparfit, but</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page75">{75}</span>it procedeth of thinges that ben
    al hoole and absolut, and</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXNL21" id="BIIIPXL21" class="pginternal">descendeth</a> so doun in-to outterest thinges, and
    in-to thinges</p>
<p>empty and with-outen frut. But, as I have y-shewed a litel</p>
<p>her-biforn, that yif ther be a blisfulnesse that be freele and</p>
<p>veyn and inparfit, ther may no man doute that ther nis som</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">blisfulnesse that is sad, stedefast, and parfit.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><i>Boece.</i> 'This is concluded,' quod I, 'fermely and sothfastly.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><i>Philosophie.</i> 'But considere also,' quod she, 'in wham this</p>
<p>blisfulnesse enhabiteth. The comune acordaunce and conceite</p>
<p>of the corages of men proeveth and graunteth, that god, prince</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of alle thinges, is good. For, so as nothing ne may ben thought</p>
<p>bettre than god, it may nat ben douted thanne that he, that</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXNL31" id="BIIIPXL31" class="pginternal">nothing nis bettre</a>, that he <a href="#BIIIPXNL32" id="BIIIPXL32" class="pginternal">nis good</a>. Certes, resoun sheweth</p>
<p>that god is so good, that it proveth by verray force that parfit</p>
<p>good is in him. For yif god ne is swich, he ne may nat ben</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">prince of alle thinges; for certes som-thing possessing in it-self</p>
<p>parfit good, sholde ben more worthy than god, and it sholde</p>
<p>semen that thilke thing were first, and elder than god. For</p>
<p>we han shewed apertly that alle thinges that ben parfit ben</p>
<p>first or thinges that ben unparfit; and for-thy, <a href="#BIIIPXNL39" id="BIIIPXL39" class="pginternal">for as
    moche</a> as</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that my resoun or my proces ne go nat a-wey with-oute an</p>
<p>ende, we owen to graunten that the soverein god is right ful</p>
<p>of soverein parfit good. And we han establisshed that the</p>
<p>soverein good is verray blisfulnesse: thanne mot it nedes be,</p>
<p>that verray blisfulnesse is set in soverein god.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">45</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'This take I wel,' quod I, 'ne this ne may nat ben withseid</p>
<p>in no manere.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'But I preye,' quod she, 'see now how thou mayst proeven,</p>
<p>holily and with-oute corupcioun, this that I have seyd, that the</p>
<p>soverein god is right ful of soverein good.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">50</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'In which manere?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Wenest thou aught,' quod she, 'that <a href="#BIIIPXNL51" id="BIIIPXL51" class="pginternal">this
    prince</a> of alle</p>
<p>thinges have y-take thilke soverein good any-wher out of him-self,</p>
<p>of which soverein good men proveth that he is ful, right</p>
<p>as thou mightest thinken that god, that hath blisfulnesse in</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page76">{76}</span>him-self, and thilke blisfulnesse
    that is in him, weren dyvers in</p>
<p>substaunce? For yif thou wene that god have received thilke</p>
<p>good out of him-self, thou mayst wene that he that yaf thilke</p>
<p>good to god be more worthy than is god. But I am bi-knowen</p>
<p>and confesse, and that right dignely, that god is right worthy</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">aboven alle thinges; and, yif so be that this good be in him</p>
<p>by nature, but that it is dyvers fro him by weninge resoun,</p>
<p>sin we speke of god prince of alle thinges: <a href="#BIIIPXNL62" id="BIIIPXL62" class="pginternal">feigne</a>
    who-so</p>
<p>feigne may, who was he that hath conioigned thise dyverse</p>
<p>thinges to-gider? And eek, at the laste, see wel that a thing</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that is dyvers from any thing, that thilke thing nis nat that</p>
<p>same thing fro which it is understonden to ben dyvers. Thanne</p>
<p>folweth it, that thilke thing that by his nature is dyvers fro</p>
<p>soverein good, that that thing nis nat soverein good; but certes,</p>
<p>that were a felonous corsednesse to thinken that of him that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">nothing nis more worth. For alwey, of alle thinges, the nature</p>
<p>of hem ne may nat ben bettre than his biginning; for which</p>
<p>I may concluden, by right verray resoun, that thilke that is</p>
<p>biginning of alle thinges, thilke same thing is soverein good</p>
<p>in his substaunce.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">75</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><i>Boece.</i> 'Thou hast seyd rightfully,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza"><i>Philosophie.</i> 'But we han graunted,' quod she, 'that the</p>
<p>soverein good is blisfulnesse.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'And that is sooth,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne,' quod she, 'moten we nedes graunten and confessen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that thilke same soverein good be god.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod I, 'I ne may nat denye ne withstonde the</p>
<p>resouns purposed; and I see wel that it folweth by strengthe</p>
<p>of the premisses.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Loke now,' quod she, 'yif this be proved yit more fermely</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">85</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thus: that ther ne mowen nat ben two soverein goodes that</p>
<p>ben dyverse amonge hem-self. For certes, the goodes that</p>
<p>ben dyverse amonges hem-self, that oon nis nat that that other</p>
<p>is; <a href="#BIIIPXNL88" id="BIIIPXL88" class="pginternal">thanne ne [may]</a> neither of hem ben parfit, so as
    either of</p>
<p>hem lakketh to other. But that that nis nat parfit, men may</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page77">{77}</span>seen apertly that it nis nat
    soverein. The thinges, thanne, that</p>
<p>ben sovereinly goode, ne mowen by no wey ben dyverse. But</p>
<p>I have wel concluded that blisfulnesse and god ben the soverein</p>
<p>good; for whiche it mot nedes ben, that soverein blisfulnesse</p>
<p>is soverein divinitee.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">95</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Nothing,' quod I, 'nis more soothfast than this, ne more</p>
<p>ferme by resoun; ne a more worthy thing than god may nat</p>
<p>ben concluded.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'<a href="#BIIIPXNL98" id="BIIIPXL98" class="pginternal">Up-on thise thinges</a> thanne,' quod
    she, 'right as thise geometriens,</p>
<p>whan they han shewed hir proposiciouns, ben wont</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to bringen in thinges that they clepen <a href="#BIIIPXNL100" id="BIIIPXL100" class="pginternal">porismes</a>, <i>or declaraciouns</i></p>
<p><i>of forseide thinges</i>, right so wole I yeve thee heer <a href="#BIIIPXNL101" id="BIIIPXL101" class="pginternal">as a corollarie</a>,</p>
<p><i>or a mede of coroune</i>. For-why, for as moche as by the getinge</p>
<p>of blisfulnesse men ben maked blisful, and blisfulnesse is</p>
<p>divinitee: thanne is it manifest and open, that by the getinge</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of divinitee men ben maked blisful. Right as by the getinge</p>
<p>of Iustice <a href="#BIIIPXNL106" id="BIIIPXL106" class="pginternal">[they ben maked iust]</a>, and by the
    getinge of sapience</p>
<p>they ben maked wyse: right so, nedes, by the semblable resoun,</p>
<p>whan they han geten divinitee, they ben maked goddes. Thanne</p>
<p>is every blisful man god; but certes, by nature, ther nis but</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">o god; but, by the participacioun of divinitee, ther ne let ne</p>
<p>desturbeth nothing that ther ne ben manye goddes.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'This is,' quod I, 'a fair thing and a precious, clepe it as</p>
<p>thou wolt; be it porisme or corollarie,' <i>or mede of coroune or</i></p>
<p><i>declaringes</i>.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">115</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Certes,' quod she, 'nothing nis fayrer than is the thing that</p>
<p>by resoun sholde ben added to thise forseide thinges.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'What thing?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'So,' quod she, 'as it semeth that blisfulnesse conteneth many</p>
<p>thinges, it were for to witen whether that alle thise thinges maken</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">120</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">or conioignen as a maner body of blisfulnesse, by dyversitee of</p>
<p>parties or of membres; or elles, yif that any of alle thilke thinges</p>
<p>be swich that it acomplisshe by him-self the substaunce of</p>
<p>blisfulnesse, so that alle thise othre thinges ben referred and</p>
<p>brought to blisfulnesse,' <i>that is to seyn, as to the cheef of hem</i>.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">125</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'I wolde,' quod I, 'that thou makedest me cleerly to understonde</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page78">{78}</span>what thou seyst, and that thou recordedest me
    the forseyde</p>
<p>thinges.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Have I nat iuged,' quod she, 'that blisfulnesse is good?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Yis, forsothe,' quod I; 'and that soverein good.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">130</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Adde thanne,' quod she, 'thilke good, <i>that is maked
    blisfulnesse</i>,</p>
<p>to alle the forseide thinges; for thilke same blisfulnesse</p>
<p>that is demed to ben soverein suffisaunce, thilke selve is soverein</p>
<p>power, soverein reverence, soverein cleernesse <i>or noblesse</i>, and</p>
<p>soverein delyt. <b>Conclusio.</b> What seyst thou thanne of alle thise</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">135</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thinges, that is to seyn, suffisaunce, power, and this othre thinges;</p>
<p>ben they thanne as membres of blisfulnesse, or ben they referred</p>
<p>and brought to soverein good, right as alle thinges that ben brought</p>
<p>to the chief of hem?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'I understonde wel;' quod I, 'what thou purposest to seke;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">but I desire for to herkne that thou shewe it me.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Tak now thus the discrecioun of this questioun,' quod she.</p>
<p>'Yif alle thise thinges,' quod she, 'weren membres to felicitee,</p>
<p>than weren they dyverse that oon from that other; and swich is</p>
<p>the nature of parties or of membres, that dyverse membres compounen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">145</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">a body.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod I, 'it hath wel ben shewed heer-biforn, that alle</p>
<p>thise thinges ben alle o thing.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne ben they none membres,' quod she; 'for elles it</p>
<p>sholde seme that blisfulnesse were conioigned al of on membre</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">150</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">allone; but that is a thing that may nat be don.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'This thing,' quod I, 'nis nat doutous; but I abyde to herknen</p>
<p>the remnaunt of thy questioun.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'This is open and cleer,' quod she, 'that alle othre thinges ben</p>
<p>referred and brought to good. For therefore is suffisaunce requered,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">155</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">for it is demed to ben good; and forthy is power requered,</p>
<p>for men trowen also that it be good; and this same thing mowen</p>
<p>we thinken and coniecten of reverence, and of noblesse, and of</p>
<p>delyt. Thanne is soverein good the somme and the cause of al</p>
<p>that aughte ben desired; for-why thilke thing that with-holdeth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">160</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">no good in it-self, ne semblaunce of good, it ne may nat wel in</p>
<p>no manere be desired ne requered. And the contrarie: for</p>
<p>thogh that thinges by hir nature ne ben nat goode, algates, yif</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page79">{79}</span>men wene that ben goode, yit ben they desired as
    though that</p>
<p>they weren verrayliche goode. And therfor is it that men oughten</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">165</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to wene by right, that bountee be <a href="#BIIIPXNL165" id="BIIIPXL165" class="pginternal">the
    soverein fyn</a>, and the cause</p>
<p>of alle the thinges that ben to requeren. But certes, thilke that</p>
<p>is cause for which men requeren any thing, it semeth that thilke</p>
<p>same thing be most desired. As thus: yif that a wight wolde</p>
<p>ryden for cause of hele, he ne desireth nat so mochel the moevinge</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">170</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to ryden, as the effect of his hele. Now thanne, sin that</p>
<p>alle thinges ben requered for the grace of good, they ne ben nat</p>
<p>desired of alle folk more thanne the same good. But we han</p>
<p>graunted that blisfulnesse is that thing, for whiche that alle thise</p>
<p>othre thinges ben desired; thanne is it thus: that, certes, only</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">175</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">blisfulnesse is requered and desired. By whiche thing it sheweth</p>
<p>cleerly, that of good and of blisfulnesse is al oon and the same</p>
<p>substaunce.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'I see nat,' quod I, 'wherfore that men mighten discorden in</p>
<p>this.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">180</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'And we han shewed that god and verray blisfulnesse is al oo</p>
<p>thing.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'That is sooth,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne mowen we conclude sikerly, that the substaunce of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">184</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">god is set in thilke same good, and in non other place.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. X.</span> 6. A. diffinissed; C. dyffynnyssed; Ed. diffynished.
  10. <i>After</i> us, A. <i>ins.</i> this is to seyne (<i>needlessly</i>). // C. A. denoyed
  (<i>error for</i> deneyed); Ed. denyed. 12. A. al; C. alle. 14. C. ther-of; A. Ed. her-of. // C.
  comht (<i>for</i> comth). 20. C. absolut, i. laws. 21. C. dessendeth. 28. C. conseite; A.
  conceite. 31. A. <i>om.</i> he that. 32. A. is bettre. 35. C. Ed. it-self; A. hym self. 36. A.
  <i>om.</i> it. 39. A. inperfit. 40. C. as that; A. <i>om.</i> that. // A. Ed. proces; C.
  processes. 41. owen] A. ouȝt. 44. A. <i>om.</i> that ... is. 50. A. <i>om.</i> In which ...
  I. 51. C. Wenesthow awht. 56. A. receyued; C. resseyud. 58. A. goode (<i>for</i> worthy). 61. A.
  it is; C. is is (<i>sic</i>). // fro him] A. <i>om.</i> him. 63. A. <i>om.</i> hath. 70. A. Ed.
  nis; C. is. 73. A. <i>om.</i> soverein. 84. A. <i>om.</i> yit. 86, 87. A. <i>om.</i> For certes
  ... hem-self. // C. othre. 88. A. <i>om.</i> ne. // C. A. Ed. mowen; <i>read</i> may. 90. A. Ed.
  nis; C. is. 106. <i>I supply</i> they ben maked iust; Lat. <i>iusti</i>. 110. C. by thy
  (<i>wrongly</i>); A. Ed. by the. 119. A. witen; C. whyten. // C. wheyther that; A. <i>om.</i>
  that. // A. thise; C. this. 120. A. Ed. by; C. be. 121. C. or of; A. <i>om.</i> of. 122. Ed.
  accomplysshe; C. acomplyse; A. acomplise. 126. A. recordest. 134. C. <i>om.</i> thise. 141. Ed.
  discrecion; A. discressioun; C. descressioun. 143. C. swhych. 157. C. coniecten; A. coneiten; Lat.
  <i>coniectare</i>. 159. C. awht; A. auȝt. 161. A. requered; C. required. 171. A. requered;
  C. required. 176. C. of good; A. <i>om.</i> of; Lat. <i>boni</i>. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre X.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Huc omnes pariter uenite capti.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>O cometh alle to-gider now, ye that ben y-caught and y-bounde</p>
<p>with wikkede cheynes, by the deceivable delyt of erthely thinges</p>
<p>enhabitinge in your thought! Heer shal ben the reste of your</p>
<p>labours, heer is the havene stable in peysible quiete; this allone</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">is the open refut to wrecches. <b>Glosa.</b> <i>This is to seyn, that
    ye</i></p>
<p><i>that ben combred and deceived with worldely affecciouns, cometh now</i></p>
<p><i>to this soverein good, that is god, that is refut to hem that wolen</i></p>
<p><i>comen to him.</i> <b>Textus.</b> Alle the thinges that the river <a href="#BIIIMXNL8" id="BIIIMXL8" class="pginternal">Tagus</a></p>
<p>yeveth yow with his goldene gravailes, or elles alle the thinges</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that the river <a href="#BIIIMXNL10" id="BIIIMXL10" class="pginternal">Hermus</a> yeveth with his
    <a href="#BIIIMXNL10" class="pginternal">rede brinke</a>, or that <a href="#BIIIMXNL10" class="pginternal">Indus</a></p>
<p>yeveth, that is next the hote party of the world, that <a href="#BIIIMXNL11" id="BIIIMXL11" class="pginternal">medleth</a> the</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page80">{80}</span>grene stones with the whyte, ne sholde nat
    cleeren the lookinge</p>
<p>of your thought, but hyden rather your blinde corages with-in hir</p>
<p>derknesse. Al that lyketh yow heer, and excyteth and moeveth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">your thoughtes, the erthe hath norisshed it in hise lowe caves.</p>
<p>But the shyninge, by whiche the hevene is governed and whennes</p>
<p>he hath his strengthe, <a href="#BIIIMXNL17" id="BIIIMXL17" class="pginternal">that eschueth</a> the derke
    overthrowinge of</p>
<p>the sowle; and who-so may knowen thilke light of blisfulnesse,</p>
<p>he shal wel seyn, that the whyte bemes of the sonne ne ben nat</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">cleer.'</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. X.</span> 3. A. Ed. Here; C. He. 6. A. deceyued; C. desseyued.
  10. A. Ed. Hermus; C. Herynus (!). 12. C. grene stones, <i>i. smaragdes</i>; with the whyte, <i>i.
  margaretes</i>. 14. Ed. derkenesse; C. dyrknesse. 16. A. by the whiche. 17. C. eschueth; A.
  chaseth; Lat. <i>uitat</i>. // A. derke; C. dyrke. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose XI.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Assentior, inquam.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p><i>Boece.</i> 'I assente me,' quod I; 'for alle thise thinges ben</p>
<p>strongly bounden with right ferme resouns.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><i>Philosophie.</i> '<a href="#BIIIPXINL3" id="BIIIPXIL3" class="pginternal">How mochel</a> wilt
    thou preysen it,' quod she,</p>
<p>'yif that thou knowe what thilke good is?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">5</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'I wol preyse it,' quod I, 'by prys with-outen ende, yif it shal</p>
<p>bityde me to knowe also to-gider god that is good.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod she, 'that shal I do thee by verray resoun, yif</p>
<p>that tho thinges that I have concluded a litel her-biforn dwellen</p>
<p>only in hir first graunting.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">10</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'They dwellen graunted to thee,' quod I; <i>this is to seyn, as</i></p>
<p><i>who seith: I graunte thy forseide conclusiouns</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Have I nat shewed thee,' quod she, 'that the thinges that ben</p>
<p>requered of many folkes ne ben nat verray goodes ne parfite, for</p>
<p>they ben dyverse that oon fro that othre; and so as ech of hem</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">is lakkinge to other, they ne han no power to bringen a good that</p>
<p>is ful and absolut? But thanne at erst ben they verray good,</p>
<p>whanne they ben gadered to-gider alle in-to o forme and in-to oon</p>
<p>wirkinge, so that thilke thing that is suffisaunce, thilke same be</p>
<p>power, and reverence, and noblesse, and mirthe; and forsothe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">but-yif alle thise thinges ben alle oon same thing, they ne han nat</p>
<p>wherby that they mowen ben put in the noumber of thinges that</p>
<p>oughten ben requered or desired.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page81">{81}</span>'It is shewed,' quod I; 'ne
    her-of may ther no man douten.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#BIIIPXINL24" id="BIIIPXIL24" class="pginternal">'The thinges thanne,'</a> quod she,
    'that ne ben no goodes</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">whanne they ben dyverse, and whan they beginnen to ben alle</p>
<p>oon thing thanne ben they goodes, ne comth it hem nat thanne</p>
<p>by the getinge of unitee, that they ben maked goodes?'</p>
