<p class="stanza">'So it semeth,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'But al thing that is good,' quod she, 'grauntest thou that it be</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">good by the participacioun of good, or no?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'I graunte it,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne most thou graunten,' quod she, 'by semblable resoun,</p>
<p>that oon and good be oo same thing. For of thinges, of whiche</p>
<p>that the effect nis nat naturelly diverse, nedes the substance mot</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">be oo same thing.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'I ne may nat denye that,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Hast thou nat knowen wel,' quod she, 'that al thing that is</p>
<p>hath so longe his dwellinge and his substaunce as longe as it is</p>
<p>oon; but whan it forleteth to ben oon, it mot nedes dyen and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">corumpe to-gider?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'In which manere?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Right as in bestes,' quod she, 'whan the sowle and the body</p>
<p>ben conioigned in oon and dwellen to-gider, it is cleped a beest.</p>
<p>And whan hir unitee is destroyed by the disseveraunce of that oon</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">from that other, than sheweth it wel that it is a ded thing, and</p>
<p>that it nis no lenger no beest. And the body of a wight, whyl</p>
<p>it dwelleth in oo forme by coniunccioun of membres, it is</p>
<p>wel seyn that it is a figure of man-kinde. And yif the parties</p>
<p>of the body ben so devyded and dissevered, <i>that oon fro that</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>other</i>, that they destroyen unitee, the body forleteth to ben that</p>
<p>it was biforn. And, who-so wolde renne in the same manere by</p>
<p>alle thinges, he sholde seen that, with-oute doute, every thing is</p>
<p>in his substaunce as longe as it is oon; and whan it forleteth to</p>
<p>ben oon, it dyeth and perissheth.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">55</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Whan I considere,' quod I, 'manye thinges, I see <a href="#BIIIPXINL55" id="BIIIPXIL55" class="pginternal">non other</a>.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Is ther any-thing thanne,' quod she, 'that, in as moche as it</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page82">{82}</span>liveth naturelly, that forleteth the talent or
    appetyt of his beinge,</p>
<p>and desireth to come to deeth and to corupcioun?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Yif I considere,' quod I, 'the beestes that han any maner</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">nature of wilninge and of nillinge, I ne finde no beest, but-yif</p>
<p>it be constreined fro with-oute forth, that forleteth or</p>
<p>despyseth the entencioun to liven and to duren, or that wole,</p>
<p>his thankes, hasten him to dyen. For every beest <a href="#BIIIPXINL63" id="BIIIPXIL63" class="pginternal">travaileth him</a></p>
<p>to deffende and kepe the savacioun of his lyf, and eschueth deeth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and destruccioun.</p>
<p class="stanza">But certes, I doute me of herbes and of trees, <i>that is to</i></p>
<p><i>seyn, that I am in a doute of swiche thinges as herbes or trees</i>, that</p>
<p>ne han no felinge sowles, <i>ne no naturel wirkinges servinge to</i></p>
<p><i>appetytes as bestes han, whether they han appetyt to dwellen</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>and to duren</i>.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod she, 'ne ther-of <a href="#BIIIPXINL71" id="BIIIPXIL71" class="pginternal">thar
    thee nat doute</a>. Now</p>
<p>loke up-on thise herbes and thise trees; they wexen first in</p>
<p>swiche places as ben covenable to hem, in whiche places they</p>
<p>ne mowen nat sone dyen ne dryen, as longe as hir nature may</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">deffenden hem. For som of hem waxen in feeldes, and som</p>
<p>in mountaignes, and othre waxen in mareys, and othre cleven</p>
<p>on roches, and somme waxen plentivous in sondes; and yif</p>
<p>that any wight enforce him to beren hem in-to othre places,</p>
<p>they wexen drye. For nature yeveth to every thing that that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">is convenient to him, and travaileth that they ne dye nat, as</p>
<p>longe as they han power to dwellen and to liven. <a href="#BIIIPXINL81" id="BIIIPXIL81" class="pginternal">What
    woltow</a></p>
<p>seyn of this, that they drawen alle hir norisshinges by hir rotes,</p>
<p>right as they hadden hir mouthes y-plounged with-in the erthes,</p>
<p>and sheden by hir maryes hir wode and hir bark? And what</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">85</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">woltow seyn of this, that thilke thing that is right softe, as the</p>
<p>marye is, that is alwey hid in the sete, al with-inne, and that</p>
<p>is defended fro with-oute by the stedefastnesse of wode; and</p>
<p>that the uttereste bark is put ayeins the destemperaunce of</p>
<p>the hevene, as a defendour mighty to suffren harm? And thus,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page83">{83}</span>certes, maystow wel seen how greet
    is the diligence of nature;</p>
<p>for alle thinges <a href="#BIIIPXINL91" id="BIIIPXIL91" class="pginternal">renovelen and puplisshen hem</a> with
    seed y-multiplyed;</p>
<p>ne ther nis no man that ne wot wel <a href="#BIIIPXINL92" id="BIIIPXIL92" class="pginternal">that they
    ne</a></p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXINL92" class="pginternal">ben</a> right as a foundement and edifice, for to duren nat only</p>
<p>for a tyme, but right as for to duren perdurably by generacioun.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And the thinges eek that men wenen ne haven none sowles,</p>
<p>ne desire they nat ech of hem by semblable resoun to kepen</p>
<p>that is hirs, <i>that is to seyn, that is acordinge to hir nature in</i></p>
<p><i>conservacioun of hir beinge and enduringe</i>? For wher-for elles</p>
<p>bereth lightnesse the flaumbes up, and the weighte presseth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the erthe a-doun, but for as moche as thilke places and thilke</p>
<p>moevinges ben covenable to everich of hem? And forsothe</p>
<p>every thing kepeth thilke that is acordinge and propre to him,</p>
<p>right as thinges that ben contraries and enemys corompen hem.</p>
<p>And yit the harde thinges, as stones, clyven and holden hir</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">parties to-gider right faste and harde, and deffenden hem in</p>
<p>withstondinge that they ne departe nat lightly a-twinne. And</p>
<p>the thinges that ben softe and fletinge, as is water and eyr,</p>
<p>they departen lightly, and yeven place to hem that breken or</p>
<p>devyden hem; but natheles, they retornen sone ayein in-to</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the same thinges fro whennes they ben arraced. <a href="#BIIIPXINL110" id="BIIIPXIL110" class="pginternal">But fyr</a> fleeth</p>
<p>and refuseth al devisioun. Ne I ne trete nat heer now of</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXINL112" id="BIIIPXIL112" class="pginternal">wilful</a> moevinges of the sowle that is knowinge,
    but of the</p>
<p>naturel entencioun of thinges, as thus: right as we swolwe the</p>
<p>mete that we receiven and ne thinke nat on it, and as we</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">drawen our breeth in slepinge that we wite it nat whyle we</p>
<p>slepen. For certes, in the beestes, the love of hir livinges ne</p>
<p>of hir beinges ne comth nat of the wilninges of the sowle, but</p>
<p>of the biginninges of nature. For certes, thorugh constreininge</p>
<p>causes, wil desireth and embraceth ful ofte tyme the deeth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">120</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that nature dredeth; <i>that is to seyn as thus: that a man may</i></p>
<p><i>ben constreyned so, by som cause, that his wil desireth and</i></p>
<p><i>taketh the deeth which that nature hateth and dredeth ful sore</i>.</p>
<p>And <a href="#BIIIPXINL123" id="BIIIPXIL123" class="pginternal">somtyme</a> we seeth the contrarye, as thus:
    that the wil</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page84">{84}</span>of a wight destorbeth and constreyneth that that
    nature desireth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and requereth al-wey, <i>that is to seyn</i>, the werk of generacioun,</p>
<p>by the whiche generacioun only dwelleth and is sustened the</p>
<p>long durabletee of mortal thinges.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#BIIIPXINL128" id="BIIIPXIL128" class="pginternal">And thus</a> this charitee and this
    love, that every thing hath</p>
<p>to him-self, ne comth nat of the moevinge of the sowle, but</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of the entencioun of nature. For the purviaunce of god hath</p>
<p>yeven to thinges that ben creat of him this, that is a ful</p>
<p>gret cause to liven and to duren; for which they desiren</p>
<p>naturelly hir lyf as longe as ever they mowen.  For which</p>
<p>thou mayst nat drede, by no manere, that alle the thinges</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">135</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that ben anywhere, that they ne requeren naturelly the ferme</p>
<p>stablenesse of perdurable dwellinge, and eek the eschuinge of</p>
<p>destruccioun.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><i>Boece.</i> 'Now confesse I wel,' quod I, 'that I see now wel</p>
<p>certeinly, with-oute doutes, the thinges that whylom semeden</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">uncertain to me.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'But,' quod she, 'thilke thing that desireth to be and to</p>
<p>dwellen perdurably, he desireth to ben oon; <a href="#BIIIPXINL142" id="BIIIPXIL142" class="pginternal">for yif
    that</a> that</p>
<p>oon were destroyed, certes, beinge ne shulde ther non dwellen</p>
<p>to no wight.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">145</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'That is sooth,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne,' quod she, 'desiren alle thinges oon?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'I assente,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'And I have shewed,' quod she, 'that thilke same oon is</p>
<p>thilke that is good?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">150</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Ye, for sothe,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Alle thinges thanne,' quod she, 'requiren good; and thilke</p>
<p>good thanne mayst thou descryven right thus: good is thilke</p>
<p>thing that every wight desireth.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Ther ne may be thought,' quod I, 'no more verray thing.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">155</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For either alle thinges ben referred and brought to nought,</p>
<p>and <a href="#BIIIPXINL156" id="BIIIPXIL156" class="pginternal">floteren</a> with-oute governour, despoiled of
    oon as of hir</p>
<p>propre heved; or elles, yif ther be any thing to which that</p>
<p>alle thinges tenden and hyen, that thing moste ben the soverein</p>
<p>good of alle goodes.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">160</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">Thanne seyde she thus: 'O my nory,' quod she, 'I have</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page85">{85}</span>gret gladnesse of thee; <a href="#BIIIPXINL161" id="BIIIPXIL161" class="pginternal">for thou hast</a> ficched in thyn herte</p>
<p>the middel soothfastnesse, <i>that is to seyn</i>, the prikke; but this</p>
<p>thing hath ben descovered to thee, <a href="#BIIIPXINL163" id="BIIIPXIL163" class="pginternal">in that</a> thou
    seydest that</p>
<p>thou wistest nat a litel her-biforn.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">165</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'What was that?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'That thou ne wistest nat,' quod she, 'which was the ende</p>
<p>of thinges; and certes, that is the thing that every wight</p>
<p>desireth; and for as mochel as we han gadered and comprehended</p>
<p>that good is thilke thing that is desired of alle, thanne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">170</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">moten we nedes confessen, that good is the fyn of alle thinges.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. XI.</span> 3. C. wylthow. 5. C. pr<i>e</i>ys; A. Ed. price. 6.
  A. Ed. bytyde; C. betydde. 7. C. <i>om.</i> that. // A. Ed. resoun; C. resouns; Lat.
  <i>ratione</i>. 17. C. in on; A. in to oon; Ed. in to one. 23. C. <i>om.</i> ther. 29. C.
  grauntisthow. 32. Ed. muste thou; C. mosthow; A. mayst thou. // Ed. semblable; A. sembleable; C.
  semlable. 37. C. Hasthow. 43. A. conioigned; C. conioigne. 44. A. disseueraunce; C. desseueraunce;
  <i>after which</i> C. A. <i>om.</i> of, <i>which</i> Ed. <i>retains</i>. 51. A. Ed. who so; C.
  who. 54. Ed. perissheth; C. periseth; A. perissith. 60. C. wylnynge; A. Ed. willynge. 62. A.
  <i>om.</i> the entencioun. 64. C. <i>om.</i> and <i>bef.</i> eschueth. 68. A. soule. 69. A. Ed.
  appetite; C. apetid. 76. Ed. mareys; A. mareis; C. marys. // A. <i>has here lost a leaf, from</i>
  and othre <i>to past end of</i> Met. xi. 84. C. maryes, <i>i. medulle</i>. 86. Ed. seete; C. feete
  (!); Lat. <i>sede</i>. 87. Ed. is; C. is is (<i>sic</i>). // C. stidefastnesse. 88. C. <i>om.</i>
  the <i>bef.</i> destemperaunce; Ed. <i>has it</i>. 91. C. pupllisen; Ed. publysshen. 94. Ed.
  perdurably; C. perdurablely. 103. Ed. corrumpen. 106. Ed. <i>om.</i> nat lightly ... departen. //
  C. a twyne. 110. Ed. araced. // Ed. fleeth and; C. and (<i>om.</i> fleeth); Lat. <i>refugit</i>.
  112. Ed. wylful; C. weleful; Lat. <i>uoluntariis</i>. 114. Ed. receyuen; C. resseyuen. 116. Ed.
  slepen; C. slepyt. 127. Ed. durabylite. 142. Ed. perdurablye; C. perdurablely. 152. Ed. thou; C.
  <i>om.</i> // Ed. discryuen. 161. C. fichched; Ed. fyxed. 163. Ed. discouered. 165. Ed. is that
  (<i>for</i> was that). </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre XI.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quisquis profunda mente uestigat uerum.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Who-so that seketh sooth by a deep thoght, and coveiteth</p>
<p>nat to ben deceived by no <a href="#BIIIMXINL2" id="BIIIMXIL2" class="pginternal">mis-weyes</a>, lat him <a href="#BIIIMXINL2" class="pginternal">rollen and trenden</a></p>
<p>with-inne him-self the light of his inward sighte; and lat him</p>
<p>gadere ayein, enclyninge in-to a compas, the longe moevinges</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>of his thoughtes</i>; and lat him techen his corage that he hath</p>
<p>enclosed and hid in his tresors, al that he compasseth or seketh</p>
<p>fro with-oute. And thanne thilke thinge, that the <a href="#BIIIMXINL7" id="BIIIMXIL7" class="pginternal">blake
    cloude</a></p>
<p>of errour whylom hadde y-covered, shal <a href="#BIIIMXINL8" id="BIIIMXIL8" class="pginternal">lighten</a> more
    cleerly</p>
<p>thanne Phebus him-self ne shyneth.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">10</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><b><a href="#BIIIMXINL10" id="BIIIMXIL10" class="pginternal">Glosa.</a></b> <i>Who-so wole
    seken the deep grounde of sooth in his</i></p>
<p><i>thought, and wol nat be deceived by false proposiciouns that goon</i></p>
<p><i>amis fro the trouthe, lat him wel examine and rolle with-inne him-self</i></p>
<p><i>the nature and the propretees of the thing; and lat him yit</i></p>
<p><i>eftsones examine and rollen his thoughtes by good deliberacioun, or</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>that he deme; and lat him techen his sowle that it hath, by natural</i></p>
<p><i>principles kindeliche y-hid with-in it-self, alle the trouthe the whiche</i></p>
<p><i>he imagineth to ben in thinges with-oute. And thanne alle the</i></p>
<p><i>derknesse of his misknowinge shal seme more evidently to sighte of</i></p>
<p><i>his understondinge thanne the sonne ne semeth to sighte</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>with-oute-forth.</i></p>
<p class="stanza">For certes the body, bringinge the weighte of foryetinge, ne</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page86">{86}</span>hath nat chased out of your thoughte al the
    cleernesse <i>of your</i></p>
<p><i>knowinge</i>; for certeinly the seed of sooth haldeth and clyveth</p>
<p>with-in your corage, and it is awaked and excyted by the winde</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and by the blastes of doctrine. For wherfor elles demen ye of</p>
<p>your owne wil the rightes, whan ye ben axed, but-yif so were that</p>
<p>the norisshinge <i>of resoun</i> ne livede y-plounged in the depthe of</p>
<p>your herte? <i>this is to seyn, how sholden men demen the sooth of</i></p>
<p><i>any thing that were axed, yif ther nere a rote of soothfastnesse that</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>were y-plounged and hid in naturel principles, the whiche
    soothfastnesse</i></p>
<p><i>lived with-in the deepnesse of the thought</i>. And yif so be</p>
<p>that the Muse and the doctrine of <a href="#BIIIMXINL32" id="BIIIMXIL32" class="pginternal">Plato</a> singeth
    sooth, al that</p>
<p>every wight lerneth, he ne doth no-thing elles thanne but</p>
<p>recordeth, as men recorden thinges that ben foryeten.'</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. XI.</span> 2. Ed. <i>om.</i> nat. // Ed. treaten (<i>for</i>
  trenden). 18. Ed. derknesse; C. dyrknesse. // Ed. seme; C. seen (<i>but note</i> semeth
  <i>below</i>). 24. Ed. wyndes. 26. Ed. asked. 27. Ed. norisshyng; C. noryssynges; Lat.
  <i>fomes</i>. 29. Ed. asked. 30. Ed. naturel; C. the nature (<i>sic</i>). </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose XII.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Tum ego, Platoni, inquam.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Thanne seide I thus: 'I acorde me gretly to Plato, for thou</p>
<p>remembrest and recordest me thise thinges yit the secounde</p>
<p>tyme; <i>that is to seyn</i>, first whan I loste my memorie by the</p>
<p>contagious coniunccioun of the body with the sowle; and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">eftsones afterward, whan I loste it, confounded by the charge and</p>
<p>by the burdene of my sorwe.'</p>
<p class="stanza">And thanne seide she thus: 'yif thou loke,' quod she, 'first</p>
<p>the thinges that thou hast graunted, it ne shal nat ben right fer</p>
<p>that thou ne shalt remembren thilke thing that thou seydest that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thou nistest nat.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'What thing?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'By whiche governement,' quod she, 'that this world is</p>
<p>governed.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Me remembreth it wel,' quod I; 'and I confesse wel that I</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ne wiste it naught. But al-be-it so that I see now from a-fer</p>
<p>what thou purposest, algates, I desire yit to herkene it of thee</p>
<p>more pleynly.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thou ne <a href="#BIIIPXIINL18" id="BIIIPXIIL18" class="pginternal">wendest</a> nat,' quod she,
    'a litel her-biforn, that men</p>
<p>sholden doute that this world <a href="#BIIIPXIINL19" id="BIIIPXIIL19" class="pginternal">nis governed</a> by
    god.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">20</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page87">{87}</span>'Certes,' quod I, 'ne yit
    ne doute I it naught, ne I nel never</p>
<p>wene that it were to doute; <i>as who seith, but I wot wel that god</i></p>
<p><i>governeth this world</i>; and I shal shortly answeren thee by what</p>
<p>resouns I am brought to this. This world,' quod I, 'of so manye</p>
<p>dyverse and contrarious parties, ne mighte never han ben</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">assembled in o forme, but-yif ther nere oon that conioignede so</p>
<p>manye dyverse thinges; and the same dyversitee of hir natures,</p>
<p>that so discorden that oon fro that other, moste departen and</p>
<p>unioignen the thinges that ben conioigned, <a href="#BIIIPXIINL28" id="BIIIPXIIL28" class="pginternal">yif ther
    ne were</a> oon</p>
<p>that contenede that he hath conioined and y-bounde.  Ne the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">certein ordre of nature ne sholde nat <a href="#BIIIPXIINL30" id="BIIIPXIIL30" class="pginternal">bringe forth so ordenee</a></p>
<p>moevinges, by places, by tymes, by doinges, by spaces, by</p>
<p>qualitees, yif ther ne were oon that were ay stedefast dwellinge,</p>
<p>that ordeynede and disponede thise dyversitees of moevinges.</p>
<p>And thilke thing, what-so-ever it be, by which that alle thinges</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ben y-maked and y-lad, I clepe him "god"; that is a word that</p>
<p>is used to alle folk.'</p>
<p class="stanza">Thanne seyde she: 'sin thou felest thus thise thinges,' quod</p>
<p>she, 'I trowe that I have litel more to done <a href="#BIIIPXIINL38" id="BIIIPXIIL38" class="pginternal">that
    thou</a>, mighty of</p>
<p>welefulnesse, hool and sounde, ne see eftsones thy contree.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But lat us loken the thinges that we han purposed her-biforn.</p>
<p>Have I nat noumbred and seyd,' quod she, 'that suffisaunce is in</p>
<p>blisfulnesse, and we han acorded that god is thilke same blisfulnesse?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Yis, forsothe,' quod I.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">45</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'And that, to governe this world,' quod she, 'ne shal he never</p>
<p>han nede of non help fro with-oute? For elles, yif he hadde</p>
<p>nede of any help, he ne sholde nat have no ful suffisaunce?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Yis, thus it mot nedes be,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne ordeineth he by him-self al-one alle thinges?' quod she.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">50</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'That may nat be deneyed,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'And I have shewed that god is the same good?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'It remembreth me wel,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne ordeineth he alle thinges by thilke good,' quod she;</p>
<p>'sin he, which that we han acorded to be good, governeth alle</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page88">{88}</span>thinges by him-self; and he is as
    <a href="#BIIIPXIINL55" id="BIIIPXIIL55" class="pginternal">a keye and a stere</a> by which</p>
<p>that the edifice of this world is y-kept stable and with-oute</p>
<p>coroumpinge.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'I acorde me greetly,' quod I; 'and I aperceivede a litel her-biforn</p>
<p>that thou woldest seye thus; al-be-it so that it were by</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">a thinne suspecioun.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'I trowe it wel,' quod she; 'for, as I trowe, thou ledest now</p>
<p>more ententifly thyne eyen to loken the verray goodes. But</p>
<p>natheles the thing that I shal telle thee yit <a href="#BIIIPXIINL63" id="BIIIPXIIL63" class="pginternal">ne
    sheweth</a> nat lasse to</p>
<p>loken.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">65</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'What is that?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'So as men trowen,' quod she, 'and that rightfully, that god</p>
<p>governeth alle thinges <a href="#BIIIPXIINL67" id="BIIIPXIIL67" class="pginternal">by the keye</a> of his
    goodnesse, and alle thise</p>
<p>same thinges, as I have taught thee, hasten hem by naturel</p>
<p>entencioun to comen to good: ther may no man douten that they</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ne be governed voluntariely, and that they ne converten hem of</p>
<p>hir owne wil to the wil of hir ordenour, as they that ben acordinge</p>
<p>and enclyninge to hir governour and hir king.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#BIIIPXIINL73" id="BIIIPXIIL73" class="pginternal">'It mot nedes be so,'</a> quod I;
    'for the reaume ne sholde nat</p>
<p>semen blisful yif ther were a yok of misdrawinges in dyverse</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">parties; ne the savinge of obedient thinges ne sholde nat be.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne is ther nothing,' quod she, 'that kepeth his nature,</p>
<p>that enforceth him to goon ayein god?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'No,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'And yif that any-thing enforcede him to with-stonde god,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">mighte it availen at the laste ayeins him, that we han graunted to</p>
<p>ben almighty by the right of blisfulnesse?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod I, 'al-outrely it ne mighte nat availen him.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne is ther no-thing,' quod she, 'that either wole or may</p>
<p>with-stonden to this soverein good?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">85</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'I trowe nat,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne is thilke the soverein good,' quod she, 'that alle</p>
<p>thinges governeth strongly, and ordeyneth hem <a href="#BIIIPXIINL87" id="BIIIPXIIL87" class="pginternal">softely</a>.'</p>
<p class="stanza">Thanne seyde I thus: 'I delyte me,' quod I, 'nat only in the</p>
<p>endes or in the somme of the resouns that thou hast concluded</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and proeved, but thilke wordes that thou usest delyten me moche</p>
<p>more; <a href="#BIIIPXIINL91" id="BIIIPXIIL91" class="pginternal">so, at the laste</a>, fooles that sumtyme
    renden grete thinges</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page89">{89}</span>oughten ben ashamed of hem-self;' <i>that is to
    seyn, that we fooles</i></p>
<p><i>that reprehenden wikkedly the thinges that touchen goddes governaunce,</i></p>
<p><i>we oughten ben ashamed of our-self: as I, that seyde that</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>god refuseth only the werkes of men, and ne entremeteth nat of</i></p>
<p><i>hem</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thou hast wel herd,' quod she, 'the fables of <a href="#BIIIPXIINL97" id="BIIIPXIIL97" class="pginternal">the poetes</a>,</p>
<p>how the giaunts assaileden the hevene <i>with the goddes</i>; but forsothe,</p>
<p>the debonair force <i>of god</i> deposede hem, as it was worthy;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>that is to seyn, destroyede the giaunts, as it was worthy</i>. But wilt</p>
<p>thou that we ioignen to-gider thilke same resouns? For per-aventure,</p>
<p>of swich coniuncioun may sterten up som fair sparkle</p>
<p>of sooth.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Do,' quod I, 'as thee liste.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">105</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Wenest thou,' quod she, 'that god ne be almighty? No man</p>
<p>is in doute of it.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod I, 'no wight ne douteth it, yif he be in his</p>
<p>minde.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'But he,' quod she, 'that is almighty, ther nis nothing that he</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ne may?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'That is sooth,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'May god don yvel?' quod she.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Nay, forsothe,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne is yvel nothing,' quod she, 'sin that he ne may nat</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">don yvel that may don alle thinges.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#BIIIPXIINL116" id="BIIIPXIIL116" class="pginternal">'Scornest thou me?'</a> quod I;
    '<i>or elles pleyest thou or deceivest</i></p>
<p><i>thou me</i>, that hast so woven me with thy resouns <a href="#BIIIPXIINL117" id="BIIIPXIIL117" class="pginternal">the hous of</a></p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIINL117" class="pginternal">Dedalus</a>, so entrelaced that it is unable to be unlaced; thou
    that</p>
<p>other-whyle entrest ther thou issest, and other-whyle issest ther</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">120</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thou entrest, ne foldest thou nat to-gider, <i>by replicacioun of</i></p>
<p><i>wordes</i>, a maner wonderful cercle or environinge of the simplicitee</p>
<p>devyne? For certes, a litel her-biforn, whan thou bigunne at</p>
<p>blisfulnesse, thou seydest that it is soverein good; and seydest</p>
<p>that it is set in soverein god; and seydest that god him-self</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">is soverein good; and that god is the fulle blisfulnesse; <a href="#BIIIPXIINL125" id="BIIIPXIIL125" class="pginternal">for which</a></p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page90">{90}</span>thou yave me as a covenable yift, <i>that is to
    seyn</i>, that no wight</p>
<p>nis blisful but-yif he be god also ther-with. And seidest eek,</p>
<p>that the forme of good is the substaunce of god and of blisfulnesse;</p>
<p>and seidest, that thilke same oon is thilke same good, that is</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">requered and desired of alle the kinde of thinges. And thou</p>
<p>proevedest, in disputinge, that god governeth all the thinges of</p>
<p>the world <a href="#BIIIPXIINL132" id="BIIIPXIIL132" class="pginternal">by the governements</a> of bountee,
    <i>and seydest</i>, that alle</p>
<p>thinges wolen obeyen to him; and <i>seydest</i>, that the nature of yvel</p>
<p>nis no-thing. And thise thinges ne shewedest thou nat with none</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">135</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">resouns y-taken fro with-oute, but by proeves <a href="#BIIIPXIINL135" id="BIIIPXIIL135" class="pginternal"><i>in cercles and</i></a> hoomlich</p>
<p>knowen; the whiche proeves drawen to hem-self hir feith and</p>
<p>hir acord, everich of hem of other.'</p>
<p class="stanza">Thanne seyde she thus: 'I ne scorne thee nat, <i>ne pleye, ne</i></p>
<p><i>deceive thee</i>; but I have shewed thee the thing that is grettest</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">over alle thinges by the yift of god, that we whylom preyeden.</p>
<p>For this is the forme of the devyne substaunce, that is swich that</p>
<p>it ne slydeth nat in-to outterest foreine thinges, ne ne receiveth</p>
<p>no straunge thinges in him; but right as <a href="#BIIIPXIINL143" id="BIIIPXIIL143" class="pginternal">Parmenides</a> seyde <i>in</i></p>
<p><i>Greek</i> of thilke devyne substaunce; he seyde thus: that "thilke</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">145</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">devyne substaunce torneth the world and the moevable cercle of</p>
<p>thinges, whyl thilke devyne substaunce kepeth it-self with-oute</p>
<p>moevinge;" <i>that is to seyn, that it ne moeveth never-mo, and yit it</i></p>
<p><i>moeveth alle othre thinges</i>. But natheles, yif I have stired resouns</p>
<p>that ne ben nat taken fro with-oute the compas of thing of which</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">150</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">we treten, but resouns that ben bistowed with-in that compas,</p>
<p>ther nis nat why that thou sholdest merveilen; sin thou hast</p>
<p>lerned by the sentence of <a href="#BIIIPXIINL152" id="BIIIPXIIL152" class="pginternal">Plato</a>, that "nedes
    the wordes moten</p>
<p>be cosines to the thinges of which they speken."</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. XII.</span> 2. A. <i>begins again with</i> the seconde tyme.
  4. A. coniunccioun; C. coniuncsioun. 12. C. wordyl (<i>for</i> world). 19. C. world nis; Ed. A.
  worlde is. 26. A. <i>om.</i> dyverse. 27. A. discordeden. 30. C. ordene; A. ordinee. 31. A. Ed.
  spaces; C. splaces (!). 32. C. stidefast; A. stedfast. 35. Ed. ymaked; C. A. maked. 40. A. han; C.
  ha (<i>for</i> hā). 47. A. <i>om.</i> no. 50. C. denoyed (<i>for</i> deneyed); A. Ed.
  denied. 55. A. Ed. <i>om.</i> as; Lat. <i>ueluti</i>. // C. A. stiere (<i>better</i> stere). 57.
  A. corumpynge. 63. A. natheles; C. natles. 82. C. hem; A. Ed. hym. 84. A. this; C. Ed. his. 93. C.
  reprehendnen. 96. A. hem; C. Ed. it. 99. C. desposede; A. Ed. disposed; <i>read</i> deposed; Lat.
  <i>deposuit</i>. 100. A. wilt; Ed. wylte; C. wil. 105. C. Ed. be; A. is. // A. Ed. No man; C. non.
  107. A. Ed. if he; C. yif it. 110. A. may do. 116. C. scornesthow ... pleyesthow ...
  desseyuesthow. 118. Ed. Dedalus; C. dydalus; A. didalus. 119. C. A. issest; Ed. issuest. 120. C.
  fooldesthow. 125. C. fulle the; A. the ful; Lat. <i>plenam beatitudinem</i>. 127. Ed. god
  (<i>Deus</i>); C. A. good. 132. A. bountee; C. bowonte. 139. C. A. desseyue. 142. C. resseiueth.
  143. C. aparmanides; Ed. Permenides; A. parmaynws; Lat. <i>Parmenides</i>. 148. C. Ed. styred; A.
  stered. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre XII.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Felix, qui potuit boni.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Blisful is that man that may seen the clere welle of good; blisful</p>
<p>is he that may unbinden him fro the bondes of the hevy erthe.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page91">{91}</span>The poete of <a href="#BIIIMXIINL3" id="BIIIMXIIL3" class="pginternal">Trace, <i>Orpheus</i></a>, that whylom hadde right greet sorwe</p>
<p>for the deeth of his wyf, after that he hadde maked, by his <a href="#BIIIMXIINL4" id="BIIIMXIIL4" class="pginternal">weeply</a></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">songes, the wodes, <a href="#BIIIMXIINL5" id="BIIIMXIIL5" class="pginternal">moevable</a>, to
    rennen; and hadde maked the</p>
<p>riveres to stonden stille; and hadde maked the hertes and the</p>
<p>hindes to ioignen, dredeles, hir sydes to cruel lyouns, <i>for to herknen</i></p>
<p><i>his songe</i>; and hadde maked that the hare was nat agast of the</p>
<p>hounde, which that was plesed by his songe: so, whan the moste</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ardaunt love of his wif brende the entrailes of his brest, ne the</p>
<p>songes that hadden overcomen alle thinges ne mighten nat</p>
<p>asswagen hir lord <i>Orpheus</i>, he pleynede him of the <a href="#BIIIMXIINL12" id="BIIIMXIIL12" class="pginternal">hevene goddes</a></p>
<p>that weren cruel to him; he wente him to the houses of helle.</p>
<p>And there he temprede hise blaundisshinge songes by resowninge</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">strenges, and spak and song in wepinge al that ever he hadde</p>
<p>received and <a href="#BIIIMXIINL16" id="BIIIMXIIL16" class="pginternal">laved out</a> of the noble welles of
    his moder <a href="#BIIIMXIINL16" class="pginternal"><i>Calliope</i></a></p>
<p>the goddesse; <a href="#BIIIMXIINL17" id="BIIIMXIIL17" class="pginternal">and he song</a> with as mochel as he
    mighte of wepinge,</p>
<p>and with as moche as love, that doublede his sorwe, mighte</p>
<p>yeve him and techen him; and he commoevede the helle, and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">requerede and bisoughte by swete preyere the lordes of sowles</p>
<p>in helle, <a href="#BIIIMXIINL21" id="BIIIMXIIL21" class="pginternal">of relesinge</a>; <i>that is to seyn, to
    yilden him his wyf</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#BIIIMXIINL22" id="BIIIMXIIL22" class="pginternal"><i>Cerberus</i></a>, the porter of
    helle, with his three hevedes, was caught</p>
<p>and al abayst for the newe song; and the three goddesses, <a href="#BIIIMXIINL23" id="BIIIMXIIL23" class="pginternal"><i>Furies</i></a>,</p>
<p>and vengeresses of felonyes, that tormenten and agasten the sowles</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">by anoy, woxen sorwful and sory, and wepen teres for pitee.</p>
<p>Tho ne was nat the heved of <a href="#BIIIMXIINL26" id="BIIIMXIIL26" class="pginternal">Ixion</a> y-tormented by
    the <a href="#BIIIMXIINL26" class="pginternal">overthrowinge</a></p>
<p>wheel; and <a href="#BIIIMXIINL27" id="BIIIMXIIL27" class="pginternal">Tantalus</a>, that was destroyed by the
    woodnesse</p>
<p>of longe thurst, despyseth the flodes to drinke; the fowl that</p>
<p>highte voltor, that eteth the stomak or the giser of <a href="#BIIIMXIINL29" id="BIIIMXIIL29" class="pginternal">Tityus</a>, is so</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">fulfild of his song that it nil eten ne tyren no more. At the laste</p>
<p>the lord and Iuge of sowles was moeved to misericordes and</p>
<p>cryde, "we ben overcomen," quod he; "yive we to Orpheus his</p>
<p>wyf to bere him companye; he hath wel y-bought hir by his song</p>
<p>and his ditee; <a href="#BIIIMXIINL34" id="BIIIMXIIL34" class="pginternal">but we wol</a> putte a lawe in this,
    and covenaunt in</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page92">{92}</span>the yifte: <i>that is to seyn</i>,
    that, til he be out of helle, yif he loke</p>
<p>behinde him, that his wyf shal comen ayein unto us."</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#BIIIMXIINL37" id="BIIIMXIIL37" class="pginternal">But what</a> is he that may yive a
    lawe to loveres? Love is</p>
<p>a gretter lawe and a strenger to him-self <i>than any lawe that men</i></p>
<p><i>may yeven</i>. Allas! whan Orpheus and his wyf weren almest at the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">termes of the night, <i>that is to seyn, at the laste boundes of helle</i>,</p>
<p>Orpheus lokede abakward on Eurydice his wyf, and loste hir, and</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIINL42" id="BIIIMXIIL42" class="pginternal">was deed</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza">This fable aperteineth to yow alle, who-so-ever desireth or</p>
<p>seketh to lede his thought in-to the soverein day, <i>that is to seyn,</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>to cleernesse of soverein good</i>. For who-so that ever be so overcomen</p>
<p>that he ficche his eyen into the putte of helle, <i>that is to</i></p>
<p><i>seyn, who-so sette his thoughtes in erthely thinges</i>, al that ever he</p>
<p>hath drawen of the noble good celestial, he leseth it whan he</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIINL49" id="BIIIMXIIL49" class="pginternal">loketh</a> the helles,' <i>that is to seyn, in-to
    lowe thinges of the erthe</i>.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. XII.</span> 2. A. bonde; Lat. <i>uincula</i>. // A. Ed. <i>om.
  2nd</i> the. 4. C. wepply; A. Ed. wepely. 7. A. cruel; C. cruwel. 10. A. Ed. ardaunt; C. ardent.
  12. C. goodes; A. godes (<i>om.</i> hevene); Lat. <i>superos</i>. 14. C. blaundyssynge; A.
  blaundissyng. 15. C. soonge; A. song (<i>twice</i>). 16. C. resseyued; A. resceyued. // C.
  calyope; A. calliope. 17. A. as mychel as he myȝt; C. <i>om.</i> he. 19. C. thechen;
  <i>after</i> techen him, A. <i>adds</i> in his seke herte (<i>not in</i> Lat.) 23. Ed. Furyes; C.
  A. furijs. 27. C. tatalus (<i>for</i> tātalus). 28. A. thrust. 29. Ed. Tityus; C. A.
  ticius; Lat. <i>Tityi</i>. 33. A. his faire song; Lat. <i>carmine</i>. 38. A. gretter; C. gret;
  Lat. <i>maior</i>. 41. C. A. Erudice; Ed. Euridice; Lat. <i>Eurydicen</i>. 43. C. apartienyth; A.
  apperteineth. 45. C. god; A. goode. 46. C. fychche. 47. C. <i>om.</i> his <i>after</i> sette. 49.
  A. to (<i>for</i> in-to). // C. <i>om.</i> the <i>bef.</i> erthe. </p>
<p class="sp5 ac"><b>Explicit Liber tercius.</b></p>
<h2 class="sp3 ac" style="margin-bottom:2.1ex;"> <span class="larger">BOOK IV.</span></h2>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose I.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Hec cum Philosophia, dignitate uultus.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Whan Philosophye hadde songen softely and delitably the</p>
<p>forseide thinges, kepinge the dignitee of hir chere and the</p>
<p>weighte of hir wordes, I thanne, that ne hadde nat al-outerly</p>
<p>foryeten the wepinge and the mourninge that was set in myn</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">herte, <a href="#BIVPINL5" id="BIVPIL5" class="pginternal">forbrak</a> the entencioun of hir that
    entendede yit to seyn</p>
<p>some othre thinges. 'O,' quod I, 'thou that art gyderesse of</p>
<p>verrey light; the thinges that thou hast seid me hider-to ben so</p>
<p>clere to me and so shewinge by the devyne lookinge of hem, and</p>
<p>by thy resouns, that they ne mowen ben overcomen. And</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thilke thinges that thou toldest me, al-be-it so that I hadde</p>
<p>whylom foryeten hem, for the sorwe of the wrong that hath ben</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page93">{93}</span>don to me, yit natheles they ne weren nat
    al-outrely unknowen to</p>
<p>me. But this same is, namely, a right greet cause of my sorwe,</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPINL14" id="BIVPIL14" class="pginternal">so as</a> the governour of thinges is good, yif that
    yveles mowen ben</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">by any weyes; or elles yif that yveles passen with-oute punisshinge.</p>
<p>The whiche thing only, how worthy it is to ben wondred</p>
<p>up-on, thou considerest it wel thy-self certeinly. But yit to this</p>
<p>thing ther is yit another thing y-ioigned, more to ben wondred</p>
<p>up-on. For felonye is emperesse, and floureth <i>ful of richesses</i>;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and vertu nis nat al-only with-oute medes, but it is cast under and</p>
<p>fortroden under the feet of felonous folk; and it abyeth the</p>
<p>torments in stede of wikkede felounes. Of alle whiche thinges</p>
<p>ther nis no wight that may merveylen y-nough, ne compleine,</p>
<p>that swiche thinges ben doon in the regne of god, that alle thinges</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">woot and <a href="#BIVPINL25" id="BIVPIL25" class="pginternal">alle thinges may</a>, and ne wole
    nat but only gode</p>
<p>thinges.'</p>
<p class="stanza">Thanne seyde she thus: 'Certes,' quod she, 'that were a greet</p>
<p>merveyle, and <a href="#BIVPINL27" id="BIVPIL27" class="pginternal">an enbasshinge with-outen ende</a>, and wel
    more</p>
<p>horrible than alle monstres, yif it were as thou wenest; <i>that is to</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>seyn</i>, that in the <a href="#BIVPINL30" id="BIVPIL30" class="pginternal">right ordenee</a>
    hous of so mochel a fader and an</p>
<p>ordenour of meynee, that the vesseles that ben foule and vyle</p>
<p>sholden ben honoured and <a href="#BIVPINL32" id="BIVPIL32" class="pginternal">heried</a>, and the precious
    vesseles</p>
<p>sholden ben defouled and vyle; but it nis nat so. For yif tho</p>
<p>thinges that I have concluded a litel her-biforn ben kept hole</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and unraced, thou shalt wel knowe by the autoritee of god, of the</p>
<p>whos regne I speke, that certes the gode folk ben alwey mighty,</p>
<p>and shrewes ben alwey out-cast and feble; ne the vyces ne ben</p>
<p>never-mo with-oute peyne, ne the vertues ne ben nat with-oute</p>
<p>mede; and that blisfulnesses comen alwey to goode folk, and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">infortune comth alwey to wikked folk. And thou shalt wel</p>
<p>knowe many thinges of this kinde, that shollen <a href="#BIVPINL41" id="BIVPIL41" class="pginternal">cesen</a>
    thy pleintes,</p>
<p>and strengthen thee with stedefast sadnesse. And for thou hast</p>
<p>seyn the forme of the verray blisfulnesse by me, that have</p>
<p>whylom shewed it thee, and thou hast knowen in whom blisfulnesse</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page94">{94}</span>is y-set, <a href="#BIVPINL45" id="BIVPIL45" class="pginternal">alle thinges</a> y-treted that I trowe ben necessarie to</p>
<p>putten forth, I shal shewe thee the wey that shal bringen thee</p>
<p>ayein un-to thyn hous. And I shal ficchen <a href="#BIVPINL47" id="BIVPIL47" class="pginternal">fetheres</a> in
    thy thought,</p>
<p>by whiche it may arysen in heighte, so that, alle tribulacioun</p>
<p>y-don awey, thou, by my gydinge and by my path and by my</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIVPINL50" id="BIVPIL50" class="pginternal">sledes</a>, shalt mowe retorne hool and
    sound in-to thy contree.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. I.</span> 6. A. <i>om.</i> some. // A. Se (<i>for</i> O); Lat.
  <i>o</i>. // C. <i>om.</i> that. 7. A. <i>om.</i> me. 9. A. Ed. thy; C. the. 14. C. so as; Ed. so
  that as; A. that so as. 19. C. imperisse; A. emperisse; Ed. emperesse. // A. rycchesse. 20. A.
  vertues (<i>badly</i>). 22. Ed. stede; C. stide; A. sted. 25. C. good; A. goode. 28. A.
  enbaissynge; Ed. abasshyng. 29. C. horible. // C. al; A. alle. 31. A. Ed. vyle; C. vyl
  (<i>twice</i>). 32. C. he heryed (<i>mistake for</i> heryed). 33. C. tho; A. Ed. the. 35. Ed.
  vnaraced. 37. A. yuel (<i>for</i> out-cast). 42. C. strengthyn; A. stedfast (!). // C. stidfast;
  A. stedfast. 45. C. I tretyd; A. I treted; Ed. treated; Lat. <i>decursis omnibus</i>. 48. C.
  areysen. 50. C. sledys; A. Ed. sledes. // C. shal (<i>for</i> shalt). </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre I.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Sunt etenim pennae uolucres mihi.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>I have, forsothe, swifte fetheres that surmounten the heighte of</p>
<p>hevene. <a href="#BIVMINL2" id="BIVMIL2" class="pginternal">Whan the swifte thought hath clothed it-self</a> in
    tho</p>
<p>fetheres, it despyseth the hateful erthes, and surmounteth the</p>
<p>roundnesse of the grete ayr; and it seeth the cloudes behinde his</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">bak; and passeth the heighte of the region of the <a href="#BIVMINL5" id="BIVMIL5" class="pginternal">fyr</a>, that</p>
<p>eschaufeth by the swifte moevinge of the firmament, til that he</p>
<p>areyseth him in-to the houses that beren the sterres, and ioyneth</p>
<p>his weyes with the sonne Phebus, and felawshipeth the wey of</p>
<p>the olde colde <a href="#BIVMINL9" id="BIVMIL9" class="pginternal">Saturnus</a>; <a href="#BIVMINL9" class="pginternal">and he
    y-maked</a> a knight of the clere</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">sterre; <i>that is to seyn, that the thought is maked goddes knight by</i></p>
<p><i>the sekinge of trouthe to comen to the verray knowleche of god</i>.</p>
<p>And thilke thoght renneth by the cercle of the sterres, in alle</p>
<p>places ther-as the shyninge night is peinted; <i>that is to seyn, the</i></p>
<p><i>night that is cloudeles; for on nightes that ben cloudeles it semeth as</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>the hevene were peinted with dyverse <a href="#BIVMINL15" id="BIVMIL15" class="pginternal">images of sterres</a></i>. And</p>
<p>whanne he hath y-doon ther y-nough, he shal forleten the laste</p>
<p>hevene, and he shal pressen and wenden on the bak of the</p>
<p>swifte firmament, and he shal ben maked parfit of the <a href="#BIVMINL18" id="BIVMIL18" class="pginternal">worshipful</a></p>
<p><a href="#BIVMINL18" class="pginternal">light</a> <i>of god</i>. Ther halt the lord of kinges the ceptre of
    his</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">might, and atempreth the governements of the world, and the</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page95">{95}</span>shyninge Iuge of thinges, stable in him-self,
    governeth the <a href="#BIVMINL22" id="BIVMIL22" class="pginternal">swifte</a></p>
<p><a href="#BIVMINL22" class="pginternal">cart</a> or wayn, <i>that is to seyn, the circuler moevinge of the
    sonne</i>.</p>
<p>And yif thy wey ledeth thee ayein so that thou be brought thider,</p>
<p>thanne wolt thou seye now that that is the contree that thou</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">requerest, of which thou ne haddest no minde: "<a href="#BIVMINL25" id="BIVMIL25" class="pginternal">but now</a> it</p>
<p>remembreth me wel, heer was I born, <a href="#BIVMINL26" id="BIVMIL26" class="pginternal">heer wol I fastne
    my</a></p>
<p><a href="#BIVMINL26" class="pginternal">degree</a>, heer wole I dwelle." <a href="#BIVMINL27" id="BIVMIL27" class="pginternal">But
    yif</a> thee lyketh thanne to loken</p>
<p>on the derknesse of the erthe that thou hast forleten, thanne</p>
<p>shalt thou seen that thise felonous tyraunts, that the wrecchede</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">peple dredeth, now shollen ben exyled fro thilke fayre contree.'</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. I.</span> 1. C. swife (<i>for</i> swifte). 4. A.
  heyȝenesse (<i>for</i> roundnesse); Lat. <i>globum</i>. // A. hir (<i>for</i> his). 6. A.
  til that she areisith hir in-til ... hir weyes. 9. C. saturnis; A. saturnus. // A. she (<i>for</i>
  he). 10. A. soule (<i>for</i> thought); <i>twice</i>. 12. C. alle; A. alle the; Ed. al the. 13.
  Ed. ypaynted; A. depeynted. 16. A. And whan the soule hath gon ynouȝ she shal forleten the
  last poynt of the heuene, and she. 17. A. Ed. wenden; C. wyndyn. 18. A. she (<i>for</i> he). 18,
  19. C. Ed. worshipful lyht; A. dredefulle clerenesse. // A. haldeth. 20. A. this; <i>for</i> the
  (2). 22. A. <i>om.</i> or wayn. 25. C. requerest; Ed. requirest; A. requeredest. 27. A. lyke
  (<i>for</i> lyketh). 28. C. dyrknesses; A. derkenesse; Lat. <i>noctem</i>. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose II.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Tum ego, Papae, inquam.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Than seyde I thus: '<a href="#BIVPIINL1" id="BIVPIIL1" class="pginternal">owh!</a> I wondre me that thou
    bihetest me</p>
<p>so grete thinges; ne I ne doute nat that thou ne mayst wel</p>
<p>performe that thou bihetest. But I preye thee only this, that</p>
<p>thou ne tarye nat to telle me thilke thinges that thou hast</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">moeved.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'First,' quod she, 'thou most nedes knowen, that goode folk</p>
<p>ben alwey stronge and mighty, and the shrewes ben feble and</p>
<p>desert and naked of alle strengthes. And of thise thinges, certes,</p>
<p>everich of hem is declared and shewed by other. For so as</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">good and yvel ben two contraries, yif so be that good be stedefast,</p>
<p>than sheweth the feblesse of yvel al openly; and yif thou</p>
<p>knowe cleerly the frelenesse of yvel, the stedefastnesse of good is</p>
<p>knowen. But for as moche as the <a href="#BIVPIINL13" id="BIVPIIL13" class="pginternal">fey</a> of my sentence
    shal be the</p>
<p>more ferme and haboundaunt, I will gon by that oo wey and by</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that other; and I wole conferme the thinges that ben purposed,</p>
<p>now on this syde and now on that syde. Two thinges ther ben</p>
<p>in whiche the effect of alle the dedes of mankinde standeth, that</p>
<p>is to seyn, wil and power; and yif that oon of thise two fayleth,</p>
<p>ther nis nothing that may be don. For yif that wil lakketh, ther</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page96">{96}</span>nis no wight that undertaketh to
    don that he wol nat don; and</p>
<p>yif power fayleth, the wil nis but in ydel and stant for naught.</p>
<p>And ther-of cometh it, that yif thou see a wight that wolde geten</p>
<p>that he may nat geten, thou mayst nat douten that power ne</p>
<p>fayleth him to haven that he wolde.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">25</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'This is open and cleer,' quod I; 'ne it may nat ben deneyed</p>
<p>in no manere.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'And yif thou see a wight,' quod she, 'that hath doon that he</p>
<p>wolde doon, thou nilt nat douten that he ne hath had power to</p>
<p>don it?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">30</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'No,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'<a href="#BIVPIINL31" id="BIVPIIL31" class="pginternal">And in that that</a> every wight <a href="#BIVPIINL31" class="pginternal">may</a>, in that men may holden</p>
<p>him mighty; <i>as who seyth, in so moche as man is mighty to don a</i></p>
<p><i>thing, in so mochel men halt him mighty</i>; and in that that he ne</p>
<p>may, in that men demen him to be feble.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">35</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'I confesse it wel,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Remembreth thee,' quod she, 'that I have gadered and</p>
<p>shewed by forseyde resouns that al the entencioun of the wil of</p>
<p>mankinde, which that is <a href="#BIVPIINL38" id="BIVPIIL38" class="pginternal">lad</a> by dyverse <a href="#BIVPIINL38" class="pginternal">studies</a>, hasteth to</p>
<p>comen to blisfulnesse?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">40</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'It remembreth me wel,' quod I, 'that it hath ben shewed.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'And recordeth thee nat thanne,' quod she, 'that blisfulnesse</p>
<p>is thilke same good that men requeren; so that, whan that</p>
<p>blisfulnesse is requered of alle, that good also is requered and</p>
<p>desired of alle?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">45</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'It ne recordeth me nat,' quod I; 'for I have it gretly alwey</p>
<p>ficched in my memorie.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Alle folk thanne,' quod she, 'goode and eek badde, enforcen</p>
<p>hem with-oute difference of entencioun to comen to good?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'This is a verray consequence,' quod I.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">50</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'And certein is,' quod she, 'that by the getinge of good ben</p>
<p>men y-maked goode?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'This is certein,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne geten goode men that they desiren?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'So semeth it,' quod I.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">55</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page97">{97}</span>'But wikkede folk,' quod
    she, 'yif they geten the good that</p>
<p>they desiren, they ne mowe nat be wikkede?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'So is it,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne, so as that oon and that other,' quod she, 'desiren</p>
<p>good; and the goode folk geten good, and nat the wikke folk;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thanne nis it no doute that the goode folk ne ben mighty and</p>
<p>the wikkede folk ben feble?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Who-so that ever,' quod I, 'douteth of this, he ne may nat</p>
<p>considere the nature of thinges ne the consequence of resouns.'</p>
<p class="stanza">And over this quod she, 'yif that ther be two thinges that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">han oo same purpose by kinde, and that oon of hem pursueth</p>
<p>and parformeth thilke same thing by naturel office, and that</p>
<p>other ne may nat doon thilke naturel office, but folweth, by other</p>
<p>manere thanne is convenable to nature, him that acomplissheth</p>
<p>his purpos kindely, and yit he ne acomplissheth nat his owne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">purpos: whether of thise two demestow for more mighty?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'<a href="#BIVPIINL71" id="BIVPIIL71" class="pginternal">Yif that</a> I coniecte,' quod I, 'that
    thou wolt seye, algates yit</p>
<p>I desire to herkne it more pleynly of thee.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thou wilt nat thanne deneye,' quod she, 'that the moevement</p>
<p>of goinge nis in men by kinde?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">75</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'No, forsothe,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Ne thou ne doutest nat,' quod she, 'that thilke naturel office</p>
<p>of goinge ne be the office of feet?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'I ne doute it nat,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne,' quod she, 'yif that a wight be mighty to moeve and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">goth upon his feet, and another, to whom thilke naturel office of</p>
<p>feet lakketh, enforceth him to gon crepinge up-on his handes:</p>
<p>whiche of thise two oughte to ben holden the more mighty by</p>
<p>right?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'<a href="#BIVPIINL84" id="BIVPIIL84" class="pginternal">Knit forth</a> the remenaunt,' quod I;
    'for no wight ne douteth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">85</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that he that may gon by naturel office of feet ne be more mighty</p>
<p>than he that ne may nat.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'But the soverein good,' quod she, 'that is eveneliche purposed</p>
<p>to the gode folk and to badde, the gode folk seken it by naturel</p>
<p>office of vertues, and the shrewes enforcen hem to geten it by</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page98">{98}</span>dyverse coveityse <i>of erthely
    thinges</i>, which that nis no naturel office</p>
<p>to geten thilke same soverein good. Trowestow that it be any</p>
<p>other wyse?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Nay,' quod I; 'for the consequence is open and <a href="#BIVPIINL93" id="BIVPIIL93" class="pginternal">shewinge</a> of</p>
<p>thinges that I have graunted; that nedes gode folk moten ben</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">mighty, and shrewes feeble and unmighty.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thou rennest a-right biforn me,' quod she, 'and this is the</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIINL97" id="BIVPIIL97" class="pginternal">Iugement</a>; <i>that is to seyn, I iuge of thee</i>
    right as thise leches ben</p>
<p>wont to hopen <i>of syke folk, whan they aperceyven</i> that nature is</p>
<p>redressed and withstondeth to the maladye. But, for I see thee</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">now al redy to the understondinge, I shal shewe thee more thikke</p>
<p>and continuel resouns. For loke now how greetly sheweth the</p>
<p>feblesse and infirmitee of wikkede folk, that ne mowen nat comen</p>
<p>to that hir naturel entencioun <a href="#BIVPIINL103" id="BIVPIIL103" class="pginternal">ledeth hem</a>, and yit
    almost thilke</p>
<p>naturel entencioun constreineth hem. <a href="#BIVPIINL104" id="BIVPIIL104" class="pginternal">And what</a>
<i>were to demen</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>thanne of shrewes</i>, yif thilke naturel help hadde forleten hem, the</p>
<p>which <i>naturel help of intencioun</i> goth awey biforn hem, and is so</p>
<p>greet that unnethe it may ben overcome? Consider thanne how</p>
<p>greet defaute of power and how greet feblesse ther is in wikkede</p>
<p>felonous folk; <i>as who seyth, the gretter thing that is coveited and</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>the desire nat acomplisshed, of the lasse might is he that coveiteth
    it</i></p>
<p><i>and may nat acomplisshe. And forthy Philosophie seyth thus by</i></p>
<p><i>soverein good</i>: <a href="#BIVPIINL112" id="BIVPIIL112" class="pginternal">Ne shrewes</a> ne requeren nat
    lighte medes ne veyne</p>
<p>games, whiche they ne may folwen ne holden; but they failen of</p>
<p>thilke somme and of the heighte of thinges, <i>that is to seyn, soverein</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>good</i>; ne thise wrecches ne comen nat to the effect <i>of
    soverein</i></p>
<p><i>good</i>, the which they enforcen hem only to geten, by nightes and</p>
<p>by dayes; in the getinge of which good the strengthe of good folk</p>
<p>is ful wel y-sene. For right so as thou mightest demen him mighty</p>
<p>of goinge, that gooth on his feet til he mighte come to thilke</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">120</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">place, fro the whiche place ther ne <a href="#BIVPIINL120" id="BIVPIIL120" class="pginternal">laye</a> no wey forther to ben</p>
<p>gon; right so most thou nedes demen him for right mighty, that</p>
<p>geteth and ateyneth to the ende of alle thinges that ben to desire,</p>
<p>biyonde the whiche ende ther nis nothing to desire. Of the</p>
<p>which <i>power of good folk</i> men may conclude, that the wikked</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page99">{99}</span>men semen to be bareine and naked
    of alle strengthe. For-why</p>
<p>forleten they vertues and folwen vyces? Nis it nat for that they</p>
<p>ne knowen nat the goodes? But what thing is more feble and</p>
<p>more caitif thanne is the blindnesse of ignoraunce? Or elles they</p>
<p>knowen ful wel whiche thinges that they oughten folwe, but</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">lecherye and coveityse overthroweth hem mistorned; and certes,</p>
<p>so doth distemperaunce to feble men, that ne mowen nat wrastlen</p>
<p>ayeins the vyces. Ne knowen they nat thanne wel that they</p>
<p>forleten the good wilfully, and tornen hem wilfully to vyces? And</p>
<p>in this wyse they ne forleten nat only to ben mighty, but they</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">135</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">forleten al-outrely in any wyse for to ben. For they that forleten</p>
<p>the comune fyn of alle thinges that ben, they forleten also therwith-al</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIINL137" id="BIVPIIL137" class="pginternal">for to ben</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza">And per-aventure it sholde semen to som folk that this were</p>
<p>a merveile to seyen: that shrewes, whiche that contienen the more</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">partye of men, ne ben nat ne han no beinge; but natheles, it is so,</p>
<p>and thus stant this thing. For they that ben shrewes, I deneye</p>
<p>nat that they ben shrewes; but I deneye, and seye simplely and</p>
<p>pleinly, that they ne ben nat, ne han no beinge. For right as</p>
<p>thou mightest seyen of the carayne of a man, that it were a deed</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">145</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">man, but thou ne mightest nat simplely callen it a man; so graunte</p>
<p>I wel forsothe, that vicious folk ben wikked, but I ne may nat</p>
<p>graunten absolutly and simplely that they ben. For thilke thing</p>
<p>that with-holdeth ordre and kepeth nature, thilke thing is and</p>
<p>hath beinge; but what thing that faileth of that, <i>that is to seyn,</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">150</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>that he forleteth naturel ordre</i>, he forleteth thilke thing that is
    set</p>
<p>in his nature. But thou wolt seyn, that shrewes <a href="#BIVPIINL151" id="BIVPIIL151" class="pginternal">mowen</a>. Certes,</p>
<p>that ne deneye I nat; but certes, hir power ne descendeth nat of</p>
<p>strengthe, but of feblesse. For they mowen don wikkednesses;</p>
<p>the whiche they ne mighte nat don, yif they mighten dwellen in</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">155</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the forme and in the doinge of good folk. And thilke power</p>
<p>sheweth ful evidently that they ne mowen right naught. For so</p>
<p>as I have gadered and proeved a litel her-biforn, that yvel is</p>
<p>naught; and so as shrewes mowen only but shrewednesses, this</p>
<p>conclusioun is al cleer, that shrewes ne mowen right naught, ne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">160</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">han no power.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page100">{100}</span><a href="#BIVPIINL161" id="BIVPIIL161" class="pginternal">And for as moche as thou understonde</a> which is the strengthe</p>
<p>of this power of shrewes, I have definisshed a litel her-biforn, that</p>
<p>nothing is so mighty as soverein good.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'That is sooth,' quod I.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">165</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'And thilke same soverein good may don non yvel?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes, no,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Is ther any wight thanne,' quod she, 'that weneth that men</p>
<p>mowen doon alle thinges?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'No man,' quod I, 'but-yif he be out of his witte.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">170</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'But, certes, shrewes mowen don yvel,' quod she.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Ye, wolde god,' quod I, 'that they mighten don non!'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne,' quod she, 'so as he that is mighty to doon only but</p>
<p>goode thinges may don alle thinges; and they that ben mighty to</p>
<p>don yvele thinges ne mowen nat alle thinges: thanne is it open</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">175</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thing and manifest, that they that mowen don yvel ben of lasse</p>
<p>power. And yit, <i>to proeve this conclusioun</i>, ther helpeth me this,</p>
<p>that I have y-shewed her-biforn, that alle power is to be noumbred</p>
<p>among thinges that men oughten requere. And I have shewed</p>
<p>that alle thinges, that oughten ben desired, ben referred to good,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">180</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">right as to a maner heighte of hir nature. But for to mowen don</p>
<p>yvel and felonye ne may nat ben referred to good. Thanne nis</p>
<p>nat yvel of the noumbir of thinges that oughte ben desired. But</p>
<p>alle power oughte ben desired and requered. Than is it open and</p>
<p>cleer that the power ne the mowinge of shrewes nis no power; and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">185</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of alle thise thinges it sheweth wel, that the goode folke ben certeinly</p>
<p>mighty, and the shrewes douteles ben unmighty. And it is</p>
<p>cleer and open that thilke opinioun of <a href="#BIVPIINL187" id="BIVPIIL187" class="pginternal">Plato</a> is
    verray and sooth, that</p>
<p>seith, that only wyse men may doon that they desiren; and</p>
<p>shrewes mowen haunten that hem lyketh, but that they desiren,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">190</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>that is to seyn, to comen to sovereign good</i>, they ne han no power</p>
<p>to acomplisshen that. For shrewes don that hem list, whan, by</p>
<p>tho thinges in which they delyten, they wenen to ateine to thilke</p>
<p>good that they desiren; but they ne geten ne ateinen nat ther-to,</p>
<p>for vyces ne comen nat to blisfulnesse.</p>
</div>
<p><span class="sc">Pr. II.</span> 1. C. owh; Ed. O; A. <i>om.</i>; Lat. <i>Papae</i>. 8. C.
  dishert; A. desert; Ed. deserte; Lat. <i>desertos</i>. // <i>All</i> strengthes; Lat.
  <i>uiribus</i>. 10. C. stidefast; A. stedfast. 12. C. stidefastnesse; A. stedfastnesse. 13. C. A.
  fey; Ed. faythe. 19. C. lakkit; A. lakketh. 25. C. denoyed. 28. C. <i>om.</i> he <i>bef.</i> ne.
  33. C. halt; A. halden; Ed. holde. // A. Ed. that that; C. that. 42. A. whan that; C. Ed.
  <i>om.</i> that. 45. C. It ne ... nat; A. It recordeth me wel; Lat. <i>Minimè ... recordor</i>.
  48. C. defference; A. Ed. difference. 63. A. resoun; Lat. <i>rationum</i>. 67. C. by (<i>for</i>
  but; <i>by mistake</i>). 68. Ed. accomplyssheth; A. acomplisith; C. a-complesseth (<i>twice</i>).
  70. A. demest thou. 73. C. denoye (<i>for</i> deneye); A. Ed. denye. // A. moeuementz; Lat.
  <i>motum</i>. 88. C. good folk (<i>1st time</i>); goode folk (<i>2nd time</i>). 91. A. trowest
  thou. 92. A. wyse; C. whise. 99. C. maledie; A. maladie. 104. C. <i>om.</i> hem <i>after</i>
  constreineth. 109. A. the gretter thinges that ben. 110. C. acomplised; A. accomplissed; Ed.
  accomplysshed. 112. C. veyn; A. veyne. 120. A. lay. 122. C. desired (<i>for</i> desire, <i>by
  mistake</i>). 135. A. wise; C. whise. 141. C. denoye (<i>for</i> deneye); A. denye
  (<i>thrice</i>). 142. C. sympeli (<i>1st time</i>). 149. C. Ed. what; A. that. 151. C. shrewen
  (<i>by mistake</i>). 152. A. descendeth; C. dessendit (<i>sic</i>). 158. A. shrewednesse; Lat.
  <i>mala</i>. 160. A. to han (<i>for</i> ne han no). 162. C. diffinissed; A. diffinised; Ed.
  defynisshed; Lat. <i>definiuimus</i>. 169. A. but yif; Ed. but if; C. but. 186. A. <i>om.</i> ben.
  188. A. <i>om.</i> doon. 192. C. the; A. Ed. tho. 194. C. <i>om.</i> to. </p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page101">{101}</span></div>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre II.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quos uides sedere celsos.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Who-so that the covertoures of hir veyne aparailes mighte strepen</p>
<p>of thise proude kinges, that thou seest sitten on heigh in hir</p>
<p>chaires gliteringe in shyninge purpre, envirouned with sorwful</p>
<p>armures, manasinge with cruel mouth, blowinge by woodnesse of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">herte, he shulde seen thanne that thilke lordes beren with-inne hir</p>
<p>corages ful streite cheines. For lecherye tormenteth hem in that</p>
<p>oon syde with gredy venims; and troublable ire, that araiseth in</p>
<p>him the flodes <i>of troublinges</i>, tormenteth up-on that other syde</p>
<p>hir thought; or sorwe halt hem wery and y-caught; or slydinge</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and deceivinge hope tormenteth hem. And therfore, sen thou</p>
<p>seest oon heed, <i>that is to seyn, oon tyraunt</i>, beren so manye</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIINL12" id="BIVMIIL12" class="pginternal">tyrannyes</a>, thanne ne doth thilke tyraunt nat that he
    desireth, sin</p>
<p>he is cast doun with so manye wikkede lordes; <i>that is to seyn, with</i></p>
<p><i>so manye vyces, that han so wikkedly lordshipes over him</i>.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. II.</span> 1. Ed. vayne; C. A. veyn. 2. A. Ed. in; C. on. 3.
  Ed. chayres; C. (<i>miswritten</i>) charyes; A. chayeres. 4. A. manasyng; C. manassinge. 8. A.
  troublynges; C. trwblynges. 9. C. hym (<i>for</i> hem). 12. C. Ed. tyrannyes; A. tyrauntis. 14. A.
  wicked (<i>for</i> wikkedly). </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose III.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Videsne igitur quanto in coeno.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Seestow nat thanne in how grete filthe thise shrewes ben</p>
<p>y-wrapped, and with which cleernesse thise good folk shynen? In</p>
<p>this sheweth it wel, that to goode folk ne lakketh never-mo hir</p>
<p>medes, ne shrewes lakken never-mo torments. For of alle thinges</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that ben y-doon, thilke thing, for which any-thing is don, it semeth</p>
<p>as by right that thilke thing be the mede of that; as thus: yif</p>
<p>a man renneth in the <a href="#BIVPIIINL7" id="BIVPIIIL7" class="pginternal">stadie</a>, <i>or in the
    forlong</i>, for the corone,</p>
<p>thanne lyth the mede in the corone for which he renneth. And</p>
<p>I have shewed that blisfulnesse is thilke same good for which</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that alle thinges ben doon. Thanne is thilke same good <a href="#BIVPIIINL10" id="BIVPIIIL10" class="pginternal">purposed</a></p>
<p>to the workes of mankinde right as a comune mede; which</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page102">{102}</span>mede ne may ben dissevered fro good folk. For
    no wight as by</p>
<p>right, fro thennes-forth that him lakketh goodnesse, ne shal ben</p>
<p>cleped good. <a href="#BIVPIIINL14" id="BIVPIIIL14" class="pginternal">For which thing</a>, folk of goode
    maneres, hir medes</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ne forsaken hem never-mo. For al-be-it so that shrewes wexen</p>
<p>as wode as hem list <i>ayeins goode folk</i>, yit never-the-lesse the</p>
<p>corone of wyse men shal nat fallen ne faden. For foreine shrewednesse</p>
<p>ne binimeth nat fro the corages of goode folk hir propre</p>
<p>honour. But yif that any wight reioyse him of goodnesse that he</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">hadde take fro with-oute (<i>as who seith, yif that any wight hadde</i></p>
<p><i>his goodnesse of any other man than of him-self</i>), certes, he that yaf</p>
<p>him thilke goodnesse, or elles som other wight, mighte binime it</p>
<p>him. But for as moche as to every wight his owne propre bountee</p>
<p>yeveth him his mede, thanne at erst shal he failen of mede whan</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">he forleteth to ben good. And at the laste, <a href="#BIVPIIINL25" id="BIVPIIIL25" class="pginternal">so as</a> alle medes ben</p>
<p>requered <a href="#BIVPIIINL26" id="BIVPIIIL26" class="pginternal">for men</a> wenen that they ben goode, who is
    he that</p>
<p>wolde deme, that he that is right mighty of good were <a href="#BIVPIIINL27" id="BIVPIIIL27" class="pginternal">part-les</a> of</p>
<p>mede? And of what mede shal he be guerdoned? Certes, of</p>
<p>right faire mede and right grete aboven alle medes. Remembre</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thee of thilke noble corolarie that I yaf thee a litel her-biforn;</p>
<p>and gader it to-gider in this manere:—so as good him-self is</p>
<p>blisfulnesse, thanne is it cleer and certein, that alle good folk ben</p>
<p>maked blisful for they ben goode; and thilke folk that ben blisful,</p>
<p>it acordeth and is covenable to ben goddes. Thanne is the mede</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of goode folk swich that <a href="#BIVPIIINL35" id="BIVPIIIL35" class="pginternal">no day</a> shal
    enpeiren it, ne no wikkednesse</p>
<p>ne shal derken it, ne power of no wight ne shal nat amenusen it,</p>
<p><i>that is to seyn</i>, to ben maked goddes.</p>
<p class="stanza">And sin it is thus, <i>that goode men ne failen never-mo of hir mede</i>,</p>
<p>certes, no wys man ne may doute of <a href="#BIVPIIINL39" id="BIVPIIIL39" class="pginternal">undepartable</a>
    peyne of the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">shrewes; <i>that is to seyn, that the peyne of shrewes ne departeth nat</i></p>
<p><i>from hem-self never-mo</i>. For so as goode and yvel, and peyne and</p>
<p>medes ben contrarye, it mot nedes ben, that right as we seen</p>
<p>bityden in guerdoun of goode, that also mot the peyne of yvel</p>
<p>answery, by the contrarye party, to shrewes. Now thanne, so as</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page103">{103}</span>bountee and prowesse ben the
    mede to goode folk, al-so is</p>
<p>shrewednesse it-self torment to shrewes. Thanne, who-so that</p>
<p>ever is entecched and defouled with peyne, he ne douteth nat,</p>
<p>that he is entecched and defouled with yvel. Yif shrewes thanne</p>
<p>wolen preysen hem-self, <a href="#BIVPIIINL49" id="BIVPIIIL49" class="pginternal">may it semen</a> to hem that
    they ben with-outen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">party of torment, sin they ben swiche that the uttereste</p>
<p>wikkednesse (<i>that is to seyn, wikkede thewes, which that is the</i></p>
<p><i>uttereste and the worste kinde of shrewednesse</i>) ne defouleth ne</p>
<p>enteccheth nat hem only, but infecteth and envenimeth hem</p>
<p>gretly? And also look on shrewes, that ben the contrarie party</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of goode men, how greet peyne felawshipeth and folweth hem!</p>
<p>For thou hast lerned a litel her-biforn, that al thing that is and</p>
<p>hath beinge is oon, and thilke same oon is good; thanne is this</p>
<p>the consequence, that it semeth wel, that al that is and hath beinge</p>
<p>is good; <i>this is to seyn, as who seyth, that beinge and unitee and</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>goodnesse is al oon</i>. And in this manere it folweth thanne, that al</p>
<p>thing that faileth to ben good, it stinteth for to be and for to han</p>
<p>any beinge; wherfore it is, that shrewes stinten for to ben that</p>
<p>they weren. But thilke other forme of mankinde, that is to seyn,</p>
<p>the forme of the body with-oute, sheweth yit that thise shrewes</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">weren whylom men; wher-for, whan they ben perverted and</p>
<p>torned in-to malice, certes, than han they forlorn the nature of</p>
<p>mankinde. But so as only bountee and prowesse may enhaunsen</p>
<p>every man over other men; thanne mot it nedes be that shrewes,</p>
<p>which that shrewednesse hath cast out of the condicioun of mankinde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ben put <a href="#BIVPIIINL70" id="BIVPIIIL70" class="pginternal">under</a> the merite and the
    desert of men. Thanne</p>
<p>bitydeth it, that yif thou seest a wight that be transformed into</p>
<p>vyces, thou ne mayst nat wene that he be a man.</p>
<p class="stanza">For yif he be ardaunt in avaryce, and that he be a ravinour by</p>
<p>violence of foreine richesse, thou shalt seyn that he is lyke to the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">wolf. And yif he be felonous and with-oute reste, and exercyse</p>
<p>his tonge to chydinges, thou shalt lykne him to the hound. And</p>
