<p><span class="pagenum" id="page104">{104}</span>yif he be a prevey awaitour y-hid, and
    reioyseth him to ravisshe</p>
<p>by wyles, thou shalt seyn him lyke to the fox-whelpes. And yif he</p>
<p>be distempre and quaketh for ire, men shal wene that he bereth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the corage of a lyoun. And yif he be dredful and fleinge, and</p>
<p>dredeth thinges that ne oughten nat to ben dred, men shal holden</p>
<p>him lyk to the hert. And yif he be slow and astoned and lache, he</p>
<p>liveth as an asse. And yif he be light and unstedefast of corage, and</p>
<p>chaungeth ay his studies, he is lykned to briddes. And if he be</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">85</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">plounged in foule and unclene luxuries, he is with-holden in the</p>
<p>foule delyces of the foule sowe. Thanne folweth it, that he that forleteth</p>
<p>bountee and prowesse, he forleteth to ben a man; sin he may</p>
<p>nat passen in-to the condicioun of god, he is torned in-to a beest.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. III.</span> 1. A. Seest thou. 16. A. les; C. leese (<i>error
  for</i> lesse). 17. C. faaden. 25. A. laste; C. last. 27. A. wolde; C. Ed. nolde; Lat. <i>quis ...
  iudicet</i>. 27, 28. A. Ed. of mede; C. of the mede. // C. A. gerdoned; Ed. reguerdoned. 30. C.
  yat (<i>miswritten for</i> yaf). 31. C. good him-self; A. Ed. god him-self; Lat. <i>ipsum
  bonum</i>. // C. his (<i>error for</i> is); <i>after</i> him-self. 36. A. endirken (<i>for</i>
  derken). 38. A. medes. 43. C. gerdown; A. gerdoun; Ed. guerdone. 44. A. Ed. answer<i>e</i>. // A.
  Ed. by the; C. <i>om.</i> the. 45. A. medes; Lat. <i>praemium</i>. 47. C. entechched. //
  <i>Both</i> MSS. <i>om.</i> peyne ... defouled with; <i>but</i> Ed. <i>has</i>: payne, he ne
  douteth not, that he is entetched and defouled with; Lat. <i>quisquis afficitur poena, malo se
  affectum esse non dubitat</i>. 50. A. <i>om.</i> uttereste ... which that is the. 52. C. vtteriste
  (<i>1st time</i>); owttereste (<i>2nd time</i>). 55. C. folueth. 56. C. alle; A. al. 58. C. alle;
  A. al (<i>twice</i>). 67. A. Ed. so as; C. <i>om.</i> as. // C. enhawsen (<i>for</i>
  enhaw<i>n</i>sen). 73. A. rauynour; Ed. rauenour; C. rauaynour. 75. A. Ed. a wolf. // C.
  excersise. 77. A. rauysshe; C. rauysse. 78. A. Ed. wyles; C. whiles; Lat. <i>fraudibus</i>. 81. C.
  dredd. 82. A. Ed. slowe; C. slowh. 83. C. vnstidefast. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre III.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Vela Neritii dulcis.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Eurus <i>the wind</i> <a href="#BIVMIIINL1" id="BIVMIIIL1" class="pginternal">aryvede</a> <a href="#BIVMIIINL1" class="pginternal">the sailes</a> of <i>Ulixes</i>, duk of the contree</p>
<p>of Narice, and his wandringe shippes by the see, in-to the ile</p>
<p>ther-as <a href="#BIVMIIINL3" id="BIVMIIIL3" class="pginternal"><i>Circes</i></a>, the faire goddesse, doughter
    of the sonne,</p>
<p>dwelleth; that medleth to hir newe gestes drinkes that ben</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">touched and maked with enchauntements. And after that hir</p>
<p>hand, mighty over the herbes, hadde chaunged hir gestes in-to</p>
<p>dyverse maneres; <a href="#BIVMIIINL7" id="BIVMIIIL7" class="pginternal">that oon of hem</a>, is covered his
    face with forme</p>
<p>of a boor; that other is chaunged in-to a lyoun of the contree of</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIIINL9" id="BIVMIIIL9" class="pginternal">Marmorike</a>, and his nayles and his teeth wexen; that
    other of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">hem is neweliche chaunged in-to a wolf, and howleth whan he</p>
<p>wolde wepe; that other goth debonairely in the hous as a tygre</p>
<p>of Inde.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#BIVMIIINL13" id="BIVMIIIL13" class="pginternal">But al-be-it</a> so that the godhed of
    <i>Mercurie, that is cleped</i> the</p>
<p>brid of Arcadie, hath had mercy of the duke <i>Ulixes</i>, biseged with</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">dyverse yveles, and hath unbounden him fro the pestilence of</p>
<p>his ostesse, <a href="#BIVMIIINL16" id="BIVMIIIL16" class="pginternal">algates</a> the roweres and the marineres
    hadden by this</p>
<p>y-drawen in-to hir mouthes and dronken the wikkede drinkes.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page105">{105}</span>They that weren woxen swyn hadden by this
    y-chaunged hir</p>
<p>mete of breed, for to eten <a href="#BIVMIIINL19" id="BIVMIIIL19" class="pginternal">akornes of okes</a>. Non of
    hir limes ne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">dwelleth with hem hole, but they han lost the voice and the</p>
<p>body; only hir thought dwelleth with hem stable, that wepeth</p>
<p>and biweileth the monstruous chaunginge that they suffren. O</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIIINL23" id="BIVMIIIL23" class="pginternal">overlight</a> hand (<i>as who seyth, O! feble and
    light is the hand of</i></p>
<p><i>Circes the enchaunteresse, that chaungeth the bodyes of folkes in-to</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>bestes, to regard and to comparisoun of mutacioun that is maked by</i></p>
<p><i>vyces</i>); ne the herbes <i>of Circes</i> ne ben nat mighty. For al-be-it</p>
<p>so that they may chaungen the limes of the body, algates yit</p>
<p>they may nat chaunge the hertes; for with-inne is y-hid the</p>
<p>strengthe and vigor of men, in the secree tour <i>of hir hertes; that</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>is to seyn, the strengthe of resoun</i>. But thilke venims <i>of vyces</i>
    to-drawen</p>
<p>a man to hem more mightily <i>than the venim of Circes</i>;</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIIINL32" id="BIVMIIIL32" class="pginternal">for vyces</a> ben so cruel that they percen and
    thorugh-passen the</p>
<p>corage with-inne; and, thogh they ne anoye nat the body, yit</p>
<p>vyces wooden <i>to destroye men</i> by wounde of thought.'</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. III.</span> 1. C. A. Ed. wynde. 2. C. A. Ed. Narice; Lat.
  <i>Neritii</i>. 3. C. Ed. Circes; A. Circe. 8. C. boer; A. boor. 9. C. A. Ed. Marmorike; Lat.
  <i>Marmaricus leo</i>. 14. A. Arcadie; C. Ed. Archadie; Lat. <i>Arcadis alitis</i>. 15. A. Ed.
  vnbounden; C. vnbounded. // A. pestilence; C. pestelence. 16. A. oosteresse (!). 18. A. Ed. woxen;
  C. wexen. 19. C. akkornes; A. acorns. // C. lemes; A. lymes; Ed. lymmes. 20. A. Ed. hoole; C.
  hool. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose IV.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Tum ego, Fateor, inquam.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Than seyde I thus: 'I confesse and am a-knowe it,' quod I;</p>
<p>'<a href="#BIVPIVNL2" id="BIVPIVL2" class="pginternal">ne I ne see nat</a> that men may sayn, as by right, that
    shrewes ne</p>
<p>ben chaunged in-to bestes by the qualitee of hir soules, al-be-it so</p>
<p>that they kepen yit the forme of the body of mankinde. But I</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIVPIVNL4" id="BIVPIVL4" class="pginternal">nolde</a> nat of shrewes, of which the
    thought cruel woodeth al-wey</p>
<p>in-to destruccioun of goode men, that it were leveful to hem to</p>
<p>don that.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod she, 'ne is nis nat leveful to hem, as I shal wel</p>
<p>shewe thee in covenable place; but natheles, yif so were that thilke</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that men wenen be leveful to shrewes were binomen hem, <i>so that</i></p>
<p><i>they ne mighte nat anoyen or doon harm to goode men</i>, certes, a</p>
<p>greet partye of the peyne to shrewes sholde ben allegged and</p>
<p>releved. For al-be-it so that this ne seme nat credible thing,</p>
<p>per-aventure, to some folk, yit moot it nedes be, that shrewes ben</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page106">{106}</span>more wrecches and unsely whan
    they may doon and performe</p>
<p>that they coveiten, than yif they mighte nat complisshen that they</p>
<p>coveiten. For yif so be that it be wrecchednesse to wilne to don</p>
<p>yvel, than is more wrecchednesse <a href="#BIVPIVNL18" id="BIVPIVL18" class="pginternal">to mowen don</a> yvel;
    with-oute</p>
<p>whiche mowinge the wrecched wil sholde languisshe with-oute</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">effect. Than, sin that everiche of thise thinges hath his</p>
<p>wrecchednesse, <i>that is to seyn, wil to don yvel and mowinge to don</i></p>
<p><i>yvel</i>, it moot nedes be that they ben constreyned by <a href="#BIVPIVNL22" id="BIVPIVL22" class="pginternal">three</a></p>
<p>unselinesses, that wolen and mowen and performen felonyes and</p>
<p>shrewednesses.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">25</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'I acorde me,' quod I; 'but I desire gretly that shrewes</p>
<p>losten sone <a href="#BIVPIVNL26" id="BIVPIVL26" class="pginternal">thilke unselinesse</a>, <i>that is to
    seyn</i>, that shrewes weren</p>
<p>despoyled of mowinge to don yvel.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'<a href="#BIVPIVNL28" id="BIVPIVL28" class="pginternal">So shullen</a> they,' quod she, 'soner,
    per-aventure, than thou</p>
<p>woldest; or soner than they hem-self wene to lakken <i>mowinge to</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>don yvel</i>. <a href="#BIVPIVNL30" id="BIVPIVL30" class="pginternal">For ther</a> nis no-thing
    so late in so shorte boundes of</p>
<p>this lyf, that is long to abyde, nameliche, to a corage inmortel;</p>
<p>of whiche shrewes the grete hope, and the hye compassinges of</p>
<p>shrewednesses, is ofte destroyed by a sodeyn ende, or they ben</p>
<p>war; and that thing estableth to shrewes the ende of hir</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">shrewednesse. For yif that shrewednesse maketh wrecches, than</p>
<p>mot he nedes ben most wrecched that lengest is a shrewe; the</p>
<p>whiche wikked shrewes wolde I demen aldermost unsely and caitifs,</p>
<p>yif that hir shrewednesse ne were finisshed, at the leste wey, by</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVNL39" id="BIVPIVL39" class="pginternal">the outtereste</a> deeth. For yif I have concluded sooth
    of the unselinesse</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of shrewednesse, than sheweth it cleerly that thilke</p>
<p>wrecchednesse is with-outen ende, the whiche is certein to ben</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVNL42" id="BIVPIVL42" class="pginternal">perdurable</a>.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod I, 'this conclusioun is hard and wonderful to</p>
<p>graunte; but I knowe wel that it acordeth moche to the thinges</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that I have graunted her-biforn.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thou hast,' quod she, 'the right estimacioun of this; but</p>
<p>who-so-ever wene that it be a hard thing to acorde him to a</p>
<p>conclusioun, it is right that he shewe that some of the premisses</p>
<p>ben false; or elles he moot shewe that the collacioun of proposiciouns</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page107">{107}</span>nis nat speedful to a necessarie
    conclusioun. And yif it</p>
<p>be nat so, but that the premisses ben y-graunted, <a href="#BIVPIVNL51" id="BIVPIVL51" class="pginternal">ther
    is not why</a></p>
<p>he sholde blame the argument.</p>
<p class="stanza">For this thing that I shal telle thee now ne shal nat seme lasse</p>
<p>wonderful; <a href="#BIVPIVNL54" id="BIVPIVL54" class="pginternal">but of the thinges</a> that ben taken also it
    is necessarie;'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>as who seyth, it folweth of that which that is purposed biforn</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza">'What is that?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod she, 'that is, that thise wikked shrewes ben</p>
<p>more blisful, <i>or elles lasse wrecches</i>, that abyen the torments that</p>
<p>they han deserved, than yif no peyne of Iustice ne chastysede</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">hem. Ne this ne seye I nat now, for that any man mighte</p>
<p>thenke, that the maners of shrewes ben coriged and chastysed by</p>
<p>veniaunce, and that they ben brought to the right wey by the</p>
<p>drede of the torment, ne for that they yeven to other folk</p>
<p>ensaumple to fleen fro vyces; but <a href="#BIVPIVNL64" id="BIVPIVL64" class="pginternal">I understande</a> yit
    in another</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">manere, that shrewes ben more unsely whan they ne ben nat</p>
<p>punisshed, al-be-it so that ther ne be had no resoun or lawe of</p>
<p>correccioun, ne non ensaumple of lokinge.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'And what manere shal that ben,' quod I, 'other than hath be</p>
<p>told her-biforn?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">70</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Have we nat thanne graunted,' quod she, 'that goode folk</p>
<p>ben blisful, and shrewes ben wrecches?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Yis,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne,' quod she, 'yif that any good were added to the</p>
<p>wrecchednesse of any wight, nis he nat more weleful than he that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ne hath no medlinge of good in his solitarie wrecchednesse?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'So semeth it,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'And what seystow thanne,' quod she, 'of thilke wrecche that</p>
<p>lakketh alle goodes, <i>so that no good nis medled in his wrecchednesse</i>,</p>
<p>and yit, over al his wikkednesse for which he is a wrecche, that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ther be yit another yvel anexed and knit to him, shal nat men</p>
<p>demen him more unsely than thilke wrecche of whiche the unselinesse</p>
<p>is releved by the participacioun of som good?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Why sholde he nat?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne, certes,' quod she, 'han shrewes, whan they ben</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">85</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">punisshed, som-what of good anexed to hir wrecchednesse, that is</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page108">{108}</span>to seyn, the same peyne that they suffren,
    which that is good by</p>
<p>the resoun of Iustice; and whan thilke same shrewes ascapen</p>
<p>with-oute torment, than han they som-what more of yvel yit over</p>
<p>the wikkednesse that they han don, <i>that is to seyn</i>, defaute of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">peyne; <a href="#BIVPIVNL90" id="BIVPIVL90" class="pginternal">which defaute</a> of peyne, thou
    hast graunted, is yvel for</p>
<p>the deserte of felonye.' 'I ne may nat denye it,' quod I. 'Moche</p>
<p>more thanne,' quod she, 'ben shrewes unsely, whan they ben</p>
<p>wrongfully delivered fro peyne, than whan they ben punisshed by</p>
<p>rightful veniaunce. But this is open thing and cleer, that it is</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">right that shrewes ben punisshed, and it is wikkednesse and</p>
<p>wrong that they escapen unpunisshed.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Who mighte deneye that?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'But,' quod she, 'may any man denye that al that is right nis</p>
<p>good; and also the contrarie, that al that is wrong is wikke?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">100</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Certes,' quod I, 'these thinges ben clere y-nough; and that</p>
<p>we han concluded a litel her-biforn. But I praye thee that thou</p>
<p>telle me, yif thou acordest <a href="#BIVPIVNL102" id="BIVPIVL102" class="pginternal">to leten</a> no torment to
    sowles, after that</p>
<p>the body is ended by the deeth;' <i>this is to seyn, understandestow</i></p>
<p><i>aught that sowles han any torment after the deeth of the body?</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">105</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Certes,' quod she, 'ye; and that right greet; of which sowles,'</p>
<p>quod she, 'I trowe that some ben tormented by asprenesse of</p>
<p>peyne; and some sowles, I trowe, ben exercised by a purginge</p>
<p>mekenesse. But my conseil nis nat to determinye of thise peynes.</p>
<p>But I have travailed and told yit hiderto, for thou sholdest knowe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that the mowinge of shrewes, which mowinge thee semeth to ben</p>
<p>unworthy, nis no mowinge: and eek of shrewes, of which thou</p>
<p>pleinedest that they ne were nat punisshed, that thou woldest</p>
<p>seen that they ne weren never-mo with-outen the torments of hir</p>
<p>wikkednesse: and of the licence <i>of the mowinge to don yvel</i>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that thou preydest that it mighte sone ben ended, and that thou</p>
<p>woldest fayn lernen that it ne sholde nat longe dure: and that</p>
<p>shrewes ben more unsely yif they were of lenger duringe, and</p>
<p>most unsely yif they weren perdurable. And after this, I have</p>
<p>shewed thee that more unsely ben shrewes, whan they escapen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">120</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">with-oute hir rightful peyne, than whan they ben punisshed by</p>
<p>rightful veniaunce. And of this sentence folweth it, that thanne</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page109">{109}</span>ben shrewes constreined at the laste with most
    grevous torment,</p>
<p>whan men wene that they ne be nat punisshed.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Whan I consider thy resouns,' quod I, 'I ne trowe nat that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">men seyn any-thing more verayly. And yif I torne ayein to the</p>
<p>studies of men, who is he to whom it sholde seme that he ne</p>
<p>sholde nat only leven thise thinges, but eek gladly herkne</p>
<p>hem?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod she, 'so it is; but men may nat. For they han</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">hir eyen so wont to the derknesse <i>of erthely thinges</i>, that they ne</p>
<p>may nat liften hem up to the light of cleer sothfastnesse; but</p>
<p>they ben lyke to <a href="#BIVPIVNL132" id="BIVPIVL132" class="pginternal">briddes</a>, of which the night
    lightneth hir lokinge,</p>
<p>and the day blindeth hem. For whan men loken nat the ordre of</p>
<p>thinges, but hir lustes and talents, they wene that either the leve</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">135</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">or the mowinge to don wikkednesse, or elles the scapinge with-oute</p>
<p>peyne, be weleful. But consider the Iugement of the</p>
<p>perdurable lawe. For yif thou conferme thy corage to the beste</p>
<p>thinges, thou ne hast no nede of no Iuge to yeven thee prys or</p>
<p>mede; for thou hast ioyned thy-self to the most excellent thing.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And yif thou have enclyned thy studies to the wikked thinges, ne</p>
<p>seek no foreyne wreker out of thy-self; for thou thy-self hast</p>
<p>thrist thy-self in-to wikke thinges: <a href="#BIVPIVNL142" id="BIVPIVL142" class="pginternal">right as thou</a>
    mightest loken by</p>
<p>dyverse tymes the foule erthe and the hevene, and that alle other</p>
<p>thinges stinten fro with-oute, <i>so that thou nere neither in hevene</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">145</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>ne in erthe, ne saye no-thing more</i>; than it sholde semen to</p>
<p>thee, as by only resoun of lokinge, that thou were now in the</p>
<p>sterres and now in the erthe. But the poeple ne loketh nat on</p>
<p>thise thinges. What thanne? Shal we thanne aprochen us to</p>
<p>hem that I have shewed that they ben lyk to bestes? And what</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">150</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">woltow seyn of this: yif that a man hadde al forlorn his sighte</p>
<p>and hadde foryeten that he ever saugh, and wende that no-thing</p>
<p>ne faylede him of perfeccioun of mankinde, now we that mighten</p>
<p>seen the same thinges, wolde we nat wene that <a href="#BIVPIVNL153" id="BIVPIVL153" class="pginternal">he</a>
    were blinde?</p>
<p>Ne also ne acordeth nat the poeple to that I shal seyn, the which</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">155</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thing is sustened by a stronge foundement of resouns, <i>that is to</i></p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page110">{110}</span><i>seyn</i>, that more unsely ben they that
    don wrong to othre folk</p>
<p>than they that the wrong suffren.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'I wolde heren thilke same resouns,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Denyestow,' quod she, 'that alle shrewes ne ben worthy to</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">160</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">han torment?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Nay,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'But,' quod she, 'I am certein, by many resouns, that shrewes</p>
<p>ben unsely.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'It acordeth,' quod I.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">165</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Thanne ne doutestow nat,' quod she, 'that thilke folk that ben</p>
<p>worthy of torment, that they ne ben wrecches?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'It acordeth wel,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Yif thou were thanne,' quod she, 'y-set a Iuge or a knower of</p>
<p>thinges, whether, trowestow, that men sholden tormenten him</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">170</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that hath don the wrong, or elles him that hath suffred the</p>
<p>wrong?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'I ne doute nat,' quod I, 'that I nolde don suffisaunt satisfaccioun</p>
<p>to him that hadde suffred the wrong by the sorwe of him</p>
<p>that hadde don the wrong.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">175</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Thanne semeth it,' quod she, 'that the doere of wrong is</p>
<p>more wrecche than he that suffred wrong?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'That folweth wel,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Than,' quod she, 'by these causes and by othre causes that</p>
<p>ben enforced by the same rote, filthe or sinne, by the propre</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">180</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">nature of it, maketh men wrecches; and it sheweth wel, that the</p>
<p>wrong that men don nis nat the wrecchednesse of him that</p>
<p>receyveth the wrong, but the wrecchednesse of him that doth the</p>
<p>wrong. But certes,' quod she, 'thise oratours or advocats don al</p>
<p>the contrarye; for they enforcen hem to commoeve the Iuges to</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">185</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">han pitee of hem that han suffred and receyved the thinges that</p>
<p>ben grevous and aspre, and yit men sholden more rightfully han</p>
<p>pitee of hem that don the grevaunces and the wronges; the</p>
<p>whiche shrewes, it were a more covenable thing, that the</p>
<p>accusours or advocats, nat wroth but pitous and debonair, ledden</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">190</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page111">{111}</span>tho shrewes that han don wrong
    to the Iugement, right as men</p>
<p>leden syke folk to the leche, for that they sholde seken out the</p>
<p>maladyes of sinne by torment. And by this covenaunt, either the</p>
<p>entente of deffendours or advocats sholde faylen and cesen <a href="#BIVPIVNL193" id="BIVPIVL193" class="pginternal">in al</a>,</p>
<p>or elles, yif the office of advocats wolde bettre profiten to men,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">195</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">it sholde ben torned in-to the habite of accusacioun; <i>that is to</i></p>
<p><i>seyn, they sholden accuse shrewes, and nat excuse hem</i>. And eek</p>
<p>the shrewes hem-self, yif hit were leveful to hem to seen <a href="#BIVPIVNL197" id="BIVPIVL197" class="pginternal">at any</a></p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVNL197" class="pginternal">clifte</a> the vertu that they han forleten, and <a href="#BIVPIVNL197" class="pginternal">sawen</a> that they</p>
<p>sholden putten adoun the filthes of hir vyces, by the torments of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">200</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">peynes, they ne oughte nat, <a href="#BIVPIVNL200" id="BIVPIVL200" class="pginternal">right
    for</a> the recompensacioun for to</p>
<p>geten hem bountee and prowesse which that they han lost,</p>
<p>demen ne holden that thilke peynes weren torments to hem; and</p>
<p>eek they wolden refuse the attendaunce of hir advocats, and</p>
<p>taken hem-self to hir Iuges and to hir accusors. For which it</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">205</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">bitydeth that, as to the wyse folk, ther nis no place <a href="#BIVPIVNL205" id="BIVPIVL205" class="pginternal">y-leten</a> to</p>
<p>hate; <i>that is to seyn, that ne hate hath no place amonges wyse men</i>.</p>
<p>For no wight nil haten goode men, but-yif he were over-mochel a</p>
<p>fool; and for to haten shrewes, it nis no resoun. For right so as</p>
<p>languissinge is maladye of body, right so ben vyces and sinne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">210</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">maladye of corage. And so as we ne deme nat, that they that ben</p>
<p>syke of hir body ben worthy to ben hated, but rather worthy of</p>
<p>pitee: wel more worthy, nat to ben hated, but for to ben had in</p>
<p>pitee, ben they of whiche the thoughtes ben constreined by</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">215</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">felonous wikkednesse, that is more cruel than any languissinge of</p>
<p>body.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. IV.</span> 1. A. <i>om.</i> it. 3. C. ne ben; A. ne ben nat;
  Ed. ben. 10. C. to; A. for. 16. A. <i>om.</i> than yif ... coveiten. 19. C. languesse. 22. A.
  thre; C. the; Lat. <i>triplici</i>. 26. Ed. vnselynesse; C. A. vnselynysses; Lat. <i>hoc
  infortunio</i>. 29. A. to lakken ... yvel; C. Ed. <i>omit</i>. 30. A. Ed. so short; C. the shorte;
  Lat. <i>tam breuibus</i>. 38. A. yfinissed. 49. A. colasioun; Ed. collacyon; C. collacions; Lat.
  <i>collationem</i>. 58. A. byen (<i>for</i> abyen). 59. A. chastied. 61. A. thenk; C. thinke. //
  C. A. Ed. coriged. 64. A. yitte; Ed. yet; C. yif. 66. Ed. punysshed; C. A. punyssed. 67. C.
  correcsioun. 78. C. lakked; A. lakketh. 80. A. knyt; C. knytte. 96. A. escapin. 99. A. nis wicked.
  101. A. a litel; C. alyter. 103. A. dedid (<i>for</i> ended). 108. A. this peyne; Lat. <i>de
  his</i>. 109. C. yit; Ed. yet; A. it. 110. C. mowynge, i. myght. 113. A. seen; C. seyn;
  <i>uideres</i>. 116. C. dure; A. endure. 120. A. <i>om.</i> hir. 124. A. resouns; C. resoun;
  <i>rationes</i>. 135. A. escaping; C. schapynge (<i>for</i> scapynge). 138. C. of no; A. to no.
  142. A. threst the. 143. C. <i>puts</i> the foule erthe <i>before</i> by dyverse tymes. 145. A.
  <i>om.</i> nere neither ... erthe; Ed. were in neyther (<i>om.</i> in hevene ... erthe). 147. A.
  Ed. on; C. in. 149. A. to the bestes. 150. A. wilt thou. 153. A. thing; <i>eadem</i>. 155. C.
  <i>om.</i> is. 159. A. Deniest thou. 165. A. dowtest thou. 168. C. Ed. <i>om.</i> quod she. 169.
  C. <i>om.</i> whether. // A. trowest thou. 172. C. <i>om.</i> suffisaunt. 176. C. that (<i>for</i>
  than). // A. that hath suffred the wrong. 179. C. <i>wrongly ins.</i> of <i>bef.</i> enforced. //
  A. <i>ins.</i> that <i>bef.</i> filthe. 182, 3. C. <i>om.</i> but the ... wrong. 198. A. Ed.
  sawen; C. sawh. 199. C. felthes. 209. A. languissing; C. langwissynges. // C. maledye; A. maladie.

<h3> <span class="sc">Metre IV.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quid tantos iuuat excitare motus.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p><a href="#BIVMIVNL1" id="BIVMIVL1" class="pginternal">What delyteth you</a> to excyten so grete moevinges <i>of
    hateredes</i>,</p>
<p>and to hasten and bisien the fatal disposicioun of your deeth with</p>
<p>your propre handes? <i>that is to seyn, by batailes or by contek</i>. For</p>
<p>yif ye axen the deeth, it hasteth him of his owne wil; ne deeth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ne tarieth nat his swifte hors. And the men that the serpent and</p>
<p>the lyoun and the tygre and the bere and the boor seken to sleen</p>
<p>with hir teeth, yit thilke same men seken to sleen everich of hem</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page112">{112}</span>other with swerd. <a href="#BIVMIVNL8" id="BIVMIVL8" class="pginternal">Lo!</a> for hir maneres ben dyverse and descordaunt,</p>
<p>they moeven unrightful ostes and cruel batailes, <a href="#BIVMIVNL9" id="BIVMIVL9" class="pginternal">and
    wilnen</a></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to perisshe by entrechaunginge of dartes. <a href="#BIVMIVNL10" id="BIVMIVL10" class="pginternal">But the resoun</a> of</p>
<p>crueltee nis nat y-nough rightful.</p>
<p class="stanza">Wiltow thanne yelden a covenable guerdoun to the desertes of</p>
<p>men? Love rightfully goode folk, and have pitee on shrewes.'</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. IV.</span> 1. A. deliteth it yow. // A. moewynges; C.
  moeuynge; <i>motus</i>. 5. hors <i>is plural</i>; Lat. <i>equos</i>. // A. serpentz. 6. A. lyouns.
  8. A. discordaunt. 10. Ed. perysshe; A. perisse; C. perise.  A. Ed. -chaungynge; C. -chaungynges.
  12. C. A. gerdoun; Ed. guerdon. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose V.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Hic ego uideo inquam.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>'Thus see I wel,' quod I, 'either what blisfulnesse or elles</p>
<p>what unselinesse is establisshed in the desertes of goode men and</p>
<p>of shrewes. But in this ilke fortune of poeple I see somwhat of</p>
<p>good and somwhat of yvel. For no wyse man hath lever ben</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">exyled, poore and nedy, and nameles, than for to dwellen in his</p>
<p>citee and flouren of richesses, and be redoutable by honour, and</p>
<p>strong of power. For in this wyse more cleerly and more witnesfully</p>
<p>is the office of wyse men y-treted, whan the blisfulnesse and</p>
<p>the poustee of governours is, as it were, <a href="#BIVPVNL9" id="BIVPVL9" class="pginternal">y-shad</a> amonges
    poeples</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that be neighebours <i>and subgits</i>; sin that, namely, prisoun, lawe,</p>
<p>and thise othre torments of laweful peynes ben rather owed to</p>
<p>felonous citezeins, for the whiche felonous citezeins tho peynes</p>
<p>ben establisshed, <i>than for good folk</i>. Thanne I mervaile me</p>
<p>greetly,' quod I, 'why that the thinges ben so mis entrechaunged,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that torments of felonyes pressen and confounden goode folk, and</p>
<p>shrewes ravisshen medes of vertu, <i>and ben in honours and in</i></p>
<p><i>gret estats</i>. And I desyre eek for to witen of thee, what semeth</p>
<p>thee to ben the resoun of this so wrongful a conclusioun? For I</p>
<p>wolde wondre wel the lasse, yif I trowede that al thise thinges</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">weren medled by fortunous happe; but now <a href="#BIVPVNL20" id="BIVPVL20" class="pginternal">hepeth</a> and encreseth</p>
<p>myn astonyinge god, governour of thinges, that, so as god</p>
<p>yeveth ofte tymes to gode men godes and mirthes, and to shrewes</p>
<p>yveles and aspre thinges: and yeveth ayeinward to gode folk hardnesses,</p>
<p>and to shrewes he graunteth hem hir wil and that they</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page113">{113}</span>desyren: what difference thanne
    may ther be bitwixen that that</p>
<p>god doth, and the happe of fortune, yif men ne knowe nat the</p>
<p>cause why that it is?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Ne it nis no mervaile,' quod she, 'though that men wenen that</p>
<p>ther be somewhat folissh and confuse, whan the resoun of the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ordre is unknowe. But al-though that thou ne knowe nat the</p>
<p>cause of so greet a disposicioun, natheles, for as moche as god,</p>
<p>the gode governour, atempreth and governeth the world, ne doute</p>
<p>thee nat that alle thinges ben doon a-right.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. V.</span>  4. C. hath leuere; A. hath nat leuer; Ed. had not
  leuer.  8. A. Ed. witnes-; C. witnesse-. 10. A. neyȝbours; C. nesshebors. 17. A. witen; C.
  weten. 21. C. A. astonyenge. 25. C. defference. 28. C. Ne it nis; A. it nis. 33. C. ben; A. ne
  ben. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre V.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Si quis Arcturi sidera nescit.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Who-so that ne knowe nat the <a href="#BIVMVNL1" id="BIVMVL1" class="pginternal">sterres of Arcture</a>,
    y-torned neigh</p>
<p>to the soverein contree or point, <i>that is to seyn, y-torned neigh to</i></p>
<p><i>the soverein pool of the firmament</i>, and wot nat why <a href="#BIVMVNL3" id="BIVMVL3" class="pginternal"><i>the sterre</i></a></p>
<p>Bootes passeth or gadereth his weynes, and drencheth his late</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">flambes in the see, and why that Bootes <i>the sterre</i> unfoldeth his</p>
<p>over-swifte arysinges, thanne shal he wondren of the lawe of the</p>
<p>heye eyr.</p>
<p class="stanza"><i>And eek, yif that he ne knowe nat why that</i> the hornes of <a href="#BIVMVNL8" id="BIVMVL8" class="pginternal">the fulle</a></p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVNL8" class="pginternal">mone</a> wexen pale and <a href="#BIVMVNL9" id="BIVMVL9" class="pginternal">infect</a> by
    the boundes of the derke night;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and <i>how</i> the mone, derk and <a href="#BIVMVNL9" class="pginternal">confuse</a>, discovereth
    the sterres that</p>
<p>she hadde y-covered by hir clere visage. <a href="#BIVMVNL11" id="BIVMVL11" class="pginternal">The comune
    errour</a></p>
<p>moeveth folk, and maketh wery hir basins of bras by <a href="#BIVMVNL12" id="BIVMVL12" class="pginternal">thikke</a></p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVNL12" class="pginternal">strokes</a>; <i>that is to seyn, that ther is a maner of poeple that
    highte</i></p>
<p><i>Coribantes, that wenen that, whan the mone is in the eclipse, that it</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>be enchaunted; and therfore, for to rescowe the mone, they beten hir</i></p>
<p><i>basins with thikke strokes</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza">Ne no man ne wondreth whan the blastes of the wind Chorus</p>
<p>beten the strondes of the see <a href="#BIVMVNL18" id="BIVMVL18" class="pginternal">by quakinge flodes</a>; ne
    no man ne</p>
<p>wondreth whan the weighte of the snowe, y-harded by the colde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">is resolved by the brenninge hete of Phebus the sonne; for heer</p>
<p>seen men redely the causes.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page114">{114}</span>But the causes y-hid, <i>that
    is to seyn, in hevene</i>, troublen the</p>
<p>brestes of men; the moevable poeple is astoned of <a href="#BIVMVNL23" id="BIVMVL23" class="pginternal">alle
    thinges</a></p>
<p>that comen selde and sodeinly in our age. But yif the <a href="#BIVMVNL24" id="BIVMVL24" class="pginternal">troubly</a></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIVMVNL24" class="pginternal">errour</a> of our ignoraunce departede fro us, <i>so that
    we wisten the</i></p>
<p><i>causes why that swiche thinges bi-tyden</i>, certes, they sholden cese</p>
<p>to seme wondres.'</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. V.</span>  1. Ed. Arcture; C. Arctour; A. aritour.  4. Ed.
  Bootes; C. A. boetes (<i>twice</i>).  9. A. Ed. by the; C. by. 11. A. Ed. had; C. hadde. 12. C.
  basynnes (1<i>st time</i>); basyns (2<i>nd</i>). 14. Ed. Coribantes; C. A. coribandes. 17. A. Ed.
  blastes; C. blases. 18. A. Ed. man ne; C. manne. 19. A. Ed. the snowe; C. sonwh (<i>sic</i>;
  <i>om.</i> the). </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose VI.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Ita est, inquam.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>'Thus is it,' quod I. 'But so as thou hast yeven or bi-hight</p>
<p>me to unwrappen the hid causes of thinges, and to discovere me</p>
<p>the resouns covered with derknesses, I prey thee that thou devyse</p>
<p>and iuge me of this matere, and that thou do me to understonden</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">it; for this miracle or this wonder troubleth me right gretly.'</p>
<p class="stanza">And thanne she, a litel what smylinge, seyde: 'thou clepest</p>
<p>me,' quod she, 'to telle thing that is grettest of alle thinges that</p>
<p>mowen ben axed, and to the whiche questioun unnethes is ther</p>
<p>aught y-nough to <a href="#BIVPVINL9" id="BIVPVIL9" class="pginternal">laven it</a>; <i>as who seyth, unnethes
    is ther suffisauntly</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>anything to answere parfitly to thy questioun</i>. For the</p>
<p>matere of it is swich, that whan o doute is determined and cut</p>
<p>awey, ther wexen other doutes with-oute number; right as the</p>
<p>hevedes wexen of <a href="#BIVPVINL13" id="BIVPVIL13" class="pginternal">Ydre</a>, <i>the serpent that Ercules
    slowh</i>. Ne ther</p>
<p>ne were <a href="#BIVPVINL13" class="pginternal">no manere ne non ende</a>, <a href="#BIVPVINL14" id="BIVPVIL14" class="pginternal">but-yif</a> that a wight constreinede</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">tho doutes by a right lyfly and quik fyr of thought; <i>that is to</i></p>
<p><i>seyn, by vigour and strengthe of wit</i>. For in this manere men</p>
<p>weren wont to maken questions of the simplicitee of the purviaunce</p>
<p>of god, and of the order of destinee, and of sodein</p>
<p>happe, and of the knowinge and predestinacioun divyne, and of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the libertee of free wille; the whiche thinges thou thy-self</p>
<p>aperceyvest wel, of what weight they ben. But for as mochel</p>
<p>as the knowinge of thise thinges is a maner porcioun of the</p>
<p>medicine of thee, al-be-it so that I have litel tyme to don it,</p>
<p>yit natheles I wol enforcen me to shewe somwhat of it. But</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIVPVINL24" id="BIVPVIL24" class="pginternal">al-thogh</a> the norisshinges of ditee of
    musike delyteth thee, thou</p>
<p>most suffren and forberen a litel of thilke delyte, whyle that</p>
<p>I weve to thee resouns y-knit by ordre.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page115">{115}</span>'As it lyketh to thee,' quod I,
    'so do.' Tho spak she right as</p>
<p>by another biginninge, and seyde thus. 'The engendringe of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">alle thinges,' quod she, 'and alle the progressiouns of <a href="#BIVPVINL30" id="BIVPVIL30" class="pginternal">muable</a></p>
<p>nature, and al that moeveth in any manere, taketh his causes, his</p>
<p>ordre, and his formes, of the stablenesse of the divyne thoght;</p>
<p>and thilke divyne thought, that is y-set and put <a href="#BIVPVINL33" id="BIVPVIL33" class="pginternal">in the
    tour</a>, <i>that</i></p>
<p><i>is to seyn, in the heighte</i>, of the simplicitee of god, stablissheth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">many maner gyses to thinges that ben to done; the whiche</p>
<p>maner, whan that men loken it in thilke pure clennesse of the</p>
<p>divyne intelligence, it is y-cleped purviaunce; but whan thilke</p>
<p>maner is referred by men to thinges that it moveth and disponeth,</p>
<p>thanne of olde men it was cleped destinee. The whiche thinges,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">yif that any wight loketh wel in his thought the strengthe of that</p>
<p>oon and of that other, he shal lightly mowen seen, that thise two</p>
<p>thinges ben dyverse. For purviaunce is thilke divyne reson that</p>
<p>is establisshed in the soverein prince of thinges; the whiche purviaunce</p>
<p>disponeth alle thinges. But destinee is the disposicioun</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and ordinaunce clyvinge to moevable thinges, by the whiche</p>
<p>disposicioun the purviaunce knitteth alle thinges in hir ordres;</p>
<p>for purviaunce embraceth alle thinges to-hepe, al-thogh that they</p>
<p>ben dyverse, and al-thogh they ben infinite; <a href="#BIVPVINL48" id="BIVPVIL48" class="pginternal">but
    destinee</a> departeth</p>
<p>and ordeineth alle thinges singulerly, and divyded in</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">moevinges, in places, in formes, in tymes, as thus: lat the</p>
<p>unfoldinge of temporel ordinaunce, assembled and ooned in the</p>
<p>lokinge of the divyne thought, be cleped purviaunce; and thilke</p>
<p>same assemblinge and ooninge, divyded and unfolden by tymes,</p>
<p>lat that ben called destinee. And al-be-it so that thise thinges</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ben dyverse, yit natheles hangeth that oon on that other; for-why</p>
<p>the order destinal procedeth of the simplicitee of purviaunce.</p>
<p>For right as a werkman, that aperceyveth in his thoght the forme</p>
<p>of the thing that he wol make, and moeveth the effect of the</p>
<p>werk, <a href="#BIVPVINL59" id="BIVPVIL59" class="pginternal">and ledeth</a> that he hadde loked biforn in his
    thoght simply</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and presently, by temporel ordinaunce: certes, right so god</p>
<p>disponeth in his purviaunce, singulerly and stably, the thinges</p>
<p>that ben to done, but he aministreth in many maneres and in</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page116">{116}</span>dyverse tymes, by destinee, thilke same
    thinges that he hath</p>
<p>disponed.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">65</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">Thanne, whether that destinee be exercysed outher by some</p>
<p>divyne spirits, servaunts to the divyne purviaunce, or elles by</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVINL67" id="BIVPVIL67" class="pginternal">som sowle</a>, or elles by alle nature servinge to god,
    or elles by the</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVINL68" id="BIVPVIL68" class="pginternal">celestial moevinges</a> of sterres, or elles by the
    vertu of angeles, or</p>
<p>elles by the dyverse subtilitee of develes, or elles by any of hem,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">or elles by hem alle, the destinal ordinaunce is y-woven and</p>
<p>acomplisshed. Certes, it is open thing, that the purviaunce is</p>
<p>an unmoevable and simple forme of thinges to done; and the</p>
<p>moveable bond and the temporel ordinaunce of thinges, whiche</p>
<p>that the divyne simplicitee of purviaunce hath ordeyned to done,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that is destinee. For which it is, that alle thinges that ben put</p>
<p>under destinee ben, certes, subgits to purviaunce, to whiche purviaunce</p>
<p>destinee itself is subgit and under. But some thinges</p>
<p>ben put under purviaunce, that surmounten the ordinaunce of</p>
<p>destinee; and tho ben thilke that stably ben y-ficched negh to the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">firste godhed: they surmounten the ordre of destinal moevabletee.</p>
<p>For right as of cercles that tornen a-boute <a href="#BIVPVINL81" id="BIVPVIL81" class="pginternal">a same
    centre</a> or a-boute</p>
<p>a poynt, thilke cercle that is innerest or most with-inne ioyneth to</p>
<p>the simplesse of the middel, and is, as it were, a centre or a poynt</p>
<p>to that other cercles that tornen a-bouten him; and thilke that is</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">85</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">outterest, compassed by larger envyronninge, is unfolden by</p>
<p>larger spaces, in so moche as it is forthest fro the middel simplicitee</p>
<p>of the poynt; <a href="#BIVPVINL87" id="BIVPVIL87" class="pginternal">and yif ther be</a> any-thing that
    knitteth and</p>
<p>felawshippeth him-self to thilke middel poynt, it is constreined</p>
<p>in-to simplicitee, <i>that is to seyn, in-to unmoevabletee</i>, and it ceseth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to be shad and to fleten dyversely: right so, by semblable resoun,</p>
<p>thilke thing that departeth forthest fro the first thoght of god, it is</p>
<p>unfolden and summitted to gretter bondes of destinee: and in so</p>
<p>moche is the thing more free and <a href="#BIVPVINL93" id="BIVPVIL93" class="pginternal">laus</a> fro destinee,
    as it axeth and</p>
<p>holdeth him ner to thilke centre of thinges, <i>that is to seyn, god</i>.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And yif the thing clyveth to the stedefastnesse of the thoght of god,</p>
<p>and be with-oute moevinge, certes, it sormounteth the necessitee of</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page117">{117}</span>destinee. <a href="#BIVPVINL97" id="BIVPVIL97" class="pginternal">Thanne right swich</a> comparisoun as it is of skilinge to</p>
<p>understondinge, and of thing that is engendred to thing that is, and</p>
<p>of tyme to eternitee, and of the cercle to the centre, right so is the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ordre of moevable destinee to the stable simplicitee of purviaunce.</p>
<p class="stanza">Thilke ordinaunce moeveth the hevene and the sterres, and</p>
<p>atempreth the elements to-gider amonges hem-self, and transformeth</p>
<p>hem by entrechaungeable mutacioun; and thilke same</p>
<p>ordre neweth ayein alle thinges growinge and fallinge a-doun, by</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">semblable progressiouns of sedes and of sexes, <i>that is to seyn,</i></p>
<p><i>male and femele</i>. And this ilke ordre constreineth the fortunes and</p>
<p>the dedes of men by a bond of causes, nat able to ben unbounde;</p>
<p>the whiche destinal causes, <a href="#BIVPVINL108" id="BIVPVIL108" class="pginternal">whan they passen</a> out
    fro the biginninges</p>
<p>of the unmoevable purviaunce, it mot nedes be that they</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ne be nat mutable. And thus ben the thinges ful wel y-governed,</p>
<p>yif that the simplicitee dwellinge in the divyne thoght sheweth</p>
<p>forth the ordre of causes, <a href="#BIVPVINL112" id="BIVPVIL112" class="pginternal">unable to ben y-bowed</a>;
    and this ordre</p>
<p>constreineth by his propre stabletee the moevable thinges, or elles</p>
<p>they <a href="#BIVPVINL114" id="BIVPVIL114" class="pginternal">sholden fleten</a> folily. <a href="#BIVPVINL114" class="pginternal">For which it is</a>, that alle thinges semen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to ben confus and trouble to us men, for we ne mowen nat considere</p>
<p>thilke ordinaunce; <a href="#BIVPVINL116" id="BIVPVIL116" class="pginternal">natheles</a>, the propre maner of
    every</p>
<p>thinge, dressinge hem to goode, disponeth hem alle.</p>
<p class="stanza">For ther nis no-thing don for cause of yvel; ne thilke thing</p>
<p>that is don by wikkede folk <i>nis nat don for yvel</i>. The whiche</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">120</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">shrewes, as I have shewed ful plentivously, seken good, but</p>
<p>wikked errour mistorneth hem, <a href="#BIVPVINL121" id="BIVPVIL121" class="pginternal">ne the ordre</a> cominge
    fro the</p>
<p>poynt of soverein good ne declyneth nat fro his biginninge. But</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVINL123" id="BIVPVIL123" class="pginternal">thou mayst seyn</a>, what unreste may ben a worse
    confusioun than</p>
<p>that gode men han somtyme adversitee and somtyme prosperitee,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and shrewes also now han thinges that they desiren, and now</p>
<p>thinges that they haten? Whether men liven now in swich</p>
<p>hoolnesse of thoght, (<i>as who seyth, ben men now so wyse</i>), that</p>
<p>swiche folk as they demen to ben gode folk or shrewes, that</p>
<p>it moste nedes ben that folk ben swiche as they wenen? But in</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">this manere the domes of men discorden, that thilke men that</p>
<p>some folk demen worthy of mede, other folk demen hem worthy of</p>
<p>torment. But lat us graunte, I pose that som man may wel demen</p>
<p>or knowen the gode folk and the badde; may he thanne knowen</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page118">{118}</span>and seen thilke innereste atempraunce of
    corages, as it hath ben</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">135</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">wont to be seyd of bodies; <i>as who seyth, may a man speken and</i></p>
<p><i>determinen of atempraunces in corages, as men were wont to demen or</i></p>
<p><i>speken of complexiouns and atempraunces of bodies?</i> <a href="#BIVPVINL138" id="BIVPVIL138" class="pginternal">Ne it ne is nat</a></p>
<p>an unlyk miracle, to hem that ne knowen it nat, (<i>as who seith, but it</i></p>
<p><i>is lyke a merveil or a miracle to hem that ne knowen it nat</i>), why that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">swete thinges ben covenable to some bodies that ben hole, and to</p>
<p>some bodies bittere thinges ben covenable; and also, why that</p>
<p>some syke folk ben holpen with lighte medicynes, and some folk</p>
<p>ben holpen with sharpe medicynes. But natheles, the leche that</p>
<p>knoweth the manere and the atempraunce of hele and of maladye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">145</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ne merveileth of it no-thing. But what other thing semeth <a href="#BIVPVINL145" id="BIVPVIL145" class="pginternal">hele</a></p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVINL145" class="pginternal">of corages</a> but bountee and prowesse? And what other thing</p>
<p>semeth maladye <i>of corages</i> but vyces? Who is elles kepere of</p>
<p>good or dryver awey of yvel, but god, governour and <a href="#BIVPVINL148" id="BIVPVIL148" class="pginternal">lecher</a> of</p>
<p>thoughtes? The whiche god, whan he hath biholden from the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">150</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">heye tour of his purveaunce, he knoweth what is covenable to</p>
<p>every wight, and <a href="#BIVPVINL151" id="BIVPVIL151" class="pginternal">leneth hem</a> that he wot that is
    covenable to hem.</p>
<p>Lo, her-of comth and her-of is don this noble miracle of the ordre</p>
<p>destinal, whan god, that al knoweth, doth swiche thing, of which</p>
<p>thing that unknowinge folk ben astoned. But <a href="#BIVPVINL154" id="BIVPVIL154" class="pginternal">for to
    constreine</a>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">155</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>as who seyth, but for to comprehende and telle</i> a fewe thinges of the</p>
<p>divyne deepnesse, the whiche that mannes resoun may understonde,</p>
<p>thilke man that thou wenest to ben right Iuste and <a href="#BIVPVINL157" id="BIVPVIL157" class="pginternal">right</a></p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVINL157" class="pginternal">kepinge</a> of equitee, the contrarie of that semeth to the divyne</p>
<p>purveaunce, that al wot. And Lucan, <a href="#BIVPVINL159" id="BIVPVIL159" class="pginternal">my familer</a>,
    telleth that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">160</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">"the victorious cause lykede to the goddes, and the cause over-comen</p>
<p>lykede to Catoun." Thanne, what-so-ever thou mayst seen</p>
<p>that is don in this werld unhoped or unwened, certes, it is the</p>
<p>right ordre of thinges; but, as to thy wikkede opinioun, it is a</p>
<p>confusioun. But I suppose that som man be so wel y-thewed,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">165</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that the divyne Iugement and the Iugement of mankinde acorden</p>
<p>hem to-gider of him; but he is so unstedefast of corage, that, yif</p>
<p>any adversitee come to him, he wol forleten, par-aventure, to</p>
<p>continue innocence, by the whiche he ne may nat <a href="#BIVPVINL168" id="BIVPVIL168" class="pginternal">with-holden</a></p>
<p>fortune. Thanne the wyse dispensacioun of god spareth him, the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">170</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page119">{119}</span>whiche man adversitee mighte
    enpeyren; for that god wol nat</p>
<p>suffren him to travaile, to whom that travaile nis nat covenable.</p>
<p>Another man is parfit in alle vertues, and is an holy man, and</p>
<p>negh to god, so that the purviaunce of god wolde demen, that</p>
<p>it were a felonye that he were touched with any adversitees; so</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">175</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that he wol nat suffre that swich a man be moeved with any</p>
<p>bodily maladye. But so as seyde a philosophre, the more excellent</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVINL176" id="BIVPVIL176" class="pginternal">by me</a>: <i>he seyde <a href="#BIVPVINL177" id="BIVPVIL177" class="pginternal">in Grek</a></i>, that "vertues han edified the body</p>
<p>of the holy man." And ofte tyme it bitydeth, that the somme of</p>
<p>thinges that ben to done is <a href="#BIVPVINL179" id="BIVPVIL179" class="pginternal">taken</a> to governe to
    gode folk, for that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">180</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the malice haboundaunt of shrewes sholde ben abated. And god</p>
<p>yeveth and departeth to othre folk prosperitees and adversitees</p>
<p>y-medled to-hepe, after the qualitee of hir corages, and <a href="#BIVPVINL182" id="BIVPVIL182" class="pginternal">remordeth</a></p>
<p>som folk <i>by adversitee</i>, for they ne sholde nat wexen proude by</p>
<p>longe welefulnesse. And other folk he suffreth to ben travailed</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">185</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">with harde thinges, for that they sholden confermen the vertues</p>
<p>of corage by the usage and exercitacioun of pacience. And</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVINL186" id="BIVPVIL186" class="pginternal">other folk</a> dreden more than they oughten [that]
    whiche they</p>
<p>mighten wel beren; and somme dispyse that they mowe nat</p>
<p>beren; and thilke folk god ledeth in-to experience of himself by</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">190</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">aspre and sorwful thinges. And many othre folk han bought</p>
<p>honourable renoun of this world by the prys of glorious deeth.</p>
<p>And som men, that ne mowen nat ben overcomen by torments,</p>
<p>have yeven ensaumple to othre folk, that vertu may nat ben overcomen</p>
<p>by adversitees; and of alle thinges ther nis no doute, that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">195</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">they ne ben don rightfully and ordenely, to the profit of hem to</p>
<p>whom we seen thise thinges bityde. For certes, that adversitee</p>
<p>comth somtyme to shrewes, and somtyme that that they desiren,</p>
<p>it comth of thise forseide causes. And of sorwful thinges <i>that</i></p>
<p><i>bityden to shrewes</i>, certes, no man ne wondreth; for alle men</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">200</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">wenen that they han wel deserved it, and that they ben of</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVINL201" id="BIVPVIL201" class="pginternal">wikkede merite</a>; of whiche shrewes the torment
    somtyme agasteth</p>
<p>othre to don felonyes, and somtyme it amendeth hem that suffren</p>
<p>the torments. And the prosperitee <i>that is yeven to shrewes</i></p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page120">{120}</span>sheweth a greet argument to gode folk, what
    thing they sholde</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">205</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">demen of thilke welefulnesse, the whiche prosperitee men seen</p>
<p>ofte <a href="#BIVPVINL206" id="BIVPVIL206" class="pginternal">serven to shrewes</a>. In the which thing I trowe
    that god</p>
<p>dispenseth; for, per-aventure, the nature of som man is so <a href="#BIVPVINL207" id="BIVPVIL207" class="pginternal">overthrowinge</a></p>
<p><i>to yvel</i>, and so uncovenable, that the nedy povertee of</p>
<p>his houshold mighte rather <a href="#BIVPVINL209" id="BIVPVIL209" class="pginternal">egren him</a> to don
    felonyes. And to</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">210</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the maladye of him god putteth remedie, to yeven him richesses.</p>
<p>And som other man biholdeth his conscience defouled with sinnes,</p>
<p>and maketh comparisoun of his fortune and of him-self; and</p>
<p>dredeth, per-aventure, that his blisfulnesse, of which the usage is</p>
<p>Ioyeful to him, that the lesinge of thilke blisfulnesse ne be nat</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">215</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">sorwful to him; and therfor he wol chaunge his maneres, and, for</p>
<p>he dredeth to lese his fortune, he forleteth his wikkednesse. To</p>
<p>othre folk is welefulnesse y-yeven unworthily, the whiche overthroweth</p>
<p>hem in-to distruccioun that they han deserved. And to</p>
<p>som othre folk is yeven power to punisshen, for that it shal be</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">220</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BIVPVINL219" id="BIVPVIL219" class="pginternal">cause</a> of <i>continuacioun and</i>
    exercysinge to gode folk and cause of</p>
<p>torment to shrewes. For so as ther nis non alyaunce by-twixe</p>
<p>gode folk and shrewes, ne shrewes ne mowen nat acorden amonges</p>
<p>hem-self. And why nat? For shrewes discorden of hem-self by</p>
<p>hir vyces, the whiche vyces al to-renden hir consciences; and don</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">225</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ofte tyme thinges, the whiche thinges, whan they han don hem,</p>
<p>they demen that tho thinges ne sholden nat han ben don. For</p>
<p>which thing thilke soverein purveaunce hath maked ofte tyme fair</p>
<p>miracle; so that shrewes han maked shrewes to ben gode men.</p>
<p>For whan that som shrewes seen that they suffren wrongfully</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">230</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">felonyes of othre shrewes, they wexen eschaufed in-to hate of hem</p>
<p>that anoyeden hem, and retornen to the frut of vertu, whan they</p>
<p>studien to ben unlyk to hem that they han hated. Certes, only</p>
<p>this is the divyne might, to the whiche might yveles ben thanne</p>
<p>gode, whan it useth tho yveles covenably, and draweth out the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">235</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">effect of any gode; <i>as who seyth, that yvel is good only to the
    might</i></p>
<p><i>of god, for the might of god ordeyneth thilke yvel to good</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza">For oon ordre embraseth alle thinges, so that what wight that</p>
<p>departeth fro the resoun of thilke ordre which that is assigned to</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page121">{121}</span>him, algates yit he slydeth in-to another
    ordre, so that no-thing</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">240</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">nis leveful to folye in the reame of the divyne purviaunce; <i>as who</i></p>
<p><i>seyth, nothing nis with-outen ordinaunce in the reame of the divyne</i></p>
<p><i>purviaunce</i>; <a href="#BIVPVINL242" id="BIVPVIL242" class="pginternal">sin that</a> the right stronge god
    governeth alle thinges</p>
<p>in this world. For it nis nat leveful to man to comprehenden by</p>
<p>wit, ne unfolden by word, alle the subtil ordinaunces and disposiciouns</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">245</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of the divyne entente. For only it oughte suffise to</p>
<p>han loked, that god him-self, maker of alle natures, ordeineth and</p>
<p>dresseth alle thinges to gode; whyl that he hasteth to <a href="#BIVPVINL247" id="BIVPVIL247" class="pginternal">with-holden</a></p>
<p>the thinges that he hath maked in-to his semblaunce, <i>that is to</i></p>
<p><i>seyn, for to with-holden thinges in-to good, for he him-self is good</i>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">250</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">he chaseth out al yvel fro the boundes of his comunalitee by the</p>
<p>ordre of necessitee destinable. For which it folweth, that yif thou</p>
<p>loke the purviaunce ordeininge the thinges that men wenen ben</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVINL253" id="BIVPVIL253" class="pginternal">outrageous or haboundant</a> in erthes, thou ne shalt
    nat seen in no</p>
<p>place no-thing of yvel. But I see now that thou art charged with</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">255</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the weighte of the questioun, and wery with the lengthe of my</p>
<p>resoun; and that thou abydest som sweetnesse of songe. Tak</p>
<p>thanne this draught; <a href="#BIVPVINL257" id="BIVPVIL257" class="pginternal">and whan</a> thou art wel
    refresshed and refect,</p>
<p>thou shal be more stedefast to stye in-to heyere questiouns.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. VI.</span>  4. A. Ed. do; C. don.  5. C. meracle.  6. A.

<h3> <span class="sc">Metre VI.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Si uis celsi iura tonantis.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p><a href="#BIVMVINL1" id="BIVMVIL1" class="pginternal">If thou, wys,</a> wilt demen in thy pure thought the
    rightes or the</p>
<p>lawes of the heye thonderer, <i>that is to seyn, of god</i>, loke thou and</p>
<p>bihold the heightes of the soverein hevene. There kepen the</p>
<p>sterres, by rightful alliaunce of thinges, hir olde pees. The sonne,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">y-moeved by his rody fyr, ne distorbeth nat the colde <a href="#BIVMVINL5" id="BIVMVIL5" class="pginternal">cercle</a> of</p>
<p>the mone. <a href="#BIVMVINL6" id="BIVMVIL6" class="pginternal">Ne the sterre</a> y-cleped "the Bere," that
    enclyneth his</p>
<p>ravisshinge courses abouten the soverein heighte of the worlde, ne</p>
<p>the same sterre Ursa nis never-mo wasshen in the depe westrene</p>
<p>see, ne coveiteth nat to deyen his flaumbes in the see of the occian,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">al-thogh he see othre sterres y-plounged in the see. And <a href="#BIVMVINL10" id="BIVMVIL10" class="pginternal">Hesperus</a></p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page122">{122}</span><i>the sterre</i> bodeth and telleth alwey the
    late nightes; and <a href="#BIVMVINL10" class="pginternal">Lucifer</a></p>
<p><i>the sterre</i> bringeth ayein the clere day.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#BIVMVINL13" id="BIVMVIL13" class="pginternal">And thus</a> maketh Love entrechaungeable
    the perdurable courses;</p>
<p>and thus is discordable bataile y-put out of the contree of the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">sterres. This acordaunce atempreth by evenelyk maneres the</p>
<p>elements, that the moiste thinges, stryvinge with the drye thinges,</p>
<p>yeven place by stoundes; and the colde thinges ioynen hem by</p>
<p>feyth to the hote thinges; and that the lighte fyr aryseth in-to</p>
<p>heighte; and the hevy erthes avalen by hir weightes. By thise</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">same causes the floury yeer yildeth swote smelles in the firste</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVINL20" id="BIVMVIL20" class="pginternal">somer-sesoun</a> warminge; and the hote somer dryeth the
    cornes;</p>
<p>and autumpne comth ayein, hevy of apples; and the fletinge reyn</p>
<p>bideweth the winter. This atempraunce norissheth and bringeth</p>
<p>forth al thing that [bretheth] lyf in this world; <a href="#BIVMVINL24" id="BIVMVIL24" class="pginternal">and
    thilke</a> same</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">atempraunce, ravisshinge, hydeth and binimeth, and drencheth</p>
<p>under the laste deeth, alle thinges y-born.</p>
<p class="stanza">Amonges thise thinges sitteth the heye maker, king and lord,</p>
<p>welle and biginninge, lawe and wys Iuge, to don equitee; and</p>
<p>governeth and enclyneth the brydles of thinges. <a href="#BIVMVINL29" id="BIVMVIL29" class="pginternal">And
    tho</a> thinges</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that he stereth to gon by moevinge, he withdraweth and aresteth;</p>
<p>and affermeth the moevable or wandringe thinges. <a href="#BIVMVINL31" id="BIVMVIL31" class="pginternal">For
    yif</a> that</p>
<p>he ne clepede ayein the right goinge of thinges, and yif that he ne</p>
<p>constreinede hem nat eft-sones in-to roundnesses enclynede, the</p>
<p>thinges that ben now continued by stable ordinaunce, they sholden</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">departen from hir welle, <i>that is to seyn, from hir biginninge</i>, and</p>
<p>faylen, <i>that is to seyn, torne in-to nought</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#BIVMVINL37" id="BIVMVIL37" class="pginternal">This is</a> the comune Love to alle
    thinges; and alle thinges axen</p>
<p>to ben holden by the fyn of good. For elles ne mighten they nat</p>
<p>lasten, yif they ne come nat eft-sones ayein, by Love retorned, to</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the cause that hath yeven hem beinge, <i>that is to seyn, to god</i>.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. VI.</span> 1. A. <i>om.</i> wys; Lat. <i>sollers</i>. 3. C.
  the souereyn; A. <i>om.</i> the. 5. C. clerke (!); <i>for</i> cercle. 7. C. cours (<i>meatus</i>);
  <i>see</i> 13. 9. A. dyȝen; C. deeyn, <i>glossed</i> tingere; Ed. deyen. 10. A. in-to
  (<i>for</i> in). 16. A. striuen nat with the drye thinges, but yiuen. 24. A. al; C. alle. // A.
  bredith; C. Ed. bereth; <i>read</i> bretheth (<i>spirat</i>). 31. C. <i>om.</i> the. 35. A.
  bygynnynge; C. bygynge. </p>
<h3><span class="sc">Prose</span> VII.</h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Iamne igitur uides.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Seestow nat thanne what thing folweth alle the thinges that I</p>
<p>have seyd?' <i>Boece.</i> 'What thing?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page123">{123}</span>'Certes,' quod she,
    'al-outrely, that alle fortune is good.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'And how may that be?' quod I.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">5</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Now understand,' quod she, 'so as alle fortune, whether so it</p>
<p>be Ioyeful fortune or aspre fortune, is yeven either by cause of</p>
<p>guerdoning or elles of exercysinge of good folk, or elles by cause</p>
<p>to punisshen or elles chastysen shrewes; thanne is alle fortune</p>
<p>good, the whiche fortune is certein that it be either rightful or</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">elles profitable.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Forsothe, this is a ful verray resoun,' quod I; 'and yif I consider</p>
<p>the purviaunce and the destinee that thou taughtest me a</p>
<p>litel her-biforn, this sentence is sustened by stedefast resouns.</p>
<p>But yif it lyke unto thee, lat us noumbren hem amonges thilke</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thinges, of whiche thou seydest a litel her-biforn, that they ne were</p>
<p>nat able to ben wened to the poeple.' 'Why so?' quod she.</p>
<p class="stanza">'For that the comune word of men,' quod I, 'misuseth this</p>
<p><i>maner speche of fortune</i>, and seyn ofte tymes that the fortune of</p>
<p>som wight is wikkede.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">20</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Wiltow thanne,' quod she, 'that I aproche a litel to the wordes</p>
<p>of the poeple, so that it seme nat to hem that I be overmoche departed</p>
<p>as fro the usage of mankinde?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'As thou wolt,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Demestow nat,' quod she, 'that al thing that profiteth is good?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">25</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Yis,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'And certes, thilke thing that exercyseth or corigeth, profiteth?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'I confesse it wel,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne is it good?' quod she.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Why nat?' quod I.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">30</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'But this is the fortune,' quod she, 'of hem that either ben put</p>
<p>in vertu and batailen ayeins aspre thinges, or elles of hem that</p>
<p>eschuen and declynen fro vyces and taken the wey of vertu.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'This ne may I nat denye,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'But what seystow of the mery fortune that is yeven to good</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">folk in guerdoun? Demeth aught the poeple that it is wikked?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Nay, forsothe,' quod I; 'but they demen, as it sooth is, that it</p>
<p>is right good.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page124">{124}</span>'And what seystow of that other
    fortune,' quod she, 'that,</p>
<p>al-thogh that it be aspre, and restreineth the shrewes by rightful</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">torment, weneth aught the poeple that it be good?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Nay,' quod I, 'but the poeple demeth that it is most wrecched</p>
<p>of alle thinges that may ben thought.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'War now, and loke wel,' quod she, 'lest that we, in folwinge</p>
<p>the opinioun of the poeple, have confessed and concluded thing</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that is unable to be wened <i>to the poeple</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza">'What is that?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Certes,' quod she, 'it folweth or comth of thinges that ben</p>
<p>graunted, that alle fortune, what-so-ever it be, of hem that ben</p>
<p>either in possessioun of vertu, or in the encres of vertu, or elles in</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the purchasinge of vertu, that thilke fortune is good; and that alle</p>
<p>fortune is right wikkede to hem that dwellen in shrewednesse;' <i>as</i></p>
<p><i>who seyth, and thus weneth nat the poeple</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza">'That is sooth,' quod I, 'al-be-it so that no man dar confesse it</p>
<p>ne biknowen it.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">55</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'Why so?' quod she; 'for right as the stronge man ne semeth</p>
<p>nat to abaissen or disdaignen as ofte tyme as he hereth the noise</p>
<p>of the bataile, <a href="#BIVPVIINL57" id="BIVPVIIL57" class="pginternal">ne also it</a> ne semeth nat, to the
    wyse man, to beren</p>
<p>it grevously, as ofte as he is lad in-to the stryf of fortune. For</p>
<p>bothe to that oon man and eek to that other thilke difficultee is</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the <a href="#BIVPVIINL60" id="BIVPVIIL60" class="pginternal">matere</a>; to that oon man, of
    encres of his glorious renoun,</p>
<p>and to that other man, to confirme his sapience, <i>that is to seyn, to</i></p>
<p><i>the asprenesse of his estat</i>. For therfore is it called <a href="#BIVPVIINL62" id="BIVPVIIL62" class="pginternal">"vertu,"</a> for</p>
<p>that it susteneth and enforseth, by hise strengthes, that it nis nat</p>
<p>overcomen by adversitees. <a href="#BIVPVIINL64" id="BIVPVIIL64" class="pginternal">Ne certes</a>, thou that art
    put in the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">encres or in the heighte of vertu, ne hast nat comen to fleten with</p>
<p>delices, and for to welken in bodily luste; thou sowest or plauntest</p>
<p>a ful egre bataile <i>in thy corage</i> ayeins every fortune: for that the</p>
<p>sorwful fortune ne confounde thee nat, ne that the merye fortune</p>
<p>ne corumpe thee nat, occupye the mene by stedefast strengthes.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For al that ever is under the mene, or elles al that overpasseth the</p>
<p>mene, despyseth welefulnesse (<i>as who seyth, it is vicious</i>), and ne</p>
<p>hath no mede of his travaile. For it is set <a href="#BIVPVIINL72" id="BIVPVIIL72" class="pginternal">in your
    hand</a> (<i>as who</i></p>
<p><i>seyth, it lyth in your power</i>) what fortune yow is levest, <i>that is to</i></p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page125">{125}</span><i>seyn, good or yvel</i>. For alle fortune
    that semeth sharp or aspre,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">yif it ne exercyse nat <i>the gode folk</i> ne chastyseth <i>the wikked
    folk</i>, it</p>
<p>punissheth.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr.</span> VII. 1. A. Sest thou; C. Sestow.  5, 6. A. <i>om.</i>
  alle ... aspre. 7. Ed. guerdonyng; C. A. gerdonynge. // C. excersisinge. 16. A. ywened. 20. A.
  proche. 24. A. Demest thou; Ed. Wenest thou.  A. al; C. alle. 26. C. excersiseth.  C. corigit; A.
  corigith; Ed. corrygeth. 34. A. seist thou. 35. Ed. guerdon; C. A. gerdoun.  C. Ed. demeth; A.
  deuinith; <i>decernit</i>.  A. poeples; <i>uulgus</i>. 38. A. seist thou. 41. C. Ed. is; A. be.
  49. A. <i>om.</i> or in ... vertu. 55. C. the stronge; A. no strong. 56. Ed. abasshen; A. abassen.
  66. A. welken; Ed. walken; C. wellen; <i>emarcescere</i>. 69. A. Ed. corrumpe.  C. Ocupye; A.
  Occupy.  C. stydefast. 75. C. excersyse. 76. C. punysseth; A. punisseth. </p>
<h3><span class="sc">Metre</span> VII.</h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Bella bis quinis operatus annis.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>The <a href="#BIVMVIINL1" id="BIVMVIIL1" class="pginternal">wreker</a> Attrides, <i>that is to seyn,
    Agamenon</i>, that wroughte</p>
<p>and continuede the batailes by ten yeer, <a href="#BIVMVIINL2" id="BIVMVIIL2" class="pginternal">recovered</a>
    and purgede</p>
<p><i>in wrekinge</i>, by the destruccioun of Troye, the loste chaumbres of</p>
<p>mariage of his brother; <i>this is to seyn, that he, Agamenon, wan</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>ayein Eleyne, that was <a href="#BIVMVIINL5" id="BIVMVIIL5" class="pginternal">Menelaus wyf his
    brother</a></i>. In the mene</p>
<p>whyle that thilke <i>Agamenon</i> desirede to yeven sayles to the</p>
<p>Grekissh navye, and boughte ayein the windes by blood, he unclothede</p>
<p>him of pitee of fader; and the sory preest yiveth in</p>
<p>sacrifyinge the wrecched cuttinge of throte of the doughter; <i>that</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>is to seyn, that Agamenon let cutten the throte of his <a href="#BIVMVIINL9" id="BIVMVIIL9" class="pginternal">doughter</a> by the</i></p>
<p><i>preest, to maken allyaunce with his goddes, and for to han winde</i></p>
<p><i>with whiche he mighte wenden to Troye</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#BIVMVIINL13" id="BIVMVIIL13" class="pginternal">Itacus</a>, <i>that is to seyn,
    Ulixes</i>, biwepte his felawes y-lorn, the</p>
<p>whiche felawes the ferse Poliphemus, ligginge in his grete cave,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">hadde freten and dreynt in his <a href="#BIVMVIINL15" id="BIVMVIIL15" class="pginternal">empty</a>
    wombe. But natheles</p>
<p>Poliphemus, wood for his blinde visage, yald to Ulixes Ioye by</p>
<p>his sorwful teres; <i>this is to seyn, that Ulixes smoot out the eye of</i></p>
<p><i>Poliphemus that stood in his forehed, for which Ulixes hadde Ioye,</i></p>
<p><i>whan he say Poliphemus wepinge and blinde</i>.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">20</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><a href="#BIVMVIINL20" id="BIVMVIIL20" class="pginternal">Hercules</a> is celebrable for
    his harde travailes; he dauntede the</p>
<p>proude <a href="#BIVMVIINL21" id="BIVMVIIL21" class="pginternal">Centaures</a>, <i>half hors, half man</i>; and
    he birafte the dispoylinge</p>
<p>fro the cruel <a href="#BIVMVIINL22" id="BIVMVIIL22" class="pginternal">lyoun</a>, <i>that is to seyn, he slowh
    the lyoun and</i></p>
<p><i>rafte him his skin</i>. He smoot the briddes <i>that highten <a href="#BIVMVIINL23" id="BIVMVIIL23" class="pginternal">Arpyes</a></i></p>
<p>with certein arwes. He ravisshede apples fro the wakinge <a href="#BIVMVIINL25" id="BIVMVIIL25" class="pginternal">dragoun</a>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and his hand was the more hevy for the goldene metal.</p>
<p>He drow <a href="#BIVMVIINL26" id="BIVMVIIL26" class="pginternal">Cerberus</a>, <i>the hound of helle</i>, by
    his treble cheyne. He,</p>
<p>overcomer, as it is seyd, hath put an <a href="#BIVMVIINL27" id="BIVMVIIL27" class="pginternal">unmeke</a> lord
    foddre to his</p>
<p>cruel hors; <i>this is to seyn, that Hercules slowh Diomedes, and made</i></p>
<p><i>his hors to freten him</i>. And he, Hercules, slowh <a href="#BIVMVIINL29" id="BIVMVIIL29" class="pginternal">Ydra</a> <i>the serpent</i>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page126">{126}</span>and brende the venim. And <a href="#BIVMVIINL30" id="BIVMVIIL30" class="pginternal">Achelous</a> the flood, defouled in his</p>
