<p>forhed, dreynte his shamefast visage in his strondes; <i>this is to</i></p>
<p><i>seyn, that Achelous coude transfigure him-self in-to dyverse lyknesses;</i></p>
<p><i>and, as he faught with Hercules, at the laste he tornede him in-to a</i></p>
<p><i>bole; and Hercules brak of oon of his hornes, and he, for shame,</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>hidde him in his river</i>. And he, Hercules, caste adoun <a href="#BIVMVIINL35" id="BIVMVIIL35" class="pginternal">Antheus</a></p>
<p>the gyaunt in the strondes of Libie; and <a href="#BIVMVIINL36" id="BIVMVIIL36" class="pginternal">Cacus</a>
    apaysede the</p>
<p>wratthes of Evander; <i>this is to seyn, that Hercules slowh the</i></p>
<p><i>monstre Cacus, and apaysede with that deeth the wratthe of</i></p>
<p><i>Evander</i>. And the bristlede <a href="#BIVMVIINL39" id="BIVMVIIL39" class="pginternal">boor</a> markede
    with scomes the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">shuldres of Hercules, <a href="#BIVMVIINL40" id="BIVMVIIL40" class="pginternal">the whiche</a>
    shuldres the heye cercle of</p>
<p>hevene sholde thriste. And the laste of his labours was, that he</p>
<p>sustened the hevene up-on his nekke unbowed; and he deservede</p>
<p>eft-sones the hevene, to ben the prys of his laste travaile.</p>
<p class="stanza">Goth now thanne, ye stronge men, ther-as the heye wey of the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">grete ensaumple ledeth yow. O nyce men, why <a href="#BIVMVIINL45" id="BIVMVIIL45" class="pginternal">nake</a> ye youre</p>
<p>bakkes? <i>As who seyth: O ye slowe and delicat men, why flee ye</i></p>
<p><i>adversitees, and ne fighten nat ayeins hem by vertu, to winnen the</i></p>
<p><i>mede of the hevene?</i> For the erthe, overcomen, yeveth the sterres';</p>
<p><i>this is to seyn, that, whan that erthely lust is overcomen, a man is</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>maked worthy to the hevene</i>.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp5"><span class="sc">Me.</span> VII. 4. A. Ed. <i>om.</i> he. 8. A. pite as fader. 16.
  A. yeld. 22. A. slouȝ. 23. Ed. Arpyes; C. A. arpiis; <i>glossed</i>—in the palude of
  lyrne. 26. C. drowh; A. drouȝ. 28. C. slowgh; A. slouȝ (<i>thrice</i>). 28, 31, 37,
  49. C. this (<i>for</i> this is). 29. A. etyn (<i>for</i> freten). 30. C. achelows (<i>1st
  time</i>); achelous (<i>2nd</i>); A. achelaus (<i>twice</i>). 34. C. he, <i>glossed</i> achelous;
  A. achelaus (<i>om.</i> he). 39. Ed. vomes (<i>for</i> scomes). 40. A. Ed. cercle; C. clerke (!).
  48. A. mede of the. // A. Ed. the sterres; C. <i>om.</i> the. </p>
<h2 class="sp3 ac" style="margin-bottom:2.1ex;"> <span class="larger">BOOK V.</span></h2>
<h3><span class="sc">Prose</span> I.</h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Dixerat, orationisque cursum.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>She hadde seyd, and torned the cours of hir resoun to some</p>
<p>othre thinges to ben treted and to ben y-sped. Thanne seyde I,</p>
<p>'<a href="#BVPINL3" id="BVPIL3" class="pginternal">Certes, rightful is thyn amonestinge</a> and ful digne by
    auctoritee.</p>
<p>But that thou seidest whylom, that the questioun of the divyne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">purviaunce is enlaced with many other questiouns, I understonde</p>
<p>wel and proeve it by the same thing. But I axe yif that thou</p>
<p>wenest that hap be any thing in any weys; and, yif thou wenest</p>
<p>that hap be anything, what is it?'</p>
<p class="stanza">Thanne quod she, 'I haste me to yilden and <a href="#BVPINL9" id="BVPIL9" class="pginternal">assoilen to thee</a></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page127">{127}</span>the dette of my bihest, and to
    shewen and opnen the wey, by</p>
<p>which wey thou mayst come ayein to thy contree. But al-be-it</p>
<p>so that the thinges which that thou axest ben right profitable to</p>
<p>knowe, yit ben they diverse somwhat fro the path of my purpos;</p>
<p>and it is <a href="#BVPINL14" id="BVPIL14" class="pginternal">to douten</a> that thou ne be maked wery by
    mis-weyes, so</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that thou ne mayst nat suffyce to mesuren the right wey.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Ne doute thee ther-of nothing,' quod I. 'For, for to knowen</p>
<p>thilke thinges to-gedere, in the whiche thinges I delyte me greetly,</p>
<p>that shal ben to me in stede of reste; sin it is nat to douten of</p>
<p>the thinges folwinge, whan every syde of thy disputacioun shal han</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">be stedefast to me by undoutous feith.'</p>
<p class="stanza">Thanne seyde she, 'That manere wol I don thee'; and bigan</p>
<p>to speken right thus. 'Certes,' quod she, 'yif any wight diffinisshe</p>
<p>hap in this manere, that is to seyn, that "hap is bitydinge</p>
<p>y-brought forth by foolish moevinge and by no knettinge of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">causes," I conferme that hap nis right naught in no wyse; and I</p>
<p>deme al-outrely that hap nis, ne dwelleth but a voice, <i>as who seith,</i></p>
<p><i>but an ydel word</i>, with-outen any significacioun of thing submitted</p>
<p>to that vois. For what place mighte ben <a href="#BVPINL28" id="BVPIL28" class="pginternal">left, or
    dwellinge,</a></p>
<p>to folye and to disordenaunce, sin that god ledeth and constreineth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">alle thinges by ordre? For this sentence is verray and</p>
<p>sooth, that "<a href="#BVPINL31" id="BVPIL31" class="pginternal">nothing</a> ne hath his beinge of naught"; to
    the</p>
<p>whiche sentence none of thise olde folk ne withseyde never; al-be-it</p>
<p>so that they ne understoden ne meneden it naught by god,</p>
<p><a href="#BVPINL34" id="BVPIL34" class="pginternal">prince and beginnere</a> of werkinge, but they <a href="#BVPINL34" class="pginternal">casten [it]</a> as a manere</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">foundement of subiect material, that is to seyn, of the nature of</p>
<p>alle resoun. And yif that any thing is woxen or comen of no</p>
<p>causes, than shal it seme that thilke thing is comen or woxen of</p>
<p>naught; but yif this ne may nat ben don, thanne is it nat possible,</p>
<p>that hap be any swich thing as I have diffinisshed a litel heer-biforn.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">40</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'How shal it thanne be?' quod I. 'Nis ther thanne no-thing</p>
<p>that by right may be cleped either "hap" or elles "aventure of</p>
<p>fortune"; or is ther aught, al-be-it so that it is hid fro the peple,</p>
<p>to which these wordes ben covenable?'</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page128">{128}</span>'Myn <a href="#BVPINL44" id="BVPIL44" class="pginternal">Aristotulis</a>,' quod she, 'in the book of his Phisik, diffinissheth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">this thing by short resoun, and neigh to the sothe.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'In which manere?' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'As ofte,' quod she, 'as men doon any thing <a href="#BVPINL47" id="BVPIL47" class="pginternal">for grace</a> of any</p>
<p>other thing, and an-other thing than thilke thing that men</p>
<p>entenden to don bitydeth by some causes, it is cleped "hap."</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BVPINL50" id="BVPIL50" class="pginternal">Right as</a> a man dalf the erthe <a href="#BVPINL50" class="pginternal">by cause</a> of tilyinge of the feeld,</p>
<p>and founde ther a gobet of gold bidolven, thanne wenen folk that</p>
<p>it is bifalle by fortunous bitydinge. But, for sothe, it nis nat of</p>
<p>naught, for it hath his propre causes; of whiche causes the cours</p>
<p>unforeseyn and unwar semeth to han maked hap. For yif the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">tilyere of the feld <a href="#BVPINL55" id="BVPIL55" class="pginternal">ne dolve</a> nat in the
    erthe, and yif the hyder of</p>
<p>the gold ne hadde hid the gold in thilke place, the gold ne hadde</p>
<p>nat been founde. Thise ben thanne the causes of the <a href="#BVPINL57" id="BVPIL57" class="pginternal">abregginge</a></p>
<p>of fortuit hap, the which abregginge of fortuit hap comth of causes</p>
<p>encountringe and flowinge to-gidere to hem-self, and nat by the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">entencioun of the doer. For neither the hyder of the gold ne the</p>
<p>delver of the feeld ne understoden nat that the gold sholde han</p>
<p>ben founde; but, as I sayde, it bitidde and ran to-gidere that he</p>
<p>dalf ther-as that other hadde hid the gold. Now may I thus</p>
<p>diffinisshe "hap." Hap is an unwar bitydinge of causes assembled</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">in thinges that ben don for som other thing. But thilke ordre,</p>
<p>procedinge by an <a href="#BVPINL66" id="BVPIL66" class="pginternal">uneschuable</a> bindinge to-gidere, which
    that</p>
<p>descendeth fro the welle of purviaunce that ordeineth alle thinges</p>
<p>in hir places and in hir tymes, maketh that the causes rennen and</p>
<p>assemblen to-gidere.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr.</span> I. 1. C. by cours (<i>wrongly</i>); A. Ed. the cours.
  4. C. whilom; A. som tyme. // the (2)] C. thy. 8. A. any (<i>for</i> any thing). // C. it is; A.
  Ed. is it. 9. C. Ed. to the; A. the to the; Cax. to the the (= to thee the). 13. C. and yit; A.
  Ed. <i>om</i>. and. 19. A. disputisou<i>n</i>. 19, 20. C. han be; Ed. haue ben; A. be. 22, 23. C.
  deffenysshe; <i>but</i> diffinysshed <i>in</i> 39. // C. <i>glosses</i> bitydinge <i>by</i> i.
  euentu<i>m</i>. 24. A. knyttyng. 31. A. <i>om.</i> the. 33. C. -stondyn; A. -stoden. // C. meneden
  <i>or</i> meueden; A. moeueden (<i>not in the</i> Latin <i>text</i>). 34. <i>I supply</i> it. 35.
  A. <i>om.</i> the. 38. C. <i>om.</i> yif (Lat. <i>quod si</i>). 43. C. co<i>n</i>venable. 50. C.
  to tylyinge; A. of tylienge. 52. A. fallen. 53. C. of nawht (<i>de nihilo</i>); A. for
  nauȝt. 55. C. of the feld (<i>agri</i>); A. in the erthe. // C. in the erthe
  (<i>humum</i>); A. in the felde. 57. A. abreggynge; C. abriggynge (<i>but</i> abreggynge <i>2nd
  time</i>). 58. A. fortune (!), <i>for</i> fortuit; <i>twice</i>. 66. A. vneschewable. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre I.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Rupis Achemenie scopulis, ubi uersa sequentum.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Tigris and Eufrates resolven and springen of oo welle, in the</p>
<p>cragges of the roche of the contree of <a href="#BVMINL2" id="BVMIL2" class="pginternal">Achemenie</a>, ther-as
    the</p>
<p><a href="#BVMINL3" id="BVMIL3" class="pginternal">fleinge bataile</a> ficcheth hir dartes, retorned in the
    brestes of hem</p>
<p>that folwen hem. And sone after tho same riveres, Tigris and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page129">{129}</span>Eufrates, unioinen and departen
    hir wateres. And <a href="#BVMINL5" id="BVMIL5" class="pginternal">yif they</a> comen</p>
<p>to-gideres, and ben assembled and cleped to-gidere into o cours,</p>
<p>thanne moten thilke thinges fleten to-gidere which that the water</p>
<p>of the entrechaunginge flood bringeth. The shippes and the</p>
<p>stokkes arraced with the flood moten assemblen; <a href="#BVMINL9" id="BVMIL9" class="pginternal">and the
    wateres</a></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">y-medled wrappeth or implyeth many fortunel happes or maneres;</p>
<p>the whiche wandringe happes, natheles, thilke declyninge lownesse</p>
<p>of the erthe and the flowinge ordre of the slydinge water governeth.</p>
<p>Right so Fortune, that semeth as that it fleteth with slaked or</p>
<p>ungovernede brydles, <a href="#BVMINL14" id="BVMIL14" class="pginternal">it suffereth</a> brydles, <i>that is to
    seyn, to be</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>governed</i>, and passeth by thilke lawe, <i>that is to seyn, by
    thilke</i></p>
<p><i>divyne ordenaunce</i>.'</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. I.</span> 1. A. <i>om.</i> and <i>after</i> Tigris. 3. A.
  <i>om.</i> bataile. 8. C. entrechaungynge, <i>glossed</i> i. alt<i>er</i>ni. 10. A. fortuned. 11.
  C. declynynge, <i>glossed</i> decliuitas. 13. A. <i>om.</i> that (2). 15. <i>thilke</i>] A. the.
  </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose II.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Animaduerto, inquam.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>'This understonde I wel,' quod I, 'and I acorde wel that it is</p>
<p>right as thou seyst. But I axe yif ther be any libertee of free wil</p>
<p>in this ordre of causes that clyven thus to-gidere in hem-self; or</p>
<p>elles I wolde witen yif that the <a href="#BVPIINL4" id="BVPIIL4" class="pginternal">destinal</a> cheyne
    constreineth the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">movinges of the <a href="#BVPIINL5" id="BVPIIL5" class="pginternal">corages</a> of men?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Yis,' quod she; 'ther is libertee of free wil. Ne ther ne was</p>
<p>nevere no nature of resoun that it ne hadde libertee of free wil.</p>
<p>For every thing that may naturely usen resoun, it hath doom by</p>
<p>which it decerneth and demeth every thing; thanne knoweth it,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">by it-self, <a href="#BVPIINL10" id="BVPIIL10" class="pginternal">thinges that ben to fleen</a>
    and thinges that ben to desiren.</p>
<p>And thilke thing that any wight demeth to ben desired, that axeth</p>
<p>or desireth he; and fleeth thilke thing that he troweth ben to</p>
<p>fleen. Wherfore in alle thinges that resoun <a href="#BVPIINL13" id="BVPIIL13" class="pginternal">is</a>, in hem
    also is</p>
<p>libertee of willinge and of nillinge. But I ne <a href="#BVPIINL14" id="BVPIIL14" class="pginternal">ordeyne</a>
    nat, <i>as who</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>seyth, I ne graunte nat</i>, that this libertee be evene-lyk in alle</p>
<p>thinges. Forwhy in the <a href="#BVPIINL16" id="BVPIIL16" class="pginternal">sovereines</a> devynes substaunces,
    <i>that is</i></p>
<p><i>to seyn, in spirits</i>, Iugement is more cleer, and <a href="#BVPIINL17" id="BVPIIL17" class="pginternal">wil</a> nat y-corumped,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page130">{130}</span>and <a href="#BVPIINL18" id="BVPIIL18" class="pginternal">might</a> redy to speden thinges that ben desired. But the</p>
<p>soules of men moten nedes be more free whan they loken hem in</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the speculacioun or lokinge of the devyne thought, and lasse free</p>
<p>whan they slyden in-to the bodies; and yit lasse free whan they</p>
<p>ben gadered to-gidere and comprehended in erthely membres.</p>
<p>But the laste servage is whan that they ben yeven to vyces, and</p>
<p>han y-falle from the possessioun of hir propre resoun. For after</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that they han cast awey hir eyen fro the light of the sovereyn</p>
<p>soothfastnesse to lowe thinges and derke, anon they derken by</p>
<p>the cloude of ignoraunce and ben troubled by felonous <a href="#BVPIINL27" id="BVPIIL27" class="pginternal">talents</a>; to</p>
<p>the whiche talents whan they aprochen and asenten, they hepen</p>
<p>and encresen the servage which they han ioyned to hem-self; and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">in this manere they ben <a href="#BVPIINL30" id="BVPIIL30" class="pginternal">caitifs</a> fro hir
    propre libertee. The whiche</p>
<p>thinges, nathelesse, the lokinge of the devyne purviaunce seeth,</p>
<p>that alle thinges biholdeth and seeth fro eterne, and ordeineth</p>
<p>hem everich in hir merites as they ben predestinat: <i>and it is seyd</i></p>
<p><a href="#BVPIINL34" id="BVPIIL34" class="pginternal">in Greek</a><i>, that</i> "alle thinges he seeth and alle
    thinges he hereth."</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. II.</span> 1. A. Ed. quod I; C. <i>om.</i> // C. Ed. acorde
  me; A. acorde wel. 2. C. of; A. or (<i>wrongly</i>); Lat. <i>arbitrii</i>. 3. C. hym; A. Ed. hem.
  5. C. mouynges (<i>motus</i>); A. moeueuynge (!). 12. A. <i>om.</i> thilke. // C. to ben fleen; A.
  ben to fleen; Ed. be to flyen. 16. C. dyuynes; A. deuynes (<i>as often in</i> C). 17. C. wil nat
  I-coromped (<i>uoluntas incorrupta</i>); A. wil nat be corumped (<i>wrongly</i>). 18. C. myht
  (<i>potestas</i>); A. hath myȝt. 27. C. clowdes; A. Ed. cloude (<i>nube</i>). 27, 8. Ed. A.
  to the; C. <i>om.</i> the. 31. A. purueaunce. 34. <i>The last clause, in the original, is in
  Greek.</i> </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre II.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Puro clarum lumine Phebum.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Homer with the hony mouth, <i>that is to seyn, Homer with the</i></p>
<p><i><a href="#BVMIINL1" id="BVMIIL1" class="pginternal">swete ditees</a></i>, singeth, that the sonne is <a href="#BVMIINL1" class="pginternal">cleer</a> by pure light; natheles</p>
<p>yit ne may it nat, by the infirme light of his bemes, breken or</p>
<p>percen the inwarde entrailes of the erthe, or elles of the see. So</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ne seeth nat <i>god</i>, maker of the grete world: to him, that loketh</p>
<p>alle thinges from an heigh, ne withstondeth nat no thinges by</p>
<p>hevinesse of erthe; ne the night ne withstondeth nat to him by</p>
<p>the blake cloudes. <i>Thilke god</i> seeth, in oo <a href="#BVMIINL8" id="BVMIIL8" class="pginternal">strok</a>
    of thought, alle</p>
<p>thinges that ben, or weren, or sholle comen; and <i>thilke god</i>, for</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">he loketh and seeth alle thinges alone, thou mayst seyn that he is</p>
<p>the verray sonne.'</p>
</div>
<p><span class="sc">Me. II.</span> 3. A. inferme. 6. C. <i>om.</i> nat. 7. C. heuynesse
  (<i>mole</i>); A. heuynesses. 8. C. strokk, <i>glossed</i> i. ictu. </p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page131">{131}</span></div>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose III.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Tum ego, en, inquam.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Thanne seyde I, 'now am I confounded by a more hard doute</p>
<p>than I was.'</p>
<p class="stanza">'What doute is that?' quod she. 'For certes, I coniecte now</p>
<p>by whiche thinges thou art troubled.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">5</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">'It semeth,' quod I, 'to repugnen and to contrarien greetly,</p>
<p>that god knoweth biforn alle thinges, and that ther is any freedom</p>
<p>of libertee. For yif so be that god loketh alle thinges biforn, ne</p>
<p>god ne may nat ben desseived in no manere, than mot it nedes</p>
<p>been, that alle thinges bityden the whiche that the purviaunce of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">god hath seyn biforn to comen. For which, yif that god</p>
<p>knoweth biforn nat only the werkes of men, but also hir conseiles</p>
<p>and hir willes, thanne ne shal ther be no <a href="#BVPIIINL12" id="BVPIIIL12" class="pginternal">libertee of
    arbitre</a>; ne,</p>
<p>certes, ther ne may be noon other dede, ne no wil, but thilke</p>
<p>which that the divyne purviaunce, that may nat ben desseived,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">hath feled biforn. For yif that they mighten wrythen awey in</p>
<p>othre manere than they ben purveyed, than sholde ther be no</p>
<p>stedefast prescience of thing to comen, but rather an uncertein</p>
<p>opinioun; the whiche thing to trowen of god, I deme it felonye</p>
<p>and unleveful. Ne I ne <a href="#BVPIIINL19" id="BVPIIIL19" class="pginternal">proeve</a> nat thilke same
    resoun, <i>as who</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>seyth, I ne alowe nat, or I ne preyse nat, thilke same resoun</i>, by</p>
<p>which that som men wenen that they mowen assoilen and</p>
<p>unknitten the knotte of this questioun. For, certes, they seyn</p>
<p>that thing nis nat to comen for that the purviaunce of god hath</p>
<p>seyn it biforn that is to comen, but rather the contrarye, <i>and that</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>is this</i>: that, for that the thing is to comen, therfore ne may it</p>
<p>nat ben hid fro the purviaunce of god; and in this manere this</p>
<p>necessitee slydeth ayein in-to the contrarye partye: ne it ne</p>
<p>bihoveth nat, nedes, that thinges bityden that ben purvyed, but</p>
<p>it bihoveth, nedes, that thinges that ben to comen ben y-porveyed:</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BVPIIINL30" id="BVPIIIL30" class="pginternal">but as it were y-travailed</a>, <i>as who
    seyth, that thilke answere</i></p>
<p><i>procedeth right as thogh men travaileden, or weren bisy to enqueren</i>,</p>
<p>the whiche thing is cause of the whiche thing:—as, whether the</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page132">{132}</span>prescience is cause of the necessitee of
    thinges to comen, or elles</p>
<p>that the necessitee of thinges to comen is cause of the purviaunce.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BVPIIINL35" id="BVPIIIL35" class="pginternal">But I ne</a> enforce me nat now to shewen
    it, that the bitydinge of</p>
<p>thinges y-wist biforn is necessarie, how so or in what manere</p>
<p>that the ordre of causes hath it-self; al-thogh that it ne seme nat</p>
<p>that the prescience bringe in necessitee of bitydinge to thinges to</p>
<p>comen. For certes, yif that any wight sitteth, it bihoveth by</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">necessitee that the opinioun be sooth of him that coniecteth that</p>
<p>he sitteth; and ayeinward also is it of the contrarye: yif the</p>
<p>opinioun be sooth of any wight for that he sitteth, it bihoveth by</p>
<p>necessitee that he sitte. Thanne is heer necessitee in that oon</p>
<p>and in that other: for in that oon is necessitee of sittinge, and,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">certes, in that other is necessitee of sooth. But therfore ne</p>
<p>sitteth nat a wight, for that the opinioun of the sittinge is sooth;</p>
<p>but the opinioun is rather sooth, for that a wight sitteth biforn.</p>
<p>And thus, al-thogh that the cause of the sooth cometh of that</p>
<p>other syde (<i>as who seyth, that al-thogh the cause of sooth comth</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>of the sitting, and nat of the trewe opinioun</i>), algates yit is ther</p>
<p>comune necessitee in that oon and in that other. Thus sheweth</p>
<p>it, that I may make semblable skiles of the purviaunce of god</p>
<p>and of thinges to comen. <a href="#BVPIIINL53" id="BVPIIIL53" class="pginternal">For althogh that</a>, for that
    thinges ben</p>
<p>to comen, ther-fore ben they purveyed, nat, certes, for that they</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ben purveyed, <a href="#BVPIIINL55" id="BVPIIIL55" class="pginternal">ther-fore ne bityde they
    nat</a>. Yit natheles,</p>
<p>bihoveth it by necessitee, that either the thinges to comen ben</p>
<p>y-purveyed of god, or elles that the thinges that ben purveyed of</p>
<p>god bityden. And this thing only suffiseth y-nough to destroyen</p>
<p>the freedom of oure arbitre, <i>that is to seyn, of oure free wil</i>. But</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">now, certes, <i>sheweth it wel, how fer fro the sothe and</i> how
    up-so-doun</p>
<p>is this thing that we seyn, that the bitydinge of temporel</p>
<p>thinges is cause of the eterne prescience. But for to wenen that</p>
<p>god purvyeth the thinges to comen for they ben to comen, what</p>
<p>other thing is it but for to wene that thilke thinges that bitidden</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">whylom ben causes of thilke soverein purvyaunce <i>that is in god</i>?</p>
<p>And her-to <i>I adde yit this thing</i>: that, right as whan that I wot</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page133">{133}</span>that a thing is, it bihoveth by necessitee
    that thilke selve thing be;</p>
<p>and eek, whan I have knowe that any thing shal bityden, so</p>
<p>byhoveth it by necessitee that thilke thing bityde:—so folweth it</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thanne, that the bitydinge of the thing y-wist biforn ne may nat</p>
<p>ben eschued. And <a href="#BVPIIINL71" id="BVPIIIL71" class="pginternal">at the laste</a>, yif that any wight
    wene a thing</p>
<p>to ben other weyes thanne it is, it is nat only unscience, but it is</p>
<p>deceivable opinioun ful diverse and fer fro the sothe of science.</p>
<p>Wherfore, yif any thing be so to comen, that the bitydinge of hit</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ne be nat certein ne necessarie, who may weten biforn that thilke</p>
<p>thing is to comen? For right as science ne may nat ben medled</p>
<p>with falsnesse (<i>as who seyth, that yif I wot a thing, it ne may nat</i></p>
<p><i>be false <a href="#BVPIIINL78" id="BVPIIIL78" class="pginternal">that I ne wot it</a></i>), right so thilke
    thing that is conceived by</p>
<p>science ne may nat ben non other weys than as it is conceived.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For that is the cause why that science <a href="#BVPIIINL80" id="BVPIIIL80" class="pginternal">wanteth lesing</a> (<i>as who</i></p>
<p><i>seyth, why that witinge ne receiveth nat lesinge of that it wot</i>); for</p>
<p>it bihoveth, by necessitee, that every thing be right as science</p>
<p>comprehendeth it to be. What shal I thanne seyn? In whiche</p>
<p>manere knoweth god biforn the thinges to comen, yif they ne be</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">85</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">nat certein? For yif that he deme that they ben to comen</p>
<p>uneschewably, and so may be that it is possible that they ne</p>
<p>shollen nat comen, god is deceived. But nat only to trowen that</p>
<p>god is deceived, but for to speke it with mouth, it is a felonous</p>
<p>sinne. But yif that god wot that, right so as thinges ben <i>to</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>comen</i>, so shullen they comen—so that he wite <a href="#BVPIIINL90" id="BVPIIIL90" class="pginternal">egaly</a>, <i>as who</i></p>
<p><i>seyth, <a href="#BVPIIINL90" class="pginternal">indifferently</a></i>, that thinges mowen ben doon or elles
    nat</p>
<p>y-doon—what is thilke prescience that ne comprehendeth no</p>
<p>certein thing ne stable? Or elles what difference is ther bitwixe</p>
<p>the prescience and thilke <a href="#BVPIIINL94" id="BVPIIIL94" class="pginternal">Iape-worthy</a> divyninge of
    Tiresie the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">divynour, <i>that seyde</i>: "Al that I seye," quod he, "either it shal be,</p>
<p>or elles it ne shal nat be?" Or elles how mochel is worth the</p>
<p>devyne prescience more than the opinioun of mankinde, yif so be</p>
<p>that it demeth the thinges uncertein, as men doon; of the whiche</p>
<p>domes of men the bitydinge nis nat certein? But yif so be that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">non uncertein thing ne may ben in him that is right certein welle</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page134">{134}</span>of alle thinges, thanne is the bitydinge
    certein of thilke thinges</p>
<p>whiche he hath wist biforn fermely to comen. For which it</p>
<p>folweth, that the freedom of the conseiles and of the werkes of</p>
<p>mankind nis non, sin that the thoght of god, that seeth alle</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thinges without errour of falsnesse, bindeth and constreineth</p>
<p>hem to a bitydinge <i>by necessitee</i>. And yif this thing be ones</p>
<p>y-graunted and received, <i>that is to seyn, that ther nis no free wille</i>,</p>
<p>than sheweth it wel, how greet destruccioun and how grete</p>
<p>damages ther folwen of thinges of mankinde. For in ydel ben</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ther thanne purposed and bihight medes to gode folk, and peynes</p>
<p>to badde folk, sin that no moevinge of free corage voluntarie ne</p>
<p>hath nat deserved hem, <i>that is to seyn, neither mede ne peyne</i>; and</p>
<p>it sholde seme thanne, that thilke thing is alderworst, which that</p>
<p>is now demed for aldermost iust and most rightful, <i>that is to seyn</i>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that shrewes ben punisshed, or elles that gode folk ben y-gerdoned:</p>
<p>the whiche folk, sin that hir propre wil ne <a href="#BVPIIINL116" id="BVPIIIL116" class="pginternal">sent</a>
    hem nat to that oon</p>
<p>ne to that other, <i>that is to seyn, neither to gode ne to harm</i>, but <a href="#BVPIIINL117" id="BVPIIIL117" class="pginternal">constreineth</a></p>
<p>hem certein necessitee of thinges to comen: thanne ne</p>
<p>shollen ther nevere ben, ne nevere weren, vyce ne vertu, but it</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">120</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">sholde rather ben confusioun of alle desertes medled with-outen</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIINL121" id="BVPIIIL121" class="pginternal">discrecioun</a>. <a href="#BVPIIINL121" class="pginternal">And yit</a>
<i>ther folweth an-other inconvenient</i>, of the</p>
<p>whiche ther ne may ben thoght no more felonous ne more wikke;</p>
<p><i>and that is this</i>: that, so as the ordre of thinges is y-led and</p>
<p>comth of the purviaunce of god, ne that no-thing nis leveful to</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the conseiles of mankinde (<i>as who seyth, that men han no power to</i></p>
<p><i>doon no-thing, ne wilne no-thing</i>), than folweth it, that oure vyces</p>
<p>ben referred to the maker of alle good (<i>as who seyth, than folweth</i></p>
<p><i>it, that god oughte han the blame of oure vyces, sin he constreineth us</i></p>
<p><i>by necessitee to doon vyces</i>). Thanne is ther no resoun to hopen <i>in</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>god</i>, ne for to preyen <i>to god</i>; for what sholde any wight hopen
    <i>to</i></p>
<p><i>god</i>, or why sholde he preyen <i>to god</i>, <a href="#BVPIIINL131" id="BVPIIIL131" class="pginternal">sin
    that</a> the ordenaunce of</p>
<p>destinee, which that ne may nat ben inclyned, knitteth and streineth</p>
<p>alle thinges that men may desiren? Thanne sholde ther be doon</p>
<p>awey thilke only allyaunce bitwixen god and men, that is to seyn,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">135</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page135">{135}</span>to hopen and to preyen. But by
    the prys of rightwisnesse and of</p>
<p>verray mekenesse we deserven the gerdoun of the divyne grace,</p>
<p>which that is inestimable, <i>that is to seyn, that it is so greet, that it</i></p>
<p><i>ne may nat ben ful y-preysed</i>. And this is only the manere, <i>that is</i></p>
<p><i>to seyn, hope and preyeres</i>, for which it semeth that men mowen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">speke with god, and by resoun of supplicacioun be conioined to</p>
<p>thilke cleernesse, <a href="#BVPIIINL141" id="BVPIIIL141" class="pginternal">that nis nat aproched no rather or
    that</a> men</p>
<p>beseken it and <a href="#BVPIIINL142" id="BVPIIIL142" class="pginternal">impetren</a> it. And yif men wene nat
    that hope ne</p>
<p>preyeres ne han no strengthes, by the necessitee of thinges to</p>
<p>comen y-received, what thing is ther thanne by whiche we mowen</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">145</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ben conioined and clyven to thilke soverein prince of thinges?</p>
<p>For which it bihoveth, by necessitee, that the <a href="#BVPIIINL146" id="BVPIIIL146" class="pginternal">linage
    of mankinde</a>,</p>
<p>as thou songe <a href="#BVPIIINL147" id="BVPIIIL147" class="pginternal">a litel her-biforn</a>, be departed and
    unioined from</p>
<p>his welle, and failen <i>of his biginninge, that is to seyn, god</i>.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. III.</span> 9. A. purueaunce. 14. A. <i>om.</i> that (1). 18.
  C. of; A. on. 24. C. <i>om.</i> it. // C. but; <i>glossed</i> s. aiunt. 25. C. <i>om.</i> is (1).
  // A. that therfore. 28. A. <i>om.</i> nat. // A. ypurueid. 28, 9. A. <i>om.</i> but it bihoveth
  ... y-porveyed. 32. A. whiche thinges (<i>for 2nd</i> the whiche thing). // C. weyther. 34. C.
  p<i>ur</i>uyaunce; <i>glossed</i> s. p<i>ro</i>uidencie. 35. C. it; <i>glossed</i> illud. 38. A.
  of thinges. 48, 9. A. <i>om.</i> the sooth cometh ... cause of. 53. C. Ed. that for that; A. for
  that that. 58. A. bitiden by necessite; C. <i>has the gloss</i>—s. by necessite. 60. A.
  <i>om.</i> certes. 60, 1. C. vp so down; <i>glossed</i> p<i>re</i>postere. 62. A. is the cause.
  63. A. <i>om.</i> the. 64, 5. A. bitiden som-tyme. 71. C. at the laste; <i>glossed</i> i.
  postremo. 74. A. so that the. 75. A. <i>om.</i> biforn. 79. A. <i>om.</i> nat. // C. as it is; A.
  it is be. 82. A. <i>om.</i> be. 85. C. he; <i>glossed</i> s. deus. // C. they; <i>glossed</i> s.
  thynges. 86. C. vneschwably; <i>glossed</i> i. memorabilit<i>er</i> (!) 87. C. A. desseyued
  (<i>twice</i>). 92. A. don. 94. C. Iape worthi; <i>glossed</i> i. ridiculo. 100. A. <i>om.</i> ne.
  102. C. he; <i>glossed</i> s. deus. // C. fermely; <i>glossed</i> i. firmit<i>er</i>. 106. A.
  <i>om.</i> this. 107. C. resseyuyd; A. receyued. 108. C. destruccyou<i>n</i>; <i>glossed</i> i.
  occasus. 110. C. Meedes to; A. medes of. 113. A. alther-worste. 114. A. alther-moste. 116. C. hir;
  A. the. // A. <i>om.</i> ne <i>before</i> sent. 120. C. dissertes; A. desertes. 121. <i>For</i> of
  the, <i>read</i> than; <i>see note</i>. 122. A. ne (<i>for</i> no). 128. A. <i>om.</i> us. 129. A.
  to han hopen. 135. A. p<i>re</i>is. 136. C. desseruyn; A. deserue. 139. A. <i>om.</i> men. 142.
  Ed. impetren; C. impetrent (!); A. emprenten. // A. <i>om.</i> nat. // A. <i>om.</i> hope. 143. C.
  <i>om.</i> no. 144. C. I-resseyuyd (<i>glossed</i> i. graunted); A. y-resceiued. 147. C. thou;
  <i>glossed</i> s. philosophie. // C. her by-forn, libro 4<sup>o</sup> metro sexto [<i>line</i>
  35]. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre III.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quenam discors federa rerum.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p><a href="#BVMIIINL1" id="BVMIIIL1" class="pginternal">What</a> discordable cause hath to-rent and unioined the
    bindinge,</p>
<p><i>or the alliaunce</i>, of thinges, <i>that is to seyn, the <a href="#BVMIIINL2" id="BVMIIIL2" class="pginternal">coniunccioun</a> of god</i></p>
<p><i>and man</i>? <a href="#BVMIIINL3" id="BVMIIIL3" class="pginternal">Whiche god</a> hath establisshed so greet
    bataile bitwixen</p>
<p>thise two soothfast or verray thinges, <i>that is to seyn,</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>bitwixen the purviaunce of god and free wil</i>, that they ben singuler</p>
<p>and devyded, ne that they ne wolen nat be medeled ne coupled</p>
<p>to-gidere? <a href="#BVMIIINL7" id="BVMIIIL7" class="pginternal">But ther nis</a> no discord to the verray
    thinges, but they</p>
<p>clyven, certein, alwey to hem-self. But the thought of man, confounded</p>
<p>and overthrowen by the dirke membres of the body, ne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">may nat, <a href="#BVMIIINL10" id="BVMIIIL10" class="pginternal">by fyr</a> of his derked looking,
    <i>that is to seyn, by the vigour</i></p>
<p><i>of his insighte, whyl the soule is in the body</i>, knowe the thinne</p>
<p>subtil knittinges of thinges. <a href="#BVMIIINL12" id="BVMIIIL12" class="pginternal">But wherfore</a>
    enchaufeth it so, by so</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page136">{136}</span>greet love, to finden thilke notes of sooth
    y-covered; <i>that is to</i></p>
<p><i>seyn, wherfore enchaufeth the thoght of man by so greet desyr to</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>knowen thilke notificacions that ben y-hid under the covertoures of</i></p>
<p><i>sooth?</i> <a href="#BVMIIINL16" id="BVMIIIL16" class="pginternal">Wot it</a> aught thilke thing that it,
    anguissous, desireth to</p>
<p>knowe? <i>As who seith, nay; for no man travaileth for to witen</i></p>
<p><i>thinges that he wot. And therfore the texte <a href="#BVMIIINL18" id="BVMIIIL18" class="pginternal">seith
    thus</a></i>: but who</p>
<p>travaileth to witen thinges y-knowe? And yif that he ne knoweth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">hem nat, what seketh thilke blinde thoght? What is he that</p>
<p>desireth any thing of which he wot right naught? <i>As who seith,</i></p>
<p><i>who so desireth any thing, nedes, somwhat he knoweth of it; or</i></p>
<p><i>elles, he ne coude nat desire it.</i> <a href="#BVMIIINL23" id="BVMIIIL23" class="pginternal">Or who</a> may
    folwen thinges that ne</p>
<p>ben nat y-wist? <i>And thogh that he seke tho thinges</i>, wher shal he</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">finde hem? What wight, that is al unconninge and ignoraunt,</p>
<p>may knowen the forme that is y-founde? <a href="#BVMIIINL26" id="BVMIIIL26" class="pginternal">But whan</a> the
    soule</p>
<p>biholdeth and seeth the heye thoght, <i>that is to seyn, god</i>, than</p>
<p>knoweth it to-gidere the somme and the singularitees, <i>that is to</i></p>
<p><i>seyn, the principles and everich by him-self</i>.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">30</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">But now, whyl the soule is hid in the cloude and in the derkenesse</p>
<p>of the membres of the body, it ne hath nat al for-yeten</p>
<p>it-self, but it <a href="#BVMIIINL32" id="BVMIIIL32" class="pginternal">with-holdeth</a> the somme of thinges,
    and leseth the</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIIINL33" id="BVMIIIL33" class="pginternal">singularitees</a>. Thanne, who-so that seeketh
    soothnesse, he nis in</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIIINL34" id="BVMIIIL34" class="pginternal">neither nother</a> habite; for he noot nat al, ne he ne
    hath nat al</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">foryeten: but yit him remembreth the somme of thinges that he</p>
<p>with-holdeth, and axeth conseil, and <a href="#BVMIIINL36" id="BVMIIIL36" class="pginternal">retreteth</a>
    deepliche thinges</p>
<p>y-seyn biforn, <i>that is to seyn, the grete somme in his minde</i>: so that</p>
<p>he mowe adden the parties that he hath for-yeten to thilke that he</p>
<p>hath with-holden.'</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. III.</span> 1. C. vnioygnyd, <i>glossed</i> s. ne se
  compaciant<i>ur</i> si<i>mi</i>l<i>iter</i>. 2. C. coniuncciou<i>n</i>s; A. coniuncc<i>i</i>oun.
  3. C. man, <i>quasi dicat, nullus</i>. // C. which that god; A. Ed. whiche god (<i>quis Deus</i>).
  6. C. deuydyd, <i>quasi dicat, non est ita</i>. 7. A. <i>om.</i> the. // C. thinges, <i>s.
  prudencia et liberum arbitrium</i>. 8. A. cleuen. 10. A. dirk. 12. C. it, <i>s. anima</i>. 13. A.
  note (Lat. <i>notas</i>). 16. C. it, <i>s. anima</i>. 18. <i>After</i> thus, A.
  <i>adds</i>—Si enim anima ignorat istas subtiles connexiones, responde, vnde est quod
  desiderat scire cum nil ignotum possit desiderare; <i>but both</i> C. <i>and</i> Ed. <i>omit
  this</i>. 21. wot] C. not. // C. nawht, <i>quasi dicat, non</i>. 24. A. <i>om.</i> that. 26. C.
  yfownde, <i>quasi dicat, nullus</i>. 29. A. Ed. principles; C. principulis. 34. A. nouthir habit.
  36. C. retretith, <i>i. retractat</i>; A. tretith. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose IV.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Tum illa: Vetus, inquit, hec est.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Thanne seide she: 'this is,' quod she, 'the olde question of</p>
<p>the purviaunce of god; and <a href="#BVPIVNL2" id="BVPIVL2" class="pginternal">Marcus Tullius</a>, whan he
    devyded the</p>
<p>divynaciouns, <i>that is to seyn, in his book that he wroot of divynaciouns</i>,</p>
<p>he moevede gretly this questioun; and thou thy-self has y-sought</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page137">{137}</span>it mochel, and outrely, and
    longe; but yit ne hath it nat ben</p>
<p>determined ne y-sped fermely and diligently of any of yow. And</p>
<p>the cause of this derkenesse and of this difficultee is, for that the</p>
<p>moevinge of the resoun of mankinde ne may nat <a href="#BVPIVNL8" id="BVPIVL8" class="pginternal">moeven to</a>
    (<i>that</i></p>
<p><i>is to seyn, applyen or ioinen to</i>) the simplicitee of the devyne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">prescience; the whiche <i>simplicitee of the devyne prescience</i>, yif</p>
<p>that men mighten thinken it in any maner, <i>that is to seyn, that yif</i></p>
<p><i>men mighten thinken and comprehenden the thinges as god seeth</i></p>
<p><i>hem</i>, thanne ne sholde ther dwellen outrely no doute: the whiche</p>
<p><i>resoun and cause of difficultee</i> I shal assaye at the laste to shewe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and to speden, whan I have first <a href="#BVPIVNL15" id="BVPIVL15" class="pginternal">y-spended</a> and answered to tho</p>
<p>resouns by which thou art y-moeved. For I axe why thou wenest</p>
<p>that thilke resouns of hem that assoilen this questioun ne ben</p>
<p>nat speedful y-nough ne sufficient: the whiche <i>solucioun, or the</i></p>
<p><i>whiche resoun</i>, for that it demeth that the prescience nis nat cause</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of necessitee to thinges to comen, than ne weneth it nat that</p>
<p>freedom of wil be destorbed or y-let by prescience. For ne</p>
<p>drawestow nat arguments <a href="#BVPIVNL22" id="BVPIVL22" class="pginternal">from elles-where</a> of the
    necessitee of</p>
<p>thinges to-comen (<i>as who seith, any other wey than thus</i>) but that</p>
<p>thilke thinges that the prescience wot biforn ne mowen nat <a href="#BVPIVNL24" id="BVPIVL24" class="pginternal">unbityde</a>?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>That is to seyn, that they moten bityde.</i> But thanne, yif</p>
<p>that prescience ne putteth no necessitee to thinges to comen, as</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVNL27" id="BVPIVL27" class="pginternal">thou thy-self</a> hast confessed it and biknowen a litel
    her-biforn, what</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVNL28" id="BVPIVL28" class="pginternal">cause</a> or what is it (<i>as who seith, ther may no
    cause be</i>) by which</p>
<p>that the <a href="#BVPIVNL29" id="BVPIVL29" class="pginternal">endes</a> voluntarie of thinges mighten be
    constreined to</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">certein bitydinge? For <a href="#BVPIVNL30" id="BVPIVL30" class="pginternal">by grace of
    positioun</a>, so that thou mowe</p>
<p>the betere understonde this that folweth, <a href="#BVPIVNL31" id="BVPIVL31" class="pginternal">I pose</a>,
    <i>per impossibile</i>,</p>
<p>that ther be no prescience. Thanne axe I,' quod she, 'in as</p>
<p>mochel as apertieneth to that, sholden thanne thinges that comen</p>
<p>of free wil ben constreined to bityden by necessitee?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">35</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><i>Boece.</i> 'Nay,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza">'Thanne ayeinward,' quod she, 'I suppose that ther be prescience,</p>
<p>but that it ne putteth no necessitee to thinges; thanne</p>
<p>trowe I, that thilke selve freedom of wil shal dwellen al hool and</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page138">{138}</span>absolut and unbounden. But thou wolt seyn
    that, al-be-it so that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">prescience nis nat cause of the necessitee of bitydinge to thinges</p>
<p>to comen, algates yit it is a signe that the thinges ben to bityden</p>
<p>by necessitee. By this manere thanne, al-thogh the prescience</p>
<p>ne hadde never y-ben, yit <i>algate or at the leeste weye</i> it is certein</p>
<p>thing, that the endes and bitydinges of thinges to comen sholden</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ben necessarie. For every signe sheweth and signifyeth only what</p>
<p>the thing is, but it ne maketh nat the thing that it signifyeth. For</p>
<p>which it bihoveth first to shewen, that no-thing ne bitydeth that it</p>
<p>ne bitydeth by necessitee, so that it may appere that the prescience</p>
<p>is signe of this necessitee; or elles, yif ther nere no necessitee,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">certes, thilke prescience ne mighte nat be signe of thing that nis</p>
<p>nat. But certes, it is now certein that the proeve of this,</p>
<p>y-sustened by stidefast resoun, ne shal nat ben lad ne proeved by</p>
<p>signes ne by arguments y-taken fro with-oute, but by causes</p>
<p>covenable and necessarie. But <i>thou mayst seyn</i>, how may it be</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that the thinges ne bityden nat that ben y-purveyed to comen?</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVNL56" id="BVPIVL56" class="pginternal">But, certes, right</a> as we trowen that tho thinges which
    that the</p>
<p>purviance wot biforn to comen ne ben nat to bityden; but that</p>
<p>ne sholden we nat demen; but rather, al-thogh that they shal</p>
<p>bityden, yit ne have they no necessitee of hir kinde to bityden.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And this maystow lightly aperceiven by this that I shal seyn. For</p>
<p>we seen many thinges whan they ben don biforn oure eyen, right</p>
<p>as men seen the cartere worken <a href="#BVPIVNL62" id="BVPIVL62" class="pginternal">in the torninge</a> or
    atempringe or</p>
<p>adressinge of hise cartes or charietes. <a href="#BVPIVNL63" id="BVPIVL63" class="pginternal">And by</a> this
    manere (<i>as</i></p>
<p><i>who seith, maystow understonde</i>) of alle othere <i>workmen</i>. Is ther</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thanne any necessitee, <i>as who seith, in oure lokinge</i>, that
    constreineth</p>
<p>or compelleth any of thilke thinges to ben don so?'</p>
<p class="stanza"><i>Boece.</i> 'Nay,' quod I; 'for in ydel and in veyn were al the</p>
<p>effect of craft, yif that alle thinges weren moeved by constreininge;'</p>
<p><i>that is to seyn, by constreininge of oure eyen or of oure sight</i>.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">70</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><i>Philosophie.</i> 'The thinges thanne,' quod she, 'that, whan men</p>
<p>doon hem, ne han no necessitee that men doon hem, eek tho</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page139">{139}</span>same thinges, first or they ben doon, they ben
    to comen with-oute</p>
<p>necessitee. For-why ther ben somme thinges to bityden, of which</p>
<p>the endes and the bitydinges of hem ben absolut and quit of alle</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">necessitee. For certes, I ne trowe nat that any man wolde seyn</p>
<p>this: that tho thinges that men doon now, that they ne weren to</p>
<p>bityden first or they weren y-doon; and thilke same thinges,</p>
<p>al-thogh that men had y-wist hem biforn, yit they han free</p>
<p>bitydinges. For right as science of thinges present ne bringeth in</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">no necessitee to thinges that men doon, right so the prescience of</p>
<p>thinges to comen ne bringeth in no necessitee to thinges to</p>
<p>bityden. But thou mayst seyn, that of thilke same it is y-douted,</p>
<p>as whether that of thilke thinges that ne han non issues and</p>
<p>bitydinges necessaries, yif ther-of may ben any prescience; for</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">85</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">certes, they semen to discorden. For thou wenest that, yif that</p>
<p>thinges ben y-seyn biforn, that necessitee folweth hem; and yif</p>
<p>necessitee faileth hem, they ne mighten nat ben wist biforn, and</p>
<p>that no-thing ne may ben comprehended by science but certein;</p>
<p>and yif tho thinges that ne han no certein bitydinges ben purveyed</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">as certein, it sholde ben dirknesse of opinioun, nat soothfastnesse</p>
<p>of science. And thou wenest that it be diverse fro the hoolnesse</p>
<p>of science that any man sholde deme a thing to ben other-weys</p>
<p>thanne it is it-self. And the cause of this erroure is, that of alle</p>
<p>the thinges that every wight hath y-knowe, they wenen that tho</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thinges been y-knowe al-oonly by the strengthe and by the nature</p>
<p>of the thinges that ben y-wist or y-knowe; and it is al the</p>
<p>contrarie. For al that ever is y-knowe, it is rather comprehended</p>
<p>and knowen, nat after his strengthe and his nature, but after the</p>
<p>facultee, <i>that is to seyn, the power and the nature</i>, of hem that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">knowen. <a href="#BVPIVNL100" id="BVPIVL100" class="pginternal">And, for that this thing shal
    mowen shewen</a> by a short</p>
<p>ensaumple: the same <a href="#BVPIVNL101" id="BVPIVL101" class="pginternal">roundnesse</a> of a body, other-weys
    the sighte</p>
<p>of the eye knoweth it, and other-weyes the touchinge. The</p>
<p>lokinge, by castinge of his bemes, waiteth and seeth from afer al</p>
<p>the body to-gidere, with-oute moevinge of it-self; but the touchinge</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">clyveth and conioineth to the rounde body, and moeveth aboute</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page140">{140}</span>the environinge, and comprehendeth by parties
    the roundnesse.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVNL107" id="BVPIVL107" class="pginternal">And the man</a> him-self, other-weys wit biholdeth him,
    and</p>
<p>other-weys imaginacioun, and other-weys resoun, and other-weys</p>
<p>intelligence. For the wit comprehendeth withoute-forth the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">figure of the body of the man that is establissed in the</p>
<p>matere subiect; but the imaginacioun comprehendeth only the</p>
<p>figure withoute the matere. Resoun surmounteth imaginacioun,</p>
<p>and comprehendeth by universal lokinge the comune <a href="#BVPIVNL113" id="BVPIVL113" class="pginternal">spece</a> that</p>
<p>is in the singuler peces. But the eye of <a href="#BVPIVNL114" id="BVPIVL114" class="pginternal">intelligence</a> is heyere; for</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">it surmounteth the environinge of the <a href="#BVPIVNL115" id="BVPIVL115" class="pginternal">universitee</a>, and looketh,</p>
<p>over that, by pure subtilitee of thoght, thilke same simple forme</p>
<p><i>of man that is perdurably in the divyne thoght</i>. In whiche this</p>
<p>oughte greetly to ben considered, that the heyeste strengthe to</p>
<p>comprehenden thinges enbraseth and contieneth the lowere</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">120</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">strengthe; but the lowere strengthe ne aryseth nat in no manere</p>
<p>to heyere strengthe. For wit ne may no-thing comprehende out</p>
<p>of matere, ne the imaginacioun ne loketh nat the universels</p>
<p>speces, ne resoun taketh nat the simple forme <i>so as intelligence</i></p>
<p><i>taketh it</i>; but intelligence, that looketh al aboven, whan it hath</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">comprehended the forme, it knoweth and demeth alle the thinges</p>
<p>that ben under that forme. But <i>she knoweth hem</i> in thilke manere</p>
<p>in the whiche it comprehendeth thilke same simple forme that</p>
<p>ne may never ben knowen to none of that other; <i>that is to seyn,</i></p>
<p><i>to none of tho three forseide thinges of the sowle</i>. For it knoweth</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the universitee of resoun, and the figure of the imaginacioun,</p>
<p>and the sensible material <i>conceived by wit</i>; ne it ne useth nat nor</p>
<p>of resoun ne of imaginacioun ne of wit withoute-forth; but it</p>
<p>biholdeth alle thinges, so as I shal seye, <a href="#BVPIVNL133" id="BVPIVL133" class="pginternal">by a
    strok</a> of thought</p>
<p>formely, <i>withoute discours or collacioun</i>. Certes resoun, whan it</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">135</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">looketh any-thing universel, it ne useth nat of imaginacioun, nor</p>
<p>of witte, and algates yit it comprehendeth the thinges imaginable</p>
<p>and sensible; for resoun is she that <a href="#BVPIVNL137" id="BVPIVL137" class="pginternal">diffinisseth</a>
    the universel of hir</p>
<p>conseyte right thus:—man is a resonable two-foted beest. And</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page141">{141}</span>how so that this knowinge is universel, yet
    nis ther no wight that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ne woot wel that a man is a thing imaginable and sensible; and</p>
<p>this same considereth wel resoun; but that nis nat by imaginacioun</p>
<p>nor by wit, but it looketh it by a resonable concepcioun. Also</p>
<p>imaginacioun, al-be-it so that it taketh of wit the beginninges to</p>
<p>seen and to formen the figures, algates, al-thogh that wit ne were</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">145</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">nat present, yit it environeth and comprehendeth alle thinges</p>
<p>sensible; nat by resoun sensible of deminge, but by resoun</p>
<p>imaginatif. Seestow nat thanne that alle the thinges, in knowinge,</p>
<p>usen more of hir facultee or of hir power than <i>they doon of the</i></p>
<p><i>facultee or power</i> of thinges that ben y-knowe? Ne that nis nat</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">150</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">wrong; for so as every Iugement is the dede or doinge of him</p>
<p>that demeth, it bihoveth that every wight performe the werk and</p>
<p>his entencioun, nat of foreine power, but of his propre power.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Pr. IV.</span> 2. C. deuynede; Ed. deuyded; A. deuided;
  <i>distribuit</i>. 7. C. dirknesse; A. derkenesse. // A. <i>om. 2nd</i> of this. 11, 12. A.
  <i>om.</i> mighten thinken it ... yif men. 15. A. <i>om.</i> y-spended and. // C. the; A. tho. 22.
  A. drawest thou. 24. A. thinge. // A. <i>om.</i> ne. 28. A. <i>om.</i> or what. 29. C. A.
  <i>gloss</i> endes <i>by</i> exitus. 30. Ed. posycion (Lat. <i>positionis</i>); C. A. possessioun;
  <i>and</i> C. <i>glosses</i> For ... possessioun <i>by</i> uerbi gratia. 31. A.
  <i>inpossibile</i>; C. <i>per impossibile</i> (as a gloss). 37. Ed. it; C. is. 44. C. endes, <i>i.
  exitus</i>. // A. and the (<i>for</i> and). 46. C. thing is, <i>i. se eius significatum</i>. // C.
  maketh, <i>glossed</i> causat. 47, 48. A. <i>om.</i> that it ne bitydeth. 48, 49. C. <i>om.</i> so
  that ... necessitee. 51. A. preue. 52. A. stedfast. // A. p<i>ro</i>ued. 57. C. but that; A.
  <i>om.</i> that. 58. A. <i>om.</i> that. 60. A. maist thou. 62. A. and in attempryng or in
  adressyng. 63. A. chariottes. 64. A. mayst thou. 65. A. <i>om.</i> that. 66. C. <i>om.</i> thilke.
  // C. so, <i>quasi dicat, non</i>. 70. A. thise thingus. 80, 81. A. <i>om.</i> that men doon ...
  to thinges. 83. C. Ed. issues; A. endes; C. <i>adds</i>—<i>i. exitus</i>. 87, 88. C. and yif
  (<i>wrongly</i>); A. Ed. and that. 91-93. A. <i>om.</i> And thou ... is it-self <i>here, but
  inserts the same in a wrong place</i> (131 <i>below</i>). 99. A. <i>om. 2nd</i> the. 100. A. Ed.
  that; C. <i>om.</i> // Ed. thing; C. A. <i>om.</i> 103. C. after; A. afer; Ed. a-ferre. 105. C.
  body, <i>glossed</i> orbis; A. body, <i>glossed</i> orbi (Lat. <i>orbi</i>). 109. A. fro
  with-outen furthe. 111. C. comprehendeth, <i>vel iudicat</i>. 111, 2. A. <i>om.</i> comprehendeth
  ... imaginacioun. 113. C. Ed. by; A. by an. // C. A. (<i>gloss</i>) speciem. 120, 121. A.
  <i>om.</i> but the ... strengthe. // A. Ed. For; C. <i>om.</i> 124. A. Ed. it; C. <i>om.</i> // A.
  but the. // A. Ed. that; C. <i>om.</i> 126. C. she; <i>glossed</i> intelligence. // C. Ed. in; A.
  vndir. 131. <i>Here</i> A. <i>wrongly inserts a clause omitted above</i> (91-93). 136. A.
  <i>om.</i> it. // A. comprendith. 139. A. <i>om.</i> is. 140. A. <i>om.</i> a thing. 142. A.
  <i>om.</i> a. 147. A. Sest thou. 148. A. of faculte or of power. 149. A. Ed. no (<i>for</i> nat).
  150. A. or the. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Metre IV.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quondam porticus attulit.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p><a href="#BVMIVNL1" id="BVMIVL1" class="pginternal">The Porche</a>, <i>that is to seyn, a gate of the town of
    Athenes ther-as</i></p>
<p><i>philosophres hadden hir congregacioun to desputen</i>, thilke Porche</p>
<p>broughte som-tyme olde men, ful derke in hir sentences, <i>that is to</i></p>
<p><i>seyn, philosophres that highten Stoiciens</i>, that wenden that images</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and sensibilitees, <i>that is to seyn, sensible imaginaciouns, or elles</i></p>
<p><i>imaginaciouns of sensible thinges</i>, weren empreinted in-to sowles</p>
<p>fro bodies withoute-forth; <i>as who seith, that thilke Stoiciens wenden</i></p>
<p><i>that the sowle hadde ben naked of it-self, as a mirour or a clene</i></p>
<p><i>parchemin, so that alle figures mosten first comen fro thinges fro</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>withoute-forth in-to sowles, and ben empreinted in-to sowles</i>: <a href="#BVMIVNL10" id="BVMIVL10" class="pginternal"><b>Text</b></a>:</p>
<p>right as we ben wont som-tyme, by a swifte <a href="#BVMIVNL11" id="BVMIVL11" class="pginternal">pointel</a>, to
    ficchen</p>
<p>lettres empreinted in the smothenesse or in the pleinnesse of the</p>
<p>table of wex <i>or in parchemin</i> that ne hath no figure ne note in it.</p>
<p><b>Glose.</b> <i>But now argueth Boece ayeins that opinioun, and seith</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>thus</i>: <a href="#BVMIVNL15" id="BVMIVL15" class="pginternal">But yif</a> the thryvinge sowle
    ne unpleyteth no-thing, <i>that is</i></p>
<p><i>to seyn, ne doth no-thing</i>, by his propre moevinges, but suffreth and</p>
<p>lyth subgit to tho figures and to tho notes of bodies withoute-forth,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page142">{142}</span>and yildeth images ydel and veyn in the manere
    of a mirour,</p>
<p>whennes thryveth thanne or whennes comth thilke knowinge in</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">our sowle, that discerneth and biholdeth alle thinges? And</p>
<p>whennes is thilke strengthe that biholdeth the singuler thinges;</p>
<p>or whennes is the strengthe that devydeth thinges y-knowe; and</p>
<p>thilke strengthe that gadereth to-gidere the thinges devyded; and</p>
<p>the strengthe that cheseth his entrechaunged wey? For som-tyme</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">it heveth up the heved, <i>that is to seyn, that it heveth up the
    entencioun</i></p>
<p><i>to right heye thinges</i>; and som-tyme it descendeth in-to</p>
<p>right lowe thinges. And whan it retorneth in-to him-self, it reproeveth</p>
<p>and destroyeth the false thinges by the trewe thinges.</p>
<p>Certes, this strengthe is cause more efficient, and mochel</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">more mighty <i>to seen and to knowe thinges</i>, than thilke cause that</p>
<p>suffreth and receiveth the notes and the figures impressed in</p>
<p>maner of matere. Algates the <a href="#BVMIVNL32" id="BVMIVL32" class="pginternal">passioun</a>, <i>that is to
    seyn, the</i></p>
<p><i>suffraunce or the wit</i>, in the quike body, goth biforn, excitinge and</p>
<p>moevinge the strengthes of the thought. Right so as whan that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">cleernesse smyteth the eyen <i>and moeveth hem to seen</i>, or right so</p>
<p>as vois or soun hurteleth to the eres <i>and commoeveth hem to</i></p>
<p><i>herkne</i>, than is the strengthe of the thought y-moeved and</p>
<p>excited, and clepeth forth, to semblable moevinges, the speces</p>
<p>that it halt with-inne it-self; and addeth tho speces to the notes</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and to the thinges withoute-forth, and medleth the images of</p>
<p>thinges withoute-forth to tho formes y-hidde with-inne him-self.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me. IV.</span> 3. C. dirke; A. Ed. derke. 5. A. <i>om.</i> and. 9.
  A. <i>om.</i> first. 10. A. inp<i>re</i>ntid; C. apreyntyd (<i>but</i> emprientyd <i>just below,
  and</i> enpreynted <i>above</i>). 12. A. emp<i>re</i>ntid. 13. A. <i>om. 2nd.</i> ne. 14. A. Ed.
  that; C. the. 15. A. vnplitith. 17. A. subgit; Ed. subiecte; C. <i>om.</i> // A. the (<i>for</i>
  tho); <i>twice</i>. 20. A. Ed. discernith; C. decerneth. 26. C. heye thinges, <i>i.
  principijs</i>. // C. dessendith; A. discendith. 27. C. lowe thynges, s. conclu<i>sion</i>es. //
  A. rep<i>re</i>uith. 29. C. strengthe, <i>s. anima</i>. 31. C. resseyuyth; A. resceyueth; Ed.
  receyueth. // C. A. inpressed; Ed. impressed. 36. A. hurtlith. 38. C. Ed. to; A. the (Lat.
  <i>Ad</i>). 40. A. medeleth. 41. A. to the forme. </p>
<h3> <span class="sc">Prose V.</span></h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quod si in corporibus sentiendis.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p><a href="#BVPVNL1" id="BVPVL1" class="pginternal">But what yif</a> that in bodies to ben feled, <i>that is to
    seyn, in the</i></p>
<p><i>takinge of knowelechinge of bodily thinges</i>, and al-be-it so that the</p>
<p>qualitees of bodies, that ben obiecte fro withoute-forth, moeven</p>
<p>and <a href="#BVPVNL4" id="BVPVL4" class="pginternal">entalenten</a> the instruments of the wittes; and al-be-it
    so that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the passioun of the body, <i>that is to seyn, the wit or the
    suffraunce</i>,</p>
<p>goth to-forn the strengthe of the workinge corage, the which</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page143">{143}</span>passioun or suffraunce clepeth forth the dede
    of the thoght in him-self,</p>
<p>and moeveth and exciteth in this mene whyle the formes that</p>
<p>resten withinne-forth; and yif that, in sensible bodies, as I have</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">seyd, our corage nis nat y-taught or empreinted by passioun <i>to</i></p>
<p><i>knowe thise thinges</i>, but demeth and knoweth, of his owne strengthe,</p>
<p>the passioun or suffraunce subiect to the body: moche more</p>
<p>thanne tho thinges that ben absolut and quite fro alle talents</p>
<p>or affecciouns of bodies, <i>as god or his aungeles</i>, ne folwen nat in</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">discerninge thinges obiect fro withoute-forth, but they accomplisshen</p>
<p>and speden the dede of hir thoght. By this resoun</p>
<p>thanne ther comen many maner knowinges to dyverse and</p>
<p>differinge substaunces. <a href="#BVPVNL18" id="BVPVL18" class="pginternal">For the wit</a> of the body, the
    whiche</p>
<p>wit is naked and despoiled of alle other knowinges, thilke wit</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">comth to beestes that ne mowen nat moeven hem-self her and</p>
<p>ther, as <i><a href="#BVPVNL21" id="BVPVL21" class="pginternal">oystres</a> and muscules, and other swiche</i>
    shelle-fish of the</p>
<p>see, that clyven and ben norisshed to roches. But the imaginacioun</p>
<p>comth to <a href="#BVPVNL23" id="BVPVL23" class="pginternal">remuable</a> beestes, that semen to han <a href="#BVPVNL23" class="pginternal">talent</a> to</p>
<p>fleen or to desiren any thing. But resoun is al-only to the linage</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of mankinde, right as intelligence is only [to] the devyne nature:</p>
<p>of which it folweth, that thilke knowinge is more worth than thise</p>
<p>othre, sin it knoweth by his propre nature nat only his subiect, <i>as</i></p>
<p><i>who seith, it ne knoweth nat al-only that apertieneth properly to his</i></p>
<p><i>knowinge</i>, but it knoweth the subiects of alle other knowinges.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BVPVNL30" id="BVPVL30" class="pginternal">But how shal it thanne be, yif that</a> wit
    and imaginacioun stryven</p>
<p>ayein resoninge, and seyn, that of thilke universel thing that</p>
<p>resoun weneth to seen, that it nis right naught? <i>For wit and</i></p>
<p><i>imaginacioun seyn <a href="#BVPVNL33" id="BVPVL33" class="pginternal">that</a></i> <a href="#BVPVNL33" class="pginternal">that,
    that</a> is sensible or imaginable, it ne</p>
<p>may nat be universel. Thanne is either the Iugement of resoun</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">sooth, <a href="#BVPVNL35" id="BVPVL35" class="pginternal">ne that ther nis</a> nothing sensible;
    or elles, for that resoun</p>
<p>wot wel that many thinges ben subiect to wit and to imaginacioun,</p>
<p>thanne is the concepcioun of resoun veyn and false, which that</p>
<p>loketh and comprehendeth that that is sensible and singuler as</p>
<p>universel. And yif that resoun wolde answeren ayein to thise</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">two, <i>that is to seyn, to witte and to imaginacioun</i>, and seyn, that</p>
<p>soothly she hir-self, <i>that is to seyn, resoun</i>, loketh and comprehendeth,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page144">{144}</span>by resoun of universalitee, bothe that that is
    sensible</p>
<p>and that that is imaginable; and that thilke two, <i>that is to seyn,</i></p>
<p><i>wit and imaginacioun</i>, ne mowen nat strecchen ne enhansen hem-self</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to the knowinge of universalitee, for that the knowinge of</p>
<p>hem ne may exceden ne surmounte the bodily figures: certes, of</p>
<p>the knowinge of thinges, men oughten rather yeven credence to</p>
<p>the more stedefast and to the more parfit Iugement. In this</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVNL49" id="BVPVL49" class="pginternal">maner stryvinge</a> thanne, we that han strengthe of
    resoninge and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of imagininge and of wit, <i>that is to seyn, by resoun and by
    imaginacioun</i></p>
<p><i>and by wit</i>, we sholde rather preyse the cause of resoun; <i>as</i></p>
<p><i>who seith, than the cause of wit and of imaginacioun</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza">Semblable thing is it, that the resoun of mankinde ne weneth</p>
<p>nat that the devyne intelligence bi-holdeth or knoweth thinges to</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">comen, but right as the resoun of mankinde knoweth hem. For</p>
<p>thou arguest and seyst thus: that yif it ne seme nat to men that</p>
<p>some thinges han certein and necessarie bitydinges, they ne</p>
<p>mowen nat ben wist biforn certeinly to bityden. And thanne</p>
<p>nis ther no prescience of thilke thinges; and yif we trowe that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">prescience be in thise thinges, thanne is ther no-thing that it ne</p>
<p>bitydeth by necessitee. But certes, yif we mighten han the Iugement</p>
<p>of the devyne thoght, as we ben <a href="#BVPVNL62" id="BVPVL62" class="pginternal">parsoneres</a> of resoun,
    right</p>
<p>so as we han demed that it behoveth that imaginacioun and wit</p>
<p>be binethe resoun, right so wolde we demen that it were rightful</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thing, that mannes resoun oughte to submitten it-self and to ben</p>
<p>binethe the divyne thoght. <a href="#BVPVNL66" id="BVPVL66" class="pginternal">For which</a>, yif that we mowen,
    <i>as</i></p>
<p><i>who seith, that, yif that we mowen, I counseyle, that</i> we enhanse us</p>
<p>in-to the heighte of thilke sovereyn intelligence; for ther shal</p>
<p>resoun wel seen that, that it ne may nat biholden in it-self. And</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">certes that is this, in what maner the prescience of god seeth alle</p>
<p>thinges certeins and diffinisshed, al-thogh they ne han no certein</p>
<p>issues or bitydinges; ne this is non opinioun, but it is rather the</p>
<p>simplicitee of the sovereyn science, that nis nat enclosed nor</p>
<p>y-shet within none boundes.</p>
</div>
<p><span class="sc">Pr. V.</span> 1. A. <i>om.</i> yif (Lat. <i>Quod si</i>). 5. C. A. witte; Ed.
  wytte. // A. <i>om.</i> or the. 6, 7. A. <i>om.</i> goth ... suffraunce. 10. A. enp<i>re</i>ntid;
  C. emprienpted. 20, 1. A. here ne there. // A. muscles. 25. <i>I supply</i> to. 26, 7. C. thise
  oothr<i>e</i>; A. is other. 29. A. subgitz. 31. Ed. vnyuersal thynge; A. vniuersel thinges; C.
  vniuersels thinges (Lat. <i>uniuersale</i>). 35. C. soth; Ed. sothe; A. <i>om.</i> // C. sensible,
  <i>quod absurdum est</i>. 41. C. seyn; A. seyn that. 44. C. enhansen; A. enhaunsen. 45. Ed. the
  knowing; A. knowynge; C. knowy (Lat. <i>cognitionem</i>). 46. A. figure. 48. C. stidefast; A.
  stedfast. 51. C. and we; A. Ed. <i>om.</i> and. 52. C. Ed. and of; A. or. 56. A. Ed. ne; C.
  <i>om.</i> 58. A. <i>om.</i> And. 59. A. <i>om.</i> ther. 61. C. bideth (!). 62. C. parsoneres; A.
  parsoners; Ed. parteners. 63. A. <i>om. 1st</i> that. 65. A. su<i>m</i>mitten. 66. C. yif that;
  Ed. if; A. that yif. 71. C. diffinysshed; A. difinissed. 72. A. Ed. is; C. nis. </p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page145">{145}</span></div>
<h3><span class="sc">Metre</span> V.</h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quam uariis terris animalia permeant figuris.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>The beestes <a href="#BVMVNL1" id="BVMVL1" class="pginternal">passen by</a> the erthes by ful diverse figures.
    For</p>
<p>som of hem han hir bodies straught and crepen in the dust, and</p>
<p>drawen after hem a tras or a foruh y-continued; <i>that is to seyn, as</i></p>
<p><i>nadres or snakes</i>. And other beestes, by the wandringe lightnesse</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of hir winges, beten the windes, and over-swimmen the spaces of</p>
<p>the longe eyr by <a href="#BVMVNL6" id="BVMVL6" class="pginternal">moist fleeinge</a>. And other beestes <a href="#BVMVNL6" class="pginternal">gladen hem-self</a></p>
<p>to diggen hir tras or hir steppes in the erthe <a href="#BVMVNL7" id="BVMVL7" class="pginternal">with hir
    goings</a></p>
<p>or with hir feet, and to goon either by the grene feldes, or elles to</p>
<p><a href="#BVMVNL9" id="BVMVL9" class="pginternal">walken under</a> the wodes. And al-be-it so that thou seest
    that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">they alle discorden by diverse formes, algates hir faces, <a href="#BVMVNL10" id="BVMVL10" class="pginternal">enclined</a>,</p>
<p><a href="#BVMVNL11" id="BVMVL11" class="pginternal">hevieth</a> hir dulle wittes. Only the linage of man heveth
    heyeste</p>
<p>his heye heved, and stondeth <a href="#BVMVNL12" id="BVMVL12" class="pginternal">light</a> with his up-right
    body, and</p>
<p>biholdeth the erthes under him. And, but-yif thou, erthely man,</p>
<p>wexest yvel out of thy wit, this figure amonesteth thee, that <a href="#BVMVNL14" id="BVMVL14" class="pginternal">axest</a></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the hevene with thy righte visage, and hast areysed thy fore-heved,</p>
<p>to beren up a-heigh thy corage; so that thy thoght ne be nat</p>
<p>y-hevied ne put lowe under fote, sin that thy body is so heye</p>
<p>areysed.</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3"><span class="sc">Me.</span> V. 3. C. traas; A. t<i>ra</i>is; Ed. trace. // C.
  forwh; A. forghe; Ed. forough. // A. Ed. continued. 4. A. addres; Ed. nedders. // A. <i>om.</i>
  the. 7. C. A. traas. // A. goynge (Lat. <i>gressibus</i>). 8. C. feeldes. // A. <i>om.</i> elles.
  10. A. <i>om.</i> faces. // A. enclini[n]g. 13. A. erthe (Lat. <i>terras</i>). // A. <i>om.</i>
  And. 16. A. on heye. </p>
<h3><span class="sc">Prose</span> VI.</h3>
<p class="ac"><i>Quoniam igitur, uti paullo ante.</i></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>Therfor thanne, as I have shewed a litel her-biforn, that al</p>
<p>thing that is y-wist nis nat knowen by his nature propre, but by</p>
<p>the nature of hem that comprehenden it, lat us loke now, in as</p>
<p>mochel as it is leveful to us, <i>as who seith, lat us loke now as we</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>mowen</i>, which that the estat is of the devyne substaunce; so that</p>
<p>we mowen eek knowen what his science is. The commune Iugement</p>
<p>of alle creatures resonables thanne is this: that god is eterne.</p>
<p>Lat us considere thanne what is eternitee; for certes that shal</p>
<p>shewen us to-gidere the devyne nature and the devyne science.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">10</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">Eternitee, thanne, is parfit possessioun and al-togidere of lyf</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page146">{146}</span>interminable; and that sheweth more cleerly by
    the comparisoun</p>
<p>or the collacioun of temporel thinges. For al thing that liveth in</p>
<p>tyme it is present, and procedeth fro preterits in-to futures, <i>that is</i></p>
<p><i>to seyn, fro tyme passed in-to tyme cominge</i>; ne ther nis no-thing</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">15</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">establisshed in tyme that may enbracen to-gider al the space of</p>
<p>his lyf. For certes, yit ne hath it taken the tyme of to-morwe, and</p>
<p>it hath lost the tyme of yisterday. And certes, in the lyf of this</p>
<p>day, ye ne liven no more but right as in the moevable and</p>
<p>transitorie moment. Thanne thilke thing that suffreth temporel</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">condicioun, al-thogh that it never bigan to be, ne thogh it never</p>
<p>cese for to be, <a href="#BVPVINL21" id="BVPVIL21" class="pginternal">as Aristotle demed</a> of the world, and
    al-thogh that</p>
<p>the lyf of it be strecched with infinitee of tyme, yit algates nis</p>
<p>it no swich thing that men mighten trowen by right that it is</p>
<p>eterne. For al-thogh that it comprehende and embrace the space</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">of lyf infinit, yit algates ne embraceth it nat the space of the lyf</p>
<p>al-togider; for it ne hath nat the futures that ne ben nat yit, <i>ne it</i></p>
<p><i>ne hath no lenger the preterits that ben y-doon or y-passed</i>. But</p>
<p>thilke thing thanne, that hath and comprehendeth to-gider al the</p>
<p>plentee of the lyf interminable, to whom ther ne faileth naught of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the future, and to whom ther nis naught of the preterit escaped</p>
<p>nor y-passed, thilke same is y-witnessed and y-proeved by right to</p>
<p>be eterne. And it bihoveth by necessitee that thilke thing be</p>
<p>al-wey <a href="#BVPVINL33" id="BVPVIL33" class="pginternal">present</a> to him-self, and compotent; <i>as who
    seith, al-wey</i></p>
<p><i>present to him-self, and so mighty that al be right at his plesaunce</i>;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and that he have al present the infinitee of the moevable tyme.</p>
<p>Wher-for som men trowen wrongfully that, whan they heren that</p>
<p>it semede to Plato that this world ne hadde never beginninge</p>
<p>of tyme, ne that it never shal han failinge, they wenen in this</p>
<p>maner that this world be maked coeterne with his maker; <i>as who</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>seith, they wene that this world and god ben maked togider eterne,</i></p>
<p><i>and that is a wrongful weninge</i>. For other thing is it to ben y-lad</p>
<p>by lyf interminable, as <a href="#BVPVINL42" id="BVPVIL42" class="pginternal">Plato</a> graunted to the world,
    and other</p>
<p>thing is it to embrace to-gider al the present of the lyf interminable,</p>
<p>the whiche thing it is cleer and manifest that it is propre to the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">devyne thoght.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page147">{147}</span>Ne it ne sholde nat semen to
    us, that god is elder thanne</p>
<p>thinges that ben y-maked by quantitee of tyme, but rather by</p>
