<p>the propretee of his simple nature. <a href="#BVPVINL48" id="BVPVIL48" class="pginternal">For this ilke</a>
    infinit moevinge</p>
<p>of temporel thinges folweth this presentarie estat of lyf unmoevable;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and so as it ne may nat countrefeten it ne feynen it ne be evenlyke</p>
<p>to it for the inmoevabletee, <i>that is to seyn, that is in the</i></p>
<p><i>eternitee of god</i>, it faileth and falleth in-to moevinge fro the simplicitee</p>
<p>of the presence <i>of god</i>, and <a href="#BVPVINL53" id="BVPVIL53" class="pginternal">disencreseth</a> in-to
    the infinit</p>
<p>quantitee of future and of preterit: and so as it ne may nat han</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to-gider al the plentee of the lyf, algates yit, for as moche as it</p>
<p>ne ceseth never for to ben in som maner, it semeth som-del to us,</p>
<p>that it folweth and resembleth thilke thing that it ne may nat</p>
<p>atayne to ne fulfillen, and bindeth it-self to som maner presence</p>
<p>of this litel and swifte moment: the which <i>presence of this litel</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>and swifte moment</i>, for that it bereth a maner image or lyknesse</p>
<p>of the ay-dwellinge presence <i>of god</i>, it graunteth, to swiche maner</p>
<p>thinges as it bitydeth to, that it semeth hem as thise thinges <i>han</i></p>
<p><i>y-ben, and</i> ben.</p>
<p class="stanza">And, for that <i>the presence of swich litel moment</i> ne may nat</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">dwelle, <a href="#BVPVINL65" id="BVPVIL65" class="pginternal">ther-for it</a> ravisshed and took
    the infinit wey of tyme, <i>that</i></p>
<p><i>is to seyn, by successioun</i>; and by this maner is it y-doon, for that</p>
<p>it sholde continue the lyf in goinge, of the whiche lyf it ne mighte</p>
<p>nat enbrace the plentee in dwellinge. And for-thy, yif we wollen</p>
<p>putten worthy names to thinges, and folwen Plato, lat us seye</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thanne soothly, that god is eterne, and the world is perpetuel.</p>
<p>Thanne, sin that every Iugement knoweth and comprehendeth by</p>
<p>his owne nature thinges that ben subiect un-to him, ther is soothly</p>
<p>to god, al-weys, an eterne and presentarie estat; and the science</p>
<p>of him, that over-passeth al temporel moevement, dwelleth in the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">simplicitee of his presence, and embraceth and considereth alle</p>
<p>the infinit spaces of tymes, preterits and futures, and loketh, in</p>
<p>his simple knowinge, alle thinges <i>of preterit</i> right as they weren</p>
<p>y-doon presently right now. Yif thou wolt thanne thenken and</p>
<p>avyse the prescience, by which it knoweth alle thinges, thou ne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">shal nat demen it as prescience of thinges to comen, but thou</p>
<p>shalt demen it more rightfully that <a href="#BVPVINL81" id="BVPVIL81" class="pginternal">it is science</a> of
    presence or of</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page148">{148}</span>instaunce, that never ne faileth. <a href="#BVPVINL82" id="BVPVIL82" class="pginternal">For which</a> it nis nat y-cleped</p>
<p>"previdence," but it sholde rather ben cleped "purviaunce," that</p>
<p>is establisshed ful fer fro right lowe thinges, and biholdeth from</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">85</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">a-fer alle thinges, right as it were fro the heye heighte of thinges.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#BVPVINL86" id="BVPVIL86" class="pginternal">Why axestow thanne</a>, or why desputestow
    thanne, that thilke</p>
<p>thinges ben doon by necessitee whiche that ben y-seyn and</p>
<p>knowen by the devyne sighte, sin that, forsothe, men ne maken</p>
<p>nat thilke thinges necessarie which that they seen ben y-doon in</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">hir sighte? For addeth thy biholdinge any necessitee to thilke</p>
<p>thinges that thou biholdest presente?'</p>
<p class="stanza">'Nay,' quod I.</p>
<p class="stanza"><i>Philosophie.</i> 'Certes, thanne, if men mighte maken any digne</p>
<p>comparisoun or collacioun of the presence devyne and of the</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">presence of mankinde, right so as ye seen some thinges in this</p>
<p>temporel present, right so seeth god alle thinges by his eterne</p>
<p>present. Wher-fore this devyne prescience ne chaungeth nat the</p>
<p>nature ne the propretee of thinges, but biholdeth swiche thinges</p>
<p>present to him-ward as they shullen bityde to yow-ward in tyme</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">to comen. Ne it confoundeth nat the Iugement of thinges; but</p>
<p>by o sighte of his thought, he knoweth the thinges to comen, as</p>
<p>wel necessarie as nat necessarie. Right so as whan ye seen</p>
<p>to-gider a man walken on the erthe and the sonne arysen in</p>
<p>the hevene, al-be-it so that ye seen and biholden that oon and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that other to-gider, yit natheles ye demen and discernen that that</p>
<p>oon is voluntarie and that other necessarie. Right so thanne the</p>
<p>devyne lookinge, biholdinge alle thinges under him, ne troubleth</p>
<p>nat the qualitee of thinges that ben certeinly present to him-ward;</p>
<p>but, as to the condicioun of tyme, forsothe, they ben future. For</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">which it folweth, that this nis noon opinioun, but rather a stedefast</p>
<p>knowinge, y-strengthed by soothnesse, that, whanne that god</p>
<p>knoweth anything to be, <a href="#BVPVINL112" id="BVPVIL112" class="pginternal">he ne unwot</a> nat that thilke
    thing wanteth</p>
<p>necessitee to be; <i>this is to seyn, that, whan that god knoweth any</i></p>
<p><i>thing to bityde, he wot wel that it ne hath no necessitee to bityde.</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">115</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">And yif thou seyst heer, that thilke thing that god seeth to</p>
<p>bityde, <a href="#BVPVINL116" id="BVPVIL116" class="pginternal">it ne may nat unbityde</a> (<i>as who seith, it
    mot bityde</i>), and</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page149">{149}</span>thilke thing that ne may nat unbityde it mot
    bityde by necessitee,</p>
<p>and that thou streyne me by this name of necessitee: certes,</p>
<p>I wol wel confessen and biknowe a thing of ful sad trouthe, but</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">120</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BVPVINL119" id="BVPVIL119" class="pginternal">unnethe</a> shal ther any wight mowe
    <i>seen it or</i> come ther-to, but-yif</p>
<p>that he be biholder of the devyne thoght. For I wol answeren</p>
<p>thee thus: that thilke thing that is future, whan it is referred</p>
<p>to the devyne knowinge, thanne is it necessarie; but certes, whan it</p>
<p>is understonden in his owne kinde, men seen it is outrely free,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">and absolut <i>fro alle necessitee</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza">For certes, ther ben two maneres of necessitee. That oon</p>
<p>necessitee is simple, as thus: that it bihoveth by necessitee, that</p>
<p>alle men be mortal <i>or deedly</i>. Another necessitee is conditionel,</p>
<p>as thus: yif thou wost that a man walketh, it bihoveth by necessitee</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that he walke. Thilke thing thanne that any wight hath y-knowe</p>
<p>to be, it ne may ben non other weyes thanne he knoweth it to be.</p>
<p>But this condicioun ne draweth nat with hir thilke necessitee</p>
<p>simple. For certes, this necessitee <i>conditionel</i>, the propre nature</p>
<p>of it ne maketh it nat, but the adieccioun of the condicioun</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">135</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>maketh it</i>. For no necessitee ne constreyneth a man to gon,</p>
<p>that goth by his propre wil; al-be-it so that, whan he goth,</p>
<p>that it is necessarie that he goth. Right on this same maner</p>
<p>thanne, yif that the purviaunce of god seeth any thing present,</p>
<p>than mot thilke thing ben by necessitee, al-thogh that it ne have</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">no necessitee of his owne nature. But certes, the futures that</p>
<p>bityden by freedom of arbitre, god seeth hem alle to-gider present.</p>
<p>Thise thinges thanne, yif they ben referred to the devyne sighte,</p>
<p>thanne ben they maked necessarie by the condicioun of the</p>
<p>devyne knowinge. But certes, yif thilke thinges be considered</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">145</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">by hem-self, they ben absolut <i>of necessitee</i>, and ne forleten nat ne</p>
<p>cesen nat of the libertee of hir owne nature. Thanne, certes,</p>
<p>with-oute doute, alle the thinges shollen ben doon which that</p>
<p>god wot biforn that they ben to comen. But som of hem comen</p>
<p>and bityden of free arbitre <i>or of free wille</i>, that, al-be-it so that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">150</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">they bityden, yit algates ne lese they nat hir propre nature in</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVINL150" id="BVPVIL150" class="pginternal">beinge</a>; <a href="#BVPVINL151" id="BVPVIL151" class="pginternal">by the
    which</a> first, or that they weren y-doon, they</p>
<p>hadden power nat to han bitid.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><i>Boece</i>. 'What is this to seyn thanne,' quod I, 'that thinges ne</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page150">{150}</span>ben nat necessarie <i>by hir propre
    nature</i>, <a href="#BVPVINL154" id="BVPVIL154" class="pginternal">so as they comen</a> in alle</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">155</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">maneres in the lyknesse of necessitee by the condicioun of the</p>
<p>devyne science?'</p>
<p class="stanza"><i>Philosophie.</i> 'This is the difference,' quod she; 'that tho</p>
<p>thinges that I purposede thee a litel heer-biforn, that is to seyn,</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVINL159" id="BVPVIL159" class="pginternal">the sonne arysinge</a> and the man walkinge, that,
    ther-whyles that</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">160</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thilke thinges been y-doon, they ne mighte nat ben undoon;</p>
<p>natheles, that oon of hem, or it was y-doon, it bihoved by necessitee</p>
<p>that it was y-doon, but nat that other. Right so <i>is it</i></p>
<p><i>here</i>, that the thinges that god hath present, with-oute doute they</p>
<p>shollen been. But som of hem descendeth of the nature of</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">165</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">thinges, <i>as the sonne arysinge</i>; and som descendeth of the power</p>
<p>of the doeres, <i>as the man walkinge</i>. Thanne seide I no wrong,</p>
<p>that yif these thinges ben referred to the devyne knowinge, thanne</p>
<p>ben they necessarie; and yif they ben considered by hem-self,</p>
<p>thanne ben they absolut fro the bond of necessitee. Right so as</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">170</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">alle thinges that apereth or sheweth to the wittes, yif thou referre</p>
<p>it to resoun, it is universel; and yif thou referre it or loke it</p>
<p>to it-self, than is it singuler. But now, yif thou seyst thus, that</p>
<p>yif it be in my power to chaunge my purpos, than shal I voide the</p>
<p>purviaunce <i>of god</i>, whan that, peraventure, I shal han chaunged</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">175</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">the thinges that he knoweth biforn, thanne shal I answere thee</p>
<p>thus. Certes, thou mayst wel chaunge thy purpos; but, for as</p>
<p>mochel as the present soothnesse of the devyne purviaunce biholdeth</p>
<p>that thou mayst chaunge thy purpos, and whether thou</p>
<p>wolt chaunge it or no, and whiderward that thou torne it, thou ne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">180</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">mayst nat eschuen the devyne prescience; right as thou ne mayst</p>
<p>nat fleen the sighte of the presente eye, al-though that thou torne</p>
<p>thy-self by thy free wil in-to dyverse acciouns. But thou mayst</p>
<p>seyn ayein: "How shal it thanne be? Shal nat the devyne</p>
<p>science be chaunged by my disposicioun, whan that I wol o thing</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">185</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">now, and now another? <a href="#BVPVINL185" id="BVPVIL185" class="pginternal">And thilke</a>
    prescience, ne semeth it nat</p>
<p>to entrechaunge stoundes of knowinge;"' <i>as who seith, ne shal it</i></p>
<p><i>nat seme to us, that the devyne prescience entrechaungeth hise dyverse</i></p>
<p><i>stoundes of knowinge, so that it knowe sum-tyme o thing and sum-tyme</i></p>
<p><i>the contrarie of that thing?</i></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">190</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page151">{151}</span>'No, forsothe,' <i>quod
    I</i>.</p>
<p class="stanza"><i>Philosophie.</i> '<a href="#BVPVINL191" id="BVPVIL191" class="pginternal">For the devyne</a>
    sighte renneth to-forn and seeth alle</p>
<p>futures, and clepeth hem ayein, and retorneth hem to the presence</p>
<p>of his propre knowinge; <a href="#BVPVINL193" id="BVPVIL193" class="pginternal">ne he ne</a> entrechaungeth nat,
    so as thou</p>
<p>wenest, the stoundes of forknowinge, as now this, now that; but</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">195</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">he ay-dwellinge comth biforn, and embraceth at o strook alle thy</p>
<p>mutaciouns. And this presence to comprehenden and to seen</p>
<p>alle thinges, god ne hath nat taken it of the bitydinge of thinges</p>
<p>to come, but of his propre simplicitee. And her-by is assoiled</p>
<p>thilke thing that thou puttest <a href="#BVPVINL199" id="BVPVIL199" class="pginternal">a litel her-biforn</a>,
    <i>that is to seyn</i>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">200</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">that it is unworthy thing to seyn, that our futures yeven cause of</p>
<p>the science of god. For certes, this strengthe of the devyne</p>
<p>science, which that embraceth alle thinges by his presentarie</p>
<p>knowinge, establissheth maner to alle thinges, and it ne oweth</p>
<p>naught to latter thinges; and sin that these thinges ben thus,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">205</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><i>that is to seyn, sin that necessitee nis nat in thinges by the
    devyne</i></p>
<p><i>prescience</i>, than is ther freedom of arbitre, that dwelleth hool and</p>
<p>unwemmed to mortal men. Ne the lawes ne <a href="#BVPVINL207" id="BVPVIL207" class="pginternal">purposen</a>
    nat</p>
<p>wikkedly medes and peynes <a href="#BVPVINL208" id="BVPVIL208" class="pginternal">to the willinges</a> of men
    that ben</p>
<p>unbounden and quite of alle necessitee. And god, biholder and</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">210</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">for-witer of alle thinges, dwelleth above; and the present eternitee</p>
<p>of his sighte <a href="#BVPVINL211" id="BVPVIL211" class="pginternal">renneth alwey with</a> the dyverse
    qualitee of oure</p>
<p>dedes, despensinge and ordeyninge medes to goode men, and</p>
<p>torments to wikked men. Ne in ydel ne in veyn ne ben ther nat</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVINL214" id="BVPVIL214" class="pginternal">put</a> in god hope and preyeres, <a href="#BVPVINL214" class="pginternal">that ne mowen</a> nat ben unspeedful</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">215</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">ne with-oute effect, whan they ben rightful.</p>
<p class="stanza">Withstond thanne and eschue thou vyces; worshipe and love</p>
<p>thou virtues; <a href="#BVPVINL217" id="BVPVIL217" class="pginternal">areys thy corage</a> to rightful hopes; <a href="#BVPVINL217" class="pginternal">yilde</a> thou</p>
<p>humble preyeres a-heigh. Gret necessitee of prowesse and vertu</p>
<p>is encharged and commaunded to yow, yif ye nil nat dissimulen;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">220</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#BVPVINL220" id="BVPVIL220" class="pginternal">sin that ye</a> worken and doon, <i>that
    is to seyn, your dedes or your</i></p>
<p><i>workes</i>, biforn the eyen of the Iuge that seeth <i>and demeth</i> alle</p>
<p>thinges.' <i><a href="#BVPVINL220" class="pginternal">To whom be glorye</a> and worshipe by infinit tymes</i>.
    <span class="sc">Amen.</span></p>
</div>
<p class="sp5"><span class="sc">Pr.</span> VI. 1, 2. C. alle thinges; A. Ed. al thing (Lat.
  <i>omne</i>). 6. A. <i>om.</i> eek. 12. A. <i>om.</i> the. // C. alle; A. al. 16. A. the morwe.
  17. A. that (<i>for</i> the tyme). 18. A. this (<i>for</i> the). 20. A. <i>om.</i> it. 22. C.
  strechched. 25. A. braceth. 30. C. preterite; A. preterit. 31. C. I-witnesshed; A. ywitnessed. //
  C. and; A. or. 34. A. plesaunce; C. pleasaunce. 35. A. infinit. 41. A. it (<i>for</i> that). 43.
  A. embracen. 49. A. of the lijf. 53. A. <i>om.</i> the. // C. in-to; A. to. 58. A. presence; C.
  presensse. 64. A. <i>om.</i> that. 65. A. <i>om.</i> it. // C. Infynyte; A. infinit. 73. A. alwey
  to god. 78. C. thinken; A. thenke. 81. A. <i>om.</i> it. 83. A. prouidence; C. puruydence
  (<i>glossed</i> p<i>r</i>ouidentia); <i>but see note</i>. 86. A. disputest thou. 88. A. yknowen.
  101. C. o; Ed. one; A. of (!); Lat. <i>unoque</i>. 104. A. <i>om.</i> the. 106. A. <i>om.</i> the.
  110. C. stidefast; A. stedfast. 116. A. bitide; C. bide (<i>miswritten</i>; <i>2nd time</i>). 120.
  A. <i>om.</i> mowe. 124. A. <i>om.</i> is. 134. A. nauȝt (<i>for</i> nat). 135, 6. A.
  <i>om.</i> gon that. 141. A. presentz. 142. A. <i>om.</i> yif. 143. C. by; A. to (Lat.
  <i>per</i>). 149. A. <i>om. 1st</i> free. 150. C. in; A. ne (<i>wrongly</i>). 161. A. byhoued; Ed.
  behoueth; C. houyd (!). 169. A. <i>om.</i> as. 170. Ed. apereth; C. apiereth; A. appiereth. 178.
  C. wheyther; A. whethir. 179. A. <i>om.</i> ne. 186. A. knowynges (Lat. <i>noscendi</i>). 189. Ed.
  of that thing; C. A. <i>om.</i> 190. Ed. quod she (<i>for</i> quod I; <i>wrongly</i>). 193. A.
  <i>om.</i> so. 194. A. <i>om.</i> as. 203. A. awith nat. 205, 6. C. <i>om.</i> that is ...
  prescience; Ed. <i>and</i> A. <i>have it</i>. 213. C. torment; A. tourmentz (<i>supplicia</i>).
  214. A. nat; Ed. not; C. ne. 216. C. withston (<i>sic</i>). 218. A. an heyȝe. 222. C. To
  whom be goye (<i>sic</i>) and worshipe bi Infynyt tymes. <span class="smaller">AMEN</span>;
  <i>which</i> A. Ed. (<i>perhaps rightly</i>) <i>omit</i>. </p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page153">{153}</span></div>
<h1 class="ac" style="margin-bottom:4.7ex;"> <span class="x-larger">TROILUS AND
  CRISEYDE.</span></h1>
<h2 class="sp3 ac" style="margin-bottom:2.1ex;"> <span class="larger">BOOK I.</span></h2>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>1. The double sorwe of Troilus to tellen,</p>
<p>That was the <a href="#TINL2" id="TIL2" class="pginternal">king Priamus sone of Troye</a>,</p>
<p>In lovinge, how his aventures fellen</p>
<p>Fro wo to wele, and after out of Ioye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">My purpos is, er that I parte <a href="#TINL5" id="TIL5" class="pginternal">fro ye</a>.</p>
<p><a href="#TINL6" id="TIL6" class="pginternal">Thesiphone</a>, thou help me for tendyte</p>
<p>Thise woful vers, that wepen as I wryte!</p>
<p class="stanza">2. To thee clepe I, thou goddesse of torment,</p>
<p>Thou cruel Furie, sorwing ever in peyne;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Help me, that am the sorwful instrument</p>
<p>That helpeth lovers, as I can, to pleyne!</p>
<p>For wel sit it, the sothe for to seyne,</p>
<p>A woful wight to han a drery <a href="#TINL13" id="TIL13" class="pginternal">fere</a>,</p>
<p>And, to a sorwful tale, a sory chere.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">15</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">3. For I, that god of Loves servaunts serve,</p>
<p><a href="#TINL16" id="TIL16" class="pginternal">Ne dar</a> to Love, for myn unlyklinesse,</p>
<p>Preyen for speed, al sholde I therfor sterve,</p>
<p>So fer am I fro his help in derknesse;</p>
<p>But nathelees, if this may doon gladnesse</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To any lover, and his cause avayle,</p>
<p><a href="#TINL21" id="TIL21" class="pginternal">Have he my thank</a>, and myn be this travayle!</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page154">{154}</span>4. But ye loveres, that bathen
    in gladnesse,</p>
<p>If any drope of pitee in yow be,</p>
<p>Remembreth yow on passed hevinesse</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That ye han felt, and on the adversitee</p>
<p>Of othere folk, and thenketh how that ye</p>
<p>Han felt that Love dorste yow displese;</p>
<p>Or ye han wonne him with to greet an ese.</p>
<p class="stanza">5. And preyeth for hem that ben in the cas</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Of Troilus, as ye may after here,</p>
<p>That love hem bringe in hevene to solas,</p>
<p>And eek for me preyeth to god so dere,</p>
<p>That I have might to shewe, in som manere,</p>
<p>Swich peyne and wo as Loves folk endure,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">In Troilus unsely aventure.</p>
<p class="stanza">6. And biddeth eek for hem that been despeyred</p>
<p>In love, that never nil recovered be,</p>
<p>And eek for hem that falsly been apeyred</p>
<p>Thorugh wikked tonges, be it he or she;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thus biddeth god, for his benignitee,</p>
<p>To graunte hem sone out of this world to pace,</p>
<p>That been despeyred out of Loves grace.</p>
<p class="stanza">7. And biddeth eek for hem that been at ese,</p>
<p>That god hem graunte ay good perseveraunce,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And sende hem might hir ladies so to plese,</p>
<p>That it to Love be worship and plesaunce.</p>
<p>For so hope I my soule best avaunce,</p>
<p>To preye for hem that Loves servaunts be,</p>
<p>And wryte hir wo, and live in charitee.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">50</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">8. And for to have of hem compassioun</p>
<p>As though I were hir owene brother dere.</p>
<p>Now herkeneth with a gode entencioun,</p>
<p>For now wol I gon streight to my matere,</p>
<p>In whiche ye may the double sorwes here</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Of Troilus, in loving of Criseyde,</p>
<p>And how that she forsook him er she deyde.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page155">{155}</span><a href="#TINL57" id="TIL57" class="pginternal">9</a>. It is wel wist, how that the Grekes stronge</p>
<p>In armes with a thousand shippes wente</p>
<p>To Troyewardes, and the citee longe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Assegeden neigh ten yeer er they stente,</p>
<p>And, in diverse wyse and oon entente,</p>
<p>The ravisshing to wreken of Eleyne,</p>
<p>By Paris doon, they wroughten al hir peyne.</p>
<p class="stanza">10. Now fil it so, that in the toun ther was</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Dwellinge a lord of greet auctoritee,</p>
<p>A gret devyn that cleped was Calkas,</p>
<p>That in science so <a href="#TINL67" id="TIL67" class="pginternal">expert</a> was, that he</p>
<p>Knew wel that Troye sholde destroyed be,</p>
<p>By answere of his god, that highte thus,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Daun Phebus or Apollo <a href="#TINL70" id="TIL70" class="pginternal">Delphicus</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza">11. So whan this Calkas knew by calculinge,</p>
<p>And eek by answere of this Appollo,</p>
<p>That Grekes sholden swich a peple bringe,</p>
<p>Thorugh which that Troye moste been for-do,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He caste anoon out of the toun to go;</p>
<p>For wel wiste he, by sort, that Troye sholde</p>
<p>Destroyed been, <a href="#TINL77" id="TIL77" class="pginternal">ye</a>, <a href="#TINL77" class="pginternal">wolde</a> who-so
    nolde.</p>
<p class="stanza">12. For which, for to departen softely</p>
<p>Took purpos ful this forknowinge wyse,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And to the Grekes ost ful prively</p>
<p>He stal anoon; and they, in curteys wyse,</p>
<p>Him deden bothe worship and servyse,</p>
<p>In trust that he hath conning hem to rede</p>
<p>In every peril which that is to drede.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">85</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">13. The noyse up roos, whan it was first aspyed,</p>
<p>Thorugh al the toun, and generally was spoken,</p>
<p>That Calkas traytor fled was, and allyed</p>
<p>With hem of Grece; and casten to ben wroken</p>
<p>On him that falsly hadde his feith so broken;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page156">{156}</span>And seyden, he and al his kin at
    ones</p>
<p><a href="#TINL91" id="TIL91" class="pginternal">Ben worthy for to brennen</a>, fel and bones.</p>
<p class="stanza">14. Now hadde Calkas left, in this meschaunce,</p>
<p>Al unwist of this false and wikked dede,</p>
<p>His doughter, which that was in gret penaunce,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For of hir lyf she was ful sore in drede,</p>
<p>As she that niste what was best to rede;</p>
<p>For bothe a widowe was she, and allone</p>
<p>Of any freend, to whom she dorste hir mone.</p>
<p class="stanza">15. <a href="#TINL99" id="TIL99" class="pginternal">Criseyde</a> was this lady name a-right;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As to my dome, in al Troyes citee</p>
<p>Nas noon so fair, for passing every wight</p>
<p>So aungellyk was hir natyf beautee,</p>
<p>That lyk a thing inmortal semed she,</p>
<p>As doth an hevenish parfit creature,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That doun were sent in scorning of nature.</p>
<p class="stanza">16. This lady, which that al-day herde at ere</p>
<p>Hir fadres shame, his falsnesse and tresoun,</p>
<p>Wel nigh out of hir wit for sorwe and fere,</p>
<p>In widewes habit large of samit broun,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">On knees she fil biforn Ector a-doun;</p>
<p>With pitous voys, and tendrely wepinge,</p>
<p>His mercy bad, hir-selven excusinge.</p>
<p class="stanza">17. Now was this Ector pitous of nature,</p>
<p>And saw that she was sorwfully bigoon,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And that she was so fair a creature;</p>
<p>Of his goodnesse he gladed hir anoon,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'lat your fadres treson goon</p>
<p>Forth with mischaunce, and ye your-self, in Ioye,</p>
<p>Dwelleth with us, whyl you <a href="#TINL119" id="TIL119" class="pginternal">good</a> list, in Troye.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">120</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">18. And al thonour that men may doon yow have,</p>
<p>As ferforth as your fader dwelled here,</p>
<p>Ye shul han, and your body shal men save,</p>
<p>As fer as I may ought enquere or here.'</p>
<p>And she him thonked with ful humble chere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page157">{157}</span>And <a href="#TINL125" id="TIL125" class="pginternal">ofter wolde</a>, and it hadde ben his wille,</p>
<p>And took hir leve, and <a href="#TINL126" id="TIL126" class="pginternal">hoom</a>, and held hir stille.</p>
<p class="stanza">19. And in hir hous she abood with swich meynee</p>
<p>As to hir honour nede was to holde;</p>
<p>And whyl she was dwellinge in that citee,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Kepte hir estat, and bothe of yonge and olde</p>
<p>Ful wel beloved, and wel men of hir tolde.</p>
<p>But whether that she <a href="#TINL132" id="TIL132" class="pginternal">children</a> hadde or noon,</p>
<p>I rede it nought; therfore I lete it goon.</p>
<p class="stanza">20. The thinges fellen, as they doon of werre,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">135</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Bitwixen hem of Troye and Grekes ofte;</p>
<p>For <a href="#TINL136" id="TIL136" class="pginternal">som day</a> boughten they of Troye it derre,</p>
<p>And eft the Grekes founden no thing softe</p>
<p>The folk of Troye; and thus <a href="#TINL138" id="TIL138" class="pginternal">fortune on-lofte</a>,</p>
<p>And under eft, gan hem to wheelen bothe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">After hir cours, ay whyl they were wrothe.</p>
<p class="stanza">21. But how this toun com to destruccioun</p>
<p>Ne falleth nought to purpos me to telle;</p>
<p>For it were here a long disgressioun</p>
<p>Fro my matere, and yow to longe dwelle.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">145</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But the <a href="#TINL145" id="TIL145" class="pginternal">Troyane gestes</a>, as they felle,</p>
<p>In <a href="#TINL146" id="TIL146" class="pginternal">Omer</a>, or in Dares, or in Dyte,</p>
<p>Who-so that can, may rede hem as they wryte.</p>
<p class="stanza">22. But though that Grekes hem of Troye shetten,</p>
<p>And hir citee bisegede al a-boute,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">150</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Hir olde usage wolde they not letten,</p>
<p>As for to honoure hir goddes ful devoute;</p>
<p>But aldermost in honour, out of doute,</p>
<p>They hadde a relik hight <a href="#TINL153" id="TIL153" class="pginternal">Palladion</a>,</p>
<p>That was hir trist a-boven everichon.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">155</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page158">{158}</span>23. And so bifel, whan
    comen was the tyme</p>
<p>Of Aperil, whan clothed is the mede</p>
<p>With newe grene, of lusty Ver the pryme,</p>
<p>And swote smellen floures whyte and rede,</p>
<p>In sondry wyses shewed, as I rede,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">160</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The folk of Troye hir observaunces olde,</p>
<p>Palladiones feste for to holde.</p>
<p class="stanza">24. And to the temple, in al hir beste wyse,</p>
<p>In general, ther wente many a wight,</p>
<p>To herknen of Palladion the servyse;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">165</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And namely, so many a lusty knight,</p>
<p>So many a lady fresh and mayden bright,</p>
<p>Ful wel arayed, bothe moste and leste,</p>
<p>Ye, bothe for the seson and the feste.</p>
<p class="stanza">25. Among thise othere folk was Criseyda,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">170</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">In widewes habite blak; but nathelees,</p>
<p>Right as our firste lettre is <a href="#TINL171" id="TIL171" class="pginternal">now an A</a>,</p>
<p>In beautee first so stood she, <a href="#TINL172" id="TIL172" class="pginternal">makelees</a>;</p>
<p>Hir godly looking gladede al the prees.</p>
<p>Nas never seyn thing to ben preysed derre,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">175</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Nor under cloude blak so bright a sterre</p>
<p class="stanza">26. As was Criseyde, as folk seyde everichoon</p>
<p>That hir bihelden in hir blake wede;</p>
<p>And yet she stood ful lowe and stille alloon,</p>
<p>Bihinden othere folk, in litel brede,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">180</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And neigh the dore, ay under shames drede,</p>
<p>Simple of a-tyr, and debonaire of chere,</p>
<p>With ful assured loking and manere.</p>
<p class="stanza">27. This Troilus, as he was wont to gyde</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page159">{159}</span>His yonge knightes, ladde hem up and doun</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">185</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">In thilke large temple on every syde,</p>
<p>Biholding ay the ladyes of the toun,</p>
<p>Now here, now there, for no devocioun</p>
<p>Hadde he to noon, to reven him his reste,</p>
<p>But gan to preyse and <a href="#TINL189" id="TIL189" class="pginternal">lakken</a> whom him leste.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">190</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">28. And in his walk ful fast he gan to wayten</p>
<p>If knight or squyer of his companye</p>
<p>Gan for to syke, or lete his eyen <a href="#TINL192" id="TIL192" class="pginternal">bayten</a></p>
<p>On any woman that he coude aspye;</p>
<p>He wolde smyle, and holden it folye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">195</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And seye him thus, 'god wot, she slepeth softe</p>
<p>For love of thee, whan thou tornest ful ofte!</p>
<p class="stanza">29. 'I have herd told, pardieux, of your livinge,</p>
<p>Ye lovers, and your lewede observaunces,</p>
<p>And which a labour folk han in winninge</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">200</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Of love, and, in the keping, which doutaunces;</p>
<p>And whan your preye is lost, wo and penaunces;</p>
<p>O verrey foles! nyce and blinde be ye;</p>
<p>Ther nis not oon can war by other be.'</p>
<p class="stanza">30. And with that word he gan cast up the browe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">205</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#TINL205" id="TIL205" class="pginternal">Ascaunces</a>, 'lo! is this nought wysly
    spoken?'</p>
<p>At which the god of love gan loken rowe</p>
<p>Right for despyt, and shoop for to ben wroken;</p>
<p>He kidde anoon his bowe nas not broken;</p>
<p>For sodeynly he hit him at the fulle;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">210</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And yet <a href="#TINL210" id="TIL210" class="pginternal">as proud a pekok</a> can he pulle.</p>
<p class="stanza">31. O blinde world, O blinde entencioun!</p>
<p>How ofte falleth al theffect contraire</p>
<p>Of surquidrye and foul presumpcioun;</p>
<p><a href="#TINL214" id="TIL214" class="pginternal">For caught is proud</a>, and caught is debonaire.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">215</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">This Troilus is clomben on the staire,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page160">{160}</span>And litel weneth that he moot descenden.</p>
<p>But al-day <a href="#TINL217" id="TIL217" class="pginternal">falleth</a> thing that foles <a href="#TINL217" class="pginternal">ne
    wenden</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza">32. As proude <a href="#TINL218" id="TIL218" class="pginternal">Bayard</a> ginneth for to
    skippe</p>
<p>Out of the wey, so priketh him his corn,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">220</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Til he a lash have of the longe whippe,</p>
<p>Than thenketh he, 'though I praunce al biforn</p>
<p>First in the trays, ful fat and newe shorn,</p>
<p>Yet am I but an hors, and horses lawe</p>
<p>I moot endure, and with my feres drawe.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">225</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">33. So ferde it by this fers and proude knight;</p>
<p>Though he a worthy kinges sone were,</p>
<p>And wende no-thing hadde had swiche might</p>
<p>Ayens his wil that sholde his herte stere,</p>
<p>Yet with a look his herte <a href="#TINL229" id="TIL229" class="pginternal">wex a-fere</a>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">230</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That he, that now was most in pryde above,</p>
<p>Wex sodeynly most subget un-to love.</p>
<p class="stanza">34. For-thy ensample taketh of this man,</p>
<p>Ye wyse, proude, and worthy folkes alle,</p>
<p>To scornen Love, which that so sone can</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">235</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The freedom of your hertes to him thralle;</p>
<p>For ever it was, and ever it shal bifalle,</p>
<p>That Love is he that alle thing may binde;</p>
<p>For may no man for-do the lawe of kinde.</p>
<p class="stanza">35. That this be sooth, <a href="#TINL239" id="TIL239" class="pginternal">hath preved</a> and
    doth yet;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">240</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For this trowe I ye knowen, alle or some,</p>
<p>Men reden not that folk han gretter wit</p>
<p>Than they that han be most with love y-nome;</p>
<p>And strengest folk ben therwith overcome,</p>
<p>The worthiest and grettest of degree;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">245</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">This was, and is, and yet men shal it see.</p>
<p class="stanza">36. And trewelich it sit wel to be so;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page161">{161}</span>For alderwysest han ther-with ben plesed;</p>
<p>And they that han ben aldermost in wo,</p>
<p>With love han ben conforted most and esed;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">250</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And ofte it hath the cruel herte apesed,</p>
<p>And worthy folk maad worthier of name,</p>
<p>And causeth most to dreden vyce and shame.</p>
<p class="stanza">37. Now sith it may not goodly be withstonde,</p>
<p>And is a thing so vertuous in kinde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">255</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Refuseth not to Love for to be bonde,</p>
<p>Sin, as him-selven list, he may yow binde.</p>
<p><a href="#TINL257" id="TIL257" class="pginternal">The yerde is bet</a> that bowen wole and winde</p>
<p>Than that that brest; and therfor I yow rede</p>
<p>To folwen him that so wel can yow lede.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">260</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">38. But for to tellen forth in special</p>
<p>As of this kinges sone of which I tolde,</p>
<p>And leten other thing collateral,</p>
<p>Of him thenke I my tale for to holde,</p>
<p>Bothe of his Ioye, and of his cares colde;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">265</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And al his werk, as touching this matere,</p>
<p>For I it gan, I wil <a href="#TINL266" id="TIL266" class="pginternal">ther-to refere</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza">39. With-inne the temple he wente him forth pleyinge,</p>
<p>This Troilus, of every wight aboute,</p>
<p>On this lady and now on that lokinge,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">270</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Wher-so she were of toune, or of with-oute:</p>
<p>And up-on cas bifel, that thorugh a route</p>
<p>His eye perced, and so depe it wente,</p>
<p>Til on Criseyde it smoot, and ther it stente.</p>
<p class="stanza">40. And sodeynly he wex ther-with astoned,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">275</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And gan hire bet biholde in thrifty wyse:</p>
<p>'O mercy, god!' thoughte he, 'wher hastow woned,</p>
<p>That art so fair and goodly to devyse?'</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page162">{162}</span>Ther-with his herte gan to sprede and
    ryse,</p>
<p>And softe sighed, lest men mighte him here,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">280</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And caughte a-yein his firste pleyinge chere.</p>
<p class="stanza">41. She nas not with the leste of hir stature,</p>
<p>But alle hir limes so wel answeringe</p>
<p>Weren to womanhode, that creature</p>
<p>Was neuer lasse mannish in seminge.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">285</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And eek the pure wyse of here meninge</p>
<p>Shewede wel, that men might in hir gesse</p>
<p>Honour, estat, and wommanly noblesse.</p>
<p class="stanza">42. To Troilus right wonder wel with-alle</p>
<p>Gan for to lyke hir mening and hir chere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">290</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Which somdel deynous was, for she leet falle</p>
<p>Hir look a lite a-side, in swich manere,</p>
<p><a href="#TINL292" id="TIL292" class="pginternal">Ascaunces</a>, 'what! may I not stonden here?'</p>
<p>And after that hir loking gan she lighte,</p>
<p>That never thoughte him seen so good a sighte.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">295</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">43. And of hir look in him ther gan to quiken</p>
<p>So greet desir, and swich affeccioun,</p>
<p>That in his hertes botme gan to stiken</p>
<p>Of hir his fixe and depe impressioun:</p>
<p>And though he erst hadde poured up and doun,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">300</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He was tho glad his hornes in to shrinke;</p>
<p>Unnethes wiste he how to loke or winke.</p>
<p class="stanza">44. Lo, he that leet him-selven so konninge,</p>
<p>And scorned hem that loves peynes dryen,</p>
<p>Was ful unwar that love hadde his dwellinge</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">305</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">With-inne the subtile stremes of hir yën;</p>
<p>That sodeynly him thoughte he felte dyen,</p>
<p>Right with hir look, the spirit in his herte;</p>
<p>Blessed be love, that thus can folk converte!</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page163">{163}</span>45. She, this in blak, lykinge
    to Troylus,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">310</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Over alle thyng he stood for to biholde;</p>
<p>Ne his desir, ne wherfor he stood thus,</p>
<p>He neither chere made, ne worde tolde;</p>
<p>But from a-fer, his maner for to holde,</p>
<p>On other thing his look som-tyme he caste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">315</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And eft on hir, whyl that servyse laste.</p>
<p class="stanza">46. And after this, not fulliche al <a href="#TINL316" id="TIL316" class="pginternal">awhaped</a>,</p>
<p>Out of the temple al esiliche he wente,</p>
<p>Repentinge him that he hadde ever y-iaped</p>
<p>Of loves folk, lest fully the descente</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">320</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Of scorn fille on him-self; but, what he mente,</p>
<p>Lest it were wist on any maner syde,</p>
<p>His wo he gan dissimulen and hyde.</p>
<p class="stanza">47. Whan he was fro the temple thus departed,</p>
<p>He streyght anoon un-to his paleys torneth,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">325</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Right with hir look thurgh-shoten and thurgh-darted,</p>
<p>Al feyneth he in lust that he soiorneth;</p>
<p>And al his chere and speche also he <a href="#TINL327" id="TIL327" class="pginternal">borneth</a>;</p>
<p>And ay, of loves servants every whyle,</p>
<p>Him-self to wrye, at hem he gan to smyle.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">330</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">48. And seyde, 'lord, so ye live al in lest,</p>
<p>Ye loveres! for the conningest of yow,</p>
<p>That serveth most ententiflich and best,</p>
<p><a href="#TINL333" id="TIL333" class="pginternal">Him tit</a> as often harm ther-of as prow;</p>
<p>Your hyre is quit ayein, ye, god wot how!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">335</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Nought wel for wel, but scorn for good servyse;</p>
<p>In feith, your <a href="#TINL336" id="TIL336" class="pginternal">ordre</a> is ruled in good wyse!</p>
<p class="stanza">49. In <a href="#TINL337" id="TIL337" class="pginternal">noun-certeyn</a> ben alle your
    observaunces,</p>
<p>But it a sely fewe poyntes be;</p>
<p>Ne no-thing asketh so grete attendaunces</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">340</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page164">{164}</span>As doth your <a href="#TINL340" id="TIL340" class="pginternal">lay</a>, and that knowe alle ye;</p>
<p>But that is not the worste, as mote I thee;</p>
<p>But, tolde I yow the worste poynt, I leve,</p>
<p>Al seyde I sooth, ye wolden at me greve!</p>
<p class="stanza">50. <a href="#TINL344" id="TIL344" class="pginternal">But tak this</a>, that ye loveres ofte
    eschuwe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">345</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Or elles doon of good entencioun,</p>
<p>Ful ofte thy lady wole it misconstrue,</p>
<p>And deme it harm in hir opinioun;</p>
<p>And yet if she, for other enchesoun,</p>
<p>Be wrooth, than shalt thou han a groyn anoon:</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">350</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Lord! wel is him that may be of yow oon!'</p>
<p class="stanza">51. But for al this, whan that he say his tyme,</p>
<p>He held his pees, non other bote him gayned;</p>
<p>For love bigan his fetheres so to lyme,</p>
<p>That wel unnethe un-to his folk he feyned</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">355</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That othere besye nedes him destrayned;</p>
<p>For wo was him, that what to doon he niste,</p>
<p>But bad his folk to goon wher that hem liste.</p>
<p class="stanza">52. And whan that he in chaumbre was allone,</p>
<p>He doun up-on his beddes feet him sette,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">360</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And first he gan to syke, and eft to grone,</p>
<p>And thoughte ay on hir so, with-outen lette,</p>
<p>That, as he sat and wook, his spirit mette</p>
<p>That he hir saw <a href="#TINL363" id="TIL363" class="pginternal">a temple</a>, and al the wyse</p>
<p>Right of hir loke, and gan it newe avyse.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">365</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">53. Thus gan he make a mirour of his minde,</p>
<p>In which he saugh al hoolly hir figure;</p>
<p>And that he wel coude in his herte finde,</p>
<p>It was to him a right good aventure</p>
<p>To love swich oon, and if he dide his cure</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">370</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To serven hir, yet mighte he falle in grace,</p>
<p>Or elles, for oon of hir servaunts pace.</p>
<p class="stanza">54. Imagininge that travaille nor grame</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page165">{165}</span>Ne mighte, for so goodly oon, be lorn</p>
<p>As she, ne him for his desir ne shame,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">375</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Al were it wist, but in prys and up-born</p>
<p>Of alle lovers wel more than biforn;</p>
<p>Thus argumented he in his ginninge,</p>
<p>Ful unavysed of his wo cominge.</p>
<p class="stanza">55. Thus took he purpos loves craft to suwe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">380</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And thoughte he wolde werken prively,</p>
<p><a href="#TINL381" id="TIL381" class="pginternal">First</a>, to hyden his desir in muwe</p>
<p>From every wight y-born, al-outrely,</p>
<p>But he mighte ought recovered be therby;</p>
<p>Remembring him, that love to wyde y-blowe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">385</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#TINL385" id="TIL385" class="pginternal">Yelt</a> bittre fruyt, though swete seed be
    sowe.</p>
<p class="stanza">56. And over al this, yet muchel more he thoughte</p>
<p>What for to speke, and what to holden inne,</p>
<p>And what to arten hir to love he soughte,</p>
<p>And on a song anoon-right to biginne,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">390</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And gan loude on his sorwe for to winne;</p>
<p>For with good hope he gan fully assente</p>
<p>Criseyde for to love, and nought repente.</p>
<p class="stanza">57. And of his song nought only the sentence,</p>
<p>As <a href="#TINL394" id="TIL394" class="pginternal">writ</a> myn autour called <a href="#TINL394" class="pginternal">Lollius</a>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">395</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But pleynly, save our tonges difference,</p>
<p>I dar wel sayn, in al that Troilus</p>
<p>Seyde in his song; lo! every word right thus</p>
<p>As I shal seyn; and who-so list it here,</p>
<p>Lo! next this vers, he may it finden here.</p>
<p class="stanza" style="margin-left:7.00em"><b>Cantus Troili.</b></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">400</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">58. 'If no love is, O god, what fele I so?</p>
<p>And if love is, what thing and whiche is he!</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page166">{166}</span>If love be good, from whennes comth my wo?</p>
<p>If it be wikke, a wonder thinketh me,</p>
<p>Whenne every torment and adversitee</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">405</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That cometh of him, may to me savory thinke;</p>
<p>For ay thurst I, the more that I it drinke.</p>
<p class="stanza">59. And if that at myn owene lust I brenne,</p>
<p>Fro whennes cometh my wailing and my pleynte?</p>
<p>If harme agree me, wher-to pleyne I thenne?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">410</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I noot, ne why unwery that I feynte.</p>
<p>O quike deeth, o swete harm so queynte,</p>
<p>How may of thee in me swich quantitee,</p>
<p>But-if that I consente that it be?</p>
<p class="stanza">60. And if that I consente, I wrongfully</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">415</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Compleyne, y-wis; thus possed to and fro,</p>
<p>Al sterelees with-inne a boot am I</p>
<p>A-mid the see, by-twixen windes two,</p>
<p>That in contrarie stonden ever-mo.</p>
<p>Allas! what is this wonder maladye?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">420</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For hete of cold, for cold of hete, I deye.'</p>
<p class="stanza">61. And to the god of love thus seyde he</p>
<p>With pitous voys, 'O lord, now youres is</p>
<p>My spirit, which that oughte youres be.</p>
<p>Yow thanke I, lord, that han me brought to this;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">425</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#TINL425" id="TIL425" class="pginternal">But whether goddesse or womman</a>, y-wis,</p>
<p>She be, I noot, which that ye do me serve;</p>
<p>But as hir man I wole ay live and sterve.</p>
<p class="stanza">62. Ye stonden in hire eyen mightily,</p>
<p>As in a place un-to your vertu digne;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">430</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Wherfore, lord, if my servyse or I</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page167">{167}</span>May lyke yow, so beth to me benigne;</p>
<p>For myn estat royal here I resigne</p>
<p>In-to hir hond, and with ful humble chere</p>
<p>Bicome hir man, as to my lady dere.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">435</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">63. In him ne deyned sparen blood royal</p>
<p>The fyr of love, wher-fro god me blesse,</p>
<p>Ne him forbar in no degree, for al</p>
<p>His vertu or his excellent prowesse;</p>
<p>But held him as his thral lowe in distresse,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">440</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And brende him so in sondry wyse ay newe,</p>
<p>That sixty tyme a day he loste his hewe.</p>
<p class="stanza">64. So muche, day by day, his owene thought,</p>
<p>For lust to hir, gan quiken and encrese,</p>
<p>That every other charge he sette at nought;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">445</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For-thy ful ofte, his hote fyr to cese,</p>
<p>To seen hir goodly look he gan to prese;</p>
<p>For ther-by to ben esed wel he wende,</p>
<p>And ay the ner he was, the more he brende.</p>
<p class="stanza">65. For ay the ner the fyr, the hotter is,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">450</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">This, trowe I, knoweth al this companye.</p>
<p>But were he fer or neer, I dar seye this,</p>
<p>By night or day, for wysdom or folye,</p>
<p>His herte, which that is his brestes yë,</p>
<p>Was ay on hir, that fairer was to sene</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">455</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Than ever was Eleyne or Polixene.</p>
<p class="stanza">66. Eek of the day ther passed nought an houre</p>
<p><a href="#TINL457" id="TIL457" class="pginternal">That</a> to him-self a thousand tyme he seyde,</p>
<p>'Good goodly, to whom serve I and laboure,</p>
<p>As I best can, now wolde god, Criseyde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">460</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ye wolden on me rewe er that I deyde!</p>
<p>My dere herte, allas! myn hele and hewe</p>
<p>And lyf is lost, but ye wole on me rewe.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page168">{168}</span>67. Alle othere dredes weren
    from him <a href="#TINL463" id="TIL463" class="pginternal">fledde</a>,</p>
<p>Bothe of the assege and his <a href="#TINL464" id="TIL464" class="pginternal">savacioun</a>;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">465</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ne in him desyr noon othere <a href="#TINL465" id="TIL465" class="pginternal">fownes</a>
    bredde</p>
<p>But arguments to this conclusioun,</p>
<p>That she on him wolde han compassioun,</p>
<p>And he to be hir man, whyl he may dure;</p>
<p>Lo, here his lyf, and from the deeth his cure!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">470</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">68. The sharpe shoures <a href="#TINL470" id="TIL470" class="pginternal">felle</a> of armes
    preve,</p>
<p>That Ector or his othere bretheren diden,</p>
<p>Ne made him only ther-fore ones meve;</p>
<p>And yet was he, wher-so men wente or <a href="#TINL473" id="TIL473" class="pginternal">riden</a>,</p>
<p>Founde oon the best, and lengest tyme <a href="#TINL473" class="pginternal">abiden</a></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">475</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ther peril was, and dide eek such travayle</p>
<p>In armes, that to thenke it was mervayle.</p>
<p class="stanza">69. But for non hate he to the Grekes hadde,</p>
<p>Ne also for the rescous of the toun,</p>
<p>Ne made him thus in armes for to madde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">480</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But only, lo, for this conclusioun,</p>
<p>To lyken hir the bet for his renoun;</p>
<p>Fro day to day in armes so he spedde,</p>
<p>That alle the Grekes as <a href="#TINL483" id="TIL483" class="pginternal">the deeth</a> him dredde.</p>
<p class="stanza">70. And fro this forth tho refte him love his sleep,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">485</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And made his mete his foo; and eek his sorwe</p>
<p>Gan multiplye, that, who-so toke keep,</p>
<p>It shewed in his hewe, bothe eve and morwe;</p>
<p>Therfor a <a href="#TINL488" id="TIL488" class="pginternal">title</a> he gan him for to borwe</p>
<p>Of other syknesse, lest of him men wende</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">490</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That the hote fyr of love him brende.</p>
<p class="stanza">71. And seyde, he hadde a fever and ferde amis;</p>
<p>But how it was, certayn, can I not seye,</p>
<p>If that his lady understood not this,</p>
<p>Or feyned hir she niste, oon of the tweye;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">495</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But wel I rede that, by no maner weye,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page169">{169}</span>Ne semed it [as] that she of him roughte,</p>
<p>Nor of his peyne, or what-so-ever he thoughte.</p>
<p class="stanza">72. But than fel to this Troylus such wo,</p>
<p>That he was wel neigh wood; for ay his drede</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">500</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Was this, that she som wight had loved so,</p>
<p>That never of him she wolde have taken hede;</p>
<p>For whiche him thoughte he felte his herte blede.</p>
<p>Ne of his wo ne dorste he not biginne</p>
<p>To tellen it, for al this world to winne.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">505</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">73. But whanne he hadde a space fro his care,</p>
<p>Thus to him-self ful ofte he gan to pleyne;</p>
<p>He sayde, 'O fool, now art thou in the snare,</p>
<p>That whilom Iapedest at loves peyne;</p>
<p>Now artow hent, now gnaw thyn owene cheyne;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">510</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thou were ay wont eche lovere reprehende</p>
<p>Of thing fro which thou canst thee nat defende.</p>
<p class="stanza">74. What wole now every lover seyn of thee,</p>
<p>If this be wist, but ever in thyn absence</p>
<p>Laughen in scorn, and seyn, "lo, ther gooth he,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">515</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That is the man of so gret sapience,</p>
<p>That held us loveres leest in reverence!</p>
<p>Now, thonked be god, he may goon in the <a href="#TINL517" id="TIL517" class="pginternal">daunce</a></p>
<p>Of hem that Love list febly for to avaunce!</p>
<p class="stanza">75. But, O thou woful Troilus, god wolde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">520</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Sin thow most loven thurgh thy destinee,</p>
<p>That thow beset were on swich oon that sholde</p>
<p>Knowe al thy wo, al lakkede hir pitee:</p>
<p>But al so cold in love, towardes thee,</p>
<p>Thy lady is, as frost in winter mone,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">525</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And thou fordoon, as snow in fyr is sone."</p>
<p class="stanza">76. God wolde I were aryved in the port</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page170">{170}</span>Of deeth, to which my sorwe wil me lede!</p>
<p>A, lord, to me it were a greet comfort;</p>
<p>Then were I quit of languisshing in drede.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">530</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#TINL530" id="TIL530" class="pginternal">For by myn hidde sorwe</a> y-blowe on brede</p>
<p>I shal bi-Iaped been a thousand tyme</p>
<p>More than that fool of whos folye men ryme.</p>
<p class="stanza">77. But now help god, and ye, swete, for whom</p>
<p>I pleyne, y-caught, ye, never wight so faste!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">535</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">O mercy, dere herte, and help me from</p>
<p>The deeth, for I, whyl that my lyf may laste,</p>
<p>More than my-self wol love yow to my laste.</p>
<p>And with som freendly look gladeth me, swete,</p>
<p>Though never more thing ye me bi-hete!'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">540</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">78. This wordes and ful manye an-other to</p>
<p>He spak, and called ever in his compleynte</p>
<p>Hir name, for to tellen hir his wo,</p>
<p>Til neigh that he in salte teres dreynte.</p>
<p>Al was for nought, she herde nought his pleynte;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">545</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And whan that he bithoughte on that folye,</p>
<p>A thousand fold his wo gan multiplye.</p>
<p class="stanza">79. Bi-wayling in his chambre thus allone,</p>
<p>A freend of his, that called was Pandare,</p>
<p>Com ones in unwar, and herde him grone,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">550</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And sey his freend in swich distresse and care:</p>
<p>'Allas!' quod he, 'who causeth al this fare?</p>
<p>O mercy, god! what unhap may this mene?</p>
<p>Han now thus sone Grekes maad yow lene?</p>
<p class="stanza">80. Or hastow som remors of conscience,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">555</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And art now falle in som devocioun,</p>
<p>And waylest for thy sinne and thyn offence,</p>
<p>And hast for ferde caught <a href="#TINL557" id="TIL557" class="pginternal">attricioun</a>?</p>
<p>God save hem that bi-seged han our toun,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page171">{171}</span>And so can leye our Iolyte <a href="#TINL559" id="TIL559" class="pginternal">on presse</a>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">560</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And bring our lusty folk to <a href="#TINL560" id="TIL560" class="pginternal">holinesse</a>!'</p>
<p class="stanza">81. These wordes seyde he for the nones alle,</p>
<p>That with swich thing he mighte him angry maken,</p>
<p>And with an angre don his sorwe falle,</p>
<p>As for the tyme, and his corage awaken;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">565</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But wel he wiste, as fer as tonges spaken,</p>
<p>Ther nas a man of gretter hardinesse</p>
<p>Than he, ne more desired worthinesse.</p>
<p class="stanza">82. 'What cas,' quod Troilus, 'or what aventure</p>
<p>Hath gyded thee to see my languisshinge,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">570</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That am refus of euery creature?</p>
<p>But for the love of god, at my preyinge,</p>
<p>Go henne a-way, for certes, my deyinge</p>
<p>Wol thee disese, and I mot nedes deye;</p>
<p>Ther-for go wey, ther is no more to seye.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">575</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">83. But if thou wene I be thus syk for drede,</p>
<p>It is not so, and ther-for scorne nought;</p>
<p>Ther is a-nother thing I take of hede</p>
<p>Wel more than ought the Grekes han y-wrought,</p>
<p>Which cause is of my deeth, for sorwe and thought.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">580</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But though that I now telle thee it ne leste,</p>
<p>Be thou nought wrooth, I hyde it for the beste.'</p>
<p class="stanza">84. This Pandare, that neigh malt for wo and routhe,</p>
<p>Ful often seyde, 'allas! what may this be?</p>
<p>Now freend,' quod he, 'if ever love or trouthe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">585</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Hath been, or is, bi-twixen thee and me,</p>
<p>Ne do thou never swiche a crueltee</p>
<p>To hyde fro thy freend so greet a care;</p>
<p>Wostow nought wel that it am I, Pandare?</p>
<p class="stanza">85. I wole parten with thee al thy peyne,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">590</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">If it be so I do thee no comfort,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page172">{172}</span>As it is freendes right, sooth for to
    seyne,</p>
<p>To entreparten wo, as glad desport.</p>
<p>I have, and shal, for trewe or fals report,</p>
<p>In wrong and right y-loved thee al my lyve;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">595</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Hyd not thy wo fro me, but telle it blyve.'</p>
<p class="stanza">86. Than gan this sorwful Troilus to syke,</p>
<p>And seyde him thus, 'god leve it be my beste</p>
<p>To telle it thee; for, sith it may thee lyke,</p>
<p>Yet wole I telle it, though myn herte breste;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">600</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And wel wot I thou mayst do me no reste.</p>
<p>But lest thow deme I truste not to thee,</p>
<p>Now herkne, freend, for thus it stant with me.</p>
<p class="stanza">87. Love, a-yeins the which who-so defendeth</p>
<p>Him-selven most, him alder-lest avayleth,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">605</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">With desespeir so sorwfully me offendeth,</p>
<p>That streyght un-to the deeth myn herte sayleth.</p>
<p>Ther-to desyr so brenningly me assaylleth,</p>
<p>That to ben slayn it were a gretter Ioye</p>
<p>To me than king of Grece been and Troye!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">610</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">88. Suffiseth this, my fulle freend Pandare,</p>
<p>That I have seyd, for now wostow my wo;</p>
<p>And for the love of god, my colde care</p>
<p>So hyd it wel, I telle it never to mo;</p>
<p>For harmes mighte folwen, mo than two,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">615</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">If it were wist; but be thou in gladnesse,</p>
<p>And lat me sterve, unknowe, of my distresse.'</p>
<p class="stanza">89. 'How hastow thus unkindely and longe</p>
<p>Hid this fro me, thou fool?' quod Pandarus;</p>
<p>'Paraunter thou might after swich oon longe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">620</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That myn avys anoon may helpen us.'</p>
<p>'This were a wonder thing,' quod Troylus,</p>
<p>'Thou coudest never in love thy-selven wisse;</p>
<p>How devel maystow bringen me to blisse?'</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page173">{173}</span>90. 'Ye, Troilus, now herke,'
    quod Pandare,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">625</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'Though I be nyce; it happeth ofte so,</p>
<p><a href="#TINL626" id="TIL626" class="pginternal">That oon</a> that exces doth ful yvele fare,</p>
<p>By good counseyl can kepe his freend ther-fro.</p>
<p>I have my-self eek seyn a blind man go</p>
<p>Ther-as he fel that coude loke wyde;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">630</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">A fool may eek a wys man ofte gyde.</p>
<p class="stanza">91. <a href="#TINL631" id="TIL631" class="pginternal">A whetston</a> is no kerving
    instrument,</p>
<p>And yet it maketh sharpe kerving-tolis.</p>
<p>And ther thow woost that I have ought miswent,</p>
<p>Eschewe thou that, for swich thing to thee scole is;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">635</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thus ofte wyse men ben war by folis.</p>
<p>If thou do so, thy wit is wel biwared;</p>
<p>By his contrarie is every thing declared.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TINL638" id="TIL638" class="pginternal">92</a>. For how might ever sweetnesse have be
    knowe</p>
<p>To him that never tasted bitternesse?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">640</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ne no man may be inly glad, I trowe,</p>
<p>That never was in sorwe or som distresse;</p>
<p>Eek whyt by blak, by shame eek worthinesse,</p>
<p>Ech set by other, more for other semeth;</p>
<p>As men may see; and so the wyse it demeth.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">645</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">93. Sith thus of two contraries is a lore,</p>
<p>I, that have in love so ofte assayed</p>
<p>Grevaunces, oughte conne, and wel the more</p>
<p>Counsayllen thee of that thou art <a href="#TINL648" id="TIL648" class="pginternal">amayed</a>.</p>
<p>Eek thee ne oughte nat ben yvel apayed,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">650</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Though I desyre with thee for to bere</p>
<p>Thyn hevy charge; it shal the lasse dere.</p>
<p class="stanza">94. I woot wel that it fareth thus by me</p>
<p>As to thy brother Parys an herdesse,</p>
<p>Which that y-cleped was <a href="#TINL654" id="TIL654" class="pginternal">Oënone</a>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">655</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page174">{174}</span>Wrot in a compleynt of hir
    hevinesse:</p>
<p>Ye say the lettre that she wroot, y gesse?'</p>
<p>Nay, never yet, y-wis,' quod Troilus.</p>
<p>'Now,' quod Pandare, 'herkneth; it was thus.—</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TINL659" id="TIL659" class="pginternal">95</a>. "Phebus, that first fond art of
    medicyne,"</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">660</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Quod she, "and coude in every wightes care</p>
<p>Remede and reed, by herbes he knew fyne,</p>
<p>Yet to him-self his conninge was ful bare;</p>
<p>For love hadde him so bounden in a snare,</p>
<p>Al for the doughter of the kinge Admete,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">665</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That al his craft ne coude his sorwe bete."—</p>
<p class="stanza">96. Right so fare I, unhappily for me;</p>
<p>I love oon best, and that me smerteth sore;</p>
<p>And yet, paraunter, can I rede thee,</p>
<p>And not my-self; repreve me no more.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">670</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I have no cause, I woot wel, for to sore</p>
<p>As doth an hauk that listeth for to pleye,</p>
<p>But to thyn help yet somwhat can I seye.</p>
<p class="stanza">97. And of o thing right siker maystow be,</p>
<p>That certayn, <a href="#TINL674" id="TIL674" class="pginternal">for to deyen</a> in the peyne,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">675</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That I shal never-mo discoveren thee;</p>
<p>Ne, by my trouthe, I kepe nat restreyne</p>
<p>Thee fro thy love, thogh that it were Eleyne,</p>
<p>That is thy brotheres wyf, if ich it wiste;</p>
<p>Be what she be, and love hir as thee liste.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">680</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">98. Therfore, as freend fullich in me assure,</p>
<p>And tel me plat what is thyn enchesoun,</p>
<p>And final cause of wo that ye endure;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page175">{175}</span>For douteth no-thing, myn entencioun</p>
<p>Nis nought to yow of reprehencioun,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">685</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To speke as now, for no wight may bireve</p>
<p>A man to love, til that him <a href="#TINL686" id="TIL686" class="pginternal">list to leve</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza">99. And witeth wel, that bothe two ben vyces,</p>
<p><a href="#TINL688" id="TIL688" class="pginternal">Mistrusten alle</a>, or elles alle leve;</p>
<p>But wel I woot, the mene of it no vyce is,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">690</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For for to trusten sum wight is a preve</p>
<p>Of trouthe, and for-thy wolde I fayn remeve</p>
<p>Thy wrong conceyte, and do thee som wight triste,</p>
<p>Thy wo to telle; and tel me, if thee liste.</p>
<p class="stanza">100. <a href="#TINL694" id="TIL694" class="pginternal">The wyse</a> seyth, "wo him that is
    allone,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">695</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For, and he falle, he hath noon help to ryse;"</p>
<p>And sith thou hast a felawe, tel thy mone;</p>
<p>For this nis not, certeyn, the nexte wyse</p>
<p>To winnen love, as techen us the wyse,</p>
<p>To walwe and wepe as <a href="#TINL699" id="TIL699" class="pginternal">Niobe</a> the quene,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">700</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Whos teres yet in marbel been y-sene.</p>
<p class="stanza">101. Lat be thy weping and thy drerinesse,</p>
<p>And lat us lissen wo with other speche;</p>
<p>So may thy woful tyme seme lesse.</p>
<p>Delyte not in wo thy wo to seche,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">705</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As doon thise foles that hir sorwes <a href="#TINL705" id="TIL705" class="pginternal">eche</a></p>
<p>With sorwe, whan they han misaventure,</p>
<p>And <a href="#TINL707" id="TIL707" class="pginternal">listen</a> nought to seche hem other cure.</p>
<p class="stanza">102. Men seyn, "<a href="#TINL708" id="TIL708" class="pginternal">to wrecche is
    consolacioun</a></p>
<p>To have an-other felawe in his peyne;"</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">710</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That oughte wel ben our opinioun,</p>
<p>For, bothe thou and I, of love we pleyne;</p>
<p>So ful of sorwe am I, soth for to seyne,</p>
<p>That certeynly no more <a href="#TINL713" id="TIL713" class="pginternal">harde grace</a></p>
<p>May sitte on me, for-why ther is no space.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">715</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page176">{176}</span>103. If god wole thou art
    not agast of me,</p>
<p>Lest I wolde of thy lady thee bigyle,</p>
<p>Thow wost thy-self whom that I love, pardee,</p>
<p>As I best can, gon sithen longe whyle.</p>
<p>And sith thou wost I do it for no wyle,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">720</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And sith I am he that thou tristest most,</p>
<p>Tel me sumwhat, sin al my wo thou wost.'</p>
<p class="stanza">104. Yet Troilus, for al this, no word seyde,</p>
<p>But longe he lay as stille as he ded were;</p>
<p>And after this with sykinge he abreyde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">725</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And to Pandarus voys he lente his ere,</p>
<p>And up his eyen caste he, that in fere</p>
<p>Was Pandarus, lest that in frenesye</p>
<p>He sholde falle, or elles sone dye:</p>
<p class="stanza">105. And cryde 'a-wake' ful wonderly and sharpe;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">730</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'<a href="#TINL730" id="TIL730" class="pginternal">What?</a> slombrestow as in a lytargye?</p>
<p>Or artow lyk an asse to the harpe,</p>
<p>That hereth soun, whan men the strenges plye,</p>
<p>But in his minde of that no melodye</p>
<p>May sinken, him to glade, for that he</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">735</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">So dul is of his bestialitee?'</p>
<p class="stanza">106. And with that Pandare of his wordes stente;</p>
<p>But Troilus yet him no word answerde,</p>
<p>For-why to telle nas not his entente</p>
<p>To never no man, <a href="#TINL739" id="TIL739" class="pginternal">for whom</a> that he so ferde.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">740</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For it is seyd, 'man maketh ofte a yerde</p>
<p>With which the maker is him-self <a href="#TINL740" id="TIL740" class="pginternal">y-beten</a></p>
<p>In sondry maner,' as thise wyse treten,</p>
<p class="stanza">107. And namely, in his counseyl tellinge</p>
<p>That toucheth love that oughte be secree;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">745</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For of him-self it wolde y-nough <a href="#TINL745" id="TIL745" class="pginternal">out-springe</a>,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page177">{177}</span>But-if that it the bet governed be.</p>
<p><a href="#TINL747" id="TIL747" class="pginternal">Eek som-tyme</a> it is craft to seme flee</p>
<p>Fro thing which in effect men hunte faste;</p>
<p>Al this gan Troilus in his herte caste.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">750</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">108. But nathelees, whan he had herd him crye</p>
<p>'Awake!' he gan to syke wonder sore,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'freend, though that I stille lye,</p>
<p>I am not deef; now pees, and cry no more;</p>
<p>For I have herd thy wordes and thy lore;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">755</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But suffre me my mischef to biwayle,</p>
<p>For thy proverbes may me nought avayle.</p>
<p class="stanza">109. Nor other cure canstow noon for me.</p>
<p>Eek I nil not be cured, I wol deye;</p>
<p>What knowe I of the quene Niobe?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">760</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Lat be thyne olde ensaumples, I thee preye.'</p>
<p>'No,' quod tho Pandarus, 'therfore I seye,</p>
<p>Swich is delyt of foles to biwepe</p>
<p>Hir wo, but <a href="#TINL763" id="TIL763" class="pginternal">seken bote</a> they ne kepe.</p>
<p class="stanza">110. Now knowe I that ther reson in thee fayleth.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">765</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But tel me, if I wiste what she were</p>
<p>For whom that thee al this misaunter ayleth?</p>
<p>Dorstestow that I tolde hir in hir ere</p>
<p>Thy wo, sith thou darst not thy-self for fere,</p>
<p>And hir bisoughte on thee to han som routhe?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">770</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'Why, nay,' quod he, 'by god and by my trouthe!'</p>
<p class="stanza">111. 'What? not as bisily,' quod Pandarus,</p>
<p>'As though myn owene lyf lay on this nede?'</p>
<p>'No, certes, brother,' quod this Troilus.</p>
<p>'And why?'—'For that thou sholdest never spede.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">775</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'Wostow that wel?'—'Ye, that is out of drede,'</p>
<p>Quod Troilus, 'for al that ever ye conne,</p>
<p>She nil to noon swich wrecche as I be wonne.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page178">{178}</span>112. Quod Pandarus, 'allas!
    what may this be,</p>
<p>That thou despeyred art thus causelees?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">780</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">What? liveth not thy lady? <a href="#TINL780" id="TIL780" class="pginternal"><i>benedicite!</i></a></p>
<p>How wostow so that thou art gracelees?</p>
<p>Swich yvel is not alwey botelees.</p>
<p>Why, put not impossible thus thy cure,</p>
<p>Sin thing to come is ofte in aventure.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">785</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">113. I graunte wel that thou endurest wo</p>
<p>As sharp as doth he, <a href="#TINL786" id="TIL786" class="pginternal">Ticius</a>, in helle,</p>
<p>Whos stomak foules tyren ever-mo</p>
<p>That highte volturis, as bokes telle.</p>
<p>But I may not endure that thou dwelle</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">790</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">In so unskilful an opinioun</p>
<p>That of thy wo is no curacioun.</p>
<p class="stanza">114. But ones niltow, for thy coward herte,</p>
<p>And for thyn ire and folish wilfulnesse,</p>
<p>For wantrust, tellen of thy sorwes smerte,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">795</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ne to thyn owene help do bisinesse</p>
<p>As muche as speke a resoun more or lesse,</p>
<p>But lyest as he that list of no-thing recche.</p>
<p>What womman coude love swich a wrecche?</p>
<p class="stanza">115. What may she demen other of thy deeth,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">800</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">If thou thus deye, and she not why it is,</p>
<p>But that for fere is yolden up thy breeth,</p>
<p>For Grekes han biseged us, y-wis?</p>
<p>Lord, which a thank than shaltow han of this!</p>
<p>Thus wol she seyn, and al the toun at ones,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">805</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">"The wrecche is deed, the devel have his bones!"</p>
<p class="stanza">116. Thou mayst allone here wepe and crye and knele;</p>
<p>But, love a woman that she woot it nought,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page179">{179}</span>And she wol quyte that thou shalt not
    fele;</p>
<p>Unknowe, unkist, and lost that is un-sought.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">810</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">What! many a man hath love ful dere y-bought</p>
<p><a href="#TINL811" id="TIL811" class="pginternal">Twenty winter</a> that his lady wiste,</p>
<p>That never yet his lady mouth he kiste.</p>
<p class="stanza">117. What? shulde he therfor fallen in despeyr,</p>
<p>Or be recreaunt for his owene tene,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">815</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Or sleen him-self, al be his lady fayr?</p>
<p>Nay, nay, but ever in oon be fresh and grene</p>
<p>To serve and love his dere hertes quene,</p>
