<p class="stanza">116. And after that, hir thought bigan to clere,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'he which that <a href="#TIINL807" id="TIIL807" class="pginternal">no-thing under-taketh</a>,</p>
<p>No-thing ne acheveth, be him looth or dere.'</p>
<p>And with an other thought hir herte quaketh;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">810</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Than slepeth hope, and after dreed awaketh;</p>
<p>Now hoot, now cold; but thus, bi-twixen tweye,</p>
<p>She rist hir up, and went hir for to pleye.</p>
<p class="stanza">117. Adoun the steyre anoon-right tho she wente</p>
<p>In-to the gardin, with hir neces three,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">815</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And up and doun ther made many a wente,</p>
<p>Flexippe, she, Tharbe, and Antigone,</p>
<p>To pleyen, that it Ioye was to see;</p>
<p>And othere of hir wommen, a gret route,</p>
<p>Hir folwede in the gardin al aboute.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">820</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">118. This yerd was large, and rayled alle the aleyes,</p>
<p>And shadwed wel with blosmy bowes grene,</p>
<p>And benched newe, and sonded alle the weyes,</p>
<p>In which she walketh arm in arm bi-twene;</p>
<p>Til at the laste Antigone the shene</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">825</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Gan on a Troian song to singe clere,</p>
<p>That it an heven was hir voys to here.—</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page215">{215}</span>119. She seyde, 'O love, to
    whom I have and shal</p>
<p>Ben humble subgit, trewe in myn entente,</p>
<p>As I best can, to yow, lord, yeve ich al</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">830</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For ever-more, myn <a href="#TIINL830" id="TIIL830" class="pginternal">hertes lust to
    rente</a>.</p>
<p>For never yet thy grace <a href="#TIINL831" id="TIIL831" class="pginternal">no wight</a> sente</p>
<p>So blisful cause as me, my lyf to lede</p>
<p>In alle Ioye and seurtee, out of drede.</p>
<p class="stanza">120. Ye, blisful god, han me so wel beset</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">835</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">In love, y-wis, that al that bereth lyf</p>
<p>Imaginen ne cowde how to ben bet;</p>
<p>For, lord, with-outen Ialousye or stryf,</p>
<p>I love oon which that is most ententyf</p>
<p>To serven wel, unwery or unfeyned,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">840</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That ever was, and leest with harm distreyned.</p>
<p class="stanza">121. As he that is the welle of worthinesse,</p>
<p>Of trouthe ground, mirour of goodliheed,</p>
<p>Of wit Appollo, stoon of sikernesse,</p>
<p>Of vertu rote, of lust findere and heed,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">845</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thurgh which is alle sorwe fro me deed,</p>
<p>Y-wis, I love him best, so doth he me;</p>
<p>Now good thrift have he, wher-so that he be!</p>
<p class="stanza">122. Whom sholde I thanke but yow, god of love,</p>
<p>Of al this blisse, in which to bathe I ginne?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">850</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And thanked be ye, lord, for that I love!</p>
<p>This is the righte lyf that I am inne,</p>
<p>To flemen alle manere vyce and sinne:</p>
<p>This doth me so to vertu for to entende,</p>
<p>That day by day I in my wil amende.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">855</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">123. And who-so seyth that for to love is vyce,</p>
<p>Or thraldom, though he fele in it distressse,</p>
<p>He outher is envyous, or right nyce,</p>
<p>Or is unmighty, for his shrewednesse,</p>
<p>To loven; for swich maner folk, I gesse,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">860</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page216">{216}</span>Defamen love, as no-thing of him
    knowe;</p>
<p>They speken, but they bente never <a href="#TIINL861" id="TIIL861" class="pginternal">his bowe</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza">124. What is the sonne wers, of kinde righte,</p>
<p>Though that a man, for feblesse of his yën,</p>
<p>May nought endure on it to see for brighte?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">865</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Or love the wers, though wrecches on it cryen?</p>
<p>No wele is worth, that may no <a href="#TIINL866" id="TIIL866" class="pginternal">sorwe dryen</a>.</p>
<p>And for-thy, who that hath an <a href="#TIINL867" id="TIIL867" class="pginternal">heed of verre</a>,</p>
<p>Fro cast of stones war him in the werre!</p>
<p class="stanza">125. But I with al myn herte and al my might,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">870</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As I have seyd, wol love, un-to my laste,</p>
<p>My dere herte, and al myn owene knight,</p>
<p>In which myn herte growen is so faste,</p>
<p>And his in me, that it shal ever laste.</p>
<p>Al dredde I first to love him to biginne,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">875</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Now woot I wel, ther is no peril inne.'</p>
<p class="stanza">126. And of hir song right with that word she stente,</p>
<p>And therwith-al, 'now, nece,' quod Criseyde,</p>
<p>'Who made this song with so good entente?'</p>
<p>Antigone answerde anoon, and seyde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">880</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'Ma dame, y-wis, the goodlieste mayde</p>
<p>Of greet estat in al the toun of Troye;</p>
<p>And <a href="#TIINL882" id="TIIL882" class="pginternal">let</a> hir lyf in most honour and Ioye.'</p>
<p class="stanza">127. 'Forsothe, so it semeth by hir song,'</p>
<p>Quod tho Criseyde, and gan ther-with to <a href="#TIINL884" id="TIIL884" class="pginternal">syke</a>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">885</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And seyde, 'lord, is there swich blisse among</p>
<p>These lovers, as they conne faire endyte?'</p>
<p>'Ye, wis,' quod fresh Antigone the whyte,</p>
<p>'For alle the folk that han or been on lyve</p>
<p>Ne conne wel the blisse of love discryve.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">890</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">128. But wene ye that every wrecche woot</p>
<p>The parfit blisse of love? why, nay, y-wis;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page217">{217}</span>They wenen al be love, if oon be hoot;</p>
<p>Do wey, do wey, they woot no-thing of this!</p>
<p>Men mosten axe at seyntes if it is</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">895</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Aught fair in hevene; why? for they conne telle;</p>
<p>And axen fendes, is it foul in helle.'</p>
<p class="stanza">129. Criseyde un-to that purpos nought answerde,</p>
<p>But seyde, 'y-wis, it wol be night as faste.'</p>
<p>But every word which that she of hir herde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">900</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">She gan to prenten in hir herte faste;</p>
<p>And ay gan love hir lasse for to agaste</p>
<p>Than it dide erst, and sinken in hir herte,</p>
<p>That she wex somwhat able to converte.</p>
<p class="stanza">130. The dayes honour, and the hevenes yë,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">905</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The nightes fo, al this clepe I the sonne,</p>
<p>Gan westren faste, and dounward for to wrye,</p>
<p>As he that hadde his dayes cours y-ronne;</p>
<p>And whyte thinges wexen dimme and donne</p>
<p>For lak of light, and sterres for to appere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">910</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That she and al hir folk in wente y-fere.</p>
<p class="stanza">131. So whan it lyked hir to goon to reste,</p>
<p>And voyded weren they that voyden oughte,</p>
<p>She seyde, that to slepe wel hir leste.</p>
<p>Hir wommen sone til hir bed hir broughte.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">915</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Whan al was hust, than lay she stille, and thoughte</p>
<p>Of al this thing the manere and the wyse.</p>
<p>Reherce it nedeth nought, for ye ben wyse.</p>
<p class="stanza">132. A nightingale, upon a cedre grene,</p>
<p>Under the chambre-wal ther as she lay,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">920</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#TIINL920" id="TIIL920" class="pginternal">Ful loude sang</a> ayein the mone shene,</p>
<p>Paraunter, in his briddes wyse, a lay</p>
<p>Of love, that made hir herte fresh and gay.</p>
<p>That herkned she so longe in good entente,</p>
<p>Til at the laste the dede sleep hir hente.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">925</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page218">{218}</span>133. And, as she sleep,
    anoon-right tho hir mette,</p>
<p>How that an egle, fethered whyt as boon,</p>
<p>Under hir brest his longe clawes sette,</p>
<p>And out hir herte he rente, and that a-noon,</p>
<p>And dide his herte in-to hir brest to goon,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">930</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Of which she nought agroos ne no-thing smerte,</p>
<p>And forth he fleigh, with herte left for herte.</p>
<p class="stanza">134. Now lat hir slepe, and we our tales holde</p>
<p>Of Troilus, that is to paleys riden,</p>
<p>Fro the scarmuch, of the whiche I tolde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">935</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And in his chambre sit, and hath abiden</p>
<p>Til two or three of his messages yeden</p>
<p>For Pandarus, and soughten him ful faste,</p>
<p>Til they him founde, and broughte him at the laste.</p>
<p class="stanza">135. This Pandarus com leping in at ones</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">940</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And seide thus, 'who hath ben wel y-bete</p>
<p>To-day with swerdes, and with slinge-stones,</p>
<p>But Troilus, that hath caught him an hete?'</p>
<p>And gan to Iape, and seyde, 'lord, so ye swete!</p>
<p>But rys, and lat us soupe and go to reste;'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">945</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And he answerde him, 'do we as thee leste.'</p>
<p class="stanza">136. With al the haste goodly that they mighte,</p>
<p>They spedde hem fro the souper un-to bedde;</p>
<p>And every wight out at the dore him dighte,</p>
<p>And wher him list upon his wey he spedde;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">950</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But Troilus, that thoughte his herte bledde</p>
<p>For wo, til that he herde som tydinge,</p>
<p>He seyde, 'freend, shal I now wepe or singe?'</p>
<p class="stanza">137. Quod Pandarus, 'ly stille, and lat me slepe,</p>
<p>And don thyn hood, thy nedes spedde be;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">955</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page219">{219}</span>And chese, if thou wolt singe or
    daunce or lepe;</p>
<p>At shorte wordes, thow shall trowe me.—</p>
<p>Sire, my nece wol do wel by thee,</p>
<p>And love thee best, by god and by my trouthe,</p>
<p><a href="#TIINL959" id="TIIL959" class="pginternal">But lak of pursuit</a> make it in thy slouthe.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">960</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">138. For thus ferforth I have thy work bigonne,</p>
<p>Fro day to day, til this day, by the morwe,</p>
<p>Hir love of freendship have I to thee wonne,</p>
<p>And also hath she leyd hir feyth to borwe.</p>
<p>Algate a foot is <a href="#TIINL964" id="TIIL964" class="pginternal">hameled</a> of thy sorwe.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">965</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">What sholde I lenger sermon of it holde?</p>
<p>As ye han herd bifore, al he him tolde.</p>
<p class="stanza">139. But right as floures, thorugh the colde of night</p>
<p>Y-closed, stoupen on hir stalkes lowe,</p>
<p>Redressen hem a-yein the sonne bright,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">970</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And spreden on hir kinde cours by rowe;</p>
<p>Right so gan tho his eyen up to throwe</p>
<p>This Troilus, and seyde, 'O Venus dere,</p>
<p>Thy might, thy grace, y-heried be it here!'</p>
<p class="stanza">140. And to Pandare he held up bothe his hondes,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">975</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And seyde, 'lord, al thyn be that I have;</p>
<p>For I am hool, al brosten been my bondes;</p>
<p>A thousand Troians who so that me yave,</p>
<p>Eche after other, god so wis me save,</p>
<p>Ne mighte me so gladen; lo, myn herte,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">980</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">It spredeth so for Ioye, it wol to-sterte!</p>
<p class="stanza">141. But lord, how shal I doon, how shal I liven?</p>
<p>Whan shal I next my dere herte see?</p>
<p>How shal this longe tyme a-wey be driven,</p>
<p>Til that thou be ayein at hir fro me?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">985</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thou mayst answere, "a-byd, a-byd," but he</p>
<p>That hangeth by the nekke, sooth to seyne,</p>
<p>In grete disese abydeth for the peyne.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page220">{220}</span>142. 'Al esily, now, for the
    love of Marte,'</p>
<p>Quod Pandarus, 'for every thing hath tyme;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">990</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">So longe abyd til that the night departe;</p>
<p>For al so siker as thow lyst here by me,</p>
<p>And god toforn, I wol be there at pryme,</p>
<p>And for thy werk somwhat as I shal seye,</p>
<p>Or on som other wight this charge leye.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">995</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">143. For pardee, god wot, I have ever yit</p>
<p>Ben redy thee to serve, and to this night</p>
<p>Have I nought fayned, but emforth my wit</p>
<p>Don al thy lust, and shal with al my might.</p>
<p>Do now as I shal seye, and fare a-right;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1000</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And if thou nilt, wyte al thy-self thy care,</p>
<p><a href="#TIINL1001" id="TIIL1001" class="pginternal">On me is nought</a> along thyn yvel fare.</p>
<p class="stanza">144. I woot wel that thow wyser art than I</p>
<p>A thousand fold, but if I were as thou,</p>
<p>God helpe me so, as I wolde outrely,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1005</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Right of myn owene hond, wryte hir right now</p>
<p>A lettre, in which I wolde hir tellen how</p>
<p>I ferde amis, and hir beseche of routhe;</p>
<p>Now help thy-self, and leve it not for slouthe.</p>
<p class="stanza">145. And I my-self shal ther-with to hir goon;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1010</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And whan thou wost that I am with hir there,</p>
<p>Worth thou up-on a courser right anoon,</p>
<p>Ye, hardily, right in thy beste gere,</p>
<p>And ryd forth by the place, as nought ne were,</p>
<p>And thou shalt finde us, if I may, sittinge</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1015</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">At som windowe, in-to the strete lokinge.</p>
<p class="stanza">146. And if thee list, than maystow us saluwe,</p>
<p><a href="#TIINL1017" id="TIIL1017" class="pginternal">And up-on me</a> makë thy contenaunce;</p>
<p>But, by thy lyf, be war and faste eschuwe</p>
<p>To tarien ought, god shilde us fro mischaunce!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1020</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page221">{221}</span>Ryd forth thy wey, and hold thy
    governaunce;</p>
<p>And we shal speke of thee som-what, I trowe,</p>
<p>Whan thou art goon, to do thyne <a href="#TIINL1022" id="TIIL1022" class="pginternal">eres glowe</a>!</p>
<p class="stanza">147. Touching thy lettre, thou art wys y-nough,</p>
<p>I woot thow nilt it digneliche endyte;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1025</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As make it with thise argumentes tough;</p>
<p><a href="#TIINL1026" id="TIIL1026" class="pginternal">Ne scrivenish</a> or craftily thou it wryte;</p>
<p><a href="#TIINL1027" id="TIIL1027" class="pginternal">Beblotte it</a> with thy teres eek a lyte;</p>
<p>And if thou wryte a goodly word al softe,</p>
<p>Though it be good, reherce it not to ofte.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1030</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">148. For though the beste harpour upon lyve</p>
<p>Wolde on the beste souned Ioly harpe</p>
<p>That ever was, with alle his fingres fyve,</p>
<p>Touche ay o streng, or ay <a href="#TIINL1033" id="TIIL1033" class="pginternal">o werbul harpe</a>,</p>
<p>Were his nayles poynted never so sharpe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1035</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">It shulde maken every wight to dulle,</p>
<p>To here his glee, and of his strokes fulle.</p>
<p class="stanza">149. Ne Iompre eek no discordaunt thing y-fere,</p>
<p>As thus, to usen termes of phisyk;</p>
<p>In loves termes, hold of thy matere</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1040</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The forme alwey, and do that it be lyk;</p>
<p>For if a peyntour wolde peynte a <a href="#TIINL1041" id="TIIL1041" class="pginternal">pyk</a></p>
<p>With asses feet, and hede it as an ape,</p>
<p>It cordeth nought; so nere it but a Iape.'</p>
<p class="stanza">150. This counseyl lyked wel to Troilus;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1045</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But, as a dreedful lover, he seyde this:—</p>
<p>'Allas, my dere brother Pandarus,</p>
<p>I am ashamed for to wryte, y-wis,</p>
<p>Lest of myn innocence I seyde a-mis,</p>
<p>Or that she nolde it for despyt receyve;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1050</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thanne were I deed, ther mighte it no-thing weyve.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page222">{222}</span>151. To that Pandare answerde,
    'if thee lest,</p>
<p>Do that I seye, and lat me therwith goon;</p>
<p>For by that lord that formed est and west,</p>
<p>I hope of it to bringe answere anoon</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1055</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Right of hir hond, and if that thou nilt noon,</p>
<p>Lat be; and sory mote he been his lyve,</p>
<p>Ayeins thy lust that helpeth thee to thryve.'</p>
<p class="stanza">152. Quod Troilus, '<i>Depardieux</i>, I assente;</p>
<p>Sin that thee list, I will aryse and wryte;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1060</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And blisful god preye ich, with good entente,</p>
<p>The vyage, and the lettre I shal endyte,</p>
<p>So spede it; and thou, <a href="#TIINL1062" id="TIIL1062" class="pginternal">Minerva</a>, the whyte,</p>
<p>Yif thou me wit my lettre to devyse:'</p>
<p>And sette him doun, and wroot right in this wyse.—</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1065</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">153. First he gan hir his righte lady calle,</p>
<p>His hertes lyf, his lust, his sorwes leche,</p>
<p>His blisse, and eek this othere termes alle,</p>
<p>That in swich cas these loveres alle seche;</p>
<p>And in ful humble wyse, as in his speche,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1070</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He gan him recomaunde un-to hir grace;</p>
<p>To telle al how, it axeth muchel space.</p>
<p class="stanza">154. And after this, ful lowly he hir prayde</p>
<p>To be nought wrooth, though he, of his folye,</p>
<p>So hardy was to hir to wryte, and seyde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1075</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That love <a href="#TIINL1075" id="TIIL1075" class="pginternal">it made</a>, or elles moste he
    dye,</p>
<p>And pitously gan mercy for to crye;</p>
<p>And after that he seyde, and <a href="#TIINL1075" class="pginternal">ley</a> ful loude,</p>
<p>Him-self was litel worth, and lesse he coude;</p>
<p class="stanza">155. And that she sholde han his conning excused,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1080</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That litel was, and eek he dredde hir so,</p>
<p>And his unworthinesse he ay acused;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page223">{223}</span>And after that, than gan he telle his wo;</p>
<p>But that was endeles, with-outen ho;</p>
<p>And seyde, he wolde in trouthe alwey him holde;—</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1085</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And radde it over, and gan the lettre folde.</p>
<p class="stanza">156. And with his salte teres gan he bathe</p>
<p>The ruby in his signet, and it sette</p>
<p>Upon the wex deliverliche and rathe;</p>
<p>Ther-with a thousand tymes, er he lette,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1090</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He kiste tho the lettre that he shette,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'lettre, a blisful destenee</p>
<p>Thee shapen is, my lady shal thee see.'</p>
<p class="stanza">157. This Pandare took the lettre, and that by tyme</p>
<p>A-morwe, and to his neces paleys sterte,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1095</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And faste he swoor, that it was passed pryme,</p>
<p>And gan to Iape, and seyde, 'y-wis, myn herte,</p>
<p>So fresh it is, al-though it sore smerte,</p>
<p>I may not slepe never a Mayes morwe;</p>
<p>I have a Ioly wo, a lusty sorwe.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1100</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">158. Criseyde, whan that she hir uncle herde,</p>
<p>With dreedful herte, and desirous to here</p>
<p>The cause of his cominge, thus answerde,</p>
<p>'Now by your feyth, myn uncle,' quod she, 'dere,</p>
<p>What maner windes gydeth yow now here?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Tel us your Ioly wo and your penaunce,</p>
<p>How ferforth be ye put in loves daunce.'</p>
<p class="stanza">159. 'By god,' quod he, 'I <a href="#TIINL1107" id="TIIL1107" class="pginternal">hoppe</a> alwey
    bihinde!'</p>
<p>And she <a href="#TIINL1108" id="TIIL1108" class="pginternal">to-laugh</a>, it thoughte hir herte breste.</p>
<p>Quod Pandarus, 'loke alwey that ye finde</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Game in myn hood, but herkneth, if yow leste;</p>
<p>Ther is right now come in-to toune a geste,</p>
<p>A Greek espye, and telleth newe thinges,</p>
<p>For which come I to telle yow tydinges.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page224">{224}</span>160. Into the gardin go we, and
    we shal here,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Al prevely, of this a long sermoun.'</p>
<p>With that they wenten arm in arm y-fere</p>
<p>In-to the gardin from the chaumbre doun.</p>
<p>And whan that he so fer was that the soun</p>
<p>Of that he <a href="#TIINL1119" id="TIIL1119" class="pginternal">speke</a>, no man here mighte,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1120</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He seyde hir thus, and out the lettre plighte,</p>
<p class="stanza">161. 'Lo, he that is al hoolly youres free</p>
<p>Him recomaundeth lowly to your grace,</p>
<p>And <a href="#TIINL1123" id="TIIL1123" class="pginternal">sent</a> to you this lettre here by me;</p>
<p>Avyseth you on it, whan ye han space,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And of som goodly answere yow purchace;</p>
<p>Or, helpe me god, so pleynly for to seyne,</p>
<p>He may not longe liven for his peyne.'</p>
<p class="stanza">162. Ful dredfully tho gan she stonde stille,</p>
<p>And took it nought, but al hir humble chere</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Gan for to chaunge, and seyde, 'scrit ne bille,</p>
<p>For love of god, that toucheth swich matere,</p>
<p>Ne bring me noon; and also, uncle dere,</p>
<p>To myn estat have more reward, I preye,</p>
<p>Than to his lust; what sholde I more seye?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1135</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">163. And loketh now if this be resonable,</p>
<p>And letteth nought, for favour ne for slouthe,</p>
<p>To seyn a sooth; now were it covenable</p>
<p>To myn estat, by god, and by your trouthe,</p>
<p>To taken it, or to han of him routhe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">In harming of my-self or in repreve?</p>
<p>Ber it a-yein, for him that ye on leve!'</p>
<p class="stanza">164. This Pandarus gan on hir for to stare,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'now is this the grettest wonder</p>
<p>That ever I sey! lat be this nyce fare!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1145</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To deethe mote I smiten be with thonder,</p>
<p>If, for the citee which that stondeth yonder,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page225">{225}</span>Wolde I a lettre un-to yow bringe or take</p>
<p>To harm of yow; what list yow thus it make?</p>
<p class="stanza">165. But thus ye faren, wel neigh alle and some,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1150</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That he that most desireth yow to serve,</p>
<p>Of him ye recche leest wher he bicome,</p>
<p>And whether that he live or elles sterve.</p>
<p>But for al that that ever I may deserve,</p>
<p>Refuse it nought,' quod he, and hente hir faste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1155</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And in hir bosom the lettre doun he thraste,</p>
<p class="stanza">166. And seyde hir, 'now cast it away anoon,</p>
<p>That folk may seen and gauren on us tweye.'</p>
<p>Quod she, 'I can abyde til they be goon,'</p>
<p>And gan to smyle, and seyde him, 'eem, I preye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1160</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Swich answere as yow list your-self purveye,</p>
<p>For trewely I nil no lettre wryte.'</p>
<p>'No? than wol I,' quod he, 'so ye endyte.'</p>
<p class="stanza">167. Therwith she lough, and seyde, 'go we dyne.'</p>
<p>And he gan at him-self to iape faste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1165</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And seyde, 'nece, I have so greet a pyne</p>
<p>For love, that every other day I faste'—</p>
<p>And gan his beste Iapes forth to caste;</p>
<p>And made hir so to laughe at his folye,</p>
<p>That she for laughter wende for to dye.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1170</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">168. And whan that she was comen in-to halle,</p>
<p>'Now, eem,' quod she, 'we wol go dyne anoon;'</p>
<p>And gan some of hir women to hir calle,</p>
<p>And streyght in-to hir chaumbre gan she goon;</p>
<p>But of hir besinesses, this was oon</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1175</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">A-monges othere thinges, out of drede,</p>
<p>Ful prively this lettre for to rede;</p>
<p class="stanza">169. <a href="#TIINL1177" id="TIIL1177" class="pginternal">Avysed</a> word by word in every
    lyne,</p>
<p>And <a href="#TIINL1177" class="pginternal">fond</a> no lak, she thoughte he <a href="#TIINL1177" class="pginternal">coude
    good</a>;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page226">{226}</span>And up it putte, and went hir in to dyne.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1180</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And Pandarus, that in a study stood,</p>
<p>Er he was war, she took him by the hood,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'ye were caught er that ye wiste;'</p>
<p>'I vouche sauf,' quod he, 'do what yow liste.'</p>
<p class="stanza">170. Tho wesshen they, and sette hem doun and ete;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1185</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And after noon ful sleyly Pandarus</p>
<p>Gan drawe him to the window next the strete,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'nece, who hath arayed thus</p>
<p>The yonder hous, that stant afor-yeyn us?'</p>
<p>'Which hous?' quod she, and gan for to biholde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1190</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And knew it wel, and whos it was him tolde,</p>
<p class="stanza">171. And fillen forth in speche of thinges smale,</p>
<p>And seten in the window bothe tweye.</p>
<p>Whan Pandarus saw tyme un-to his tale,</p>
<p>And saw wel that hir folk were alle aweye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1195</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'Now, nece myn, tel on,' quod he, 'I seye,</p>
<p>How lyketh yow the lettre that ye woot?</p>
<p>Can he ther-on? for, by my trouthe, I noot.'</p>
<p class="stanza">172. Therwith al rosy hewed tho wex she,</p>
<p>And gan to humme, and seyde, 'so I trowe.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1200</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'Aquyte him wel, for goddes love,' quod he;</p>
<p>'My-self to medes wol the lettre <a href="#TIINL1201" id="TIIL1201" class="pginternal">sowe</a>,'</p>
<p>And held his hondes up, and sat on knowe,</p>
<p>'Now, goode nece, be it never so lyte,</p>
<p>Yif me the labour, it to sowe and plyte.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1205</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">173. 'Ye, for I can so wryte,' quod she tho;</p>
<p>'And eek I noot what I sholde to him seye.'</p>
<p>'Nay, nece,' quod Pandare, 'sey not so;</p>
<p>Yet at the leste thanketh him, I preye,</p>
<p>Of his good wil, and doth him not to deye.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1210</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Now for the love of me, my nece dere,</p>
<p>Refuseth not at this tyme my preyere.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page227">{227}</span>174. '<i>Depar-dieux</i>,' quod
    she, 'god leve al be wel!</p>
<p>God helpe me so, this is the firste lettre</p>
<p>That ever I wroot, ye, al or any del.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1215</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And in-to a closet, for to avyse hir bettre,</p>
<p>She wente allone, and gan hir herte unfettre</p>
<p>Out of disdaynes prison but a lyte;</p>
<p>And sette hir doun, and gan a lettre wryte,</p>
<p class="stanza">175. Of which to telle in short is myn entente</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1220</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Theffect, as fer as I can understonde:—</p>
<p>She thonked him of al that he wel mente</p>
<p>Towardes hir, but holden him in honde</p>
<p>She nolde nought, ne make hir-selven bonde</p>
<p>In love, but as his suster, him to plese,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1225</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">She wolde fayn, to doon his herte an ese.</p>
<p class="stanza">176. She shette it, and to Pandarus gan goon,</p>
<p>There as he sat and loked in-to strete,</p>
<p>And doun she sette hir by him on a stoon</p>
<p>Of Iaspre, up-on a <a href="#TIINL1229" id="TIIL1229" class="pginternal">quisshin</a> gold y-bete,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1230</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And seyde, 'as wisly helpe me god the grete,</p>
<p>I never dide a thing with more peyne</p>
<p>Than wryte this, to which ye me constreyne;'</p>
<p class="stanza">177. And took it him: he thonked hir and seyde,</p>
<p>'God woot, of thing ful ofte looth bigonne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1235</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Cometh ende good; and nece myn, Criseyde,</p>
<p>That ye to him of hard now ben y-wonne</p>
<p>Oughte he be glad, by god and yonder sonne!</p>
<p>For-why men seyth, "<a href="#TIINL1238" id="TIIL1238" class="pginternal">impressiounes lighte</a></p>
<p>Ful lightly been ay redy to the flighte."</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1240</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">178. But ye han pleyed tyraunt neigh to longe,</p>
<p>And hard was it your herte for to grave;</p>
<p>Now stint, that ye no longer on it honge,</p>
<p>Al wolde ye the forme of daunger save.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page228">{228}</span>But hasteth yow to doon him Ioye have;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1245</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For trusteth wel, to longe y-doon hardnesse</p>
<p>Causeth despyt ful often, for distresse.'</p>
<p class="stanza">179. And right as they declamed this matere,</p>
<p>Lo, Troilus, right at the stretes ende,</p>
<p>Com ryding with his tenthe <a href="#TIINL1249" id="TIIL1249" class="pginternal">some</a> y-fere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1250</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Al softely, and thiderward gan bende</p>
<p>Ther-as they sete, as was his wey to wende</p>
<p>To paleys-ward; and Pandare him aspyde,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'nece, y-see who cometh here ryde!</p>
<p class="stanza">180. O flee not in, he seeth us, I suppose;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1255</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Lest he may thinke that ye him eschuwe.'</p>
<p>'Nay, nay,' quod she, and wex as reed as rose.</p>
<p>With that he gan hir humbly to saluwe,</p>
<p>With dreedful chere, and ofte his hewes muwe;</p>
<p>And up his look debonairly he caste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1260</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And bekked on Pandare, and forth he paste.</p>
<p class="stanza">181. God woot if he sat on his hors a-right,</p>
<p>Or goodly was beseyn, that ilke day!</p>
<p>God woot wher he was lyk a manly knight!</p>
<p>What sholde I drecche, or telle of his aray?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1265</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Criseyde, which that alle these thinges say,</p>
<p>To telle in short, hir lyked al y-fere,</p>
<p>His persone, his aray, his look, his chere,</p>
<p class="stanza">182. His goodly manere and his gentillesse,</p>
<p>So wel, that never, sith that she was born,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1270</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ne hadde she swich routhe of his distresse;</p>
<p>And how-so she hath hard ben her-biforn,</p>
<p>To god hope I, she hath now caught a thorn.</p>
<p>She shal not pulle it out this nexte wyke;</p>
<p>God sende mo swich thornes <a href="#TIINL1274" id="TIIL1274" class="pginternal">on to pyke</a>!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1275</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page229">{229}</span>183. Pandare, which that
    stood hir faste by,</p>
<p>Felte <a href="#TIINL1276" id="TIIL1276" class="pginternal">iren hoot</a>, and he bigan to smyte,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'nece, I pray yow hertely,</p>
<p>Tel me that I shal axen yow a lyte.</p>
<p>A womman, that were of his deeth to wyte,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1280</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">With-outen his gilt, but for hir lakked routhe,</p>
<p>Were it wel doon?' Quod she, 'nay, by my trouthe!'</p>
<p class="stanza">184. 'God helpe me so,' quod he, 'ye sey me sooth.</p>
<p>Ye felen wel your-self that I not lye;</p>
<p>Lo, yond he rit!' Quod she, 'ye, so he dooth.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1285</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'Wel,' quod Pandare, 'as I have told yow thrye,</p>
<p>Lat be your nyce shame and your folye,</p>
<p>And spek with him in esing of his herte;</p>
<p>Lat nycetee not do yow bothe smerte.'</p>
<p class="stanza">185. But ther-on was <a href="#TIINL1289" id="TIIL1289" class="pginternal">to heven</a> and to
    done;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1290</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Considered al thing, it may not be;</p>
<p>And why, <a href="#TIINL1291" id="TIIL1291" class="pginternal">for shame</a>; and it were eek to sone</p>
<p>To graunten him so greet a libertee.</p>
<p>'For playnly hir entente,' as seyde she,</p>
<p>Was for to love him unwist, if she mighte,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1295</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And guerdon him with no-thing but with sighte.'</p>
<p class="stanza">186. But Pandarus thoughte, 'it shal not be so,</p>
<p>If that I may; this nyce opinioun</p>
<p>Shal not be holden fully yeres two.'</p>
<p>What sholde I make of this a long sermoun?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1300</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He moste assente on that conclusioun</p>
<p>As for the tyme; and whan that it was eve,</p>
<p>And al was wel, he roos and took his leve.</p>
<p class="stanza">187. And on his wey ful faste homward he spedde,</p>
<p>And right for Ioye he felte his herte daunce;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1305</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And Troilus he fond alone a-bedde,</p>
<p>That lay as dooth these loveres, in a traunce,</p>
<p>Bitwixen hope and derk desesperaunce.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page230">{230}</span>But Pandarus, right at his in-cominge,</p>
<p>He song, as who seyth, 'lo! sumwhat I bringe.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1310</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">188. And seyde, 'who is in his bed so sone</p>
<p>Y-buried thus?' 'It am I, freend,' quod he.</p>
<p>'Who, Troilus? nay helpe me so the mone,'</p>
<p>Quod Pandarus, 'thou shalt aryse and see</p>
<p>A charme that was sent right now to thee,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1315</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The which can helen thee of thyn <a href="#TIINL1315" id="TIIL1315" class="pginternal">accesse</a>,</p>
<p>If thou do forth-with al thy besinesse.'</p>
<p class="stanza">189. 'Ye, through the might of god!' quod Troilus.</p>
<p>And Pandarus gan him the lettre take,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'pardee, god hath holpen us;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1320</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Have here a light, and loke on al this blake.'</p>
<p>But ofte gan the herte glade and quake</p>
<p>Of Troilus, whyl that he gan it rede,</p>
<p>So as the wordes yave him hope or drede.</p>
<p class="stanza">190. But fynally, he took al for the beste</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1325</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That she him wroot, for sumwhat he biheld</p>
<p>On which, him thoughte, he mighte his herte reste,</p>
<p>Al covered she the wordes under sheld.</p>
<p>Thus to the more worthy part he held,</p>
<p>That, what for hope and Pandarus biheste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1330</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">His grete wo for-yede he at the leste.</p>
<p class="stanza">191. But as we may alday our-selven see,</p>
<p>Through more wode or col, the more fyr;</p>
<p>Right so encrees of hope, of what it be,</p>
<p>Therwith ful ofte encreseth eek desyr;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1335</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Or, as an ook cometh of a litel spyr,</p>
<p>So through this lettre, which that she him sente,</p>
<p>Encresen gan desyr, of which he brente.</p>
<p class="stanza">192. Wherfore I seye alwey, that day and night</p>
<p>This Troilus gan to desiren more</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1340</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page231">{231}</span>Than he dide erst, thurgh hope,
    and dide his might</p>
<p>To pressen on, as by Pandarus lore,</p>
<p>And wryten to hir of his sorwes sore</p>
<p>Fro day to day; he leet it not <a href="#TIINL1343" id="TIIL1343" class="pginternal">refreyde</a>,</p>
<p>That by Pandare he wroot somwhat or seyde;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1345</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">193. And dide also his othere observaunces</p>
<p>That to a lovere longeth in this cas;</p>
<p>And, after that these dees turnede on chaunces,</p>
<p>So was he outher glad or seyde 'allas!'</p>
<p>And held <a href="#TIINL1349" id="TIIL1349" class="pginternal">after his gestes</a> ay his pas;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1350</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And aftir swiche answeres as he hadde,</p>
<p>So were his dayes sory outher gladde.</p>
<p class="stanza">194. But to Pandare alwey was his recours,</p>
<p>And pitously gan ay til him to pleyne,</p>
<p>And him bisoughte of rede and som socours;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1355</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And Pandarus, that sey his wode peyne,</p>
<p>Wex wel neigh deed for routhe, sooth to seyne,</p>
<p>And bisily with al his herte caste</p>
<p>Som of his wo to sleen, and that as faste;</p>
<p class="stanza">195. And seyde, 'lord, and freend, and brother dere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1360</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">God woot that thy disese dooth me wo.</p>
<p>But woltow stinten al this woful chere,</p>
<p>And, by my trouthe, or it be dayes two,</p>
<p>And god to-forn, yet shal I shape it so,</p>
<p>That thou shalt come in-to a certayn place,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1365</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ther-as thou mayst thy-self hir preye of grace.</p>
<p class="stanza">196. And certainly, I noot if thou it wost,</p>
<p>But tho that been expert in love it seye,</p>
<p>It is oon of the thinges that furthereth most,</p>
<p>A man to have a leyser for to preye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1370</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And siker place his wo for to biwreye;</p>
<p>For in good herte it moot som routhe impresse,</p>
<p>To here and see the giltles in distresse.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page232">{232}</span>197. Paraunter thenkestow:
    though it be so</p>
<p>That kinde wolde doon hir to biginne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1375</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To han a maner routhe up-on my wo,</p>
<p>Seyth Daunger, "Nay, thou shalt me never winne;</p>
<p>So reuleth hir hir hertes goost with-inne,</p>
<p>That, though she bende, yet she stant on rote;</p>
<p>What in effect is this un-to my bote?"</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1380</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">198. Thenk here-ayeins, whan that the sturdy ook,</p>
<p>On which men hakketh ofte, for the nones,</p>
<p>Receyved hath the happy falling strook,</p>
<p>The grete sweigh doth it come al at ones,</p>
<p>As doon these rokkes or these milne-stones.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1385</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For swifter cours cometh thing that is of wighte,</p>
<p>Whan it descendeth, than don thinges lighte.</p>
<p class="stanza">199. And reed that boweth doun for every blast,</p>
<p>Ful lightly, cesse wind, it wol aryse;</p>
<p>But so nil not an ook whan it is cast;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1390</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">It nedeth me nought thee longe to <a href="#TIINL1390" id="TIIL1390" class="pginternal">forbyse</a>.</p>
<p>Men shal reioysen of a greet empryse</p>
<p>Acheved wel, and stant with-outen doute,</p>
<p>Al han men been the lenger ther-aboute.</p>
<p class="stanza">200. But, Troilus, yet tel me, if thee lest,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1395</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">A thing now which that I shal axen thee;</p>
<p>Which is thy brother that thou lovest best</p>
<p>As in thy verray hertes privetee?'</p>
<p>'Y-wis, my brother <a href="#TIINL1398" id="TIIL1398" class="pginternal">Deiphebus</a>,' quod he.</p>
<p>'Now,' quod Pandare, 'er houres twyes twelve,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1400</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He shal thee ese, unwist of it him-selve.</p>
<p class="stanza">201. Now lat me allone, and werken as I may,'</p>
<p>Quod he; and to Deiphebus wente he tho</p>
<p>Which hadde his lord and grete freend ben ay;</p>
<p>Save Troilus, no man he lovede so.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1405</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To telle in short, with-outen wordes mo,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page233">{233}</span>Quod Pandarus, 'I pray yow that ye be</p>
<p>Freend to a cause which that toucheth me.'</p>
<p class="stanza">202. 'Yis, pardee,' quod Deiphebus, 'wel thow wost,</p>
<p>In al that ever I may, and god to-fore,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1410</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Al nere it <a href="#TIINL1410" id="TIIL1410" class="pginternal">but for man I love most</a>,</p>
<p>My brother Troilus; but sey wherfore</p>
<p>It is; for sith that day that I was bore,</p>
<p>I nas, ne never-mo to been I thinke,</p>
<p>Ayeins a thing that mighte thee for-thinke.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1415</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">203. Pandare gan him thonke, and to him seyde,</p>
<p>'Lo, sire, I have a lady in this toun,</p>
<p>That is my nece, and called is Criseyde,</p>
<p>Which som men wolden doon oppressioun,</p>
<p>And wrongfully have hir possessioun:</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1420</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Wherfor I of your lordship yow biseche</p>
<p>To been our freend, with-oute more speche.'</p>
<p class="stanza">204. Deiphebus him answerde, 'O, is not this,</p>
<p>That thow spekest of to me thus straungely,</p>
<p>Crisëyda, my freend?' He seyde, 'Yis.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1425</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'Than nedeth,' quod Deiphebus hardely,</p>
<p>'Na-more to speke, for trusteth wel, that I</p>
<p>Wol be hir champioun with <a href="#TIINL1427" id="TIIL1427" class="pginternal">spore and yerde</a>;</p>
<p>I roughte nought though alle hir foos it herde.</p>
<p class="stanza">205. But tel me, thou that woost al this matere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1430</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">How I might best avaylen? now lat see.'</p>
<p>Quod Pandarus, 'if ye, my lord so dere,</p>
<p>Wolden as now don this honour to me,</p>
<p>To prayen hir to-morwe, lo, that she</p>
<p>Com un-to yow hir pleyntes to devyse,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1435</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Hir adversaries wolde of hit agryse.</p>
<p class="stanza">206. And if I more dorste preye as now,</p>
<p>And chargen yow to have so greet travayle,</p>
<p>To han som of your bretheren here with yow,</p>
<p>That mighten to hir cause bet avayle,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1440</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page234">{234}</span>Than, woot I wel, she mighte
    never fayle</p>
<p>For to be holpen, what at your instaunce,</p>
<p>What with hir othere freendes governaunce.'</p>
<p class="stanza">207. Deiphebus, which that comen was, of kinde,</p>
<p>To al honour and bountee to consente,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1445</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Answerde, 'it shal be doon; and I can finde</p>
<p>Yet gretter help to this in myn entente.</p>
<p>What wolt thow seyn, if I for Eleyne sente</p>
<p>To speke of this? I trowe it be the beste;</p>
<p>For she may leden Paris as hir leste.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1450</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">208. Of Ector, which that is my lord, my brother,</p>
<p>It nedeth nought to preye him freend to be;</p>
<p>For I have herd him, o tyme and eek other,</p>
<p>Speke of Criseyde swich honour, that he</p>
<p>May seyn no bet, swich hap to him hath she.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1455</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">It nedeth nought his helpes for to crave;</p>
<p>He shal be swich, right as we wole him have.</p>
<p class="stanza">209. Spek thou thy-self also to Troilus</p>
<p>On my bihalve, and pray him with us dyne.'</p>
<p>'Sire, al this shal be doon,' quod Pandarus;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1460</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And took his leve, and never gan to fyne,</p>
<p>But to his neces hous, as streyt as lyne,</p>
<p>He com; and fond hir fro the mete aryse;</p>
<p>And sette him doun, and spak right in this wyse.</p>
<p class="stanza">210. He seyde, 'O veray god, so have I ronne!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1465</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Lo, nece myn, see ye nought how I swete?</p>
<p>I noot whether ye the more thank me conne.</p>
<p>Be ye nought war how that fals Poliphete</p>
<p>Is now aboute eft-sones for to plete,</p>
<p>And bringe on yow advocacyës newe?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1470</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'I? no,' quod she, and chaunged al hir hewe.</p>
<p class="stanza">211. 'What is he more aboute, me to drecche</p>
<p>And doon me wrong? what shal I do, allas?</p>
<p>Yet of him-self no-thing ne wolde I recche,</p>
<p>Nere it for Antenor and Eneas,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1475</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page235">{235}</span>That been his freendes in swich
    maner cas;</p>
<p>But, for the love of god, myn uncle dere,</p>
<p>No fors of that, lat him have al y-fere;</p>
<p class="stanza">212. With-outen that, I have ynough for us.'</p>
<p>'Nay,' quod Pandare, 'it shal no-thing be so.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1480</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For I have been right now at Deiphebus,</p>
<p>And Ector, and myne othere lordes mo,</p>
<p>And shortly maked eche of hem his fo;</p>
<p>That, by my thrift, he shal it never winne</p>
<p>For ought he can, whan that so he biginne.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1485</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">213. And as they casten what was best to done,</p>
<p>Deiphebus, of his owene curtasye,</p>
<p>Com hir to preye, in his propre persone,</p>
<p>To holde him on the morwe companye</p>
<p>At diner, which she nolde not denye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1490</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But goodly gan to his preyere obeye.</p>
<p>He thonked hir, and wente up-on his weye.</p>
<p class="stanza">214. Whanne this was doon, this Pandare up a-noon,</p>
<p>To telle in short, and forth gan for to wende</p>
<p>To Troilus, as stille as any stoon,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1495</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And al this thing he tolde him, <a href="#TIINL1495" id="TIIL1495" class="pginternal">word and
    ende</a>;</p>
<p>And how that he Deiphebus gan to blende;</p>
<p>And seyde him, 'now is tyme, if that thou conne,</p>
<p>To bere thee wel to-morwe, and al is wonne.</p>
<p class="stanza">215. Now spek, now prey, now pitously compleyne;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1500</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Lat not for nyce shame, or drede, or slouthe;</p>
<p>Som-tyme a man mot telle his owene peyne;</p>
<p>Bileve it, and she shal han on thee routhe;</p>
<p>Thou shalt be saved by thy feyth, in trouthe.</p>
<p>But wel wot I, thou art now in a drede;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1505</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And what it is, I leye, I can arede.</p>
<p class="stanza">216. Thow thinkest now, "how sholde I doon al this?</p>
<p>For by my cheres mosten folk aspye,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page236">{236}</span>That for hir love is that I fare a-mis;</p>
<p>Yet hadde I lever unwist for sorwe dye."</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1510</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Now thenk not so, for thou dost greet folye.</p>
<p>For right now have I founden o manere</p>
<p>Of sleighte, for to coveren al thy chere.</p>
<p class="stanza">217. Thow shall gon over night, and that as blyve,</p>
<p>Un-to Deiphebus hous, as thee to pleye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1515</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thy maladye a-wey the bet to dryve,</p>
<p>For-why thou semest syk, soth for to seye.</p>
<p>Sone after that, doun in thy bed thee leye,</p>
<p>And sey, thow mayst no lenger up endure,</p>
<p>And lye right there, and byde thyn aventure.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1520</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">218. Sey that thy fever is wont thee for to take</p>
<p>The same tyme, and lasten til a-morwe;</p>
<p>And lat see now how wel thou canst it make,</p>
<p>For, par-dee, syk is he that is in sorwe.</p>
<p>Go now, farewel! and, Venus here to borwe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1525</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I hope, and thou this purpos holde ferme,</p>
<p>Thy grace she shal fully ther conferme.'</p>
<p class="stanza">219. Quod Troilus, 'y-wis, thou nedelees</p>
<p>Counseylest me, that sykliche I me feyne!</p>
<p>For I am syk in ernest, doutelees,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1530</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">So that wel neigh I sterve for the peyne.'</p>
<p>Quod Pandarus, 'thou shalt the bettre pleyne,</p>
<p>And hast the lasse nede to countrefete;</p>
<p>For him men demen hoot that men seen swete.</p>
<p class="stanza">220. Lo, holde thee at thy <a href="#TIINL1534" id="TIIL1534" class="pginternal">triste</a>
    cloos, and I</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1535</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Shal wel the deer un-to thy bowe dryve.'</p>
<p>Therwith he took his leve al softely,</p>
<p>And Troilus to paleys wente blyve.</p>
<p>So glad ne was he never in al his lyve;</p>
<p>And to Pandarus reed gan al assente,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1540</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And to Deiphebus hous at night he wente.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page237">{237}</span>221. What nedeth yow to tellen
    al the chere</p>
<p>That Deiphebus un-to his brother made,</p>
<p>Or his accesse, or his syklych manere,</p>
<p>How men gan him with clothes for to lade,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1545</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Whan he was leyd, and how men wolde him glade?</p>
<p>But al for nought, he held forth ay the wyse</p>
<p>That ye han herd Pandare er this devyse.</p>
<p class="stanza">222. But certeyn is, er Troilus him leyde,</p>
<p>Deiphebus had him prayed, over night,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1550</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To been a freend and helping to Criseyde.</p>
<p>God woot, that he it grauntede anon-right,</p>
<p>To been hir fulle freend with al his might.</p>
<p>But swich a nede was to preye him thenne,</p>
<p>As for to bidde a wood man for to <a href="#TIINL1554" id="TIIL1554" class="pginternal">renne</a>.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1555</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">223. The morwen com, and neighen gan the tyme</p>
<p>Of meel-tyd, that the faire quene Eleyne</p>
<p>Shoop hir to been, an houre after the pryme,</p>
<p>With Deiphebus, to whom she nolde feyne;</p>
<p>But as his suster, hoomly, sooth to seyne,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1560</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">She com to diner in hir playn entente.</p>
<p>But god and Pandare wiste al what this mente.</p>
<p class="stanza">224. Come eek Criseyde, al innocent of this,</p>
<p>Antigone, hir sister Tarbe also;</p>
<p>But flee we now <a href="#TIINL1564" id="TIIL1564" class="pginternal">prolixitee</a> best is,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1565</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For love of god, and lat us faste go</p>
<p>Right to the effect, with-oute tales mo,</p>
<p>Why al this folk assembled in this place;</p>
<p>And lat us of hir saluinges pace.</p>
<p class="stanza">225. Gret honour dide hem Deiphebus, certeyn,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1570</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And fedde hem wel with al that mighte lyke.</p>
<p>But ever-more, 'allas!' was his refreyn,</p>
<p>'My goode brother Troilus, the syke,</p>
<p>Lyth yet'—and therwith-al he gan to syke;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page238">{238}</span>And after that, he peyned him to glade</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1575</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Hem as he mighte, and chere good he made.</p>
<p class="stanza">226. Compleyned eek Eleyne of his syknesse</p>
<p>So feithfully, that pitee was to here,</p>
<p>And every wight gan waxen for accesse</p>
<p>A leche anoon, and seyde, 'in this manere</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1580</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Men curen folk; this charme I wol yow lere.'</p>
<p>But there sat oon, al list hir nought <a href="#TIINL1581" id="TIIL1581" class="pginternal">to teche</a>,</p>
<p>That thoughte, best coude I yet been his leche.</p>
<p class="stanza">227. After compleynt, him gonnen they to preyse,</p>
<p>As folk don yet, whan som wight hath bigonne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1585</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To preyse a man, and up with prys him reyse</p>
<p>A thousand fold yet hyer than the sonne:—</p>
<p>'He is, he can, that fewe lordes conne.'</p>
<p>And Pandarus, of that they wolde afferme,</p>
<p>He not for-gat hir preysing to conferme.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1590</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">228. Herde al this thing Criseyde wel y-nough,</p>
<p>And every word gan for to notifye;</p>
<p>For which with sobre chere hir herte lough;</p>
<p>For who is that ne wolde hir glorifye,</p>
<p><a href="#TIINL1594" id="TIIL1594" class="pginternal">To mowen</a> swich a knight don live or dye?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1595</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But al passe I, lest ye to longe dwelle;</p>
<p>For for o fyn is al that ever I telle.</p>
<p class="stanza">229. The tyme com, fro diner for to ryse,</p>
<p>And, as hem oughte, arisen everychoon,</p>
<p>And gonne a while of this and that devyse.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1600</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But Pandarus brak al this speche anoon,</p>
<p>And seyde to Deiphebus, 'wole ye goon,</p>
<p>If yourë wille be, as I yow preyde,</p>
<p>To speke here of the nedes of Criseyde?'</p>
<p class="stanza">230. Eleyne, which that by the hond hir held,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1605</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Took first the tale, and seyde, 'go we blyve;'</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page239">{239}</span>And goodly on Criseyde she biheld,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'Ioves lat him never thryve,</p>
<p>That dooth yow harm, and bringe him sone of lyve!</p>
<p>And yeve me sorwe, but he shal it rewe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1610</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">If that I may, and alle folk be trewe.'</p>
<p class="stanza">231. 'Tel thou thy neces cas,' quod Deiphebus</p>
<p>To Pandarus, 'for thou canst best it telle.'—</p>
<p>'My lordes and my ladyes, it stant thus;</p>
<p>What sholde I lenger,' quod he, 'do yow dwelle?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1615</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He rong hem out a proces lyk a belle,</p>
<p>Up-on hir fo, that highte Poliphete,</p>
<p>So hëynous, that men mighte on it spete.</p>
<p class="stanza">232. Answerde of this ech worse of hem than other,</p>
<p>And Poliphete they gonnen thus to warien,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1620</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'An-honged be swich oon, were he my brother;</p>
<p>And so he shal, for it ne may not varien.'</p>
<p>What sholde I lenger in this tale tarien?</p>
<p>Pleynly, alle at ones, they hir highten,</p>
<p>To been hir helpe in al that ever they mighten.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1625</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">233. Spak than Eleyne, and seyde, 'Pandarus,</p>
<p>Woot ought my lord, my brother, this matere,</p>
<p>I mene, Ector? or woot it Troilus?'</p>
<p>He seyde, 'ye, but wole ye now me here?</p>
<p>Me thinketh this, sith Troilus is here,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1630</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">It were good, if that ye wolde assente,</p>
<p>She tolde hir-self him al this, er she wente.</p>
<p class="stanza">234. For he wole have the more hir grief at herte,</p>
<p>By cause, lo, that she a lady is;</p>
<p>And, by your leve, I wol but right in sterte,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1635</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And do yow wite, and that anoon, y-wis,</p>
<p>If that he slepe, or wole ought here of this.'</p>
<p>And in he lepte, and seyde him in his ere,</p>
<p>'God have thy soule, y-brought have I thy bere!'</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page240">{240}</span>235. To smylen of this gan tho
    Troilus,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1640</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And Pandarus, with-oute rekeninge,</p>
<p>Out wente anoon to Eleyne and Deiphebus,</p>
<p>And seyde hem, 'so there be no taryinge,</p>
<p>Ne more pres, he wol wel that ye bringe</p>
<p>Crisëyda, my lady, that is here;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1645</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And as he may enduren, he wole here.</p>
<p class="stanza">236. But wel ye woot, the chaumbre is but lyte,</p>
<p>And fewe folk may lightly make it warm;</p>
<p>Now loketh ye, (for I wol have no wyte,</p>
<p>To bringe in prees that mighte doon him harm</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1650</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Or him disesen, <a href="#TIINL1650" id="TIIL1650" class="pginternal">for my bettre arm</a>),</p>
<p>Wher it be bet she byde til eft-sones;</p>
<p>Now loketh ye, that knowen what to doon is.</p>
<p class="stanza">237. I sey for me, best is, as I can knowe,</p>
<p>That no wight in ne wente but ye tweye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1655</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But it were I, for I can, in a throwe,</p>
<p>Reherce hir cas, unlyk that she can seye;</p>
<p>And after this, she may him ones preye</p>
<p>To ben good lord, in short, and take hir leve;</p>
<p>This may not muchel of his ese him reve.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1660</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">238. And eek, for she is straunge, he wol forbere</p>
<p>His ese, which that <a href="#TIINL1661" id="TIIL1661" class="pginternal">him thar nought</a> for yow;</p>
<p>Eek other thing, that toucheth not to here,</p>
<p>He wol me telle, I woot it wel right now,</p>
<p>That secret is, and for the tounes prow.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1665</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And they, that no-thing knewe of this entente,</p>
<p>With-oute more, to Troilus in they wente.</p>
<p class="stanza">239. Eleyne in al hir goodly softe wyse,</p>
<p>Gan him saluwe, and womanly to pleye,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'ywis, ye moste alweyes aryse!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1670</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Now fayre brother, beth al hool, I preye!'</p>
<p>And gan hir arm right over his sholder leye,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page241">{241}</span>And him with al hir wit to recomforte;</p>
<p>As she best coude, she gan him to disporte.</p>
<p class="stanza">240. So after this quod she, 'we yow biseke,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1675</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">My dere brother, Deiphebus, and I,</p>
<p>For love of god, and so doth Pandare eke,</p>
<p>To been good lord and freend, right hertely,</p>
<p>Un-to Criseyde, which that certeinly</p>
<p>Receyveth wrong, as woot wel here Pandare,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1680</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That can hir cas wel bet than I declare.'</p>
<p class="stanza">241. This Pandarus gan newe his tunge affyle,</p>
<p>And al hir cas reherce, and that anoon;</p>
<p>Whan it was seyd, sone after, in a whyle,</p>
<p>Quod Troilus, 'as sone as I may goon,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1685</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I wol right fayn with al my might ben oon,</p>
<p>Have god my trouthe, hir cause to sustene.'</p>
<p>'Good thrift have ye,' quod Eleyne the quene.</p>
<p class="stanza">242. Quod Pandarus, 'and it your wille be,</p>
<p>That she may take hir leve, er that she go?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1690</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'Or elles god for-bede,' tho quod he,</p>
<p>'If that she vouche sauf for to do so.'</p>
<p>And with that word quod Troilus, 'ye two,</p>
<p>Deiphebus, and my suster leef and dere,</p>
<p>To yow have I to speke of o matere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1695</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">243. To been avysed by your reed the bettre':—</p>
<p>And fond, as hap was, at his beddes heed,</p>
<p>The copie of a tretis and a lettre,</p>
<p>That Ector hadde him sent to axen reed,</p>
<p>If swich a man was worthy to ben deed,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1700</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Woot I nought who; but in a grisly wyse</p>
<p>He preyede hem anoon on it avyse.</p>
<p class="stanza">244. Deiphebus gan this lettre to unfolde</p>
<p>In ernest greet; so dide Eleyne the quene;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page242">{242}</span>And rominge outward, fast it gan biholde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1705</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Downward a steyre, in-to an herber grene.</p>
<p>This ilke thing they redden hem bi-twene;</p>
<p>And largely, the mountaunce of an houre,</p>
<p>They gonne on it to reden and to poure.</p>
<p class="stanza">245. Now lat hem rede, and turne we anoon</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1710</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To Pandarus, that gan ful faste prye</p>
<p>That al was wel, and out he gan to goon</p>
<p>In-to the grete chambre, and that in hye,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'god save al this companye!</p>
<p>Com, nece myn; my lady quene Eleyne</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1715</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Abydeth yow, and eek my lordes tweyne.</p>
<p class="stanza">246. Rys, take with yow your nece Antigone,</p>
<p>Or whom yow list, or no fors, hardily;</p>
<p>The lasse prees, the bet; com forth with me,</p>
<p>And loke that ye thonke humblely</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1720</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Hem alle three, and, whan ye may goodly</p>
<p>Your tyme y-see, taketh of hem your leve,</p>
<p>Lest we to longe his restes him bireve.'</p>
<p class="stanza">247. Al innocent of Pandarus entente,</p>
<p>Quod tho Criseyde, 'go we, uncle dere';</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1725</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And arm in arm inward with him she wente,</p>
<p>Avysed wel hir wordes and hir chere;</p>
<p>And Pandarus, in ernestful manere,</p>
<p>Seyde, 'alle folk, for goddes love, I preye,</p>
<p>Stinteth right here, and softely yow pleye.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1730</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">248. Aviseth yow what folk ben here with-inne,</p>
<p>And in what plyt oon is, god him amende!</p>
<p>And inward thus ful softely biginne;</p>
<p>Nece, I coniure and heighly yow defende,</p>
<p>On his half, which that sowle us alle sende,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1735</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And in the vertue of <a href="#TIINL1735" id="TIIL1735" class="pginternal">corounes
    tweyne</a>,</p>
<p>Slee nought this man, that hath for yow this peyne!</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page243">{243}</span>249. <a href="#TIINL1737" id="TIIL1737" class="pginternal">Fy on the devel</a>! thenk which oon he is,</p>
<p>And in what plyt he lyth; <a href="#TIINL1738" id="TIIL1738" class="pginternal">com of</a> anoon;</p>
<p>Thenk al swich taried tyd, but lost it nis!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1740</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That wol ye bothe seyn, whan ye ben oon.</p>
<p>Secoundelich, ther yet devyneth noon</p>
<p>Up-on yow two; com of now, if ye conne;</p>
<p>Whyl folk is blent, lo, al the tyme is wonne!</p>
<p class="stanza">250. In titering, and pursuite, and delayes,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1745</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The folk devyne at wagginge of a stree;</p>
<p>And though ye wolde han after merye dayes,</p>
<p>Than dar ye nought, and why? for she, and she</p>
<p>Spak swich a word; thus loked he, and he;</p>
<p>Lest tyme I loste, I dar not with yow dele;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1750</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Com of therfore, and bringeth him to hele.'</p>
<p class="stanza">251. But now <a href="#TIINL1751" id="TIIL1751" class="pginternal">to yow</a>, ye lovers that ben
    here,</p>
<p>Was Troilus nought in a <a href="#TIINL1752" id="TIIL1752" class="pginternal">cankedort</a>,</p>
<p>That lay, and mighte whispringe of hem here,</p>
<p>And thoughte, 'O lord, right now renneth my sort</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1755</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Fully to dye, or han anoon comfort';</p>
<p>And was the firste tyme he shulde hir preye</p>
<p>Of love; O mighty god, what shal he seye?</p>
</div>

<div><span class="pagenum" id="page244">{244}</span></div>
<h2 class="sp3 ac" style="margin-bottom:2.1ex;"> <span class="larger">BOOK III.</span></h2>
<p class="ac"><b>Incipit Prohemium Tercii Libri.</b></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#TIIINL1" id="TIIIL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. O Blisful light, of whiche the bemes
    clere</p>
<p>Adorneth al the <a href="#TIIINL2" id="TIIIL2" class="pginternal">thridde hevene</a> faire!</p>
<p>O <a href="#TIIINL3" id="TIIIL3" class="pginternal">sonnes leef</a>, O Ioves doughter dere,</p>
<p>Plesaunce of love, O goodly debonaire,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">In gentil hertes ay redy to repaire!</p>
<p>O verray cause of hele and of gladnesse,</p>
<p>Y-heried be thy might and thy goodnesse!</p>
<p class="stanza">2. In hevene and helle, in erthe and salte see</p>
<p>Is felt thy might, if that I wel descerne;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As man, brid, best, fish, herbe and grene tree</p>
<p>Thee fele in tymes with <a href="#TIIINL11" id="TIIIL11" class="pginternal">vapour</a> eterne.</p>
<p>God loveth, and to love wol nought werne;</p>
<p>And in this world no lyves creature,</p>
<p>With-outen love, is worth, or may endure.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">15</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">3. Ye Ioves first to thilke effectes glade,</p>
<p>Thorugh which that thinges liven alle and be,</p>
<p><a href="#TIIINL15" id="TIIIL15" class="pginternal">Comeveden</a>, and amorous <a href="#TIIINL15" class="pginternal">him</a>
    made</p>
<p>On mortal thing, and as yow list, ay ye</p>
<p>Yeve him in love ese or adversitee;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And in a thousand formes doun him sente</p>
<p>For love in erthe, and whom yow liste, he hente.</p>
<p class="stanza">4. Ye fierse <a href="#TIIINL22" id="TIIIL22" class="pginternal">Mars</a> apeysen of his ire,</p>
<p>And, as yow list, ye maken hertes digne;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page245">{245}</span>Algates, hem that ye wol sette a-fyre,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">They dreden shame, and vices they resigne;</p>
<p>Ye do hem corteys be, fresshe and benigne,</p>
<p>And hye or lowe, after a wight <a href="#TIIINL27" id="TIIIL27" class="pginternal">entendeth</a>;</p>
<p>The Ioyes that he hath, your might him sendeth.</p>
<p class="stanza">5. <a href="#TIIINL29" id="TIIIL29" class="pginternal">Ye holden regne</a> and hous in
    unitee;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ye soothfast cause of frendship been also;</p>
<p><a href="#TIIINL31" id="TIIIL31" class="pginternal">Ye knowe</a> al thilke covered qualitee</p>
<p>Of thinges which that folk on wondren so,</p>
<p>Whan they can not construe how it may <a href="#TIIINL31" class="pginternal">io</a>,</p>
<p>She loveth him, or why he loveth here;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As why this fish, and nought that, cometh to <a href="#TIIINL35" id="TIIIL35" class="pginternal">were</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza">6. Ye folk a lawe <a href="#TIIINL36" id="TIIIL36" class="pginternal">han set</a> in
    universe,</p>
<p>And this knowe I by hem that loveres be,</p>
<p>That who-so stryveth with yow hath the werse:</p>
<p>Now, lady bright, for thy benignitee,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">At reverence of hem that serven thee,</p>
<p>Whos clerk I am, so techeth me devyse</p>
<p>Som Ioye of that is felt in thy servyse.</p>
<p class="stanza">7. Ye in my naked herte sentement</p>
<p><a href="#TIIINL44" id="TIIIL44" class="pginternal">Inhelde</a>, and do me shewe of thy swetnesse.—</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#TIIINL44" class="pginternal">Caliope</a>, thy vois be now present,</p>
<p>For now is nede; sestow not my destresse,</p>
<p>How I mot telle anon-right the gladnesse</p>
<p>Of Troilus, to Venus heryinge?</p>
<p>To which gladnes, who nede hath, god him bringe!</p>
</div>
<p class="sp3 ac"><b>Explicit prohemium Tercii Libri.</b></p>
<p class="ac"><b>Incipit Liber Tercius.</b></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">50</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">8. Lay al this mene whyle Troilus,</p>
<p>Recordinge his lessoun in this manere,</p>
<p>'Ma fey!' thought he, 'thus wole I seye and thus;</p>
<p>Thus wole I pleyne un-to my lady dere;</p>
<p>That word is good, and this shal be my chere;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page246">{246}</span>This nil I not foryeten in no
    wyse.'</p>
<p>God leve him werken as he gan devyse.</p>
<p class="stanza">9. And lord, so that his herte gan to quappe,</p>
<p>Heringe hir come, and shorte for to syke!</p>
<p>And Pandarus, that ladde hir by the lappe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Com ner, and gan in at the curtin pyke,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'god do bote on alle syke!</p>
<p>See, who is here yow comen to visyte;</p>
<p>Lo, here is she that is your deeth to wyte.'</p>
<p class="stanza">10. Ther-with it semed as he wepte almost;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'A ha,' quod Troilus so rewfully,</p>
<p>'Wher me be wo, O mighty god, thou wost!</p>
<p>Who is al there? I see nought trewely.'</p>
<p>'Sire,' quod Criseyde, 'it is Pandare and I.'</p>
<p>'Ye, swete herte? allas, I may nought ryse</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To knele, and do yow honour in som wyse.'</p>
<p class="stanza">11. And dressede him upward, and she right tho</p>
<p>Gan bothe here hondes softe upon him leye,</p>
<p>'O, for the love of god, do ye not so</p>
<p>To me,' quod she, 'ey! what is this to seye?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Sire, come am I to yow for causes tweye;</p>
<p>First, yow to thonke, and of your lordshipe eke</p>
<p>Continuaunce I wolde yow biseke.'</p>
<p class="stanza">12. This Troilus, that herde his lady preye</p>
<p>Of lordship him, wex neither quik ne deed,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ne mighte a word for shame to it seye,</p>
<p>Al-though men sholde smyten of his heed.</p>
<p>But lord, so he wex sodeinliche reed,</p>
<p>And sire, his lesson, that he wende conne,</p>
<p>To preyen hir, is thurgh his wit y-ronne.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">85</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">13. Cryseyde al this aspyede wel y-nough,</p>
<p>For she was wys, and lovede him never-the-lasse,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page247">{247}</span>Al nere he <a href="#TIIINL87" id="TIIIL87" class="pginternal">malapert</a>, or made it tough,</p>
<p>Or was to bold, to singe a fool a masse.</p>
<p>But whan his shame gan somwhat to passe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">His resons, as I may my rymes holde,</p>
<p>I yow wol telle, as techen bokes olde.</p>
<p class="stanza">14. In chaunged vois, right for his verrey drede,</p>
<p>Which vois eek quook, and ther-to his manere</p>
<p>Goodly abayst, and now his hewes rede,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Now pale, un-to Criseyde, his lady dere,</p>
<p>With look doun cast and humble yolden chere,</p>
<p>Lo, the alderfirste word that him asterte</p>
<p>Was, twyes, 'mercy, mercy, swete herte!'</p>
<p class="stanza">15. And stinte a whyl, and whan he mighte out-bringe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The nexte word was, 'god wot, for I have,</p>
<p>As feythfully as I have had konninge,</p>
<p>Ben youres, also god my sowle save;</p>
<p>And shal, til that I, woful wight, be grave.</p>
<p>And though I dar ne can un-to yow pleyne,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Y-wis, I suffre nought the lasse peyne.</p>
<p class="stanza">16. Thus muche as now, O wommanliche wyf,</p>
<p>I may out-bringe, and if this yow displese,</p>
<p>That shal I wreke upon myn owne lyf</p>
<p>Right sone, I trowe, and doon your herte an ese,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">If with my deeth your herte I may apese.</p>
<p>But sin that ye han herd me som-what seye,</p>
<p>Now recche I never how sone that I deye.'</p>
<p class="stanza">17. Ther-with his manly sorwe to biholde,</p>
<p>It mighte han maad an herte of stoon to rewe;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And Pandare weep as he <a href="#TIIINL115" id="TIIIL115" class="pginternal">to watre
    wolde</a>,</p>
<p>And poked ever his nece newe and newe,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'wo bigon ben hertes trewe!</p>
<p>For love of god, make of this thing an ende,</p>
<p>Or slee us bothe at ones, er that ye wende.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">120</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page248">{248}</span>18. <a href="#TIIINL120" id="TIIIL120" class="pginternal">'I? what?'</a> quod she, 'by god and by my trouthe,</p>
<p>I noot nought what ye wilne that I seye.'</p>
<p>'I? what?' quod he, 'that ye han on him routhe,</p>
<p>For goddes love, and doth him nought to deye.'</p>
<p>'Now thanne thus,' quod she, 'I wolde him preye</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To telle me the fyn of his entente;</p>
<p>Yet wiste I never wel what that he mente.'</p>
<p class="stanza">19. 'What that I mene, O swete herte dere?'</p>
<p>Quod Troilus, 'O goodly fresshe free!</p>
<p>That, with the stremes of your eyen clere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ye wolde som-tyme freendly on me see,</p>
<p>And thanne agreën that I may ben he,</p>
<p>With-oute braunche of vyce in any wyse,</p>
<p>In trouthe alwey to doon yow my servyse</p>
<p class="stanza">20. As to my lady right and chief resort,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">135</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">With al my wit and al my diligence,</p>
<p><a href="#TIIINL136" id="TIIIL136" class="pginternal">And I to han</a>, right as yow list, comfort,</p>
<p>Under your yerde, egal to myn offence,</p>
<p>As deeth, if that I breke your defence;</p>
<p>And that ye deigne me so muche honoure,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Me to comaunden ought in any houre.</p>
<p class="stanza">21. And I to ben your verray humble trewe,</p>
<p>Secret, and in my paynes pacient,</p>
<p>And ever-mo desire freshly newe,</p>
<p>To serven, and been y-lyke ay diligent,</p>
