<p class="lined">Whan that she hereth <a href="#TIIINL1235" id="TIIIL1235" class="pginternal">any herde
    tale</a>,</p>
<p>Or in the hegges any wight steringe,</p>
<p>And after siker dooth hir voys out-ringe;</p>
<p>Right so Criseyde, whan hir drede stente,</p>
<p>Opned hir herte, and tolde him hir entente.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1240</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">178. And right as he that seeth his deeth y-shapen,</p>
<p>And deye moot, in ought that he may gesse,</p>
<p>And sodeynly rescous doth him escapen,</p>
<p>And from his deeth is brought in sikernesse,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page283">{283}</span>For al this world, in swich present
    gladnesse</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1245</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Was Troilus, and hath his lady swete;</p>
<p>With worse hap god lat us never mete!</p>
<p class="stanza">179. Hir armes smale, hir streyghte bak and softe,</p>
<p>Hir sydes longe, fleshly, smothe, and whyte</p>
<p>He gan to stroke, and <a href="#TIIINL1249" id="TIIIL1249" class="pginternal">good thrift bad ful ofte</a></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1250</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Hir snowish throte, hir brestes rounde and lyte;</p>
<p>Thus in this hevene he gan him to delyte,</p>
<p>And ther-with-al a thousand tyme hir kiste;</p>
<p>That, what to done, for Ioye unnethe he wiste.</p>
<p class="stanza">180. Than seyde he thus, 'O, Love, O, Charitee,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1255</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thy moder eek, Citherea the swete,</p>
<p>After thy-self next heried be she,</p>
<p>Venus mene I, the <a href="#TIIINL1257" id="TIIIL1257" class="pginternal">wel-willy</a> planete;</p>
<p>And next that, <a href="#TIIINL1258" id="TIIIL1258" class="pginternal">Imenëus</a>, I thee grete;</p>
<p>For never man was to yow goddes holde</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1260</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As I, which ye han brought fro cares colde.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TIIINL1261" id="TIIIL1261" class="pginternal">181</a>. Benigne Love, thou holy bond of
    thinges,</p>
<p>Who-so wol grace, and list thee nought honouren,</p>
<p>Lo, his desyr wol flee with-outen winges.</p>
<p>For, noldestow of bountee hem socouren</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1265</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That serven best and most alwey labouren,</p>
<p>Yet were al lost, that dar I wel seyn, certes,</p>
<p>But-if thy grace passed our desertes.</p>
<p class="stanza">182. And for thou me, that coude leest deserve</p>
<p>Of hem that nombred been un-to thy grace,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1270</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Hast holpen, ther I lykly was to sterve,</p>
<p>And me bistowed in so heygh a place</p>
<p>That thilke boundes may no blisse pace,</p>
<p>I can no more, but laude and reverence</p>
<p>Be to thy bounte and thyn excellence!'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1275</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page284">{284}</span>183. And therwith-al
    Criseyde anoon he kiste,</p>
<p>Of which, certeyn, she felte no disese.</p>
<p>And thus seyde he, 'now wolde god I wiste,</p>
<p>Myn herte swete, how I yow mighte plese!</p>
<p>What man,' quod he, 'was ever thus at ese</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1280</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As I, on whiche the faireste and the beste</p>
<p>That ever I say, deyneth hir herte reste.</p>
<p class="stanza">184. Here may men seen that <a href="#TIIINL1282" id="TIIIL1282" class="pginternal">mercy passeth
    right</a>;</p>
<p>The experience of that is felt in me,</p>
<p>That am unworthy to so swete a wight.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1285</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But herte myn, of your benignitee,</p>
<p>So thenketh, though that I unworthy be,</p>
<p>Yet mot I nede amenden in som wyse,</p>
<p>Right thourgh the vertu of your heyghe servyse.</p>
<p class="stanza">185. And for the love of god, my lady dere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1290</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Sin god hath wrought me for I shal yow serve,</p>
<p>As thus I mene, that ye wol be my stere,</p>
<p>To do me live, if that yow liste, or sterve,</p>
<p>So techeth me how that I may deserve</p>
<p>Your thank, so that I, thurgh myn ignoraunce,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1295</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ne do no-thing that yow be displesaunce.</p>
<p class="stanza">186. For certes, fresshe wommanliche wyf,</p>
<p>This dar I seye, that trouthe and diligence,</p>
<p>That shal ye finden in me al my lyf,</p>
<p>Ne I wol not, certeyn, breken your defence;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1300</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And if I do, present or in absence,</p>
<p>For love of god, lat slee me with the dede,</p>
<p>If that it lyke un-to your womanhede.'</p>
<p class="stanza">187. 'Y-wis,' quod she, 'myn owne hertes list,</p>
<p>My ground of ese, and al myn herte dere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1305</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page285">{285}</span>Graunt mercy, for on that is al
    my trist;</p>
<p>But late us falle awey fro this matere;</p>
<p>For it suffyseth, this that seyd is here.</p>
<p>And at o word, with-outen repentaunce,</p>
<p>Wel-come, my knight, my pees, my suffisaunce!'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1310</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">188. Of hir delyt, or Ioyes oon the leste</p>
<p>Were impossible to my wit to seye;</p>
<p>But iuggeth, ye that han ben at the feste,</p>
<p>Of swich gladnesse, if that hem liste pleye!</p>
<p>I can no more, but thus thise ilke tweye</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1315</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That night, be-twixen dreed and sikernesse,</p>
<p>Felten in love the grete worthinesse.</p>
<p class="stanza">189. O blisful night, of hem so longe y-sought,</p>
<p>How blithe un-to hem bothe two thou were!</p>
<p>Why ne hadde I swich on with my soule y-bought,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1320</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ye, or the leeste Ioye that was there?</p>
<p>A-wey, thou foule daunger and thou fere,</p>
<p>And lat hem in this hevene blisse dwelle,</p>
<p>That is so heygh, that al ne can I telle!</p>
<p class="stanza">190. But sooth is, though I can not tellen al,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1325</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As can myn auctor, of his excellence,</p>
<p>Yet have I seyd, and, god to-forn, I shal</p>
<p>In every thing al hoolly his sentence.</p>
<p>And if that I, at loves reverence,</p>
<p>Have any word in eched for the beste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1330</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Doth therwith-al right as your-selven leste.</p>
<p class="stanza">191. For myne wordes, here and every part,</p>
<p>I speke hem alle under correccioun</p>
<p>Of yow, that feling han in loves art,</p>
<p>And putte it al in your discrecioun</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1335</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To encrese or maken diminucioun</p>
<p>Of my langage, and that I yow bi-seche;</p>
<p>But now to purpos of my rather speche.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page286">{286}</span>192. Thise ilke two, that ben
    in armes laft,</p>
<p>So looth to hem a-sonder goon it were,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1340</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That ech from other wende been biraft,</p>
<p>Or elles, lo, this was hir moste fere,</p>
<p>That al this thing but nyce dremes were;</p>
<p>For which ful ofte ech of hem seyde, 'O swete,</p>
<p>Clippe ich yow thus, or <a href="#TIIINL1344" id="TIIIL1344" class="pginternal">elles I it mete</a>?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1345</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">193. And, lord! so he gan goodly on hir see,</p>
<p>That never his look ne bleynte from hir face,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'O dere herte, may it be</p>
<p>That it be sooth, that ye ben in this place?'</p>
<p>'Ye, herte myn, god thank I of his grace!'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1350</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Quod tho Criseyde, and therwith-al him kiste,</p>
<p>That where his spirit was, for Ioye he niste.</p>
<p class="stanza">194. This Troilus ful ofte hir eyen two</p>
<p>Gan for to kisse, and seyde, 'O eyen clere,</p>
<p>It were ye that wroughte me swich wo,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1355</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ye humble nettes of my lady dere!</p>
<p>Though ther be mercy writen in your chere,</p>
<p>God wot, the text ful hard is, <a href="#TIIINL1357" id="TIIIL1357" class="pginternal">sooth</a>, to finde,</p>
<p>How coude ye with-outen bond me binde?'</p>
<p class="stanza">195. Therwith he gan hir faste in armes take,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1360</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And wel an hundred tymes gan he syke,</p>
<p>Nought swiche sorwful sykes as men make</p>
<p>For wo, or elles whan that folk ben syke,</p>
<p>But esy sykes, swiche as been to lyke,</p>
<p>That shewed his affeccioun with-inne;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1365</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Of swiche sykes coude he nought bilinne.</p>
<p class="stanza">196. Sone after this they speke of sondry thinges,</p>
<p>As fil to purpos of this aventure,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page287">{287}</span>And pleyinge entrechaungeden hir ringes,</p>
<p>Of which I can nought tellen no <a href="#TIIINL1369" id="TIIIL1369" class="pginternal">scripture</a>;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1370</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But wel I woot a broche, gold and asure,</p>
<p>In whiche a ruby set was lyk an herte,</p>
<p>Criseyde him yaf, and stak it on his sherte.</p>
<p class="stanza">197. Lord! trowe ye, a coveitous, a wrecche,</p>
<p>That blameth love and <a href="#TIIINL1374" id="TIIIL1374" class="pginternal">holt</a> of it despyt,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1375</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That, <a href="#TIIINL1375" id="TIIIL1375" class="pginternal">of tho pens</a> that he can mokre
    and kecche,</p>
<p>Was ever yet y-yeve him swich delyt,</p>
<p>As is in love, in oo poynt, in som plyt?</p>
<p>Nay, doutelees, for also god me save,</p>
<p>So parfit Ioye may no nigard have!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1380</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">198. They wol sey 'yis,' but lord! so that they lye,</p>
<p>Tho bisy wrecches, ful of wo and drede!</p>
<p>They callen love a woodnesse or folye,</p>
<p>But it shal falle hem as I shal yow rede;</p>
<p>They shul forgo the <a href="#TIIINL1384" id="TIIIL1384" class="pginternal">whyte</a> and eke the <a href="#TIIINL1384" class="pginternal">rede</a>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1385</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And live in wo, ther god yeve hem mischaunce,</p>
<p>And every lover in his trouthe avaunce!</p>
<p class="stanza">199. As wolde god, tho wrecches, that dispyse</p>
<p>Servyse of love, hadde eres al-so longe</p>
<p>As hadde <a href="#TIIINL1389" id="TIIIL1389" class="pginternal">Myda</a>, ful of coveityse;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1390</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And ther-to dronken hadde as hoot and stronge</p>
<p>As <a href="#TIIINL1391" id="TIIIL1391" class="pginternal">Crassus</a> dide for his affectis wronge,</p>
<p>To techen hem that they ben in the vyce,</p>
<p>And loveres nought, al-though they holde hem nyce!</p>
<p class="stanza">200. Thise ilke two, of whom that I yow seye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1395</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Whan that hir hertes wel assured were,</p>
<p>Tho gonne they to speken and to pleye,</p>
<p>And eek rehercen how, and whanne, and where,</p>
<p>They knewe hem first, and every wo and fere</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page288">{288}</span>That passed was; but al swich hevinesse,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1400</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I thanke it god, was tourned to gladnesse.</p>
<p class="stanza">201. And ever-mo, whan that hem fel to speke</p>
<p>Of any thing of swich a tyme agoon,</p>
<p>With kissing al that tale sholde breke,</p>
<p>And fallen in a newe Ioye anoon,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1405</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And diden al hir might, sin they were oon,</p>
<p>For to recoveren blisse and been at ese,</p>
<p>And passed wo with Ioye <a href="#TIIINL1407" id="TIIIL1407" class="pginternal">countrepeyse</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza">202. Reson wil not that I speke of sleep,</p>
<p>For it accordeth nought to my matere;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1410</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">God woot, they toke of that ful litel keep,</p>
<p>But lest this night, that was to hem so dere,</p>
<p>Ne sholde in veyn escape in no manere,</p>
<p>It was biset in Ioye and bisinesse</p>
<p>Of al that souneth in-to gentilnesse.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1415</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">203. But whan the cok, <a href="#TIIINL1415" id="TIIIL1415" class="pginternal">comune
    astrologer</a>,</p>
<p>Gan on his brest to bete, and after crowe,</p>
<p>And <a href="#TIIINL1417" id="TIIIL1417" class="pginternal">Lucifer</a>, the dayes messager,</p>
<p>Gan for to ryse, and out hir bemes throwe;</p>
<p>And estward roos, to him that coude it knowe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1420</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#TIIINL1417" class="pginternal"><i>Fortuna maior</i></a>, [than] anoon Criseyde,</p>
<p>With herte sore, to Troilus thus seyde:—</p>
<p class="stanza">204. 'Myn hertes lyf, my trist and my plesaunce,</p>
<p>That I was born, allas! what me is wo,</p>
<p>That day of us mot make desseveraunce!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1425</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For tyme it is to ryse, and hennes go,</p>
<p>Or elles I am lost for evermo!</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page289">{289}</span>O night, allas! why niltow over us hove,</p>
<p>As longe as whanne <a href="#TIIINL1428" id="TIIIL1428" class="pginternal">Almena</a> lay by Iove?</p>
<p class="stanza">205. O blake night, as folk in bokes rede,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1430</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That shapen art by god this world to hyde</p>
<p>At certeyn tymes with thy derke wede,</p>
<p>That under that men mighte in reste abyde,</p>
<p>Wel oughte bestes pleyne, and folk thee chyde,</p>
<p>That there-as day with labour wolde us breste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1435</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That thou thus fleest, and deynest us nought reste!</p>
<p class="stanza">206. Thou dost, allas! to shortly thyn offyce,</p>
<p>Thou rakel night, <a href="#TIIINL1437" id="TIIIL1437" class="pginternal">ther</a> god, makere of kinde,</p>
<p>Thee, for thyn hast and thyn unkinde vyce,</p>
<p>So faste ay to our hemi-spere binde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1440</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That never-more under the ground thou winde!</p>
<p>For now, for thou so hyest out of Troye,</p>
<p>Have I forgon thus hastily my Ioye!'</p>
<p class="stanza">207. This Troilus, that with tho wordes felte,</p>
<p>As thoughte him tho, for pietous distresse,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1445</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The blody teres from his herte melte,</p>
<p>As he that never yet swich hevinesse</p>
<p>Assayed hadde, out of so greet gladnesse,</p>
<p>Gan therwith-al Criseyde his lady dere</p>
<p>In armes streyne, and seyde in this manere:—</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1450</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">208. 'O cruel day, accusour of the Ioye</p>
<p>That night and love han stole and faste y-wryen,</p>
<p>A-cursed be thy coming in-to Troye,</p>
<p>For every <a href="#TIIINL1453" id="TIIIL1453" class="pginternal">bore</a> hath oon of thy bright yën!</p>
<p>Envyous day, what list thee so to spyen?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1455</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">What hastow lost, why sekestow this place,</p>
<p>Ther god thy lyght so quenche, for his grace?</p>
<p class="stanza">209. Allas! what han thise loveres thee agilt,</p>
<p>Dispitous day? thyn be the pyne of helle!</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page290">{290}</span>For many a lovere hastow shent, and wilt;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1460</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thy pouring in wol no-wher lete hem dwelle.</p>
<p>What proferestow thy light here for to selle?</p>
<p>Go selle it hem that <a href="#TIIINL1462" id="TIIIL1462" class="pginternal">smale seles graven</a>,</p>
<p>We wol thee nought, us nedeth no day haven.'</p>
<p class="stanza">210. And eek the sonne <a href="#TIIINL1464" id="TIIIL1464" class="pginternal">Tytan</a> gan he
    chyde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1465</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And seyde, 'O fool, wel may men thee dispyse,</p>
<p>That hast the Dawing al night by thy syde,</p>
<p>And suffrest hir so sone up fro thee ryse,</p>
<p>For to disesen loveres in this wyse.</p>
<p>What! hold your bed ther, thou, and eek thy Morwe!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1470</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I bidde god, so yeve yow bothe sorwe!'</p>
<p class="stanza">211. Therwith ful sore he sighte, and thus he seyde,</p>
<p>'My lady right, and of my wele or wo</p>
<p>The welle and rote, O goodly myn, Criseyde,</p>
<p>And shal I ryse, allas! and shal I go?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1475</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Now fele I that myn herte moot a-two!</p>
<p>For how sholde I my lyf an houre save,</p>
<p>Sin that with yow is al the lyf I have?</p>
<p class="stanza">212. What shal I doon, for certes, I not how,</p>
<p>Ne whanne, allas! I shal the tyme see,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1480</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That in this plyt I may be eft with yow;</p>
<p>And of my lyf, god woot, how that shal be,</p>
<p>Sin that desyr right now so byteth me,</p>
<p>That I am deed anoon, but I retourne.</p>
<p>How sholde I longe, allas! fro yow soiourne?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1485</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">213. But nathelees, myn owene lady bright,</p>
<p>Yit were it so that I wiste outrely,</p>
<p>That I, your humble servaunt and your knight,</p>
<p>Were in your herte set so fermely</p>
<p>As ye in myn, the which thing, trewely,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1490</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page291">{291}</span>Me lever <a href="#TIIINL1490" id="TIIIL1490" class="pginternal">were</a> than <a href="#TIIINL1490" class="pginternal">thise worldes tweyne</a>,</p>
<p>Yet sholde I bet enduren al my peyne.'</p>
<p class="stanza">214. To that Cryseyde answerde right anoon,</p>
<p>And with a syk she seyde, 'O herte dere,</p>
<p>The game, y-wis, so ferforth now is goon,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1495</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That first shal <a href="#TIIINL1495" id="TIIIL1495" class="pginternal">Phebus falle fro his
    spere</a>,</p>
<p>And every egle been the dowves fere,</p>
<p>And every roche out of his place sterte,</p>
<p>Er Troilus out of Criseydes herte!</p>
<p class="stanza">215. Ye be so depe in-with myn herte grave,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1500</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That, though I wolde it turne out of my thought,</p>
<p>As wisly verray god my soule save,</p>
<p>To <a href="#TIIINL1502" id="TIIIL1502" class="pginternal">dyen in the peyne</a>, I coude nought!</p>
<p>And, for the love of god that us hath wrought,</p>
<p>Lat in your brayn non other fantasye</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1505</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">So crepe, that it cause me to dye!</p>
<p class="stanza">216. And that ye me wolde han as faste in minde</p>
<p>As I have yow, that wolde I yow bi-seche;</p>
<p>And, if I wiste soothly that to finde,</p>
<p>God mighte not a poynt my Ioyes eche!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1510</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But, herte myn, with-oute more speche,</p>
<p>Beth to me trewe, or elles were it routhe;</p>
<p>For I am thyn, by god and by my trouthe!</p>
<p class="stanza">217. Beth glad for-thy, and live in sikernesse;</p>
<p>Thus seyde I never er this, ne shal to <a href="#TIIINL1514" id="TIIIL1514" class="pginternal">mo</a>;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1515</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And if to yow it were a gret gladnesse</p>
<p>To turne ayein, soone after that ye go,</p>
<p>As fayn wolde I as ye, it were so,</p>
<p>As wisly god myn herte bringe at reste!'</p>
<p>And him in armes took, and ofte keste.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1520</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">218. Agayns his wil, sin it mot nedes be,</p>
<p>This Troilus up roos, and faste him cledde,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page292">{292}</span>And in his armes took his lady free</p>
<p>An hundred tyme, and on his wey him spedde,</p>
<p>And with swich wordes as his herte bledde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1525</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He seyde, 'farewel, my dere herte swete,</p>
<p>Ther god us graunte sounde and sone to mete!'</p>
<p class="stanza">219. To which no word for sorwe she answerde,</p>
<p>So sore gan his parting hir destreyne;</p>
<p>And Troilus un-to his palays ferde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1530</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As woo bigon as she was, sooth to seyne;</p>
<p>So hard him wrong of sharp desyr the peyne</p>
<p>For to ben eft there he was in plesaunce,</p>
<p>That it may never out of his remembraunce.</p>
<p class="stanza">220. Retorned to his real palais, sone</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1535</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He softe in-to his bed gan for to slinke,</p>
<p>To slepe longe, as he was wont to done,</p>
<p>But al for nought; he may wel ligge and winke,</p>
<p>But sleep ne may ther in his herte sinke;</p>
<p>Thenkinge how she, for whom desyr him brende,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1540</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">A thousand-fold was worth more than he wende.</p>
<p class="stanza">221. And in his thought gan up and doun to winde</p>
<p>Hir wordes alle, and every contenaunce,</p>
<p>And fermely impressen in his minde</p>
<p>The leste poynt that to him was plesaunce;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1545</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And verrayliche, of thilke remembraunce,</p>
<p>Desyr <a href="#TIIINL1546" id="TIIIL1546" class="pginternal">al newe him brende</a>, and lust to brede</p>
<p>Gan more than erst, and yet took he non hede.</p>
<p class="stanza">222. Criseyde also, right in the same wyse,</p>
<p>Of Troilus gan in hir herte shette</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1550</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">His worthinesse, his lust, his dedes wyse,</p>
<p>His gentilesse, and how she with him mette,</p>
<p>Thonkinge love he so wel hir bisette;</p>
<p>Desyring eft to have hir herte dere</p>
<p>In swich a plyt, she dorste make him chere.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1555</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page293">{293}</span>223. Pandare, a-morwe
    which that comen was</p>
<p>Un-to his nece, and gan hir fayre grete,</p>
<p>Seyde, 'al this night so reyned it, allas!</p>
<p>That al my drede is that ye, nece swete,</p>
<p>Han litel layser had to slepe and mete;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1560</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Al night,' quod he, 'hath reyn so do me wake,</p>
<p>That som of us, I trowe, hir hedes ake.'</p>
<p class="stanza">224. And ner he com, and seyde, 'how stont it now</p>
<p>This mery morwe, nece, how can ye fare?'</p>
<p>Criseyde answerde, 'never the bet for yow,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1565</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Fox that ye been, god yeve your herte care!</p>
<p>God helpe me so, ye caused al this fare,</p>
<p>Trow I,' quod she, 'for alle your wordes whyte;</p>
<p>O! who-so seeth yow knoweth yow ful lyte!'</p>
<p class="stanza">225. With that she gan hir face for to wrye</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1570</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">With the shete, and wex for shame al reed;</p>
<p>And Pandarus gan under for to prye,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'nece, if that I shal ben deed,</p>
<p>Have here a swerd, and smyteth of myn heed.'</p>
<p>With that his arm al sodeynly he thriste</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1575</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Under hir nekke, and at the laste hir kiste.</p>
<p class="stanza">226. I passe al that which chargeth nought to seye,</p>
<p>What! <a href="#TIIINL1577" id="TIIIL1577" class="pginternal">God foryaf his deeth</a>, and she al-so</p>
<p>Foryaf, and with hir uncle gan to pleye,</p>
<p>For other cause was ther noon than so.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1580</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But of this thing right to the effect to go,</p>
<p>Whan tyme was, hom til hir hous she wente,</p>
<p>And Pandarus hath fully his entente.</p>
<p class="stanza">227. Now torne we ayein to Troilus,</p>
<p>That resteles ful longe a-bedde lay,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1585</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page294">{294}</span>And prevely sente after
    Pandarus,</p>
<p>To him to come in al the haste he may.</p>
<p>He com anoon, nought ones seyde he 'nay,'</p>
<p>And Troilus ful sobrely he grette,</p>
<p>And doun upon his beddes syde him sette.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1590</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">228. This Troilus, with al the affeccioun</p>
<p>Of frendes love that herte may devyse,</p>
<p>To Pandarus on kneës fil adoun,</p>
<p>And er that he wolde of the place aryse,</p>
<p>He gan him thonken in his beste wyse;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1595</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">A hondred sythe he gan the tyme blesse,</p>
<p>That he was born to bringe him fro distresse.</p>
<p class="stanza">229. He seyde, 'O frend, of frendes the alderbeste</p>
<p>That ever was, the sothe for to telle,</p>
<p>Thou hast in hevene y-brought my soule at reste</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1600</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#TIIINL1600" id="TIIIL1600" class="pginternal">Fro Flegiton</a>, the fery flood of
    helle;</p>
<p>That, though I mighte a thousand tymes selle,</p>
<p>Upon a day, my lyf in thy servyse,</p>
<p>It mighte nought a mote in that suffyse.</p>
<p class="stanza">230. The sonne, which that al the world may see,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1605</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Saw never yet, my lyf, that dar I leye,</p>
<p>So inly fair and goodly as is she,</p>
<p>Whos I am al, and shal, til that I deye;</p>
<p>And, that I thus am hires, dar I seye,</p>
<p>That thanked be the heighe worthinesse</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1610</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Of love, and eek thy kinde bisinesse.</p>
<p class="stanza">231. Thus hastow me no litel thing y-yive,</p>
<p>Fo which to thee obliged be for ay</p>
<p>My lyf, and why? for thorugh thyn help I live;</p>
<p>For elles deed hadde I be many a day.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1615</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And with that word doun in his bed he lay,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page295">{295}</span>And Pandarus ful sobrely him herde</p>
<p>Til al was seyd, and thanne he him answerde:</p>
<p class="stanza">232. 'My dere frend, if I have doon for thee</p>
<p>In any cas, god wot, it is me leef;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1620</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And am as glad as man may of it be,</p>
<p>God help me so; but tak now not a-greef</p>
<p>That I shal seyn, be war of this myscheef,</p>
<p>That, there-as thou now brought art in-to blisse,</p>
<p>That thou thy-self ne cause it nought to misse.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1625</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><a href="#TIIINL1625" id="TIIIL1625" class="pginternal">233</a>. For of fortunes sharp
    adversitee</p>
<p>The worst kinde of infortune is this,</p>
<p>A man to have ben in prosperitee,</p>
<p>And it remembren, whan it passed is.</p>
<p>Thou art wys y-nough, for-thy do nought amis;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1630</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Be not to rakel, though thou sitte warme,</p>
<p>For if thou be, certeyn, it wol thee harme.</p>
<p class="stanza">234. Thou art at ese, and holde thee wel ther-inne.</p>
<p>For also seur as reed is every fyr,</p>
<p><a href="#TIIINL1634" id="TIIIL1634" class="pginternal">As greet a craft</a> is kepe wel as winne;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1635</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Brydle alwey wel thy speche and thy desyr.</p>
<p>For worldly Ioye halt not but by a wyr;</p>
<p>That preveth wel, it brest alday so ofte;</p>
<p>For-thy nede is to werke with it softe.'</p>
<p class="stanza">235. Quod Troilus, 'I hope, and god to-forn,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1640</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">My dere frend, that I shal so me bere,</p>
<p>That in my gilt ther shal no thing be lorn,</p>
<p><a href="#TIIINL1642" id="TIIIL1642" class="pginternal">Ne I</a> nil not <a href="#TIIINL1642" class="pginternal">rakle</a> as for
    to greven here;</p>
<p>It nedeth not this matere ofte tere;</p>
<p>For wistestow myn herte wel, Pandare,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1645</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">God woot, of this thou woldest litel care.'</p>
<p class="stanza">236. Tho gan he telle him of his glade night.</p>
<p>And wher-of first his herte dredde, and how,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page296">{296}</span>And seyde, 'freend, as I am trewe knight,</p>
<p>And by that feyth I <a href="#TIIINL1649" id="TIIIL1649" class="pginternal">shal</a> to god and yow,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1650</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I hadde it never half so hote as now;</p>
<p>And ay the more that desyr me byteth</p>
<p>To love hir best, the more it me delyteth.</p>
<p class="stanza">237. I noot my-self not wisly what it is;</p>
<p>But now I fele a newe qualitee,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1655</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ye, al another than I dide er this.'</p>
<p>Pandare answerde, and seyde thus, that he</p>
<p>That ones may in hevene blisse be,</p>
<p>He feleth other weyes, dar I leye,</p>
<p>Than thilke tyme he first herde of it seye.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1660</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">238. This is o word for al; this Troilus</p>
<p>Was never ful, to speke of this matere,</p>
<p>And for to preysen un-to Pandarus</p>
<p>The bountee of his righte lady dere,</p>
<p>And Pandarus to thanke and maken chere.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1665</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">This tale ay was span-newe to biginne</p>
<p>Til that the night departed hem a-twinne.</p>
<p class="stanza">239. Sone after this, for that fortune it wolde,</p>
<p>I-comen was the blisful tyme swete,</p>
<p>That Troilus was warned that he sholde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1670</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ther he was erst, Criseyde his lady mete;</p>
<p>For which he felte his herte in Ioye flete;</p>
<p>And feythfully gan alle the goddes herie;</p>
<p>And lat see now if that he can be merie.</p>
<p class="stanza">240. And holden was the forme and al the wyse,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1675</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Of hir cominge, and eek of his also,</p>
<p>As it was erst, which nedeth nought devyse.</p>
<p>But playnly to the effect right for to go,</p>
<p>In Ioye and seurte Pandarus hem two</p>
<p>A-bedde broughte, whan hem bothe leste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1680</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And thus they ben in quiete and in reste.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page297">{297}</span>241. Nought nedeth it to yow,
    sin they ben met,</p>
<p>To aske at me if that they blythe were;</p>
<p>For if it erst was wel, tho was it bet</p>
<p>A thousand-fold, this nedeth not enquere.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1685</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">A-gon was every sorwe and every fere;</p>
<p>And bothe, y-wis, they hadde, and so they wende,</p>
<p>As muche Ioye as herte may <a href="#TIIINL1687" id="TIIIL1687" class="pginternal">comprende</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza">242. This is no litel thing of for to seye,</p>
<p>This passeth every wit for to devyse;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1690</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For eche of hem gan otheres lust obeye;</p>
<p>Felicitee, which that thise clerkes wyse</p>
<p>Commenden so, ne may not here suffyse.</p>
<p>This Ioye may not writen been with inke,</p>
<p>This passeth al that herte may bithinke.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1695</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">243. But cruel day, so wel-awey the stounde!</p>
<p>Gan for to aproche, as they by signes knewe,</p>
<p>For whiche hem thoughte felen dethes wounde;</p>
<p>So wo was hem, that changen gan hir hewe,</p>
<p>And day they gonnen to dispyse al newe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1700</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Calling it traytour, envyous, and worse,</p>
<p>And bitterly the dayes light they curse.</p>
<p class="stanza">244. Quod Troilus, 'allas! now am I war</p>
<p>That <a href="#TIIINL1703" id="TIIIL1703" class="pginternal">Pirous</a> and tho swifte stedes three,</p>
<p>Whiche that drawen forth the sonnes char,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1705</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Han goon <a href="#TIIINL1705" id="TIIIL1705" class="pginternal">som by-path</a> in despyt of
    me;</p>
<p>That maketh it so sone day to be;</p>
<p>And, for the sonne him hasteth thus to ryse,</p>
<p>Ne shal I never doon him sacrifyse!'</p>
<p class="stanza">245. But nedes day departe moste hem sone,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1710</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And whanne hir speche doon was and hir chere,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page298">{298}</span>They twinne anoon as they were wont to
    done,</p>
<p>And setten tyme of meting eft y-fere;</p>
<p>And many a night they wroughte in this manere.</p>
<p>And thus Fortune a tyme ladde in Ioye</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1715</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Criseyde, and eek this kinges sone of Troye.</p>
<p class="stanza">246. In suffisaunce, in blisse, and in singinges,</p>
<p>This Troilus gan al his lyf to lede;</p>
<p>He spendeth, Iusteth, maketh festeyinges;</p>
<p>He yeveth frely ofte, and chaungeth wede,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1720</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And held aboute him alwey, out of drede,</p>
<p>A world of folk, as cam him wel of kinde,</p>
<p>The fressheste and the beste he coude fynde;</p>
<p class="stanza">247. That swich a voys was of hym and a stevene</p>
<p>Thorugh-out the world, of honour and largesse,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1725</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That it up rong un-to the yate of hevene.</p>
<p>And, as in love, he was in swich gladnesse,</p>
<p>That in his herte he demede, as I gesse,</p>
<p>That there nis lovere in this world at ese</p>
<p>So wel as he, and thus gan love him plese.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1730</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">248. The godlihede or beautee which that kinde</p>
<p>In any other lady hadde y-set</p>
<p>Can not the <a href="#TIIINL1732" id="TIIIL1732" class="pginternal">mountaunce of a knot</a> unbinde,</p>
<p>A-boute his herte, of al Criseydes net.</p>
<p>He was so narwe <a href="#TIIINL1734" id="TIIIL1734" class="pginternal">y-masked</a> and y-knet,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1735</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That it undon on any manere syde,</p>
<p>That nil not been, for ought that may betyde.</p>
<p class="stanza">249. And by the hond ful ofte he wolde take</p>
<p>This Pandarus, and in-to gardin lede,</p>
<p>And swich a feste and swich a proces make</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1740</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Him of Criseyde, and of hir womanhede,</p>
<p>And of hir beautee, that, with-outen drede,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page299">{299}</span>It was an hevene his wordes for to here;</p>
<p>And thanne he wolde singe in this manere.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TIIINL1744" id="TIIIL1744" class="pginternal">250</a>. 'Love, that of erthe and see
    hath governaunce,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1745</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Love, that his hestes hath in hevene hye,</p>
<p>Love, that with an holsom alliaunce</p>
<p>Halt peples ioyned, as him list hem gye,</p>
<p>Love, that knetteth lawe of companye,</p>
<p>And couples doth in vertu for to dwelle,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1750</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Bind this acord, that I have told and telle;</p>
<p class="stanza">251. That that the world with feyth, which that is stable,</p>
<p>Dyverseth so his stoundes concordinge,</p>
<p>That elements that been so discordable</p>
<p>Holden a bond perpetuely duringe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1755</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That Phebus mote his rosy day forth bringe,</p>
<p>And that the mone hath lordship over the nightes,</p>
<p>Al this doth Love; ay heried be his mightes!</p>
<p class="stanza">252. That that the see, that gredy is to flowen,</p>
<p>Constreyneth to a certeyn ende so</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1760</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">His flodes, that so fersly they ne growen</p>
<p>To drenchen erthe and al for ever-mo;</p>
<p>And if that Love ought lete his brydel go,</p>
<p>Al that now loveth a-sonder sholde lepe,</p>
<p>And lost were al, that Love halt now <a href="#TIIINL1764" id="TIIIL1764" class="pginternal">to-hepe</a>.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1765</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">253. So wolde god, that auctor is of kinde,</p>
<p>That, with his bond, <a href="#TIIINL1766" id="TIIIL1766" class="pginternal">Love of his vertu liste</a></p>
<p>To cerclen hertes alle, and faste binde,</p>
<p>That from his bond no wight the wey out wiste.</p>
<p>And hertes colde, hem wolde I that he twiste</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1770</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page300">{300}</span>To make hem love, and that hem
    leste ay rewe</p>
<p>On hertes sore, and kepe hem that ben trewe.'</p>
<p class="stanza">254. In alle nedes, for the tounes werre,</p>
<p>He was, and ay the firste in armes dight;</p>
<p>And certeynly, but-if that bokes erre,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1775</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Save Ector, most y-drad of any wight;</p>
<p>And this encrees of hardinesse and might</p>
<p>Cam him of love, his ladies thank to winne,</p>
<p>That altered his spirit so with-inne.</p>
<p class="stanza">255. <a href="#TIIINL1779" id="TIIIL1779" class="pginternal">In tyme of trewe</a>, on haukinge
    wolde he ryde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1780</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Or elles hunten boor, bere, or lyoun;</p>
<p>The smale bestes leet he gon bi-syde.</p>
<p>And whan that he com rydinge in-to toun,</p>
<p>Ful ofte his lady, from hir window doun,</p>
<p>As fresh as faucon comen out of muwe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1785</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ful redy was, him goodly to saluwe.</p>
<p class="stanza">256. And most of love and vertu was his speche,</p>
<p>And in despyt hadde alle wrecchednesse;</p>
<p>And doutelees, no nede was him biseche</p>
<p>To honouren hem that hadde worthinesse,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1790</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And esen hem that weren in distresse.</p>
<p>And glad was he if any wight wel ferde,</p>
<p>That lover was, whan he it wiste or herde.</p>
<p class="stanza">257. For sooth to seyn, he lost held every wight</p>
<p>But-if he were in loves heigh servyse,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1795</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I mene folk that oughte it been of right.</p>
<p>And over al this, so wel coude he devyse</p>
<p>Of sentement, and in so unkouth wyse</p>
<p>Al his array, that every lover thoughte,</p>
<p>That al was wel, what-so he seyde or wroughte.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1800</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">258. And though that he be come of blood royal,</p>
<p>Him liste of pryde at no wight for to chase;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page301">{301}</span>Benigne he was to ech in general,</p>
<p>For which he gat him thank in every place.</p>
<p>Thus wolde Love, y-heried be his grace,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1805</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That Pryde, Envye, Ire, and <a href="#TIIINL1805" id="TIIIL1805" class="pginternal">Avaryce</a></p>
<p>He gan to flee, and every other vyce.</p>
<p class="stanza">259. Thou <a href="#TIIINL1807" id="TIIIL1807" class="pginternal">lady</a> bright, the doughter
    to Dione,</p>
<p>Thy blinde and winged sone eek, daun Cupyde;</p>
<p>Ye sustren <a href="#TIIINL1809" id="TIIIL1809" class="pginternal">nyne</a> eek, that by Elicone</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1810</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">In hil Parnaso listen for to abyde,</p>
<p>That ye thus fer han deyned me to gyde,</p>
<p>I can no more, but sin that ye wol wende,</p>
<p>Ye heried been for ay, with-outen ende!</p>
<p class="stanza">260. Thourgh yow have I seyd fully in my song</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1815</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Theffect and Ioye of Troilus servyse,</p>
<p>Al be that ther was som disese among,</p>
<p>As to myn auctor listeth <a href="#TIIINL1817" id="TIIIL1817" class="pginternal">to devyse</a>.</p>
<p>My thridde book now ende ich in this wyse;</p>
<p>And Troilus in luste and in quiete</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1820</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Is with Criseyde, his owne herte swete.</p>
</div>

  moote; Cl. mot. 1608. Cp. H. hires; Cl. heres. 1609. Cp. heighe; Cm. hye; Cl. H. heigh. 1611. Cp.
  y-ȝiue; Cl. y-yeue. 1613. Cl. Cm. leue; <i>rest</i> lyue. 1619, 1621, 1622. Cl. Cp. lief,
  grief, mischief; Cm. lef, gref, myschef; H2. leef, greef, mischeef. 1621. now] Cl. it. 1622. Cl.
  of of (!); <i>rest</i> of this. 1627. Cl. H2. be; <i>rest</i> ben. 1629. Cp. H. Thart. // Cl.
  ynowh. 1634. Cl. kep; <i>rest</i> kepe. 1642. Cp. H. Ny. 1644. Cm. wistist thou; Ed. wystest thou;
  Cp. wystestow; Cl. H. wistow. 1655. than] Cl. er. 1656. H. answerde; Cl. answerede. 1657. Cl. Cm.
  onys. 1659. Cp. H. Cm. herde; Cl. herd. 1662. H. Cp. preysen; Cl.preyse. 1663. Cp. Cm. righte; Cl.
  H. right. 1664. chere] Cl. clere. 1671. Cp. Cm. felte; Cl. H. felt. 1675. Cm. H2. ek; <i>rest
  om.</i> 1677. Cp. H. theffect. 1679. <i>Al</i> brought. // Cl. Cp. H. H2. whan that; Cm. Ed.
  <i>om.</i> that. 1680. Cl. <i>om.</i> thus. 1687. Cl. complende(!); Cp. comprende; <i>rest</i>
  comprehende. 1693. H. wryten; H2. writyn; Cl. y-wrete. 1694. Cl. by-thenke; <i>rest</i> by-thynke.
  1696. signes] Cl. synes. 1700. traytour] Cl. traytous. 1702. Cl. Cp. H. <i>om.</i> allas. 1703.
  H2. Pirous; Ed. Pyrous; H. Pirors; Cl. Cp. Cm. Piros. 1704. Ed. Whiche; <i>rest</i> Which. 1708.
  him] Cl. here; Cp. H. hire. // Cl. sacrifice. 1711. Cl. woned; Cp. H2. Ed. wont; H. wonte; Cm.
  wone. 1713. Cp. Cm. wroughte; Cl. H. wrought. 1718. Cl. H. festeynynges; Cp. H2. festynges; Cm.
  festyngys; (<i>read</i> festeyinges). 1720. aboute him] Cl. hym aboute. 1722. H. fresshiste; Cl.
  fresshest. 1723. Cl. <i>om. 2nd</i> a. // stevene] H. neuene. 1725. Cl. rong vp into. 1731. Cl.
  ony. 1734. Cl. y-maked(!). 1738. Cp. H. Cm. Ed. gardyn; Cl. gardeyn. 1745. Cl. heste. 1747. Cl.
  hem lyst hym (<i>wrongly</i>). 1748. Cl. Cp. knetteth; H. knettheth; Ed. knytteth; H2. kennyth;
  Cm. endytyth. // Cl. Cm. of; H. Cp. Ed. and; H2. <i>om.</i> 1753. Cl. elementes; Cp. H. elementz.
  1755. Cp. H2. Ed. mote; Cl. H. mot; Cm. may. 1759. Cl. Constreyne. 1760. Cl. <i>om.</i> so. // Cp.
  H. Ed. fiersly; Cm. fersely; H2. fersly; Cl. freshly. 1762. Cp. H. lete; Cl. late; Cm. let; Ed.
  lette. 1767. H. Cp. cerclen; Cm. serkelyn; Cl. cerchen; Ed. serchen; H2. cherysson. 1768. Cp. H.
  wey; Cl. weye. 1769. twiste] Cl. it wyste. 1770. Cl. lest; Cp. H. liste. 1771. Cl. kep. 1774. Cl.
  certaynly. 1776. Cl. H. Cm. encres; Ed. encrease. 1779. Cl. <i>om</i>. he. 1780. Cp. boor; Cm.
  bor; <i>rest</i> bore. 1784. Cl. H2. cometh; <i>rest</i> comen. 1787. Cl. Cp. H. alle; <i>rest</i>
  al. 1794. Cl. heyghe; Cp. H. heigh. 1797. Cm. vnkouth; Cl. vnkow; Cp. vnkoude; <i>rest</i>
  vnkouthe. 1800. Cm. real. 1801. Cl. Lyst hym; Cp. H. Him liste. 1804. Cp. Cm. wolde; Cl. H. wold.
  1805. Cp. H. Ed. pride and Ire enuye. 1807-1820. <i>Lost in</i> Cm. 1810. In] Cl. I. // Cp. H.
  tabide. 1815. Cl. seruyce. 1816. Cl. dishese. 1818. wyse] Cl. wys. <span class="sc">Colophon.</span> <i>From</i> Ed.; Cl. Cp. H. H2. <i>wrongly place it after</i> Book IV,
  l. 28. </p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page302">{302}</span></div>
<h2 class="ac" style="margin-bottom:2.1ex;"> <span class="larger">BOOK IV.</span></h2>
<p class="ac">[<b>Prohemium.</b>]</p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p><a href="#TIVNL1" id="TIVL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. But al to litel, weylawey the whyle,</p>
<p>Lasteth swich Ioye, y-thonked be Fortune!</p>
<p><a href="#TIVNL3" id="TIVL3" class="pginternal">That semeth trewest</a>, whan she wol bygyle,</p>
<p>And can to foles so hir song entune,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That she hem <a href="#TIVNL5" id="TIVL5" class="pginternal">hent and blent</a>, traytour
    comune;</p>
<p><a href="#TIVNL6" id="TIVL6" class="pginternal">And whan a wight</a> is from hir wheel y-throwe,</p>
<p>Than laugheth she, and maketh him the mowe.</p>
<p class="stanza">2. From Troilus she gan hir brighte face</p>
<p>Awey to wrythe, and took of him non hede,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But caste him clene oute of his lady grace,</p>
<p>And on hir wheel she sette up Diomede;</p>
<p>For which right now myn herte ginneth blede,</p>
<p>And now my penne, allas! with which I wryte,</p>
<p>Quaketh for drede of that I moot endyte.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">15</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">3. For how Criseyde Troilus forsook,</p>
<p>Or at the leste, how that she was unkinde,</p>
<p>Mot hennes-forth ben matere of my book,</p>
<p>As wryten folk thorugh which it is in minde.</p>
<p>Allas! that they shulde ever cause finde</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To speke hir harm; and if they on hir lye,</p>
<p>Y-wis, hem-self sholde han the vilanye.</p>
<p class="stanza">4. O ye <a href="#TIVNL22" id="TIVL22" class="pginternal">Herines</a>, Nightes doughtren
    three,</p>
<p>That endelees compleynen ever in pyne,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page303">{303}</span>Megera, Alete, and eek Thesiphone;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thou cruel Mars eek, fader to <a href="#TIVNL25" id="TIVL25" class="pginternal">Quiryne</a>,</p>
<p>This ilke ferthe book me helpeth fyne,</p>
<p>So that the los of lyf and love y-fere</p>
<p>Of Troilus be fully shewed here.</p>
</div>
<p class="ac"><b>Explicit</b> [<b>prohemium</b>]. <b>Incipit Quartus Liber.</b></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>5. <a href="#TIVNL29" id="TIVL29" class="pginternal">Ligginge</a> in ost, as I have seyd er this,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The Grekes stronge, aboute Troye toun,</p>
<p>Bifel that, whan that Phebus shyning is</p>
<p>Up-on the brest of <a href="#TIVNL32" id="TIVL32" class="pginternal">Hercules Lyoun</a>,</p>
<p>That Ector, with ful many a bold baroun,</p>
<p>Caste on a day with Grekes for to fighte,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As he was wont to greve hem what he mighte.</p>
<p class="stanza">6. Not I how longe or short it was bitwene</p>
<p>This purpos and that day they fighte mente;</p>
<p>But on a day wel armed, bright and shene,</p>
<p>Ector, and many a worthy wight out wente,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">With spere in hond and bigge bowes bente;</p>
<p>And <a href="#TIVNL41" id="TIVL41" class="pginternal">in the berd</a>, with-oute lenger lette,</p>
<p>Hir fomen in the feld anoon hem mette.</p>
<p class="stanza">7. The longe day, with speres sharpe y-grounde,</p>
<p>With arwes, dartes, swerdes, maces felle,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">They fighte and bringen hors and man to grounde,</p>
<p>And with hir axes out the braynes quelle.</p>
<p>But in the laste <a href="#TIVNL47" id="TIVL47" class="pginternal">shour</a>, sooth for to telle,</p>
<p>The folk of Troye hem-selven so misledden,</p>
<p>That with the worse at night homward they fledden.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">50</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><a href="#TIVNL50" id="TIVL50" class="pginternal">8</a>. At whiche day was taken
    Antenor,</p>
<p>Maugre Polydamas or Monesteo,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page304">{304}</span>Santippe, Sarpedon, Polynestor,</p>
<p>Polyte, or eek the Troian daun Ripheo,</p>
<p>And othere lasse folk, as Phebuseo.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">So that, for harm, that day the folk of Troye</p>
<p>Dredden to lese a greet part of hir Ioye.</p>
<p class="stanza">9. Of Pryamus was yeve, at Greek requeste,</p>
<p>A tyme of trewe, and tho they gonnen trete,</p>
<p>Hir prisoneres to chaungen, moste and leste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And for the surplus yeven sommes grete.</p>
<p>This thing anoon was couth in every strete,</p>
<p>Bothe in <a href="#TIVNL62" id="TIVL62" class="pginternal">thassege</a>, in toune, and every-where,</p>
<p>And with the firste it cam to Calkas ere.</p>
<p class="stanza">10. Whan <a href="#TIVNL64" id="TIVL64" class="pginternal">Calkas</a> knew this tretis sholde
    holde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">In consistorie, among the Grekes, sone</p>
<p>He gan in thringe forth, with lordes olde,</p>
<p>And sette him there-as he was wont to done;</p>
<p>And with a chaunged face hem bad a bone,</p>
<p>For love of god, to don that reverence,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To stinte noyse, and yeve him audience.</p>
<p class="stanza">11. Thanne seyde he thus, 'lo! lordes myne, I was</p>
<p>Troian, as it is knowen out of drede;</p>
<p>And if that yow remembre, I am Calkas,</p>
<p>That alderfirst yaf comfort to your nede,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And tolde wel how that ye sholden spede.</p>
<p>For dredelees, thorugh yow, shal, in a stounde,</p>
<p>Ben Troye y-brend, and beten doun to grounde.</p>
<p class="stanza">12. And in what forme, or in what maner wyse</p>
<p><a href="#TIVNL79" id="TIVL79" class="pginternal">This town to shende</a>, and al your lust to acheve,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ye han er this wel herd it me devyse;</p>
<p>This knowe ye, my lordes, as I leve.</p>
<p>And for the Grekes weren me so leve,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page305">{305}</span>I com my-self in my propre persone,</p>
<p>To teche in this how yow was best to done;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">85</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">13. Havinge un-to my tresour ne my rente</p>
<p>Right no <a href="#TIVNL86" id="TIVL86" class="pginternal">resport</a>, to respect of your ese.</p>
<p>Thus al my good I loste and to yow wente,</p>
<p>Wening in this you, lordes, for to plese.</p>
<p>But al that los ne doth me no disese.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I vouche-sauf, as wisly have I Ioye,</p>
<p>For you to lese al that I have in Troye,</p>
<p class="stanza">14. Save of a doughter, that I lafte, allas!</p>
<p>Slepinge at hoom, whanne out of Troye I sterte.</p>
<p>O sterne, O cruel fader that I was!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">How mighte I have in that so hard an herte?</p>
<p>Allas! I ne hadde y-brought hir <a href="#TIVNL96" id="TIVL96" class="pginternal">in hir sherte</a>!</p>
<p>For sorwe of which I wol not live to morwe,</p>
<p>But-if ye lordes rewe up-on my sorwe.</p>
<p class="stanza">15. For, by that cause <a href="#TIVNL99" id="TIVL99" class="pginternal">I say no tyme</a> er
    now</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Hir to delivere, I holden have my pees;</p>
<p>But now or never, if that it lyke yow,</p>
<p>I may hir have right sone, doutelees.</p>
<p>O help and grace! amonges al this prees,</p>
<p>Rewe on this olde caitif in destresse,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Sin I through yow have al this hevinesse!</p>
<p class="stanza">16. Ye have now caught and fetered in prisoun</p>
<p>Troians y-nowe; and if your willes be,</p>
<p>My child with oon may have redempcioun.</p>
<p>Now for the love of god and of bountee,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Oon of so fele, allas! so yeve him me.</p>
<p>What nede were it this preyere for to werne,</p>
<p>Sin ye shul bothe han folk and toun <a href="#TIVNL112" id="TIVL112" class="pginternal">as yerne</a>?</p>
<p class="stanza">17. On peril of my lyf, I shal not lye,</p>
<p>Appollo hath me told it feithfully;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page306">{306}</span>I have eek founde it by
    astronomye,</p>
<p>By sort, and by augurie eek trewely,</p>
<p>And dar wel seye, the tyme is faste by,</p>
<p>That fyr and flaumbe on al the toun shal sprede;</p>
<p>And thus shal Troye turne in asshen dede.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">120</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">18. For certeyn, Phebus and Neptunus bothe,</p>
<p>That makeden the walles of the toun,</p>
<p>Ben with the folk of Troye alwey so wrothe,</p>
<p>That thei wol bringe it to confusioun,</p>
<p>Right in despyt of king <a href="#TIVNL120" id="TIVL120" class="pginternal">Lameadoun</a>.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">By-cause he nolde payen hem hir hyre,</p>
<p>The toun of Troye shal ben set on-fyre.'</p>
<p class="stanza">19. Telling his tale alwey, this olde greye,</p>
<p>Humble in speche, and in his lokinge eke,</p>
<p>The salte teres from his eyën tweye</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ful faste ronnen doun by eyther cheke.</p>
<p>So longe he gan of socour hem by-seke</p>
<p>That, for to hele him of his sorwes sore,</p>
<p>They yave him <a href="#TIVNL133" id="TIVL133" class="pginternal">Antenor, with-oute more</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza">20. But who was glad y-nough but Calkas tho?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">135</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And of this thing ful sone his nedes leyde</p>
<p>On hem that sholden for the tretis go,</p>
<p>And hem for Antenor ful ofte preyde</p>
<p>To bringen hoom king Toas and Criseyde;</p>
<p>And whan Pryam his save-garde sente,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thembassadours to Troye streyght they wente.</p>
<p class="stanza">21. The cause y-told of hir cominge, the olde</p>
<p>Pryam the king ful sone in general</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page307">{307}</span>Let here-upon his <a href="#TIVNL143" id="TIVL143" class="pginternal">parlement</a> to holde,</p>
<p>Of which the effect rehersen yow I shal.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">145</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thembassadours ben answered for fynal,</p>
<p>Theschaunge of prisoners and al this nede</p>
<p>Hem lyketh wel, and forth in they procede.</p>
<p class="stanza">22. This Troilus was present in the place,</p>
<p>Whan axed was for Antenor Criseyde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">150</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For which ful sone chaungen gan his face,</p>
<p>As he that with tho wordes wel neigh deyde.</p>
<p>But nathelees, he no word to it seyde,</p>
<p>Lest men sholde his affeccioun espye;</p>
<p>With mannes herte he gan his sorwes drye.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">155</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">23. And ful of anguish and of grisly drede</p>
<p>Abood what lordes wolde un-to it seye;</p>
<p>And if they wolde graunte, as god forbede,</p>
<p>Theschaunge of hir, than thoughte he thinges tweye,</p>
<p>First, how to save hir honour, and what weye</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">160</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He mighte best theschaunge of hir withstonde;</p>
<p>Ful faste he caste how al this mighte stonde.</p>
<p class="stanza">24. Love him made al prest to doon hir byde,</p>
<p>And rather dye than she sholde go;</p>
<p>But resoun seyde him, on that other syde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">165</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'With-oute assent of hir ne do not so,</p>
<p>Lest for thy werk she wolde be thy fo,</p>
<p>And seyn, that thorugh thy medling is y-blowe</p>
<p><a href="#TIVNL168" id="TIVL168" class="pginternal">Your bother love</a>, there it was erst unknowe.'</p>
<p class="stanza">25. For which he gan deliberen, for the beste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">170</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That though the lordes wolde that she wente,</p>
<p>He wolde late hem graunte what hem leste,</p>
<p>And telle his lady first what that they mente.</p>
<p>And whan that she had seyd him hir entente,</p>
<p>Ther-after wolde he werken also blyve,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">175</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Though al the world ayein it wolde stryve.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page308">{308}</span>26. Ector, which that wel the
    Grekes herde,</p>
<p>For Antenor how they wolde han Criseyde,</p>
<p>Gan it withstonde, and sobrely answerde:—</p>
<p>'Sires, she nis no prisoner,' he seyde;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">180</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'I noot on yow who that this charge leyde,</p>
<p>But, on my part, ye may eft-sone him telle,</p>
<p>We usen here no wommen for to selle.'</p>
<p class="stanza">27. The noyse of peple up-stirte thanne at ones,</p>
<p>As breme as blase of straw y-set on fyre;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">185</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For infortune it wolde, for the nones,</p>
<p>They sholden hir confusioun desyre.</p>
<p>'Ector,' quod they, 'what goost may yow enspyre,</p>
<p>This womman thus to shilde and doon us lese</p>
<p>Daun Antenor?—a wrong wey now ye chese—</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">190</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">28. That is so wys, and eek so bold baroun,</p>
<p>And we han nede of folk, as men may see;</p>
<p>He is eek oon, the grettest of this toun;</p>
<p>O Ector, lat tho fantasyës be!</p>
<p>O king Pryam,' quod they, 'thus seggen we,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">195</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That al our voys is to for-gon Criseyde;'</p>
<p>And to deliveren Antenor they preyde.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TIVNL197" id="TIVL197" class="pginternal">29</a>. O Iuvenal, lord! trewe is thy
    sentence,</p>
<p>That litel witen folk <a href="#TIVNL198" id="TIVL198" class="pginternal">what is to yerne</a></p>
<p>That they ne finde in hir desyr <a href="#TIVNL198" class="pginternal">offence</a>;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">200</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For cloud of errour lat hem not descerne</p>
<p>What best is; and lo, here ensample as yerne.</p>
<p>This folk desiren now deliveraunce</p>
<p>Of Antenor, that broughte hem to <a href="#TIVNL203" id="TIVL203" class="pginternal">mischaunce</a>!</p>
<p class="stanza">30. For he was after traytour to the toun</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">205</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Of Troye; allas! they quitte him out to rathe;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page309">{309}</span>O nyce world, lo, thy discrecioun!</p>
<p>Criseyde, which that never dide hem skathe,</p>
<p>Shal now no lenger in hir blisse bathe;</p>
<p>But Antenor, he shal com hoom to toune,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">210</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And she shal out; thus seyden <a href="#TIVNL210" id="TIVL210" class="pginternal">here and
    howne</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza">31. For which delibered was by parlement,</p>
<p>For Antenor to yelden up Criseyde,</p>
<p>And it pronounced by the president,</p>
<p>Al-theigh that Ector 'nay' ful ofte preyde.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">215</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And fynaly, what wight that it with-seyde,</p>
<p>It was for nought, it moste been, and sholde;</p>
<p>For substaunce of the parlement it wolde.</p>
<p class="stanza">32. Departed out of parlement echone,</p>
<p>This Troilus, with-oute wordes mo,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">220</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Un-to his chaumbre spedde him faste allone,</p>
<p>But-if it were a man of his or two,</p>
<p>The whiche he bad out faste for to go,</p>
<p>By-cause he wolde slepen, as he seyde,</p>
<p>And hastely up-on his bed him leyde.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">225</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><a href="#TIVNL225" id="TIVL225" class="pginternal">33</a>. And as in winter leves been
    biraft,</p>
<p>Eche after other, til the tree be bare,</p>
<p>So that ther nis but bark and braunche y-laft,</p>
<p>Lyth Troilus, biraft of ech wel-fare,</p>
<p>Y-bounden in the blake bark of care,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">230</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Disposed wood out of his wit to breyde,</p>
<p>So sore him sat the chaunginge of Criseyde.</p>
<p class="stanza">34. He rist him up, and every dore he shette</p>
<p>And windowe eek, and tho this sorweful man</p>
<p>Up-on his beddes syde a-doun him sette,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">235</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ful lyk a deed image pale and wan;</p>
<p>And in his brest the heped wo bigan</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page310">{310}</span>Out-breste, and he to werken in this wyse</p>
<p>In his woodnesse, as I shal yow devyse.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TIVNL239" id="TIVL239" class="pginternal">35</a>. Right as the wilde bole biginneth
    springe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">240</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Now here, now there, y-darted to the herte,</p>
<p>And of his deeth roreth in compleyninge,</p>
<p>Right so gan he aboute the chaumbre sterte,</p>
<p>Smyting his brest ay with his festes smerte;</p>
<p>His heed to the wal, his body to the grounde</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">245</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ful ofte he swapte, him-selven to confounde.</p>
<p class="stanza">36. His eyen two, for pitee of his herte,</p>
<p>Out stremeden as swifte welles tweye;</p>
<p>The heighe sobbes of his sorwes smerte</p>
<p>His speche him rafte, unnethes mighte he seye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">250</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'O deeth, allas! why niltow do me deye?</p>
<p><a href="#TIVNL251" id="TIVL251" class="pginternal">A-cursed be the day</a> which that nature</p>
<p>Shoop me to ben a lyves creature!'</p>
<p class="stanza">37. But after, whan the furie and the rage</p>
<p>Which that his herte twiste and faste threste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">255</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">By lengthe of tyme somwhat gan asswage,</p>
<p>Up-on his bed he leyde him doun to reste;</p>
<p>But tho bigonne his teres more out-breste,</p>
<p>That wonder is, the body may suffyse</p>
<p>To half this wo, which that I yow devyse.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">260</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">38. Than seyde he thus, 'Fortune! allas the whyle!</p>
<p>What have I doon, what have I thus a-gilt?</p>
<p>How mightestow for reuthe me bigyle?</p>
<p>Is ther no grace, and shal I <a href="#TIVNL263" id="TIVL263" class="pginternal">thus</a> be spilt?</p>
<p>Shal thus Criseyde awey, for that thou wilt?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">265</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Allas! how maystow in thyn herte finde</p>
<p>To been to me thus cruel and unkinde?</p>
<p class="stanza">39. Have I thee nought honoured al my lyve,</p>
<p>As thou wel wost, above the goddes alle?</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page311">{311}</span>Why wiltow me fro Ioye thus depryve?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">270</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">O Troilus, what may men now thee calle</p>
<p>But wrecche of wrecches, out of honour falle</p>
<p>In-to <a href="#TIVNL272" id="TIVL272" class="pginternal">miserie</a>, in which I wol biwayle</p>
<p>Criseyde, allas! til that the breeth me fayle?</p>
<p class="stanza">40. Allas, Fortune! if that my lyf in Ioye</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">275</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Displesed hadde un-to thy foule envye,</p>
<p>Why ne haddestow my fader, king of Troye,</p>
<p>By-raft the lyf, or doon my bretheren dye,</p>
<p>Or slayn my-self, that thus compleyne and crye,</p>
<p>I, <a href="#TIVNL279" id="TIVL279" class="pginternal">combre-world</a>, that may of no-thing serve,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">280</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But ever dye, and never fully sterve?</p>
<p class="stanza">41. If that Criseyde allone were me laft,</p>
<p>Nought roughte I whider thou woldest me stere;</p>
<p>And hir, allas! than hastow me biraft.</p>
<p>But ever-more, lo! this is thy manere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">285</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To reve a wight that most is to him dere,</p>
<p>To preve in that thy <a href="#TIVNL286" id="TIVL286" class="pginternal">gerful</a> violence.</p>
<p>Thus am I lost, ther helpeth no defence!</p>
<p class="stanza">42. O verray lord of love, O god, allas!</p>
<p>That knowest best myn herte and al my thought,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">290</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">What shal my sorwful lyf don in this cas</p>
<p>If I for-go that I so dere have bought?</p>
<p>Sin ye Cryseyde and me han fully brought</p>
<p>In-to your grace, and bothe our hertes seled,</p>
<p>How may ye suffre, allas! it be repeled?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">295</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">43. What I may doon, I shal, whyl I may dure</p>
<p>On lyve in torment and in cruel peyne,</p>
<p>This infortune or this disaventure,</p>
<p>Allone as I was born, y-wis, compleyne;</p>
<p>Ne never wil I seen it shyne or reyne;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">300</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page312">{312}</span>But ende I wil, as <a href="#TIVNL300" id="TIVL300" class="pginternal">Edippe</a>, in derknesse</p>
<p>My sorwful lyf, and dyen in distresse.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TIVNL302" id="TIVL302" class="pginternal">44</a>. O wery goost, that errest to and
    fro,</p>
<p>Why niltow fleen out of the wofulleste</p>
<p>Body, that ever mighte on grounde go?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">305</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">O soule, lurkinge in this wo, <a href="#TIVNL305" id="TIVL305" class="pginternal">unneste</a>,</p>
<p>Flee forth out of myn herte, and lat it breste,</p>
<p>And folwe alwey Criseyde, thy lady dere;</p>
<p>Thy righte place is now no lenger here!</p>
<p class="stanza">45. O wofulle eyen two, sin your disport</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">310</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Was al to seen Criseydes eyen brighte,</p>
<p>What shal ye doon but, for my discomfort,</p>
<p>Stonden for nought, and wepen out your sighte?</p>
<p>Sin she is queynt, that wont was yow to lighte,</p>
<p>In veyn fro-this-forth have I eyen tweye</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">315</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Y-formed, sin your vertue is a-weye.</p>
<p class="stanza">46. O my Criseyde, O lady sovereyne</p>
<p>Of thilke woful soule that thus cryeth,</p>
<p>Who shal now yeven comfort to <a href="#TIVNL318" id="TIVL318" class="pginternal">the</a> peyne?</p>
<p>Allas, no wight; but when myn herte dyeth,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">320</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">My spirit, which that so un-to yow hyeth,</p>
<p>Receyve in gree, for that shal ay yow serve;</p>
<p>For-thy no fors is, though the body sterve.</p>
<p class="stanza">47. O ye loveres, that heighe upon the wheel</p>
<p>Ben set of Fortune, in good aventure,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">325</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">God leve that ye finde ay love of steel,</p>
<p>And longe mot your lyf in Ioye endure!</p>
<p>But whan ye comen by my sepulture,</p>
<p>Remembreth that your felawe resteth there;</p>
<p>For I lovede eek, though I unworthy were.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">330</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page313">{313}</span>48. O olde <a href="#TIVNL330" id="TIVL330" class="pginternal">unholsom</a> and mislyved man,</p>
<p>Calkas I mene, allas! what eyleth thee</p>
<p>To been a Greek, sin thou art born Troian?</p>
<p>O Calkas, which that wilt my bane be,</p>
<p>In cursed tyme was thou born for me!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">335</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As wolde blisful Iove, for his Ioye,</p>
<p>That I thee hadde, where I wolde, in Troye!'</p>
<p class="stanza">49. A thousand sykes, hottere than the glede,</p>
<p>Out of his brest ech after other wente,</p>
<p>Medled with pleyntes newe, his wo to fede,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">340</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For which his woful teres never stente;</p>
<p>And shortly, so his peynes him to-rente,</p>
<p>And wex so mat, that Ioye nor penaunce</p>
<p>He feleth noon, but lyth forth in a traunce.</p>
<p class="stanza">50. Pandare, which that in the parlement</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">345</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Hadde herd what every lord and burgeys seyde,</p>
<p>And how ful graunted was, by oon assent,</p>
<p>For Antenor to yelden so Criseyde,</p>
<p>Gan wel neigh wood out of his wit to breyde,</p>
<p>So that, for wo, he niste what he mente;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">350</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But in a rees to Troilus he wente.</p>
<p class="stanza">51. A certeyn knight, that for the tyme kepte</p>
<p>The chaumbre-dore, un-dide it him anoon;</p>
<p>And Pandare, that ful tendreliche wepte,</p>
<p>In-to the derke chaumbre, as stille as stoon,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">355</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Toward the bed gan softely to goon,</p>
<p><a href="#TIVNL356" id="TIVL356" class="pginternal">So confus</a>, that he niste what to seye;</p>
<p>For verray wo his wit was neigh aweye.</p>
<p class="stanza">52. And with his chere and loking al to-torn,</p>
<p>For sorwe of this, and with his armes folden,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">360</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He stood this woful Troilus biforn,</p>
<p>And on his pitous face he gan biholden;</p>
<p>But lord, so often gan his herte colden,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page314">{314}</span>Seing his freend in wo, whos hevinesse</p>
<p>His herte slow, as thoughte him, for distresse.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">365</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">53. This woful wight, this Troilus, that felte</p>
<p>His freend Pandare y-comen him to see,</p>
<p>Gan as the snow ayein the sonne melte,</p>
<p>For which this sorwful Pandare, of pitee,</p>
<p>Gan for to wepe as tendreliche as he;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">370</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And specheles thus been thise ilke tweye,</p>
<p>That neyther mighte o word for sorwe seye.</p>
<p class="stanza">54. But at the laste this woful Troilus,</p>
<p>Ney deed for smert, gan bresten out to rore,</p>
<p>And with a sorwful noyse he seyde thus,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">375</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Among his sobbes and his sykes sore,</p>
<p>'Lo! Pandare, I am deed, with-outen more.</p>
<p>Hastow nought herd at parlement,' he seyde,</p>
<p>'For Antenor how lost is my Criseyde?'</p>
<p class="stanza">55. This Pandarus, ful deed and pale of hewe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">380</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ful pitously answerde and seyde, 'yis!</p>
<p><a href="#TIVNL381" id="TIVL381" class="pginternal">As wisly were it fals</a> as it is trewe,</p>
<p>That I have herd, and wot al how it is.</p>
<p>O mercy, god, who wolde have trowed this?</p>
<p>Who wolde have wend that, in so litel a throwe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">385</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Fortune our Ioye wolde han over-throwe?</p>
<p class="stanza">56. For in this world ther is no creature,</p>
<p>As to my doom, that ever saw ruyne</p>
<p>Straungere than this, thorugh cas or aventure.</p>
<p>But who may al eschewe or al devyne?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">390</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Swich is this world; for-thy I thus defyne,</p>
<p>Ne trust no wight to finden in Fortune</p>
<p>Ay <a href="#TIVNL392" id="TIVL392" class="pginternal">propretee</a>; hir yeftes been comune.</p>
<p class="stanza">57. But tel me this, why thou art now so mad</p>
<p>To sorwen thus? Why lystow in this wyse,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">395</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page315">{315}</span>Sin thy desyr al holly hastow
    had,</p>
<p>So that, by right, it oughte y-now suffyse?</p>
<p>But I, that never felte in my servyse</p>
<p>A frendly chere or loking of an yë,</p>
<p>Lat me thus wepe and wayle, til I dye.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">400</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">58. And over al this, as thou wel wost thy-selve,</p>
<p>This town is ful of ladies al aboute;</p>
<p>And, to my doom, fairer than swiche twelve</p>
<p>As ever she was, shal I finde, in som route,</p>
<p>Ye, oon or two, with-outen any doute.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">405</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For-thy be glad, myn owene dere brother,</p>
<p>If she be lost, we shul recovere another.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TIVNL407" id="TIVL407" class="pginternal">59</a>. What, god for-bede alwey that ech
    plesaunce</p>
<p>In o thing were, and in non other wight!</p>
<p>If oon can singe, another can wel daunce;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">410</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">If this be goodly, she is glad and light;</p>
<p>And this is fayr, and that can good a-right.</p>
<p>Ech for his vertu holden is for dere,</p>
<p>Bothe <a href="#TIVNL413" id="TIVL413" class="pginternal">heroner</a> and <a href="#TIVNL413" class="pginternal">faucon for
    rivere</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza">60. And eek, as writ <a href="#TIVNL414" id="TIVL414" class="pginternal">Zanzis</a>, that was ful
    wys,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">415</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">"The newe love out chaceth ofte the olde;"</p>
<p>And up-on newe cas lyth newe avys.</p>
<p>Thenk eek, thy-self to saven artow holde;</p>
<p>Swich fyr, by proces, shal of kinde colde.</p>
<p>For sin it is but casuel plesaunce,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">420</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Som cas shal putte it out of remembraunce.</p>
<p class="stanza">61. For al-so seur as day cometh after night,</p>
<p>The newe love, labour or other wo,</p>
<p>Or elles selde seinge of a wight,</p>
<p>Don olde affecciouns alle over-go.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">425</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And, for thy part, thou shalt have oon of tho</p>
<p>To abrigge with thy bittre peynes smerte;</p>
<p>Absence of hir shal dryve hir out of herte.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page316">{316}</span>62. Thise wordes seyde he for
    the nones alle,</p>
<p>To helpe his freend, lest he for sorwe deyde.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">430</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For doutelees, to doon his wo to falle,</p>
<p>He roughte not what unthrift that he seyde.</p>
<p>But Troilus, that neigh for sorwe deyde,</p>
<p>Tok litel hede of al that ever he mente;</p>
<p>Oon ere it herde, at the other out it wente:—</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">435</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">63. But at the laste answerde and seyde, 'freend,</p>
<p>This lechecraft, or heled thus to be,</p>
<p>Were wel sitting, if that I were a feend,</p>
<p>To traysen hir that trewe is unto me!</p>
<p>I pray god, lat this consayl never y-thee;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">440</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But do me rather sterve anon-right here</p>
<p>Er I thus do as thou me woldest lere.</p>
<p class="stanza">64. She that I serve, y-wis, what so thou seye,</p>
<p>To whom myn herte enhabit is by right,</p>
<p>Shal han me holly hires til that I deye.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">445</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For, Pandarus, sin I have trouthe hir hight,</p>
<p>I wol not been untrewe for no wight;</p>
<p>But as hir man I wol ay live and sterve,</p>
<p>And never other creature serve.</p>
<p class="stanza">65. And ther thou seyst, thou shall as faire finde</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">450</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As she, lat be, make no comparisoun</p>
<p>To creature y-formed here by kinde.</p>
<p>O leve Pandare, in conclusioun,</p>
<p>I wol not be of thyn opinioun,</p>
<p>Touching al this; for whiche I thee biseche,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">455</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">So hold thy pees; thou sleest me with thy speche.</p>
