<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1550</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ber witnesse of this word that seyd is here,</p>
<p>That thilke day that ich untrewe be</p>
<p>To Troilus, myn owene herte free,</p>
<p>That thou retorne bakwarde to thy welle,</p>
<p>And I with body and soule sinke in helle!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1555</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">223. But that ye speke, awey thus for to go</p>
<p>And leten alle your freendes, god for-bede,</p>
<p>For any womman, that ye sholden so,</p>
<p>And namely, sin Troye hath now swich nede</p>
<p>Of help; and eek of o thing taketh hede,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1560</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">If this were wist, my lif <a href="#TIVNL1560" id="TIVL1560" class="pginternal">laye</a> in
    balaunce,</p>
<p>And your honour; god shilde us fro mischaunce!</p>
<p class="stanza">224. And if so be that pees her-after <a href="#TIVNL1562" id="TIVL1562" class="pginternal">take</a>,</p>
<p>As alday happeth, after anger, game,</p>
<p>Why, lord! the sorwe and wo ye wolden make,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1565</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That ye ne dorste come ayein for shame!</p>
<p>And er that ye Iuparten so your name,</p>
<p>Beth nought to hasty in this hote fare;</p>
<p>For hasty man ne wanteth never care.</p>
<p class="stanza">225. What trowe ye the peple eek al aboute</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1570</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Wolde of it seye? It is ful light to arede.</p>
<p>They wolden seye, and swere it, out of doute,</p>
<p>That love ne droof yow nought to doon this dede,</p>
<p>But lust voluptuous and coward drede.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page353">{353}</span>Thus were al lost, y-wis, myn herte dere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1575</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Your honour, which that now shyneth so clere.</p>
<p class="stanza">226. And also thenketh on myn honestee,</p>
<p>That floureth yet, how foule I sholde it shende,</p>
<p>And with what filthe it spotted sholde be,</p>
<p>If in this forme I sholde with yow wende.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1580</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ne though I livede un-to the worldes ende,</p>
<p>My name sholde I never ayeinward winne;</p>
<p>Thus were I lost, and that were routhe and sinne.</p>
<p class="stanza">227. And for-thy slee with reson al this hete;</p>
<p>Men seyn, <a href="#TIVNL1584" id="TIVL1584" class="pginternal">"the suffraunt overcometh,"</a> pardee;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1585</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Eek <a href="#TIVNL1585" id="TIVL1585" class="pginternal">"who-so wol han leef, he leef mot
    lete;"</a></p>
<p>Thus maketh vertue of necessitee</p>
<p>By pacience, and thenk that lord is he</p>
<p>Of fortune ay, that nought wol of hir recche;</p>
<p>And she ne daunteth no wight but a wrecche.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1590</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">228. And trusteth this, that certes, herte swete,</p>
<p>Er Phebus suster, <a href="#TIVNL1591" id="TIVL1591" class="pginternal">Lucina</a> the shene,</p>
<p>The Leoun passe out of this Ariete,</p>
<p>I wol ben here, with-outen any wene.</p>
<p>I mene, as helpe me Iuno, hevenes quene,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1595</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The tenthe day, but-if that deeth me assayle,</p>
<p>I wol yow seen, with-outen any fayle.'</p>
<p class="stanza">229. 'And now, so this be sooth,' quod Troilus,</p>
<p>'I shal wel suffre un-to the tenthe day,</p>
<p>Sin that I see that nede it moot be thus.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1600</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But, for the love of god, if it be may,</p>
<p>So lat us stele prively away;</p>
<p>For ever in oon, as for to live in reste,</p>
<p>Myn herte seyth that it wol been the beste.'</p>
<p class="stanza">230. 'O mercy, god, what lyf is this?' quod she;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1605</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'Allas, ye slee me thus for verray tene!</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page354">{354}</span>I see wel now that ye mistrusten me;</p>
<p>For by your wordes it is wel y-sene.</p>
<p>Now, for the love of <a href="#TIVNL1608" id="TIVL1608" class="pginternal">Cynthia</a> the shene,</p>
<p>Mistrust me not thus causeles, for routhe;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1610</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Sin to be trewe I have yow plight my trouthe.</p>
<p class="stanza">231. And thenketh wel, that som tyme it is wit</p>
<p>To spende a tyme, <a href="#TIVNL1612" id="TIVL1612" class="pginternal">a tyme for to winne</a>;</p>
<p>Ne, pardee, lorn am I nought fro yow yit,</p>
<p>Though that we been a day or two a-twinne.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1615</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Dryf out the fantasyes yow with-inne;</p>
<p>And trusteth me, and leveth eek your sorwe,</p>
<p>Or here my trouthe, I wol not live til morwe.</p>
<p class="stanza">232. For if ye wiste how sore it doth me smerte,</p>
<p>Ye wolde cesse of this; for god, thou wost,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1620</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The <a href="#TIVNL1620" id="TIVL1620" class="pginternal">pure</a> spirit wepeth in myn herte,</p>
<p>To see yow wepen that I love most,</p>
<p>And that I moot gon to the Grekes ost.</p>
<p>Ye, nere it that I wiste remedye</p>
<p>To come ayein, right here I wolde dye!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1625</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">233. But certes, I am not so nyce a wight</p>
<p>That I ne can imaginen a way</p>
<p>To come ayein that day that I have hight.</p>
<p>For who may holde thing <a href="#TIVNL1628" id="TIVL1628" class="pginternal">that wol a-way?</a></p>
<p>My fader nought, for al his queynte pley.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1630</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And by my thrift, my wending out of Troye</p>
<p>Another day shal torne us alle to Ioye.</p>
<p class="stanza">234. For-thy, with al myn herte I yow beseke,</p>
<p>If that yow list don ought for my preyere,</p>
<p>And for the love which that I love yow eke,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1635</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That er that I departe fro yow here,</p>
<p>That of so good a comfort and a chere</p>
<p>I may you seen, that ye may bringe at reste</p>
<p>Myn herte, which that is at point to breste.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page355">{355}</span>235. And over al this, I pray
    yow,' quod she tho,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1640</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'Myn owene hertes soothfast suffisaunce,</p>
<p>Sin I am thyn al hool, with-outen mo,</p>
<p>That whyl that I am absent, no plesaunce</p>
<p>Of othere do me fro your remembraunce.</p>
<p>For I am ever a-gast, for-why men rede,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1645</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That <a href="#TIVNL1645" id="TIVL1645" class="pginternal">"love is thing ay ful of bisy
    drede."</a></p>
<p class="stanza">236. For in this world ther liveth lady noon,</p>
<p>If that ye were untrewe, as god defende!</p>
<p>That so bitraysed were or wo bigoon</p>
<p>As I, that alle trouthe in yow entende.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1650</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And douteles, if that ich other wende,</p>
<p>I nere but deed; and er ye cause finde,</p>
<p>For goddes love, so beth me not unkinde.'</p>
<p class="stanza">237. To this answerde Troilus and seyde,</p>
<p>'Now god, to whom ther nis no cause y-wrye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1655</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Me glade, as wis I never un-to Criseyde,</p>
<p>Sin thilke day I saw hir first with yë,</p>
<p>Was fals, ne never shal til that I dye.</p>
<p>At shorte wordes, wel ye may me leve;</p>
<p>I can no more, it shal be founde at preve.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1660</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">238. 'Graunt mercy, goode myn, y-wis,' quod she,</p>
<p>'And blisful Venus lat me never sterve</p>
<p>Er I may stonde of plesaunce in degree</p>
<p>To quyte him wel, that so wel can deserve;</p>
<p>And whyl that god my wit wol me conserve,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1665</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I shal so doon, so trewe I have yow founde,</p>
<p>That ay honour to me-ward shal rebounde.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TIVNL1667" id="TIVL1667" class="pginternal">239</a>. For trusteth wel, that your estat
    royal</p>
<p>Ne veyn delyt, nor only worthinesse</p>
<p>Of yow in werre, or torney marcial,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1670</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ne pompe, array, nobley, or eek richesse,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page356">{356}</span>Ne made me to rewe on your distresse;</p>
<p>But moral vertue, grounded upon trouthe,</p>
<p>That was the cause I first hadde on yow routhe!</p>
<p class="stanza">240. Eek gentil herte and manhod that ye hadde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1675</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And that ye hadde, as me thoughte, in despyt</p>
<p>Every thing that souned in-to badde,</p>
<p>As rudenesse and <a href="#TIVNL1677" id="TIVL1677" class="pginternal">poeplish</a> appetyt;</p>
<p>And that your reson brydled your delyt,</p>
<p>This made, aboven every creature,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1680</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That I was your, and shal, whyl I may dure.</p>
<p class="stanza">241. And this may lengthe of yeres not for-do,</p>
<p>Ne remuable <a href="#TIVNL1682" id="TIVL1682" class="pginternal">fortune</a> deface;</p>
<p>But Iuppiter, that of his might may do</p>
<p>The sorwful to be glad, so yeve us grace,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1685</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Er nightes ten, to meten in this place,</p>
<p>So that it may your herte and myn suffyse;</p>
<p>And fareth now wel, for tyme is that ye ryse.'</p>
<p class="stanza">242. And after that they longe y-pleyned hadde,</p>
<p>And ofte y-kist and streite in armes folde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1690</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The day gan ryse, and Troilus him cladde,</p>
<p>And rewfulliche his lady gan biholde,</p>
<p>As he that felte dethes cares colde.</p>
<p>And to hir grace he gan him recomaunde;</p>
<p>Wher him was wo, this holde I no demaunde.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1695</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">243. For mannes heed imaginen ne can,</p>
<p>Ne entendement considere, ne tonge telle</p>
<p>The cruel peynes of this sorwful man,</p>
<p>That passen every torment doun in helle.</p>
<p>For whan he saugh that she ne mighte dwelle,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1700</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Which that his soule out of his herte rente,</p>
<p>With-outen more, out of the chaumbre he wente.</p>
</div>

  <i>om.</i> that. 1608. H. cynthia; Cp. Cinthia; Cl. Cynthes (!); Ed. Scythia (!). 1623. Cp. H. Cm.
  wiste; Cl. H2. wist. 1624. Cl. H. com. 1626. H. H2. way; Cp. wey; Cl. weye. 1632. Cl. Cm. beseche.
  1633. Cl. ough. 1636. so] Cl. the. // Cl. good of; Cm. good; <i>rest</i> good a. 1637. Cl.
  <i>om.</i> ye. 1638. Ed. at; H2. in; H. a; Cl. Cp. Cm. o. // point] Cl. poyn. 1640. Cp. Cm. owene;
  Ed. owne; Cl. owen. 1642. Cl. assent (!). 1643. Cl. do ye me. 1649. Cp. H2. alle; <i>rest</i> al.
  1655. Cm. Ed. glade; H2. gladde; Cl. H. glad. 1656. H2. yhe; <i>rest</i> eye. 1658. Cm. schorte;
  Cp. Ed. shorte; <i>rest</i> short. 1660. Cp. H. Cm. goode; Cl. good. 1664. Cl. <i>om.</i> god.
  1667-1701. Cm. <i>omits</i>. 1669. H. tournay; H2. tourney. 1670. Cl. aray. 1677. and] Cl. an. //
  Cl. pepelyssh; H. Cp. H2. poeplissh. 1682. <i>Read</i> fortun-è. 1689. Cp. H2. streite; H.
  streyte; Cl. streyght. 1691. Cl. Cp. rowfullych; H. rewfulliche; H2. pitously. 1693. hir] Cl. his.
  1696. Ed. H2. Ne entendement; Cl. Cp. Nentendement. 1697. The] Cl. This. // H. cruel; Cp. cruele;
  Cl. cruwel. 1699. Cl. <i>om.</i> whan. </p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page357">{357}</span></div>
<h2 class="ac" style="margin-bottom:2.1ex;"> <span class="larger">BOOK V.</span></h2>
<p class="ac"><b>Incipit Liber Quintus.</b></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<p>1. Aprochen gan the fatal destinee</p>
<p>That Ioves hath in disposicioun,</p>
<p>And to yow, angry <a href="#TVNL3" id="TVL3" class="pginternal">Parcas</a>, sustren three,</p>
<p>Committeth, to don execucioun;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">5</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For which Criseyde moste out of the toun,</p>
<p>And Troilus shal dwelle forth in pyne</p>
<p>Til <a href="#TVNL7" id="TVL7" class="pginternal">Lachesis</a> his threed no lenger twyne.—</p>
<p class="stanza">2. The <a href="#TVNL8" id="TVL8" class="pginternal">golden-tressed</a>. Phebus heighe
    on-lofte</p>
<p>Thryës hadde alle with his bemes shene</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">10</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The snowes molte, and Zephirus as ofte</p>
<p>Y-brought ayein the tendre leves grene,</p>
<p>Sin that the <a href="#TVNL12" id="TVL12" class="pginternal">sone of Ecuba</a> the quene</p>
<p>Bigan to love <a href="#TVNL13" id="TVL13" class="pginternal">hir</a> first, for whom his sorwe</p>
<p>Was al, that she departe sholde a-morwe.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">15</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">3. Ful redy was at pryme <a href="#TVNL15" id="TVL15" class="pginternal">Dyomede</a>,</p>
<p>Criseyde un-to the Grekes ost to lede,</p>
<p>For sorwe of which she felte hir herte blede,</p>
<p>As she that niste what was best to rede.</p>
<p>And trewely, as men in bokes rede,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">20</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Men wiste never womman han the care,</p>
<p>Ne was so looth out of a toun to fare.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page358">{358}</span>4. This Troilus, with-outen
    reed or <a href="#TVNL22" id="TVL22" class="pginternal">lore</a>,</p>
<p>As man that hath his Ioyes eek forlore,</p>
<p>Was waytinge on his lady ever-more</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">25</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As she that was the soothfast <a href="#TVNL25" id="TVL25" class="pginternal">crop</a> and <a href="#TVNL25" class="pginternal">more</a></p>
<p>Of al his lust, or Ioyes here-tofore.</p>
<p>But Troilus, now farewel al thy Ioye,</p>
<p>For shaltow never seen hir eft in Troye!</p>
<p class="stanza">5. Soth is, that whyl he bood in this manere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">30</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He gan his wo ful manly for to hyde,</p>
<p>That wel unnethe it seen was in his chere;</p>
<p>But at the yate ther she sholde oute ryde</p>
<p>With certeyn folk, he hoved hir tabyde,</p>
<p>So wo bigoon, al wolde he nought him pleyne,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">35</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That on his hors unnethe he sat for peyne.</p>
<p class="stanza">6. For ire he quook, so gan his herte gnawe,</p>
<p>Whan Diomede on horse gan him dresse,</p>
<p>And seyde un-to him-self this ilke sawe,</p>
<p>'Allas,' quod he, 'thus foul a wrecchednesse</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">40</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Why suffre ich it, why nil ich it redresse?</p>
<p>Were it not bet at ones for to dye</p>
<p>Than ever-more in langour thus to drye?</p>
<p class="stanza">7. Why nil I make at ones riche and pore</p>
<p>To have y-nough to done, er that she go?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">45</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Why nil I bringe al Troye upon a rore?</p>
<p>Why nil I sleen this Diomede also?</p>
<p>Why nil I rather with a man or two</p>
<p>Stele hir a-way? Why wol I this endure?</p>
<p>Why nil I helpen to myn owene cure?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">50</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">8. But why he nolde doon so fel a dede,</p>
<p>That shal I seyn, and why him liste it spare:</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page359">{359}</span>He hadde in herte alwey a maner drede,</p>
<p>Lest that Criseyde, <a href="#TVNL53" id="TVL53" class="pginternal">in rumour of this fare</a>,</p>
<p>Sholde han ben slayn; lo, this was al his care.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">55</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And elles, certeyn, as I seyde yore,</p>
<p>He hadde it doon, with-outen wordes more.</p>
<p class="stanza">9. Criseyde, whan she redy was to ryde,</p>
<p>Ful sorwfully she sighte, and seyde 'allas!'</p>
<p>But forth she moot, for ought that may bityde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">60</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And forth she rit ful sorwfully a pas.</p>
<p>Ther nis non other remedie in this cas.</p>
<p>What wonder is though that hir sore smerte,</p>
<p>Whan she forgoth hir owene swete herte?</p>
<p class="stanza">10. This Troilus, in wyse of curteisye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">65</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#TVNL65" id="TVL65" class="pginternal">With hauke on hond</a>, and with an huge route</p>
<p>Of knightes, rood and dide hir companye,</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL67" id="TVL67" class="pginternal">Passinge</a> al the <a href="#TVNL67" class="pginternal">valey</a> fer
    with-oute.</p>
<p>And ferther wolde han riden, out of doute,</p>
<p>Ful fayn, and wo was him to goon so sone;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">70</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But torne he moste, and it was eek to done.</p>
<p class="stanza">11. And right with that was <a href="#TVNL71" id="TVL71" class="pginternal">Antenor</a>
    y-come</p>
<p>Out of the Grekes ost, and every wight</p>
<p>Was of it glad, and seyde he was wel-come.</p>
<p>And Troilus, al nere his herte light,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">75</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He peyned him with al his fulle might</p>
<p>Him to with-holde of wepinge at the leste,</p>
<p>And Antenor he kiste, and made feste.</p>
<p class="stanza">12. And ther-with-al he moste his leve take,</p>
<p>And caste his eye upon hir pitously,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">80</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And neer he rood, his cause for to make,</p>
<p>To take hir by the honde al sobrely.</p>
<p>And lord! so she gan wepen tendrely!</p>
<p>And he ful softe and sleighly gan hir seye,</p>
<p>'Now hold your day, and dooth me not to deye.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">85</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page360">{360}</span>13. With that his courser
    torned he a-boute</p>
<p>With face pale, and un-to Diomede</p>
<p>No word he spak, ne noon of al his route;</p>
<p>Of which the <a href="#TVNL88" id="TVL88" class="pginternal">sone of Tydeus</a> took hede,</p>
<p>As he that <a href="#TVNL89" id="TVL89" class="pginternal">coude more than the crede</a></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">90</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">In swich a craft, and <a href="#TVNL90" id="TVL90" class="pginternal">by the reyne hir
    hente</a>;</p>
<p>And Troilus to Troye homwarde he wente.</p>
<p class="stanza">14. This Diomede, that ladde hir by the brydel,</p>
<p>Whan that he saw the folk of Troye aweye,</p>
<p>Thoughte, 'al my labour shal not been on ydel,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">95</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">If that I may, for somwhat shal I seye.</p>
<p>For at the worste it may yet shorte our weye.</p>
<p>I have herd seyd, eek tymes twyës twelve,</p>
<p>"He is a fool <a href="#TVNL98" id="TVL98" class="pginternal">that wol for-yete him-selve</a>."'</p>
<p class="stanza">15. But natheles this thoughte he wel ynough,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">100</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'That certaynly I am aboute nought</p>
<p>If that I speke of love, or <a href="#TVNL101" id="TVL101" class="pginternal">make it tough</a>;</p>
<p>For douteles, if she have in hir thought</p>
<p>Him that I gesse, he may not been y-brought</p>
<p>So sone awey; but I shal finde a mene,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That she not wite as yet shal what I mene.'</p>
<p class="stanza">16. This Diomede, as he that <a href="#TVNL106" id="TVL106" class="pginternal">coude his
    good</a>,</p>
<p>Whan this was doon, gan fallen forth in speche</p>
<p>Of this and that, and asked why she stood</p>
<p>In swich disese, and gan hir eek biseche,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That if that he encrese mighte or eche</p>
<p>With any thing hir ese, that she sholde</p>
<p>Comaunde it him, and seyde he doon it wolde.</p>
<p class="stanza">17. For trewely he swoor hir, as a knight,</p>
<p>That ther nas thing with whiche he mighte hir plese,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That he nolde doon his peyne and al his might</p>
<p>To doon it, for to doon hir herte an ese.</p>
<p>And preyede hir, she wolde hir sorwe apese,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page361">{361}</span>And seyde, 'y-wis, we Grekes con have Ioye</p>
<p>To honouren yow, as wel as folk of Troye.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">120</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">18. He seyde eek thus, 'I woot, yow thinketh straunge,</p>
<p>No wonder is, for it is to yow newe,</p>
<p>Thaqueintaunce of these Troianes to chaunge,</p>
<p>For folk of Grece, that ye never knewe.</p>
<p>But wolde never god but-if as trewe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">A Greek ye shulde among us alle finde</p>
<p>As any Troian is, and eek as kinde.</p>
<p class="stanza">19. And by the cause I swoor yow right, lo, now,</p>
<p>To been your freend, and <a href="#TVNL128" id="TVL128" class="pginternal">helply</a>, to my might,</p>
<p>And for that more acqueintaunce eek of yow</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Have ich had than another straunger wight,</p>
<p>So fro this forth I pray yow, day and night,</p>
<p>Comaundeth me, how sore that me smerte,</p>
<p>To doon al that may lyke un-to your herte;</p>
<p class="stanza">20. And that ye me wolde as your brother trete,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">135</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And taketh not my frendship in despyt;</p>
<p>And though your sorwes be for thinges grete,</p>
<p>Noot I not why, but out of more respyt,</p>
<p>Myn herte hath for to amende it greet delyt.</p>
<p>And if I may your harmes not redresse,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I am right sory for your hevinesse.</p>
<p class="stanza">21. And though ye Troians with us Grekes wrothe</p>
<p>Han many a day be, alwey yet, pardee,</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL143" id="TVL143" class="pginternal">O god of love</a> in sooth we serven bothe.</p>
<p>And, for the love of god, my lady free,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">145</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Whom so ye hate, as beth not wroth with me.</p>
<p>For trewely, ther can no wight yow serve,</p>
<p>That half so looth your wraththe wolde deserve.</p>
<p class="stanza">22. And nere it that we been so neigh the tente</p>
<p>Of Calkas, which that seen us bothe may,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">150</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page362">{362}</span>I wolde of this yow telle al myn
    entente;</p>
<p>But <a href="#TVNL151" id="TVL151" class="pginternal">this enseled</a> til another day.</p>
<p>Yeve me your hond, I am, and shal ben ay,</p>
<p>God help me so, whyl that my lyf may dure,</p>
<p>Your owene aboven every creature.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">155</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">23. Thus seyde I never er now to womman born;</p>
<p>For god myn herte as wisly glade so,</p>
<p>I lovede never womman here-biforn</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL158" id="TVL158" class="pginternal">As paramours</a> ne never shal no mo.</p>
<p>And, for the love of god, beth not my fo;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">160</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Al can I not to yow, my lady dere,</p>
<p>Compleyne aright, for I am yet to lere.</p>
<p class="stanza">24. And wondreth not, myn owene lady bright,</p>
<p>Though that I speke of love to you thus blyve;</p>
<p>For I have herd or this of many a wight,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">165</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Hath loved thing he never saugh his lyve.</p>
<p>Eek I am not of power for to stryve</p>
<p>Ayens the god of love, but him obeye</p>
<p>I wol alwey, and mercy I yow preye.</p>
<p class="stanza">25. Ther been so worthy knightes in this place,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">170</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And ye so fair, that everich of hem alle</p>
<p>Wol peynen him to stonden in your grace.</p>
<p>But mighte me so fair a grace falle,</p>
<p>That ye me for your servaunt wolde calle,</p>
<p>So lowly ne so trewely you serve</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">175</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Nil noon of hem, as I shal, til I sterve.'</p>
<p class="stanza">26. Criseide un-to that purpos lyte answerde,</p>
<p>As she that was with sorwe oppressed so</p>
<p>That, in effect, she nought his tales herde,</p>
<p>But here and there, now here a word or two.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">180</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Hir thoughte hir sorwful herte <a href="#TVNL180" id="TVL180" class="pginternal">brast</a>
    a-two.</p>
<p>For whan she gan hir fader fer aspye,</p>
<p>Wel neigh doun of hir hors she gan to <a href="#TVNL182" id="TVL182" class="pginternal">sye</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page363">{363}</span>27. But natheles she thonked
    Diomede</p>
<p>Of al his travaile, and his goode chere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">185</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And that him liste his friendship hir to bede;</p>
<p>And she accepteth it in good manere,</p>
<p>And wolde do fayn that is him leef and dere;</p>
<p>And trusten him she wolde, and wel she mighte,</p>
<p>As seyde she, and from hir hors she alighte.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">190</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">28. Hir fader hath hir in his armes nome,</p>
<p>And tweynty tyme he kiste his doughter swete,</p>
<p>And seyde, 'O dere doughter myn, wel-come!'</p>
<p>She seyde eek, she was fayn with him to mete,</p>
<p>And stood forth <a href="#TVNL194" id="TVL194" class="pginternal">mewet, mildë</a>, and mansuete.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">195</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But here I leve hir with hir fader dwelle,</p>
<p>And forth I wol of Troilus yow telle.</p>
<p class="stanza">29. To Troye is come this woful Troilus,</p>
<p>In sorwe aboven alle sorwes smerte,</p>
<p>With felon look, and face dispitous.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">200</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Tho sodeinly doun from his hors he sterte,</p>
<p>And thorugh his paleys, with a swollen herte,</p>
<p>To chambre he wente; of no-thing took he hede,</p>
<p>Ne noon to him dar speke a word for drede.</p>
<p class="stanza">30. And there his sorwes that he spared hadde</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">205</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He yaf an issue large, and 'deeth!' he cryde;</p>
<p>And in his throwes frenetyk and madde</p>
<p>He cursed Iove, Appollo, and eek Cupyde,</p>
<p>He cursed Ceres, Bacus, and <a href="#TVNL208" id="TVL208" class="pginternal">Cipryde</a>,</p>
<p>His burthe, him-self, his fate, and eek nature,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">210</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And, save his lady, every creature.</p>
<p class="stanza">31. To bedde he goth, and weyleth there and torneth</p>
<p>In <a href="#TVNL212" id="TVL212" class="pginternal">furie</a>, as dooth he, Ixion, in helle;</p>
<p>And in this wyse he neigh til day soiorneth.</p>
<p>But tho bigan his herte a lyte unswelle</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">215</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thorugh teres which that gonnen up to welle;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page364">{364}</span>And pitously he cryde up-on Criseyde,</p>
<p>And to him-self right thus he spak, and seyde:—</p>
<p class="stanza">32. 'Wher is myn owene lady lief and dere,</p>
<p>Wher is hir whyte brest, wher is it, where?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">220</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Wher ben hir armes and hir eyen clere,</p>
<p>That yesternight this tyme with me were?</p>
<p>Now may I wepe allone many a tere,</p>
<p>And graspe aboute I may, but in this place,</p>
<p>Save a pilowe, I finde nought tenbrace.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">225</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">33. How shal I do? Whan shal she com ayeyn?</p>
<p>I noot, allas! why leet ich hir to go?</p>
<p>As wolde god, ich hadde as tho be sleyn!</p>
<p>O herte myn, Criseyde, O swete fo!</p>
<p>O lady myn, that I love and no mo!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">230</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To whom for ever-mo myn herte I dowe;</p>
<p>See how I deye, ye nil me not rescowe!</p>
<p class="stanza">34. Who seeth yow now, my righte lode-sterre?</p>
<p>Who sit right now or stant in your presence?</p>
<p>Who can conforten now your hertes werre?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">235</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Now I am gon, whom yeve ye audience?</p>
<p>Who speketh for me right now in myn absence?</p>
<p>Allas, no wight; and that is al my care;</p>
<p>For wel wot I, as yvel as I ye fare.</p>
<p class="stanza">35. How shulde I thus ten dayes ful endure,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">240</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Whan I the firste night have al this tene?</p>
<p>How shal she doon eek, sorwful creature?</p>
<p>For tendernesse, how shal she this sustene,</p>
<p>Swich wo for me? O pitous, pale, and grene</p>
<p>Shal been your fresshe wommanliche face</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">245</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For langour, er ye torne un-to this place.'</p>
<p class="stanza">36. And whan he fil in any slomeringes,</p>
<p>Anoon biginne he sholde for to grone,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page365">{365}</span>And dremen of the dredfulleste thinges</p>
<p>That mighte been; <a href="#TVNL249" id="TVL249" class="pginternal">as, mete</a> he were allone</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">250</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">In place horrible, makinge ay his mone,</p>
<p>Or meten that he was amonges alle</p>
<p>His enemys, and in hir hondes falle.</p>
<p class="stanza">37. And ther-with-al his body sholde sterte,</p>
<p>And with the stert al sodeinliche awake,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">255</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And swich a tremour fele aboute his herte,</p>
<p>That of the feer his body sholde quake;</p>
<p>And there-with-al he sholde a noyse make,</p>
<p>And seme as though he sholde falle depe</p>
<p>From heighe a-lofte; and than he wolde wepe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">260</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">38. And rewen on him-self so pitously,</p>
<p>That wonder was to here his fantasye.</p>
<p>Another tyme he sholde mightily</p>
<p>Conforte him-self, and seyn it was folye,</p>
<p>So causeles swich drede for to drye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">265</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And eft biginne his aspre sorwes newe,</p>
<p>That every man mighte on his sorwes rewe.</p>
<p class="stanza">39. Who coude telle aright or ful discryve</p>
<p>His wo, his pleynte, his langour, and his pyne?</p>
<p>Nought al the men that han or been on-lyve.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">270</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thou, redere, mayst thy-self ful wel devyne</p>
<p>That swich a wo my wit can not defyne.</p>
<p>On ydel for to wryte it sholde I swinke,</p>
<p>Whan that my wit is wery it to thinke.</p>
<p class="stanza">40. On hevene yet the sterres were sene,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">275</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Al-though ful pale y-waxen was the mone;</p>
<p>And whyten gan the orisonte shene</p>
<p>Al estward, as it woned is to done.</p>
<p>And Phebus with his rosy carte sone</p>
<p>Gan after that to dresse him up to fare,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">280</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Whan Troilus hath sent after Pandare.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page366">{366}</span>41. This Pandare, that of al
    the day biforn</p>
<p>Ne mighte have comen Troilus to see,</p>
<p>Al-though he <a href="#TVNL283" id="TVL283" class="pginternal">on his heed</a> it hadde y-sworn,</p>
<p>For with the king Pryam alday was he,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">285</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">So that it lay not in his libertee</p>
<p>No-wher to gon, but on the morwe he wente</p>
<p>To Troilus, whan that he for him sente.</p>
<p class="stanza">42. For in his herte he coude wel devyne,</p>
<p>That Troilus al night for sorwe wook;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">290</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And that he wolde telle him of his pyne,</p>
<p>This knew he wel y-nough, with-oute book.</p>
<p>For which to chaumbre streight the wey he took,</p>
<p>And Troilus tho sobreliche he grette,</p>
<p>And on the bed ful sone he gan him sette.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">295</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">43. 'My Pandarus,' quod Troilus, 'the sorwe</p>
<p>Which that I drye, I may not longe endure.</p>
<p>I trowe I shal not liven til to-morwe;</p>
<p>For whiche I wolde alwey, on aventure,</p>
<p>To thee devysen of my sepulture</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">300</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The forme, and of my moeble thou dispone</p>
<p>Right as thee semeth best is for to done.</p>
<p class="stanza">44. But of the fyr and flaumbe funeral</p>
<p>In whiche my body brenne shal to glede,</p>
<p>And of the feste and pleyes <a href="#TVNL304" id="TVL304" class="pginternal">palestral</a></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">305</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">At my vigile, I pray thee take good hede</p>
<p>That al be wel; and <a href="#TVNL306" id="TVL306" class="pginternal">offre Mars my stede</a>,</p>
<p>My swerd, myn helm, and, leve brother dere,</p>
<p>My sheld to Pallas yef, that shyneth clere.</p>
<p class="stanza">45. The poudre in which myn herte y-brend shal torne,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">310</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That preye I thee thou take and it conserve</p>
<p>In a vessel, that men clepeth an urne,</p>
<p>Of gold, and to my lady that I serve,</p>
<p>For love of whom thus pitously I sterve,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page367">{367}</span>So yeve it hir, and do me this plesaunce,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">315</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To preye hir kepe it for a remembraunce.</p>
<p class="stanza">46. For wel I fele, by my maladye,</p>
<p>And by my dremes now and yore ago,</p>
<p>Al certeinly, that I mot nedes dye.</p>
<p>The owle eek, which that hight <a href="#TVNL319" id="TVL319" class="pginternal">Ascaphilo</a>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">320</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Hath after me shright alle thise nightes two.</p>
<p>And, god <a href="#TVNL321" id="TVL321" class="pginternal">Mercurie</a>! of me now, woful wrecche,</p>
<p>The soule gyde, and, whan thee list, it fecche!'</p>
<p class="stanza">47. Pandare answerde, and seyde, 'Troilus,</p>
<p>My dere freend, as I have told thee yore,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">325</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That it is folye for to sorwen thus,</p>
<p>And causeles, for whiche I can no-more.</p>
<p>But who-so wol not trowen reed ne lore,</p>
<p>I can not seen in him no remedye,</p>
<p>But lete him worthen with his fantasye.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">330</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">48. But Troilus, I pray thee tel me now,</p>
<p>If that thou trowe, er this, that any wight</p>
<p>Hath loved <a href="#TVNL332" id="TVL332" class="pginternal">paramours</a> as wel as thou?</p>
<p>Ye, god wot, and fro many a worthy knight</p>
<p>Hath his lady goon a fourtenight,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">335</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And he not yet made halvendel the fare.</p>
<p>What nede is thee to maken al this care?</p>
<p class="stanza">49. Sin day by day thou mayst thy-selven see</p>
<p>That from his love, or elles from his wyf,</p>
<p>A man mot twinnen of necessitee,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">340</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ye, though he love hir as his owene lyf;</p>
<p>Yet nil he with him-self thus maken stryf.</p>
<p>For wel thow wost, my leve brother dere,</p>
<p>That alwey freendes may nought been y-fere.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page368">{368}</span>50. How doon this folk that
    seen hir loves wedded</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">345</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#TVNL345" id="TVL345" class="pginternal">By freendes might</a>, as it bi-tit ful
    ofte,</p>
<p>And seen hem in hir spouses bed y-bedded?</p>
<p>God woot, they take it wysly, faire and softe.</p>
<p>For-why good hope halt up hir herte on-lofte,</p>
<p>And for they can a tyme of sorwe endure;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">350</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As tyme hem <a href="#TVNL350" id="TVL350" class="pginternal">hurt</a>, a tyme doth hem cure.</p>
<p class="stanza">51. So sholdestow endure, and late slyde</p>
<p>The tyme, and fonde to ben glad and light.</p>
<p>Ten dayes nis so longe not tabyde.</p>
<p>And sin she thee to comen hath bihight,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">355</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">She nil hir hestes breken for no wight.</p>
<p>For dred thee not that she nil finden weye</p>
<p>To come ayein, my lyf that dorste I leye.</p>
<p class="stanza">52. Thy swevenes eek and al swich fantasye</p>
<p>Dryf out, and lat hem faren to mischaunce;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">360</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For <a href="#TVNL360" id="TVL360" class="pginternal">they</a> procede of thy malencolye,</p>
<p>That doth thee fele in sleep al this penaunce.</p>
<p>A straw for alle swevenes signifiaunce!</p>
<p>God helpe me so, I counte hem not a bene,</p>
<p>Ther woot no man aright what dremes mene.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">365</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><a href="#TVNL365" id="TVL365" class="pginternal">53</a>. For prestes of the temple tellen
    this,</p>
<p>That dremes been the revelaciouns</p>
<p>Of goddes, and as wel they telle, y-wis,</p>
<p>That they ben infernals illusiouns;</p>
<p>And leches seyn, that of complexiouns</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">370</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Proceden they, or fast, or glotonye.</p>
<p>Who woot in sooth thus what they signifye?</p>
<p class="stanza">54. Eek othere seyn that thorugh impressiouns,</p>
<p>As if a wight hath faste a thing in minde,</p>
<p>That ther-of cometh swiche avisiouns;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">375</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And othere seyn, as they in bokes finde,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page369">{369}</span>That, after tymes of the yeer by kinde,</p>
<p>Men dreme, and that theffect goth by the mone;</p>
<p>But leve no dreem, for it is nought to done.</p>
<p class="stanza">55. Wel worth of dremes ay <a href="#TVNL379" id="TVL379" class="pginternal">thise olde
    wyves</a>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">380</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And treweliche eek augurie of thise foules;</p>
<p>For fere of which men wenen lese her lyves,</p>
<p>As ravenes qualm, or shryking of thise oules.</p>
<p>To trowen on it bothe fals and foul is.</p>
<p>Allas, allas, so noble a creature</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">385</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As is a man, shal drede swich ordure!</p>
<p class="stanza">56. For which with al myn herte I thee beseche,</p>
<p>Un-to thy-self that al this <a href="#TVNL387" id="TVL387" class="pginternal">thou foryive</a>;</p>
<p>And rys up now with-oute more speche,</p>
<p>And lat us caste how forth may best be drive</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">390</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">This tyme, and eek how freshly we may live</p>
<p>Whan that she cometh, the which shal be right sone;</p>
<p>God help me so, the beste is thus to done.</p>
<p class="stanza">57. Rys, lat us speke of lusty lyf in Troye</p>
<p>That we han lad, and forth the tyme dryve;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">395</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And eek of tyme cominge us reioye,</p>
<p>That bringen shal our blisse now so blyve;</p>
<p>And langour of these twyës dayes fyve</p>
<p>We shal ther-with so foryete or oppresse,</p>
<p>That wel unnethe it doon shal us duresse.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">400</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">58. This toun is ful of lordes al aboute,</p>
<p>And trewes lasten al this mene whyle.</p>
<p>Go we pleye us in som lusty route</p>
<p>To <a href="#TVNL403" id="TVL403" class="pginternal">Sarpedon</a>, not hennes but a myle.</p>
<p>And thus thou shalt the tyme wel bigyle,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">405</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And dryve it forth un-to that blisful morwe,</p>
<p>That thou hir see, that cause is of thy sorwe.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page370">{370}</span>59. Now rys, my dere brother
    Troilus;</p>
<p>For certes, it noon honour is to thee</p>
<p>To wepe, and in thy bed to <a href="#TVNL409" id="TVL409" class="pginternal">iouken</a> thus.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">410</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For trewely, of o thing trust to me,</p>
<p>If thou thus ligge a day, or two, or three,</p>
<p>The folk wol wene that thou, for cowardyse,</p>
<p>Thee feynest syk, and that thou darst not ryse.'</p>
<p class="stanza">60. This Troilus answerde, 'O brother dere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">415</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">This knowen folk that han y-suffred peyne,</p>
<p>That though he wepe and make sorwful chere,</p>
<p>That feleth harm and smert in every veyne,</p>
<p>No wonder is; and though I ever pleyne,</p>
<p>Or alwey wepe, I am no-thing to blame,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">420</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Sin I have lost the cause of al my game.</p>
<p class="stanza">61. But sin <a href="#TVNL421" id="TVL421" class="pginternal">of fyne force</a> I moot aryse,</p>
<p>I shal aryse, as sone as ever I may;</p>
<p>And god, to whom myn herte I sacrifyse,</p>
<p>So sende us hastely the tenthe day!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">425</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For was ther never fowl so fayn of May,</p>
<p>As I shal been, whan that she cometh in Troye,</p>
<p>That cause is of my torment and my Ioye.</p>
<p class="stanza">62. But whider is thy reed,' quod Troilus,</p>
<p>'That we may pleye us best in al this toun?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">430</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'By god, my conseil is,' quod Pandarus,</p>
<p>'To ryde and pleye us with king Sarpedoun.'</p>
<p>So longe of this they speken up and doun,</p>
<p>Til Troilus gan at the laste assente</p>
<p>To ryse, and forth to Sarpedoun they wente.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">435</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">63. This Sarpedoun, as he that honourable</p>
<p>Was ever his lyve, and ful of heigh prowesse,</p>
<p>With al that mighte y-served been on table,</p>
<p>That deyntee was, al coste it greet richesse,</p>
<p>He fedde hem day by day, that swich noblesse,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">440</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page371">{371}</span>As seyden bothe the moste and
    eek the leste,</p>
<p>Was never er that day wist at any feste.</p>
<p class="stanza">64. Nor in this world ther is non instrument</p>
<p>Delicious, through wind, or touche, or corde,</p>
<p>As fer as any wight hath ever y-went,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">445</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That tonge telle or herte may recorde,</p>
<p>That at that feste it nas wel herd acorde;</p>
<p>Ne of ladies eek so fayr a companye</p>
<p>On daunce, er tho, was never y-seyn with yë.</p>
<p class="stanza">65. But what avayleth this to Troilus,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">450</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That for his sorwe no-thing of it roughte?</p>
<p>For ever in oon his herte <a href="#TVNL451" id="TVL451" class="pginternal">piëtous</a></p>
<p>Ful bisily Criseyde his lady soughte.</p>
<p>On hir was ever al that his herte thoughte.</p>
<p>Now this, now that, so faste imagininge,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">455</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That glade, y-wis, can him no festeyinge.</p>
<p class="stanza">66. These ladies eek that at this feste been,</p>
<p>Sin that he saw his lady was a-weye,</p>
<p>It was his sorwe upon hem for to seen,</p>
<p>Or for to here on instrumentz so pleye.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">460</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#TVNL460" id="TVL460" class="pginternal">For</a> she, that of his herte berth the
    keye,</p>
<p>Was absent, lo, this was his fantasye,</p>
<p>That no wight sholde make melodye.</p>
<p class="stanza">67. Nor ther nas houre in al the day or night,</p>
<p>Whan he was ther-as no wight mighte him here,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">465</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That he ne seyde, 'O lufsom lady bright,</p>
<p>How have ye faren, sin that ye were here?</p>
<p>Wel-come, y-wis, myn owene lady dere.'</p>
<p>But welaway, al this nas but a mase;</p>
<p>Fortune his howve entended bet <a href="#TVNL469" id="TVL469" class="pginternal">to glase</a>.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">470</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page372">{372}</span>68. The lettres eek, that
    she of olde tyme</p>
<p>Hadde him y-sent, he wolde allone rede,</p>
<p>An hundred sythe, a-twixen noon and pryme;</p>
<p>Refiguringe hir shap, hir womanhede,</p>
<p>With-inne his herte, and every word and dede</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">475</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That passed was, and thus he droof to an ende</p>
<p>The ferthe day, and seyde, he wolde wende.</p>
<p class="stanza">69. And seyde, 'leve brother Pandarus,</p>
<p>Intendestow that we shul <a href="#TVNL478" id="TVL478" class="pginternal">herë</a> bleve</p>
<p>Til Sarpedoun wol forth <a href="#TVNL479" id="TVL479" class="pginternal">congeyen us</a>?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">480</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Yet were it fairer that we toke our leve.</p>
<p>For goddes love, lat us now sone at eve</p>
<p>Our leve take, and homward lat us torne;</p>
<p>For trewely, I nil not thus soiorne.'</p>
<p class="stanza">70. Pandare answerde, 'be we comen hider</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">485</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#TVNL484" id="TVL484" class="pginternal">To fecchen fyr</a>, and rennen hoom ayeyn?</p>
<p>God helpe me so, I can not tellen whider</p>
<p>We mighten goon, if I shal soothly seyn,</p>
<p>Ther any wight is of us more fayn</p>
<p>Than Sarpedoun; and if we hennes hye</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">490</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thus sodeinly, I holde it vilanye,</p>
<p class="stanza">71. Sin that we seyden that we wolde bleve</p>
<p>With him a wouke; and now, thus sodeinly,</p>
<p>The ferthe day to take of him our leve,</p>
<p>He wolde wondren on it, trewely!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">495</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Lat us holde forth our purpos fermely;</p>
<p>And sin that ye bihighten him to byde,</p>
<p>Hold forward now, and after lat us ryde.'</p>
<p class="stanza">72. Thus Pandarus, with alle peyne and wo,</p>
<p>Made him to dwelle; and at the woukes ende,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">500</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page373">{373}</span>Of Sarpedoun they toke hir leve
    tho,</p>
<p>And on hir wey they spedden hem to wende.</p>
<p>Quod Troilus, 'now god me grace sende,</p>
<p>That I may finden, at myn hom-cominge,</p>
<p>Criseyde comen!' and ther-with gan he singe.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">505</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">73. 'Ye, <a href="#TVNL505" id="TVL505" class="pginternal">hasel-wode</a>!' thoughte this
    Pandare,</p>
<p>And to him-self ful softely he seyde,</p>
<p>'God woot, refreyden may this hote fare</p>
<p>Er Calkas sende Troilus Criseyde!'</p>
<p>But natheles, he Iaped thus, and seyde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">510</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And swor, y-wis, his herte him wel bihighte,</p>
<p>She wolde come as sone as ever she mighte.</p>
<p class="stanza">74. Whan they un-to the paleys were y-comen</p>
<p>Of Troilus, they doun of hors alighte,</p>
<p>And to the chambre hir wey than han they nomen.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">515</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And in-to tyme that it gan to nighte,</p>
<p>They spaken of Crisëyde the brighte.</p>
<p>And after this, whan that hem bothe leste,</p>
<p>They spedde hem fro the soper un-to reste.</p>
<p class="stanza">75. On morwe, as sone as day bigan to clere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">520</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">This Troilus gan of his sleep tabreyde,</p>
<p>And to Pandare, his owene brother dere,</p>
<p>'For love of god,' ful pitously he seyde,</p>
<p>'As go we seen the paleys of Criseyde;</p>
<p>For sin we yet may have namore feste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">525</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">So lat us seen hir paleys at the leste.'</p>
<p class="stanza">76. And ther-with-al, his meyne for to blende,</p>
<p>A cause he fond in toune for to go,</p>
<p>And to Criseydes hous they gonnen wende.</p>
<p>But lord! this sely Troilus was wo!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">530</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Him thoughte his sorweful herte braste a-two.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page374">{374}</span>For whan he saugh hir dores sperred alle,</p>
<p>Wel neigh for sorwe a-doun he gan to falle.</p>
<p class="stanza">77. Therwith whan he was war and gan biholde</p>
<p>How shet was every windowe of the place,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">535</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As frost, him thoughte, his herte gan to colde;</p>
<p>For which with chaunged deedlich pale face,</p>
<p>With-outen word, he forth bigan to pace;</p>
<p>And, as god wolde, he gan so faste ryde,</p>
<p>That no wight of his contenaunce aspyde.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">540</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">78. Than seyde he thus, 'O paleys desolat,</p>
<p>O hous, of houses <a href="#TVNL541" id="TVL541" class="pginternal">whylom best y-hight</a>,</p>
<p>O paleys empty and disconsolat,</p>
<p>O thou lanterne, of which queynt is the light,</p>
<p>O paleys, whylom day, that now art night,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">545</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Wel oughtestow to falle, and I to dye,</p>
<p>Sin she is went that wont was us to gye!</p>
<p class="stanza">79. O paleys, whylom croune of houses alle,</p>
<p>Enlumined with sonne of alle blisse!</p>
<p>O ring, fro which the ruby is out-falle,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">550</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">O cause of wo, that cause hast been of lisse!</p>
<p>Yet, sin I may no bet, fayn wolde I <a href="#TVNL552" id="TVL552" class="pginternal">kisse</a></p>
<p>Thy colde dores, dorste I for this route;</p>
<p>And fare-wel shryne, of which the seynt is oute!'</p>
<p class="stanza">80. Ther-with he caste on Pandarus his yë</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">555</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">With chaunged face, and pitous to biholde;</p>
<p>And whan he mighte his tyme aright aspye,</p>
<p>Ay as he rood, to Pandarus he tolde</p>
<p>His newe sorwe, and eek his Ioyes olde,</p>
<p>So pitously and with so dede an hewe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">560</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That every wight mighte on his sorwe rewe.</p>
<p class="stanza">81. Fro thennesforth he rydeth up and doun,</p>
<p>And every thing com him to remembraunce</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page375">{375}</span>As he rood forth by places of the toun</p>
<p>In whiche he whylom hadde al his plesaunce.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">565</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'Lo, yond saugh I myn owene lady daunce;</p>
<p>And in that temple, with hir eyen clere,</p>
<p>Me caughte first my righte lady dere.</p>
<p class="stanza">82. And yonder have I herd ful lustily</p>
<p>My dere herte laughe, and yonder pleye</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">570</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Saugh I hir ones eek ful blisfully.</p>
<p>And yonder ones to me gan she seye,</p>
<p>"Now goode swete, love me wel, I preye."</p>
<p>And yond so goodly gan she me biholde,</p>
<p>That to the deeth myn herte is to hir holde.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">575</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">83. And at that corner, in the yonder hous,</p>
<p>Herde I myn alderlevest lady dere</p>
<p>So wommanly, with voys melodious,</p>
<p>Singen so wel, so goodly, and so clere,</p>
<p>That in my soule yet me thinketh I here</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">580</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The blisful soun; and, in that yonder place,</p>
<p>My lady first me took un-to hir grace.'</p>
<p class="stanza">84. Thanne thoughte he thus, 'O blisful lord Cupyde,</p>
<p>Whanne I the proces have in my memorie,</p>
<p>How thou me hast werreyed on every syde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">585</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Men mighte a book make of it, lyk a storie.</p>
<p>What nede is thee to seke on me victorie,</p>
<p>Sin I am thyn, and hoolly at thy wille?</p>
<p>What Ioye hastow thyn owene folk to spille?</p>
<p class="stanza">85. Wel hastow, lord, y-wroke on me thyn ire,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">590</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thou mighty god, and dredful for to greve!</p>
<p>Now mercy, lord, thou wost wel I desire</p>
<p>Thy grace most, of alle lustes leve.</p>
<p>And live and deye I wol in thy bileve;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page376">{376}</span>For which I naxe in guerdon but a bone,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">595</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That thou Criseyde ayein me sende sone.</p>
<p class="stanza">86. Distreyne hir herte as faste to retorne</p>
<p>As thou dost myn to longen hir to see;</p>
<p>Than woot I wel, that she nil not soiorne.</p>
<p>Now, blisful lord, so cruel thou ne be</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">600</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Un-to the blood of Troye, I preye thee,</p>
<p>As <a href="#TVNL601" id="TVL601" class="pginternal">Iuno</a> was un-to the blood Thebane,</p>
<p>For which the folk of Thebes caughte hir bane.'</p>
<p class="stanza">87. And after this he to the yates wente</p>
<p>Ther-as Criseyde out-rood a ful good paas,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">605</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And up and doun ther made he many a wente,</p>
<p>And to him-self ful ofte he seyde 'allas!</p>
<p>From hennes rood my blisse and my solas!</p>
<p>As wolde blisful god now, for his Ioye,</p>
<p>I mighte hir seen ayein come in-to Troye.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">610</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">88. And to the yonder hille I gan hir gyde,</p>
<p>Allas! and there I took of hir my leve!</p>
<p>And yond I saugh hir to hir fader ryde,</p>
<p>For sorwe of which myn herte shal to-cleve.</p>
<p>And hider hoom I com whan it was eve;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">615</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And here I dwelle out-cast from alle Ioye,</p>
<p>And shal, til I may seen hir eft in Troye.'</p>
<p class="stanza">89. And of him-self imagined he ofte</p>
<p>To ben defet, and pale, and waxen lesse</p>
<p>Than he was wont, and that men seyde softe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">620</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'What may it be? who can the sothe gesse</p>
<p>Why Troilus hath al this hevinesse?'</p>
<p>And al this nas but his malencolye,</p>
<p>That he hadde of him-self swich fantasye.</p>
<p class="stanza">90. Another tyme imaginen he wolde</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">625</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That every wight that wente by the weye</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page377">{377}</span>Had of him routhe, and that they seyen
    sholde,</p>
<p>'I am right sory Troilus wol deye.'</p>
<p>And thus he droof a day yet forth or tweye.</p>
<p>As ye have herd, swich lyf right gan he lede,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">630</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As he that stood bitwixen hope and drede.</p>
<p class="stanza">91. For which him lyked in his songes shewe</p>
<p>Thencheson of his wo, as he best mighte,</p>
<p>And make a song of wordes but a fewe,</p>
<p>Somwhat his woful herte for to lighte.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">635</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And whan he was from every mannes sighte,</p>
<p>With softe voys he, of his lady dere,</p>
<p>That was absent, gan singe as ye may here.</p>
<p class="stanza">92. 'O sterre, of which I lost have al the light,</p>
<p>With herte soor wel oughte I to bewayle,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">640</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That ever derk in torment, night by night,</p>
<p>Toward my deeth with wind in stere I sayle;</p>
<p>For which <a href="#TVNL642" id="TVL642" class="pginternal">the tenthe night</a> if that I fayle</p>
<p>The gyding of thy bemes brighte an houre,</p>
<p>My ship and me Caribdis wol devoure.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">645</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">93. This song when he thus songen hadde, sone</p>
<p>He fil ayein in-to his sykes olde;</p>
<p>And every night, as was his wone to done,</p>
<p>He stood the brighte mone to beholde,</p>
<p>And al his sorwe he to the mone tolde;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">650</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And seyde, 'y-wis, whan thou art horned newe,</p>
<p>I shal be glad, if al the world be trewe!</p>
<p class="stanza">94. I saugh thyn hornes olde eek by the morwe,</p>
<p>Whan hennes rood my righte lady dere,</p>
<p>That cause is of my torment and my sorwe;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">655</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For whiche, O brighte <a href="#TVNL655" id="TVL655" class="pginternal">Lucina</a> the clere,</p>
<p>For love of god, ren faste aboute thy spere!</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page378">{378}</span>For whan thyn hornes newe ginne springe,</p>
<p>Than shal she come, that may my blisse bringe!'</p>
<p class="stanza">95. The day is more, and lenger every night,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">660</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Than they be wont to be, him thoughte tho;</p>
<p>And that the sonne wente his course unright</p>
<p>By lenger wey than it was wont to go;</p>
<p>And seyde, 'y-wis, me dredeth ever-mo,</p>
<p>The sonnes sone, <a href="#TVNL664" id="TVL664" class="pginternal">Pheton</a>, be on-lyve,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">665</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And that his fadres cart amis he dryve.'</p>
<p class="stanza">96. Upon the walles faste eek wolde he walke,</p>
<p>And on the Grekes ost he wolde see,</p>
<p>And to him-self right thus he wolde talke,</p>
<p>'Lo, yonder is myn owene lady free,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">670</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Or elles yonder, ther tho tentes be!</p>
<p>And thennes comth this eyr, that is so sote,</p>
<p>That in my soule I fele it doth me bote.</p>
<p class="stanza">97. And hardely this wind, that more and more</p>
<p>Thus stoundemele encreseth in my face,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">675</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Is of my ladyes depe sykes sore.</p>
<p>I preve it thus, for in non othere place</p>
<p>Of al this toun, save onliche in this space,</p>
<p>Fele I no wind that souneth so lyk peyne;</p>
<p>It seyth, "allas! why twinned be we tweyne?"'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">680</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">98. This longe tyme he dryveth forth right thus,</p>
<p>Til fully passed was the nynthe night;</p>
<p>And ay bi-syde him was this Pandarus,</p>
<p>That bisily dide alle his fulle might</p>
<p>Him to comforte, and make his herte light;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">685</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Yevinge him hope alwey, the tenthe morwe</p>
<p>That she shal come, and stinten al his sorwe.</p>
<p class="stanza">99. Up-on that other syde eek was Criseyde,</p>
<p>With wommen fewe, among the Grekes stronge;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page379">{379}</span>For which ful ofte a day 'allas!' she
    seyde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">690</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'That I was born! Wel may myn herte longe</p>
<p>After my deeth; for now live I to longe!</p>
<p>Allas! and I ne may it not amende;</p>
<p>For now is wors than ever yet I wende.</p>
<p class="stanza">100. My fader nil for no-thing do me grace</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">695</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To goon ayein, for nought I can him queme;</p>
<p>And if so be that I my terme passe,</p>
<p>My Troilus shal in his herte deme</p>
<p>That I am fals, and so it may wel seme.</p>
<p>Thus shal I have unthank on every syde;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">700</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That I was born, so weylawey the tyde!</p>
<p class="stanza">101. And if that I me putte in Iupartye,</p>
<p>To stele awey by nighte, and it bifalle</p>
<p>That I be caught, I shal be holde a spye;</p>
<p>Or elles, lo, this drede I most of alle,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">705</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">If in the hondes of som wrecche I falle,</p>
<p>I am but lost, al be myn herte trewe;</p>
<p>Now mighty god, thou on my sorwe rewe!'</p>
<p class="stanza">102. Ful pale y-waxen was hir brighte face,</p>
<p>Hir limes lene, as she that al the day</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">710</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Stood whan she dorste, and loked on the place</p>
<p>Ther she was born, and ther she dwelt hadde ay.</p>
<p>And al the night wepinge, allas! she lay.</p>
<p>And thus despeired, out of alle cure,</p>
<p>She ladde hir lyf, this woful creature.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">715</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">103. Ful ofte a day she sighte eek for destresse,</p>
<p>And in hir-self she wente ay portrayinge</p>
<p>Of Troilus the grete worthinesse,</p>
<p>And alle his goodly wordes recordinge</p>
<p>Sin first that day hir love bigan to springe.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">720</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page380">{380}</span>And thus she sette hir woful
    herte a-fyre</p>
<p>Thorugh remembraunce of that she gan desyre.</p>
<p class="stanza">104. In al this world ther nis so cruel herte</p>
<p>That hir hadde herd compleynen in hir sorwe,</p>
<p>That nolde han wopen for hir peynes smerte,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">725</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">So tendrely she weep, bothe eve and morwe.</p>
<p>Hir nedede no teres for to borwe.</p>
<p>And this was yet the worste of al hir peyne,</p>
<p>Ther was no wight to whom she dorste hir pleyne.</p>
<p class="stanza">105. Ful rewfully she loked up-on Troye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">730</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Biheld the toures heighe and eek the halles;</p>
<p>'Allas!' quod she, 'the plesaunce and the Ioye</p>
<p>The whiche that now al torned in-to galle is,</p>
<p>Have I had ofte with-inne yonder walles!</p>
<p>O Troilus, what dostow now,' she seyde;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">735</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'Lord! whether yet thou thenke up-on Criseyde?</p>
<p class="stanza">106. Allas! I ne hadde trowed on your lore,</p>
<p>And went with yow, as ye me radde er this!</p>
<p>Thanne hadde I now not syked half so sore.</p>
<p>Who mighte have seyd, that I had doon a-mis</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">740</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To stele awey with swich on as he is?</p>
<p>But al to late cometh the letuarie,</p>
<p>Whan men the cors un-to the grave carie.</p>
<p class="stanza">107. To late is now to speke of this matere;</p>
<p>Prudence, allas! oon of <a href="#TVNL744" id="TVL744" class="pginternal">thyn eyen three</a></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">745</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Me lakked alwey, er that I cam here;</p>
<p>On tyme y-passed, wel remembred me;</p>
<p>And present tyme eek coude I wel y-see.</p>
<p>But futur tyme, er I was in the snare,</p>
<p>Coude I not seen; that causeth now my care.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">750</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page381">{381}</span>108. But natheles, bityde
    what bityde,</p>
<p>I shal to-morwe at night, by est or weste,</p>
<p>Out of this ost stele on som maner syde,</p>
<p>And go with Troilus wher-as him leste.</p>
<p>This purpos wol I holde, and this is beste.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">755</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">No fors of wikked tonges Ianglerye,</p>
<p>For ever on love han wrecches had envye.</p>
<p class="stanza">109. For who-so wole of every word take hede,</p>
<p>Or rewlen him by every wightes wit,</p>
<p>Ne shal he never thryven, out of drede.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">760</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For that that som men blamen ever yit,</p>
<p>Lo, other maner folk commenden it.</p>
<p>And as for me, for al swich variaunce,</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL763" id="TVL763" class="pginternal">Felicitee clepe I</a> my suffisaunce.</p>
<p class="stanza">110. For which, with-outen any wordes mo,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">765</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To Troye I wol, as for conclusioun.'</p>
<p>But god it wot, er fully monthes two,</p>
<p>She was ful fer fro that entencioun.</p>
<p>For bothe Troilus and Troye toun</p>
<p>Shal <a href="#TVNL769" id="TVL769" class="pginternal">knotteles</a> through-out hir herte slyde;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">770</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For she wol take a purpos for tabyde.</p>
<p class="stanza">111. This Diomede, of whom yow telle I gan,</p>
<p>Goth now, with-inne him-self ay arguinge</p>
<p>With al the sleighte and al that ever he can,</p>
<p>How he may best, with shortest taryinge,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">775</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">In-to his net Criseydes herte bringe.</p>
<p>To this entente he coude never fyne;</p>
<p>To fisshen hir, he leyde out hook and lyne.</p>
<p class="stanza">112. But natheles, wel in his herte he thoughte,</p>
<p>That she nas nat with-oute a love in Troye.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">780</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page382">{382}</span>For never, sithen he hir thennes
    broughte,</p>
<p>Ne coude he seen her laughe or make Ioye.</p>
<p>He niste how best hir herte for tacoye.</p>
<p>'But for to assaye,' he seyde, 'it nought ne greveth;</p>
<p>For he that nought nassayeth, <a href="#TVNL784" id="TVL784" class="pginternal">nought nacheveth</a>.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">785</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">113. Yet seide he to him-self upon a night,</p>
<p>'Now am I not a fool, that woot wel how</p>
<p>Hir wo for love is of another wight,</p>
<p>And here-up-on to goon assaye hir now?</p>
<p>I may wel wite, it nil not been my prow.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">790</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For wyse folk in bokes it expresse,</p>
<p>"Men shal not wowe a wight in hevinesse."</p>
<p class="stanza">114. But who-so mighte winnen swich a flour</p>
<p>From him, for whom she morneth night and day,</p>
<p>He mighte seyn, he were a conquerour.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">795</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And right anoon, as he that bold was ay,</p>
<p>Thoughte in his herte, 'happe, how happe may,</p>
<p>Al sholde I deye, I wole hir herte seche;</p>
<p>I shal no more lesen but my speche.'</p>
<p class="stanza">115. This Diomede, as bokes us declare,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">800</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Was in his nedes prest and corageous;</p>
<p>With sterne voys and mighty limes square,</p>
<p>Hardy, testif, strong, and chevalrous</p>
<p>Of dedes, lyk his fader Tideus.</p>
<p>And som men seyn, he was of tunge large;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">805</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And heir he was of <a href="#TVNL805" id="TVL805" class="pginternal">Calidoine and Arge</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TVNL806" id="TVL806" class="pginternal">116</a>. Criseyde mene was of hir stature,</p>
<p>Ther-to of shap, of face, and eek of chere,</p>
<p>Ther mighte been no fairer creature.</p>
<p>And ofte tyme this was hir manere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">810</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To gon y-tressed with hir heres clere</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page383">{383}</span>Doun by hir coler at hir bak bihinde,</p>
<p>Which with a threde of gold she wolde binde.</p>
<p class="stanza">117. And, save hir browes ioyneden y-fere,</p>
<p>Ther nas no lak, in ought I can espyen;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">815</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But for to speken of hir eyen clere,</p>
<p>Lo, trewely, they writen that hir syen,</p>
<p>That Paradys stood formed in hir yën.</p>
<p>And with hir riche beautee ever-more</p>
<p>Strof love in hir, ay which of hem was more.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">820</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">118. She sobre was, eek simple, and wys with-al,</p>
<p>The beste y-norisshed eek that mighte be,</p>
<p>And goodly of hir speche in general,</p>
<p>Charitable, estatliche, lusty, and free;</p>
<p>Ne never-mo ne lakkede hir pitee;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">825</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Tendre-herted, slydinge of corage;</p>
<p>But trewely, I can not telle hir age.</p>
<p class="stanza">119. And <a href="#TVNL827" id="TVL827" class="pginternal">Troilus</a> wel waxen was in
    highte,</p>
<p>And complet formed by proporcioun</p>
<p>So wel, that kinde it not amenden mighte;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">830</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Yong, fresshe, strong, and hardy as lyoun;</p>
<p>Trewe as steel in ech condicioun;</p>
<p>On of the beste enteched creature,</p>
<p>That is, or shal, whyl that the world may dure.</p>
<p class="stanza">120. And certainly in storie it is y-founde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">835</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That Troilus was never un-to no wight,</p>
<p>As in his tyme, <a href="#TVNL836" id="TVL836" class="pginternal">in no degree secounde</a></p>
<p>In <a href="#TVNL837" id="TVL837" class="pginternal">durring don</a> that longeth to a knight.</p>
<p>Al mighte a geaunt passen him of might,</p>
<p>His herte ay with the firste and with the beste</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">840</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Stod paregal, to durre don that him leste.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page384">{384}</span>121. But for to tellen forth of
    Diomede:—</p>
<p>It fil that after, on the tenthe day,</p>
<p>Sin that Criseyde out of the citee yede,</p>
<p>This Diomede, as fresshe as braunche in May,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">845</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Com to the tente ther-as Calkas lay,</p>
<p>And feyned him with Calkas han to done;</p>
<p>But what he mente, I shal yow telle sone.</p>
<p class="stanza">122. Criseyde, at shorte wordes for to telle,</p>
<p>Welcomed him, and doun by hir him sette;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">850</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And he was ethe y-nough to maken dwelle.</p>
<p>And after this, with-outen longe lette,</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL852" id="TVL852" class="pginternal">The spyces and the wyn</a> men forth hem fette;</p>
<p>And forth they speke of this and that y-fere,</p>
<p>As freendes doon, of which som shal ye here.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">855</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">123. He gan first fallen of the werre in speche</p>
<p>Bitwixe hem and the folk of Troye toun;</p>
<p>And of thassege he gan hir eek byseche,</p>
<p>To telle him what was hir opinioun.</p>
<p>Fro that demaunde he so descendeth doun</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">860</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To asken hir, if that hir straunge thoughte</p>
<p>The Grekes gyse, and werkes that they wroughte?</p>
<p class="stanza">124. And why hir fader tarieth so longe</p>
<p>To wedden hir un-to som worthy wight?</p>
<p>Criseyde, that was in hir peynes stronge</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">865</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For love of Troilus, hir owene knight,</p>
<p>As fer-forth as she conning hadde or might,</p>
<p>Answerde him tho; but, as of his entente,</p>
<p>It semed not she wiste what he mente.</p>
<p class="stanza">125. But natheles, this ilke Diomede</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">870</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Gan in him-self assure, and thus he seyde,</p>
<p>'If ich aright have taken of yow hede,</p>
<p>Me thinketh thus, O lady myn, Criseyde,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page385">{385}</span>That sin I first hond on your brydel
    leyde,</p>
<p>Whan ye out come of Troye by the morwe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">875</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ne coude I never seen yow but in sorwe.</p>
<p class="stanza">126. Can I not seyn what may the cause be</p>
<p>But-if for love of som Troyan it were,</p>
<p>The which right sore wolde athinken me</p>
<p>That ye, for any wight that dwelleth there,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">880</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Sholden spille a quarter of a tere,</p>
<p>Or pitously your-selven so bigyle;</p>
<p>For dredelees, it is nought worth the whyle.</p>
<p class="stanza">127. The folk of Troye, <a href="#TVNL883" id="TVL883" class="pginternal">as who seyth</a>, alle
    and some</p>
<p>In preson been, as ye your-selven see;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">885</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For thennes shal not oon on-lyve come</p>
<p>For al the gold bitwixen sonne and see.</p>
<p>Trusteth wel, and understondeth me,</p>
<p>Ther shal not oon to mercy goon on-lyve,</p>
<p>Al were he lord of worldes twyës fyve!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">890</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">128. Swich wreche on hem, for fecching of Eleyne,</p>
<p>Ther shal be take, er that we hennes wende,</p>
<p>That <a href="#TVNL892" id="TVL892" class="pginternal">Manes</a>, which that goddes ben of peyne,</p>
<p>Shal been agast that Grekes wol hem shende.</p>
<p>And men shul drede, un-to the worldes ende,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">895</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">From hennes-forth to ravisshe any quene,</p>
<p>So cruel shal our wreche on hem be sene.</p>
<p class="stanza">129. And but-if Calkas lede us with <a href="#TVNL897" id="TVL897" class="pginternal">ambages</a>,</p>
<p>That is to seyn, with double wordes slye,</p>
<p>Swich as men clepe a "word with two visages,"</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">900</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ye shul wel knowen that I nought ne lye,</p>
<p>And al this thing right seen it with your yë,</p>
<p>And that anoon; ye nil not trowe how sone;</p>
<p>Now taketh heed, for it is for to done.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page386">{386}</span>130. What wene ye your wyse
    fader wolde</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">905</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Han yeven Antenor for yow anoon,</p>
<p>If he ne wiste that the citee sholde</p>
<p>Destroyed been? Why, nay, so mote I goon!</p>
<p>He knew ful wel ther shal not scapen oon</p>
<p>That Troyan is; and for the grete fere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">910</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He dorste not, ye dwelte lenger there.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TVNL911" id="TVL911" class="pginternal">131</a>. What wole ye more, lufsom lady
    dere?</p>
<p>Lat Troye and Troyan fro your herte pace!</p>
<p>Dryf out that bittre hope, and make good chere,</p>
<p>And clepe ayein the beautee of your face,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">915</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That ye with salte teres so deface.</p>
<p>For Troye is brought in swich a Iupartye,</p>
<p>That, it to save, is now no remedye.</p>
<p class="stanza">132. And thenketh wel, ye shal in Grekes finde,</p>
<p>A more parfit love, er it be night,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">920</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Than any Troyan is, and more kinde,</p>
<p>And bet to serven yow wol doon his might.</p>
<p>And if ye vouche sauf, my lady bright,</p>
<p>I wol ben he to serven yow my-selve,</p>
<p>Ye, lever than be lord of Greces twelve!'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">925</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">133. And with that word he gan to waxen reed,</p>
<p>And in his speche a litel wight he quook,</p>
<p>And caste a-syde a litel wight his heed,</p>
<p>And stinte a whyle; and afterward awook,</p>
<p>And sobreliche on hir he threw his look,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">930</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And seyde, 'I am, al be it yow no Ioye,</p>
<p>As gentil man as any wight in Troye.</p>
<p class="stanza">134. For if my fader Tydeus,' he seyde,</p>
<p>'Y-lived hadde, I hadde been, er this,</p>
<p>Of <a href="#TVNL934" id="TVL934" class="pginternal">Calidoine and Arge</a> a king, Criseyde!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">935</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And so hope I that I shal yet, y-wis.</p>
