<p><span class="pagenum" id="page387">{387}</span><a href="#TVNL937" id="TVL937" class="pginternal">But he was
    slayn</a>, allas! the more harm is,</p>
<p>Unhappily at Thebes al to rathe,</p>
<p>Polymites and many a man to scathe.</p>
<p class="stanza">135. But herte myn, sin that I am your man,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">940</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And been the ferste of whom I seche grace,</p>
<p>To serven you as hertely as I can,</p>
<p>And ever shal, whyl I to live have space,</p>
<p>So, er that I departe out of this place,</p>
<p>Ye wol me graunte, that I may to-morwe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">945</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">At bettre leyser, telle yow my sorwe.'</p>
<p class="stanza">136. What shold I telle his wordes that he seyde?</p>
<p>He spak y-now, for o day at the meste;</p>
<p>It preveth wel, he spak so that Criseyde</p>
<p>Graunted, on the morwe, at his requeste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">950</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For to speken with him at the leste,</p>
<p>So that he nolde speke of swich matere;</p>
<p>And thus to him she seyde, as ye may here:</p>
<p class="stanza">137. As she that hadde hir herte on Troilus</p>
<p>So faste, that ther may it noon arace;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">955</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And straungely she spak, and seyde thus:</p>
<p>'O Diomede, I love that ilke place</p>
<p>Ther I was born; and Ioves, for his grace,</p>
<p>Delivere it sone of al that doth it care!</p>
<p>God, for thy might, so leve it wel to fare!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">960</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">138. That Grekes wolde hir wraththe on Troye wreke,</p>
<p>If that they mighte, I knowe it wel, y-wis.</p>
<p>But it shal not bifallen as ye speke;</p>
<p>And god to-forn, and ferther over this,</p>
<p>I wot my fader wys and redy is;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">965</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And that he me hath bought, as ye me tolde,</p>
<p>So dere, I am the more un-to him holde.</p>
<p class="stanza">139. That Grekes been of heigh condicioun,</p>
<p>I woot eek wel; but certein, men shal finde</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page388">{388}</span>As worthy folk with-inne Troye toun,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">970</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As conning, and as parfit and as kinde,</p>
<p>As been bitwixen <a href="#TVNL971" id="TVL971" class="pginternal">Orcades</a> and Inde.</p>
<p>And that ye coude wel your lady serve,</p>
<p>I trowe eek wel, hir thank for to deserve.</p>
<p class="stanza">140. But as to speke of love, y-wis,' she seyde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">975</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'I hadde a lord, <a href="#TVNL975" id="TVL975" class="pginternal">to whom I wedded was</a>,</p>
<p>The whos myn herte al was, til that he deyde;</p>
<p>And other love, as helpe me now Pallas,</p>
<p>Ther in myn herte nis, ne never was.</p>
<p>And that ye been of noble and heigh kinrede,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">980</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I have wel herd it tellen, out of drede.</p>
<p class="stanza">141. And that doth me to han so gret a wonder,</p>
<p>That ye wol scornen any womman so.</p>
<p>Eek, god wot, love and I be fer a-sonder;</p>
<p>I am disposed bet, so mote I go,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">985</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Un-to my deeth, to pleyne and maken wo.</p>
<p>What I shal after doon, I can not seye;</p>
<p>But trewely, as yet me list not pleye.</p>
<p class="stanza">142. Myn herte is now in tribulacioun,</p>
<p>And ye in armes bisy, day by day.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">990</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Here-after, whan ye wonnen han the toun,</p>
<p>Paraunter, thanne so it happen may,</p>
<p>That whan I see <a href="#TVNL992" id="TVL992" class="pginternal">that I never er say</a>,</p>
<p>Than wole I werke that I never wroughte!</p>
<p>This word to yow y-nough suffysen oughte.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">995</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">143. To-morwe eek wol I speke with yow fayn,</p>
<p>So that ye touchen nought of this matere.</p>
<p>And whan yow list, ye may come here ayeyn;</p>
<p>And, er ye gon, thus muche I seye yow here:</p>
<p>As helpe me Pallas with hir heres clere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1000</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">If that I sholde of any Greek han routhe,</p>
<p>It sholde be your-selven, by my trouthe!</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page389">{389}</span>144. I sey not therfore that I
    wol yow love,</p>
<p>Ne I sey not nay, but in conclusioun,</p>
<p>I mene wel, by god that sit above:'—</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1005</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And ther-with-al she caste hir eyen doun,</p>
<p>And gan to syke, and seyde, 'O Troye toun,</p>
<p>Yet bidde I god, in quiete and in reste</p>
<p>I may yow seen, or do myn herte breste.'</p>
<p class="stanza">145. But in effect, and shortly for to seye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1010</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">This Diomede al freshly newe ayeyn</p>
<p>Gan pressen on, and faste hir mercy preye;</p>
<p>And after this, the sothe for to seyn,</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL1013" id="TVL1013" class="pginternal">Hir glove he took</a>, of which he was ful fayn.</p>
<p>And fynally, whan it was waxen eve,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1015</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And al was wel, he roos and took his leve.</p>
<p class="stanza">146. <a href="#TVNL1016" id="TVL1016" class="pginternal">The brighte Venus folwede</a> and ay
    taughte</p>
<p>The wey, ther brode Phebus doun alighte;</p>
<p>And <a href="#TVNL1018" id="TVL1018" class="pginternal">Cynthea</a> hir char-hors over-raughte</p>
<p>To whirle out of the Lyon, if she mighte;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1020</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And <a href="#TVNL1020" id="TVL1020" class="pginternal">Signifer</a> his candeles shewed
    brighte,</p>
<p>Whan that Criseyde un-to hir bedde wente</p>
<p>In-with hir fadres faire brighte tente.</p>
<p class="stanza">147. Retorning in hir soule ay up and doun</p>
<p>The wordes of this sodein Diomede,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1025</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">His greet estat, and peril of the toun,</p>
<p>And that she was allone and hadde nede</p>
<p>Of freendes help; and thus bigan to brede</p>
<p>The cause why, the sothe for to telle,</p>
<p>That she tok fully purpos for to dwelle.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1030</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">148. The morwe com, and goostly for to speke,</p>
<p>This Diomede is come un-to Criseyde,</p>
<p>And shortly, lest that ye my tale breke,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page390">{390}</span>So wel he for him-selve spak and seyde,</p>
<p>That alle hir sykes sore adoun he leyde.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1035</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And fynally, the sothe for to seyne,</p>
<p>He refte hir of the grete of al hir peyne.</p>
<p class="stanza">149. And after this the story telleth us,</p>
<p>That she him yaf the faire baye stede,</p>
<p>The which <a href="#TVNL1039" id="TVL1039" class="pginternal">he ones wan</a> of Troilus;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1040</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And eek a broche (and that was litel nede)</p>
<p>That Troilus was, she yaf this Diomede.</p>
<p>And eek, the bet from sorwe him to releve,</p>
<p>She made him were a <a href="#TVNL1043" id="TVL1043" class="pginternal">pencel</a> of hir sleve.</p>
<p class="stanza">150. I finde eek in <a href="#TVNL1044" id="TVL1044" class="pginternal">the stories
    elles-where</a>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1045</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Whan through the body hurt was Diomede</p>
<p>Of Troilus, tho weep she many a tere,</p>
<p>Whan that she saugh his wyde woundes blede;</p>
<p>And that she took to kepen him good hede,</p>
<p>And for to hele him of his sorwes smerte.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1050</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Men seyn, I not, that she yaf him hir herte.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TVNL1051" id="TVL1051" class="pginternal">151</a>. But trewely, the story telleth
    us,</p>
<p>Ther made never womman more wo</p>
<p>Than she, whan that she falsed Troilus.</p>
<p>She seyde, 'allas! for now is clene a-go</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1055</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">My name of trouthe in love, for ever-mo!</p>
<p>For I have falsed oon, the gentileste</p>
<p>That ever was, and oon the worthieste!</p>
<p class="stanza">152. Allas, of me, un-to the worldes ende,</p>
<p>Shal neither been y-writen nor y-songe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1060</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">No good word, for thise bokes wol me shende.</p>
<p>O, rolled shal I been on many a tonge;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page391">{391}</span>Through-out the world <a href="#TVNL1062" id="TVL1062" class="pginternal">my belle shal be ronge</a>;</p>
<p>And wommen most wol hate me of alle.</p>
<p>Allas, that swich a cas me sholde falle!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1065</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">153. They wol seyn, in as muche as in me is,</p>
<p>I have hem don dishonour, weylawey!</p>
<p>Al be I not the firste that dide amis,</p>
<p>What helpeth that to do my blame awey?</p>
<p>But sin I see there is no bettre way,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1070</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And that to late is now for me to rewe,</p>
<p>To Diomede algate I wol be trewe.</p>
<p class="stanza">154. But Troilus, sin I no better may,</p>
<p>And sin that thus departen ye and I,</p>
<p>Yet preye I god, so yeve yow right good day</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1075</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As for the gentileste, trewely,</p>
<p>That ever I say, to serven feithfully,</p>
<p>And best can ay his lady honour kepe:'—</p>
<p>And with that word she brast anon to wepe.</p>
<p class="stanza">155. 'And certes, yow ne haten shal I never,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1080</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And freendes love, that shal ye han of me,</p>
<p>And my good word, al mighte I liven ever.</p>
<p>And, trewely, I wolde sory be</p>
<p>For to seen yow in adversitee.</p>
<p>And giltelees, I woot wel, I yow leve;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1085</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But al shal passe; and thus take I my leve.'</p>
<p class="stanza">156. But trewely, how longe it was bitwene,</p>
<p>That she for-sook him for this Diomede,</p>
<p>Ther is non auctor telleth it, I wene.</p>
<p>Take every man now to his bokes hede;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1090</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He shal no terme finden, out of drede.</p>
<p>For though that he bigan to wowe hir sone,</p>
<p>Er he hir wan, yet was ther more to done.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page392">{392}</span>157. Ne me ne list this sely
    womman chyde</p>
<p>Ferther than the story wol devyse.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1095</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Hir name, allas! is publisshed so wyde,</p>
<p>That for hir gilt it oughte y-now suffyse.</p>
<p>And if I mighte excuse hir any wyse,</p>
<p>For she so sory was for hir untrouthe,</p>
<p>Y-wis, I wolde excuse hir yet for routhe.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1100</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">158. This Troilus, as I biforn have told,</p>
<p>Thus dryveth forth, as wel as he hath might.</p>
<p>But often was his herte hoot and cold,</p>
<p>And namely, that ilke nynthe night,</p>
<p>Which <a href="#TVNL1104" id="TVL1104" class="pginternal">on the morwe</a> she hadde him byhight</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1105</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To come ayein: god wot, ful litel reste</p>
<p>Hadde he that night; no-thing to slepe him leste.</p>
<p class="stanza">159. The <a href="#TVNL1107" id="TVL1107" class="pginternal">laurer-crouned Phebus</a>, with his
    hete,</p>
<p>Gan, in his course ay upward as he wente,</p>
<p>To warmen of the est see the wawes wete;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1110</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And <a href="#TVNL1110" id="TVL1110" class="pginternal">Nisus doughter</a> song with fresh
    entente,</p>
<p>Whan Troilus his Pandare after sente;</p>
<p>And on the walles of the toun they pleyde,</p>
<p>To loke if they can seen ought of Criseyde.</p>
<p class="stanza">160. Til it was <a href="#TVNL1114" id="TVL1114" class="pginternal">noon</a>, they stoden for to
    see</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1115</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Who that ther come; and every maner wight,</p>
<p>That cam fro fer, they seyden it was she,</p>
<p>Til that they coude knowen him a-right.</p>
<p>Now was his herte dul, now was it light;</p>
<p>And thus by-iaped stonden for to stare</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1120</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Aboute nought, this Troilus and Pandare.</p>
<p class="stanza">161. To Pandarus this Troilus tho seyde,</p>
<p>'For ought I wot, bi-for noon, sikerly,</p>
<p>In-to this toun ne comth nought here Criseyde.</p>
<p>She hath y-now to done, hardily,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1125</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page393">{393}</span>To winnen from hir fader, so
    trowe I;</p>
<p>Hir olde fader wol yet make hir dyne</p>
<p>Er that she go; god yeve his herte pyne!'</p>
<p class="stanza">162. Pandare answerde, 'it may wel be, certeyn;</p>
<p>And for-thy lat us dyne, I thee biseche;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1130</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And after noon than mayst thou come ayeyn.'</p>
<p>And hoom they go, with-oute more speche;</p>
<p>And comen ayein, but longe may they seche</p>
<p>Er that they finde that they after <a href="#TVNL1133" id="TVL1133" class="pginternal">cape</a>;</p>
<p>Fortune hem bothe thenketh for to Iape.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1135</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">163. Quod Troilus, 'I see wel now, that she</p>
<p>Is taried with hir olde fader so,</p>
<p>That er she come, it wol neigh even be.</p>
<p>Com forth, I wol un-to the yate go.</p>
<p>Thise portours been unkonninge ever-mo;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1140</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And I wol doon hem holden up the <a href="#TVNL1140" id="TVL1140" class="pginternal">yate</a></p>
<p>As nought ne were, al-though she come late.'</p>
<p class="stanza">164. The day goth faste, and after that comth eve,</p>
<p>And yet com nought to Troilus Criseyde.</p>
<p>He loketh forth by hegge, by tree, by greve,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1145</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And fer his heed over the wal he leyde.</p>
<p>And at the laste he torned him, and seyde,</p>
<p>'By god, I woot hir mening now, Pandare!</p>
<p>Al-most, y-wis, al newe was my care.</p>
<p class="stanza">165. Now douteles, this lady can hir good;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1150</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I woot, she meneth ryden prively.</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL1151" id="TVL1151" class="pginternal">I comende</a> hir wysdom, by myn hood!</p>
<p>She wol not maken peple nycely</p>
<p>Gaure on hir, whan she comth; but softely</p>
<p>By nighte in-to the toun she thenketh ryde.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1155</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And, dere brother, thenk <a href="#TVNL1155" id="TVL1155" class="pginternal">not longe to
    abyde</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page394">{394}</span>166. We han nought elles for to
    don, y-wis.</p>
<p>And Pandarus, now woltow trowen me?</p>
<p>Have here my trouthe, I see hir! yond she is.</p>
<p>Heve up thyn eyen, man! maystow not see?'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1160</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Pandare answerde, 'nay, so mote I thee!</p>
<p>Al wrong, by god; what seystow, man, wher art?</p>
<p>That I see yond nis but a <a href="#TVNL1162" id="TVL1162" class="pginternal">fare-cart</a>.'</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TVNL1163" id="TVL1163" class="pginternal">167</a>. 'Allas, thou seist right sooth,'
    quod Troilus;</p>
<p>'But hardely, it is not al for nought</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1165</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That in myn herte I now reioyse thus.</p>
<p>It is ayein som good I have a thought.</p>
<p>Noot I not how, but sin that I was wrought,</p>
<p>Ne felte I swich a confort, dar I seye;</p>
<p>She comth to-night, my lyf, that dorste I leye!'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1170</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">168. Pandare answerde, 'it may be wel, y-nough';</p>
<p>And held with him of al that ever he seyde;</p>
<p>But in his herte he thoughte, and softe lough,</p>
<p>And to him-self ful sobrely he seyde:</p>
<p>'From hasel-wode, ther <a href="#TVNL1174" id="TVL1174" class="pginternal">Ioly Robin</a> pleyde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1175</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Shal come al that that thou abydest here;</p>
<p>Ye, fare-wel al the snow of <a href="#TVNL1176" id="TVL1176" class="pginternal">ferne yere</a>!'</p>
<p class="stanza">169. The wardein of the yates gan to calle</p>
<p>The folk which that with-oute the yates were,</p>
<p>And bad hem dryven in hir bestes alle,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1180</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Or al the night they moste bleven there.</p>
<p>And fer with-in the night, with many a tere,</p>
<p>This Troilus gan hoomward for to ryde;</p>
<p>For wel he seeth it helpeth nought tabyde.</p>
<p class="stanza">170. But natheles, he gladded him in this;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1185</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He thoughte he misacounted hadde his day,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page395">{395}</span>And seyde, 'I understonde have al a-mis.</p>
<p>For thilke night I last Criseyde say,</p>
<p>She seyde, "I shal ben here, if that I may,</p>
<p>Er that the mone, O dere herte swete!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1190</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#TVNL1190" id="TVL1190" class="pginternal">The Lyon passe</a>, out of this Ariete."</p>
<p class="stanza">171. For which she may yet holde al hir biheste.'</p>
<p>And on the morwe un-to the yate he wente,</p>
<p>And up and down, by west and eek by este,</p>
<p>Up-on the walles made he many a wente.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1195</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But al for nought; his hope alwey him blente;</p>
<p>For which at night, in sorwe and sykes sore</p>
<p>He wente him hoom, with-outen any more.</p>
<p class="stanza">172. This hope al clene out of his herte fledde,</p>
<p>He nath wher-on now lenger for to honge;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1200</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But for the peyne him thoughte his herte bledde,</p>
<p>So were his throwes sharpe and wonder stronge.</p>
<p>For when he saugh that she abood so longe,</p>
<p>He niste what he iuggen of it mighte,</p>
<p>Sin she hath broken that she him bihighte.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1205</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">173. The thridde, ferthe, fifte, sixte day</p>
<p>After tho dayes ten, of which I tolde,</p>
<p>Bitwixen hope and drede his herte lay,</p>
<p>Yet som-what trustinge on hir hestes olde.</p>
<p>But whan he saugh she nolde hir terme holde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1210</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He can now seen non other remedye,</p>
<p>But for to shape him sone for to dye.</p>
<p class="stanza">174. Ther-with the wikked spirit, god us blesse,</p>
<p>Which that men clepeth wode Ialousye,</p>
<p>Gan in him crepe, in al this hevinesse;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1215</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For which, by-cause he wolde sone dye,</p>
<p>He ne eet ne dronk, for his malencolye,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page396">{396}</span>And eek from every companye he fledde;</p>
<p>This was the lyf that al the tyme he ledde.</p>
<p class="stanza">175. He so defet was, that no maner man</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1220</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Unnethe mighte him knowe ther he wente;</p>
<p>So was he lene, and ther-to pale and wan,</p>
<p>And feble, that he walketh <a href="#TVNL1222" id="TVL1222" class="pginternal">by potente</a>;</p>
<p>And with his ire he thus him-selven shente.</p>
<p>And who-so axed him wher-of him smerte,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1225</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He seyde, his harm was al aboute his herte.</p>
<p class="stanza">176. Pryam ful ofte, and eek his moder dere,</p>
<p>His bretheren and his sustren gonne him freyne</p>
<p>Why he so sorwful was in al his chere,</p>
<p>And what thing was the cause of al his peyne?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1230</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But al for nought; he nolde his cause pleyne,</p>
<p>But seyde, he felte a grevous maladye</p>
<p>A-boute his herte, and fayn he wolde dye.</p>
<p class="stanza">177. So on a day he leyde him doun to slepe,</p>
<p>And so bifel that in his sleep him thoughte,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1235</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That in a forest faste he welk to wepe</p>
<p>For love of hir that him these peynes wroughte;</p>
<p>And up and doun as he the forest soughte,</p>
<p>He mette he saugh a boor with tuskes grete,</p>
<p>That sleep ayein the brighte sonnes hete.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1240</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">178. And by this boor, faste in his armes folde,</p>
<p>Lay kissing ay his lady bright Criseyde:</p>
<p>For sorwe of which, whan he it gan biholde,</p>
<p>And for despyt, out of his slepe he breyde,</p>
<p>And loude he cryde on Pandarus, and seyde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1245</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'O Pandarus, now knowe I crop and rote!</p>
<p>I nam but deed, ther nis non other bote!</p>
<p class="stanza">179. My lady bright Criseyde hath me bitrayed,</p>
<p>In whom I trusted most of any wight,</p>
<p>She elles-where hath now hir herte apayed;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1250</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page397">{397}</span>The blisful goddes, through hir
    grete might,</p>
<p>Han in my dreem y-shewed it ful right.</p>
<p>Thus in my dreem Criseyde I have biholde'—</p>
<p>And al this thing to Pandarus he tolde.</p>
<p class="stanza">180. 'O my Criseyde, allas! what subtiltee,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1255</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">What newe lust, what beautee, what science,</p>
<p>What wratthe of iuste cause have ye to me?</p>
<p>What gilt of me, whal fel experience</p>
<p>Hath fro me raft, allas! thyn advertence?</p>
<p>O trust, O feyth, O depe asëuraunce,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1260</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Who hath me reft Criseyde, al my plesaunce?</p>
<p class="stanza">181. Allas! why leet I you from hennes go,</p>
<p>For which wel neigh out of my wit I breyde?</p>
<p>Who shal now trowe on any othes mo?</p>
<p>God wot I wende, O lady bright, Criseyde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1265</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That every word was gospel that ye seyde!</p>
<p>But who may bet bigylen, if him liste,</p>
<p>Than he on whom men weneth best to triste?</p>
<p class="stanza">182. What shal I doon, my Pandarus, allas!</p>
<p>I fele now so sharpe a newe peyne,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1270</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Sin that ther is no remedie in this cas,</p>
<p>That bet were it I with myn hondes tweyne</p>
<p>My-selven slow, than alwey thus to pleyne.</p>
<p>For through my deeth my wo sholde han an ende,</p>
<p>Ther every day with lyf my-self <a href="#TVNL1274" id="TVL1274" class="pginternal">I shende</a>.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1275</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">183. Pandare answerde and seyde, 'allas the whyle</p>
<p>That I was born; have I not seyd er this,</p>
<p>That dremes many a maner man bigyle?</p>
<p>And why? for folk expounden hem a-mis.</p>
<p>How darstow seyn that fals thy lady is,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1280</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For any dreem, right for thyn owene drede?</p>
<p>Lat be this thought, thou canst no dremes rede.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page398">{398}</span>184. Paraunter, ther thou
    dremest of this boor,</p>
<p>It may so be that it may signifye</p>
<p>Hir fader, which that old is and eek hoor,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1285</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ayein the sonne lyth, on poynt to dye,</p>
<p>And she for sorwe ginneth wepe and crye,</p>
<p>And kisseth him, ther he lyth on the grounde;</p>
<p>Thus shuldestow thy dreem a-right expounde.'</p>
<p class="stanza">185. 'How mighte I thanne do?' quod Troilus,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1290</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'To knowe of this, ye, were it never so lyte?'</p>
<p>'Now seystow wysly,' quod this Pandarus,</p>
<p>'My reed is this, sin thou canst wel endyte,</p>
<p>That hastely a lettre thou hir wryte,</p>
<p>Thorugh which thou shalt wel bringen it aboute,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1295</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To knowe a sooth of that thou art in doute.</p>
<p class="stanza">186. And see now why; for this I dar wel seyn,</p>
<p>That if so is that she untrewe be,</p>
<p>I can not trowe that she wol wryte ayeyn.</p>
<p>And if she wryte, thou shalt ful sone see,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1300</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As whether she hath any libertee</p>
<p>To come ayein, or elles in som clause,</p>
<p>If she be let, she wol assigne a cause.</p>
<p class="stanza">187. Thou hast not writen hir sin that she wente,</p>
<p>Nor she to thee, and this I dorste leye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1305</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ther may swich cause been in hir entente,</p>
<p>That hardely thou wolt thy-selven seye,</p>
<p>That hir a-bood the beste is for yow tweye.</p>
<p>Now wryte hir thanne, and thou shalt fele sone</p>
<p>A sothe of al; ther is no more to done.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1310</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">188. Acorded been to this conclusioun,</p>
<p>And that anoon, these ilke lordes two;</p>
<p>And hastely sit Troilus adoun,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page399">{399}</span>And <a href="#TVNL1313" id="TVL1313" class="pginternal">rolleth</a> in his herte to and fro,</p>
<p>How he may best discryven hir his wo.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1315</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And to Criseyde, his owene lady dere,</p>
<p>He wroot right thus, and seyde as ye may here.</p>
<p class="stanza">189. 'Right fresshe flour, whos I have been and shal,</p>
<p>With-outen part of elles-where servyse,</p>
<p>With herte, body, lyf, lust, thought, and al;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1320</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">I, woful wight, in every humble wyse</p>
<p>That tonge telle or herte may devyse,</p>
<p>As ofte as matere occupyeth place,</p>
<p>Me recomaunde un-to your noble grace.</p>
<p class="stanza">190. Lyketh it yow to witen, swete herte,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1325</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As ye wel knowe how longe tyme agoon</p>
<p>That ye me lafte in aspre peynes smerte,</p>
<p>Whan that ye wente, of which yet bote noon</p>
<p>Have I non had, but ever wers bigoon</p>
<p>Fro day to day am I, and so mot dwelle,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1330</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">While it yow list, of wele and wo my welle!</p>
<p class="stanza">191. For which to yow, with dredful herte trewe,</p>
<p>I wryte, as he that sorwe dryfth to wryte,</p>
<p>My wo, that every houre encreseth newe,</p>
<p>Compleyninge as I dar or can endyte.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1335</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And that defaced is, that may ye wyte</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL1335" id="TVL1335" class="pginternal">The teres</a>, which that fro myn eyen reyne,</p>
<p>That wolde speke, if that they coude, and pleyne.</p>
<p class="stanza">192. Yow first biseche I, that your eyen clere</p>
<p>To look on this defouled ye not holde;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1340</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And over al this, that ye, my lady dere,</p>
<p>Wol vouche-sauf this lettre to biholde.</p>
<p>And by the cause eek of my cares colde,</p>
<p>That sleeth my wit, if ought amis me asterte,</p>
<p>For-yeve it me, myn owene swete herte.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1345</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">193. If any servant dorste or oughte of right</p>
<p>Up-on his lady pitously compleyne,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page400">{400}</span>Than wene I, that ich oughte be that
    wight,</p>
<p>Considered this, that ye these monthes tweyne</p>
<p>Han taried, ther ye seyden, sooth to seyne,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1350</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But dayes ten ye nolde in ost soiourne,</p>
<p>But in two monthes yet ye not retourne.</p>
<p class="stanza">194. But for-as-muche as me mot nedes lyke</p>
<p>Al that yow list, I dar not pleyne more,</p>
<p>But humbely <a href="#TVNL1354" id="TVL1354" class="pginternal">with sorwful sykes syke</a>;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1355</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Yow wryte ich myn unresty sorwes sore,</p>
<p>Fro day to day desyring ever-more</p>
<p>To knowen fully, if your wil it were,</p>
<p>How ye han ferd and doon, whyl ye be there.</p>
<p class="stanza">195. The whos wel-fare and hele eek god encresse</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1360</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">In honour swich, that upward in degree</p>
<p>It growe alwey, so that it never cesse;</p>
<p>Right as your herte ay can, my lady free,</p>
<p>Devyse, I prey to god so mote it be.</p>
<p>And graunte it that ye sone up-on me rewe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1365</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As wisly as in al I am yow trewe.</p>
<p class="stanza">196. And if yow lyketh knowen of the fare</p>
<p>Of me, whos wo ther may no wight discryve,</p>
<p>I can no more but, <a href="#TVNL1368" id="TVL1368" class="pginternal">cheste of every care</a>,</p>
<p>At wrytinge of this lettre I was on-lyve,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1370</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Al redy out my woful gost to dryve;</p>
<p>Which I delaye, and holde him yet in honde,</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL1372" id="TVL1372" class="pginternal">Upon the sight of matere</a> of your sonde.</p>
<p class="stanza">197. Myn eyen two, in veyn with which I see,</p>
<p>Of sorweful teres salte arn waxen welles;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1375</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">My song, in pleynte of myn adversitee;</p>
<p>My good, in harm; myn ese eek waxen helle is.</p>
<p>My Ioye, in wo; I can sey yow nought elles,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page401">{401}</span>But turned is, for which my lyf I warie,</p>
<p>Everich Ioye or ese in his contrarie.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1380</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">198. Which with your cominge hoom ayein to Troye</p>
<p>Ye may redresse, and, more a thousand sythe</p>
<p>Than ever ich hadde, encressen in me Ioye.</p>
<p>For was ther never herte yet so blythe</p>
<p>To han his lyf, as I shal been as swythe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1385</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As I yow see; and, though no maner routhe</p>
<p>Commeve yow, yet thinketh on your trouthe.</p>
<p class="stanza">199. And if so be my gilt hath deeth deserved,</p>
<p>Or if you list no more up-on me see,</p>
<p>In guerdon yet of that I have you served,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1390</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Biseche I yow, myn hertes lady free,</p>
<p>That here-upon ye wolden wryte me,</p>
<p>For love of god, my righte lode-sterre,</p>
<p>Ther deeth may make an ende of al my werre.</p>
<p class="stanza">200. If other cause aught doth yow for to dwelle,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1395</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That with your lettre ye me recomforte;</p>
<p>For though to me your absence is an helle,</p>
<p>With pacience I wol my wo comporte.</p>
<p>And with your lettre of hope I wol desporte.</p>
<p>Now wryteth, swete, and lat me thus not pleyne;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1400</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">With hope, or deeth, delivereth me fro peyne.</p>
<p class="stanza">201. Y-wis, myn owene dere herte trewe,</p>
<p>I woot that, whan ye next up-on me see,</p>
<p>So lost have I myn hele and eek myn hewe,</p>
<p>Criseyde shal nought conne knowe me!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1405</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Y-wis, myn hertes day, my lady free,</p>
<p>So thursteth ay myn herte to biholde</p>
<p>Your beautee, that my lyf unnethe I holde.</p>
<p class="stanza">202. I sey no more, al have I for to seye</p>
<p>To you wel more than I telle may;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1410</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page402">{402}</span>But whether that ye do me live
    or deye,</p>
<p>Yet pray I god, so yeve yow right good day.</p>
<p>And fareth wel, goodly fayre fresshe may,</p>
<p>As ye that lyf or deeth me may comaunde;</p>
<p>And to your trouthe ay I me recomaunde</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1415</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">203. With hele swich that, but ye yeven me</p>
<p>The same hele, I shal noon hele have.</p>
<p>In you lyth, whan yow list that it so be,</p>
<p>The day in which me clothen shal my grave.</p>
<p>In yow my lyf, in yow might for to save</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1420</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Me from disese of alle peynes smerte;</p>
<p>And fare now wel, myn owene swete herte!</p>
<p style="margin-left:9.80em"><b>Le vostre T.'</b></p>
<p class="stanza">204. This lettre forth was sent un-to Criseyde,</p>
<p>Of which hir answere in effect was this;</p>
<p>Ful pitously she wroot ayein, and seyde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1425</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That al-so sone as that she might, y-wis,</p>
<p>She wolde come, and mende al that was mis.</p>
<p>And fynally she wroot and seyde him thanne,</p>
<p>She wolde come, ye, but she niste whanne.</p>
<p class="stanza">205. But in hir lettre made she swich festes,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1430</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That wonder was, and swereth she loveth him best,</p>
<p>Of which he fond but <a href="#TVNL1431" id="TVL1431" class="pginternal">botmelees bihestes</a>.</p>
<p>But Troilus, thou mayst now, est or west,</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL1433" id="TVL1433" class="pginternal">Pype in an ivy leef</a>, if that thee lest;</p>
<p>Thus gooth the world; god shilde us fro mischaunce,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1435</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And every wight that meneth trouthe avaunce!</p>
<p class="stanza">206. Encresen gan the wo fro day to night</p>
<p>Of Troilus, for taryinge of Criseyde;</p>
<p>And lessen gan his hope and eek his might,</p>
<p>For which al doun he in his bed him leyde;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1440</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He ne eet, ne dronk, ne sleep, ne word he seyde,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page403">{403}</span>Imagininge ay that she was unkinde;</p>
<p>For which wel neigh he wex out of his minde.</p>
<p class="stanza">207. This dreem, of which I told have eek biforn,</p>
<p>May never come out of his remembraunce;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1445</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He thoughte ay wel he hadde his lady lorn,</p>
<p>And that Ioves, of his purveyaunce,</p>
<p>Him shewed hadde in sleep the signifiaunce</p>
<p>Of hir untrouthe and his disaventure,</p>
<p>And that the boor was shewed him in figure.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1450</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">208. For which he for <a href="#TVNL1450" id="TVL1450" class="pginternal">Sibille</a> his
    suster sente,</p>
<p>That called was Cassandre eek al aboute;</p>
<p>And al his dreem he tolde hir er he stente,</p>
<p>And hir bisoughte assoilen him the doute</p>
<p>Of the stronge boor, with tuskes stoute;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1455</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And fynally, with-inne a litel stounde,</p>
<p>Cassandre him gan right thus his dreem expounde.</p>
<p class="stanza">209. She gan first smyle, and seyde, 'O brother dere,</p>
<p>If thou a sooth of this desyrest knowe,</p>
<p>Thou most a fewe of olde stories here,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1460</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To purpos, how that fortune over-throwe</p>
<p>Hath lordes olde; through which, with-inne a throwe,</p>
<p>Thou wel this boor shalt knowe, and of what kinde</p>
<p>He comen is, as men in bokes finde.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TVNL1464" id="TVL1464" class="pginternal">210</a>. Diane, which that wrooth was and in
    ire</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1465</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For Grekes nolde doon hir sacrifyse,</p>
<p>Ne encens up-on hir auter sette a-fyre,</p>
<p>She, for that Grekes gonne hir so dispyse,</p>
<p>Wrak hir in a wonder cruel wyse.</p>
<p>For with a boor as greet as oxe in stalle</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1470</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">She made up frete hir corn and vynes alle.</p>
<p class="stanza">211. To slee this boor was al the contree reysed,</p>
<p>A-monges which ther com, this boor to see,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page404">{404}</span>A mayde, oon of this world the best
    y-preysed;</p>
<p>And Meleagre, lord of that contree,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1475</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He lovede so this fresshe mayden free</p>
<p>That with his manhod, er he wolde stente,</p>
<p>This boor he slow, and hir the heed he sente;</p>
<p class="stanza">212. Of which, as olde bokes tellen us,</p>
<p>Ther roos a contek and a greet envye;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1480</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And of this lord descended <a href="#TVNL1480" id="TVL1480" class="pginternal">Tydeus</a></p>
<p>By ligne, or elles olde bokes lye;</p>
<p>But how this Meleagre gan to dye</p>
<p>Thorugh his <a href="#TVNL1483" id="TVL1483" class="pginternal">moder</a>, wol I yow not telle,</p>
<p>For al to long it were for to dwelle.'</p>
<p class="stanza">[<i>Argument of the 12 Books of</i> Statius' Thebais.]</p>
<p class="stanza"><b>Associat profugum Tideo</b> primus <b>Polimitem;</b></p>
<p><b>Tidea legatum docet insidiasque</b> secundus<b>;</b></p>
<p>Tercius <b>Hemoniden canit et vates latitantes;</b></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">4</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Quartus <b>habet reges ineuntes prelia septem;</b></p>
<p><b>Mox furie Lenne</b> quinto <b>narratur et anguis;</b></p>
<p><b>Archimori bustum</b> sexto <b>ludique leguntur;</b></p>
<p><b>Dat Graios Thebes et vatem</b> septimus <b>vmbris;</b></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">8</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Octauo <b>cecidit Tideus, spes, vita Pelasgis;</b></p>
<p><b>Ypomedon</b> nono <b>moritur cum Parthonopeo;</b></p>
<p><b>Fulmine percussus,</b> decimo <b>Capaneus superatur;</b></p>
<p>Vndecimo <b>sese perimunt per vulnera fratres;</b></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">12</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><b>Argiuam flentem narrat</b> duodenus <b>et ignem.</b></p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1485</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><a href="#TVNL1485" id="TVL1485" class="pginternal">213</a>. She toldë eek how Tydeus, er
    she stente,</p>
<p>Un-to the stronge citee of Thebes,</p>
<p>To cleyme kingdom of the citee, wente,</p>
<p>For his felawe, daun Polymites,</p>
<p>Of which the brother, daun Ethyocles</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1490</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page405">{405}</span>Ful wrongfully of Thebes held
    the strengthe;</p>
<p>This tolde she by proces, al by lengthe.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TVNL1492" id="TVL1492" class="pginternal">214</a>. She tolde eek how Hemonides
    asterte,</p>
<p>Whan Tydeus slough fifty knightes stoute.</p>
<p>She told eek al the prophesyes by herte,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1495</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And how that sevene kinges, with hir route,</p>
<p>Bisegeden the citee al aboute;</p>
<p>And of the holy serpent, and the welle,</p>
<p>And of the furies, al she gan him telle.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TVNL1499" id="TVL1499" class="pginternal">215</a>. Of Archimoris buryinge and the
    pleyes,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1500</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And how Amphiorax fil through the grounde,</p>
<p>How Tydeus was slayn, lord of Argeyes,</p>
<p>And how Ypomedoun in litel stounde</p>
<p>Was dreynt, and deed Parthonope of wounde;</p>
<p>And also how Cappanëus the proude</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1505</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">With thonder-dint was slayn, that cryde loude.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TVNL1506" id="TVL1506" class="pginternal">216</a>. She gan eek telle him how that
    either brother,</p>
<p>Ethyocles and Polimyte also,</p>
<p>At a scarmyche, eche of hem slough other,</p>
<p>And of Argyves wepinge and hir wo;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1510</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And how the town was brent she tolde eek tho.</p>
<p>And so descendeth doun from gestes olde</p>
<p>To Diomede, and thus she spak and tolde.</p>
<p class="stanza">217. 'This ilke boor bitokneth Diomede,</p>
<p>Tydeus sone, that doun descended is</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1515</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#TVNL1514" id="TVL1514" class="pginternal">Fro Meleagre</a>, that made the boor to
    blede.</p>
<p>And thy lady, wher-so she be, y-wis,</p>
<p>This Diomede hir herte hath, and she his.</p>
<p>Weep if thou wolt, or <a href="#TVNL1518" id="TVL1518" class="pginternal">leef</a>; for, out of doute,</p>
<p>This Diomede is inne, and thou art oute.'</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1520</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page406">{406}</span>218. 'Thou seyst nat
    sooth,' quod he, 'thou sorceresse,</p>
<p>With al thy false goost of prophesye!</p>
<p>Thou wenest been a greet devyneresse;</p>
<p>Now <a href="#TVNL1523" id="TVL1523" class="pginternal">seestow</a> not this fool of fantasye</p>
<p>Peyneth hir on ladyes for to lye?</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1525</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Awey,' quod he, 'ther Ioves yeve thee sorwe!</p>
<p>Thou shalt be fals, paraunter, yet to-morwe!</p>
<p class="stanza">219. As wel thou mightest lyen on <a href="#TVNL1527" id="TVL1527" class="pginternal">Alceste</a>,</p>
<p>That was of creatures, <a href="#TVNL1528" id="TVL1528" class="pginternal">but</a> men lye,</p>
<p>That ever weren, kindest and the beste.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1530</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For whanne hir <a href="#TVNL1530" id="TVL1530" class="pginternal">housbonde</a> was in
    Iupartye</p>
<p>To dye him-self, but-if she wolde dye,</p>
<p>She chees for him to dye and go to helle,</p>
<p>And starf anoon, as us the bokes telle.'</p>
<p class="stanza">220. Cassandre goth, and he with cruel herte</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1535</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For-yat his wo, for angre of hir speche;</p>
<p>And from his bed al sodeinly he sterte,</p>
<p>As though al hool him hadde y-mad a leche.</p>
<p>And day by day he gan enquere and seche</p>
<p>A sooth of this, with al his fulle cure;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1540</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And thus he dryeth forth his aventure.</p>
<p class="stanza">221. Fortune, whiche that permutacioun</p>
<p>Of thinges hath, as it is hir committed</p>
<p>Through purveyaunce and disposicioun</p>
<p>Of heighe Iove, as regnes shal ben flitted</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1545</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Fro folk in folk, or whan they shal ben <a href="#TVNL1545" id="TVL1545" class="pginternal">smitted</a>,</p>
<p>Gan pulle awey the fetheres brighte of Troye</p>
<p>Fro day to day, til they ben bare of Ioye.</p>
<p class="stanza">222. Among al this, the <a href="#TVNL1548" id="TVL1548" class="pginternal">fyn of the
    parodie</a></p>
<p>Of Ector gan approchen wonder blyve;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1550</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The fate wolde his soule sholde unbodie,</p>
<p>And shapen hadde a mene it out to dryve;</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page407">{407}</span>Ayeins which fate him helpeth not to
    stryve;</p>
<p>But on a day to fighten gan he wende,</p>
<p>At which, allas! he caughte his lyves ende.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1555</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">223. For which me thinketh every maner wight</p>
<p>That haunteth armes oughte to biwayle</p>
<p>The deeth of him that was so noble a knight;</p>
<p>For <a href="#TVNL1558" id="TVL1558" class="pginternal">as he drough a king</a> by thaventayle,</p>
<p>Unwar of this, Achilles through the mayle</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1560</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And through the body gan him for to ryve;</p>
<p>And thus this worthy knight was brought of lyve.</p>
<p class="stanza">224. For whom, as olde bokes tellen us,</p>
<p>Was mad swich wo, that tonge it may not telle;</p>
<p>And namely, the sorwe of Troilus,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1565</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That next him was of worthinesse welle.</p>
<p>And in this wo gan Troilus to dwelle,</p>
<p>That, what for sorwe, and love, and for unreste,</p>
<p>Ful ofte a day he bad his herte breste.</p>
<p class="stanza">225. But natheles, though he gan him dispeyre,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1570</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And dradde ay that his lady was untrewe,</p>
<p>Yet ay on hir his herte gan repeyre.</p>
<p>And as these loveres doon, he soughte ay newe</p>
<p>To gete ayein Criseyde, bright of hewe.</p>
<p>And in his herte he wente hir excusinge,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1575</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That Calkas causede al hir taryinge.</p>
<p class="stanza">226. And ofte tyme he was in purpos grete</p>
<p>Him-selven lyk a pilgrim to disgyse,</p>
<p>To seen hir; but he may not contrefete</p>
<p>To been unknowen of folk that weren wyse,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1580</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ne finde excuse aright that may suffyse,</p>
<p>If he among the Grekes knowen were;</p>
<p>For which he weep ful ofte many a tere.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page408">{408}</span>227. To hir he wroot yet ofte
    tyme al newe</p>
<p>Ful pitously, he lefte it nought for slouthe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1585</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Biseching hir that, sin that he was trewe,</p>
<p>She wolde come ayein and holde hir trouthe.</p>
<p>For which Criseyde up-on a day, for routhe,</p>
<p>I take it so, touchinge al this matere,</p>
<p>Wrot him ayein, and seyde as ye may here.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1590</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">228. 'Cupydes sone, ensample of goodlihede,</p>
<p>O swerd of knighthod, sours of gentilesse!</p>
<p>How mighte a wight in torment and in drede</p>
<p>And helelees, yow sende as yet gladnesse?</p>
<p>I hertelees, I syke, I in distresse;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1595</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Sin ye with me, nor I with yow may dele,</p>
<p>Yow neither sende ich herte may nor hele.</p>
<p class="stanza">229. Your lettres ful, the papir al y-pleynted,</p>
<p>Conseyved hath myn hertes piëtee;</p>
<p>I have eek seyn with teres al depeynted</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1600</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Your lettre, and how that ye requeren me</p>
<p>To come ayein, which yet ne may not be.</p>
<p>But why, lest that this lettre founden were,</p>
<p>No mencioun ne make I now, for fere.</p>
<p class="stanza">230. Grevous to me, god woot, is your unreste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1605</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Your haste, and that, the goddes ordenaunce,</p>
<p>It semeth not ye take it for the beste.</p>
<p>Nor other thing nis in your remembraunce,</p>
<p>As thinketh me, but only your plesaunce.</p>
<p>But beth not wrooth, and that I yow biseche;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1610</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For that I tarie, is al for wikked speche.</p>
<p class="stanza">231. For I have herd wel more than I wende,</p>
<p>Touchinge us two, how thinges han y-stonde;</p>
<p>Which I shal with dissimulinge amende.</p>
<p>And beth nought wrooth, I have eek understonde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1615</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page409">{409}</span>How ye ne doon but holden me in
    honde.</p>
<p>But now no fors, I can not in yow gesse</p>
<p>But alle trouthe and alle gentilesse.</p>
<p class="stanza">232. Comen I wol, but yet in swich disioynte</p>
<p>I stonde as now, that what yeer or what day</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1620</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That this shal be, that can I not apoynte.</p>
<p>But in effect, I prey yow, as I may,</p>
<p>Of your good word and of your frendship ay.</p>
<p>For trewely, whyl that my lyf may dure,</p>
<p>As for a freend, ye may in me assure.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1625</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">233. Yet preye I yow on yvel ye ne take,</p>
<p>That it is short which that I to yow wryte;</p>
<p>I dar not, ther I am, wel lettres make,</p>
<p>Ne never yet ne coude I wel endyte.</p>
<p>Eek greet effect men wryte in place lyte.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1630</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Thentente is al, and nought the lettres space;</p>
<p>And fareth now wel, god have you in his grace!</p>
<p style="margin-left:10.15em"><b>La vostre C.'</b></p>
<p class="stanza">234. This Troilus this lettre thoughte al straunge,</p>
<p>Whan he it saugh, and sorwefully he sighte;</p>
<p>Him thoughte it lyk a <a href="#TVNL1634" id="TVL1634" class="pginternal">kalendes</a> of chaunge;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1635</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But fynally, he ful ne trowen mighte</p>
<p>That she ne wolde him holden that she highte;</p>
<p>For with ful yvel wil list him to leve</p>
<p>That loveth wel, in swich cas, though him greve.</p>
<p class="stanza">235. But natheles, men seyn that, at the laste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1640</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For any thing, men shal the sothe see;</p>
<p>And swich a cas bitidde, and that as faste,</p>
<p>That Troilus wel understood that she</p>
<p>Nas not so kinde as that hir oughte be.</p>
<p>And fynally, he woot now, out of doute,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1645</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That al is lost that he hath been aboute.</p>
<p class="stanza"><span class="pagenum" id="page410">{410}</span>236. Stood on a day in his
    malencolye</p>
<p>This Troilus, and in suspecioun</p>
<p>Of hir for whom he wende for to dye.</p>
<p>And so bifel, that through-out Troye toun,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1650</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">As was the gyse, y-bore was up and doun</p>
<p>A maner cote-armure, as seyth the storie,</p>
<p>Biforn Deiphebe, in signe of his victorie,</p>
<p class="stanza">237. The whiche cote, as telleth <a href="#TVNL1653" id="TVL1653" class="pginternal">Lollius</a>,</p>
<p>Deiphebe it hadde y-rent from Diomede</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1655</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">The same day; and whan this Troilus</p>
<p>It saugh, he gan to taken of it hede,</p>
<p>Avysing of the lengthe and of the brede,</p>
<p>And al the werk; but as he gan biholde,</p>
<p>Ful sodeinly his herte gan to colde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1660</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">238. As he that on the coler fond with-inne</p>
<p>A broche, that he Criseyde yaf that morwe</p>
<p>That she from Troye moste nedes twinne,</p>
<p>In remembraunce of him and of his sorwe;</p>
<p>And she him leyde ayein hir feyth to borwe</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1665</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">To kepe it ay; but now, ful wel he wiste,</p>
<p>His lady nas no lenger on to triste.</p>
<p class="stanza">239. He gooth him hoom, and gan ful sone sende</p>
<p>For Pandarus; and al this newe chaunce,</p>
<p>And of this broche, he tolde him <a href="#TVNL1669" id="TVL1669" class="pginternal">word and ende</a>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1670</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Compleyninge of hir hertes variaunce,</p>
<p>His longe love, his trouthe, and his penaunce;</p>
<p>And after deeth, with-outen wordes more,</p>
<p>Ful faste he cryde, his reste him to restore.</p>
<p class="stanza">240. Than spak he thus, 'O lady myn Criseyde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1675</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Wher is your feyth, and wher is your biheste?</p>
<p>Wher is your love, wher is your trouthe,' he seyde;</p>
<p>'Of Diomede have ye now al this feste!</p>
<p>Allas, I wolde have trowed at the leste,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page411">{411}</span>That, sin ye nolde in trouthe to me
    stonde,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1680</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That ye thus nolde han holden me in honde!</p>
<p class="stanza">241. Who shal now trowe on any othes mo?</p>
<p>Allas, I never wolde han wend, er this,</p>
<p>That ye, Criseyde, coude han chaunged so;</p>
<p>Ne, but I hadde a-gilt and doon amis,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1685</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">So cruel wende I not your herte, y-wis,</p>
<p>To slee me thus; allas, your name of trouthe</p>
<p>Is now for-doon, and that is al my routhe.</p>
<p class="stanza">242. Was ther non other broche yow liste lete</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL1689" id="TVL1689" class="pginternal">To feffe with your newe love</a>,' quod he,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1690</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">'But thilke broche that I, with teres wete,</p>
<p>Yow yaf, as for a remembraunce of me?</p>
<p>Non other cause, allas, ne hadde ye</p>
<p>But for despyt, and eek for that ye mente</p>
<p>Al-outrely to shewen your entente!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1695</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">243. Through which I see that clene out of your minde</p>
<p>Ye han me cast, and I ne can nor may,</p>
<p>For al this world, with-in myn herte finde</p>
<p>To unloven yow a quarter of a day!</p>
<p>In cursed tyme I born was, weylaway!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1700</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That ye, that doon me al this wo endure,</p>
<p>Yet love I best of any creature.</p>
<p class="stanza">244. Now god,' quod he, 'me sende yet the grace</p>
<p>That I may meten with this Diomede!</p>
<p>And trewely, if I have might and space,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1705</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Yet shal I make, I hope, his sydes blede.</p>
<p>O god,' quod he, 'that oughtest taken hede</p>
<p>To fortheren trouthe, and wronges to punyce,</p>
<p>Why niltow doon a vengeaunce on this vyce?</p>
<p class="stanza">245. O Pandare, that in dremes for to triste</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1710</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Me blamed hast, and wont art ofte up-breyde,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page412">{412}</span>Now maystow see thy-selve, if that thee
    liste,</p>
<p>How trewe is now thy nece, bright Criseyde!</p>
<p>In sondry formes, god it woot,' he seyde,</p>
<p>'The goddes shewen bothe Ioye and tene</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1715</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">In slepe, and by my dreme it is now sene.</p>
<p class="stanza">246. And certaynly, with-oute more speche,</p>
<p>From hennes-forth, as ferforth as I may,</p>
<p>Myn owene deeth in armes wol I seche;</p>
<p>I recche not how sone be the day!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1720</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But trewely, Criseyde, swete may,</p>
<p>Whom I have ay with al my might y-served,</p>
<p>That ye thus doon, I have it nought deserved.'</p>
<p class="stanza">247. This Pandarus, that alle these thinges herde,</p>
<p>And wiste wel he seyde a sooth of this,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1725</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">He nought a word ayein to him answerde;</p>
<p>For sory of his frendes sorwe he is,</p>
<p>And shamed, for his nece hath doon a-mis;</p>
<p>And stant, astoned of these causes tweye,</p>
<p>As stille as stoon; a word ne coude he seye.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1730</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">248. But at the laste thus he spak, and seyde,</p>
<p>'My brother dere, I may thee do no-more.</p>
<p>What shulde I seyn? I hate, y-wis, Criseyde!</p>
<p>And god wot, I wol hate hir evermore!</p>
<p>And that thou me bisoughtest doon of yore,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1735</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Havinge un-to myn honour ne my reste</p>
<p>Right no reward, I dide al that thee leste.</p>
<p class="stanza">249. If I dide ought that mighte lyken thee,</p>
<p>It is me leef; and of this treson now,</p>
<p>God woot, that it a sorwe is un-to me!</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1740</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And dredelees, for hertes ese of yow,</p>
<p>Right fayn wolde I amende it, wiste I how.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page413">{413}</span>And fro this world, almighty god I preye,</p>
<p>Delivere hir sone; I can no-more seye.'</p>
<p class="stanza">250. Gret was the sorwe and pleynt of Troilus;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1745</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But forth hir cours fortune ay gan to holde.</p>
<p>Criseyde loveth the sone of Tydeus,</p>
<p>And Troilus mot wepe in cares colde.</p>
<p>Swich is this world; who-so it can biholde,</p>
<p>In eche estat is litel hertes reste;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1750</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">God leve us for to take it for the beste!</p>
<p class="stanza">251. In many cruel batayle, out of drede,</p>
<p>Of Troilus, this ilke noble knight,</p>
<p>As men may in these olde bokes rede,</p>
<p>Was sene his knighthod and his grete might.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1755</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And dredelees, his ire, day and night,</p>
<p>Ful cruelly the Grekes ay aboughte;</p>
<p>And alwey most this Diomede he soughte.</p>
<p class="stanza">252. And ofte tyme, I finde that they mette</p>
<p>With blody strokes and with wordes grete,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1760</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Assayinge how hir speres weren <a href="#TVNL1760" id="TVL1760" class="pginternal">whette</a>;</p>
<p>And god it woot, with many a cruel hete</p>
<p>Gan Troilus upon his helm to-bete.</p>
<p>But natheles, fortune it nought ne wolde,</p>
<p>Of otheres hond that either deyen sholde.—</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1765</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined"><a href="#TVNL1764" id="TVL1764" class="pginternal">253</a>. And if I hadde y-taken for to
    wryte</p>
<p>The armes of this ilke worthy man,</p>
<p>Than wolde I of his batailles endyte.</p>
<p>But for that I to wryte first bigan</p>
<p>Of his love, I have seyd as that I can.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1770</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">His worthy dedes, who-so list hem here,</p>
<p>Reed <a href="#TVNL1771" id="TVL1771" class="pginternal">Dares</a>, he can telle hem alle y-fere.</p>
<p class="stanza">254. Bisechinge every lady bright of hewe,</p>
<p>And every gentil womman, what she be,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page414">{414}</span>That al be that Criseyde was untrewe,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1775</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">That for that gilt she be not wrooth with me.</p>
<p>Ye may hir gilt in othere bokes see;</p>
<p>And gladlier I wol wryten, if yow leste,</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL1778" id="TVL1778" class="pginternal">Penelopeës</a> trouthe and good <a href="#TVNL1778" class="pginternal">Alceste</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza">255. Ne I sey not this al-only for these men,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1780</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But most for wommen that bitraysed be</p>
<p>Through false folk; god yeve hem sorwe, amen!</p>
<p>That with hir grete wit and subtiltee</p>
<p>Bitrayse yow! and this commeveth me</p>
<p>To speke, and in effect yow alle I preye,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1785</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Beth war of men, and herkeneth what I seye!—</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TVNL1786" id="TVL1786" class="pginternal">256</a>. Go, litel book, go litel myn
    tregedie,</p>
<p>Ther god thy maker yet, er that he dye,</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL1787" id="TVL1787" class="pginternal">So sende might</a> to make in som comedie!</p>
<p>But litel book, <a href="#TVNL1789" id="TVL1789" class="pginternal">no making thou nenvye</a>,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1790</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But subgit be to alle poesye;</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL1791" id="TVL1791" class="pginternal">And kis the steppes</a>, wher-as thou seest pace</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL1792" id="TVL1792" class="pginternal">Virgile, Ovyde, Omer, Lucan, and Stace</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza">257. And for ther is so greet diversitee</p>
<p>In English and in wryting of our tonge,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1795</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">So preye I god that noon miswryte thee,</p>
<p>Ne thee <a href="#TVNL1796" id="TVL1796" class="pginternal">mismetre</a> for defaute of tonge.</p>
<p>And <a href="#TVNL1797" id="TVL1797" class="pginternal">red</a> wher-so thou be, or elles songe,</p>
<p>That thou be understonde I god beseche!</p>
<p>But yet to purpos of my rather speche.—</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1800</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">258. The wraththe, as I began yow for to seye,</p>
<p>Of Troilus, the Grekes boughten dere;</p>
<p>For <a href="#TVNL1802" id="TVL1802" class="pginternal">thousandes</a> his hondes maden deye,</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page415">{415}</span>As he that was with-outen any pere,</p>
<p>Save Ector, in his tyme, as I can here.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1805</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">But weylaway, save only goddes wille,</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL1806" id="TVL1806" class="pginternal">Dispitously him slough the fiers Achille</a>.</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TVNL1807" id="TVL1807" class="pginternal">259</a>. And whan that he was slayn in this
    manere,</p>
<p>His lighte goost ful blisfully is went</p>
<p>Up to the holownesse of the seventh spere,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1810</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><a href="#TVNL1810" id="TVL1810" class="pginternal">In convers letinge</a> every element;</p>
<p>And ther he saugh, with ful avysement,</p>
<p>The erratik sterres, herkeninge armonye</p>
<p>With sownes fulle of hevenish melodye.</p>
<p class="stanza">260. And doun from thennes faste he gan avyse</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1815</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">This <a href="#TVNL1815" id="TVL1815" class="pginternal">litel spot of erthe</a>, that with the
    see</p>
<p>Enbraced is, and fully gan despyse</p>
<p>This wrecched world, and held al vanitee</p>
<p>To respect of the pleyn felicitee</p>
<p>That is in hevene above; and at the laste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1820</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Ther he was slayn, his loking doun he caste;</p>
<p class="stanza">261. And in him-self he lough right at the wo</p>
<p>Of hem that wepten for his deeth so faste;</p>
<p>And dampned al our werk that folweth so</p>
<p>The blinde lust, the which that may not laste,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1825</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And <a href="#TVNL1825" id="TVL1825" class="pginternal">sholden</a> al our herte on hevene
    caste.</p>
<p>And forth he wente, shortly for to telle,</p>
<p>Ther as Mercurie <a href="#TVNL1827" id="TVL1827" class="pginternal">sorted</a> him to dwelle.—</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TVNL1828" id="TVL1828" class="pginternal">262</a>. Swich fyn hath, lo, this Troilus for
    love,</p>
<p>Swich fyn hath al his grete worthinesse;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1830</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Swich fyn hath his estat real above,</p>
<p>Swich fyn his lust, swich fyn hath his noblesse;</p>
<p>Swich fyn hath false worldes brotelnesse.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum" id="page416">{416}</span>And thus bigan his lovinge of Criseyde,</p>
<p>As I have told, and in this wyse he deyde.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35 stanza">1835</div>
</div>
<p class="stanza lined">263. O yonge fresshe folkes, he or she,</p>
<p>In which that love up groweth with your age,</p>
<p>Repeyreth hoom from worldly vanitee,</p>
<p><a href="#TVNL1838" id="TVL1838" class="pginternal">And of your herte</a> up-casteth the visage</p>
<p>To thilke god that after his image</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1840</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Yow made, and <a href="#TVNL1840" id="TVL1840" class="pginternal">thinketh al nis but a
    fayre</a></p>
<p>This world, that passeth sone as floures fayre.</p>
<p class="stanza">264. And loveth him, the which that right for love</p>
<p>Upon a cros, our soules for to beye,</p>
<p>First starf, and roos, and sit in hevene a-bove;</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1845</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">For he nil falsen no wight, dar I seye,</p>
<p>That wol his herte al hoolly on him leye.</p>
<p>And sin he best to love is, and most meke,</p>
<p>What nedeth feyned loves for to seke?</p>
<p class="stanza">265. Lo here, of Payens corsed olde rytes,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1850</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Lo here, what alle hir goddes may availle;</p>
<p>Lo here, these wrecched worldes appetytes;</p>
<p>Lo here, the fyn and guerdon for travaille</p>
<p>Of Iove, Appollo, of Mars, of swich rascaille!</p>
<p>Lo here, the forme of olde clerkes speche</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1855</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">In poetrye, if ye hir bokes seche.—</p>
<p class="stanza">266. O <a href="#TVNL1856" id="TVL1856" class="pginternal">moral Gower</a>, this book I
    directe</p>
<p>To thee, and to the philosophical <a href="#TVNL1857" id="TVL1857" class="pginternal">Strode</a>,</p>
<p>To vouchen sauf, ther nede is, to corecte,</p>
<p>Of your benignitees and zeles gode.</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1860</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">And to that sothfast Crist, that starf on rode,</p>
<p>With al myn herte of mercy ever I preye;</p>
<p>And to the lord right thus I speke and seye:</p>
<p class="stanza"><a href="#TVNL1863" id="TVL1863" class="pginternal">267</a>. Thou oon, and two, and three, eterne
    on-lyve,</p>
<p>That regnest ay in three and two and oon,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">1865</div>
</div>
<p class="lined"><span class="pagenum" id="page417">{417}</span>Uncircumscript, and al mayst
    circumscryve,</p>
<p>Us from visible and invisible foon</p>
<p>Defende; and to thy mercy, everichoon,</p>
<p>So make us, Iesus, for thy grace digne,</p>
<p>For love of mayde and moder thyn benigne! Amen.</p>
</div>
<p class="ac"><b>Explicit Liber Troili et Criseydis.</b></p>

<div><span class="pagenum" id="page419">{419}</span></div>
<h1 class="sp3 ac" style="margin-bottom:4.7ex;"> <span class="x-larger">NOTES TO
  BOETHIUS.</span></h1>
<h2>BOOK I.</h2>
<p><b>Metre 1.</b> In order to elucidate the English text, I frequently quote the original Latin,
  usually from the text of T. Obbarius, Jena, 1843. See further in the Introduction.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIL3" id="BIMINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>rendinge</i>, Lat. 'lacerae'; rather rent, or
  tattered. The sense 'rending' occurs in Ovid, Met. viii. 880.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIL6" id="BIMINL6" class="pginternal">6</a>. <i>that is to seyn.</i> The words in italics are not in
  the original, but were added by Chaucer as explanatory. Throughout the treatise, I print all such
  passages in italics.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIL8" id="BIMINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>werdes</i>, 'weirds,' fate.</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Gloria felicis olim uiridisque iuuentae</p>
<p style="margin-left:0.70em">Solantur maesti nunc mea fata senis.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#BIMIL12" id="BIMINL12" class="pginternal">12</a>. <i>slake</i>, better <i>slakke</i>; cf. Cant. Ta. E.
  1849. <i>empted</i>, 'effeto.' MS. C. has <i>emty</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIL13" id="BIMINL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>in yeres ... swete</i>: 'dulcibus annis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIL14" id="BIMINL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>y-cleped</i>, invoked; 'uocata,' sc. 'mors.' Cf.
  Troilus, iv. 503.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIL16" id="BIMINL16" class="pginternal">16</a>. <i>naiteth</i>, refuseth; 'negat.' Icel. <i>neita</i>,
  to say nay.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIL17" id="BIMINL17" class="pginternal">17</a>. <i>lighte</i>, i.e. transitory; 'leuibus ... bonis.'
  The gloss 'sc. temporels' (in A) gives the right sense. <i>sc.</i> = scilicet, namely; the form
  <i>temporels</i> is the French plural.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIL18" id="BIMINL18" class="pginternal">18, 19</a>. <i>But now</i>:</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Nunc quia fallacem mutauit nubila uultum,</p>
<p style="margin-left:0.70em">Protrahit ingratas impia uita moras.'</p>
</div>
<p>The translation <i>unagreable dwellinges</i> is an unhappy one.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIL22" id="BIMINL22" class="pginternal">22</a>. <i>in stedefast degree</i>, in a secure position;
  'stabili ... gradu.'</p>
<p>With regard to the last sentence, Mr. Stewart remarks, in his essay on Boethius, that Chaucer
  here 'actually reproduces the original Latin metre,' i.e. a hexameter and pentameter. The true M.
  E. pronunciation must, for this purpose, be entirely neglected; which amounts to saying that
  Chaucer must have been profoundly unconscious of any such intention.</p>
<p><b>Prose 1.</b> <a href="#BIPIL2" id="BIPINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>and markede</i>: 'querimoniamque
  lacrimabilem stili officio designarem.' Hence <i>markede</i> is 'wrote down'; and <i>pointel</i>
  refers to the <i>stilus</i>. Cf. Som. Tale, D 1742. <i>with office</i>, by the use (of).</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page420">{420}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIPIL6" id="BIPINL6" class="pginternal">6</a>. <i>empted</i>, exhausted; 'inexhausti uigoris.' Of course
  the woman here described is <i>Philosophia</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIL9" id="BIPINL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>doutous</i>; 'statura discretionis ambiguae.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIL12" id="BIPINL12" class="pginternal">12</a>. <i>heef</i>, heaved; A. S. <i>hōf</i>. In
  Layamon, <i>hof</i>, <i>haf</i>, <i>heaf</i>. I put <i>heef</i> for <i>hef</i>, because the
  <i>e</i> is long.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIL13" id="BIPINL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>so that</i>: 'respicientiumque hominum frustrabatur
  intuitum.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIL14" id="BIPINL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>delye</i> (so in both MSS.) = <i>deli-ē</i>,
  O. F. <i>deliè</i> (see Cotgrave), delicate, thin, slender, from Lat. <i>delicatus</i>, with the
  usual loss of <i>c</i> between two vowels and before the accented syllable; Lat. 'tenuissimis
  filis.'</p>
<p>After <i>crafte</i> it would have been better to insert <i>and</i>; Lat.
  'indissolubili<i>que</i> materiâ.' But some MSS., including C., omit <i>que</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIL18" id="BIPINL18" class="pginternal">18</a>. <i>as it is wont</i>: 'ueluti fumosas imagines
  solet.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIL21" id="BIPINL21" class="pginternal">21</a>. <i>a Grekissh P</i>; i.e. <span class="fsn" title="P">Π</span>. <i>a Grekissh T</i>; i.e. <span class="fsn" title="TH">Θ</span>,
  not <span class="fsn" title="T">Τ</span>; the Greek <span class="fsn" title="th">θ</span> being pronounced as <i>t</i> in Latin. The reference is to <span class="fsn" title="philosophia praktikê kai theôrêtikê">φιλοσοφία
  πρακτικὴ καὶ
  θεωρητική</span>; in Latin, Philosophia Actiua
  et Contemplatiua; i. e. Practical (or Active) and Theoretical (or Contemplative) Philosophy.
  This is the same distinction as that between the <i>Vita Actiua</i> and <i>Vita Contemplatiua</i>,
  so common in medieval literature; see note (3) to the Sec. Non. Tale, G 87; and note to P.
  Plowman, B. vi. 251.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIL26" id="BIPINL26" class="pginternal">26</a>. <i>corven</i>, cut, cut away pieces from; Lat.
  'sciderant.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIL33" id="BIPINL33" class="pginternal">33</a>. <i>cruel</i>, i. e. stern; 'toruis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIL34" id="BIPINL34" class="pginternal">34</a>. <i>thise comune</i>: 'has scenicas meretriculas.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIL39" id="BIPINL39" class="pginternal">39</a>. <i>no-thing fructefyinge</i>; 'infructuosis.' Hence we
  may perhaps prefer to read <i>no-thing fructuous</i>, as in Caxton and Thynne.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIL41" id="BIPINL41" class="pginternal">41</a>. <i>holden</i>: 'hominumque mentes assuefaciunt morbo,
  non liberant.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIL45" id="BIPINL45" class="pginternal">45</a>. <i>for-why</i>, because (very common); seldom
  interrogative.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIL47" id="BIPINL47" class="pginternal">47</a>. <i>me</i>, from me; and, in fact, Caxton and Thynne
  read <i>from me</i> or <i>fro me</i>. The forms <i>Eleaticis</i>, &amp;c. are due to the Lat.
  text—'Eleaticis atque Academicis studiis.' He should rather have said—'scoles of Elea
  and of the Academie.' The <i>Eleatici philosophi</i> were the followers of Zeno of Elea (Zeno
  Eleates, born about <span class="smaller">B. C.</span> 488 at Elea (Velia) in Italy), and the
  favourite disciple of Parmenides (who is expressly mentioned in Book iii. pr. 12, l. 143). The
  Academic philosophers were followers of Plato.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIL49" id="BIPINL49" class="pginternal">49</a>. <i>mermaidenes</i>; Lat. 'Sirenes,' Sirens; cf. N. P.
  Tale, B 4461, and note.</p>
<p><i>til it be at the laste</i>; a false translation. Rather <i>unto destruction</i>; 'usque in
  exitium.' But, instead of <i>exitium</i>, MS. C. has <i>exitum</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIL55" id="BIPINL55" class="pginternal">55</a>. <i>plounged</i>, drowned; 'mersa.' Cf. <i>dreint</i>,
  Met. 2, l. 1.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIL59" id="BIPINL59" class="pginternal">59</a>. <i>ner</i>, nearer; comparative, not positive;
  'propius.'</p>
<p><b>Metre 2.</b> <a href="#BIMIIL2" id="BIMIINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>mintinge</i>, intending; 'tendit ...
  ire.' Still in use in Cambridgeshire.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIIL8" id="BIMIINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>sterres of the cold moon</i>: 'gelidae sidera
  lunae.' I suppose this means the constellations seen by moonlight, but invisible in the day. The
  expression <i>sidus lunae</i>, the moon's bright form, occurs in Pliny, <span class="pagenum" id="page421">{421}</span>Nat. Hist. ii. 9. 6; but it is difficult to see how <i>sidera</i> can
  have the same sense, as some commentators say.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIIL9" id="BIMIINL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>recourses</i>, orbits; referring to the planets.</p>
<p><i>y-flit</i>, moved or whirled along by their different spheres; alluding to the old Ptolemaic
  system of astronomy, which supposed that each planet was fastened to a revolving sphere, thus
  causing it to perform its orbit in a certain time, varying in the case of each.</p>
<p><i>this man</i>: 'Comprensam [sc. stellam] in numeris uictor habebat.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIIL16" id="BIMIINL16" class="pginternal">16</a>. <i>highteth</i>, adorns; 'ornet.' Prob. from the sb.
  <i>hight</i>, <i>hiht</i> (A. S. <i>hyht</i>), joy, delight.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIIL17" id="BIMIINL17" class="pginternal">17</a>. <i>fleteth</i>, flows (i.e. abounds); 'grauidis
  influat uuis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIIL20" id="BIMIINL20" class="pginternal">20</a>. <i>empted</i>: 'Nunc iacet effeto lumine
  mentis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIIL22" id="BIMIINL22" class="pginternal">22</a>. <i>fool</i>, i.e. foolish, witless, senseless;
  'stolidam.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 2.</b> <a href="#BIPIIL6" id="BIPIINL6" class="pginternal">6</a>. <i>armures</i>, i.e. defensive armour;
  'arma.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIL8" id="BIPIINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>in sikernesse</i>: 'inuicta te firmitate
  tuerentur.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIL14" id="BIPIINL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>litargie</i>; better <i>letargye</i>, i.e.
  lethargy. Cf. Troil. i. 730.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIL19" id="BIPIINL19" class="pginternal">19</a>. <i>yplyted</i>, pleated into a wrinkle; 'contracta
  in rugam ueste.'</p>
<p><b>Metre 3.</b> <a href="#BIMIIIL1" id="BIMIIINL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>discussed</i>, driven away;
  'discussâ ... nocte.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIIIL4" id="BIMIIINL4" class="pginternal">4</a>. <i>clustred</i>; 'glomerantur'; or 'covered with
  clouds,' as Chaucer says.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIIIL5" id="BIMIIINL5" class="pginternal">5</a>. <i>Chorus</i>, Corus, or Caurus, the north-west
  wind.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIIIL6" id="BIMIIINL6" class="pginternal">6</a>. <i>ploungy</i>, stormy, rainy; 'nimbosis ...
  imbribus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIIIL8" id="BIMIIINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>Borias</i>, Boreas, the north wind, from
  Thrace.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIIIL9" id="BIMIIINL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>caves</i>; better <i>cave</i>, as in Caxton and
