  Thynne; Lat. 'antro.' <i>beteth</i>; 'uerberet'; hence Chaucer's gloss.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIIIL11" id="BIMIIINL11" class="pginternal">11</a>. <i>y-shaken</i>, 'uibratus'; i.e. tremulous,
  sparkling.</p>
<p><b>Prose 3.</b> <a href="#BIPIIIL2" id="BIPIIINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>took</i>, drew in, received light;
  'hausi caelum.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIIL4" id="BIPIIINL4" class="pginternal">4</a>. <i>beholde</i>, the present tense; 'respicio.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIIL10" id="BIPIIINL10" class="pginternal">10</a>. <i>norry</i>, pupil, lit. nourished one;
  'alumne.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIIL11" id="BIPIIINL11" class="pginternal">11</a>. <i>parten the charge</i>, share the burden.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIIL15" id="BIPIIINL15" class="pginternal">15</a>. <i>redoute my blame</i>, fear blame.
  <i>agrysen</i>, shudder.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIIL16" id="BIPIIINL16" class="pginternal">16</a>. <i>quasi diceret non</i>, as if she would say no;
  as if she expected the answer no. This remark is often inserted by Chaucer.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIIL19" id="BIPIIINL19" class="pginternal">19</a>. <i>Plato</i>; <span class="smaller">B.C.</span>
  428-347. Before his time, Solon, Anaxagoras, and Pythagoras all met with opposition. The fate of
  Socrates is well known.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIIL21" id="BIPIIINL21" class="pginternal">21</a>. <i>The heritage</i>: 'Cuius hereditatem cum
  deinceps Epicureum uulgus ac Stoicum, ceterique pro sua quisque parte raptum ire molirentur, meque
  reclamantem renitentemque uelut in partem praedae detraherent, uestem, quam meis texueram manibus,
  disciderunt, abreptisque ab ea panniculis, totam me sibi cessisse credentes abiere.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIIL38" id="BIPIIINL38" class="pginternal">38</a>. <i>Anaxogore</i>, Anaxagoras, a Greek philosopher
  (<span class="smaller">B.C.</span> 500-428); exiled from Athens (<span class="smaller">B.C.</span>
  450).</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIIL39" id="BIPIIINL39" class="pginternal">39</a>. <i>Zeno</i>; Zeno of Elea (see p. 420), born about
  <span class="smaller">B.C.</span> 488, is said to have risked his life to defend his country. His
  fate is doubtful.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIIL40" id="BIPIIINL40" class="pginternal">40</a>. <i>Senecciens</i>, apparently meant for 'the
  followers of Seneca.' <span class="pagenum" id="page422">{422}</span>The original has: 'at Canios,
  at Senecas, at Soranos ... scire potuisti.'</p>
<p><i>Canios</i>, the Canii; i. e. men like Canius. The constancy and death of Julius Canius
  (or Canus) is related by Seneca, De Tranquillitate, cap. xiv. Cf. Pr. iv. 131, and note, p.
  424.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIIL41" id="BIPIIINL41" class="pginternal">41</a>. <i>Sorans</i>, the Sorani; men like Soranus.
  Soranus is mentioned in Tacitus, Annal. xvi. 23. Caxton and Thynne read <i>Soranos</i>, as in the
  Latin text.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIIL42" id="BIPIIINL42" class="pginternal">42</a>. <i>unsolempne</i>, uncelebrated; 'incelebris.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIIL49" id="BIPIIINL49" class="pginternal">49</a>. <i>it is to dispyse</i>, it (the host) is to be
  despised.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIIL53" id="BIPIIINL53" class="pginternal">53</a>. <i>ententif</i>, busy about seizing useless
  baggage as spoil.</p>
<p><i>sarpulers</i>, sacks made of coarse canvas; in Caxton, <i>sarpleris</i>; 'sarcinulas.'
  Cotgrave has: '<i>Serpillere</i>, a Sarpler, or Sarp-cloth, a piece of course canvas to pack up
  things in.' Cf. mod. F. <i>serpillière</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIIIL56" id="BIPIIINL56" class="pginternal">56</a>. <i>palis</i>, also spelt <i>paleis</i> (O. F.
  <i>palis</i>), lit. a palisading, or a piece of strong paling, a rampart, used to translate Lat.
  <i>uallum</i>. When spelt <i>paleis</i>, it must not be confused with <i>paleis</i>, a palace.</p>
<p><b>Metre 4.</b> <a href="#BIMIVL3" id="BIMIVNL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>either fortune</i>, good fortune or
  bad.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIVL5" id="BIMIVNL5" class="pginternal">5</a>. <i>hete</i>: 'Versum funditus excitantis aestum.' I
  suppose that <i>aestum</i> is rather 'surge' than 'heat' here. See Met. vii. below, l. 3.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIVL6" id="BIMIVNL6" class="pginternal">6</a>. <i>Vesevus</i>, 'Veseuus'; the same as Vesuvius; cf.
  Vergil, Georg. ii. 224.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIVL7" id="BIMIVNL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>wrytheth</i>, writhes out, throws forth wreaths of
  smoke. Here the old printed editions by Caxton and Thynne, as well as MS. Ii. 1. 38, happily
  restore the text; Lat. 'Torquet.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIVL8" id="BIMIVNL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. Caxton and Thynne have <i>thonder-leyte</i>, which is
  perhaps better. MS. Ii. 1. 38 has <i>thonder leit</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMIVL13" id="BIMIVNL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>stable of his right</i>: 'stabilis, suique
  iuris.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 4.</b> <a href="#BIPIVL2" id="BIPIVNL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>Artow lyk</i>. The original is
  partly in Greek. 'An <span class="fsn" title="onos luras">ὄνος
  λύρας</span>?' Some MSS. have: 'Esne <span class="fsn" title="onos pros luran">ὄνος πρὸς
  λύραν</span>?' And MS. C. has: 'Esne asinus ad liram?' In an edition of
  Boethius by Renatus Vallinus, printed in 1656, I find the following note: 'Ut et omnes veteres
  scripsere, Varro in satyra quæ Testamentum inscribitur apud Agellium, lib. iii. cap. xvi:
  <i>Ii</i> liberi, <i>si erunt</i> <span class="fsn" title="onoi luras">ὄνοι
  λύρας</span>, <i>exheredes sunto</i>. Suidas ex Menandro, Lucianus,
  Martian. Capella, lib. viii., atque alii quos refert Erasmus, in eo adagio. Imo et apud Varronem
  id nominis satyra extitit.' It has clearly a proverbial reference to dullness of perception. Ch.
  quotes it again in his Troilus, i. 731, where he so explains it.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL3" id="BIPIVNL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>why spillestow teres</i>, why do you waste tears;
  'Quid lacrimis manas?' After these words occur, in the original, four Greek words which Chaucer
  does not translate, viz.: <span class="fsn" title="Exauda, mê keuthe noô">Ἐξαύδα, μὴ
  κεῦθε νόῳ</span>: i. e. speak out, do not
  hide them in your mind; quoted from Homer, Iliad i. 363.</p>
<p>With lines 3 and 4 compare Troilus, i. 857.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL7" id="BIPIVNL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>by him-self</i>, in itself; 'per se.' Alluding to
  'sharpnesse,' i. e. 'asperitas.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page423">{423}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL15" id="BIPIVNL15" class="pginternal">15</a>. <i>enformedest</i>, didst conform; 'formares.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL17" id="BIPIVNL17" class="pginternal">17</a>. <i>ordre of hevene</i>; 'ad caelestis ordinis
  exemplar.' This refers to the words of Plato just at the end of the 9th book of The Republic:
  <span class="fsn" title="en ouranô isôs paradeigma anakeitai.">ἐν
  ὀυρανῷ ἴσως
  παράδειγμα
  ἀνάκειται.</span> Cf. also the last lines of
  Book II of the present treatise.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL18" id="BIPIVNL18" class="pginternal">18</a>. <i>confermedest</i> (MS. A, <i>enfourmedist</i>),
  didst confirm; 'sanxisti.' The reading <i>conformedest</i> evidently arose from confusion with
  <i>enformedest</i> above, in l. 15.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL19" id="BIPIVNL19" class="pginternal">19</a>. <i>mouth of Plato</i>; referring to Book V (473 D)
  of the Republic: <span class="fsn" title="ean mê, ê hoi philosophoi basileusôsin   en tais polesin, ê hoi basilês te nyn   legomenoi ki dynastai philosophêsôsi   gnêsiôs te kai hikanôs, kai touto eis   tauton xympesê, dynamis te politikê kai   philosophia; tôn de nyn poreuomenôn   chôris eph' hekateron hai pollai physeis   ex anankês apokleisthôsin, ouk esti   kakôn paula ... tais polesi; dokô de,   oude tô anthrôpinô genei.">ἐὰν μὴ, ἢ ὁι
  φιλόσοφοι
  βασιλεύσωσιν ἐν
  ταῖς πόλεσιν, ἠ
  ὁι βασιλῆς τε νῦν
  λεγόμενοι κὶ
  δυνάσται
  φιλοσοφήσωσι
  γνησίως τε καὶ
  ἱκανῶς, καὶ
  τοῦτο ἐις ταὐτὸν
  ξυμπέσῃ, δύναμίς
  τε πολιτικὴ καὶ
  φιλοσοφία· τῶν
  δε νῦν πορευομένων
  χωρὶς ἐφ' ἑκάτερον
  ἁι πολλαὶ
  φύσεις ἐξ
  ἀνάγκης ἀποκλεισθῶσιν,
  ὀυκ ἔστι κακῶν
  παῦλα ... ταῖς
  πόλεσι· δοκῶ
  δὲ, ὀυδὲ τῳ
  ἀνθρωπίνῳ
  γένει.</span></p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL24" id="BIPIVNL24" class="pginternal">24</a>. <i>the same Plato</i>; in the 6th Dialogue on the
  Republic.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL25" id="BIPIVNL25" class="pginternal">25</a>. <i>cause</i>, reason; 'caussam.' <i>wyse</i>, i.e.
  '<i>for</i> wise men.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL27" id="BIPIVNL27" class="pginternal">27</a>. <i>felonous tormentours citizenes</i>, citizens who
  are wicked and oppressive; the substantives are in apposition.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL33" id="BIPIVNL33" class="pginternal">33</a>. <i>knowinge with me</i>, my witnesses; 'mihi ...
  conscii.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL36" id="BIPIVNL36" class="pginternal">36</a>. <i>discordes ... preyeres</i>; 'inexorabilesque
  discordiae.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL37" id="BIPIVNL37" class="pginternal">37</a>. <i>for this libertee</i>, &amp;c.; 'et quod
  conscientiae libertas habet.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL41" id="BIPIVNL41" class="pginternal">41</a>. <i>Conigaste</i>, Conigastus, or Cunigastus;
  mentioned in Cassiodorus, Epist. lib. viii. ep. 28. The facts here referred to are known only from
  the present passage.</p>
<p><i>prospre fortunes</i> translates 'fortunas' simply; it seems to mean 'success' or
  'well-being.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL43" id="BIPIVNL43" class="pginternal">43</a>. <i>Trigwille</i>, Triguilla; 'regiae praepositum
  domus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL45" id="BIPIVNL45" class="pginternal">45</a>. <i>auctoritee</i>; 'obiecta periculis auctoritate
  protexi.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL52" id="BIPIVNL52" class="pginternal">52</a>. <i>cariages</i>, taxes; 'uectigalibus.' See a
  similar use in the Pers. Tale, I 752, and note.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL59" id="BIPIVNL59" class="pginternal">59</a>. <i>inplitable</i>, intricate: 'inexplicabilis.'
  <i>coempcioun</i>, an imposition so called; see Chaucer's explanation below, in l. 64. In Greek,
  <span class="fsn" title="synônê">συνωνή</span>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL61" id="BIPIVNL61" class="pginternal">61</a>. <i>Campaigne</i>, Campania, in Italy,
  <i>provost</i>; 'praefectum praetorii.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL64" id="BIPIVNL64" class="pginternal">64-67</a>. See the footnote. I have here transposed this
  gloss, so as to make it <i>follow</i>, instead of <i>preceding</i>, the mention of
  <i>coempcioun</i> in the text.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL68" id="BIPIVNL68" class="pginternal">68</a>. <i>Paulin</i>, Decius Paulinus, consul in 498;
  mentioned in Cassiodorus, Epist. lib. i. epist. 23, lib. iii. epist. 29.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL69" id="BIPIVNL69" class="pginternal">69</a>. <i>houndes</i>; 'Palatini canes.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL73" id="BIPIVNL73" class="pginternal">73</a>. <i>Albin</i>, perhaps Decius Albinus, to whom
  Theodoric addressed a letter preserved in Cassiodorus, lib. iv. ep. 30. See l. 156 below.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL75" id="BIPIVNL75" class="pginternal">75</a>. <i>Ciprian</i>, Cyprian. We know something of him
  from two letters in Cassiodorus, Epist. v. 40, 41. Theodoric esteemed him highly. See a discussion
  of his career in H. F. Stewart's Essay on Boethius, pp. 42-52.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL78" id="BIPIVNL78" class="pginternal">78</a>. <i>to hem-ward</i>, i.e. for the benefit of the
  officers around me; 'mihi ... nihil apud aulicos, quo magis essem tutior, reseruaui.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page424">{424}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL81" id="BIPIVNL81" class="pginternal">81</a>. <i>Basilius</i>. Not much is known of him; see H. F.
  Stewart, as above, p. 48.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL82" id="BIPIVNL82" class="pginternal">82</a>. <i>compelled</i>, i.e. bribed to accuse me. <i>for
  nede of foreine moneye</i>: 'alienae aeris necessitate.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL84" id="BIPIVNL84" class="pginternal">84</a>. <i>Opilion</i>, Opilio; the Opilio mentioned in
  Cassiodorus, lib. v. epist. 41, and lib. viii. epist. 16, and brother of the Cyprian mentioned
  above, l. 75. His father's name was Opilio likewise.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL89" id="BIPIVNL89" class="pginternal">89</a>. <i>aperceived</i>, made known. <i>the king</i>, i.e.
  Theodoric, king of Italy for 33 years, <span class="smaller">A.D.</span> 493-526. His reign was,
  on the whole, good and glorious, but he committed the great crime of putting to death both
  Boethius and his aged father-in-law Symmachus, for which he afterwards expressed his deep
  repentance. See Gibbon's Roman Empire. The chief record of his reign is in the collection of
  twelve books of public epistles composed in his name by Cassiodorus. The seat of his government
  was Ravenna, as mentioned below.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL93" id="BIPIVNL93" class="pginternal">93</a>. <i>lykned</i>; rather, <i>added</i>; Lat. 'posse
  <i>adstrui</i> uidetur.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL95" id="BIPIVNL95" class="pginternal">95-194</a>. See a translation into modern English of the
  whole of this passage, in H. F. Stewart's Essay, pp. 37-41.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL101" id="BIPIVNL101" class="pginternal">101</a>. <i>axestow in somme</i>, if you ask particularly;
  'summam quaeris?'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL106" id="BIPIVNL106" class="pginternal">106, 107</a>. <i>forsake</i>, deny. <i>have wold</i>, have
  willed, did wish.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL109" id="BIPIVNL109" class="pginternal">109</a>. <i>and that I confesse</i>. Here Chaucer's
  version seems to be quite at fault. 'At uolui, nec unquam uelle desistam. Fatebimur? [MS. C. Et
  fatebimur.] Sed impediendi delatoris opera cessabit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL113" id="BIPIVNL113" class="pginternal">113</a>. <i>by me</i>, with regard to me; 'de me.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL117" id="BIPIVNL117" class="pginternal">117</a>. <i>Socrates</i>; in Plato's Republic, Book VI:
  <span class="fsn" title="tên apseudeian ... misein, tên d'   alêtheian stergein">τὴν ἀψεύδειαν
  ... μισεῖν, τὴν δ'
  ἀλήθειαν
  στέργειν</span> (485 C).</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL120" id="BIPIVNL120" class="pginternal">120</a>. <i>preisen</i>, appraise, judge of:
  'aestimandum.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL131" id="BIPIVNL131" class="pginternal">131</a>. <i>Canius</i>, better <i>Canus</i>, i.e. 'Julius
  Canus, whose philosophic death is described by Seneca, De Tranquillitate Animi, cap.
  xiv.'—Gibbon. He has already been mentioned above, Prose iii. l. 40.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL132" id="BIPIVNL132" class="pginternal">132</a>. <i>Germeynes sone</i>, the son of Germanicus.
  This Gaius Cæsar is better known as Caligula, the emperor who succeeded Tiberius.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL143" id="BIPIVNL143" class="pginternal">143</a>. <i>famileres</i>, friends, i.e. disciples, viz.
  Epicurus, in the De Ira Divina, cap. xiii (Stewart).</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL154" id="BIPIVNL154" class="pginternal">154</a>. <i>Verone</i>, Verona; next to Ravenna, the
  favourite residence of Theodoric.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL156" id="BIPIVNL156" class="pginternal">156</a>. <i>his real maiestee</i>, high treason, lit. 'his
  royal majesty'; Lat. 'maiestatis crimen.' The king was intent upon repressing all freedom of
  speech.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL167" id="BIPIVNL167" class="pginternal">167</a>. <i>submittede</i>, subdued: 'summitteret.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL171" id="BIPIVNL171" class="pginternal">171</a>. <i>present</i>, i.e. he would, even in such a
  case, have been allowed to appear in his defence, would have been called upon to confess his
  crime, and would have been condemned in a regular manner.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL173" id="BIPIVNL173" class="pginternal">173</a>. <i>fyve hundred</i>, nearly 500 miles. Boethius
  was imprisoned in a tower at Pavia.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL176" id="BIPIVNL176" class="pginternal">176</a>. <i>as who seith, nay</i>; i.e. it is said
  ironically. The senate well <span class="pagenum" id="page425">{425}</span>deserve that no one
  should ever defend them as I did, and be convicted for it.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL181" id="BIPIVNL181" class="pginternal">181</a>. <i>sacrilege</i>; glossed <i>sorcerie</i>:
  'sacrilegio.' Sorcery or magic is intended. 'At the command of the barbarians, the occult science
  of a philosopher was stigmatised with the names of sacrilege and magic.'—Gibbon. See below,
  l. 196.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL186" id="BIPIVNL186" class="pginternal">186</a>. <i>Pictagoras</i>, Pythagoras. The saying here
  attributed to him is given in the original in Greek—<span class="fsn" title="hepou theô">ἕπου θεῷ</span>. Some MSS. add the
  gloss, <i>i. deo non diis seruiendum</i>. MS. C. has: <i>deo et non diis sacrificandum</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL188" id="BIPIVNL188" class="pginternal">188</a>. <i>I</i>, i. e. for me. A remarkable
  grammatical use.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL190" id="BIPIVNL190" class="pginternal">190</a>. <i>right clene</i>: 'penetral innocens
  domus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL193" id="BIPIVNL193" class="pginternal">193</a>. <i>thorugh</i>, i. e. for. Caxton and Thynne
  read <i>for</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL195" id="BIPIVNL195" class="pginternal">195</a>. <i>feith</i>: 'de te tanti criminis fidem
  capiunt.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL198" id="BIPIVNL198" class="pginternal">198</a>. <i>it suffiseth nat only ... but-yif</i>, this
  alone is insufficient ... unless thou also, &amp;c. <i>of thy free wille</i>: 'ultro.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL212" id="BIPIVNL212" class="pginternal">212</a>. <i>good gessinge</i>, high esteem: 'existimatio
  bona.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL215" id="BIPIVNL215" class="pginternal">215</a>. <i>charge</i>, burden, load: 'sarcinam.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL219" id="BIPIVNL219" class="pginternal">219</a>. <i>by gessinge</i>, in men's esteem:
  'existimatione.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPIVL223" id="BIPIVNL223" class="pginternal">223</a>. <i>for drede</i>: 'nostri discriminis
  terrore.'</p>
<p><b>Metre 5.</b> <a href="#BIMVL1" id="BIMVNL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>whele</i>, sphere: 'orbis.' Not only
  were there seven spheres allotted to the planets, but there was an eighth larger sphere, called
  the sphere of fixed stars, and a ninth 'sphere of first motion,' or <i>primum mobile</i>, which
  revolved round the earth once in 24 hours, according to the Ptolemaic astronomy. This is here
  alluded to. God is supposed to sit in an immoveable throne beyond it.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVL3" id="BIMVNL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>sweigh</i>, violent motion; the very word used in the
  same connexion in the Man of Lawes Tale, B 296; see note to that passage.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVL4" id="BIMVNL4" class="pginternal">4</a>. <i>ful hornes</i>, i. e. her horns filled up, as at
  full moon, when she meets 'with alle the bemes' of the Sun, i. e. reflects them fully.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVL7" id="BIMVNL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>derke hornes</i>, horns faintly shining, as when the
  moon, a thin crescent, is near the sun and nearly all obscured.</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'The bente mone with hir hornes pale;' Troil. iii. 624.</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#BIMVL9" id="BIMVNL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>cometh eft ayein hir used cours</i>, returns towards
  her accustomed course, i. e. appears again, as usual, as a morning-star, in due course. I
  think the text is incorrect; for <i>cometh</i> read <i>torneth</i>, i. e. turns. Lat. text:
  'Solitas iterum mutet habenas.' The planet Venus, towards one apparent extremity of her orbit,
  follows the sun, as an evening-star; and again, towards the other apparent extremity, precedes it
  as a morning-star. So Cicero, De Nat. Deorum, ii. 20. 53: 'dicitur Lucifer, cum antegreditur
  solem, cum subsequitur autem, Hesperus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVL11" id="BIMVNL11" class="pginternal">11</a>. <i>restreinest</i>, shortenest; the sun's apparent
  course being shorter in winter. Lat. 'stringis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVL13" id="BIMVNL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>swifte tydes</i>, short times; viz. of the summer
  nights.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVL19" id="BIMVNL19" class="pginternal">19</a>. <i>Arcturus</i>, <span class="fsn" title="a">α</span> Boötis, in the sign Libra; conspicuous in the nights of spring.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVL20" id="BIMVNL20" class="pginternal">20</a>. <i>Sirius</i>, <span class="fsn" title="a">α</span> Canis Maioris, or the Dog-star, in the sign of <span class="pagenum" id="page426">{426}</span>Cancer; seen before sun-rise in the so-called dog-days, in July and
  August. It was supposed that the near approach of Sirius to the Sun caused great heat.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVL21" id="BIMVNL21" class="pginternal">21</a>. <i>his lawe</i>, i.e. '<i>its</i> law'; and so again
  in <i>his propre</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVL28" id="BIMVNL28" class="pginternal">28</a>. <i>on.</i> Caxton and Thynne rightly read
  <i>on</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVL29" id="BIMVNL29" class="pginternal">29</a>. <i>derke derknesses</i>, obscure darkness: 'obscuris
  ... tenebris.' Not a happy expression.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVL31" id="BIMVNL31" class="pginternal">31</a>. <i>covered and kembd</i>: 'compta.' Cf. <i>kembde</i>
  in Squi. Ta. F 560.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVL37" id="BIMVNL37" class="pginternal">37</a>. <i>erthes</i>, lands; the pl. is used, to translate
  'terras.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVL41" id="BIMVNL41" class="pginternal">41</a>. <i>bonde</i>, i.e. the chain of love; see Bk. ii. Met.
  8. l. 15.</p>
<p><b>Prose 5.</b> <a href="#BIPVL1" id="BIPVNL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>borken out</i>, barked out;
  'delatraui.' MS. A. changes <i>borken</i> into <i>broken</i>. The glossaries, &amp;c., all seem to
  miss this excellent example of the strong pp. of <i>berken</i>. <i>Borken</i> appears as a pt. t.
  pl. in the King of Tars, l. 400. The A.S. pp. <i>borcen</i> appears in the A.S. Leechdoms, ed.
  Cockayne, i. 170, l. 17.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVL14" id="BIPVNL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>oo ... king.</i> The original is in
  Greek—<span class="fsn" title="heis koiranos estin, heis basileus">εἷς
  κοίρανος ἐστὶν,
  εἷς βασιλεύς</span>:
  quoted from Homer, Iliad, ii. 204, with the change from <span class="fsn" title="estô">ἔστω</span> to <span class="fsn" title="estin">ἐστίν</span>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVL18" id="BIPVNL18" class="pginternal">18, 19</a>. <i>thy citee</i>, i.e. the city of heaven; note
  the context.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVL22" id="BIPVNL22" class="pginternal">22</a>. <i>palis</i>, paling, rampart; 'uallo.' Clearer than
  <i>paleis</i>, as in A, which might mean palace; but both spellings occur in French.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVL25" id="BIPVNL25" class="pginternal">25</a>. <i>face</i> (facies), the look of this prison.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVL31" id="BIPVNL31" class="pginternal">31</a>. <i>in comune good</i>, for the common good: 'in
  commune bonum.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVL34" id="BIPVNL34" class="pginternal">34</a>. <i>thinges ... aposed</i>, accusations;
  'delatorum.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVL45" id="BIPVNL45" class="pginternal">45</a>. <i>thy wode Muse</i>: 'Musae saeuientis'; cf. Met. 5
  above, l. 22.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVL51" id="BIPVNL51" class="pginternal">51</a>. <i>thilke passiouns</i>: 'ut quae in tumorem
  perturbationibus influentibus induruerunt.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVL54" id="BIPVNL54" class="pginternal">54</a>. <i>by an esier touchinge</i> refers to the preceding
  <i>mowen ... softe</i>: 'tactu blandiore mollescant.'</p>
<p><b>Metre 6.</b> This Metre refers to the necessity of doing everything in its proper
  season.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVIL2" id="BIMVINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. 'When the sun is in Cancer'; i.e. in the month of
  June.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVIL4" id="BIMVINL4" class="pginternal">4</a>. <i>lat him gon</i>, let him go and eat acorns.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVIL6" id="BIMVINL6" class="pginternal">6</a>. <i>whan the feld</i>: 'Cùm saeuis Aquilonibus Stridens
  campus inhorruit.' <i>Chirkinge</i>, hoarse, rustling; alluding to the rustling of frozen grass in
  a high wind.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVIL15" id="BIMVINL15" class="pginternal">15</a>. <i>And forthy</i>: 'Sic quod praecipiti uiâ Certum
  deserit ordinem, Laetos non habet exitus.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 6.</b> <a href="#BIPVIL10" id="BIPVINL10" class="pginternal">10</a>. <i>by fortunous fortune</i>:
  'fortuitis casibus.' Not well expressed.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVIL14" id="BIPVINL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>the same ... thou</i>, thou didst sing the same
  thing. See Met. v. 22.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVIL17" id="BIPVINL17" class="pginternal">17</a>. <i>owh!</i> an exclamation of astonishment: Lat.
  'papae.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVIL18" id="BIPVINL18" class="pginternal">18</a>. <i>why that thou</i>: 'cur in tam salubri sententiâ
  locatus aegrotes.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVIL20" id="BIPVINL20" class="pginternal">20</a>. <i>I not ... what</i>: 'nescio, quid abesse
  coniecto.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVIL22" id="BIPVINL22" class="pginternal">22</a>. <i>with whiche governailes</i>, by what sort of
  government.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVIL28" id="BIPVINL28" class="pginternal">28</a>. <i>the strengthe</i>, the strength of the gaping
  stockade discloses an <span class="pagenum" id="page427">{427}</span>opening: 'uelut hiante ualli
  robore.' The corruption of <i>chyning</i> to <i>schynyng</i> in MS. A. makes sad nonsense of the
  passage.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVIL42" id="BIPVINL42" class="pginternal">42</a>. <i>they may nat al</i>: 'sibique totum extirpare non
  possint.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVIL55" id="BIPVINL55" class="pginternal">55</a>. <i>or elles the entree</i>: 'uel aditum
  reconciliandae sospitatis inueni.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVIL56" id="BIPVINL56" class="pginternal">56</a>. <i>For-why, for</i>, Because, since. <i>for-thy</i>,
  therefore.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVIL64" id="BIPVINL64" class="pginternal">64</a>. <i>the auctor ... of hele</i>: 'sospitatis
  auctori.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVIL65" id="BIPVINL65" class="pginternal">65</a>. <i>norisshinges</i>; perhaps better
  <i>norisshing</i>, as in Caxton and Thynne; 'fomitem,' i. e. furtherance.</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVIL71" id="BIPVINL71" class="pginternal">71</a>. <i>faster</i>, firmer, stronger: 'firmioribus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVIL76" id="BIPVINL76" class="pginternal">76</a>. <i>to maken thinne and wayk</i>: 'attenuare.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIPVIL77" id="BIPVINL77" class="pginternal">77</a>. <i>meneliche</i>, moderate: 'mediocribus.'</p>
<p><b>Metre 7.</b> <a href="#BIMVIIL1" id="BIMVIINL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>yeten a-doun</i>, pour down;
  'fundere.' Not <i>geten</i>, as in A.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVIIL2" id="BIMVIINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>trouble</i>, turbid; 'Turbidus Auster.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVIIL3" id="BIMVIINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>medleth the hete</i>: 'Misceat aestum.' See above,
  Met. iv. l. 5.</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVIIL5" id="BIMVIINL5" class="pginternal">5</a>. <i>clere as glas</i>; cf. Knight's Tale, A 1958.</p>
<p><i>withstande</i>: 'Mox resoluto Sordida caeno, Visibus obstat.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIMVIIL7" id="BIMVIINL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>royleth</i>, wanders; 'uagatur.' Not 'rolls.'</p>
<p class="sp3"><a href="#BIMVIIL11" id="BIMVIINL11" class="pginternal">11</a>. <i>holden</i>, keep to; cf. 'Hold the
  hye wey'; Truth, l. 20. <i>weyve</i>: 'Gaudia pelle, Pelle timorem; Spemque fugato.'</p>
<h2>BOOK II.</h2>
<p><b>Prose 1.</b> <a href="#BIIPIL13" id="BIIPINL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>to begyle</i>; copied in Troil.
  iv. 2, 3<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:1.90em">'—— y-thonked be Fortune,</p>
<p>That semeth trewest whan she wol bigyle.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#BIIPIL22" id="BIIPINL22" class="pginternal">22</a>. <i>myn entree</i>: 'de nostro adyto.' But Chaucer
  has translated 'adyto' as if it were 'aditu.' He translates <i>aditum</i> by <i>entree</i> in Bk.
  i. Pr. 6, l. 55. <i>Adyto</i> is 'sanctuary.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIL28" id="BIIPINL28" class="pginternal">28</a>. <i>Com</i>, i. e. let (it) come; imperative:
  'Adsit igitur rhetoricae suadela dulcedinis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIL32" id="BIIPINL32" class="pginternal">32</a>. <i>moedes</i>, moods, strains; 'modos.'
  <i>prolaciouns</i>, utterances.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIL35" id="BIIPINL35" class="pginternal">35</a>. Compare Chaucer's poem on Fortune; and see the long
  note at the beginning of the Notes to that poem.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIL45" id="BIIPINL45" class="pginternal">45</a>. <i>use hir maneres</i>; rather, make the best of her
  conduct: 'utere moribus.' <i>agrysest</i>, shudderest at, dreadest.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIL48" id="BIIPINL48" class="pginternal">48</a>. <i>She hath forsaken</i>: 'Reliquit enim te, quam
  non relicturam nemo umquam poterit esse securus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIL51" id="BIIPINL51" class="pginternal">51</a>. The MSS. usually agree in this clause. Chaucer's
  gloss is due to an obscure note in MS. C., viz. 'vel quam non relictam, secundum alios libros.'
  Other notes occur there, but do not help us.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page428">{428}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIIPIL68" id="BIIPINL68" class="pginternal">68</a>. <i>floor</i>: 'intra fortunae aream.' We say 'area'
  or 'domain.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIL77" id="BIIPINL77" class="pginternal">77</a>. <i>amonges</i>, at various times, from time to time,
  now and then; see New E. Dict., s.v. <i>Among</i>, B. 2.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIL83" id="BIIPINL83" class="pginternal">83</a>. <i>cesede</i>, would cease; copied in Troil. i.
  848<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'For if hir wheel stinte any-thing to torne,</p>
<p>Than cessed she Fortune anoon to be.'</p>
</div>
<p><b>Metre 1.</b> <a href="#BIIMIL3" id="BIIMINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>Eurype</i>, Euripus; a narrow
  channel, with a strong current; especially that between Boeotia and Euboea. This use of the word
  is here seen to be far older in English than the quotation from Holland's Pliny in the New E.
  Dict.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMIL8" id="BIIMINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>so hard</i>: 'Ultroque gemitus, dura quos fecit,
  ridet.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMIL9" id="BIIMINL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>laugheth</i>, laughs at; 'ridet.' It is impossible
  to accept the reading <i>lyssheth</i> in C. There seems to be no such word. It probably arose from
  the attempt of the scribe to represent the guttural sound of <i>gh</i>, because we actually find
  him writing <i>neysshebour</i> for <i>neighbour</i> twice, viz. in Bk. ii. Pr. 3. 24, and in Pr.
  7. 57. This passage is imitated in Troil. iv. 7: 'Than laugheth she and maketh him the mowe.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 2.</b> <a href="#BIIPIIL1" id="BIIPIINL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. Compare Chaucer's 'Fortune'; l. 25,
  &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIL4" id="BIIPIINL4" class="pginternal">4</a>. <i>every-dayes</i>, daily: 'cottidianis
  querelis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIL37" id="BIIPIINL37" class="pginternal">37</a>. <i>I torne</i>: 'Rotam uolubili orbe
  uersamus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIL39" id="BIIPIINL39" class="pginternal">39</a>. <i>Worth up</i>, climb up: 'Ascende.' Cf. P.
  Plowman, B. vii. 91; Wars of Alexander, 2878, 2973.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIL42" id="BIIPIINL42" class="pginternal">42</a>. <i>Cresus</i>, Croesus; see note to Monk. Tale, B
  3917.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIL47" id="BIIPIINL47" class="pginternal">47</a>. <i>Perciens</i>, Persians. But Chaucer is here
  wrong. The Lat. text has 'Persi regis,' i. e. king Perseus. Perseus, or Perses III, was the
  last king of Macedonia, who was defeated by L. Æmilius Paulus in a decisive battle fought near
  Pydna, in June, <span class="smaller">B.C.</span> 168. 'When brought before Æmilius [here,
  Paulus], he is said to have degraded himself by the most abject supplications; but he was treated
  with kindness by the Roman general;' Smith, Class. Dict. See Livy, xl. 57; xli. 53; xliv. 32;
  &amp;c.; Plutarch, Life of Æmilius.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIL51" id="BIIPIINL51" class="pginternal">51</a>. <i>Tragedie.</i> Cf. the definition in the Monk.
  Prol. B 3163; and note to Anelida, 320.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIL53" id="BIIPIINL53" class="pginternal">53</a>. <i>in Greke.</i> These two words are not in the
  original, but the following quotation is given in Greek: <span class="fsn" title="duo tous pithous, ton men hena kakôn,   ton de heteron kalôn">δύο τοὺς
  πίθους, τὸν μὲν
  ἕνα κακῶν, τὸν δὲ
  ἕτερον καλῶν</span>. Some MSS. add:
  'duo dolia quidem malum alterum bonum.' From Homer, Iliad, xxiv. 527:</p>
<div class="poem">
<p><span class="fsn" title="doioi gar te pithoi katakeiatai en Dios     oudei,">δοιοὶ γάρ τε
    πίθοι κατακείαται
    ἐν Διὸς οὔδει,</span></p>
<p><span class="fsn" title="dôrôn, hoia didôsi, kakôn, heteros de     eaôn.">δώρων, οἷα
    δίδωσι, κακῶν,
    ἕτερος δὲ
    ἐάων.</span></p>
</div>
<p>Cf. notes to Wyf of Bathes Prol. D 170, and to Leg. of Good Women, 195.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIL54" id="BIIPIINL54" class="pginternal">54</a>. <i>in the entree</i>: 'in Iouis limine': <span class="fsn" title="en Dios oudei">ἐν Διὸς
  οὔδει</span>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIL61" id="BIIPIINL61" class="pginternal">61</a>. <i>realme</i>: 'intra commune omnibus regnum
  locatus.'</p>
<p><b>Metre 2.</b> <a href="#BIIMIIL1" id="BIIMIINL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>hielde</i>, pour: 'Tantas fundat
  opes, nec retrahat manum Pleno copia cornu.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page429">{429}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIIMIIL8" id="BIIMIINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>as fool-large</i>, like one that is foolishly
  lavish: 'Multi prodigus auri.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMIIL11" id="BIIMIINL11" class="pginternal">11</a>. <i>other gapinges</i>: 'Alios pandit hiatus.' Some
  MSS. have <i>Altos</i>, but Chaucer evidently read <i>Alios</i>, as in MS. C.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMIIL13" id="BIIMIINL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>to any ... ende</i>; rather, 'within a
  prescribed boundary'; 'Certo fine retentent.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 3.</b> <a href="#BIIPIIIL22" id="BIIPIIINL22" class="pginternal">22</a>. <i>princes.</i> These were, in
  particular, Festus and Symmachus. Boethius married Rusticiana, the daughter of Symmachus. Hence
  the allusion to his <i>fadres-in-lawe</i> (socerorum) just below, in l. 26; where the right sense
  is <i>parents-in-law</i>. See Stewart's Essay, p. 24.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIIL23" id="BIIPIIINL23" class="pginternal">23</a>. <i>leef</i>: 'delectusque in affinitatem
  principum ciuitatis, quod pretiosissimum propinquitatis genus est, priùs carus, quam proximus esse
  coepisti.' Hence <i>the whiche thing</i> really refers back to <i>affinitee</i>, which is hardly
  obvious in the E. version.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIIL40" id="BIIPIIINL40" class="pginternal">40</a>. <i>whan thou</i>: 'cùm in Circo duorum medius
  consulum circumfusae multitudinis exspectationem triumphali largitione satiasti.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIIL43" id="BIIPIIINL43" class="pginternal">43</a>. <i>gave thou wordes</i>: 'Dedisti ... uerba
  fortunae.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIIL48" id="BIIPIIINL48" class="pginternal">48</a>. <i>privee</i>, a man of private station, not of
  noble rank: 'priuato.' The reference is to the election of his two sons as consuls in one day.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIIL55" id="BIIPIIINL55" class="pginternal">55</a>. <i>Art thou</i>: 'An tu in hanc uitae scenam
  nunc primum subitus hospesque uenisti.' Thus <i>shadwe or tabernacle</i> is meant to translate
  <i>scenam</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIIL60" id="BIIPIIINL60" class="pginternal">60</a>. <i>laste day</i>; quoted in Chaucer's 'Fortune,'
  l. 71; see note to the line.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIIL61" id="BIIPIIINL61" class="pginternal">61</a>. <i>and also</i>, i. e. even to such Fortune
  as abides and does <i>not</i> desert the man: 'fortunae ... etiam manentis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIIIL62" id="BIIPIIINL62" class="pginternal">62</a>. <i>thar recche</i>; it is absolutely necessary
  to insert <i>thee</i> after <i>thar</i>; i. e. And therefore, what, do you suppose, need you
  care? <i>yif thou</i>, i. e. whether thou.</p>
<p><b>Metre 3.</b> <a href="#BIIMIIIL10" id="BIIMIIINL10" class="pginternal">10</a>. <i>the fairnesse</i>: 'Iam
  spinis abeat decus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMIIIL13" id="BIIMIIINL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>over-whelveth</i>, turns over: 'Verso
  concitat aequore.' <i>whelveth</i> is the right form, as noted by Stratmann; it occurs in MS. Ii.
  1. 38, and in the black-letter editions. It occurs again in Palladius on Husbandry, i. 161: 'For
  harme ... may ... perchaunce the <i>overwhelve</i>,' i.e. for perhaps harm may overthrow thee. And
  again, in the same, i. 781: '<i>overwhelve</i> hit upsodowne,' i.e. turn it (the land) right
  over.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMIIIL16" id="BIIMIIINL16" class="pginternal">16</a>. <i>tomblinge</i>, fleeting, transitory;
  'caducis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMIIIL18" id="BIIMIIINL18" class="pginternal">18</a>. <i>nis</i>, is; we must disregard the second
  negative.</p>
<p><b>Prose 4.</b> <a href="#BIIPIVL3" id="BIIPIVNL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>ne be comen</i>, is not come; i.e.
  did not come. It refers to past time.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL5" id="BIIPIVNL5" class="pginternal">5</a>. <i>For in alle</i>: 'Nam in omni aduersitate fortunae
  infelicissimum genus est infortunii, fuisse felicem.' This famous sentence has been several times
  copied. See, e.g., Troil. iii. 1625-8; Dante, <i>Inferno</i>, v. 121-3; Tennyson, <i>Locksley
  Hall</i>, 76.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL8" id="BIIPIVNL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>But that thou</i>, i.e. 'but the fact that thou.'
  <i>abyest</i>, sufferest: 'falsae opinionis supplicium luis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL12" id="BIIPIVNL12" class="pginternal">12</a>. <i>For al be it</i>: 'Nam si te hoc inane nomen
  fortuitae felicitatis mouet.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page430">{430}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL20" id="BIIPIVNL20" class="pginternal">20</a>. <i>Symacus</i>, Symmachus. There were several
  distinguished men of this family. Q. Aurelius Symmachus was a statesman and author in the latter
  half of the fourth century. The one here referred to is Q. Aurelius Memmius Symmachus, who had
  been consul under Odoacer in 485, and was involved in the fate of Boethius, being put to death by
  Theodoric in 525, shortly after the execution of Boethius in 524. He had two daughters, Rusticiana
  and Galla, of whom the former married Boethius. See Procopius, de Bello Gothico, lib. i., and
  several Epistles in Cassiodorus, viz. lib. iv. epist. 22, 37, 66.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL25" id="BIIPIVNL25" class="pginternal">25</a>. <i>thy wyf</i>; i. e. Rusticiana, daughter of
  Symmachus; for there is no proof that Boethius was twice married (Stewart, p. 24). She survived
  the capture of Rome by the Goths under Totila, <span class="smaller">A.D.</span> 546. 'The riches
  of Rusticiana, the daughter of Symmachus and widow of Boethius, had been generously devoted to
  alleviate the calamities of famine. But the barbarians were exasperated by the report, that she
  had prompted the people to overthrow the statue of the great Theodoric; and the life of that
  venerable matron would have been sacrificed to his memory, if Totila had not respected her birth,
  her virtues, and even the pious motive of her revenge.'—Gibbon, Rom. Empire, ch. 43.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL31" id="BIIPIVNL31" class="pginternal">31</a>. <i>two sones</i>; the two spoken of just above
  (Pr. iii. l. 35), as being both made consuls together. This was in 522.</p>
<p><i>conseilours</i>, i.e. of consular rank: 'consulares.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL40" id="BIIPIVNL40" class="pginternal">40</a>. <i>thyne ancres</i>. Hence the line, 'Yit halt
  thyn ancre.' Fortune, l. 38.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL52" id="BIIPIVNL52" class="pginternal">52</a>. <i>thy delices</i>: 'delicias tuas.' The sense
  here intended is 'effeminacy,' or 'unmanly weakness.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL56" id="BIIPIVNL56" class="pginternal">56</a>. <i>ful anguissous</i>, very full of anxieties:
  'Anxia enim res,' &amp;c. Repeated in Troilus, iii. 816, q.v.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL68" id="BIIPIVNL68" class="pginternal">68</a>. <i>for alwey</i>, &amp;c. Very obscure. Chaucer
  seems to mean—'for always, in every man's case, there is, in something or other, that which
  (if he has not experienced it) he does not understand; or else he dreads that which he has already
  experienced.' The Latin is clearer: 'inest enim singulis, quod inexpertus ignoret, expertus
  exhorreat.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL79" id="BIIPIVNL79" class="pginternal">79</a>. <i>nothing [is] wrecched</i>. The insertion of
  <i>is</i> completes the sense: 'adeo nihil <i>est</i> miserum, nisi cùm putes.' Observe '<i>nis a
  wrecche</i>' in Chaucer's own gloss (l. 81); and see l. 25 of 'Fortune.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL83" id="BIIPIVNL83" class="pginternal">83</a>. <i>by the agreabletee</i>, by means of the
  equanimity: 'aequanimitate tolerantis.' Not having the word 'equanimity' at command, Chaucer
  paraphrases it by 'agreeabletee or egalitee,' i. e. accommodating or equable behaviour. Cf.
  l. 92.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL86" id="BIIPIVNL86" class="pginternal">86</a>. <i>The swetnesse</i>, &amp;c. Cf. Troilus, iii.
  813-5; and Man of Lawes Tale, B 421-2, and note.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL89" id="BIIPIVNL89" class="pginternal">89</a>. <i>withholden</i>, retained: 'retineri non
  possit.' <i>that</i>, so that.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL107" id="BIIPIVNL107" class="pginternal">107</a>. <i>sheweth it wel</i>, it is plain: 'manifestum
  est.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL110" id="BIIPIVNL110" class="pginternal">110</a>. <i>either he woot</i>, &amp;c.; copied in
  Troilus, iii. 820-833.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL115" id="BIIPIVNL115" class="pginternal">115</a>. <i>lest he lese that ... it</i>, lest he lose
  that which. MS. A. <i>omits</i> 'it'; but the phrase is idiomatic.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page431">{431}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL119" id="BIIPIVNL119" class="pginternal">119</a>. <i>this is to seyn that men</i>, that is to say
  that, in such a case, men, &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL120" id="BIIPIVNL120" class="pginternal">120</a>. <i>lost</i>, loss. This form of the sb. occurs
  elsewhere; as in Gower, i. 147 (goth to <i>lost</i>); and in P. Plowman, C. vii. 275; &amp;c. See
  Stratmann.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPIVL131" id="BIIPIVNL131" class="pginternal">131</a>. <i>it ne maketh</i>, it does not make men
  miserable.</p>
<p><b>Metre 4.</b> <a href="#BIIMIVL7" id="BIIMIVNL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>lause</i>, loose; Icel.
  <i>lauss</i>: 'solutae.' Usually <i>loos</i>, as in Cant. Ta. A 4064, 4352.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMIVL8" id="BIIMIVNL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>forthy if thou</i>: 'Fugiens periculosam Sortem
  sedis amoenae, Humili domum memento Certus figere saxo.' Chaucer's translation is hardly correct;
  <i>sortem</i> and <i>sedis</i> must be taken in close connection. 'Avoiding the perilous condition
  of a fair (and exposed) situation, take care to found thy house securely on a low-lying (and
  sheltered) rock.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMIVL12" id="BIIMIVNL12" class="pginternal">12</a>. <i>weleful</i>: 'Felix robore ualli Duces serenus
  aeuum.' <i>palis</i>, stockade, rampart; as before, Bk. i. Pr. 3. 56, Pr. 5. 22.</p>
<p><b>Prose 5.</b> <a href="#BIIPVL10" id="BIIPVNL10" class="pginternal">10</a>. <i>to hem that despenden it</i>;
  rather, by spending it; Lat. 'effundendo.' So again, in l. 11, <i>to thilke folke that mokeren
  it</i> answers to the Lat. gerund 'coaceruando.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL11" id="BIIPVNL11" class="pginternal">11</a>. <i>mokeren it</i>, hoard it. Perhaps related to O.F.
  <i>mucier</i>; see <i>Curmudgeon</i> in my Etym. Dict. See <i>mokereres</i>, misers, below.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL15" id="BIIPVNL15" class="pginternal">15</a>. <i>stenteth to ben had</i>, ceases to be possessed:
  'desinit possideri.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL16" id="BIIPVNL16" class="pginternal">16</a>. <i>large</i>, lavish; 'largiendi usu desinit
  possideri.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL18" id="BIIPVNL18" class="pginternal">18</a>. <i>as of that</i>, as regards that hoard.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL19" id="BIIPVNL19" class="pginternal">19</a>. <i>a voys al hool</i>, a voice not yet dispersed:
  'uox ... tota.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL32" id="BIIPVNL32" class="pginternal">32</a>. <i>yif it wanteth</i>, if it lacks: 'carens animae
  motu atque membrorum compage.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL35" id="BIIPVNL35" class="pginternal">35</a>. <i>of the laste</i>: 'postremae aliquid
  pulcritudinis.'  Perhaps it means 'of the lowest kind of beauty.' Mr. Stewart, in his Essay, p.
  225, reads <i>postremo</i>, for which I find <i>no</i> authority. MS. C. has <i>postreme</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL36" id="BIIPVNL36" class="pginternal">36</a>. <i>through the distinccioun</i>: 'suique
  distinctione.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL40" id="BIIPVNL40" class="pginternal">40</a>. <i>Why sholde it nat</i>, &amp;c. In some editions,
  this passage is not marked as being assigned to Boethius. In others, it is.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL85" id="BIIPVNL85" class="pginternal">85</a>. <i>ostelments</i>, furniture, household goods:
  'supellectilis.' O.F. <i>ostillement</i>, <i>oustillement</i>, furniture; cf. mod. F.
  <i>outil</i>, a word of doubtful origin. Cf. l. 94.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL90" id="BIIPVNL90" class="pginternal">90</a>. <i>subgit</i>; as if for 'suppositis'; but the Lat.
  text has 'sepositis,' i.e. separate, independent.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL92" id="BIIPVNL92" class="pginternal">92</a>. <i>beest</i>, animal: 'diuinum merito rationis
  animal.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL97" id="BIIPVNL97" class="pginternal">97</a>. <i>of the lowest</i>, &amp;c., 'by means of vilest
  things.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL101" id="BIIPVNL101" class="pginternal">101</a>. <i>yif that al</i>, &amp;c., 'if all the good
  possessed is more valuable than the thing possessing it.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL105" id="BIIPVNL105" class="pginternal">105</a>. <i>and certes</i>: 'quod quidem haud immerito
  cadit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL111" id="BIIPVNL111" class="pginternal">111</a>. <i>it cometh</i>: 'it arises from some defect in
  them.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL121" id="BIIPVNL121" class="pginternal">121</a>. <i>Gabbe I of this</i>, do I lie concerning
  this?</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL125" id="BIIPVNL125" class="pginternal">125</a>. <i>weneth.</i> The texts have <i>and weneth</i>;
  but I suppress <i>and</i> to <span class="pagenum" id="page432">{432}</span>make sense, and to
  make the translation agree with the Latin. 'Atqui diuitiae possidentibus persaepè nocuerunt, cùm
  pessimus quisque, eóque alieni magis auidus, quidquid usquam auri gemmarumque est, se solum qui
  habeat dignissimum putat.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL128" id="BIIPVNL128" class="pginternal">128</a>. <i>way-feringe</i>; MS. A, <i>way-faryng</i>.
  Both forms, <i>feringe</i> and <i>faring(e)</i> occur; see Stratmann. <i>Feringe</i> = A. S.
  <i>fērende</i>, from the weak verb <i>fēran</i>, to go, travel; whilst
  <i>faringe</i> = A. S. <i>farende</i>, from the strong verb <i>faran</i>, to go.
  <i>Fēran</i> (= <i>*fōrian</i>) is derived, with vowel-mutation, from the stem
  <i>*fōr</i>, appearing in <i>fōr</i>, the pt. t. of <i>faran</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVL130" id="BIIPVNL130" class="pginternal">130</a>. <i>singe</i>, &amp;c. Doubtless from Juvenal,
  Sat. x. 22; see Wyf of Bathes Tale, D 1191, and the note.</p>
<p><b>Metre 5.</b> Largely imitated in Chaucer's poem called 'The Former Age,' which see. See also
  the Notes to the same.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVL5" id="BIIMVNL5" class="pginternal">5</a>. <i>They ne coude</i>, they knew not how: 'Non Bacchica
  munera norant Liquido confundere melle.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVL6" id="BIIMVNL6" class="pginternal">6</a>. <i>piment</i>, usually spiced wine; here, wine mixed
  with honey. See Rom. of the Rose, 6027, and the note. <i>clarree</i>, wine mixed with honey and
  spices, and then strained till it is clear; clarified wine. See Rom. of the Rose, 5967, 6026;
  Former Age, 16; Kn. Tale, A 1471. Chaucer uses these two words here in conjunction, for the simple
  reason that he was thinking of the parallel passage in the French Rom. de la Rose, which is
  imitated from the present passage in Boethius. Ll. 8418-9 are<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Et de l'iaue simple bevoient</p>
<p>Sans querre <i>piment</i> ne <i>claré</i>.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#BIIMVL7" id="BIIMVNL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>ne they coude</i>: 'Nec lucida uellera Serum Tyrio
  miscere ueneno.' Hence the <i>Seriens</i> are the <i>Seres</i>, or Chinese; and <i>the venim of
  Tyrie</i> should rather be <i>the venim of Tyre</i>, but Chaucer follows the adjectival form in
  the original, both here and in Bk. iii. Met. 4, l. 2. <i>Venim</i> is not the right word here;
  'ueneno' merely means 'dye.' The reference is to the <i>murex</i> or purple shell-fish. See
  Vergil, Aen. iv. 262: '<i>Tyrio</i>que ardebat <i>murice</i> laena'; and Georg. ii. 465:
  '<i>alba</i> nec Assyrio <i>fucatur lana ueneno</i>.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVL13" id="BIIMVNL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>gest ne straungere</i>: 'hospes.' Cf. Former Age,
  21.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVL17" id="BIIMVNL17" class="pginternal">17</a>. <i>armures</i>, defensive armour: 'arma.' The usual
  reading is <i>arua</i>, i. e. fields; but more than six MSS. have <i>arma</i>, and Chaucer's
  copy had the same; as appears from MS. C.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVL18" id="BIIMVNL18" class="pginternal">18</a>. <i>For wherto</i>: 'for to what purpose, or what
  sort of madness of enemies would first take up arms, when they saw but cruel wounds (as the
  result) and no rewards for the blood that was shed?'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVL22" id="BIIMVNL22" class="pginternal">22</a>. <i>But the anguissous</i>: 'Sed saeuior ignibus
  Aetnae Feruens amor ardet habendi.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVL24" id="BIIMVNL24" class="pginternal">24</a>. <i>Allas!</i> &amp;c. Cf. Former Age, 27-32. <i>the
  gobetes or the weightes of gold</i>: 'Auri ... pondera.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVL26" id="BIIMVNL26" class="pginternal">26</a>. <i>He dalf</i>: 'Pretiosa pericula fodit.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 6.</b> <a href="#BIIPVIL8" id="BIIPVINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>the imperie of consulers</i>,
  consular rank: 'consulare <span class="pagenum" id="page433">{433}</span>imperium.' The reference
  is to the creation of Decemviri; see Livy, iii. 32.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIL20" id="BIIPVINL20" class="pginternal">20</a>. <i>so requerable</i>, in such request:
  'expetibilis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIL29" id="BIIPVINL29" class="pginternal">29</a>. <i>into the ... body</i>: 'in secreta
  quaeque.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIL32" id="BIIPVINL32" class="pginternal">32</a>. <i>the whiche I clepe</i>, by which I mean; so
  again below, l. 39.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIL35" id="BIIPVINL35" class="pginternal">35</a>. <i>a thought</i>, a mind; 'mentem firma sibi
  ratione cohaerentem.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIL36" id="BIIPVINL36" class="pginternal">36</a>. <i>a free man</i>; Anaxarchus of Abdera, <span class="smaller">B.C.</span> 323. The <i>tyraunt</i> was Nicocreon, king of Cyprus. See Valerius
  Maximus, iii. 3.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIL44" id="BIIPVINL44" class="pginternal">44</a>. <i>But what</i>: 'Quid autem est, quod in alium
  quisquam facere possit, quod sustinere ab alio ipse non possit?'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIL47" id="BIIPVINL47" class="pginternal">47</a>. <i>Busirides</i>, Busiris (gen. case,
  <i>Busiridis</i>), a king of Egypt, who sacrificed all strangers on his altars. But Hercules,
  coming to Egypt, slew him and abolished the custom. See Vergil, Georg. iii. 5; Ovid, Tr. iii. 11.
  39. In the Monkes Tale, B 3293, Chaucer calls him <i>Busirus</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIL49" id="BIIPVINL49" class="pginternal">49</a>. <i>Regulus</i>; M. Regulus, taken prisoner by the
  Carthaginians, <span class="smaller">B.C.</span> 255. The story of his embassy to Rome is well
  known.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIL63" id="BIIPVINL63" class="pginternal">63</a>. <i>may I.</i> It is necessary to insert <i>I</i>
  (only found in the black-letter editions) to complete the sense. 'Quod quidem de cunctis fortunae
  muneribus dignius existimari potest.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIL71" id="BIIPVINL71" class="pginternal">71</a>. <i>as of wil</i>, i.e. when it can: 'ultro.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIL80" id="BIIPVINL80" class="pginternal">80</a>. <i>reproeved</i>, disproved: 'redarguuntur.'</p>
<p><b>Metre 6.</b> <a href="#BIIMVIL2" id="BIIMVINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>Nero.</i> Cf. Monkes Tale, B
  3653-84.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIL4" id="BIIMVINL4" class="pginternal">4</a>. <i>his brother</i>; Britannicus, poisoned by Nero;
  Tacitus, Annal. xiii. 16; Suetonius, Nero, 33.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIL8" id="BIIMVINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>domesman</i>, judge; see Monk. Ta. B 3680, and
  note.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIL15" id="BIIMVINL15" class="pginternal">15</a>. <i>septem triones</i>, properly, the seven chief
  stars in the Lesser Bear; also sometimes used of the seven bright stars in the Greater Bear. The
  leading star in the Lesser Bear is the pole-star; and as that remains fixed in the north, the
  whole constellation came to signify the north. Hence, in the Monk. Ta. B 3657, we are told that
  Nero ruled over 'Both Est and West, South and <i>Septemtrioun</i>'; see note to that line.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIL18" id="BIIMVINL18" class="pginternal">18</a>. <i>Nothus</i>, Notus, the south wind; see below.
  <i>scorkleth</i>, scorches; MS. A has <i>scorchith</i>. The Prompt. Parv. has: 'Scorkelyn,
  <i>ustulo</i>, <i>ustillo</i>'; and 'Scorklyd, <i>ustillatus</i>.' As Mr. Bradley notes, it is a
  variant of <i>scorknen</i> or <i>scorpnen</i>. The orig. Icel. verb is <i>skorpna</i>, to become
  shrivelled, allied to <i>skorpinn</i>, shrivelled. This is a pp. form as if from <i>*skerpa</i>,
  pt. t. <i>*skarp</i>; cf. <i>skera</i>, pt. t. <i>skar</i>, pp. <i>skorinn</i>. The adj.
  <i>skarpr</i> means 'sharp,' whence the weak verb <i>skerpa</i>, to sharpen. The sense of the
  primitive verb <i>*skerpa</i> was, doubtless, 'to cut'; and <i>scorklen</i> is, lit., 'to cause to
  be cut about,' when used as a transitive verb; hence, 'to shrivel up,' from the appearance of
  plants 'cut' with frost or parched with heat.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIL21" id="BIIMVINL21" class="pginternal">21</a>. <i>Allas!</i></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Heu grauem sortem, quoties iniquus</p>
<p>Additur saeuo gladius ueneno!'</p>
</div>
<p>More correctly, 'lordshippe to venimous crueltee.' MS. C has 'gladius, i. potestas exercendi
  gladium'; and 'ueneno, i. venenose crudelitati.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page434">{434}</span></div>
<p><b>Prose 7.</b> <a href="#BIIPVIIL3" id="BIIPVIINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>I have wel desired</i>:
  'materiam gerendis rebus optauimus, quo ne uirtus tacita consenesceret.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIL10" id="BIIPVIINL10" class="pginternal">10</a>. <i>drawen to governaunce</i>: 'allicere,'
  i. e. allure (simply).</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIL18" id="BIIPVIINL18" class="pginternal">18</a>. <i>a prikke</i>, a point; cf. Parl. of Foules,
  57; Troil. v. 1815; Ho. Fame, 907. From Ptolemy, Syntaxis, lib. i. cap. 6; cf. Macrobius, In
  Somnium Scipionis, lib. ii. c. 9.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIL23" id="BIIPVIINL23" class="pginternal">23</a>. <i>Tholomee</i>, Ptolemy; viz. in the beginning
  of book ii. of his Megale Syntaxis. See the same in Pliny, Nat. Hist. ii. 68.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIL28" id="BIIPVIINL28" class="pginternal">28</a>. <i>wel unnethe</i>, scarcely, hardly at all:
  'uix angustissima inhabitandi hominibus area relinquetur.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIL34" id="BIIPVIINL34" class="pginternal">34</a>. <i>And also sette</i>: 'Adde, quod hoc ipsum
  breuis habitaculi septum plures incolunt nationes.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIL38" id="BIIPVIINL38" class="pginternal">38</a>. <i>defaute ... marchaundise</i>; Lat. only: 'tum
  conmercii insolentia.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIL41" id="BIIPVIINL41" class="pginternal">41</a>. <i>Marcus Tullius</i>, i.e. Cicero, in his
  Somnium Scipionis, which originally formed part of the sixth book of the De Republica. See cap.
  vi. of that work, and Note to Parl. Foules, 31.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIL43" id="BIIPVIINL43" class="pginternal">43</a>. <i>Caucasus</i>; mentioned again in the Wyf of
  Bathes Tale, D 1140.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIL45" id="BIIPVIINL45" class="pginternal">45</a>. <i>Parthes</i>, Parthians.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIL59" id="BIIPVIINL59" class="pginternal">59</a>. <i>hath the wrecched</i>: 'scriptorum inops
  deleuit obliuio.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIL69" id="BIIPVIINL69" class="pginternal">69</a>. <i>ended</i>: 'definitum.' We now say
  'finite.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIL73" id="BIIPVIINL73" class="pginternal">73</a>. <i>endeles</i>: 'interminabilem.' We now say
  'infinite.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIL77" id="BIIPVIINL77" class="pginternal">77</a>. <i>were thought</i>, were considered in
  comparison with eternity.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIL89" id="BIIPVIINL89" class="pginternal">89</a>. <i>This rather man</i>, this former man, the
  former.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIL95" id="BIIPVIINL95" class="pginternal">95</a>. <i>seyde</i>: 'Iam tandem, inquit, intelligis me
  esse philosophum? Tum ille nimium mordaciter, Intellexeram, inquit, si tacuisses.' This story is
  alluded to in Piers Plowman; see my note to that poem, C. xiv. 226.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIL108" id="BIIPVIINL108" class="pginternal">108</a>. <i>despyseth it</i>; cf. Troilus, v.
  1821-7.</p>
<p><b>Metre 7.</b> <a href="#BIIMVIIL1" id="BIIMVIINL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>with overthrowing thought</i>:
  'mente praecipiti.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIIL3" id="BIIMVIINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>shewinge</i>, evident, open to the view: 'Latè
  patentes ... plagas.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIIL7" id="BIIMVIINL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>dedly</i>, mortal, perishable: 'mortali
  iugo.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIIL8" id="BIIMVIINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>ferne</i>, distant: 'remotos.' This is
  important, as settling the sense of 'ferne halwes' in the Prologue to the Tales, l. 14.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIIL13" id="BIIMVIINL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>Fabricius</i>, the conqueror of Pyrrhus;
  censor in <span class="smaller">B.C.</span> 275. <i>Brutus</i>, the slayer of Cæsar.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIIL14" id="BIIMVIINL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>Catoun</i>, Cato of Utica (<span class="smaller">B.C.</span> 95-46).</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIIL17" id="BIIMVIINL17" class="pginternal">17</a>. <i>Liggeth</i>, lie ye; 'Iacetis.' The
  imperative mood.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIIL20" id="BIIMVIINL20" class="pginternal">20</a>. <i>cruel</i>; Lat. 'sera,' which Chaucer has
  taken as 'seua.' 'Cum sera uobis rapiet hoc etiam dies.' <i>thanne is</i>: 'Iam uos secunda mors
  manet.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 8.</b> <a href="#BIIPVIIIL2" id="BIIPVIIINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>untretable</i>, not to be
  treated with, intractable, inexorable: 'inexorabile.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIIL7" id="BIIPVIIINL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>unpleyten</i>, unplait, explain:
  'explicare.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIIL17" id="BIIPVIIINL17" class="pginternal">17</a>. <i>windinge.</i> Read <i>windy</i>, i.e.
  unstable; Lat. 'uentosam.' Caxton's edition has <i>wyndy</i>, which proves the point. So also
  other old black-letter editions.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page435">{435}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIIL23" id="BIIPVIIINL23" class="pginternal">23</a>. <i>aspre</i>: 'haec aspera, haec horribilis
  fortuna.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIPVIIIL26" id="BIIPVIIINL26" class="pginternal">26</a>. <i>visages</i>, faces. See Notes to the poem
  on Fortune.</p>
<p><b>Metre 8.</b> <a href="#BIIMVIIIL1" id="BIIMVIIINL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. It begins 'Quòd mundus stabile
  fide Concordes uariat uices; Quòd pugnantia semina Foedus perpetuum tenent.' The whole of this
  metre reappears in Troilus, iii. 1744-1764.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIIIL6" id="BIIMVIIINL6" class="pginternal">6</a>. <i>hath brought</i>, hath led in, introduced:
  'duxerit.'</p>
<p><i>greedy to flowen</i>; the Lat. text merely has <i>auidum</i>; 'Ut fluctus auidum mare Certo
  fine coerceat.' The Lat. <i>fluctus</i> answers to 'hise flodes.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIIIL7" id="BIIMVIIINL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>ende</i>, boundary: 'fine.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIIIL8" id="BIIMVIIINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>termes or boundes</i>, borders:
  'terminos.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIIIL10" id="BIIMVIIINL10" class="pginternal">10</a>. <i>Love</i>: 'Et caelo imperitans amor.' On
  this passage is founded one in the Knightes Tale, A 2991-3.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIMVIIIL11" id="BIIMVIIINL11" class="pginternal">11</a>. <i>slakede</i>, were to relax. The last lines
  are<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem sp3">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Et quam nunc socia fide Pulcris motibus incitant,</p>
<p>Certent soluere machinam. Hic sancto populos quoque</p>
<p>Iunctos foedere continet: Hic et coniugii sacrum</p>
<p>Castis nectit amoribus: Hic fidis etiam sua</p>
<p>Dictat iura sodalibus. O felix hominum genus,</p>
<p>Si uestros animos amor, Quo caelum regitur, regat!'</p>
</div>
<h2>BOOK III.</h2>
<p><b>Prose 1.</b> <a href="#BIIIPIL3" id="BIIIPINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>streighte</i>, pp., i.e.
  stretched; 'adrectis ... auribus.' The form <i>streight-e</i> is plural.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIL6" id="BIIIPINL6" class="pginternal">6</a>. <i>so</i>, i.e. so much. Better 'how much'; Lat.
  <i>quantum</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIL8" id="BIIIPINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>unparigal</i>, unequal; 'imparem.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIL11" id="BIIIPINL11" class="pginternal">11</a>. <i>nat only that</i>, it is not only the case
  that. It would be clearer if <i>that</i> were omitted.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIL12" id="BIIIPINL12" class="pginternal">12</a>. <i>agrisen</i>, filled with dread; pp., with short
  <i>i</i>, of <i>agrysen</i>. Cf. <i>agryseth</i>, Bk. i. Met. 6, l. 7.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIL15" id="BIIIPINL15" class="pginternal">15</a>. <i>ravisshedest</i>, didst greedily receive;
  'rapiebas.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIL32" id="BIIIPINL32" class="pginternal">32</a>. <i>for the cause of thee</i>, for thy sake; 'tui
  caussa.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIL33" id="BIIIPINL33" class="pginternal">33</a>. <i>but I wol</i>, &amp;c.; 'sed quae tibi caussa
  notior est, eam prius designare uerbis atque informare conabor.'</p>
<p><b>Metre 1.</b> <a href="#BIIIMIL2" id="BIIIMINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>hook</i>, sickle; 'falce.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIL4" id="BIIIMINL4" class="pginternal">4</a>. <i>Hony</i>; cf. Troilus, i. 638, iii. 1219.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIL6" id="BIIIMINL6" class="pginternal">6</a>. <i>Nothus</i>, Notus, the South wind. <i>ploungy</i>,
  stormy, rainy; 'imbriferos.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIL9" id="BIIIMINL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>bigin</i>, do thou begin; imperative;
  'incipe.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 2.</b> <a href="#BIIIPIIL2" id="BIIIPIINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>streite sete</i>, narrow
  (retired) seat; 'in angustam sedem.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL3" id="BIIIPIINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>cures</i>, endeavours; 'omnis mortalium
  cura.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page436">{436}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL7" id="BIIIPIINL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>over that</i>, beyond it; 'ulterius.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL8" id="BIIIPIINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>sovereyn good</i>; 'omnium summum bonorum.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL11" id="BIIIPIINL11" class="pginternal">11</a>. <i>out of ... good</i>; 'extrinsecus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL28" id="BIIIPIINL28" class="pginternal">28</a>. <i>mesuren</i>, &amp;c.; 'Plurimi uerò boni
  fructum gaudio laetitiâque metiuntur.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL34" id="BIIIPIINL34" class="pginternal">34</a>. <i>is torned</i>; a bad translation of
  'uersatur,' i.e. 'resides.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL38" id="BIIIPIINL38" class="pginternal">38</a>. <i>merinesse</i>, enjoyment; 'iocunditatis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL50" id="BIIIPIINL50" class="pginternal">50</a>. <i>for which</i>, on which account; 'quare.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL55" id="BIIIPIINL55" class="pginternal">55</a>. <i>Epicurus.</i> See Cant. Tales, Prol. 336-8,
  where this is quoted; and see Merch. Ta. E 2021; Troil. iii. 1691; 'Epicurus ... sibi summum bonum
  uoluptatem esse constituit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL57" id="BIIIPIINL57" class="pginternal">57</a>. <i>birefte awey.</i> But the Lat. text has
  precisely the opposite sense: 'quod caetera omnia iocunditatem animo uideantur adferre.' For
  <i>adferre</i> [MS. C <i>afferre</i>], Chaucer has given us the sense of <i>auferre</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL58" id="BIIIPIINL58" class="pginternal">58</a>. <i>studies</i>, i.e. endeavours; 'studia.'
  <i>corage</i>; 'animus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL59" id="BIIIPIINL59" class="pginternal">59</a>. <i>al be it</i>, &amp;c.; 'et si caligante
  memoria.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL60" id="BIIIPIINL60" class="pginternal">60</a>. <i>not</i>, knows not; 'uelut ebrius, domum quo
  tramite reuertatur, ignorat.' See Cant. Tales, A 1262.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL67" id="BIIIPIINL67" class="pginternal">67</a>. <i>that ... it</i>: 'qui quod sit optimum, id
  etiam ... putant.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL75" id="BIIIPIINL75" class="pginternal">75</a>. <i>forsake</i>, deny; 'sequestrari nequit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL77" id="BIIIPIINL77" class="pginternal">77</a>. <i>be anguissous</i>, i.e. 'be <i>neither</i>
  full of anxiety.' The <i>neither</i> is implied in the following <i>ne</i>; 'non esse anxiam
  tristemque.' It is clearer if we supply <i>nat</i>, as in the text.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL83" id="BIIIPIINL83" class="pginternal">83</a>. <i>Than is it good</i>, then it is the <i>summum
  bonum</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIL86" id="BIIIPIINL86" class="pginternal">86</a>. <i>lovinge</i>, as if translating
  <i>diligendo</i>, which occurs in many MSS.; but the better reading is 'deligendo,' i.e.
  selecting.</p>
<p><b>Metre 2.</b> <a href="#BIIIMIIL1" id="BIIIMIINL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>with slakke ... strenges</i>;
  'fidibus lentis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIIL2" id="BIIIMIINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>enclineth and flitteth</i>; 'flectat.'
  <i>flitteth</i> here means 'shifts.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIIL3" id="BIIIMIINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>purveyable</i>, with provident care;
  'prouida.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIIL6" id="BIIIMIINL6" class="pginternal">6</a>. <i>of the contre of Pene</i>; 'Poeni leones'; lions
  of North Africa, supposed to be extremely ferocious.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIIL8" id="BIIIMIINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>sturdy</i>, cruel, hard; 'trucem ...
  magistrum.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIIL13" id="BIIIMIINL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>and hir mayster</i>: 'Primusque lacer dente
  cruento Domitor rabidas imbuit iras.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIIL15" id="BIIIMIINL15" class="pginternal">15</a>. <i>Iangelinge</i>, garrulous; 'garrula.' This
  passage is imitated twice in the Cant. Tales, F 607-617, H 163-174.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIIL17" id="BIIIMIINL17" class="pginternal">17</a>. <i>pleyinge bisinesse</i>; 'ludens cura.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIIL19" id="BIIIMIINL19" class="pginternal">19</a>. <i>agreables</i>; this form of the pl. adj. is
  only used in the case of words of French origin. Examples are not very common; cf.
  <i>reverents</i> below, Bk. iii. Met. 4, l. 6; and <i>delitables</i>, C. T. F 899.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIIL26" id="BIIIMIINL26" class="pginternal">26</a>. <i>by privee path</i>, by an unseen route;
  'secreto tramite.' Alluding to the apparent passage of the sun below the horizon and, as it were,
  underneath the world. Cf. Troil. iii. 1705.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIIL27" id="BIIIMIINL27" class="pginternal">27</a>. <i>Alle thinges</i>: 'Repetunt proprios quaeque
  recursus.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 3.</b> <a href="#BIIIPIIIL1" id="BIIIPIIINL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>beestes</i>, animals;
  'animalia.' Chaucer always uses <i>beest</i> for 'animal.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page437">{437}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIIL15" id="BIIIPIIINL15" class="pginternal">15</a>. <i>fals beautee</i>, a false beauty; 'falsa
  ... beatitudinis species.' But 'species' may simply mean 'semblance.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIIL17" id="BIIIPIIINL17" class="pginternal">17</a>. After <i>axe</i>, Caxton and Thynne insert
  <i>the</i>, i.e. thee; 'te ipsum.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIIL24" id="BIIIPIIINL24" class="pginternal">24</a>. <i>thee lakked</i>: 'uel aberat quod abesse
  non uelles, uel aderat quod adesse noluisses.' This sentence much impressed Chaucer. He again
  recurs to it in the Complaint to Pite, 99-104; Parl. Foules, 90, 91; and Complaint to his Lady,
  47-49. This fact helps to prove the genuineness of the last-named poem.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIIL36" id="BIIIPIIINL36" class="pginternal">36</a>. <i>No.</i> Observe the use of <i>no</i> after
  a sentence containing <i>nis nat</i>. If there had been no negative in the preceding sentence, the
  form would have been <i>Nay</i>. Such is the usual rule.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIIL40" id="BIIIPIIINL40" class="pginternal">40</a>, <a href="#BIIIPIIIL41" id="BIIIPIIINL41" class="pginternal">41</a>. <i>maken</i>, cause, bring it about. <i>bihighten</i>, promised.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIIL48" id="BIIIPIIINL48" class="pginternal">48</a>. <i>foreyne ... pletinges</i>; 'forenses
  querimoniae.' But <i>forenses</i> means 'public.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIIL69" id="BIIIPIIINL69" class="pginternal">69</a>. <i>be fulfild ... and axe any thing</i>;
  rather paraphrastic; 'aliquid poscens opibus expletur.' <i>fulfild</i> here means 'plentifully
  supplied,' not 'completely satisfied,' whereas in the very next line it means 'completely
  satisfied.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIIL71" id="BIIIPIIINL71" class="pginternal">71</a>. <i>I holde me stille, and telle nat</i>, I say
  nothing about; 'Taceo.' Seven E. words for one of Latin.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIIIL74" id="BIIIPIIINL74" class="pginternal">74</a>. <i>what may ... be</i>, why is it; 'quid est
  quod,' &amp;c.</p>
<p><b>Metre 3.</b> <a href="#BIIIMIIIL1" id="BIIIMIIINL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. After <i>river</i>, Caxton and
  Thynne insert <i>or a gutter</i>; Lat. 'gurgite.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIIIL2" id="BIIIMIIINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>yit sholde it never</i>. This gives quite a
  false turn to the translation, and misses the sense intended. I quote the whole Metre.</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Quamuis fluente diues auri gurgite</p>
<p style="margin-left:0.70em">Non expleturas cogat auarus opes,</p>
<p>Oneretque baccis colla rubri litoris;</p>
<p style="margin-left:0.70em">Ruraque centeno scindat opima boue:</p>
<p>Nec cura mordax deserit superstitem,</p>
<p style="margin-left:0.70em">Defunctumque leues non comitantur opes.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIIIL3" id="BIIIMIIINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>rede see</i>; lit. 'red shore.' However, the
  Red Sea is alluded to. Chaucer's translation of <i>baccis</i> by 'stones' is not happy; for
  'pearls' are meant. Cf. Horace, Epod. viii. 14; Sat. ii. 3. 241. Pliny praises the pearls from the
  Red Sea; Nat. Hist. lib. xii. c. 18.</p>
<p><b>Prose 4.</b> <a href="#BIIIPIVL9" id="BIIIPIVNL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>postum</i>, short for
  <i>apostume</i>, i.e. imposthume. <i>boch</i>, botch, pustule. Lat. <i>struma</i>. Catullus is the
  well-known poet, and the allusion is to his lines addressed to himself (Carm. 52)<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Quid est, Catulle, quid moraris emori?</p>
<p>Sella in curuli struma Nonius sedet.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIVL14" id="BIIIPIVNL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>Certes, thou</i>, &amp;c. Rather involved.
  'Tu quoque num tandem tot periculis adduci potuisti, ut cum Decorato gerere magistratum putares,
  cùm in eo mentem nequissimi scurrae delatorisque respiceres?' <i>With</i> is used for <i>by</i>:
  'by so many perils' is intended. See Chaucer's gloss.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page438">{438}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIVL16" id="BIIIPIVNL16" class="pginternal">16</a>. <i>Decorat</i>, Decoratus. He seems to have been
  in high favour with king Theodoric, who wrote him a letter which is preserved in Cassiodorus, lib.
  v. 31. It is clear that Boethius thought very ill of him.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIVL32" id="BIIIPIVNL32" class="pginternal">32</a>. <i>that he is despysed</i>, i.e. <i>because</i>
  he is despised. The argument is, that a wicked man seems the more wicked when he is despised by a
  very great number of people; and if he be of high rank, his rank makes him more conspicuous, and
  therefore the more generally contemned. The MSS. vary here; perhaps the scribes did not see their
  way clearly. See the footnote.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIVL35" id="BIIIPIVNL35" class="pginternal">35</a>. <i>and ... nat unpunisshed</i>; 'Verùm non
  impunè.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIVL40" id="BIIIPIVNL40" class="pginternal">40</a>. <i>comen by</i>, arise from; 'per has umbratiles
  dignitates non posse contingere.' See Chaucer's Balade on Gentilesse, l. 5.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIVL42" id="BIIIPIVNL42" class="pginternal">42</a>. <i>many maner</i>, a mistranslation: 'Si quis
  multiplici consulatu functus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIVL46" id="BIIIPIVNL46" class="pginternal">46</a>. <i>to don his office</i>, to perform its
  function. Cf. Wyf of Bathes Tale, D 1144.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIVL50" id="BIIIPIVNL50" class="pginternal">50</a>. <i>that wenen</i>, i.e. (folk or people) who
  suppose.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIVL56" id="BIIIPIVNL56" class="pginternal">56</a>. <i>provostrie</i>, i.e. the prætorship;
  'praetura.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIVL57" id="BIIIPIVNL57" class="pginternal">57</a>. <i>rente</i>, income; 'et senatorii census
  grauis sarcina.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIVL58" id="BIIIPIVNL58" class="pginternal">58</a>. <i>the office</i>; this alludes to the
  <i>Praefectus annonae</i>, once an honourable title. It was borne by Augustus, when emperor.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIVL64" id="BIIIPIVNL64" class="pginternal">64</a>. <i>by the opinioun of usaunces</i>; 'opinione
  utentium.' Chaucer's phrase seems to mean 'by estimation of the mode in which it is used.' He
  should have written 'by the opinioun of hem that usen it.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIVL66" id="BIIIPIVNL66" class="pginternal">66</a>. <i>of hir wille</i>, of their own accord (as it
  were); 'ultro.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIVL68" id="BIIIPIVNL68" class="pginternal">68</a>. <i>what is it</i>; 'quid est, quòd in se
  expetendae pulcritudinis habeant, nedum aliis praestent?'</p>
<p><b>Metre 4.</b> Cf. Monkes Tale, B 3653-60.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIVL2" id="BIIIMIVNL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>Tirie</i>, Tyre; lit. 'Tyrian,' the adjectival
  form; 'Tyrio superbus ostro.' So above, Bk. ii. Met. 5, l. 8.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIVL3" id="BIIIMIVNL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>throf he</i>, he flourished (lit. throve);
  'uigebat.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIVL6" id="BIIIMIVNL6" class="pginternal">6</a>. <i>reverents</i>, the pl. form of the adj. See
  above, Bk. iii. Met. 2, l. 19. <i>unworshipful</i>, &amp;c.; 'indecores curules.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 5.</b> <a href="#BIIIPVL1" id="BIIIPVNL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>regnes</i>, kingdoms;
  <i>familiaritees</i>, friendships.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVL2" id="BIIIPVNL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>How elles</i>, why not? 'Quidni?' <i>whan</i>,
  whenever.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVL4" id="BIIIPVNL4" class="pginternal">4</a>. <i>kinges ben chaunged.</i> This is the subject of
  Chaucer's Monkes Tale. Examples are certainly numerous. In the time of Boethius (470-524), they
  were not wanting. Thus Basiliscus, emperor of the East, had a reign which Gibbon describes as
  'short and turbulent,' and perished miserably of hunger in 476; and Odoacer was killed by
  Theodoric in 493; see Gibbon's History.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVL13" id="BIIIPVNL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>upon thilke syde that</i>, on whichever
  side.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVL14" id="BIIIPVNL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>noun-power ... undernethe</i>; 'impotentia
  subintrat.' <i>nounpower</i>, lack of power, occurs in P. Plowman, C. xx. 292; see my note.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVL17" id="BIIIPVNL17" class="pginternal">17</a>. <i>A tyraunt</i>; Dionysius, tyrant of Syracuse,
  in Sicily, who caused <span class="pagenum" id="page439">{439}</span>a sword to be hung by a
  slender thread over the head of his favourite Damocles, to teach him that riches could not make
  happy the man whose death was imminent. See Cicero, Tuscul. v. 21. 6; Horace, Carm. iii. 1. 17;
  Persius, Sat. iii. 40. And see Ch. Kn. Tale, A 2029.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVL27" id="BIIIPVNL27" class="pginternal">27</a>. <i>seriaunts</i>, serjeants (satellite), different
  from <i>servauntes</i> (seruientium) below. The difference is one of use only; for the form
  <i>seriaunt</i>, E. <i>serjeant</i>, represents the Lat. <i>seruientem</i>, whilst
  <i>servaunt</i>, E. <i>servant</i>, represents the O. F. pres. part. of the O. F. verb
  <i>servir</i>; which comes to much about the same thing.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVL30" id="BIIIPVNL30" class="pginternal">30</a>. <i>what</i>, why; <i>what ... anything</i> answers
  to Lat. 'quid.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVL33" id="BIIIPVNL33" class="pginternal">33</a>. <i>in hool</i>, &amp;c., whether that power is
  unimpaired or lost; Lat. 'incolumis ... lapsa.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVL34" id="BIIIPVNL34" class="pginternal">34</a>. <i>Nero</i>; see note to Monkes Tale, B 3685.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVL35" id="BIIIPVNL35" class="pginternal">35</a>. <i>Antonius</i>, a mistake for <i>Antoninus</i>,
  as in the Lat. text. By Antoninus is meant the infamous emperor Caracalla, on whom Septimius
  Severus had conferred the title of Antoninus. Papinianus was a celebrated Roman jurist, who was
  put to death at the command of Caracalla; see Gibbon, Roman Empire, ch. vi.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVL39" id="BIIIPVNL39" class="pginternal">39</a>. <i>Senek</i>, Seneca; see Tacitus, Annal. xiv.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVL41" id="BIIIPVNL41" class="pginternal">41</a>. <i>But whan</i>; 'Sed dum ruituros moles ipsa
  trahit, neuter, quod uoluit, effecit.' I.e. neither Papinian nor Seneca found it possible to
  forego their position.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVL48" id="BIIIPVNL48" class="pginternal">48</a>. <i>Certes, swiche folk</i>; see Monkes Ta. B
  3434-5.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVL50" id="BIIIPVNL50" class="pginternal">50</a>. <i>pestilence</i>; see Merch. Ta. E. 1784, and
  1793-4.</p>
