<p><b>Metre 5.</b> <a href="#BIIIMVL1" id="BIIIMVNL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. For <i>corage</i>, Caxton and Thynne
  have <i>corages</i>, but this may be an alteration due to the Latin which they quote as a heading:
  'Qui se uolet esse potentem, <i>Animos</i>,' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMVL5" id="BIIIMVNL5" class="pginternal">5</a>. <i>Tyle</i>; 'ultima Thule.' Supposed to be Iceland,
  or one of the Shetland Islands.</p>
<p><b>Prose 6.</b> <a href="#BIIIPVIL3" id="BIIIPVINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>tragedies</i>; see note to Cant.
  Ta. B 3163.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVIL3" class="pginternal">3, 4</a>. <i>O glorie.</i> The original has: <span class="fsn" title="ô doxa doxa myrioisi dê brotôn, ouden   gegôsi bioton ônkôsas megan">ὦ δόξα
  δόξα μυρίοισι δὴ
  βροτῶν, ὀυδὲν
  γεγῶσι βίοτον
  ὤγκωσας μέγαν</span>. See
  Euripides, Andromache, 319. For this, MS. C. gives, as the Latin equivalent—'o gloria,
  gloria, in milibus hominum nichil aliud facta nisi auribus inflatio magna'; an interpretation
  which Chaucer here follows.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVIL24" id="BIIIPVINL24" class="pginternal">24</a>. <i>gentilesse.</i> See remarks (in the notes) on
  Chaucer's Balade of Gentilesse.</p>
<p><b>Metre 6.</b> <a href="#BIIIMVIL8" id="BIIIMVINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>For yif thou loke your</i>; the
  change from <i>thy</i> to <i>your</i> is due to the Latin: 'Si promordia <i>uestra</i> Auctoremque
  Deum <i>spectes</i>.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMVIL9" id="BIIIMVINL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>forlived</i>, degenerate; 'degener.' In Prose 6
  (above), l. 37, <i>outrayen or forliven</i> translates 'degenerent.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 7.</b> <a href="#BIIIPVIIL1" id="BIIIPVIINL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>delices</i>; 'uoluptatibus.'
  The MSS. so confuse the words <i>delices</i> and <i>delyts</i> that it is hardly possible to say
  which is meant, except when the Lat. text has <i>deliciae</i>. Both E. words seem to correspond to
  <i>uoluptates</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVIIL12" id="BIIIPVIINL12" class="pginternal">12</a>. <i>Iolitee</i>: intended to translate
  'lasciuiam,' a reading of some <span class="pagenum" id="page440">{440}</span>MSS.; MS. C. has
  this reading, glossed 'voluptatem.' Most MSS. read <i>lacunam</i>, i.e. void, want. <i>were</i>,
  would be; 'foret.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVIIL14" id="BIIIPVIINL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>that children</i>: 'nescio quem filios
  inuenisse tortores.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVIIL15" id="BIIIPVIINL15" class="pginternal">15</a>. <i>bytinge</i>; 'mordax.' <i>anguissous</i>:
  'anxium.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVIIL16" id="BIIIPVIINL16" class="pginternal">16</a>. <i>or</i>, ere; in fact, Caxton has
  <i>ere</i>, and Thynne, <i>er</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVIIL18" id="BIIIPVIINL18" class="pginternal">18</a>. <i>Euripidis</i>; in the gen. case, as in the
  Lat. text. The reference is to Euripides, Andromache, 418: <span class="fsn" title="pasi d' anthrôpois ar' ên psychê, tekn';   hostis d' aut' apeiros ôn psegei, hêsson   men algei, dystychôn d' eudaimonei">πᾶσι δ'
  ἀνθρώποις ἄρ' ἦν
  ψυχὴ, τεκν'· ὅστις
  δ' ἄυτ' ἄπειρος ὢν
  ψέγει, ἧσσον μὲν
  ἀλγεῖ, δυστυχῶν
  δ' ἐυδαιμονεῖ</span>.</p>
<p><b>Metre 7.</b> <a href="#BIIIMVIIL3" id="BIIIMVIINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>he fleeth</i>: 'Fugit et nimis
  tenaci Ferit icta corda morsu.' As to the use of <i>flyes</i> for 'bees,' see note to Parl.
  Foules, 353.</p>
<p><b>Prose 8.</b> <a href="#BIIIPVIIIL1" id="BIIIPVIIINL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>that thise weyes</i>: 'quin
  hae ad beatitudinem uiae deuiae quaedam sint.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVIIIL8" id="BIIIPVIIINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>supplien</i>, supplicate, beg: 'danti
  supplicabis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVIIIL11" id="BIIIPVIIINL11" class="pginternal">11</a>. <i>awaytes</i>, snares: 'subiectorum
  insidiis obnoxius periculis subiacebis.' <i>anoyously</i>; a mistranslation of 'obnoxius,'; see
  above.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVIIIL12" id="BIIIPVIIINL12" class="pginternal">12</a>. <i>destrat</i>, distracted:
  'distractus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVIIIL16" id="BIIIPVIIINL16" class="pginternal">16</a>. <i>brotel</i>, brittle, frail:
  'fragilissimae.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPVIIIL28" id="BIIIPVIIINL28" class="pginternal">28</a>. <i>of the somer-sesoun</i>: 'uernalium.' So
  elsewhere, <i>somer-sesoun</i> really means the spring. Cf. P. Plowman, line 1.</p>
<p><i>Aristotle.</i> The reference is not known; but the belief was common. It is highly probable
  that the fable about the lynx's sharp sight arose from a confusion with the sharp sight of
  Lynceus; and it is Lynceus who is really meant in the present passage; 'Lynceis oculis.' Cf.
  Horace, Sat. i. 2. 90:</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:2.45em">—'ne corporis optima Lyncei</p>
<p>Contemplere oculis.'</p>
</div>
<p><b>Metre 8.</b> <a href="#BIIIMVIIIL5" id="BIIIMVIIINL5" class="pginternal">5</a>. <i>ginnes</i>, snares:
  'laqueos.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMVIIIL7" id="BIIIMVIIINL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>Tyrene</i>; 'Tyrrhena ... uada'; see Vergil,
  Aen. i. 67.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMVIIIL14" id="BIIIMVIIINL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>echines</i>: 'uel asperis Praestent
  echinis litora.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 9.</b> <a href="#BIIIPIXL10" id="BIIIPIXNL10" class="pginternal">10</a>. <i>thorugh a litel clifte</i>:
  'rimulâ.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIXL14" id="BIIIPIXNL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>misledeth it and transporteth</i>:
  'traducit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIXL16" id="BIIIPIXNL16" class="pginternal">16</a>. <i>Wenest thou</i>: 'An tu arbitraris, quod
  nihilo indigeat, egere potentia?'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIXL38" id="BIIIPIXNL38" class="pginternal">38</a>. <i>Consider</i>: 'Considera uero, ne, quod
  nihilo indigere, quod potentissimum, quod honore dignissimum esse concessum est, egere
  claritudine, quam sibi praestare non possit, atque ob id aliqua ex parte uideatur abiectius.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIXL53" id="BIIIPIXNL53" class="pginternal">53</a>. <i>This is a consequence</i>: 'Consequitur.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIXL69" id="BIIIPIXNL69" class="pginternal">69</a>. <i>they ne geten hem</i>: 'nec portionem, quae
  nulla est, nec ipsam, quam minimè affectat, assequitur.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIXL77" id="BIIIPIXNL77" class="pginternal">77</a>. <i>that power forleteth</i>: 'ei, quem ualentia
  deserit, quem molestia pungit, quem uilitas abicit, quem recondit obscuritas.' Hence <i>that</i>
  means 'whom,' and refers to the man.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIXL95" id="BIIIPIXNL95" class="pginternal">95</a>. <i>that shal he not finde.</i> This is turned
  into the affirmative instead of the interrogative form: 'sed num in his eam reperiet, quae
  demonstrauimus, id quod pollicentur, non posse conferre?'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page441">{441}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIXL119" id="BIIIPIXNL119" class="pginternal">119</a>. <i>norie</i>, pupil; Lat. 'alumne.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIXL136" id="BIIIPIXNL136" class="pginternal">136</a>. <i>that lyen</i>: 'quae autem beatitudinem
  mentiantur.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPIXL142" id="BIIIPIXNL142" class="pginternal">142</a>. <i>in Timeo</i>; 'uti in Timaeo Platoni.'
  Here Chaucer keeps the words <i>in Timaeo</i> without alteration, as if they formed the title of
  Plato's work. The passage is: <span class="fsn" title="all' ô Sôkrates, touto ge dê pantes   hosoi kai kata brachy sôphrosynês   metechousin epi pasê hormê kai smikrou   kai megalou pragmatos theon aei pou   kalousin">ἀλλ' ὦ
  Σώκρατες, τοῦτό
  γε δὴ πάντες
  ὅσοι καὶ κατὰ
  βραχύ σωφροσύνης
  μετέχουσιν ἐπὶ
  πάσῃ ὁρμῇ καὶ
  σμικροῦ καὶ
  μεγάλου
  πράγματος θεὸν
  ἀεί που καλοῦσιν</span>
  (27 C).</p>
<p><b>Metre 9.</b> <a href="#BIIIMIXL3" id="BIIIMIXNL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>from sin that age hadde
  biginninge</i>, since the world began: 'ab aeuo.'  <i>thou that dwellest</i>: cf. Kn. Tale, A
  3004.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIXL5" id="BIIIMIXNL5" class="pginternal">5</a>. <i>necesseden</i>, compelled, as by necessity:
  'pepulerunt.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIXL6" id="BIIIMIXNL6" class="pginternal">6</a>. <i>floteringe matere</i>: 'materiae fluitantis';
  see below, Pr. xi. 156.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIXL8" id="BIIIMIXNL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>beringe</i>, &amp;c.; see Leg. of Good Women,
  2229, and note.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIXL13" id="BIIIMIXNL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>Thou bindest</i>: 'Tu numeris elementa
  ligas.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIXL14" id="BIIIMIXNL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>colde.</i> Alluding to the old doctrine of
  the four elements, with their qualities. Thus the nature of fire was thought to be <i>hot</i> and
  <i>dry</i>, that of water <i>cold</i> and <i>moist</i>, that of air <i>cold</i> and <i>dry</i>,
  that of earth <i>hot</i> and <i>moist</i>. Cf. Ovid, Met. i. 19<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Frigida pugnabant calidis, humentia siccis,</p>
<p>Mollia cum duris, sine pondere habentia pondus.</p>
<p>Hanc Deus et melior litem Natura diremit ...</p>
<p>Dissociata locis concordi pace ligauit.'</p>
</div>
<p>Sometimes the four elements are represented as lying in four layers; the earth at the bottom,
  and above it the water, the air, and the fire, in due order. This arrangement is here alluded to.
  Cf. Kn. Ta. A 2992.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIXL18" id="BIIIMIXNL18" class="pginternal">18</a>. <i>Thou knittest</i>, &amp;c.</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Tu triplicis mediam naturae cuncta mouentem</p>
<p>Connectens animam per consona membra resoluis.</p>
<p>Quae cum secta duos motum glomerauit in orbes,</p>
<p>In semet reditura meat mentemque profundam</p>
<p>Circuit, et simili conuertit imagine caelum.</p>
<p>Tu caussis animas paribus uitasque minores</p>
<p>Prouehis, et leuibus sublimes curribus aptans</p>
<p>In caelum terramque seris, quas lege benigna</p>
<p>Ad te conuersas reduci facis igne reuerti.</p>
<p>Da pater angustam menti conscendere sedem,</p>
<p>Da fontem lustrare boni, da luce reperta</p>
<p>In te conspicuos animi defigere uisus.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIXL24" id="BIIIMIXNL24" class="pginternal">24</a>. <i>cartes</i>, vehicles; the bodies which
  contain the souls.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMIXL34" id="BIIIMIXNL34" class="pginternal">34</a>. <i>berer</i>: 'uector, dux, semita, terminus
  idem.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 10.</b> <a href="#BIIIPXL8" id="BIIIPXNL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>for that veyn</i>, in order that
  vain, &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXL11" id="BIIIPXNL11" class="pginternal">11</a>. <i>ne is</i>, exists. We should now drop the
  negative after 'deny.' <i>nis right as</i>, is precisely as.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXL12" id="BIIIPXNL12" class="pginternal">12</a>. <i>is proeved</i>: 'id imminutione perfecti
  imperfectum esse perhibetur.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page442">{442}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXL14" id="BIIIPXNL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>in every thing general</i>: 'in quolibet
  genere.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXL21" id="BIIIPXNL21" class="pginternal">21</a>. <i>descendeth</i>: 'in haec extrema atque effeta
  dilabitur.' Cf. Kn. Ta. 3003-10.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXL31" id="BIIIPXNL31" class="pginternal">31, 2</a>. <i>that nothing nis bettre</i>, i.e. than whom
  nothing is better. So below (l. 70) we have—'that nothing nis more worth.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXL32" id="BIIIPXNL32" class="pginternal">32</a>. <i>nis good</i>, is good. The <i>ne</i> is due to
  the preceding 'douted.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXL39" id="BIIIPXNL39" class="pginternal">39</a>. <i>for as moche</i>: 'ne in infinitum ratio
  procedat.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXL51" id="BIIIPXNL51" class="pginternal">51</a>. <i>this prince</i>; Caxton and Thynne have <i>the
  fader</i>; Lat. 'patrem.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXL62" id="BIIIPXNL62" class="pginternal">62</a>. <i>feigne</i>: 'fingat qui potest.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXL88" id="BIIIPXNL88" class="pginternal">88</a>. <i>thanne ne may</i>: 'quare neutrum poterit esse
  perfectum, cum alterutri alterum deest.' Thus we must read <i>may</i> (sing.), not <i>mowen</i>
  (pl.).</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXL98" id="BIIIPXNL98" class="pginternal">98</a>. <i>Upon thise thinges</i>, besides this: 'Super
  haec.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXL100" id="BIIIPXNL100" class="pginternal">100</a>. <i>porismes</i>: '<span class="fsn" title="porismata">πορίσματα</span>'; corollaries, or
  deductions from a foregoing demonstration.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXL101" id="BIIIPXNL101" class="pginternal">101</a>. <i>as a corollarie</i>: 'ueluti corollarium.'
  <i>Corollary</i> is derived from <i>corolla</i>, dimin. of <i>corona</i>, a garland. It meant
  money paid for a garland of flowers; hence, a gift, present, gratuity; and finally, an additional
  inference from a proposition. Chaucer gives the explanation <i>mede of coroune</i>, i.e. gift of a
  garland.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXL106" id="BIIIPXNL106" class="pginternal">106</a>. <i>they ben maked iust</i>: these four words
  must be added to make sense; it is plain that they were lost by the inadvertence of the scribes.
  Lat. text: 'Sed uti iustitiae adeptione <i>iusti</i>, sapientiae sapientes fiunt, ita diuinitatem
  adeptos, Deos fieri simili ratione necesse est.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXL165" id="BIIIPXNL165" class="pginternal">165</a>. <i>the soverein fyn</i>; Lat. text: 'ut summa,
  cardo, atque caussa.' Chaucer seems to have taken <i>summa</i> to be the superl. adjective; and
  <i>fyn</i>, i.e. end, is meant to represent <i>cardo</i>.</p>
<p><b>Metre 10.</b> <a href="#BIIIMXL8" id="BIIIMXNL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>Tagus</i>; the well-known river
  flowing by Toledo and Lisbon, once celebrated for its golden sands; see Ovid, Am. i. 15. 34; Met.
  ii. 251, &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXL10" id="BIIIMXNL10" class="pginternal">10</a>. <i>Hermus</i>, an auriferous river of Lydia, into
  which flowed the still more celebrated Pactolus. 'Auro turbidus Hermus;' Verg. Georg. ii. 137.</p>
<p><i>rede brinke</i>: 'rutilante ripa.'</p>
<p><i>Indus</i>; now the Sind, in N. W. India.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXL11" id="BIIIMXNL11" class="pginternal">11</a>. <i>that medleth</i>: 'candidis miscens uirides
  lapillos'; which Chaucer explains as mingling <i>smaragdes</i> (emeralds) with <i>margaretes</i>
  (pearls); see footnote on p. 80.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXL17" id="BIIIMXNL17" class="pginternal">17</a>. <i>that eschueth</i>: 'Vitat obscuras animae
  ruinas.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 11.</b> <a href="#BIIIPXIL3" id="BIIIPXINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>How mochel</i>; i.e. at what
  price will you appraise it: 'quanti aestimabis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIL24" id="BIIIPXINL24" class="pginternal">24</a>. <i>The thinges thanne</i>: 'Quae igitur, cùm
  discrepant, minimè bona sunt; cùm uero unum esse coeperint, bona fiunt: nonne haec ut bona sint,
  unitatis fieri adeptione contingit?'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIL55" id="BIIIPXINL55" class="pginternal">55</a>. <i>non other</i>; i.e. no other conclusion:
  'minimè aliud uidetur.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIL63" id="BIIIPXINL63" class="pginternal">63</a>. <i>travaileth him</i>, endeavours: 'tueri
  salutem laborat.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIL71" id="BIIIPXINL71" class="pginternal">71</a>. <i>thar thee nat doute</i>, thou needst not
  doubt.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page443">{443}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIL81" id="BIIIPXINL81" class="pginternal">81</a>. <i>What woltow</i>: 'Quid, quod omnes, uelut in
  terras ore demerso trahunt alimenta radicibus, ac per medullas robur corticemque diffundunt?'
  (<i>maryes</i>, marrows.)</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIL91" id="BIIIPXINL91" class="pginternal">91</a>. <i>renovelen and puplisshen hem</i>:
  'propagentur.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIL92" id="BIIIPXINL92" class="pginternal">92</a>. <i>that they ne ben</i>, that they are; the
  superfluous <i>ne</i> is due to the <i>ne</i> preceding.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIL110" id="BIIIPXINL110" class="pginternal">110</a>. <i>But fyr</i>: 'Ignis uero omnem refugit
  sectionem.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIL112" id="BIIIPXINL112" class="pginternal">112</a>. <i>wilful</i>: 'de uoluntariis animae
  cognoscentis motibus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIL123" id="BIIIPXINL123" class="pginternal">123</a>. <i>som-tyme</i>: 'gignendi opus ... interdum
  coërcet uoluntas.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIL128" id="BIIIPXINL128" class="pginternal">128</a>. <i>And thus</i>: 'Adeò haec sui caritas.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIL142" id="BIIIPXINL142" class="pginternal">142</a>. <i>for yif that that oon</i>: 'hoc enim
  sublato, nec esse quidem cuiquam permanebit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIL156" id="BIIIPXINL156" class="pginternal">156</a>. <i>floteren</i>, fluctuate, waver;
  'fluitabunt'; see above, Met. ix. 6.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIL161" id="BIIIPXINL161" class="pginternal">161</a>. <i>for thou hast</i>: 'ipsam enim mediae
  ueritatis notam mente fixisti.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIL163" id="BIIIPXINL163" class="pginternal">163</a>. <i>in that</i>, in that thing which: 'in hoc
  ... quod.'</p>
<p><b>Metre 11.</b> <a href="#BIIIMXIL2" id="BIIIMXINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>mis-weyes</i>, by-paths:
  'nullis ... deuiis.'</p>
<p><i>rollen and trenden</i>: 'reuoluat.' Chaucer here uses the causal verb <i>trenden</i>, to
  revolve, answering to an A.S. form <i>*trendan</i>, causal of a lost verb <i>*trindan</i>. The E.
  <i>trund-le</i> is from the same strong verb (pp. <i>*getrunden</i>).</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Longosque in orbem cogat inflectens motus,</p>
<p>Animumque doceat quidquid extra molitur</p>
<p>Suis retrusum possidere thesauris.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIL7" id="BIIIMXINL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. Cf. Troilus, iv. 200.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIL8" id="BIIIMXINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>lighten</i>, i.e. shine: 'Lucebit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIL10" id="BIIIMXINL10" class="pginternal">10</a>. <i>Glosa.</i> This gloss is an alternative
  paraphrase of all that precedes, from the beginning of the Metre.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIL32" id="BIIIMXINL32" class="pginternal">32</a>. <i>Plato</i>. From Plato's Phaedo, where
  Socrates says: <span class="fsn" title="hoti hêmin hê mathêsis ouk allo ti ê   anamnêsis tynchanei ousa">ὅτι ἡμῖν ἡ
  μάθησις ὀυκ
  ἄλλο τι ἢ
  ἀνάμνησις
  τυγχάνει οὖσα</span> (72
  E).</p>
<p><b>Prose 12.</b> <a href="#BIIIPXIIL18" id="BIIIPXIINL18" class="pginternal">18</a>. <i>Wendest</i>, didst ween:
  'Mundum, inquit, hunc â Deo regi paullo antè minimè dubitandum putabas.' Surely Chaucer has quite
  mistaken the construction. He should rather have said: 'Thou wendest, quod she, a litel her-biforn
  that men ne sholden nat doute,' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL19" id="BIIIPXIINL19" class="pginternal">19</a>. <i>nis governed</i>, is governed; the same
  construction as before. So also <i>but-yif there nere</i> = unless there were (l. 25).</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL28" id="BIIIPXIINL28" class="pginternal">28</a>. <i>yif ther ne were</i>: 'nisi unus esset, qui
  quod nexuit contineret.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL30" id="BIIIPXIINL30" class="pginternal">30</a>. <i>bringe forth</i>, bring about, dispose,
  arrange: 'disponeret.'</p>
<p><i>so ordenee</i>: 'tam dispositos motus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL38" id="BIIIPXIINL38" class="pginternal">38</a>. <i>that thou</i>: 'ut felicitatis compos,
  patriam sospes reuisas.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL55" id="BIIIPXIINL55" class="pginternal">55</a>. <i>a keye and a stere</i>: 'ueluti quidam
  clauus atque gubernaculum.' Here Chaucer unluckily translates <i>clauus</i> as if it were
  <i>clauis</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL63" id="BIIIPXIINL63" class="pginternal">63</a>. <i>ne sheweth</i>: 'non minùs ad contuendum
  patet'; i.e. is equally plain to be seen.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL67" id="BIIIPXIINL67" class="pginternal">67</a>. <i>by the keye</i>: 'bonitatis clauo'; see
  note to l. 55.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL73" id="BIIIPXIINL73" class="pginternal">73</a>. <i>It mot nedes be so</i>: 'Ita, inquam,
  necesse est; nec beatum <span class="pagenum" id="page444">{444}</span>regimen esse uideretur, si
  quidem detrectantium iugum foret, non obtemperantium salus.' The translation has here gone
  wrong.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL87" id="BIIIPXIINL87" class="pginternal">87</a>. <i>softely</i>, gently, pleasurably:
  'suauiter.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL91" id="BIIIPXIINL91" class="pginternal">91</a>. <i>so at the laste</i>: 'ut tandem aliquando
  stultitiam magna <i>lacerantem</i> sui pudeat.' Another common reading is <i>latrantem</i>, but
  this was evidently not the reading in Chaucer's copy; MS. C. has <i>lacerantem</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL97" id="BIIIPXIINL97" class="pginternal">97</a>. <i>the poetes.</i> See Ovid, Met. i. 151-162;
  Vergil, Georg. i. 277-283.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL116" id="BIIIPXIINL116" class="pginternal">116</a>. <i>Scornest thou me</i>: 'Ludisne, inquam,
  me, inextricabilem labyrinthum rationibus texens, quae nunc quidem, qua egrediaris, introeas; nunc
  uerò qua introieris, egrediare; an mirabilem quemdam diuinae simplicitatis orbem complicas?'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL117" id="BIIIPXIINL117" class="pginternal">117</a>. <i>the hous of Dedalus</i>; used to
  translate 'labyrinthum.' See Vergil, Aen. vi. 24-30, v. 588. No doubt Boethius borrowed the word
  <i>inextricabilis</i> from Aen. vi. 27.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL125" id="BIIIPXIINL125" class="pginternal">125</a>. <i>for which</i>: 'ex quo neminem beatum
  fore, nisi qui pariter Deus esset, quasi munusculum dabas.' Here <i>munusculum</i> refers to
  <i>corollarium</i>, which Chaucer translates by 'a mede of coroune'; see above, Pr. x. 101.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL132" id="BIIIPXIINL132" class="pginternal">132</a>. <i>by the governements</i>: 'bonitatis
  gubernaculis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL135" id="BIIIPXIINL135" class="pginternal">135</a>. <i>by proeves in cercles and hoomlich
  knowen</i>: 'atque haec nullis extrinsecus sumptis, sed altero ex altero fidem trahente insitis
  domesticisque probationibus.' Chaucer inserts <i>in cercles and</i>, by way of reference to
  arguments drawn from circles; but the chief argument of this character really occurs later, viz.
  in Bk. iv. Pr. vi. 81.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL143" id="BIIIPXIINL143" class="pginternal">143</a>. <i>Parmenides</i>, a Greek philosopher who,
  according to Plato, accompanied Zeno to Athens, where he became acquainted with Socrates, who was
  then but a young man. Plato, in his Sophistes, quotes the line of Parmenides which is here
  referred to: <span class="fsn" title="pantothen eukyklou sphairas enalinkion   onkô">πάντοθεν
  ἐυκύκλου
  σφαίρας ἐναλίγκιον
  ὄγκῳ</span>. This the MSS. explain to mean: 'rerum orbem mobilem rotat,
  dum se immobilem ipsa conseruat.' The Greek quotation is corruptly given in the MSS., but is
  restored by consulting Plato's text (244 E); hence we do not know what reading Boethius adopted.
  It can hardly have been the one here given, which signifies that God is 'like the mass of a sphere
  that is well-rounded on all sides.' Perhaps he took the idea of God's immobility from the next two
  verses<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p><span class="fsn" title="messothen isopales pantê, to gar oute ti     meizon">μεσσόθεν
    ἰσοπαλὲς πάντη,
    τὸ γὰρ ὄυτε τι
    μεῖζον</span></p>
<p><span class="fsn" title="oute bebaioteron pelei.">οὔτε
    βεβαίοτερον
    πέλει.</span></p>
</div>
<p>i.e. 'equidistant from the centre in all directions; for there is nothing greater (than Him),
  and nothing more immoveable.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIPXIIL152" id="BIIIPXIINL152" class="pginternal">152</a>. <i>Plato.</i> From Plato's Timaeus, 29 B:
  <span class="fsn" title="hôs ara tous logous hônper eisin   exêgêtai, toutôn autôn kai syngeneis   ontas">ὡς ἄρα τοὺς
  λόγους ὧνπερ
  ἐισὶν ἐξηγηταί,
  τούτων ἀυτῶν καὶ
  συγγενεῖς
  ὄντας</span>. Chaucer quotes this saying twice; see Cant. Tales, A
  741-2, H 207-210.</p>
<p><b>Metre 12.</b> <a href="#BIIIMXIIL3" id="BIIIMXIINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>Orpheus.</i> This well-known
  story is well told in Vergil, Georg. iv. 454-527; and in Ovid, Met. x. 1-85.</p>
<p><i>Trace</i>, Thrace; as in Cant. Ta. A 1972.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page445">{445}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIIL4" id="BIIIMXIINL4" class="pginternal">4</a>. <i>weeply</i>, tearful, sorrowful:
  'flebilibus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIIL5" id="BIIIMXIINL5" class="pginternal">5</a>. <i>moevable</i> should precede <i>riveres</i>;
  'Silvas currere, mobiles Amnes stare coegerat.' Chaucer took these two lines separately.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIIL12" id="BIIIMXIINL12" class="pginternal">12</a>. <i>hevene goddes</i>, gods of heaven:
  'superos.'</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Illic blanda sonantibus Chordis carmina temperans</p>
<p>Quicquid praecipuis deae Matris fontibus hauserat,</p>
<p>Quod luctus dabat impotens, Quod luctum geminans amor</p>
<p>Deflet Taenara commouens, Et dulci ueniam prece</p>
<p>Umbrarum dominos rogat.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIIL16" id="BIIIMXIINL16" class="pginternal">16</a>. <i>laved out</i>, drawn up (as from a well).
  The M. E. <i>laven</i>, to draw up water, to pour out, is from the A. S. <i>lafian</i>, to pour;
  for which see Cockayne's A. S. Leechdoms, ii. 124, ii. 74, iii. 48. It is further illustrated in
  my Etym. Dict., s. v. <i>Lavish</i>, its derivative. No doubt it was frequently confused with F.
  <i>laver</i>, to wash; but it is an independent Teutonic word, allied to G. <i>laben</i>. In E.
  Friesic we find <i>lafen sük</i> or <i>laven sük</i>, to refresh oneself. It is curious that it
  appears even in so late an author as Dryden, who translates Lat. <i>egerit</i> (Ovid, Met. xi.
  488) by <i>laves</i>, i.e. bales out. And see <i>laven</i> in Mätzner.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIIL16" class="pginternal">16</a>. <i>Calliope.</i> Orpheus was son of Oeagrus, king of Thrace, and
  of Calliope, chief of the Muses; cf. Ovid, Ibis, 484.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIIL17" id="BIIIMXIINL17" class="pginternal">17</a>. <i>and he song.</i> This does not very well
  translate the Latin text; see note to l. 12.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIIL21" id="BIIIMXIINL21" class="pginternal">21</a>. <i>of relesinge</i>: 'ueniam'; i.e. for the
  release (of Eurydice).</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIIL22" id="BIIIMXIINL22" class="pginternal">22</a>. <i>Cerberus</i>, the three-headed dog; cf.
  Verg. Georg. iv. 483; Aen. vi. 417; Ovid, Met. iv. 449.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIIL23" id="BIIIMXIINL23" class="pginternal">23</a>. <i>Furies</i>; the Eumenides; cf. Verg. Georg.
  iv. 483; Ovid, Met. x. 46.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIIL26" id="BIIIMXIINL26" class="pginternal">26</a>. <i>Ixion</i>, who was fastened to an
  ever-revolving wheel; see Georg. iv. 484; iii. 38; Ovid, Met. iv. 460.</p>
<p><i>overthrowinge</i>, turning over: 'Non Ixionium caput Velox praecipitat rota.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIIL27" id="BIIIMXIINL27" class="pginternal">27</a>. <i>Tantalus</i>, tormented by perpetual
  thirst; Ovid, Met. x. 41; iv. 457.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIIL29" id="BIIIMXIINL29" class="pginternal">29</a>. <i>Tityus</i>: 'Vultur dum satur est modis Non
  traxit Tityi iecur.' Cf. Verg. Aen. vi. 595-600; Ovid, Met. iv. 456. And see Troilus, i.
  786-8.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIIL34" id="BIIIMXIINL34" class="pginternal">34</a>. <i>But we wol</i>: 'Sed lex dona
  coërceat.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIIL37" id="BIIIMXIINL37" class="pginternal">37</a>. <i>But what</i>; quoted in Kn. Tale, A
  1164.</p>
<p><a href="#BIIIMXIIL42" id="BIIIMXIINL42" class="pginternal">42</a>. <i>and was deed</i>: 'occidit.' The common
  story does not involve the immediate death of Orpheus.</p>
<p class="sp3"><a href="#BIIIMXIIL49" id="BIIIMXIINL49" class="pginternal">49</a>. <i>loketh</i>, beholds: 'uidet
  inferos.' The story of Orpheus is excellently told in King Alfred's translation of Boethius, cap.
  xxxv. §6.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page446">{446}</span></div>
<h2>BOOK IV.</h2>
<p><b>Prose 1.</b> <a href="#BIVPIL5" id="BIVPINL5" class="pginternal">5</a>. <i>forbrak</i>, broke off, interrupted:
  'abrupi.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIL14" id="BIVPINL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>so as</i>, seeing that, since: 'cùm.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIL25" id="BIVPINL25" class="pginternal">25</a>. <i>alle thinges may</i>, is omnipotent: 'potentis
  omnia.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIL27" id="BIVPINL27" class="pginternal">27</a>. <i>an enbasshinge ... ende</i>: 'infiniti
  stuporis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIL30" id="BIVPINL30" class="pginternal">30</a>. <i>right ordenee</i>, well ordered: 'dispositissima
  domo.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIL32" id="BIVPINL32" class="pginternal">32</a>. <i>heried</i>, praised. This resembles the language
  of St. Paul; 2 Tim. ii. 20.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIL41" id="BIVPINL41" class="pginternal">41</a>. <i>cesen</i>, cause to cease: 'sopitis
  querelis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIL45" id="BIVPINL45" class="pginternal">45</a>. <i>alle thinges</i>, all things being treated of:
  'decursis omnibus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIL47" id="BIVPINL47" class="pginternal">47</a>. <i>fetheres</i>, wings; 'pennas.' The A. S. pl.
  <i>fethera</i> sometimes means wings.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIL50" id="BIVPINL50" class="pginternal">50</a>. <i>sledes</i>, sleds, i. e. sledges:
  'uehiculis.' The Vulgate version of 1 Chron. xx. 3 has: 'et fecit super eos tribulas, et
  <i>trahas</i>, et ferrata carpenta transire.' Wycliffe translates <i>trahas</i> by <i>sledis</i>
  (later version, <i>sleddis</i>).</p>
<p><b>Metre 1.</b> <a href="#BIVMIL2" id="BIVMINL2" class="pginternal">2-5</a>. Quoted in Ho. Fame, 973-8.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIL5" id="BIVMINL5" class="pginternal">5</a>. <i>fyr</i>, fire. In the old astronomy, the region of
  air was supposed to be surrounded by a region of fire, which Boethius here says was caused by the
  swift motion of the ether: 'Quique agili motu calet aetheris Transcendit ignis uerticem.' Beyond
  this region were the planetary spheres, viz. those of the moon, Mercury, Venus, the sun, Mars,
  Jupiter, and Saturn. This explains the allusion to the passage of Thought (Imagination) through
  'the houses that bear the stars' (i. e. planets), in Latin <i>astriferas domos</i>, and so,
  past the sun, to the seventh sphere of Saturn. After this, Thought soars to the eighth sphere,
  called the Sphere of the Fixed Stars (denoted below by 'the circle of the stars' or 'the
  firmament'); and after 'wending on the back of it,' i. e. getting beyond it, reaches the
  <i>primum mobile</i>, where 'the lord of kings holds the sceptre of his might.'</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Donec in astriferas surgat domos,</p>
<p style="margin-left:0.70em">Phoeboque coniungat uias,</p>
<p>Aut comitetur iter gelidi senis</p>
<p style="margin-left:0.70em">Miles corusci sideris;</p>
<p>Vel quocunque micans nox pingitur,</p>
<p style="margin-left:0.70em">Recurrat astri circulum,</p>
<p>Atque ubi iam exhausti fuerit satis,</p>
<p style="margin-left:0.70em">Polum relinquit extimum,</p>
<p>Dorsaque uelocis premat aetheris</p>
<p style="margin-left:0.70em">Compos uerendi luminis.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#BIVMIL9" id="BIVMINL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>Saturnus</i>, the planet Saturn; which Chaucer
  rightly gives as the sense of 'senis.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page447">{447}</span></div>
<p><i>and he y-maked</i>, i.e. and he (Thought) becomes a knight. I hesitate to insert <i>is</i>
  after <i>he</i>, because all the authorities omit it; in fact, the phrase <i>and he y-maked</i>
  seems to be equivalent to 'he being made.' I do not understand what is meant by 'Miles corusci
  sideris,' unless it means that Boethius imagines Thought to become a companion of Mars, and thus
  to be made a soldier, in the service of that bright planet.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIL15" id="BIVMINL15" class="pginternal">15</a>. <i>images of sterres</i>, i.e. constellations, which
  were fancifully supposed to represent various objects.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIL18" id="BIVMINL18" class="pginternal">18</a>. <i>worshipful light.</i> MS. A has <i>dredefulle
  clerenesse</i>. Both are translations of 'uerendi luminis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIL22" id="BIVMINL22" class="pginternal">22</a>. <i>swifte cart</i>: 'uolucrem currum.' <i>Cart</i>
  is sometimes used for car or chariot.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIL25" id="BIVMINL25" class="pginternal">25</a>. <i>but now</i>, &amp;c. These words are supposed to
  be spoken by Boethius, when he remembers all the truth. 'Haec dices, memini, patria est mihi.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIL26" id="BIVMINL26" class="pginternal">26</a>. <i>heer wol I fastne my degree</i>: 'hic sistam
  gradum.' The sense is rather, 'here will I [<i>or</i>, let me] fix my step,' or 'plant my foot';
  i.e. remain. Cf. 'Siste gradum,' i. e. stop; Verg. Aen. vi. 465.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIL27" id="BIVMINL27" class="pginternal">27</a>. <i>But yif</i>:</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Quod si terrarum placeat tibi</p>
<p style="margin-left:0.70em">Noctem relictam uisere,</p>
<p>Quos miseri toruos populi timent</p>
<p style="margin-left:0.70em">Cernes tyrannos exules.'</p>
</div>
<p><b>Prose 2.</b> <a href="#BIVPIIL1" id="BIVPIINL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>owh</i>, an exclamation;
  'Papae.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIL13" id="BIVPIINL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>fey</i>, the faith, the certainty: 'fides.'
  <i>sentence</i>, opinion.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIL31" id="BIVPIINL31" class="pginternal">31</a>. <i>And in that</i>: 'Quod uero quisque potest.'
  <i>may</i>, can do.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIL38" id="BIVPIINL38" class="pginternal">38</a>. <i>lad</i>, led; <i>studies</i>, desires: 'quae
  diuersis studiis agitur.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIL71" id="BIVPIINL71" class="pginternal">71</a>. <i>Yif that</i>: 'Etsi coniecto, inquam, quid
  uelis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIL84" id="BIVPIINL84" class="pginternal">84</a>. <i>knit forth</i>: 'Contexe, inquam, cetera.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIL93" id="BIVPIINL93" class="pginternal">93</a>. <i>shewinge</i>, evident; <i>is open and
  shewinge</i>: 'patet.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIL97" id="BIVPIINL97" class="pginternal">97</a>. <i>Iugement.</i> Evidently meant to translate
  <i>iudicium</i>. But Chaucer misread his text, which has <i>indicium</i>. 'Idque, ut medici
  sperare solent, indicium est erectae iam resistentisque naturae.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIL103" id="BIVPIINL103" class="pginternal">103</a>. <i>ledeth hem</i>, i. e. leads them to:
  'qui ne ad hoc quidem peruenire queunt, ad quod eos naturalis ducit, ac pene compellit,
  intentio.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIL104" id="BIVPIINL104" class="pginternal">104</a>. <i>And what</i>: 'Et quid? si hoc tam magno ac
  pene inuicto praeeuntis naturae desererentur auxilio?'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIL112" id="BIVPIINL112" class="pginternal">112</a>. <i>Ne shrewes</i>: 'Neque enim leuia aut
  ludicra praemia petunt, quae consequi atque obtinere non possunt.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIL120" id="BIVPIINL120" class="pginternal">120</a>. <i>laye</i>, might lie (subjunctive): 'quo
  nihil ulterius peruium iaceret incessui.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIL137" id="BIVPIINL137" class="pginternal">137</a>. <i>for to ben</i>, even to exist. So below,
  <i>ben</i> frequently means 'to exist,' as appears from the argument.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIL151" id="BIVPIINL151" class="pginternal">151</a>. <i>mowen</i>, have power to act: 'possunt.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIL161" id="BIVPIINL161" class="pginternal">161</a>. <i>understonde</i>, mayest understand: 'ut
  intelligas.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page448">{448}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIL187" id="BIVPIINL187" class="pginternal">187</a>. <i>Plato</i>, viz. in the Gorgias and
  Alcibiades I, where many of the arguments here used may be found.</p>
<p><b>Metre 2.</b> The subject of this metre is from Plato, De Republica, x. Chaucer's translation
  begins with the 7th line of the Latin.</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Quos uides sedere celsos Solii culmine reges,</p>
<p>Purpura claros nitente, Septos tristibus armis,</p>
<p>Ore toruo comminantes, Rabie cordis anhelos,</p>
<p>Detrahat si quis superbis Vani tegmina cultus,</p>
<p>Iam uidebit intus arctas Dominos ferre catenas.</p>
<p>Hinc enim libido uersat Auidis corda uenenis;</p>
<p>Hinc flagellat ira mentem Fluctus turbida tollens,</p>
<p>Moeror aut captos fatigat, Aut spes lubrica torquet.</p>
<p>Ergo, cum caput tot unum Cernas ferre tyrannos,</p>
<p>Non facit, quod optat, ipse Dominis pressus iniquis.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#BIVMIIL12" id="BIVMIINL12" class="pginternal">12</a>. <i>tyrannyes.</i> This reading (in C ed.) gives
  the sense better than the reading <i>tyrauntis</i> (in A); although the latter is quite
  literal.</p>
<p><b>Prose 3.</b> <a href="#BIVPIIIL7" id="BIVPIIINL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>stadie</i>, race-course: 'in
  stadio'; which Chaucer explains by 'furlong.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIIL10" id="BIVPIIINL10" class="pginternal">10</a>. <i>purposed</i>, equivalent to <i>proposed</i>;
  'praemium commune propositum.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIIL14" id="BIVPIIINL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>For which thing</i>: 'quare probos mores sua
  praemia non relinquunt.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIIL25" id="BIVPIIINL25" class="pginternal">25</a>, <a href="#BIVPIIIL26" id="BIVPIIINL26" class="pginternal">26</a>.
  <i>so as</i>, whereas. <i>for men</i>, because men.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIIL27" id="BIVPIIINL27" class="pginternal">27</a>. <i>part-les</i>, without his share of: 'praemii
  ... expertem.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIIL35" id="BIVPIIINL35" class="pginternal">35</a>. <i>no day</i>: 'quod nullus deterat dies.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIIL39" id="BIVPIIINL39" class="pginternal">39</a>. <i>undepartable</i>, inseparable: 'inseparabili
  poena.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIIL49" id="BIVPIIINL49" class="pginternal">49</a>. <i>may it semen</i>: 'possuntne sibi supplicii
  expertes uideri, quos omnium malorum extrema nequitia non afficit modò, verumetiam uehementer
  inficit?'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIIIL70" id="BIVPIIINL70" class="pginternal">70</a>. <i>under</i>, beneath, below: 'infra hominis
  meritum.'</p>
<p><b>Metre 3.</b> <a href="#BIVMIIIL1" id="BIVMIIINL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>aryvede</i>, cause to arrive,
  drove: 'appulit.'</p>
<p><i>the sailes</i>: 'Vela Neritii ducis;' Chaucer inserts <i>Ulixes</i>, i. e. Ulysses. The
  phrase is from Ovid: 'Dux quoque Neritius,' i. e. Ulysses; Fasti, iv. 69. Neritos was a
  mountain of Ithaca, the island of Ulysses. MS. C. reads <i>Naricii</i>, which accounts for the
  form <i>Narice</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIIIL3" id="BIVMIIINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>Circes</i>, Circe, as in Ho. Fame, 1272;
  inserted by Chaucer.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIIIL7" id="BIVMIIINL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>that oon of hem</i>: 'Hunc apri facies
  tegit.'—'One of them, his face is covered,' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIIIL9" id="BIVMIIINL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>Marmorike</i>: 'Marmaricus leo.' This refers to
  the country of Barca, on the N. African coast, to the W. of Egypt.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIIIL13" id="BIVMIIINL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>But al-be-it</i>: 'Sed licet uariis modis
  Numen Arcadis alitis Obsitum miserans ducens Peste soluerit hospitis.' <i>Arcas ales</i>, the
  winged Arcadian, i. e. Mercury, because born on the Arcadian mountain Cyllene.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIIIL16" id="BIVMIIINL16" class="pginternal">16</a>. <i>algates</i>, at any rate; <i>by this</i>,
  already.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIIIL19" id="BIVMIIINL19" class="pginternal">19</a>. <i>akornes of okes</i>; this is not tautology,
  for an <i>acorn</i> was, originally, any fruit of the field, as the etymology (from <i>acre</i>)
  shews.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page449">{449}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIVMIIIL23" id="BIVMIIINL23" class="pginternal">23</a>. <i>over-light</i>, too light, too feeble: 'O
  leuem nimium manum, Nec potentia gramina, Membra quae ualeant licet, Corda uertere non
  ualent.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIIIL32" id="BIVMIIINL32" class="pginternal">32</a>. <i>for vyces</i>: 'Dira, quae penitus meant, Nec
  nocentia corpori Mentis uulnere saeuiunt.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 4.</b> <a href="#BIVPIVL2" id="BIVPIVNL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>ne I ne see nat</i>: 'nec iniuria
  dici uideo uitiosos, tametsi humani corporis speciem seruent, in belluas tamen animorum qualitate
  mutari.' Chaucer's 'as by right' should rather be 'as by wrong.' It means 'I do not see that it is
  wrongly said.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL4" id="BIVPIVNL4" class="pginternal">4, 5</a>. <i>But I nolde</i>, but I would rather that it
  were not so with regard to evil men: 'eis licere noluissem.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL18" id="BIVPIVNL18" class="pginternal">18</a>. <i>to mowen don</i>, to be able to do:
  'potuisse.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL22" id="BIVPIVNL22" class="pginternal">22</a>. <i>three</i>, i. e. the triple misfortune of
  <i>wishing</i> to do evil, of <i>being able</i> to do it, and of <i>doing</i> it.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL26" id="BIVPIVNL26" class="pginternal">26</a>. <i>thilke unselinesse</i>: 'hoc infortunio';
  i. e. the ability to sin.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL28" id="BIVPIVNL28" class="pginternal">28</a>. <i>So shullen</i>: 'Carebunt, inquit, ocius, quàm
  uel tu forsitan uelis, uel illi sese existiment esse carituros.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL30" id="BIVPIVNL30" class="pginternal">30</a>. <i>For ther</i>: 'Neque enim est aliquid in tam
  breuibus uitae metis ita serum, quod exspectare longum immortalis praesertim animus putet.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL39" id="BIVPIVNL39" class="pginternal">39</a>. <i>by the outtereste</i>: 'eorum malitiam ... mors
  extrema finiret.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL42" id="BIVPIVNL42" class="pginternal">42</a>. <i>ben perdurable</i>, i. e. to exist
  eternally: 'infinitam liquet esse miseriam, quam constat esse aeternam.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL51" id="BIVPIVNL51" class="pginternal">51</a>. <i>ther is not why</i>, there is no reason
  why.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL54" id="BIVPIVNL54" class="pginternal">54</a>. <i>but of the thinges</i>: 'sed ex his, quae
  sumpta sunt, aeque est necessarium.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL64" id="BIVPIVNL64" class="pginternal">64</a>. <i>but I understande</i>: 'sed alio quodam modo
  infeliciores esse improbos arbitror impunitos, tametsi nulla ratio correctionis, nullus respectus
  habeatur exempli.' Thus 'non ensaumple of lokinge' is wrong; it should rather be 'non lokinge of
  ensaumple,' i. e. no regard to the example thus set.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL90" id="BIVPIVNL90" class="pginternal">90</a>. <i>which defaute</i>: 'quam iniquitatis merito
  malum esse confessus es.' Hence 'for the deserte of felonye' means 'when we consider what
  wickedness deserves.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL102" id="BIVPIVNL102" class="pginternal">102</a>. <i>to leten</i>, to leave: 'nullane animarum
  supplicia ... relinquis?'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL132" id="BIVPIVNL132" class="pginternal">132</a>. <i>briddes</i>, i. e. owls. See Parl.
  Foules, 599.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL142" id="BIVPIVNL142" class="pginternal">142</a>. <i>right as thou</i>: 'ueluti si uicibus
  sordidam humum caelumque respicias, cunctis extra cessantibus, ipsa cernendi ratione nunc coeno
  nunc sideribus interesse uidearis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL153" id="BIVPIVNL153" class="pginternal">153</a>. Wrong. It should rather run: 'sholde we wene
  that <i>we</i> were blinde?' Lat. 'num uidentes eadem caecos putaremus?'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL193" id="BIVPIVNL193" class="pginternal">193</a>. <i>in al</i>, altogether: 'tota,' sc. opera
  defensorum.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL197" id="BIVPIVNL197" class="pginternal">197, 8</a>. <i>at any clifte</i>: 'aliqua rimula.'</p>
<p><i>sawen</i>, if they should perceive: 'uiderent.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL200" id="BIVPIVNL200" class="pginternal">200</a>. <i>right for</i>: 'compensatione adipiscendae
  probitatis.' Hence <i>for to geten hem</i> means 'of obtaining for themselves.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPIVL205" id="BIVPIVNL205" class="pginternal">205</a>. <i>y-leten</i>, left: 'nullus prorsus odio
  locus relinquatur.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page450">{450}</span></div>
<p><b>Metre 4.</b> <a href="#BIVMIVL1" id="BIVMIVNL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>What delyteth you</i>, Why does it
  delight you? 'Quid tantos iuuat excitare motus?'</p>
<p>Lines <a href="#BIVMIVL8" id="BIVMIVNL8" class="pginternal">8-10</a> are put interrogatively in the Latin
  text.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIVL9" id="BIVMIVNL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>and wilnen</i>: 'Alternisque uolunt perire
  telis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMIVL10" id="BIVMIVNL10" class="pginternal">10</a>. <i>But the resoun</i>: 'Non est iusta satis
  saeuitiae ratio.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 5.</b> <a href="#BIVPVL9" id="BIVPVNL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>y-shad</i>, shed, spread abroad:
  'transfunditur.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVL20" id="BIVPVNL20" class="pginternal">20</a>. <i>hepeth</i>: 'Nunc stuporem meum Deus rector
  exaggerat.'</p>
<p><b>Metre 5.</b> The Latin text begins thus:—</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Si quis Arcturi sidera nescit</p>
<p>Propinqua summo cardine labi,</p>
<p>Cur legat tardus plaustra Boötes,</p>
<p>Mergatque seras aequore flammas,</p>
<p>Cum nimis celeres explicet ortus,</p>
<p>Legem stupebit aetheris alti.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#BIVMVL1" id="BIVMVNL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>sterres of Arcture</i>, the stars of the
  constellation Arcturus. Arcturus was (as here) another name for Boötes, though it properly meant
  the brightest star in that constellation. It is at no great distance from the north pole, and so
  appears to revolve round it. The passage, which is somewhat obscure, seems to refer to the manner
  of the rising and setting of Boötes; and the argument is, that a person ignorant of astronomy,
  must be puzzled to understand the laws that rule the motions of the sky.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVL3" id="BIVMVNL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>the sterre</i>, the constellation. Chaucer uses
  <i>sterre</i> in this sense in several passages; see Kn. Tale, A 2059, 2061, and the notes.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVL8" id="BIVMVNL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>the fulle mone.</i> This alludes to an eclipse of
  the moon, as appears from below.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVL9" id="BIVMVNL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>infect</i>: 'Infecta metis noctis opacae.'</p>
<p><i>confuse</i>, confounded, overcome; the light of the moon disappears in a full eclipse,
  rendering the stars brighter.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVL11" id="BIVMVNL11" class="pginternal">11</a>. <i>The comune errour</i>: 'Commouet gentes publicus
  error.' The people who do not understand an eclipse, are excited by it; they bring out basins, and
  beat them with a loud din, to frighten away the spirit that is preying on the moon. Chaucer calls
  them <i>Corybantes</i>, but these were the priests of Cybele. Still, they celebrated her rites to
  the sound of noisy music; and he may have been thinking of a passage in Ovid, Fasti, iv. 207-14.
  C. adds a gloss: 'i. vulgaris error, quo putatur luna incantari.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVL12" id="BIVMVNL12" class="pginternal">12</a>. <i>thikke strokes</i>, frequent strokes. The word
  resembles <i>thilke</i> in C., because <i>lk</i> is not unfrequently written for <i>kk</i> in the
  fifteenth century, to the confusion of some editors; see my paper on Ghost-words, in the Philol.
  Soc. Trans. 1886, p. 370.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVL18" id="BIVMVNL18" class="pginternal">18</a>. <i>by quakinge flodes</i>: 'frementi ...
  fluctu.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVL23" id="BIVMVNL23" class="pginternal">23</a>. <i>alle thinges</i>: 'Cuncta, quae rara prouehit
  aetas.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVL24" id="BIVMVNL24" class="pginternal">24</a>. <i>troubly errour</i>: 'nubilus error.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 6.</b> <a href="#BIVPVIL9" id="BIVPVINL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>laven it</i>, to exhaust the
  subject: 'cui uix exhausti quidquam satis sit.' As to <i>lave</i>, see note to Bk. iii. Met.
  12-16.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page451">{451}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL13" id="BIVPVINL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>Ydre</i>, Hydra; see note below to Met. 7. The
  form is due to <i>hydrae</i> (MS. <i>hydre</i>) in the Latin text.</p>
<p><i>Ne ther ... ende</i>: 'nec ullus fuerit modus.' <i>Manere</i> is not the sense of
  <i>modus</i> here; it rather means <i>ende</i> or 'limit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL14" id="BIVPVINL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>but-yif</i>: 'nisi quis eas uiuacissimo mentis
  igne coërceat.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL24" id="BIVPVINL24" class="pginternal">24, 5</a>. <i>But althogh</i>: 'Quòd si te musici carminis
  oblectamenta delectant, hanc oportet paullisper differas uoluptatem, dum nexas sibi ordine contexo
  rationes.' This is said, because this 'Prose' is of unusual length. For <i>sibi</i>, another
  reading is <i>tibi</i>; hence Chaucer's 'weve <i>to thee</i> resouns.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL30" id="BIVPVINL30" class="pginternal">30</a>. <i>muable</i>, mutable, changeable: 'mutabilium
  naturarum.' Cf. Kn. Tale, A 2994-3015.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL33" id="BIVPVINL33" class="pginternal">33</a>. <i>in the tour</i>: 'Haec in suae simplicitatis
  arce composita, multiplicem rebus gerendis modum statuit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL48" id="BIVPVINL48" class="pginternal">48</a>. <i>but destinee</i>: 'fatum uero singula digerit
  in motum, locis, formis, ac temporibus distributa.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL59" id="BIVPVINL59" class="pginternal">59</a>. <i>and ledeth</i>: 'et quod simpliciter
  praesentarieque prospexit, per temporales ordines ducit.' Cf. Troilus, i. 1065-9.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL67" id="BIVPVINL67" class="pginternal">67</a>. <i>by some sowle</i>; glossed 'anima mundi.' This
  idea is from Plato, De Legibus, bk. x: <span class="fsn" title="psychên dê dioikousan kai enoikousan en   hapasi tois pantê kinoumenois môn ou kai   ton ouranon anankê dioikein phanai">ψυχὴν δὴ
  διοικοῦσαν καὶ
  ἐνοικοῦσαν ἐν
  ἅπασι τοῖς πάντῃ
  κινουμένοις μῶν
  ὀυ καὶ τὸν
  ὀυρανὸν ἀνάγκη
  διοικεῖν φάναι</span>;
  (896 D).</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL68" id="BIVPVINL68" class="pginternal">68</a>. <i>by the celestial</i>, &amp;c.; alluding to the
  old astrology.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL81" id="BIVPVINL81" class="pginternal">81</a>. <i>a same centre</i>; i.e. concentric circles, as
  on a target.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL87" id="BIVPVINL87" class="pginternal">87</a>. <i>and yif ther be</i>: 'si quid uero illi se
  medio connectat et societ, in simplicitatem cogitur, diffundique ac diffluere cessat.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL93" id="BIVPVINL93" class="pginternal">93</a>. <i>laus</i>, loose; from Icel. <i>lauss</i>. Also
  spelt <i>loos</i>, <i>los</i>. <i>it axeth</i>: 'quantò illum rerum cardinem uicinius petit.' Thus
  <i>it axeth</i> is due to 'petit,' i.e. seeks, tends to.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL97" id="BIVPVINL97" class="pginternal">97</a>. <i>Thanne right swich</i>: 'Igitur uti est ad
  intellectum ratiocinatio; ad id quod est, id quod gignitur; ad aeternitatem tempus; ad puncti
  medium circulus: ita est fati series mobilis ad prouidentiae stabilem simplicitatem.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL108" id="BIVPVINL108" class="pginternal">108</a>. <i>whan they passen</i>: 'cùm ...
  proficiscantur.' Thus <i>whan</i> should rather be <i>so as</i>, i.e. whereas, because.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL112" id="BIVPVINL112" class="pginternal">112</a>. <i>unable to ben ybowed</i>: 'indeclinabilem
  caussarum ordinem promat.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL114" id="BIVPVINL114" class="pginternal">114</a>. <i>sholden fleten</i>: 'res ... temerè
  fluituras.'</p>
<p><i>For which it is</i>: 'Quo fit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL116" id="BIVPVINL116" class="pginternal">116</a>. <i>natheles</i>: 'nihilominus tamen suus modus
  ad bonum dirigens cuncta disponat.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL121" id="BIVPVINL121" class="pginternal">121</a>. <i>ne the ordre</i>: 'ne dum ordo de summi boni
  cardine proficiscens, a suo quoquam deflectat exordio.' MS. C. has 'deflectatur.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL123" id="BIVPVINL123" class="pginternal">123</a>. 'Quae uero, inquies, potest ulla iniquior esse
  confusio.' For 'iniquior,' MS. C. has the extraordinary reading 'inquiescior,' which Chaucer seems
  to have tried to translate.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL138" id="BIVPVINL138" class="pginternal">138</a>. <i>Ne it ne is nat</i>: 'Non enim dissimile est
  miraculum nescienti.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL145" id="BIVPVINL145" class="pginternal">145</a>. <i>hele of corages</i>: 'animorum salus.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page452">{452}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL148" id="BIVPVINL148" class="pginternal">148</a>. <i>lecher</i>, i.e. leech-er, healer:
  'medicator mentium Deus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL151" id="BIVPVINL151" class="pginternal">151</a>. <i>leneth hem</i>, gives them: 'quod conuenire
  nouit, accommodat.' Printed <i>leueth</i> in Dr. Furnivall's print of MS. C., but <i>leneth</i> in
  Morris's edition of MS. A. There is no doubt as to the right reading, because <i>accommodare</i>
  and <i>lenen</i> are both used in the sense 'to lend.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL154" id="BIVPVINL154" class="pginternal">154</a>. <i>for to constreine</i>: 'ut pauca ...
  perstringam,' i.e. 'to touch lightly on a few things.' Chaucer has taken it too literally, but his
  paraphrase is nearly right.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL157" id="BIVPVINL157" class="pginternal">157</a>. <i>right kepinge</i>: 'aequi
  seruantissimum.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL159" id="BIVPVINL159" class="pginternal">159</a>. <i>my familer</i>: 'familiaris noster Lucanus.'
  Alluding to the famous line:—'Victrix caussa deis placuit, sed uicta Catoni'; Pharsalia, i.
  128.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL168" id="BIVPVINL168" class="pginternal">168</a>. <i>with-holden</i>, retain: 'retinere
  fortunam.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL176" id="BIVPVINL176" class="pginternal">176</a>. <i>by me</i>, by my means, by my help: 'Nam ut
  quidam me quoque excellentior ait.' This looks like a slip on the part of Boethius himself, for
  the supposed speaker is Philosophy herself. The philosopher here alluded to still remains unknown.
  MS. C. has 'me quidem'; and 'me' is glossed by 'philosophus per me.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL177" id="BIVPVINL177" class="pginternal">177</a>. <i>in Grek.</i> Some MSS. have: <span class="fsn" title="andros hierou sôma dynameis oikodomousi">ἀνδρὸς
  ἱεροῦ σῶμα
  δυνάμεις
  ὀικοδομοῦσι</span>. There are
  various readings, but Chaucer had before him only the interpretation: 'Viri sacri corpus
  aedificauerunt uirtutes.' Such is the reading in MS. C.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL179" id="BIVPVINL179" class="pginternal">179</a>. <i>taken</i>, delivered, entrusted. 'Fit autem
  saepe, uti bonis summa rerum gerenda deferatur.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL182" id="BIVPVINL182" class="pginternal">182</a>. <i>remordeth</i>: 'remordet,' i.e. plagues,
  troubles.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL186" id="BIVPVINL186" class="pginternal">186</a>. <i>And other folk</i>: 'Alii plus aequo
  metuunt, quod ferre possunt.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL201" id="BIVPVINL201" class="pginternal">201</a>. <i>of wikkede merite</i>: 'eos male meritos
  omnes existimant.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL206" id="BIVPVINL206" class="pginternal">206</a>. <i>serven to shrewes</i>: 'famulari saepe
  improbis.' <i>I trowe</i>: 'illud etiam dispensari credo.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL207" id="BIVPVINL207" class="pginternal">207, 8</a>. <i>overthrowinge to yvel</i>:
  'praeceps.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL209" id="BIVPVINL209" class="pginternal">209</a>. <i>egren him</i>: 'eum ... exacerbare
  possit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL219" id="BIVPVINL219" class="pginternal">219</a>. <i>shal be cause</i>: 'ut exercitii bonis, et
  malis esset caussa supplicii.' Hence <i>continuacion</i> seems to mean 'endurance' or
  'continuance.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL242" id="BIVPVINL242" class="pginternal">242</a>. <i>sin that</i>: the original is in Greek, with
  (in MS. C.) the false gloss:—'fortissimus in mundo Deus omnia regit.' The Greek
  is—<span class="fsn" title="Argaleon de me tauta theon hôs pant'   agoreuein">Ἀργαλέον δέ
  με ταῦτα θεὸν ὣς
  πάντ' ἀγορεύειν</span>.
  From Homer, Il. xii. 176, with the change from <span class="fsn" title="agoreusai">ἀγορεῦσαι</span> to <span class="fsn" title="agoreuein">ἀγορεύειν</span>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL247" id="BIVPVINL247" class="pginternal">247</a>. <i>with-holden</i>, to retain, keep, maintain;
  'retinere.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL253" id="BIVPVINL253" class="pginternal">253</a>. <i>ben outrageous or haboundant</i>:
  'abundare.' Hence <i>outrageous</i> is 'superfluous' or 'excessive.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIL257" id="BIVPVINL257" class="pginternal">257</a>. <i>and whan</i>: 'quo refectus, firmior in
  ulteriora contendas.'</p>
<p><b>Metre 6.</b> <a href="#BIVMVIL1" id="BIVMVINL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. 'Si uis celsi iura tonantis Pura
  sollers cernere mente, Adspice summi culmina caeli'; &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIL5" id="BIVMVINL5" class="pginternal">5</a>. <i>cercle</i>: 'Non Sol ... Gelidum Phoebes impedit
  axem.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIL6" id="BIVMVINL6" class="pginternal">6</a>. <i>Ne the sterre</i>: 'Nec quae summo uertice mundi
  Flectit rapidos Ursa meatus, Numquam occiduo lota profundo, Cetera cernens sidera mergi, Cupit
  Oceano tingere flammas.' Hence <i>deyen</i> is to dye, to dip.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page453">{453}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIL10" id="BIVMVINL10" class="pginternal">10</a>. <i>Hesperus</i>, the evening-star; <i>Lucifer</i>,
  the morning-star.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIL13" id="BIVMVINL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>And thus</i>: 'Sic aeternos reficit cursus
  Alternus amor; sic astrigeris Bellum discors exsulat oris. Haec concordia temperat aequis Elementa
  modis, ut pugnantia Vicibus cedant humida siccis'; &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIL20" id="BIVMVINL20" class="pginternal">20, 1</a>. <i>in the firste somer-sesoun warminge</i>:
  'uere tepenti.' This is not the only place where <i>uer</i> is translated <i>somer-sesoun</i>, a
  phrase used as applicable to May in P. Plowman, Prol. 1. Another name for 'spring' was <i>Lent</i>
  or <i>Lenten</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIL24" id="BIVMVINL24" class="pginternal">24</a>. <i>and thilke</i>: 'Eadem rapiens condit et aufert
  Obitu mergens orta supremo.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIL29" id="BIVMVINL29" class="pginternal">29</a>. <i>And tho</i>: 'Et quae motu concitat ire, Sistit
  retrahens, ac uaga firmat.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIL31" id="BIVMVINL31" class="pginternal">31</a>. <i>For yif</i>: 'Nam nisi rectos reuocans itus,
  Flexos iterum cogat in orbes, Quae nunc stabilis continet ordo, Dissepta suo fonte fatiscant.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIL37" id="BIVMVINL37" class="pginternal">37</a>. <i>This is</i>: 'Hic est cunctis communis amor
  Repetuntque boni fine teneri, Quia non aliter durare queunt, Nisi conuerso rursus amore Refluant
  caussae, quae dedit esse.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 7.</b> <a href="#BIVPVIIL57" id="BIVPVIINL57" class="pginternal">57</a>. <i>ne also it</i>: 'ita uir
  sapiens molestè ferre non debet, quotiens in fortunae certamen adducitur.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIIL60" id="BIVPVIINL60" class="pginternal">60</a>. <i>matere</i>, material, source.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIIL62" id="BIVPVIINL62" class="pginternal">62</a>. <i>vertu.</i> Boethius here derives
  <i>uirtus</i> from <i>uires</i>: 'quod suis <i>uiribus</i> nitens non superetur aduersis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIIL64" id="BIVPVIINL64" class="pginternal">64</a>. <i>Ne certes</i>: 'Neque enim uos in prouectu
  positi uirtutis, diffluere deliciis, et emarcescere uoluptate uenistis; proelium cum omni fortuna
  nimis acre conseritis, ne uos aut tristis opprimat, aut iucunda corrumpat: firmis medium uiribus
  occupate.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVPVIIL72" id="BIVPVIINL72" class="pginternal">72</a>. <i>in your hand</i>: 'In uestra enim situm est
  manu.'</p>
<p><b>Metre 7.</b> <a href="#BIVMVIIL1" id="BIVMVIINL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>wreker</i>, avenger;
  <i>Attrides</i>, Atrides, i.e. Agamemnon, son of Atreus. Chaucer derived the spelling
  <i>Agamenon</i> from a gloss in MS. C. Gower (C. A. ii. 344) has the same form.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL2" id="BIVMVIINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>recovered</i>: 'Fratris amissos thalamos
  piauit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL5" id="BIVMVIINL5" class="pginternal">5</a>. <i>Menelaus</i>, &amp;c.; 'that was his brother
  Menelaus' wife.' The usual idiom; see note to Squieres Tale, E 209.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL9" id="BIVMVIINL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>doughter</i>, i.e. Iphigenia; Ovid, Met. xii.
  27-38.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL13" id="BIVMVIINL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>Itacus</i>: 'Fleuit amissos Ithacus sodales.'
  The well-known story of Ulysses of Ithaca; from Homer, Od. ix.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL15" id="BIVMVIINL15" class="pginternal">15</a>. <i>empty</i>; as if translating 'inani.' But the
  right reading is <i>inmani</i> (or <i>immani</i>); i.e. 'vast.' MS. C. 'inmani,' glossed
  'magno.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL20" id="BIVMVIINL20" class="pginternal">20</a>. <i>Hercules.</i> See Monkes Tale, B 3285, and
  the notes. In the first note, this passage from Boethius is given at length.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL21" id="BIVMVIINL21" class="pginternal">21</a>. <i>Centaures</i>, Centaurs; Hercules was present
  at the fight between the Centauri and Lapithae; Ovid, Met. xii. 541; ix. 191.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL22" id="BIVMVIINL22" class="pginternal">22</a>. <i>lyoun</i>, the Nemean lion; Ovid, Met. ix.
  197, 235; Her. ix. 61.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL23" id="BIVMVIINL23" class="pginternal">23</a>. <i>Arpyes</i>, the Harpies; with reference to
  the destruction of the Stymphalian birds, who ate human flesh; Met. ix. 187. The gloss in the
  footnote—<i>in the palude of lyrne</i> (in the marsh of Lerna) is a mistake; it should refer
  to the Hydra mentioned below.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page454">{454}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL25" id="BIVMVIINL25" class="pginternal">25</a>. <i>dragoun</i>, the dragon in the garden of the
  Hesperides; Met. ix. 190. The 'golden metal' refers to the golden apples.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL26" id="BIVMVIINL26" class="pginternal">26</a>. <i>Cerberus</i>; Ovid, Met. ix. 185.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL27" id="BIVMVIINL27" class="pginternal">27</a>. <i>unmeke</i>, proud; see note to Monkes Tale, B
  3293; and Ovid, Met. ix. 194-6. Note that <i>hors</i> (= horses) is plural.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL29" id="BIVMVIINL29" class="pginternal">29</a>. <i>Ydra</i>, Hydra; Ovid, Met. ix. 192.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL30" id="BIVMVIINL30" class="pginternal">30</a>. <i>Achelous</i>; see the story in Ovid, Met. ix.
  1-97. Boethius imitates Ovid, l. 97, viz. 'Et lacerum cornu mediis caput abdidit undis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL35" id="BIVMVIINL35" class="pginternal">35</a>. <i>Antheus</i>, Antaeus; Ovid, Met. ix. 184. For
  the story, see Lucan, Phars. iv. 590-660; Lucan refers to <i>Lybia</i> as the place of combat; l.
  582.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL36" id="BIVMVIINL36" class="pginternal">36</a>. <i>Cacus</i>; see the story in Ovid, Fasti, i.
  543-86.</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL39" id="BIVMVIINL39" class="pginternal">39</a>. <i>boor</i>, the boar of Erymanthus; Ovid, Her.
  ix. 87. For <i>scomes</i> (lit. scums), Caxton and Thynne have <i>vomes</i>, for <i>fomes</i>
  (foams).</p>
<p><a href="#BIVMVIIL40" id="BIVMVIINL40" class="pginternal">40</a>. <i>the whiche</i>, 'which shoulders were fated
  to sustain (lit. thrust against) the high sphere of heaven.' Alluding to Hercules, when he took
  the place of Atlas.</p>
<p class="sp3"><a href="#BIVMVIIL45" id="BIVMVIINL45" class="pginternal">45</a>. <i>nake</i>, expose your unarmed
  backs (Lat. nudatis), like one who runs away. An unarmed man was usually said to be <i>naked</i>;
  as in Othello, v. 2. 258; 2 Hen. VI. iii. 2. 234; &amp;c.</p>
<h2>BOOK V.</h2>
<p><b>Prose 1.</b> <a href="#BVPIL3" id="BVPINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. A mistranslation. 'Recta quidem
  exhortatio, tuaque prorsus auctoritate dignissima.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIL9" id="BVPINL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>assoilen to thee the.</i> I prefer this reading,
  adopted from Caxton's edition, because the others make no sense. The original reading was <i>to
  the the</i> (= <i>to thee the</i>), as in MS. Ii. 1. 38, whence, by dropping one <i>the</i>, the
  reading <i>to the</i> in C. and Ed. MS. A. alters it to <i>the to the</i>, absurdly. The fact is,
  that <i>to thee</i> belongs to the next clause. 'Festino, inquit, debitum promissionis absoluere,
  uiamque <i>tibi</i>,' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIL14" id="BVPINL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>to douten</i>, to be feared; 'uerendumque est.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIL28" id="BVPINL28" class="pginternal">28</a>. <i>left, or dwellinge</i>, left, or remaining
  (<i>reliquus</i>). 'Quis enim ... locus esse ullus temeritati reliquus potest?'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIL31" id="BVPINL31" class="pginternal">31</a>. <i>nothing</i>: 'nihil ex nihilo exsistere.' Referring
  to the old saying:—'Ex nihilo nihil fit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIL34" id="BVPINL34" class="pginternal">34</a>. <i>prince and beginnere</i> oddly represents Lat.
  'principio.' <i>casten it</i>, laid it down: 'quasi quoddam iecerint fundamentum.' I supply
  <i>it</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIL44" id="BVPINL44" class="pginternal">44</a>. <i>Aristotulis</i>, Aristotle. The reference is to
  Aristotle's Physics, bk. ii. ch. 5.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIL47" id="BVPINL47" class="pginternal">47</a>. <i>for grace</i>, for the sake of; 'gratia.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIL50" id="BVPINL50" class="pginternal">50</a>. <i>Right as</i>, just as if. <i>by cause</i>, for the
  purpose.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIL55" id="BVPINL55" class="pginternal">55</a>. <i>ne dolve</i>, had not digged; subj. mood.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIL57" id="BVPINL57" class="pginternal">57</a>. <i>abregginge.</i> A mistranslation. 'Hae sunt igitur
  fortuiti caussae compendii'; these then are the causes of this fortuitous acquisition. <span class="pagenum" id="page455">{455}</span><i>Compendium</i> also means 'an abbreviating,' which
  Chaucer here expresses by <i>abbregginge</i>, introducing at the same time the word 'hap,' to make
  some sense.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIL66" id="BVPINL66" class="pginternal">66</a>. <i>uneschuable</i>, inevitable; 'ineuitabili.'</p>
<p><b>Metre 1.</b> <a href="#BVMIL2" id="BVMINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>Achemenie</i>: 'Rupis Achaemeniae
  scopulis,' in the crags of the Achæmenian rock or mountain. <i>Achaemenius</i> signifies
  'Persian,' from Achaemenes, the grandfather of Cyrus; but is here extended to mean Armenian. The
  sources of the Tigris and Euphrates are really different, though both rise in the mountains of
  Armenia; they run for a long way at no great distance apart, and at last join.</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIL3" id="BVMINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>fleinge bataile</i>, the flying troop; with reference
  to the well-known Parthian habit, of shooting arrows at those who pursue them; see Vergil, Georg.
  iii. 31.</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIL5" id="BVMINL5" class="pginternal">5</a>. <i>yif they</i>, when they; meaning that they <i>do</i>
  converge.</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIL9" id="BVMINL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>and the wateres</i>: 'Mixtaque fortuitos implicet unda
  modos: Quae tamen ipsa uagos terrae decliuia cursus Gurgitis et lapsi defluus ordo regit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIL14" id="BVMINL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>it suffereth</i>: 'Fors patitur frenos, ipsaque
  lege meat.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 2.</b> <a href="#BVPIIL4" id="BVPIINL4" class="pginternal">4</a>, <a href="#BVPIIL5" id="BVPIINL5" class="pginternal">5</a>.
  <i>destinal</i>, fatal; 'fatalis.' <i>corages</i>, minds.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIL10" id="BVPIINL10" class="pginternal">10</a>. <i>thinges ... fleen</i>, i.e. to be avoided:
  'fugienda.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIL13" id="BVPIINL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>is</i>, i.e. is in, resides in: 'quibus in ipsis
  inest ratio.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIL14" id="BVPIINL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>ordeyne</i>, determine: 'constituo.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIL16" id="BVPIINL16" class="pginternal">16</a>. <i>sovereines</i>, the supreme divine substances.
  This is a good example of adjectives of French origin with a plural in <i>-es</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIL17" id="BVPIINL17" class="pginternal">17</a>, <a href="#BVPIIL18" id="BVPIINL18" class="pginternal">18</a>.
  <i>wil</i>: 'et incorrupta uoluntas.' <i>might</i>: 'potestas.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIL27" id="BVPIINL27" class="pginternal">27</a>. <i>talents</i>, affections: 'affectibus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIL30" id="BVPIINL30" class="pginternal">30</a>. <i>caitifs</i>, captive: 'propriâ libertate
  captiuae.' Ll. 30-34 are repeated in Troilus, iv. 963-6; q.v.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIL34" id="BVPIINL34" class="pginternal">34</a>. <i>in Greek</i>: <span class="fsn" title="pant' ephora kai pant' epakouei">πάντ'
  ἐφορᾷ καὶ πάντ'
  ἐπακούει</span>. From Homer, Iliad, iii.
  277—<span class="fsn" title="Êelios th', hos pant' ephoras kai pant'   epakoueis">Ἠελιος θ', ὃς
  πάντ' ἐφορᾷς καὶ
  πάντ' ἐπακούεις</span>.
  Cf. Odys. xii. 323.</p>
<p><b>Metre 2.</b> <a href="#BVMIIL1" id="BVMIINL1" class="pginternal">1, 2</a>. <i>with the</i>, &amp;c.; 'Melliflui
  ... oris.' <i>cleer</i>, bright; alluding to the common phrase in Homer: <span class="fsn" title="lampron phaos êelioio">λαμπρὸν
  φάος ἠελίοιο</span>;
  Il. i. 605, &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIIL8" id="BVMIINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>strok</i>: 'Uno mentis cernit in ictu.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 3.</b> A large portion of this Prose, down to l. 71, is paraphrased in Troilus, iv.
  967-1078; q.v.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL12" id="BVPIIINL12" class="pginternal">12</a>. <i>libertee of arbitre</i>, freedom of will
  (arbitrii).</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL19" id="BVPIIINL19" class="pginternal">19</a>. <i>proeve</i>, approve of: 'Neque ... illam probo
  rationem.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL30" id="BVPIIINL30" class="pginternal">30</a>. <i>but ... ytravailed</i>: 'Quasi uero ...
  laboretur'; which means, rather, 'as if the question were.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL35" id="BVPIIINL35" class="pginternal">35</a>. <i>But I ne</i>, &amp;c. The translation is here
  quite wrong; and as in another place, Chaucer seems to have read <i>nitamur</i> as <i>uitamus</i>.
  The text has: 'At nos illud demonstrare nitamur.' The general sense is: 'But let me endeavour to
  shew, that, in whatever manner the order of causes be arranged, the happening of things foreseen
  is necessary, <span class="pagenum" id="page456">{456}</span>although the foreknowledge does not
  seem to impose on future things a necessity of their happening.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL53" id="BVPIIINL53" class="pginternal">53</a>. <i>For althogh that</i>; cf. Troil. iv. 1051-7,
  which is clearer.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL55" id="BVPIIINL55" class="pginternal">55</a>. <i>therfore ne bityde they nat</i>, it is not on
  <i>that</i> account that they happen. Cf. 'Nat that it comth for it purveyed is'; Troil. iv.
  1053.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL71" id="BVPIIINL71" class="pginternal">71</a>. <i>at the laste</i>, finally: 'Postremò.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL78" id="BVPIIINL78" class="pginternal">78</a>. <i>that I ne wot it.</i> The <i>ne</i> is
  superfluous, though in all the copies. The sense is—'if I know a thing, it cannot be false
  (must be true) that I know it.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL80" id="BVPIIINL80" class="pginternal">80</a>. <i>wanteth lesing</i>, is free from falsehood:
  'mendacio careat.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL90" id="BVPIIINL90" class="pginternal">90, 1</a>. <i>egaly</i>, equally: 'aeque.'
  <i>indifferently</i>, impartially.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL94" id="BVPIIINL94" class="pginternal">94</a>. <i>Iape-worthy,</i> ridiculous: 'ridiculo.' From
  Horace, Sat. ii. 5. 59—'O Laërtiade, quicquid dicam, aut erit, aut non.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL116" id="BVPIIINL116" class="pginternal">116</a>. <i>sent</i>, for <i>sendeth</i>, sends:
  'mittit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL117" id="BVPIIINL117" class="pginternal">117</a>. <i>constreineth</i>: 'futuri cogit certa
  necessitas.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL121" id="BVPIIINL121" class="pginternal">121</a>. <i>discrecioun</i>, discernment: 'indiscreta
  confusio.'</p>
<p><i>And yit</i>, &amp;c. To make sense, read <i>than whiche</i> for <i>of the whiche</i>. The
  whole clause, from <i>And yit</i> down to <i>wikke</i> is expanded from 'Quoque nihil sceleratius
  excogitari potest.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL131" id="BVPIIINL131" class="pginternal">131</a>. <i>sin that</i>: 'quando optanda omnia series
  indeflexa connectit?'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL141" id="BVPIIINL141" class="pginternal">141</a>. <i>that nis nat ... or that</i>, that cannot be
  approached before. The Latin is: 'illique inaccessae luci, prius quoque quam impetrent, ipsa
  supplicandi ratione coniungi.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL142" id="BVPIIINL142" class="pginternal">142</a>. <i>impetren</i>, ask for it; such is the
  reading of MS. Ii. 1. 38. A coined word, from the Lat. <i>impetrent</i>; see the last note.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL146" id="BVPIIINL146" class="pginternal">146</a>. <i>linage of mankind</i>, the human race; to
  which <i>his</i> (its) twice refers below.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIIIL147" id="BVPIIINL147" class="pginternal">147</a>. <i>a litel her-biforn</i>; i.e. in Bk. iv. Met.
  6. 34, where we find—'they sholden departen from hir welle, that is to seyn, from hir
  biginninge, and faylen.' See p. 122.</p>
<p><b>Metre 3.</b> <a href="#BVMIIIL1" id="BVMIIINL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>What</i>, &amp;c.: 'Quaenam
  discors foedera rerum Caussa resoluit?'</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIIIL2" id="BVMIIINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>the coniunccioun</i>; but this gloss seems to be
  wrong, for the reference is rather (as Chaucer, following a sidenote in MS. C., says in l. 5) to
  foreknowledge and free will.</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIIIL3" id="BVMIIINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>Whiche god</i>, i.e. what divinity: 'Quis tanta
  deus Veris statuit bella duobus?'</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIIIL7" id="BVMIIINL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>But ther nis.</i> The Lat. text is put
  interrogatively: 'An nulla est discordia ueris, Semperque sibi certa cohaerent?'</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIIIL10" id="BVMIIINL10" class="pginternal">10</a>. <i>by fyr</i>: 'oppressi luminis igne.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIIIL12" id="BVMIIINL12" class="pginternal">12</a>. <i>But wherefore</i>: 'Sed cur tanto flagrat amore
  Veri tectas reperire notas?' It thus appears that <i>y-covered</i>, i.e. 'that are hidden,' refers
  to <i>thilke notes</i>, not to <i>sooth</i>; cf. l. 15. But the translation is not at all
  happy.</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIIIL16" id="BVMIIINL16" class="pginternal">16</a>. <i>Wot it</i>: 'Scitne, quod appetit anxia
  nosse?'</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIIIL18" id="BVMIIINL18" class="pginternal">18</a>. <i>seith thus</i>: 'Sed quis nota scire laborat?
  At si nescit, quid caeca petit? Quis enim quidquam nescius optet?'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page457">{457}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BVMIIIL23" id="BVMIIINL23" class="pginternal">23</a>. <i>or who</i>: 'Aut quis ualeat nescita sequi?
  Quoue inueniat, quisue repertam Queat ignarus noscere formam?'</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIIIL26" id="BVMIIINL26" class="pginternal">26</a>. <i>But whan</i>: not a statement, as here taken,
  but a question. 'An cùm mentem cerneret altam Pariter summam et singula norat?' The translation is
  quite incorrect, and the passage is difficult. The reference seems to be to the supposition that
  the soul, apart from the body, sees both universals and particulars, but its power in the latter
  respect is impeded by the body; ideas taken from Plato's Meno and Phædo.</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIIIL32" id="BVMIIINL32" class="pginternal">32</a>, <a href="#BVMIIIL33" id="BVMIIINL33" class="pginternal">33</a>.
  <i>withholdeth</i>, retains: 'tenet.' <i>singularitees</i>, particulars: 'singula.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIIIL34" id="BVMIIINL34" class="pginternal">34</a>. <i>in neither nother</i>, put for <i>in ne either
  ne other</i>, i.e. not in one nor in the other; or, in modern English, 'he is neither in one
  position nor the other': 'Neutro est habitu.' This curious phrase is made clearer by comparing it
  with the commoner <i>either other</i>. Thus, in P. Plowman, B. v. 148: '<i>either</i> despiseth
  <i>other</i>'; in the same, B. v. 164: '<i>eyther</i> hitte <i>other</i>'; and again, in B. xi.
  173: 'that alle manere men .. Louen her <i>eyther other</i>'; and, in B. vii. 138: 'apposeden
  <i>either other</i>'; and lastly, in B. xvi. 207: '<i>either</i> is <i>otheres</i> Ioye.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIIIL36" id="BVMIIINL36" class="pginternal">36</a>. <i>retreteth</i>, reconsiders: 'altè uisa
  <i>retractans</i>.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 4.</b> <a href="#BVPIVL2" id="BVPIVNL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. <i>Marcus Tullius</i>, i.e. Cicero; De
  Diuinatione, lib. ii. 60.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL8" id="BVPIVNL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>moeven to</i>: 'ad diuinae praescientiae
  simplicitatem non potest admoueri.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL15" id="BVPIVNL15" class="pginternal">15</a>. <i>y-spended</i>, spent; but the right sense of the
  Latin is weighed or considered: 'si prius ea quibus moueris, <i>expendero</i>.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL22" id="BVPIVNL22" class="pginternal">22</a>. <i>from elles-where</i>: 'aliunde'; compare
  Chaucer's gloss.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL24" id="BVPIVNL24" class="pginternal">24</a>. <i>unbityde</i>, not happen: 'non euenire non
  possunt.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL27" id="BVPIVNL27" class="pginternal">27</a>. <i>thou thyself.</i> The reference is to Bk. v. Pr.
  3. l. 27, above—'ne it ne bihoveth nat, nedes, that thinges bityden that ben purvyed.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL28" id="BVPIVNL28" class="pginternal">28</a>, <a href="#BVPIVL29" id="BVPIVNL29" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>what
  cause</i>: 'quid est, quod uoluntarii exitus rerum ad certum cogantur euentum?' <i>endes</i>,
  results: 'exitus;' and so again below.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL30" id="BVPIVNL30" class="pginternal">30</a>. <i>by grace of position</i>, for the sake of a
  supposition, by way of supposition: 'positionis gratia.' Cf. Chaucer's use of <i>pose</i> for
  'suppose' in the next line. The reading <i>possessioun</i> (in both MSS.) is obviously wrong; it
  sounds as if taken down from dictation.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL31" id="BVPIVNL31" class="pginternal">31</a>. <i>I pose</i>, I suppose, I put the case: 'statuamus
  nullam esse praescientiam.' The words 'per impossibile' are inserted by Chaucer, and mean, 'to
