  take an impossible case.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL56" id="BVPIVNL56" class="pginternal">56</a>. <i>But, certes, right</i>; only, indeed, just as,
  &amp;c. It is difficult to give the right force intended; and, probably, Chaucer quite mistook the
  sense. 'Quasi uero nos ea, quae prouidentia futura esse praenoscit, non esse euentura
  credamus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL62" id="BVPIVNL62" class="pginternal">62</a>. <i>in the torninge</i>: 'in quadrigis moderandis
  atque flectendis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL63" id="BVPIVNL63" class="pginternal">63</a>. <i>And by</i>: 'atque ad hunc modum caetera.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL100" id="BVPIVNL100" class="pginternal">100</a>. <i>and for that this thing shal mowen shewen</i>,
  and in order that <span class="pagenum" id="page458">{458}</span>this may appear (lit. may be able
  to appear). The whole clause merely means—'And to make this clearer by an easy example.'
  Lat. 'Nam ut hoc breui liqueat exemplo.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL101" id="BVPIVNL101" class="pginternal">101</a>. <i>roundnesse</i> is here in the objective case:
  'eandem corporis rotunditatem aliter uisus aliter tactus agnoscit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL107" id="BVPIVNL107" class="pginternal">107</a>. <i>And the man</i>: 'Ipsum quoque hominem.'
  <i>wit</i>, i.e. sense. The 'five wits' were the five senses.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL113" id="BVPIVNL113" class="pginternal">113</a>. <i>spece</i>, species. <i>peces</i>, parts; <i>in
  the singuler peces</i>, i.e. in the particular parts.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL114" id="BVPIVNL114" class="pginternal">114</a>. <i>intelligence</i>, understanding;
  'intelligentiae.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL115" id="BVPIVNL115" class="pginternal">115</a>. <i>universitee</i>, that which is universal:
  'uniuersitatis ambitum.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL133" id="BVPIVNL133" class="pginternal">133</a>. <i>by a strok</i>: 'illo uno ictu mentis
  formaliter.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPIVL137" id="BVPIVNL137" class="pginternal">137</a>. <i>diffinissheth</i>, defines the universality of
  her conception.</p>
<p><b>Metre 4.</b> <a href="#BVMIVL1" id="BVMIVNL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>The Porche</i>; in Latin,
  <i>Porticus</i>; in Gk. <span class="fsn" title="stoa">στοά</span>, a
  roofed colonnade or porch in Athens, frequented by Zeno and his followers, who hence obtained the
  name of Stoics.</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Quondam Porticus attulit Obscuros nimium senes,</p>
<p>Qui sensus, et imagines E corporibus extimis</p>
<p>Credant mentibus imprimi.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#BVMIVL10" id="BVMIVNL10" class="pginternal">10</a>. <span class="sc">Text.</span> The Latin text
  continues thus<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Vt quondam celeri stilo Mos est aequore paginae</p>
<p>Quae nullas habeat notas, Pressas figere litteras.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#BVMIVL11" id="BVMIVNL11" class="pginternal">11</a>. <i>pointel</i>; see note to Somn. Tale, D 1742. And
  cf. Troilus, i. 365; Cant. Ta. E 1581, 2.</p>
<p><a href="#BVMIVL15" id="BVMIVNL15" class="pginternal">15</a>. <i>But yif</i>:</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Sed mens si propriis uigens Nihil motibus explicat</p>
<p>Sed tantùm patiens iacet Notis subdita corporum,</p>
<p>Cassasque in speculi uicem Rerum reddit imagines.</p>
<p>Vnde haec sic animis uiget Cernens omnia notio?</p>
<p>Quae uis singula prospicit, Aut quae cognita diuidit?</p>
<p>Quae diuisa recolligit, Alternumque legens iter</p>
<p>Nunc summis caput inserit, Nunc desidit in infima,</p>
<p>Tum sese referens sibi, Veris falsa redarguit?'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#BVMIVL32" id="BVMIVNL32" class="pginternal">32</a>. <i>passioun</i>, passive feeling, impression:
  'passio.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 5.</b> <a href="#BVPVL1" id="BVPVNL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>But what yif ... and al be it so</i>,
  Nevertheless, even if it be so: 'Quod si ... quamuis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVL4" id="BVPVNL4" class="pginternal">4</a>. <i>entalenten</i>, affect, incline, stimulate:
  'afficiant.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVL18" id="BVPVNL18" class="pginternal">18</a>. <i>For the wit</i>, i.e. the sense, the external
  senses.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVL21" id="BVPVNL21" class="pginternal">21</a>. <i>as oystres ... see</i>: the Latin merely has:
  'quales sunt conchae maris.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVL23" id="BVPVNL23" class="pginternal">23</a>. <i>remuable</i>, capable of motion from place to
  place: 'mobilibus belluis.'</p>
<p><i>talent</i>, inclination, desire, wish: 'affectus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVL30" id="BVPVNL30" class="pginternal">30</a>. <i>But how ... yif that</i>, but how will it be
  if?</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVL33" id="BVPVNL33" class="pginternal">33</a>. <i>that that that</i>, that <i>that</i> thing
  which.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVL35" id="BVPVNL35" class="pginternal">35</a>. <i>ne that ther nis</i>, so that there is: 'nec
  quicquam esse sensibile.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page459">{459}</span></div>
<p><a href="#BVPVL49" id="BVPVNL49" class="pginternal">49</a>. <i>maner stryvinge</i>, sort of strife: 'In huiusmodi
  igitur lite.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVL62" id="BVPVNL62" class="pginternal">62</a>. <i>parsoneres</i>, partners of, endowed with. The
  modern <i>partner</i> represents the M. E. <i>parcener</i>, variant of <i>parsoner</i>, from O. F.
  <i>parsonier</i>, representing a Latin form <i>*partitionarius</i>. Lat. 'participes.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVL66" id="BVPVNL66" class="pginternal">66</a>. <i>For which</i>: 'Quare in illius summae
  intelligentiae cacumen, si possumus, erigamur.'</p>
<p><b>Metre 5.</b> <a href="#BVMVL1" id="BVMVNL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>passen by</i>, move over:
  'permeant.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVMVL6" id="BVMVNL6" class="pginternal">6</a>. <i>by moist fleeinge</i>: 'liquido ... uolatu.' <i>gladen
  hemself</i>, delight: 'gaudent.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVMVL7" id="BVMVNL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>with hir goings ... feet</i>: 'gressibus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVMVL9" id="BVMVNL9" class="pginternal">9</a>. <i>to walken under</i>, to enter: 'subire.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVMVL10" id="BVMVNL10" class="pginternal">10</a>. <i>enclined</i>, i.e. enclined earthwards:
  'Prona.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVMVL11" id="BVMVNL11" class="pginternal">11</a>. <i>hevieth</i>, oppresses: 'Prona tamen facies hebetes
  ualet ingrauare sensus.' From Aristotle, On the Parts of Animals, Bk. iv. <span class="fsn" title="Dio pleionos genomenou tou barous kai   tou sômatôdous, anankê rhepein ta sômata   pros tên gên">Διὸ πλείονος
  γενομένου τοῦ
  βάρους καὶ τοῦ
  σωματώδους,
  ἀνάγκη ῥέπειν τὰ
  σώματα πρὸς τὴν
  γῆν</span> (chap. 10). As to the upright carriage of man, see the same chapter.
  Cf. Ovid, Met. i. 84, and see note to Chaucer's 'Truth,' l. 19.</p>
<p><a href="#BVMVL12" id="BVMVNL12" class="pginternal">12</a>. <i>light</i>, i.e. not bowed down: 'leuis recto stat
  corpore.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVMVL14" id="BVMVNL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>axest</i>, seemest to seek: 'caelum ... petis.'</p>
<p><b>Prose 6.</b> <a href="#BVPVIL21" id="BVPVINL21" class="pginternal">21</a>. <i>as Aristotle demed</i>; in De
  Caelo, lib. i.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL33" id="BVPVINL33" class="pginternal">33</a>. <i>present</i>: 'et sui compos praesens sibi semper
  assistere.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL42" id="BVPVINL42" class="pginternal">42</a>. <i>Plato.</i> This notion is found in Proclus and
  Plotinus, and other followers of Plato; but Plato himself really expressed a contrary opinion,
  viz. that the world had a definite beginning. See his Timæus.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL48" id="BVPVINL48" class="pginternal">48</a>. <i>For this ilke</i>: 'Hunc enim uitae immobilis
  praesentarium statum infinitus ille temporalium rerum motus imitatur; cumque eum effingere atque
  aequare non possit, ex immobilitate deficit in motum, et ex simplicitate praesentiae decrescit in
  infinitam futuri ac praeteriti quantitatem;' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL53" id="BVPVINL53" class="pginternal">53</a>. <i>disencreseth</i>; a clumsy form for
  <i>decreseth</i>: 'decrescit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL65" id="BVPVINL65" class="pginternal">65</a>. <i>therfor it</i>: 'infinitum temporis iter
  arripuit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL81" id="BVPVINL81" class="pginternal">81</a>. <i>it is science</i>: 'sed scientiam nunquam
  deficientis instantiae rectius aestimabis.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL82" id="BVPVINL82" class="pginternal">82</a>. <i>For which</i>: 'Unde non praeuidentia, sed
  prouidentia, potius dicitur.' The footnote to l. 83 is wrong, as Dr. Furnivall's reprint of MS. C.
  is here at fault. That MS. (like MS. Ii. 1. 38) has here the correct reading 'p<i>re</i>uydence,'
  without any gloss at all. The gloss 'p<i>ro</i>uidentia' belongs to the word 'purviaunce.' Hence
  the reading 'previdence,' which I thought to be unsupported, is really supported by two good
  MSS.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL86" id="BVPVINL86" class="pginternal">86</a>. <i>Why axestow ... thanne</i>: 'Quid igitur
  postulas?'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL112" id="BVPVINL112" class="pginternal">112</a>. <i>he ne unwot</i>: 'quod idem exsistendi
  necessitate carere non nesciat.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL116" id="BVPVINL116" class="pginternal">116</a>. <i>it ne may nat unbityde</i>: 'id non euenire
  non posse.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL119" id="BVPVINL119" class="pginternal">119</a>. <i>but unnethe</i>: 'sed cui uix aliquis nisi
  diuini speculator accesserit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL150" id="BVPVINL150" class="pginternal">150</a>, <a href="#BVPVIL151" id="BVPVINL151" class="pginternal">1</a>. <i>in
  beinge</i>, in coming to pass: 'exsistendo.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page460">{460}</span></div>
<p><i>by the which</i>: 'qua prius quam fierent, etiam non euenire potuissent.' MS. C. has the
  contraction for 'que,' i.e. 'quae'; but Chaucer clearly adopted the reading 'qua.' The usual
  reading is 'quia' or 'quae.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL154" id="BVPVINL154" class="pginternal">154</a>. <i>so as they comen</i>, since they come: 'cum
  ... eueniant.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL159" id="BVPVINL159" class="pginternal">159</a>. <i>the sonne arysinge.</i> See above, p. 148, l.
  102: 'Right so,' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL185" id="BVPVINL185" class="pginternal">185</a>. <i>And thilke</i>: 'illa quoque noscendi uices
  alternare uideatur?'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL191" id="BVPVINL191" class="pginternal">191</a>. <i>For the devyne</i>: 'Omne namque futurum
  diuinus praecurrit intuitus, et ad praesentiam propriae cognitionis retorquet ac reuocat.' Hence
  <i>retorneth hem</i> means 'makes them return.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL193" id="BVPVINL193" class="pginternal">193</a>. <i>ne he ne</i>: 'nec alternat, ut existimas,
  nunc hoc, nunc illud praenoscendi uices; sed uno ictu mutationes tuas manens praeuenit atque
  complectitur.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL199" id="BVPVINL199" class="pginternal">199</a>. <i>a litel her-biforn.</i> See above, Bk. v. Pr.
  3, ll. 62-65; &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL207" id="BVPVINL207" class="pginternal">207</a>. <i>purposen</i>, propose, assign:
  'proponunt.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL208" id="BVPVINL208" class="pginternal">208</a>. <i>to the willinges</i>: 'solutis omni
  necessitate uoluntatibus.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL211" id="BVPVINL211" class="pginternal">211</a>. <i>renneth ... with</i>, concurs with:
  'concurrit.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL214" id="BVPVINL214" class="pginternal">214</a>. <i>put</i>, set: 'positae.' <i>that ne mowen</i>:
  'quae cum rectae sunt, inefficaces esse non possunt.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL217" id="BVPVINL217" class="pginternal">217</a>. <i>areys thy corage</i>: 'animum subleuate.'
  <i>yilde</i>: 'humiles preces in excelsa porrigite.'</p>
<p><a href="#BVPVIL220" id="BVPVINL220" class="pginternal">220</a>. <i>sin that ye</i>: 'cum ante oculos agitis
  iudicis cuncta cernentis.' With the word 'cernentis' the Lat. treatise ends.</p>
<p class="sp5">The words—'To whom ... Amen' occur in the Cambridge MS. only; and, in all
  probability, were merely added by the scribe. However, the Latin copy in that MS. adds, after
  'cernentis,' the following: 'Qui est dominus noster Iesus Christus, cui sit honor et gloria in
  secula seculorum. <span class="sc">Amen.</span>'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page461">{461}</span></div>
<h1 class="sp3 ac" style="margin-bottom:4.7ex;"> <span class="x-larger">NOTES TO
  TROILUS.</span></h1>
<h2>BOOK I.</h2>
<p>I must refer the student to Mr. Rossetti's work (Chaucer Soc. 1875) for a detailed comparison
  of Chaucer's poem with the <i>Filostrato</i> of Boccaccio. The following table roughly indicates
  the portions of these works which are more or less similar, down to the end of Book I. Similar
  tables are prefixed to the Notes on the other books. It often happens that a stanza in Chaucer has
  a mere general resemblance to the corresponding one in Boccaccio. The lines in Chaucer not
  mentioned below are, in the main, original; e.g. 1-20, 31-56, &amp;c.; and so are many others that
  cannot be here more exactly specified.</p>
<table class="sp2 mc" title="Correspondence with Filostrato, Book I" data-summary="Correspondence with Filostrato, Book I">
<tbody><tr>

<td>ll. 21-30.</td>
<td>Bk. I. St. V, VI.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="pl1">57-213.</td>
<td class="pl2">VII-XXV.</td>

<td class="pl2">XXXII. 7-XXXVII.</td>

<p><a href="#TIL2" id="TINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. 'That was the son of King Priam of Troy.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL5" id="TINL5" class="pginternal">5</a>. <i>fro ye</i>, from you; observe the rime. The form <i>ye</i>
  is not here the nom. case, but the <i>unemphatic form</i> of the acc. <i>you</i>; pronounced
  (yə), where (ə) is the indefinite vowel, like the <i>a</i> in <i>China</i>. So in
  Shak. Two Gent. iv. 1. 3, 4, we have <i>about ye</i> (unemphatic) in l. 3, and <i>you</i> twice in
  l. 4.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL6" id="TINL6" class="pginternal">6</a>. <i>Thesiphone</i>, Tisiphone, one of the Furies, invoked as
  being a 'goddess of torment.' Cf. '<i>furial</i> pyne of helle,' Sq. Ta. F 448.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL13" id="TINL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>fere</i>, companion; viz. Tisiphone.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page462">{462}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIL16" id="TINL16" class="pginternal">16</a>. 'Nor dare pray to Love,' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL21" id="TINL21" class="pginternal">21</a>. Cf. Boccaccio: 'Tuo sia l'onore, e mio si sia l'affanno,'
  Fil. I. st. 5. And see ll. 1042, 3 below.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL57" id="TINL57" class="pginternal">57</a>. Here begins the story; cf. Fil. I. st. 7. Bell remarks
  that 'a thousand shippes,' in l. 58, may have been suggested by 'mille carinae' in Verg. Æn. ii.
  198; cf. 'anni decem' in the same line, with l. 60.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL67" id="TINL67" class="pginternal">67</a>. Read <i>éxpert</i>. <i>Calkas</i> is Homer's Calchas, Il.
  i. 69. He was a Greek, but Guido makes him a Trojan, putting him in the place of Homer's Chryses.
  See the allit. Troy-book, 7886.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL70" id="TINL70" class="pginternal">70</a>. <i>Delphicus</i>, of Delphi; cf. Ovid, Met. ii. 543.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL77" id="TINL77" class="pginternal">77</a>. <i>Ye</i>, yea. <i>wolde who-so nolde</i>, whoever wished
  it or did not wish it. This idiomatic phrase is thus expressed in the MSS. Bell's edition has
  <i>wold who so or nolde</i>, where the <i>e</i> in <i>wolde</i> is suppressed and the word
  <i>or</i> inserted without authority. I hesitate, as an editor, to alter an idiomatic phrase. Cf.
  <i>will he, nill he</i>, in which there is no <i>or</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL91" id="TINL91" class="pginternal">91</a>. 'Deserve to be burnt, both skin and bones.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL99" id="TINL99" class="pginternal">99</a>. <i>Criseyde</i>; Boccaccio has <i>Griseida</i>, answering
  to Homer's <span class="fsn" title="Chrysêida">Χρυσηΐδα</span>,
  Il. i. 143. It was common, in the Middle Ages, to adopt the accusative form as the standard one,
  especially in proper names. Her father was Chryses; see note to l. 67. But Benoît de Sainte-Maure
  calls her <i>Briseida</i>, and <i>Chryseis</i> and <i>Briseis</i> seem to have been confused. The
  allit. Troy-book has <i>Bresaide</i>; l. 8029.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL119" id="TINL119" class="pginternal">119</a>. 'While it well pleases you'; <i>good</i> is used
  adverbially. Ital. 'mentre t' aggrada.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL125" id="TINL125" class="pginternal">125</a>. 'And would have done so oftener, if,' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL126" id="TINL126" class="pginternal">126</a>. <i>and hoom</i>, and (went) home.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL132" id="TINL132" class="pginternal">132, 133</a>. This is a curious statement, and Chaucer's object
  in making it is not clear. Boccaccio says expressly that she had neither son nor daughter (st.
  15); and Benoît (l. 12977) calls her 'la pucele.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL136" id="TINL136" class="pginternal">136</a>. <i>som day</i>, one day; used quite generally.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL138" id="TINL138" class="pginternal">138</a>. 'And thus Fortune wheeled both of them up and down
  again.' Alluding to the wheel of Fortune; see the Ballade on Fortune, l. 46, and note.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL145" id="TINL145" class="pginternal">145</a>. <i>Troyane gestes</i>, Trojan history; cf. the title of
  Guido delle Colonne's book, viz. 'Historia Troiana,' which Chaucer certainly consulted, as shewn
  by several incidents in the poem.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL146" id="TINL146" class="pginternal">146</a>. <i>Omer</i>, Homer; whose account was considered
  untrustworthy by the medieval writers; see Ho. Fame, 1477, and note. <i>Dares</i>, Dares Phrygius;
  <i>Dyte</i>, Dictys Cretensis; see notes to Ho. Fame, 1467, 1468. These three authors really mean
  Guido delle Colonne, who professed to follow them.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL153" id="TINL153" class="pginternal">153</a>. <i>Palladion</i>, the Palladium or sacred image of
  Pallas, on the keeping of which the safety of Troy depended. It was stolen from Troy by Diomede
  and Ulysses; see Æneid, ii. 166. But Chaucer doubtless read the long account in Guido delle
  Colonne.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL171" id="TINL171" class="pginternal">171</a>. Hence Henrysoun, in his Testament of Criseyde, st. 12,
  calls her 'the flower and A-per-se Of Troy and Greece.' Cf. 'She was a <span class="pagenum" id="page463">{463}</span>woman A-per-se, alon'; Romance of Partenay, 1148. Boccaccio's image is
  much finer; he says that she surpassed other women as the rose does the violet. On the other hand,
  l. 175 is Chaucer's own.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL172" id="TINL172" class="pginternal">172</a>. <i>makelees</i>, matchless, peerless; cf. A.S.
  <i>gemaca</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL189" id="TINL189" class="pginternal">189</a>. <i>lakken</i>, to blame; see P. Pl. B. v. 132.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL192" id="TINL192" class="pginternal">192</a>. <i>bayten</i>, feed, feast (metaphorically); E.
  <i>bait</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL205" id="TINL205" class="pginternal">205</a>. <i>Ascaunces</i>, as if; in l. 292, the Ital. text has
  <i>Quasi dicesse</i>, as if she said. See Cant. Ta. D 1745, G 838. It is tautological, being
  formed from E. <i>as</i> and the O.F. <i>quanses</i>, as if (Godefroy); so that the literal force
  is 'as as if.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL210" id="TINL210" class="pginternal">210</a>. 'And nevertheless [or, still] he (Cupid) can pluck as
  proud a peacock (as was Troilus).' Cf. Prol. A 652.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL214" id="TINL214" class="pginternal">214-266</a>. These lines are Chaucer's own.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL217" id="TINL217" class="pginternal">217</a>. <i>falleth</i>, happens; <i>ne wenden</i>, would not
  expect. In Ray's Proverbs, ed. 1737, p. 279, is a Scotch proverb—'All fails that fools
  thinks' (<i>sic</i>); which favours the alternative reading given in the footnote.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL218" id="TINL218" class="pginternal">218</a>. <i>Bayard</i>, a name for a bay horse; see Can. Yem.
  Ta. G 1413.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL229" id="TINL229" class="pginternal">229</a>. <i>wex a-fere</i>, became on fire. <i>Fere</i> is a
  common Southern form, as a variant of <i>fyre</i>, though <i>a-fyre</i> occurs in Ho. Fame, 1858.
  The A.S. vowel is <i>ȳ</i>, the A.S. form being <i>fȳr</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL239" id="TINL239" class="pginternal">239</a>. 'Has proved (to be true), and still does so.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL257" id="TINL257" class="pginternal">257</a>. 'The stick that will bend and ply is better than one
  that breaks.' Compare the fable of the Oak and the Reed; see bk. ii. 1387.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL266" id="TINL266" class="pginternal">266</a>. <i>ther-to refere</i>, revert thereto. Halliwell gives:
  '<i>Refeere</i>, to revert; <i>Hoccleve</i>.' Chaucer here ends his own remarks, and goes back to
  the <i>Filostrato</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL292" id="TINL292" class="pginternal">292</a>. <i>Ascaunces</i>, as if (she said); see note to l.
  205.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL316" id="TINL316" class="pginternal">316</a>. <i>awhaped</i>, amazed, stupefied; see Anelida, 215;
  Leg. of Good Women, 132, 814, 2321; he was 'not utterly confounded,' but only dazed; cf. l.
  322.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL327" id="TINL327" class="pginternal">327</a>. <i>borneth</i>, burnishes, polishes up; i.e. makes
  bright and cheerful. The rime shews that it is a variant spelling of <i>burneth</i>; cf.
  <i>burned</i>, burnished, Ho. Fame, 1387; Kn. Ta. A 1983.</p>
<p>MS. Harl. 3943 has <i>vnournith</i>, an error for <i>anorneth</i>, adorns; with a like
  sense.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL333" id="TINL333" class="pginternal">333</a>. <i>Him tit</i>, to him betideth; <i>tit</i> is for
  <i>tydeth</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL336" id="TINL336" class="pginternal">336</a>. <i>ordre</i>, sect, brotherhood; a jesting allusion to
  the religious orders. So also <i>ruled</i> = under a religious rule.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL337" id="TINL337" class="pginternal">337</a>. <i>noun-certeyn</i>, uncertainty; cf. O.F.
  <i>noncerteit</i>, uncertainty (Godefroy); <i>nounpower</i>, want of power (P. Plowman); and F.
  <i>nonchalance</i>. Again spelt <i>noun-certeyn</i>, Compl. Venus, 46.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL340" id="TINL340" class="pginternal">340</a>. <i>lay</i>, law, ordinance; see Sq. Ta. F 18.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL344" id="TINL344" class="pginternal">344</a>. 'But observe this—that which ye lovers often
  avoid, or else do with a good intention, often will thy lady misconstrue it,' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL363" id="TINL363" class="pginternal">363</a>. <i>a temple</i>, i.e. in the temple.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL381" id="TINL381" class="pginternal">381</a>. <i>First</i> stands alone in the first foot. Cf. ll.
  490, 603, 811.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page464">{464}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIL385" id="TINL385" class="pginternal">385</a>. <i>Yelt</i>, short for <i>yeldeth</i>, yields.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL394" id="TINL394" class="pginternal">394</a>. <i>writ</i>, writeth. <i>Lollius</i>; Chaucer's reason
  for the use of this name is not known. Perhaps we may agree with Dr. Latham, who suggested (in a
  letter to the <i>Athenæum</i>, Oct. 3, 1868, p. 433), that Chaucer misread this line in Horace
  (<i>Epist.</i> i. 2. 1), viz. 'Troiani belli scriptorem, maxime <i>Lolli</i>'; and thence derived
  the notion that Lollius wrote on the Trojan war. This becomes the more likely if we suppose that
  he merely saw this line quoted apart from the context. Chaucer does not seem to have read Horace
  for himself. As a matter of fact, ll. 400-420 are translated from the 88th sonnet of Petrarch. See
  note to Ho. of Fame, 1468. The following is the text of Petrarch's sonnet:</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'S'amor non è, che dunque è quel ch' i'sento?</p>
<p style="margin-left:1.40em">Ma s'egli è amor, per Dio, che cosa e quale?</p>
<p style="margin-left:1.40em">Se buona, ond' è l'effetto aspro mortale?</p>
<p style="margin-left:1.40em">Se ria, ond' è si dolce ogni tormento?</p>
<p>S'a mia voglia ardo, ond' è 'l pianto e'l lamento?</p>
<p style="margin-left:1.40em">S'a mal mia grado, il lamentar che vale?</p>
<p style="margin-left:1.40em">O viva morte, o dilettoso male,</p>
<p style="margin-left:1.40em">Come puoi tanto in me s'io nol consento?</p>
<p>E s'io 'l consento, a gran torto mi doglio.</p>
<p style="margin-left:1.40em">Fra si contrari venti, in frale barca</p>
<p style="margin-left:1.40em">Mi trovo in alto mar, senza governo.</p>
<p>Sì lieve di saver, d'error sì carca</p>
<p style="margin-left:1.40em">Ch' i' medesmo non so quel ch'io mi voglio,</p>
<p style="margin-left:1.40em">E tremo a mezza state, ardendo il verno.'</p>
</div>
<p>In l. 401, <i>whiche</i> means 'of what kind.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL425" id="TINL425" class="pginternal">425</a>. Ital. text—'Non so s'io dico a donna, ovvero a
  dea'; Fil. I. 38. Cf. Æneid, i. 327. Hence the line in Kn. Ta. A 1101.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL457" id="TINL457" class="pginternal">457</a>. <i>That</i>; in modern E., we should use <i>But</i>, or
  else <i>said not</i> for <i>seyde</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL463" id="TINL463" class="pginternal">463</a>. <i>Fled-de</i> is here a plural form, the pp. being
  treated as an adjective. Cf. <i>sprad-de</i>, iv. 1422; <i>whet-te</i>, v. 1760.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL464" id="TINL464" class="pginternal">464</a>. <i>savacioun</i>; Ital. 'salute.' Mr. Rossetti thinks
  that <i>salute</i> here means 'well-being' or 'health'; and perhaps <i>savacioun</i> is intended
  to mean the same, the literal sense being 'safety.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL465" id="TINL465" class="pginternal">465</a>. <i>fownes</i>, fawns; see Book of the Duch. 429. It is
  here used, metaphorically, to mean 'young desires' or 'fresh yearnings.' This image is not in
  Boccaccio.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL470" id="TINL470" class="pginternal">470</a>. I take the right reading to be <i>felle</i>, as in Cm.
  Ed., with the sense 'destructive.' As it might also mean 'happened,' other MSS. turned it into
  <i>fille</i>, which makes a most awkward construction. The sense is: 'The sharp destructive
  assaults of the proof of arms [i.e. which afforded proof of skill in fighting], which Hector and
  his other brothers performed, not once made him move on <i>that</i> account only'; i.e. when he
  exerted himself, it was not for mere fighting's sake. Chaucer uses <i>fel</i> elsewhere; the pl.
  <i>felle</i> is in Troil. iv. 44; and see Cant. Ta. D 2002, B 2019. For <i>preve</i>, proof, see
  l. 690.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page465">{465}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIL473" id="TINL473" class="pginternal">473, 4</a>. <i>riden</i> and <i>abiden</i> (with short <i>i</i>)
  rime with <i>diden</i>, and are past tenses plural. l. 474 is elliptical: 'found (to be) one of
  the best, and (one of those who) longest abode where peril was.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL483" id="TINL483" class="pginternal">483</a>. <i>the deeth</i>, i.e. the pestilence, the plague.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL488" id="TINL488" class="pginternal">488</a>. <i>title</i>, a name; he said it was 'a fever.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL517" id="TINL517" class="pginternal">517</a>. <i>daunce</i>, i.e. company of dancers. Cf. Ho. Fame,
  639, 640.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL530" id="TINL530" class="pginternal">530-2</a>. 'For, by my hidden sorrow, (when it is) blased
  abroad, I shall be befooled more, a thousand times, than the fool of whose folly men write rimes.'
  No particular reference seems to be intended by l. 532; the Ital. text merely has 'più ch' altro,'
  more than any one.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL557" id="TINL557" class="pginternal">557</a>. <i>attricioun</i>, attrition. 'An imperfect sorrow for
  sin, as if a bruising which does not amount to utter crushing (<i>contrition</i>); horror of sin
  through fear of punishment ... while <i>contrition</i> has its motive in the love of God;' New E.
  Dict.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL559" id="TINL559" class="pginternal">559</a>. <i>ley on presse</i>, compress, diminish; cf. Prol. A
  81.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL560" id="TINL560" class="pginternal">560</a>. <i>holinesse</i>, the leanness befitting a holy
  state.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL626" id="TINL626" class="pginternal">626</a>. 'That one, whom excess causes to fare very badly.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL631" id="TINL631" class="pginternal">631-679</a>. Largely original; but, for l. 635, see note to Bk.
  III. 329.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL638" id="TINL638" class="pginternal">638-644</a>. There is a like passage in P. Pl. C. xxi. 209-217.
  Chaucer, however, here follows Le Roman de la Rose, 21819-40, q.v.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL648" id="TINL648" class="pginternal">648</a>. <i>amayed</i>, dismayed; O.F. <i>esmaier</i>. So in Bk.
  IV. l. 641.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL654" id="TINL654" class="pginternal">654</a>. <i>Oënone</i> seems to have four syllables. MS. H. has
  <i>Oonone</i>; MS. Cm. <i>senome</i> (over an erasure); MS. Harl. 3943, <i>Tynome</i>. Alluding to
  the letter of <i>Œnone</i> to Paris in Ovid, Heroid. v.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL659" id="TINL659" class="pginternal">659-665</a>. Not at all a literal translation, but it gives the
  general sense of Heroid. v. 149-152:</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Me miseram, quod amor non est medicabilis herbis!</p>
<p style="margin-left:1.05em">Deficior prudens artis ab arte mea.</p>
<p style="margin-left:0.35em">Ipse repertor opis uaccas pauisse Pheraeas</p>
<p style="margin-left:1.05em">Fertur, et a nostro saucius igne fuit.'</p>
</div>
<p><i>Ipse repertor opis</i> means Phœbus, who 'first fond art of medicyne;'
  <i>Pheraeas</i>, i.e. of Pherae, refers to Pherae in Thessaly, the residence of king Admetus.
  Admetus gained Alcestis for his wife by the assistance of Apollo, who, according to some accounts,
  served Admetus out of attachment to him, or, according to other accounts, because he was condemned
  to serve a mortal for a year. Chaucer seems to adopt a theory that Apollo loved Admetus chiefly
  for his daughter's sake. The usual story about Apollo is his love for Daphne.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL674" id="TINL674" class="pginternal">674</a>. 'Even though I had to die by torture;' cf. Kn. Ta. A
  1133.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL686" id="TINL686" class="pginternal">686</a>. 'Until it pleases him to desist.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL688" id="TINL688" class="pginternal">688</a>. 'To mistrust every one, or to believe every one.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL694" id="TINL694" class="pginternal">694</a>. <i>The wyse</i>, Solomon; see Eccles. iv. 10.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL699" id="TINL699" class="pginternal">699</a>. <i>Niobe</i>; 'lacrimas etiamnum marmora manant;' Ovid,
  Met. vi. 311.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL705" id="TINL705" class="pginternal">705</a>. 'That eke out (increase) their sorrows,' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL707" id="TINL707" class="pginternal">707</a>. 'And care not to seek for themselves another cure.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL708" id="TINL708" class="pginternal">708</a>. A proverb; see note to Can. Yem. Ta. G 746.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page466">{466}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIL713" id="TINL713" class="pginternal">713</a>. <i>harde grace</i>, misfortune; cf. Cant. Ta. G 665,
  1189. Tyrwhitt quotes Euripides, Herc. Furens, 1250: <span class="fsn" title="Gemô kakôn dê, kouket' esth' hopou tethê">Γέμω
  κακῶν δή, κὀυκέτ'
  ἐσθ' ὅπου τεθῇ</span>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL730" id="TINL730" class="pginternal">730, 731</a>. From Boethius, Bk. I. Pr. 2. l. 14, and Pr. 4. l.
  2.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL739" id="TINL739" class="pginternal">739</a>. 'On whose account he fared so.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL740" id="TINL740" class="pginternal">740</a>. Compare: 'He makes a rod for his own breech'; Hazlitt's
  Proverbs.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL745" id="TINL745" class="pginternal">745</a>. 'For it (love) would sufficiently spring to light of
  itself.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL747" id="TINL747" class="pginternal">747</a>. Cf. Rom. de la Rose, 7595-6.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL763" id="TINL763" class="pginternal">763</a>. 'But they do not care to seek a remedy.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL780" id="TINL780" class="pginternal">780</a>. Pronounced <i>ben'cite</i>; see note to Cant. Ta. B
  1170.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL786" id="TINL786" class="pginternal">786</a>. <i>Ticius</i>, Tityos. MS. H2. wrongly has
  <i>Siciphus</i>. 'The fowl that highte <i>voltor</i>, that eteth the stomak or the giser of
  Tityus, is so fulfild of his song that it nil eten ne tyren no more;' tr. of Boeth. Bk. III. Met.
  12. 28. The original has:</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Vultur, dum satur est modis,</p>
<p>Non traxit Tityi iecur.'</p>
</div>
<p>See also Verg. Æn. vi. 595; Ovid, Met. iv. 456.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL811" id="TINL811" class="pginternal">811</a>. First foot deficient, as in ll. 603, 1051, 1069,
  &amp;c. <i>winter</i>, years. Perhaps imitated from Le Rom. de la Rose, 21145-9.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL846" id="TINL846" class="pginternal">846, 847</a>. See Boethius, Bk. ii. Pr. 3. 52-54.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL848" id="TINL848" class="pginternal">848</a>. From Boethius, Lib. II. Pr. 1: 'si manere incipit, fors
  esse desistit.' See p. 26 above, l. 83.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL887" id="TINL887" class="pginternal">887</a>. 'And, to augment all this the more.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL890" id="TINL890" class="pginternal">890-966</a>. This is all Chaucer's own; so also 994-1008.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL916" id="TINL916" class="pginternal">916</a>. <i>a blaunche fevere</i>, a fever that turns men white;
  said jocosely. Lovers were supposed to be pale; Ovid, Art. Am. i. 729. Cotgrave is somewhat more
  precise. He gives: '<i>Fievres blanches</i>, the agues wherewith maidens that have the green
  sickness are troubled; hence, <i>Il a les fievres blanches</i>, either he is in love, or sick of
  wantonness.' In the Cuckoo and the Nightingale, l. 41, we find: 'I am so shaken with <i>the
  feveres white</i>.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL932" id="TINL932" class="pginternal">932</a>. <i>beet</i>; beat thy breast (to shew thy repentance).
  Cf. P. Plowm. B. v. 454.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL956" id="TINL956" class="pginternal">956</a>. A proverb. 'The more haste, the worse speed (success).'
  Cf. Bk. iii. 1567, and The Tale of Melibeus, B 2244.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL964" id="TINL964" class="pginternal">964</a>. Dr. Köppel says—cf. Albertano of Brescia, Liber
  de Amore Dei, 45b: 'Iam et Seneca dixit, Non conualescit planta, quae saepe transfertur.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL969" id="TINL969" class="pginternal">969</a>. 'A bon port estes arrivés'; Rom. de la Rose, 12964.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL977" id="TINL977" class="pginternal">977</a>. Fil. ii. st. 27: 'Io credo certo, ch' ogni donna in
  voglia Viva amorosa.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL1000" id="TINL1000" class="pginternal">1000</a>. <i>post</i>, pillar, support; as in Prol. A 214.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL1002" id="TINL1002" class="pginternal">1002</a>. Cf. 'The greater the sinner, the greater the
  saint.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL1011" id="TINL1011" class="pginternal">1011</a>. Understand <i>he</i>. 'He became, as one may say,
  untormented of his wo.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL1024" id="TINL1024" class="pginternal">1024</a>. <i>cherl</i>, man. 'You are afraid the man will fall
  out of the moon!' Alluding to the old notion that the spots on the moon's surface <span class="pagenum" id="page467">{467}</span>represent a man with a bundle of sticks. See the curious
  poem on this subject in Wright's Specimens of Lyric Poetry, p. 110; also printed in Ritson's
  Ancient Songs, i. 68, and in Böddeker's Altenglische Dichtungen, p. 176, where a fear is expressed
  that the man may fall out of the moon. Cf. Temp. ii. 2. 141; Mids. Nt. Dr. v. 1. 249; and see
  Alex. Neckam, ed. Wright, pp. xviii, 54.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL1026" id="TINL1026" class="pginternal">1026</a>. 'Why, meddle with that which really concerns you,'
  i.e. mind your own business. Some copies needlessly turn this into a question and insert <i>ne</i>
  before <i>hast</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL1038" id="TINL1038" class="pginternal">1038</a>. 'And am I to be thy surety?'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL1050" id="TINL1050" class="pginternal">1050</a>. <i>Scan</i>: 'And yet m' athink'th ... m'asterte.'
  The sense is: 'And yet it repents me that this boast should escape me.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIL1051" id="TINL1051" class="pginternal">1051</a>. Deficient in the first foot: 'Now | Pandáre.' So in
  l. 1069.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL1052" id="TINL1052" class="pginternal">1052</a>. 'But thou, being wise, thou knowest,' &amp;c. In
  this line, <i>thou</i> seems to be emphatic throughout.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL1058" id="TINL1058" class="pginternal">1058</a>. Read <i>désiróus</i>; as in Book ii. 1101, and Sq.
  Ta. F 23.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL1070" id="TINL1070" class="pginternal">1070</a>. <i>Pandare</i> is here trisyllabic; with unelided
  <i>-e</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIL1078" id="TINL1078" class="pginternal">1078</a>. The same line occurs in the Clerk. Ta. E 413.</p>
<p class="sp3"><a href="#TIL1088" id="TINL1088" class="pginternal">1088</a>. 'And is partly well eased of the aching
  of his wound, yet is none the more healed; and, like an easy patient (i.e. a patient not in pain),
  awaits (lit. abides) the prescription of him that tries to cure him; and thus he perseveres in his
  destiny.' <i>Dryveth forth</i> means 'goes on with,' or 'goes through with.' The reading
  <i>dryeth</i>, i.e. endures, is out of place here, as it implies suffering; whereas, at the
  present stage, Troilus is extremely hopeful.</p>

<p>Other passages are mainly original; as, e.g. ll. 1352-1757 at the end, and 1-264 at the
  beginning.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page468">{468}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIIL1" id="TIINL1" class="pginternal">1-3</a>. These lines somewhat resemble Dante, Purgat. i. 1-3.</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Per correr miglior acqua alza le vele</p>
<p>Omai la navicella del mio ingegno,</p>
<p>Che lascia dietro a sè mar sì crudele;' &amp;c.</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#TIIL7" id="TIINL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>calendes</i>, the introduction to the beginning; see bk.
  v. l. 1634. Thus the 'kalends of January' precede that month, being the period from Dec. 14 to
  Dec. 31.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL8" id="TIINL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. <i>Cleo</i>; so in most copies; H2. has <i>Clyo</i>; Clio,
  the muse of history.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL14" id="TIINL14" class="pginternal">14</a>. <i>Latin</i> seems, in this case, to mean Italian, which
  was called <i>Latino volgare</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL21" id="TIINL21" class="pginternal">21</a>. 'A blind man cannot judge well of colours;' a
  proverb.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL22" id="TIINL22" class="pginternal">22</a>. Doubtless from Horace's Ars Poetica, 71-3; probably
  borrowed at second-hand.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL28" id="TIINL28" class="pginternal">28</a>. A proverb. In the Proverbs of Hendyng, l. 29, we have:
  'Ase fele thede, ase fele thewes,' i.e. so many peoples, so many customs. See l. 42 below. Cf.
  Boethius, Bk. ii. Pr. 7. 49 (p. 47).</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL36" id="TIINL36" class="pginternal">36</a>. <i>went</i>, for <i>wendeth</i>; i.e. goes; pres.
  tense.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL46" id="TIINL46" class="pginternal">46</a>. 'Yet all is told, or must be told.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL48" id="TIINL48" class="pginternal">48</a>. <i>bitit</i>, for <i>bitydeth</i>; i.e. betides,
  happens.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL55" id="TIINL55" class="pginternal">55</a>. <i>Bole</i>, Bull, the sign Taurus. On the third of May,
  in Chaucer's time, the sun would be in about the 20th degree of Taurus. The epithet <i>white</i>
  is from Ovid, Met. ii. 852.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL63" id="TIINL63" class="pginternal">63</a>. <i>wente</i>, sb., a turn; i.e. he tossed about.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL64" id="TIINL64" class="pginternal">64-68</a>. <i>forshapen</i>, metamorphosed. Progne was changed
  into a swallow; Ovid, Met. vi. 668. Tereus carried off Progne's sister Philomela; see Leg. of Good
  Women (Philomela).</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL74" id="TIINL74" class="pginternal">74</a>. 'And knew that the moon was in a good plight (position)
  for him to take his journey.' That is, the moon's position was propitious; see note to Man of
  Lawes Tale, B 312.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL77" id="TIINL77" class="pginternal">77</a>. '<i>Janus</i>, god of (the) entry;' see Ovid, Fasti, i.
  125.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL81" id="TIINL81" class="pginternal">81</a>. 'And found (that) she and two other ladies were
  sitting.' <i>Sete</i> (A. S. <i>sǣton</i>) is the pt. t. pl., not the pp.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL84" id="TIINL84" class="pginternal">84</a>. The celebrated story of the Siege of Thebes, known to
  Chaucer through the Thebais of Statius; see bk. v. 1484. And see l. 100.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL87" id="TIINL87" class="pginternal">87</a>. <i>Ey</i>, eh! a note of exclamation, of frequent
  occurrence in the present poem.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL103" id="TIINL103" class="pginternal">103</a>. <i>lettres rede</i>, i.e. the rubric describing the
  contents of the next section.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL100" id="TIINL100" class="pginternal">100-105</a>. Œdipus unwittingly slew his father Laius;
  and the two sons of Œdipus contended for Thebes. For <i>Amphiorax</i>, see note to bk. v.
  1500, and to Anelida, 57.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL108" id="TIINL108" class="pginternal">108</a>. <i>bokes twelve</i>; the 12 Books of the Thebais. The
  death of Amphioraus is related at the end of Book vii.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL110" id="TIINL110" class="pginternal">110</a>. <i>barbe</i>, 'part of a woman's dress, still
  sometimes worn by nuns, consisting of a piece of white plaited linen, passed over or under the
  chin, and reaching midway to the waist;' New E. Dict. She wore it <span class="pagenum" id="page469">{469}</span>because she was a widow; see the quotations in the New E. Dict., esp.
  'wearing of <i>barbes</i> at funerals.' And see <i>Barbuta</i> in Ducange.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL112" id="TIINL112" class="pginternal">112</a>. 'Let us perform some rite in honour of May;' see note
  to Kn. Ta. A 1500.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL117" id="TIINL117" class="pginternal">117</a>. The right reading is necessarily <i>sete</i>, for A.
  S. <i>sǣte</i>, 3 p. s. pt. t. subj. of <i>sitten</i>; 'it would befit.' Cf. <i>seten</i>,
  they sat, 81, 1192.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL134" id="TIINL134" class="pginternal">134</a>. 'And I am your surety,' i.e. you may depend upon me;
  see bk. i. 1038.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL151" id="TIINL151" class="pginternal">151</a>. <i>unkouth</i>, unknown, strange; hence, very; Sc.
  <i>unco'</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL154" id="TIINL154" class="pginternal">154</a>. <i>wal</i>, wall, defence; <i>yerde</i>, rod,
  scourge, as in bk. i. 740.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL167" id="TIINL167" class="pginternal">167</a>. From Le Rom. de la Rose, 5684-6<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Lucan redit, qui moult fu sages,</p>
<p>C'onques <i>vertu et grant pooir</i></p>
<p>Ne pot nus <i>ensemble veoir</i>.'</p>
</div>
<p>Cf. Lucan, Phar. i. 92.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL236" id="TIINL236" class="pginternal">236</a>. <i>Withoute</i>, excepting sweethearts; or, excepting
  by way of passionate love. The latter is the usual sense in Chaucer.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL273" id="TIINL273" class="pginternal">273</a>. 'Therefore I will endeavour to humour her
  intelligence.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL294" id="TIINL294" class="pginternal">294</a>. <i>so well bigoon</i>, so well bestead, so fortunate.
  Cf. Parl. Foules, 171.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL318" id="TIINL318" class="pginternal">318</a>. <i>Which ... his</i>, whose; cf. <i>that ... his</i>,
  Kn. Ta. A 2710.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL328" id="TIINL328" class="pginternal">328</a>. 'Then you have fished to some purpose;' ironical. To
  <i>fish fair</i> is to catch many fish.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL329" id="TIINL329" class="pginternal">329</a>. <i>What mende ye</i>, what do you gain, though we
  both lose?</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL344" id="TIINL344" class="pginternal">344</a>. Gems were supposed to have hidden virtues.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL387" id="TIINL387" class="pginternal">387</a>. <i>fele</i>, find out, investigate.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL391" id="TIINL391" class="pginternal">391, 2</a>. Cf. Ovid, Art. Amat. ii. 107: 'Ut ameris, amabilis
  esto.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL393" id="TIINL393" class="pginternal">393</a>. In the same, 113, we find: 'Forma bonum fragile est,'
  &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL396" id="TIINL396" class="pginternal">396</a>. 'Go and love; for, when old, no one will have
  you.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL398" id="TIINL398" class="pginternal">398</a>. 'I am warned too late, when it has past away, quoth
  Beauty.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL400" id="TIINL400" class="pginternal">400</a>. The 'king's fool' got the hint from Ovid, Art. Amat.
  ii. 118: 'Iam uenient rugae,' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL403" id="TIINL403" class="pginternal">403</a>. <i>crowes feet</i>, crow's feet; wrinkles at the
  corners of the eyes; from the shape. So in Spenser, Shep. Kal. <i>December</i>, 136: 'And by myne
  eie the crow his clawe doth write.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL408" id="TIINL408" class="pginternal">408</a>. <i>breste a wepe</i>, burst out a-weeping.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL413" id="TIINL413" class="pginternal">413</a>. <i>Ret</i>, for <i>redeth</i>, advises; cf. P.
  Plowman C. iv. 410, and note.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL425" id="TIINL425" class="pginternal">425</a>. <i>Pallas</i>; perhaps invoked with reference to the
  Palladium of Troy; bk. I. l. 153. Moreover, Pallas was a virgin goddess.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL434" id="TIINL434" class="pginternal">434</a>. 'Of me no consideration need be taken.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL477" id="TIINL477" class="pginternal">477</a>. 'Except that I will not give him encouragement;' see
  1222.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL483" id="TIINL483" class="pginternal">483</a>. 'But when the cause ceases, the disease ceases.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL507" id="TIINL507" class="pginternal">507</a>. <i>gon</i>, gone; 'not very long ago.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL525" id="TIINL525" class="pginternal">525</a>. <i>mea culpa</i>, by my fault; words used in
  confession: see P. Plowman, B. v. 77, and note.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL527" id="TIINL527" class="pginternal">527</a>. <i>Ledest the fyn</i>, guidest the end; cf. Boeth.
  Bk. iv. Pr. 6. 149.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL537" id="TIINL537" class="pginternal">537</a>. <i>biwryen</i>, used in place of <i>biwreyen</i>, to
  bewray. The same rather arbitrary form appears in Parl. Foules, 348.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page470">{470}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIIL539" id="TIINL539" class="pginternal">539</a>. 'Because men cover them up,' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL586" id="TIINL586" class="pginternal">586</a>. <i>were never</i>, never would be; <i>were</i> is in
  the subjunctive mood.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL611" id="TIINL611" class="pginternal">611</a>. <i>Thascry</i>, for <i>The ascry</i>, the alarm.
  <i>Ascry</i> occurs in Wyclif, Prov. vii. 6.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL615" id="TIINL615" class="pginternal">615</a>. <i>latis</i>, lattice. The reading <i>yates</i>,
  gates, is wrong, as shewn by l. 617.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL618" id="TIINL618" class="pginternal">618</a>. Dardanus, ancestor of Priam. Cf. <i>Dardanidae</i>,
  i. e. Trojans, Verg. Aen. i. 560, ii. 72, &amp;c. Troy had six gates, according to Guido; the
  strongest of these was <i>Dardanus</i>; see the allit. Destruction of Troy, ed. Panton and
  Donaldson, l. 1557, Lydgate, Siege of Troy, b. ii. c. 11, and Shakespeare's Prologue to his
  Troilus.</p>
<p><i>ther open is the cheyne</i>, where the chain is open, or unfastened. Alluding to the chains
  sometimes drawn across a street, to block it against horsemen. The sense is, 'he will come down
  <i>this</i> street, because the others are blocked.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL621" id="TIINL621" class="pginternal">621</a>. <i>happy</i>, fortunate. It was a lucky day for
  him.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL627" id="TIINL627" class="pginternal">627</a>. <i>a pas</i>, at a foot-pace; see Prol. A 825, and l.
  620 above.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL637" id="TIINL637" class="pginternal">637</a>. <i>an heven</i>, a beautiful sight; cf. Sq. Ta. F
  558.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL639" id="TIINL639" class="pginternal">639</a>. <i>tissew</i>, lace, twisted band; from F.
  <i>tistre</i>, to weave.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL642" id="TIINL642" class="pginternal">642</a>. The shield was covered with horn, sinews or
  <i>nerf</i>, and skin or <i>rind</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL651" id="TIINL651" class="pginternal">651</a>. 'Who has given me a love-potion?'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL656" id="TIINL656" class="pginternal">656</a>. <i>for pure ashamed</i>, for being completely
  ashamed, i.e. for very shame. A curious idiom.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL666" id="TIINL666" class="pginternal">666</a>. <i>envýous</i>, envious person; accented on <i>y</i>,
  as in l. 857.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL677" id="TIINL677" class="pginternal">677</a>. <i>Ma | de</i>; two syllables. The first foot is
  imperfect.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL681" id="TIINL681" class="pginternal">681</a>. The astrological term 'house' has two senses; it
  sometimes means a zodiacal sign, as when, e.g. Taurus is called the 'house' or mansion of Venus;
  and sometimes it has another sense, as, probably, in the present passage. See Chaucer's treatise
  on the Astrolabe, pt. ii. § 37, on 'the equations of houses.' In the latter case, the whole
  celestial sphere was divided into twelve equal parts, called 'houses,' by great circles passing
  through the north and south points of the horizon. The first of these, reckoning upwards from the
  eastern horizon, was called the <i>first</i> house, and the <i>seventh</i> house, being opposite
  to it, was reckoned downwards from the western horizon. The <i>first</i> and <i>seventh</i> houses
  were both considered very fortunate; and it is here said that Venus was in her seventh house, i.e.
  was just below the western horizon at the moment when Criseyde first saw him. The same planet was
  also 'well disposed,' i.e. in a favourable sign of the zodiac; and at the same time was 'pleased
  (or made propitious) by favourable aspects' of other planets, i.e. other planets were favourably
  situated as regards their angular distances from Venus. Moreover, Venus was no foe to Troilus in
  his nativity, i.e. she was also favourably situated at the moment of his birth.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL716" id="TIINL716" class="pginternal">716</a>. Imitated from Le Rom. de la Rose, 5765-9, q.v.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL746" id="TIINL746" class="pginternal">746</a>. 'I am one (who is) the fairest.' The <i>-e</i> in
  <i>fairest-e</i> is not elided; neither is the <i>-e</i> in <i>wist-e</i> in l. 745.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page471">{471}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIIL750" id="TIINL750" class="pginternal">750</a>. I.e. 'I am my own mistress.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL752" id="TIINL752" class="pginternal">752</a>. <i>lese</i>, pasture; 'I stand, unfastened, in a
  pleasant pasture.' From A. S. <i>lǣsu</i>. Cf. Ho. Fame, 1768. It does not mean 'leash,' as
  usually said; Chaucer's form of 'leash' is <i>lees</i>, as in Cant. Ta. G 19.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL754" id="TIINL754" class="pginternal">754</a>. <i>chekmat</i>, check-mate, as in chess; see Book
  Duch. 659. Bell sees a pun in it; '<i>check</i> to my <i>mate</i>,' i.e. wife; but it remains to
  be shewn that the form <i>mate</i> (wife) was known to Chaucer, who spells it <i>make</i> (Cant.
  Ta. E 2080).</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL759" id="TIINL759" class="pginternal">759</a>. I.e. 'I am not a nun,' nor vowed to chastity.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL767" id="TIINL767" class="pginternal">767, 769</a>. <i>sprat</i>, for <i>spredeth</i>, spreads,

<p><a href="#TIIL777" id="TIINL777" class="pginternal">777</a>. According to Bell, MS. Harl. 1239 also has

<p><a href="#TIIL830" id="TIINL830" class="pginternal">830</a>. <i>hertes lust</i>, heart's pleasure; <i>to
  rente</i>, by way of rent.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL831" id="TIINL831" class="pginternal">831</a>. <i>no wight</i>, to no one; dat. case.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL861" id="TIINL861" class="pginternal">861</a>. See Hazlitt's notes on the proverb—'Many talk
  of Robin Hood, that never shot in his bow,' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL866" id="TIINL866" class="pginternal">866</a>. 'Who cannot endure sorrow deserves no joy.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL867" id="TIINL867" class="pginternal">867</a>. 'And therefore let him, who has a glass head, beware

<p><a href="#TIIL882" id="TIINL882" class="pginternal">882</a>. <i>let</i>, short for <i>ledeth</i>, leads
  (Stratmann).</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL884" id="TIINL884" class="pginternal">884</a>. The MSS. end the line with <i>syke</i>. It has been
  pointed out that <i>syke</i> is not a perfect rime to <i>endyte</i>, <i>whyte</i>, but only an
  assonance. It is difficult to believe Chaucer guilty of this oversight; and hence I would suggest,
  with all submission to the critics, that possibly Chaucer wrote <i>syte</i>. The M. E. <i>syte</i>
  means to be anxious, and occurs in the Cursor Mundi, 11675; where Joseph says to Mary:—'Bot
  I <i>site</i> for an other thing That we o water has nu wanting,' i.e. but I am anxious about
  another thing, that we lack water. The sb. <i>site</i>, grief, occurs in the Midland dialect as
  well as in Northumbrian; see <i>site</i> in Stratmann. As the word is unusual, it would naturally
  be altered by the scribes to the familiar <i>syke</i>, to sigh, with a cognate meaning.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL920" id="TIINL920" class="pginternal">920</a>. 'And loude he song ageyn the sonne shene;' Kn. Ta. A
  1509.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL959" id="TIINL959" class="pginternal">959</a>. 'Unless lack of pursuit is the cause (of failure),'
  &amp;c.; cf. 1075.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL964" id="TIINL964" class="pginternal">964</a>. <i>hameled</i>, cut off, docked; cf. P. Pl. Crede,
  300.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1001" id="TIINL1001" class="pginternal">1001</a>. 'Your ill hap is not owing to me.'</p>

  emphatic.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1022" id="TIINL1022" class="pginternal">1022</a>. When people's ears glow, it is because they are
  being talked of; according to folk-lore. See Brand's Popular Antiquities, ed. Ellis, iii. 171.</p>

<p><a href="#TIIL1033" id="TIINL1033" class="pginternal">1033</a>. 'Or always harp one tune.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1041" id="TIINL1041" class="pginternal">1041</a>. 'Humano capiti,' &amp;c.; Horace, Ars Poet. 1-5.

<p><a href="#TIIL1075" id="TIINL1075" class="pginternal">1075-7</a>. <i>it made</i>, was the cause of it. <i>ley</i>,
  lied.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1107" id="TIINL1107" class="pginternal">1107</a>. <i>hoppe</i>, dance. 'I always dance in the
  rear.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1108" id="TIINL1108" class="pginternal">1108</a>. <i>to-laugh</i> (H2, <i>to lagh</i>, Cm. <i>to
  law</i>), laughed exceedingly. I know of no other example. A better form is <i>to-lough</i>; see
  l. 1163, and Pard. Ta. C 476.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1119" id="TIINL1119" class="pginternal">1119</a>. <i>spek-e</i>, might speak, should say; pt. t.

<p><a href="#TIIL1123" id="TIINL1123" class="pginternal">1123</a>. <i>sent</i>, i. e. <i>sendeth</i>, sends; the
  pt. t. is <i>sent-e</i> or <i>send-e</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1177" id="TIINL1177" class="pginternal">1177-8</a>. <i>Avysed</i>, she took notice; pt. tense. So
  also <i>fond</i>, found, which Bell takes to be a pp.; but the pp. is <i>founden</i>. <i>Coude
  good</i>, knew what was becoming. So, in l. 1197, <i>Can he</i> means 'has he skill.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1201" id="TIINL1201" class="pginternal">1201, 1204</a>. <i>sowe</i>, to sew the pieces of parchment
  together. Tyrwhitt remarks, s. v. <i>sowe</i>; 'It was usual, and indeed necessary, formerly to
  <i>sew</i> letters, when they were written upon parchment; but the practice continued long after
  the invention of paper.' <i>plyte</i>, to fold it up.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1229" id="TIINL1229" class="pginternal">1229</a>. 'A cushion, beaten with gold;' cf. Kn. Ta. A
  979.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1238" id="TIINL1238" class="pginternal">1238</a>. A proverb: 'slight impressions soon fade.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1249" id="TIINL1249" class="pginternal">1249</a>. Tyrwhitt, s. v. <i>somme</i>, boggles over this
  line, but it is quite right. Bell takes occasion to speak of the 'rugged lines' to be found in
  this poem; which is true enough of his own peculiar text. In Beowulf, l. 207, we have
  <i>fiftēna sum</i>, one of fifteen, where the cardinal number is used; and this is the
  usual idiom. But the ordinal number is used also. In St. Juliana, p. 79, we read that 'te sea
  sencte him on his <i>thrituthe sum</i>,' the sea drowned him and 'thirtieth some' of his men,
  which I understand to mean 'and twenty-nine of his men,' the master being the thirtieth; but Mr.
  Cockayne and Mr. Bradley make it mean 'him and thirty others.' So again, in Sir Tristrem, 817, we
  have: 'He busked and made him yare hi[s] <i>fiftend som</i> of knight,' he made ready for himself
  his 'fifteenth some' of knights, which I should explain to mean a band of fifteen knights,
  <i>himself included</i>, or, himself being the fifteenth. <i>Some</i> in such phrases has a
  collective force. However, the examples in Bosworth and Toller's A. S. Dict., s. v. <i>sum</i>,
  shew that this mode of expression is also sometimes used <i>exclusively</i> of the leader.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1274" id="TIINL1274" class="pginternal">1274</a>. <i>on to pyke</i>, for her to pick upon, or pick
  at; i. e. for her to pull out; see l. 1273. See examples in Halliwell, s. v. <i>pike</i>, of
  'to <i>pyke out</i> thornes,' to pick out thorns.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1276" id="TIINL1276" class="pginternal">1276</a>. Cf. 'to strike while the iron is hot;' see
  Melibeus, B 2226.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1289" id="TIINL1289" class="pginternal">1289</a>. 'But therein he had much to heave at and to
  do.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1291" id="TIINL1291" class="pginternal">1291</a>. 'And why? for fear of shame.' Cm. has <i>for
  speche</i>, i. e. for fear of talk or scandal.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1315" id="TIINL1315" class="pginternal">1315</a>. <i>accesse</i>, attack, as of fever. See New E.
  Dict.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page473">{473}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIIL1343" id="TIINL1343" class="pginternal">1343</a>. <i>refreyde</i>, grow cool; cf. Balade to
  Rosemounde, l. 21.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1349" id="TIINL1349" class="pginternal">1349</a>. <i>after his gestes</i>, according to his deeds,
  or adventures.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1390" id="TIINL1390" class="pginternal">1390</a>. <i>forbyse</i>, to give (thee) instances. Hardly a
  correct form; it should rather be <i>forbysne</i>, short for <i>forbysnen</i>, as the verb is
  formed from the sb. <i>forbysne</i>, A. S. <i>forebȳsen</i>, an example, instance. The word
  was obsolescent.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1398" id="TIINL1398" class="pginternal">1398</a>. <i>Deiphebus</i> (= <i>Dé'phĕbús)</i> is
  always trisyllabic.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1410" id="TIINL1410" class="pginternal">1410</a>. He means that he would do more for him than for
  any one, 'except for him whom he loves most,' i. e. Troilus.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1427" id="TIINL1427" class="pginternal">1427</a>. 'With spur and whip,' i. e. with all
  expedition.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1495" id="TIINL1495" class="pginternal">1495</a>. <i>word and ende</i>, beginning and end; cf. iii.
  702, v. 1669. The right phrase is <i>ord and ende</i>, where <i>ord</i> is 'beginning;' but it
  would seem that, by Chaucer's time, <i>word</i> had been corruptly substituted for the obsolescent
  <i>ord</i>. See Monk. Ta. B 3911, and the note.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1534" id="TIINL1534" class="pginternal">1534</a>. <i>triste</i>, station for a huntsman to shoot
  from. See <i>Tristre</i> in Stratmann.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1554" id="TIINL1554" class="pginternal">1554</a>. <i>renne</i>, to run, like an excited madman.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1564" id="TIINL1564" class="pginternal">1564</a>. 'Bon fait prolixite foïr;' Rom. de la Rose,
  18498.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1581" id="TIINL1581" class="pginternal">1581</a>. 'Although it does not please her to recommend (a

<p><a href="#TIIL1594" id="TIINL1594" class="pginternal">1594</a>. <i>To mowen</i>, to have it in her power; A. S.
  <i>mugan</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1650" id="TIINL1650" class="pginternal">1650</a>. <i>for my bettre arm</i>, not even to save my
  right arm.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1661" id="TIINL1661" class="pginternal">1661</a>. <i>him thar nought</i>, 'him needeth not,' he need
  not do.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1735" id="TIINL1735" class="pginternal">1735</a>. An obscure allusion. 'Perhaps it means, in regard
  for the king and queen, his parents;' Bell. My own guess is different. I think it quite possible
  that Chaucer is referring to the two 'crowns' or garlands, one of roses and one of lilies, about
  which so much is said in his early work entitled the <i>Lyf of Seint Cecile</i>, afterwards called
  the Second Nonnes Tale (see G 270). Thus Pandarus, with his usual impudence, conjures Criseyde to
  pity Troilus by two solemn adjurations, viz. for the sake of Him who gave us all our souls, and by
  the virtue of the two heavenly crowns which an angel once brought <i>to a chaste couple</i>. He
  thus boldly insinuates that the proposed meeting is of the most innocent character. This I take to
  be the whole point of the allusion.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1737" id="TIINL1737" class="pginternal">1737</a>. 'Fie on the devil!' I. e. despise
  detraction.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1738" id="TIINL1738" class="pginternal">1738</a>. <i>com of</i>, come off; we <i>now</i> say 'come
  on!' See ll. 1742, 1750.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIL1751" id="TIINL1751" class="pginternal">1751</a>. 'But now (I appeal) to you.'</p>
<p class="sp3"><a href="#TIIL1752" id="TIINL1752" class="pginternal">1752</a>. <i>cankedort</i>, a state of suspense,
  uncertainty, or anxiety; as appears from the context. The word occurs nowhere else. Only one MS.
  (H2) has the spelling <i>kankerdort</i>, usually adopted in modern editions; Thynne has
  <i>cankedorte</i>, but it needs no final <i>e</i>. The etymology is unknown nor do we even know
  how to divide it. There is a verb <i>kanka</i>, to shake, be unsteady, &amp;c., in Swedish
  dialects (Rietz), and the Swed. <i>ort</i> is a place, quarter; if there is any relationship,
  <i>kanked-ort</i> might mean 'shaky place,' or ticklish position. Another theory is that
  <i>canker</i> relates to <i>canker</i>, a cancer, disease, and that <i>dort</i> is related to
  Lowl. Sc. <i>dort</i>, sulkiness. But this is assuming <span class="pagenum" id="page474">{474}</span>that the right spelling is <i>canker-dort</i>, a theory which the MSS. do
  not favour. Neither does the sense of 'ill-humour' seem very suitable. As I am bound, in this
  difficult case, to suggest what I can, I must add that it is also possible to suppose that
  <i>cankedort</i> is of French origin, answering to an O. F. <i>quant que dort</i>, lit. 'whenever
  he is asleep (?),' or 'although he is asleep(?);' and hence (conceivably) meaning 'in a sleepy
  state.' The phrase <i>quant que</i>, also spelt <i>kan ke</i> (and in many other ways) is
  illustrated by a column of examples in Godefroy's Dictionary; but its usual sense is 'as well as,'
  or 'whatever'; thus <i>kan ke poet</i> = as well as he can. Or can we make it = <i>com ki
  dort</i>, like one who sleeps?</p>
<h2>BOOK III.</h2>
<p>The following scheme gives a general idea of the relationship of this Book to the original.</p>
<table class="sp2 mc" title="Correspondence with Filostrato, Book III" data-summary="Correspondence with Filostrato, Book III">
