<p><a href="#TIIIL1" id="TIIINL1" class="pginternal">1-38</a>. This is an exceptionally difficult passage, and some
  of the editions make great nonsense of it, especially of ll. 15-21. It is, however, imitated from
  stanzas 74-79 of the Filostrato, Book III; where the invocation is put into the mouth of
  Troilus.</p>
<p>The key to it is that it is an address to <i>Venus</i>, both the planet and the goddess.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL2" id="TIIINL2" class="pginternal">2</a>. The planet Venus was considered to be in 'the
  <i>third</i> heaven.' The 'heavens' or spheres were named, respectively, after the Moon, Mercury,
  Venus, Sun, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, and the 'fixed stars;' beyond which was the Primum Mobile, the
  earth being in the centre of all, and immoveable. Sometimes the spheres of the seven planets were
  reckoned backwards from Saturn, Venus being then in the <i>fifth</i> heaven; see Lenvoy a Scogan,
  9, and the note.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page475">{475}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIIIL3" id="TIIINL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. 'O favourite of the Sun, O dear daughter of Jove!' Venus
  was considered a fortunate planet. Perhaps it is best to quote the Italian text here<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem poemc35">
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">585</div>
</div>
<p class="lined" style="margin-left:-0.20em">'O luce eterna, il cui lieto splendore</p>
<p>Fa bello il terzo ciel, dal qual ne piove</p>
<p>Piacer, vaghezza, pietade ed amore;</p>
<p>Del sole amica, e figliuola di Giove,</p>
<p>Benigna donna d'ogni gentil core,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">590</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Certa cagion del valor che mi muove</p>
<p>A' sospir dolci della mia salute,</p>
<p>Sempre lodata sia la tua virtute.</p>
<p class="stanza">Il ciel, la terra, lo mare e l'inferno</p>
<p>Ciascuno in sè la tua potenzia sente,</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">595</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">O chiara luce; e s'io il ver discerno,</p>
<p>Le piante, i semi, e l'erbe puramente,</p>
<p>Gli uccei, le fiere, i pesci con eterno</p>
<p>Vapor ti senton nel tempo piacente,</p>
<p>E gli uomini e gli dei, nè creatura</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">600</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Senza di te nel mondo vale o dura.</p>
<p class="stanza">Tu Giove prima agli alti affetti lieto,</p>
<p>Pe' qua' vivono e son tutte le cose,</p>
<p>Movesti, o bella dea; e mansueto</p>
<p>Sovente il rendi all' opere noiose</p>
<div class="rel">
<div class="linenum35">605</div>
</div>
<p class="lined">Di noi mortali; e il meritato fleto</p>
<p>In liete feste volgi e dilettose;</p>
<p>E in mille forme già quaggiù il mandasti,</p>
<p>Quand' ora d'una ed or d'altra il pregasti.</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#TIIIL11" id="TIIINL11" class="pginternal">11</a>. <i>vapour</i>, influence; Ital. <i>Vapor</i> (l.
  598).</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL15" id="TIIINL15" class="pginternal">15</a>. The readings in this stanza are settled by the Ital.
  text. Thus, in ll. 17, 19, 20, read <i>him</i>, not <i>hem</i>. <i>Comeveden</i>, didst move or
  instigate; agreeing with <i>ye</i>, for which Mod. E. uses <i>thou</i>. 'Thou didst first
  instigate Jove to those glad effects (influences), through which all things live and exist; and
  didst make him amorous of mortal things; and, at thy pleasure, didst ever give him, in love,
  success or trouble; and, in a thousand forms, didst send him down to (gain) love on earth; and he
  caught those whom it pleased you (he should catch).'</p>
<p>In l. 17 we find <i>Comeveden</i> sometimes turned into <i>Comenden</i>, or even
  <i>Commodious</i>! The Italian text has <i>Movesti</i> (l. 603).</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL22" id="TIIINL22" class="pginternal">22</a>. Venus was supposed to appease the angry planet Mars;
  see Compl. of Mars, 36-42.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL27" id="TIIINL27" class="pginternal">27</a>. 'According as a man wishes.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL29" id="TIIINL29" class="pginternal">29</a>. 'Tu in unità le case e li cittadi, Li regni, ...
  Tien.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL31" id="TIIINL31" class="pginternal">31-34</a>.</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Tu sola le nascosi qualitadi</p>
<p>Delle cose conosci, onde 'l costrutto</p>
<p>Vi metti tal, che fai maravigliare</p>
<p>Chi tua potenza non sa riguardare.'</p>
</div>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page476">{476}</span></div>
<p>I. e. 'Thou only knowest the hidden qualities of things, whence thou formest such a
  construction, that thou makest to marvel any one who knows not how to estimate thy power.' Chaucer
  seems to have used <i>construe</i> because suggested by <i>costrutto</i>, but he really uses it as
  answering to <i>sa</i> (in the fourth line), and omits the words <i>'l costrutto vi metti tal</i>
  altogether. Hence ll. 33-35 mean: 'when they cannot explain how it may come to pass that
  <i>she</i> loves <i>him</i>, or why <i>he</i> loves <i>her</i>; (so as to shew) why <i>this</i>
  fish, and not <i>that</i> one, comes to the weir.'</p>
<p><i>Io</i> (= <i>jo</i>), come to pass. This word is not in the dictionaries, and has been
  coolly altered into <i>go</i> (!) in various editions. But it answers to O. F. <i>joer</i> (F.
  <i>jouer</i>), to play, hence, to play a game, to make a move (as in a game); here, to come about,
  come to pass.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL35" id="TIIINL35" class="pginternal">35</a>. <i>were</i>, weir, pool where fish are caught; see
  Parl. Foules, 138, and note.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL36" id="TIIINL36" class="pginternal">36</a>. 'You have imposed a law on folks in this universe;'
  Ital. 'Tu legge, o dea, poni all' universo.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL44" id="TIIINL44" class="pginternal">44, 45</a>. <i>Inhelde</i>, pour in. <i>Caliope</i>, Calliope,
  muse of epic poetry; similarly invoked by Dante, Purg. i. 9.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL87" id="TIIINL87" class="pginternal">87</a>. 'Though he was not pert, nor made difficulties; nor
  was he too bold, (as if about) to sing a mass for a fool.' The last expression was probably
  proverbial; it seems to mean to speak without hesitation or a feeling of respect.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL115" id="TIIINL115" class="pginternal">115</a>. <i>to watre wolde</i>, would turn to water; cf.
  Squi. Ta. F 496.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL120" id="TIIINL120" class="pginternal">120</a>. '<i>I? what?</i>' i. e. 'I? what (am I to
  do)?' In l. 122, Pandarus repeats her words, mockingly: 'You say I? what? why, of course you
  should pity him.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL136" id="TIIINL136" class="pginternal">136-138</a>. 'And I (am) to have comfort, as it pleases you,
  (being at the same time) under your correction, (so as to have what is) equal to my offence, as
  (for instance) death.' See Cant. Ta. B 1287.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL150" id="TIIINL150" class="pginternal">150</a>. 'By the feast of Jupiter, who presides over
  nativities.' The reason for the use of <i>natal</i> is not obvious. Cf. 'Scit Genius, natale comes
  qui temperat astrum;' Horat. Ep. ii. 2. 187.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL188" id="TIIINL188" class="pginternal">188</a>. 'I seem to hear the town-bells ringing for this
  miracle, though no hand pulls the ropes.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL193" id="TIIINL193" class="pginternal">193, 194</a>. <i>and oon, And two</i>, 'both the one of you
  and the other.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL198" id="TIIINL198" class="pginternal">198</a>. <i>bere the belle</i>, take the former place, take
  precedence; like the bell-wether that heads the flock. See the New E. Dict.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL228" id="TIIINL228" class="pginternal">228</a>. 'Straight as a line,' i. e. directly, at
  once.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL294" id="TIIINL294" class="pginternal">294</a>. See Manc. Ta. H 333, and note.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL299" id="TIIINL299" class="pginternal">299</a>. 'Thou understandest and knowest enough proverbs
  against the vice of gossiping, even if men spoke truth as often as they lie.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL308" id="TIIINL308" class="pginternal">308</a>. 'No boaster is to be believed, in the natural
  course of things.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL328" id="TIIINL328" class="pginternal">328, 329</a>. <i>drat</i>, dreadeth. Cf. 'Felix, quem
  faciunt aliena pericula cautum.' But Chaucer took it from Le Rom. de la Rose, 8041-2: 'Moult a
  benéurée vie Cil qui par autrui se chastie.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL340" id="TIIINL340" class="pginternal">340</a>. 'And a day is appointed for making up the charters'
  (which will particularise what she has granted you); metaphorical.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page477">{477}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIIIL349" id="TIIINL349" class="pginternal">349</a>. <i>richesse</i>, abundance; not a happy word, but
  suggested by the Ital. text: 'I sospir ch'egli aveva a gran dovizia;' Fil. iii. 11. <i>Dovizia</i>
  (Lat. <i>diuitiae</i>) is precisely 'richesse.' Bell has <i>rehetyng</i>, i. e. comforting
  (from O. F. <i>rehaiter</i>, <i>reheiter</i>), which gives no sense; and explains it by
  '<i>reheating</i>!'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL354" id="TIIINL354" class="pginternal">354</a>. <i>lusty</i>, lusty person; cf. Cant. Ta. A 165,
  208.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL377" id="TIIINL377" class="pginternal">377</a>. 'Or durst (do so), or should know (how).'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL380" id="TIIINL380" class="pginternal">380</a>. <i>stokked</i>, fastened in the stocks; cf. Acts
  xvi. 24.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL404" id="TIIINL404" class="pginternal">404</a>. <i>Departe it so</i>, make this distinction.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL410" id="TIIINL410" class="pginternal">410</a>. <i>frape</i>, company, troop. Marked by Tyrwhitt as
  not understood. Other examples occur. 'With hem a god gret <i>frape</i>;' Adam Davy, &amp;c., ed.
  Furnivall, p. 60, col. 1, text 3, l. 390; and see Allit. Morte Arthure, ed. Brock, 2163, 2804,
  3548. Godefroy gives O. F. <i>frap</i>, a multitude, and <i>frapaille</i>, rabble.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL445" id="TIIINL445" class="pginternal">445</a>. 'And wished to be seised of that which he
  lacked.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL497" id="TIIINL497" class="pginternal">497</a>. 'Or to enumerate all the looks and words of one
  that is in such uncertainty.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL502" id="TIIINL502" class="pginternal">502</a>. <i>as seith</i>; but it does not appear that
  Boccaccio says anything of the kind. The same remark applies to l. 575.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL510" id="TIIINL510" class="pginternal">510</a>. <i>Fulfelle</i> is a Kentish form, the <i>e</i>
  answering to A. S. <i>y</i>. Similar forms occur in Gower. See note to Book Duch. 438.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL526" id="TIIINL526" class="pginternal">526</a>. Scan: Dréd | elées | it cleer,' &amp;c. The sense
  is: 'it was clear, in the direction of the wind, from every magpie and every spoil-sport.'
  I. e. no one could detect them; they kept (like hunters) well to leeward, and there were no
  magpies or telltale birds to windward, to give an alarm.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL529" id="TIIINL529" class="pginternal">529</a>. Scan: In this matér-e, both-e frem'd.
  <i>fremed</i>, strange, wild.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL542" id="TIIINL542" class="pginternal">542</a>. <i>holy</i>, i. e. sacred to Apollo. From
  Ovid, Met. i. 566: 'laurea .. uisa est agitasse cacumen.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL545" id="TIIINL545" class="pginternal">545</a>. 'And therefore let no one hinder him.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL572" id="TIIINL572" class="pginternal">572</a>. The readings all shew various corruptions of
  <i>thurfte</i>, which none of the scribes understood; see <i>thurfen</i>, <i>tharf</i>, in
  Stratmann. This is not the only place where <i>thurfte</i> has been ousted from the text. Cf.
  <i>thar</i> (for <i>tharf</i>) in the Reves Ta. A 4320, &amp;c. <i>Yow thurfte have</i>, you would
  need (to) have. <i>Yow</i> is the dat. case, governed by the impers. verb. The reading <i>yow
  durste</i> turns <i>yow</i> (an accusative) into an imaginary nominative; but the nom. form is
  <i>ye</i>, which the scribes did not venture to substitute.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL584" id="TIIINL584" class="pginternal">584</a>. <i>goosish</i>, goose-like, silly. This delicious
  epithet was turned into <i>gofysshe</i> by Thynne, and modern editions perpetuate the blunder.
  Tyrwhitt derived <i>gofish</i> from F. <i>goffe</i>, a word which is much later than Chaucer, and
  was probably merely adapted from Ital. <i>goffo</i>, stupid. The Century Dict. goes a step
  further, inserting a second <i>f</i>, and producing a form <i>goffish</i>, against all authority.
  Cf. Parl. Foules, 568, 586.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL601" id="TIIINL601" class="pginternal">601</a>. <i>stewe</i>, small chamber, closet; cf. G.
  <i>Stube</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL602" id="TIIINL602" class="pginternal">602</a>. 'Where he was shut in, as in a coop.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page478">{478}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIIIL609" id="TIIINL609" class="pginternal">609</a>. 'There was no dainty to be fetched'; they were all
  there.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL614" id="TIIINL614" class="pginternal">614</a>. <i>Wade</i>; this is the hero mentioned in the
  Merch. Tale, E 1424; see note.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL617" id="TIIINL617" class="pginternal">617-620</a>. Cf. Boethius, Bk. iv. Pr. 6. 60-68.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL622" id="TIIINL622" class="pginternal">622</a>. 'Without her leave, at the will of the gods.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL624" id="TIIINL624" class="pginternal">624</a>. <i>bente</i>, i. e. curved, crescent; see l.
  549. Cf. Boeth. Bk. I. Met. 5. 6, 7.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL625" id="TIIINL625" class="pginternal">625</a>. The Moon, Saturn, and Jupiter were all in
  conjunction in Cancer, which was the mansion of the moon. We are to understand that this caused
  the great rain.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL640" id="TIIINL640" class="pginternal">640</a>. <i>ron</i>, rained; so also in l. 677. The usual
  pt. t. is <i>reinede</i>, but we also find <i>roon</i>, <i>ron</i>, as in P. Plowm. B. xiv. 66 (C.
  xvi. 270), and in Trevisa, tr. of Higden, ii. 239. The pt. t. of A. S. <i>rignan</i>,
  <i>rīnan</i>, is usually <i>rīnde</i>; but the strong pt. <i>rān</i> occurs
  in the Blickling Glosses.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL648" id="TIIINL648" class="pginternal">648</a>. <i>a game</i>, in game; <i>a</i> = <i>an</i>,
  <i>on</i>; Cm. has <i>on</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL671" id="TIIINL671" class="pginternal">671</a>. <i>The wyn anon</i>, the wine (shall come) at once;
  alluding to the wine drunk just before going to bed. See Prol. A 819, 820.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL674" id="TIIINL674" class="pginternal">674</a>. 'The <i>voidè</i> being drunk, and the
  cross-curtain drawn immediately afterwards.' The best reading is <i>voyde</i> or <i>voydee</i>.
  This seems to be here used as a name for the 'loving-cup' or 'grace-cup,' which was drunk after
  the table had been cleared or <i>voided</i>. Properly, it was a slight dessert of 'spices' and
  wine; where <i>spices</i> meant sweetmeats, dried fruits, &amp;c. See Notes and Queries, 2 S. xi.
  508. The <i>traverse</i> was a screen or curtain drawn across the room; cf. Cant. Ta. E 1817;
  King's Quair, st. 90. See Additional Note, p. <a href="#page506" class="pginternal">506</a>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL690" id="TIIINL690" class="pginternal">690</a>. This refers to the attendants. They were no longer
  allowed to skip about (run on errands) or to tramp about noisily, but were packed off to bed, with
  a malediction on those who stirred about. <i>Traunceth</i>, tramps about, is used of a bull by
  Gower, C. A. ii. 72. In Beaumont and Fletcher, Fair Maid of the Inn, v. 2, we find—'but,
  <i>traunce</i> the world over, you shall never,' &amp;c. For <i>traunce</i>, Thynne reads
  <i>praunce</i>, which has a similar sense. Morris explains <i>traunce</i> here as a sb., which
  seems impossible.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL695" id="TIIINL695" class="pginternal">695</a>. <i>The olde daunce</i>, the old game; see Prol. A
  476.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL696" id="TIIINL696" class="pginternal">696</a>. <i>sey</i>, saw; perhaps read <i>seye</i>, subj.,
  might perceive. If so, read <i>al</i>, i. e. every.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL702" id="TIIINL702" class="pginternal">702</a>. 'Beginning and end;' see note to bk. II. 1495.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL711" id="TIIINL711" class="pginternal">711</a>. I. e. or else upset everything; cf. the
  phrase, 'all the fat is in the fire.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL716" id="TIIINL716" class="pginternal">716</a>. Mars and Saturn both had an evil influence.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL717" id="TIIINL717" class="pginternal">717</a>. <i>combust</i>, quenched, viz. by being too near
  the sun; see Astrolabe, pt. ii. § 4. Venus and Mercury, when thus 'combust,' lost their influence.
  <i>let</i>, hindered.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL721" id="TIIINL721" class="pginternal">721</a>. <i>Adoon</i>, Adonis; see Ovid, Met. x. 715.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL722" id="TIIINL722" class="pginternal">722</a>. <i>Europe</i>, Europa; see Leg. of Good Women, 113,
  and note.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL725" id="TIIINL725" class="pginternal">725</a>. <i>Cipris</i>, Venus; see Ho. Fame, 518.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL726" id="TIIINL726" class="pginternal">726</a>. <i>Dane</i>, Daphne; see Kn. Ta. A 2062.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page479">{479}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIIIL729" id="TIIINL729" class="pginternal">729</a>. <i>Mercúrie</i>, Mercury; <i>Herse</i>, daughter of
  Cecrops, beloved by Mercury. Her sister, Aglauros, had displeased Minerva (<i>Pallas</i>);
  whereupon Minerva made Aglauros envious of Herse. Mercury turned Aglauros into stone because she
  hindered his suit. See Ovid, Met. ii. 708-832.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL733" id="TIIINL733" class="pginternal">733</a>. 'Fatal sisters;' i.e. the Fates, Clotho, Lachesis,
  and Atropos. 'Which spun my destiny, before any cloth (infant's covering) was made for me.' See
  Kn. Ta. A 1566; Leg. G. Wom. 2629.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL764" id="TIIINL764" class="pginternal">764</a>. Let sleeping dogs lie; a proverb.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL773" id="TIIINL773" class="pginternal">773</a>. 'To hold in hand' is to feed with false hopes, to
  delude by pretended love.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL775" id="TIIINL775" class="pginternal">775</a>. Lit. 'and make him a hood above a cap.' A
  <i>calle</i> (caul) was a close-fitting cap, a skull-cap. To put on a hood over this evidently
  means to cover up the eyes, to cajole, to hoodwink.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL791" id="TIIINL791" class="pginternal">791</a>, <a href="#TIIIL797" id="TIIINL797" class="pginternal">797</a>.
  <i>shal</i>, owe to. <i>sholde love</i>, i.e. are reported to love.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL813" id="TIIINL813" class="pginternal">813-836</a>. Founded on Boethius, lib. II. Pr. 4. 'Quàm
  multis amaritudinibus humanae felicitatis dulcedo respersa est!... Anxia enim res est humanorum
  conditio bonorum, et quae uel numquam tota proueniat, uel numquam perpetua subsistat.... Ad haec,
  quem caduca ista felicitas uehit, uel scit eam, uel nescit esse mutabilem. Si nescit, quaenam
  beata sors esse potest ignorantiae caecitate? Si scit, metuat necesse est, ne amittat, quod amitti
  potest non dubitat; quare continuus timor non sinit esse felicem.... quonam modo praesens uita
  facere beatos potest?' See the E. version, ll. 86, 56, 109.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL839" id="TIIINL839" class="pginternal">839</a>. 'Why hast thou made Troilus distrust me?'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL853" id="TIIINL853" class="pginternal">853, 854</a>. 'Danger is drawn nearer by delay.' We say,
  'Delays are dangerous.' Cf. Havelok, l. 1352. <i>abodes</i>, abidings, tarryings.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL855" id="TIIINL855" class="pginternal">855</a>. <i>Néc'</i>, with elided <i>e</i>, forms the first
  foot. 'Every thing has its time;' cf. Eccl. iii. 1.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL861" id="TIIINL861" class="pginternal">861</a>. <i>farewel feldefare</i>, (and people will say)
  farewell, fieldfare! Cf. Rom. Rose, 5510. In the Rom. Rose, it refers to false friends, who, when
  fortune frowns, say 'Go! farewell fieldfare,' i.e. Begone, we have done with you. As fieldfares
  come here in the winter months, people are glad to see them go, as a sign of approaching summer.
  In the present case, the sense appears to be that, when an opportunity is missed, the harm is
  done; and people will cry, 'farewell, fieldfare!' by way of derision. We might paraphrase the line
  by saying: 'the harm is done, and nobody cares.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL885" id="TIIINL885" class="pginternal">885</a>. <i>blewe</i>, blue; the colour of
  <i>constancy</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL890" id="TIIINL890" class="pginternal">890</a>. 'Hazle-bushes shake.' This is a truism known to
  every one, and no news at all; in like manner, your ring will tell him nothing, and is
  useless.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL901" id="TIIINL901" class="pginternal">901</a>. <i>feffe him</i>, enfeoff him, bestow on him.
  <i>whyte</i>, fair.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL919" id="TIIINL919" class="pginternal">919</a>. <i>at pryme face</i>, at the first glance; <i>primâ
  facie</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL931" id="TIIINL931" class="pginternal">931</a>. <i>At dulcarnon</i>, at a non-plus, in extreme
  perplexity. <i>Dulcarnon</i>, as pointed out by Selden, in his Pref. to Drayton's Polyolbion,
  represents the Pers. and Arab. <i>dū’lkarnayn</i>, lit. two-horned; from Pers.
  <i>dū</i>, <span class="pagenum" id="page480">{480}</span>two, and <i>karn</i>, horn. It
  was a common medieval epithet of Alexander the Great, who was so called because he claimed descent
  from Jupiter Ammon, whose image was provided with horns like a ram. Speght rightly says that
  <i>Dulcarnon</i> was also a name for the 47th prop. of Euclid, Book I, but gives a false reason
  and etymology. The real reason is plain enough, viz. that the two smaller squares in the diagram
  stick up like two horns. And, as this proposition is somewhat difficult for beginners, it here
  takes the sense of 'puzzle;' hence Criseyde was <i>at Dulcarnon</i>, because she was in
  perplexity. Speght refers to Alex. Neckam, De Naturis Rerum; see Wright's edition, p. 295.</p>
<p>But this is not all. In l. 933, Pandarus explains that Dulcarnon is called 'fleming of
  wrecches.' There is a slight error here: 'fleming of wrecches,' i.e. banishment of the miserable,
  is a translation of <i>Fuga miserorum</i>, which is written opposite this line in MS. Harl. 1239;
  and further, <i>Fuga miserorum</i> is a sort of Latin translation of <i>Eleëfuga</i> or
  <i>Eleufuga</i>, from <span class="fsn" title="eleos">ἔλεος</span>
  pity, and <span class="fsn" title="phygê">φυγή</span>, flight. The error
  lies in confusing <i>Dulcarnon</i>, the 47th proposition, with <i>Eleufuga</i>, a name for the 5th
  proposition; a confusion due to the fact that both propositions were considered difficult. Roger
  Bacon, Opus Tertium, cap. 6, says: 'Quinta propositio geometricae Euclidis dicitur <i>Elefuga</i>,
  id est, <i>fuga miserorum</i>.' Ducange, s. v. <i>Eleufuga</i>, quotes from Alanus, Anticlaudiani
  lib. iii. cap. 6—'Huius tirones curantis [<i>read</i> cur artis] <i>Eleufuga</i> terret,'
  &amp;c. The word also occurs in Richard of Bury's Philobiblon, cap. xiii, somewhat oddly
  translated by J.B. Inglis in 1832. 'How many scholars has the Helleflight of Euclid repelled!'</p>
<p>This explanation, partly due to the Rev. W.G. Clark (joint-editor of the Globe Shakespeare),
  was first given in the <i>Athenæum</i>, Sept. 23, 1871, p. 393, in an article written by
  myself.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL934" id="TIIINL934" class="pginternal">934</a>. <i>It</i>, i.e. <i>Dulcarnon</i>, or Euclid's
  proposition. 'It seems hard, because the wretched pupils will not learn it, owing to their very
  sloth or other wilful defects.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL936" id="TIIINL936" class="pginternal">936</a>. <i>This</i> = <i>this is</i>; as elsewhere.
  <i>fecches</i>, vetches.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL947" id="TIIINL947" class="pginternal">947</a>. Understand <i>be</i>; 'where (I hope) good thrift
  may be.' Cf. 966.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL978" id="TIIINL978" class="pginternal">978</a>. <i>fere</i>, fire; as in Bk. i. 229. Usually
  <i>fyre</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL979" id="TIIINL979" class="pginternal">979</a>. <i>fond his contenaunce</i>, lit. found his
  demeanour, i.e. composed himself as if to read.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1010" id="TIIINL1010" class="pginternal">1010</a>. <i>wivere</i>, viper; O. F. <i>wivre</i> (F.
  <i>givre</i>), from Lat. <i>uipera</i>. The heraldic <i>wiver</i> or <i>wyvern</i> became a
  wondrous winged dragon, with two legs; wholly unlike the original viper. See Thynne's
  Animadversions, &amp;c., ed. Furnivall, p. 41.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1013" id="TIIINL1013" class="pginternal">1013</a>. 'Alas! that he, either entirely, or a slice of
  him.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1021" id="TIIINL1021" class="pginternal">1021</a>. 'That sufferest undeserved jealousy (to
  exist).'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1029" id="TIIINL1029" class="pginternal">1029</a>. <i>after that</i>, accordingly; <i>his</i>,
  its.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1035" id="TIIINL1035" class="pginternal">1035</a>. See note to Bk. ii. 784.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1046" id="TIIINL1046" class="pginternal">1046</a>. <i>ordal</i>, ordeal, trial by ordeal, i.e. by
  fire or water. See Thynne's Animadversions, ed. Furnivall, p. 66.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1056" id="TIIINL1056" class="pginternal">1056</a>. <i>wreigh</i>, covered; A. S.
  <i>wrāh</i>; see <i>wrīhen</i> in Stratmann.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page481">{481}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1064" id="TIIINL1064" class="pginternal">1064</a>. <i>shoures</i>, assaults. Bell actually
  substitutes <i>stouris</i>, as being 'clearly the true reading.' But editors have no right to
  reject real words which they fail to understand. <i>Shour</i> sometimes means a shower of arrows
  or darts, an assault, &amp;c.; cf. A.S. <i>hildescūr</i>, a flight of missiles. In fact, it
  recurs in this sense in Bk. iv. 47, where Bell again turns it into <i>stoure</i>, against
  authority.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1067" id="TIIINL1067" class="pginternal">1067</a>. 'For it seemed to him not like (mere) strokes
  with a rod ... but he felt the very cramp of death.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1106" id="TIIINL1106" class="pginternal">1106</a>. <i>al forgeve</i>, all is forgiven.
  <i>stint</i>, stopped.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1154" id="TIIINL1154" class="pginternal">1154</a>. <i>bar him on honde</i>, assured him.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1177" id="TIIINL1177" class="pginternal">1177</a>. 'For a crime, there is mercy (to be had).'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1194" id="TIIINL1194" class="pginternal">1194</a>. <i>sucre be or soot</i>, may be like sugar or
  like soot, i.e. pleasant or the reverse. We must read <i>soot</i> (not <i>sote</i>, sweet, as in
  Bell) because it rimes with <i>moot</i>. Moreover, soot was once proverbially bitter. 'Bittrore
  then the sote' occurs in Altenglische Dichtungen, ed. Boddeker, p. 121; and in Rutebuef's Vie
  Sainte Marie l'Egiptianne, ed. Jubinal, 280, we find 'plus amer que suie;' cf. Rom. Rose, 10670:
  'amer Plus que n'est suie.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1215" id="TIIINL1215" class="pginternal">1215</a>. Cf. 'Bitter pills may have sweet effects;'
  Hazlitt's Proverbs.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1231" id="TIIINL1231" class="pginternal">1231</a>. <i>Bitrent</i>, for <i>bitrendeth</i>, winds
  round; cf. iv. 870. <i>wryth</i>, for <i>wrytheth</i>, writhes.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1235" id="TIIINL1235" class="pginternal">1235</a>. 'When she hears any shepherd speak.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1249" id="TIIINL1249" class="pginternal">1249</a>. 'And often invoked good luck upon her snowy
  throat.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1257" id="TIIINL1257" class="pginternal">1257</a>. <i>welwilly</i>, full of good will,
  propitious.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1258" id="TIIINL1258" class="pginternal">1258</a>. <i>Imeneus</i>, Hymenæus, Hymen; cf. Ovid, Her.
  xiv. 27.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1261" id="TIIINL1261" class="pginternal">1261-4</a>. Imitated from Dante, Parad. xxxiii. 14<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Che qual vuol grazie, e a te non ricorre,</p>
<p>Sua disianza vuol volar senz' ali.</p>
<p>La tua benignità non pur soccorre,' &amp;c.</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1282" id="TIIINL1282" class="pginternal">1282</a>. 'Mercy prevails over (lit. surpasses)
  justice.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1344" id="TIIINL1344" class="pginternal">1344</a>. 'Or else do I dream it?'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1357" id="TIIINL1357" class="pginternal">1357</a>. <i>sooth</i>, for <i>sooth is</i>, i.e. it is
  true.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1369" id="TIIINL1369" class="pginternal">1369</a>. Bell takes <i>scripture</i> to mean the mottos
  or posies on the rings. Perhaps this is right.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1374" id="TIIINL1374" class="pginternal">1374</a>. <i>holt</i>, holds; 'that holds it in
  despite.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1375" id="TIIINL1375" class="pginternal">1375</a>. 'Of the money, that he can heap up and lay hold
  of.' For <i>mokren</i>, cf. Chaucer's Boethius, Bk. ii. Pr. 5. 11. <i>Pens</i>, pence, is a
  translation of Ital. <i>denari</i>, money, in the Filostrato, Book iii. st. 38.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1384" id="TIIINL1384" class="pginternal">1384</a>. <i>the whyte</i>, silver coins; <i>the rede</i>,
  gold coins.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1389" id="TIIINL1389" class="pginternal">1389</a>. <i>Myda</i>, Midas; see Wyf of Bathes Tale, D
  951.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1391" id="TIIINL1391" class="pginternal">1391</a>. <i>Crassus</i>; wantonly altered to
  <i>Cresus</i> in Bell's edition, on the ground that the story is told of Croesus. But Chaucer knew
  better. M. Crassus, surnamed Dives (the Rich), was slain in battle against the Parthians, <span class="smaller">B. C.</span> 53. Orodes, king of Parthia, caused molten gold to be poured into the
  mouth of his dead enemy, saying, 'Sate thyself now with that metal of which, in life, thou wast so
  greedy;' Cicero, Att. vi. 1. 14; Florus, iii. 11. 4.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page482">{482}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1407" id="TIIINL1407" class="pginternal">1407</a>. 'And to counterbalance with joy their former
  woe'.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1415" id="TIIINL1415" class="pginternal">1415</a>. The cock is called a common astrologer
  (i. e. astronomer), because he announces to all the time of day; cf. Non. Pr. Ta. B 4043;
  Parl. Foules, 350. Translated from 'vulgaris astrologus;' Alanus.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1417" id="TIIINL1417" class="pginternal">1417, 9</a>. <i>Lucifer</i>, the morning-star, the planet
  Venus. <i>Fortuna maior</i>, the planet Jupiter. Mars and Saturn were supposed to have an
  <i>evil</i> influence; the Sun, Mercury, and Moon, had no great influence either way; whilst
  Jupiter and Venus had a <i>good</i> influence, and were therefore called, respectively, <i>Fortuna
  maior</i> and <i>Fortuna minor</i>. See G. Douglas, ed. Small, ii. 288. The MSS. have <i>that
  anoon</i>, (it happened) that anon; but this requires us to suppose so awkward an ellipsis that it
  is better to read <i>than</i>, answering to <i>whan</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1428" id="TIIINL1428" class="pginternal">1428</a>. <i>Almena</i>, Alcmena; a note in MS. H. has:
  'Almena mater Herculis.' Alcmena was the mother of Hercules by Jupiter. Jupiter lengthened the
  night beyond its usual limit. Plautus has a play on the subject, called <i>Amphitruo</i>, as
  Jupiter personated Amphitryon.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1437" id="TIIINL1437" class="pginternal">1437-9</a>. <i>ther</i>, wherefore; 'wherefore (I pray
  that) God, creator of nature, may bind thee so fast to our hemisphere,' &amp;c. A similar
  construction occurs in l. 1456.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1453" id="TIIINL1453" class="pginternal">1453</a>. <i>bore</i>, aperture, chink; 'for every chink
  lets in one of thy bright rays.' See New E. Dict.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1462" id="TIIINL1462" class="pginternal">1462</a>. Engravers of small seals require a good
  light.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1464" id="TIIINL1464" class="pginternal">1464</a>. <i>Tytan</i>, Titan, frequently used as
  synonymous with the sun; as in Ovid, Met. i. 10. Chaucer has confused him with <i>Tithonus</i>,
  the husband of Aurora, whom he denotes by <i>dawing</i> in l. 1466, and by <i>morwe</i> in l.
  1469.</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Iamque, fugatura Tithoni coniuge noctem,</p>
<p style="margin-left:0.70em">Praeuius Aurorae Lucifer ortus erat.'</p>
<p style="margin-left:9.45em">Ovid, Heroid. xviii. 111.</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1490" id="TIIINL1490" class="pginternal">1490</a>. Read <i>wer-e</i>, in two syllables. <i>these
  worldes tweyne</i> seems to mean 'two worlds such as this.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1495" id="TIIINL1495" class="pginternal">1495</a>. This somewhat resembles Verg. Ecl. i. 60-4.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1502" id="TIIINL1502" class="pginternal">1502</a>. 'Even if I had to die by torture;' as in Bk. i.
  674.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1514" id="TIIINL1514" class="pginternal">1514</a>. <i>mo</i>, others; see note to Cler. Ta. E
  1039.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1546" id="TIIINL1546" class="pginternal">1546</a>. 'Desire burnt him afresh, and pleasure began to
  arise more than at first.' Cf. the parallel line in Leg. Good Wom. 1156: 'Of which ther gan to
  breden swich a fyr.' Yet Bell rejects this reading as being 'not at all in Chaucer's manner,' and
  prefers nonsense.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1577" id="TIIINL1577" class="pginternal">1577</a>. 'Christ forgave those who crucified him.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1600" id="TIIINL1600" class="pginternal">1600</a>. Cf. Æneid. vi. 550<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Quae rapidus flammis ambit torrentibus amnis</p>
<p>Tartareus Phlegethon.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1625" id="TIIINL1625" class="pginternal">1625</a>. From Boethius, lib. ii. Pr. 4: 'Sed hoc est,
  quod recolentem uehementius coquit. Nam in omni aduersitate fortunae infelicissimum genus est
  infortunii, fuisse felicem.' Cf. Dante, Inf. v. 121; Tennyson, Locksley Hall—'That a
  sorrow's crown of sorrow is remembering happier things.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page483">{483}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1634" id="TIIINL1634" class="pginternal">1634</a>. Cf. Rom. de la Rose, 8301-4; from Ovid, Art.
  Amat. ii. 13.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1642" id="TIIINL1642" class="pginternal">1642</a>. <i>Ne I</i>, read <i>N'I</i>. <i>rakle</i>,
  behave rashly; it is plainly a <i>verb</i>, formed from the adj. <i>rakel</i>. Morris inserts
  <i>ben</i> after <i>rakel</i>, to the ruin of the scansion. Cf. Norweg. <i>rakla</i>, to ramble,
  totter, be unsteady (Aasen); Swed. dial. <i>rakkla</i>, to rove (Rietz); Icel. <i>reka</i>, to
  drive.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1649" id="TIIINL1649" class="pginternal">1649</a>. <i>I shal</i>, I owe; A. S. <i>ic sceal</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1687" id="TIIINL1687" class="pginternal">1687</a>. <i>comprende</i>, comprehend; F.
  <i>comprendre</i>. This is clearly the right form. In the Sq. Ta. F 223, though the MSS. have
  <i>comprehende</i>, it is obvious that <i>comprende</i> is the real reading.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1703" id="TIIINL1703" class="pginternal">1703</a>. <i>Pirous</i>, i. e. Pyroeis, one of the
  four horses that drew the chariot of the sun. The other three were Eöus, Æthon, and Phlegon; see
  Ovid, Met. ii. 153.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1705" id="TIIINL1705" class="pginternal">1705</a>. 'Have taken some short cut, to spite me.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1732" id="TIIINL1732" class="pginternal">1732</a>. 'To the extent of a single knot.' It would not
  be necessary to explain this, if it were not for Bell's explanation of <i>knot</i> as 'gnat.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1734" id="TIIINL1734" class="pginternal">1734</a>. <i>y-masked</i>, enmeshed; cf. A. S.
  <i>masc</i>, a mesh.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1744" id="TIIINL1744" class="pginternal">1744-68</a>. Paraphrased from Boethius, lib. ii. Met. 8;
  but note that the lines italicised are transposed, and represent ll. 1744-1750:</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Quòd mundus stabili fide Concordes uariat uices,</p>
<p>Quòd pugnantia semina Foedus perpetuum tenent,</p>
<p>Quòd Phoebus roseum diem Curru prouehit aureo,</p>
<p>Ut quas duxerit Hesperus Phoebe noctibus imperet,</p>
<p>Ut fluctus auidum mare Certo fine coërceat,</p>
<p>Ne terris liceat uagis Latos tendere terminos.</p>
<p><i>Hanc rerum seriem ligat, Terras ac pelagus regens,</i></p>
<p><i>Et caelo imperitans Amor.</i> Hic si fraena remiserit,</p>
<p>Quidquid nunc amat inuicem, Bellum continuò geret:</p>
<p>Et quam nunc socia fide Pulcris motibus incitant,</p>
<p>Certent soluere machinam. Hic sancto populos quoque</p>
<p>Iunctos foedere continet: Hic et coniugii sacrum</p>
<p>Castis nectit amoribus: Hic fidis etiam sua</p>
<p>Dictat iura sodalibus. O felix hominum genus,</p>
<p>Si uestros animos Amor Quo caelum regitur, regat!'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1764" id="TIIINL1764" class="pginternal">1764</a>. <i>halt to-hepe</i>, holds together, preserves
  in concord. Bell and Morris have the corrupt reading <i>to kepe</i>. <i>To hepe</i>, to a heap,
  became the adv. <i>to-hepe</i>, together. It occurs again in Ch. Astrolabe, Part I. § 14, and in
  Boethius, Bk. iv. Pr. 6. 182. Cf. 'gaderen tresor <i>to-hepe</i>,' Polit. Songs, ed. Wright, p.
  325; 'han brought it <i>to-hepe</i>,' P. Ploughman's Crede, l. 727.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1766" id="TIIINL1766" class="pginternal">1766</a>. 'That Love, by means of his power, would be
  pleased,' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1779" id="TIIINL1779" class="pginternal">1779</a>. <i>In tyme of trewe</i>, in time of truce; as in
  Boccaccio, Fil. iii. st. 91. Bell wrongly has <i>Out of Troy</i>. Morris alters <i>trewe</i> to
  <i>trewes</i>; but see Bk. iv. l. 1312.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1805" id="TIIINL1805" class="pginternal">1805</a>. These are four of the seven deadly sins; see
  Pers. Tale.</p>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1807" id="TIIINL1807" class="pginternal">1807</a>. <i>lady</i>, i. e. Venus, called
  <i>Dionaea</i> as being daughter of Dione; Æneid. iii. 19. Cf. Homer, Il. v. 370.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page484">{484}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIIIL1809" id="TIIINL1809" class="pginternal">1809</a>. The nine Muses. Helicon was a long way from
  Mount Parnassus; but see notes to Anelida, 15, and Ho. Fame, 521.</p>
<p class="sp3"><a href="#TIIIL1817" id="TIIINL1817" class="pginternal">1817</a>. 'As it pleases my author to
  relate.'</p>
<h2>BOOK IV.</h2>
<p>The following scheme gives some notion of the relationship of the contents of this book to the
  Filostrato, but Chaucer constantly expands and adds to the original, and not unfrequently
  transposes the order of the text.</p>

<p><a href="#TIVL1" id="TIVNL1" class="pginternal">1</a>. In the Proem, ll. 1-3 correspond to Fil. iii. st. 94, ll.
  1-3; and ll. 8 and 10 to the same stanza, ll. 4 and 7. The rest is original.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL3" id="TIVNL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. Cf. Boethius, lib. ii. Pr. 1: 'Intelligo ... illius
  [Fortunae] ... cum his, quos eludere nititur, blandissimam familiaritatem.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL5" id="TIVNL5" class="pginternal">5</a>. <i>hent and blent</i>, for <i>hendeth and blendeth</i>,
  catches and blinds.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL6" id="TIVNL6" class="pginternal">6, 7</a>. Cf. Boethius, lib. ii. Met. 2: 'Ultroque gemitus, dura
  quos fecit [Fortuna], ridet.' Whence, in Le Roman de la Rose, 8076-9, the passage which Chaucer
  here imitates; <i>the mowe</i> = F. <i>la moe</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL22" id="TIVNL22" class="pginternal">22</a>. <i>Herines</i> i. e. Furies; used as the pl. of
  <i>Erynis</i> or <i>Erinnys</i>; see note to Compl. to Pite, 92. Their names (see l. 24) were
  Megaera, Alecto, and Tisiphone. Bell's remark, that Chaucer found these names in Boccaccio, does
  not seem to be founded on fact. He more likely found them in Vergil, who has <i>Erinnys</i>, Æn.
  ii. 336, 573; vii. 447, 570; <i>Alecto</i>, id. vii. 324, 341, 405, 415, 445, 476; <i>Megæra</i>,
  id. xii. 846; <i>Tisiphone</i>, vi. 571, x. 761. But I suppose that, even in Chaucer's time, MS.
  note-books existed, containing such information as the names of the Furies. Chaucer even knew that
  some (as Æschylus) considered them to be the daughters of Night.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page485">{485}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIVL25" id="TIVNL25" class="pginternal">25</a>. <i>Quiryne</i>, Quirinus. Ovid, Fasti, ii. 476, tells us
  that Quirinus was Romulus; and just above, ii. 419, that Romulus and Remus were sons of Mars.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL29" id="TIVNL29" class="pginternal">29</a>. <i>Ligginge ... The Grekes</i>, while the Greeks
  lay.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL32" id="TIVNL32" class="pginternal">32</a>. <i>Hercules Lyoun</i>, Hercules' lion, the lion of
  Hercules; alluding to the lion's skin which Hercules wore. Valerius Flaccus, Argonauticon, lib. i.
  263, has 'Herculeo ... leoni;' and Chaucer seems to have read this author, or at any rate his
  first book; see Leg. of Good Women, l. 1457, and the note. However, Chaucer shews his knowledge of
  the story clearly enough in his tr. of Boethius, Bk. iv. Met. 7. The reference is, simply, to the
  sign Leo. The sun was in this sign during the latter part of July and the former part of August;
  but we are further told that he was in the 'breast' of Leo, and therefore near the very bright
  star Regulus, called in Arabic <i>Kalbalased</i>, or the Lion's Heart, which was situated almost
  on the zodiac, and (at that time) near the 20th degree of the sign. This gives the date as being
  the first week in August.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL41" id="TIVNL41" class="pginternal">41</a>. <i>in the berd</i>, in the beard, i. e. face to
  face.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL47" id="TIVNL47" class="pginternal">47</a>. <i>shour</i>, assault, attack; see note to Bk. iii.
  1064.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL50" id="TIVNL50" class="pginternal">50-4</a>. From Boccaccio. The right names are Antenor,
  Polydamas, Menestheus or Mnestheus, Xanthippus, Sarpedon, Polymnestor, Polites, Riphaeus, all
  mentioned by Boccaccio, who probably took them from Guido delle Colonne. But Boccaccio omits
  'Phebuseo,' and I do not know who is meant. Several of these names may be found in the allit.
  Destruction of Troy, ed. Panton and Donaldson; as Antenor and his son Polydamas, at ll. 3947,
  3954; Xanthippus, king of Phrygia, l. 6107; Sarpedon, prince of Lycia, l. 5448; and in Lydgate's
  Siege of Troy, Bk. ii. capp. 16, 20. Polymestor, or Polymnestor, was king of the Thracian
  Chersonese, and an ally of the Trojans. Polites was a son of Priam (Æneid. ii. 526). Mnestheus is
  repeatedly mentioned in Vergil (Æn. v. 116, &amp;c.), and is also called Menestheus (id. x. 129);
  he is a different person from Menestheus, king of Athens, who fought on the other side. For
  Riphaeus, see Verg. Aen. ii. 339. The Ital. forms are Antenorre, Polidamas, Monesteo, Santippo,
  Serpedon, Polinestorre, Polite, Rifeo. Observe that Monostéo, Riphéo, Phebuséo rime together, with
  an accent on the penultimate.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL62" id="TIVNL62" class="pginternal">62</a>. <i>thassege</i>, for <i>the assege</i>, the siege;
  Barbour has <i>assege</i>, siege, in his Bruce, xvii. 270, xx. 8; pl. <i>assegis</i>, xx. 12. MS.
  H. wrongly has <i>thessage</i>. See l. 1480 below.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL64" id="TIVNL64" class="pginternal">64</a>. <i>Calkas</i>, Calchas; see Bk. i. 66, 71.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL79" id="TIVNL79" class="pginternal">79</a>. <i>This town to shende</i>, i. e. (it will be best
  for you) to despoil this town.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL86" id="TIVNL86" class="pginternal">86</a>. <i>resport</i>, regard. This strange word is certified
  by its reappearance in l. 850, where it rimes to <i>discomfórt</i>. It is given in Roquefort, but
  only in a technical sense. It was, doubtless, formed from O. F. <i>esport</i>, deportment,
  demeanour, regard (Godefroy), by prefixing <i>re-</i>; and means 'demeanour towards,' or (here)
  simply 'regard,' as also in <span class="pagenum" id="page486">{486}</span>l. 850. The etymology
  is from Lat. <i>re-</i>, <i>ex</i>, and <i>portare</i>. Cf. F. <i>rapport</i>, from <i>re-</i>,
  <i>ad</i>, and <i>portare</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL96" id="TIVNL96" class="pginternal">96</a>. <i>in hir sherte</i>, in her smock only; i.e. without
  much rich clothing; 'as she was.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL99" id="TIVNL99" class="pginternal">99</a>. 'For because I saw no opportunity.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL112" id="TIVNL112" class="pginternal">112</a>. <i>as yerne</i>, as briskly as possible, very soon;
  so in l. 201.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL120" id="TIVNL120" class="pginternal">120-4</a>. Laomedon, father of Priam, founded Troy. Apollo and
  Poseidon (Neptune) had been condemned for a while to serve him for wages. But Laomedon refused
  them payment, and incurred their displeasure.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL133" id="TIVNL133" class="pginternal">133</a>. Antenor had been taken prisoner by the Greeks; see
  Lydgate, Siege of Troye, Bk. iii. ch. 24. Lydgate's version is that Antenor was to be exchanged
  for Thoas, king of Calydon; and, at the request of Chalcas, it was arranged that Antenor should be
  exchanged for both Thoas and Criseyde (see l. 138); to which Priam consented.</p>
<p><i>withoute more</i>, without further ado; cf. l. 376.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL143" id="TIVNL143" class="pginternal">143</a>. <i>parlement</i>; here Boccaccio has
  <i>parlamento</i>, i.e. a parley. Chaucer gives it the English sense.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL168" id="TIVNL168" class="pginternal">168</a>. 'The love of you both, where it was before
  unknown.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL197" id="TIVNL197" class="pginternal">197</a>. From Juvenal, Sat. x. ll. 2-4<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:4.70em">'pauci dignoscere possunt</p>
<p>Vera bona atque illis multum diuersa, remota</p>
<p>Erroris nebula.'</p>
</div>
<p>Cf. Dryden's translation and Dr. Johnson's poem on the Vanity of Human Wishes.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL198" id="TIVNL198" class="pginternal">198, 9</a>. <i>what is to yerne</i>, what is desirable.
  <i>offence</i>, disappointment.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL203" id="TIVNL203" class="pginternal">203</a>. <i>mischaunce</i>; because Antenor contrived the
  removal from Troy of the Palladium, on which the safety of the city depended. Cf. Lydgate, Siege
  of Troye, Bk. iv. ch. 34; or the account by Caxton, quoted in Specimens of English from 1394-1579,
  ed. Skeat, p. 89.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL210" id="TIVNL210" class="pginternal">210</a>. <i>here and howne.</i> The sense of this phrase is
  not known; but, judging by the context, it seems to mean—'thus said every one, such was the
  common rumour.' It has been explained as 'thus said <i>hare</i> and <i>hound</i>,' i.e. people of
  all sorts; but the M. E. form of <i>hare</i> is <i>hare</i> (A. S. <i>hara</i>), and the M. E.
  form of 'hound' never appears as <i>howne</i>, which, by the way, is evidently dissyllabic. In the
  absence of further evidence, guesswork is hardly profitable; but I should like to suggest that the
  phrase may mean 'gentle and savage.' The M. E. <i>here</i>, gentle, occurs in Layamon, 25867; and
  in Amis and Amiloun, 16 (Stratmann); from A. S. <i>hēore</i>. <i>Houne</i> answers,
  phonetically, to an A. S. <i>Hūna</i>, which may mean a Hun, a savage; cf. Ger.
  <i>Hüne</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL225" id="TIVNL225" class="pginternal">225</a>. From Dante, Inf. iii. 112<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Come d'autunno si levan le foglie</p>
<p>L'una appresso dell' altra infin che 'l ramo</p>
<p>Rende alla terra tutte le sue spoglie.'</p>
</div>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page487">{487}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIVL239" id="TIVNL239" class="pginternal">239</a>. This stanza follows Boccaccio closely; but Boccaccio,
  in his turn, here imitates a passage in Dante, Inf. xii. 22<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Qual è quel toro che si slaccia in quella</p>
<p>C'ha ricevuto già 'l colpo mortale,</p>
<p>Che gir non sa, ma qua e là saltella.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#TIVL251" id="TIVNL251" class="pginternal">251, 2</a>. Almost repeated in the Clerk Ta. E 902, 3; see
  note to the latter line, and cf. Gower, Conf. Amant. ii. 14—'Right as a lives creature She
  semeth,' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL263" id="TIVNL263" class="pginternal">263</a>. In MS. H., <i>thus</i> is glossed by 'sine
  causa.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL272" id="TIVNL272" class="pginternal">272</a>. Accent <i>misérie</i> on <i>e</i>; 'Nella miseria;'
  Inf. v. 123.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL279" id="TIVNL279" class="pginternal">279</a>. <i>combre-world</i>, encumbrance of the world, a
  compound epithet. It is used by Hoccleve, in his lament for Chaucer, De Regim. Principum, st. 299.
  'A <i>cumber-world</i>, yet in the world am left;' Drayton, Pastorals, Ecl. ii. 25.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL286" id="TIVNL286" class="pginternal">286</a>. <i>gerful</i>, changeable; see note to Kn. Ta. A
  1536.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL300" id="TIVNL300" class="pginternal">300</a>. <i>Edippe</i>, Œdipus, king of Thebes, who put
  out his own eyes on finding that he had slain his father Laius and married his mother Jocasta;
  Statius, Theb. i. 46.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL302" id="TIVNL302" class="pginternal">302</a>. Rossetti thus translates Fil. iv. st. 34: 'O soul,
  wretched and astray, Why fliest thou not out of the most ill-fortuned body that lives? O soul
  brought low, part from the body, and follow Chryseis.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL305" id="TIVNL305" class="pginternal">305</a>. <i>unneste</i>, glossed in H. by 'go out of thi
  nest;' correctly.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL318" id="TIVNL318" class="pginternal">318</a>. Read <i>my</i>, not <i>the</i> or <i>thy</i>;
  Rossetti thus translates Fil. iv. st. 36: 'O my Chryseis, O sweet bliss of the sorrowing soul
  which calls on thee! Who will any more give comfort to <i>my</i> pains?'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL330" id="TIVNL330" class="pginternal">330</a>. <i>unholsom</i>; Boccaccio has <i>insano</i>, Fil.
  iv. st. 38. 'I think it pretty clear that B. means <i>insane</i> in our ordinary sense for that
  word; but Chaucer's <i>unholsom</i> is no doubt founded on B.'s epithet, and is highly
  picturesque.'—Rossetti.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL356" id="TIVNL356" class="pginternal">356, 7</a>. Nearly repeated in Man of Lawes Ta. B 608, 9. See
  l. 882.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL381" id="TIVNL381" class="pginternal">381</a>. 'As certainly do I wish it were false, as I know it
  is true.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL392" id="TIVNL392" class="pginternal">392</a>. <i>propretee</i>, his own indefeasible possession;
  see Boethius, Bk. ii. Pr. 2. 9 (p. 27), 61 (p. 28).</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL407" id="TIVNL407" class="pginternal">407</a>. Pandarus took his morality from Ovid; cf. Amorum lib.
  ii. 4. 10-44: 'Centum sunt causae, cur ego semper amem;' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL413" id="TIVNL413" class="pginternal">413</a>. <i>heroner</i>, a large falcon for herons; <i>faucon
  for rivere</i>, a goshawk for waterfowl. See note to Sir Thopas, B 1927.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL414" id="TIVNL414" class="pginternal">414, 5</a>. From Boccaccio, who does not, however, give the
  name of the author of the saying. The remark 'as Zanzis writeth' is Chaucer's own. It is quite
  clear that <i>Zanzis</i> in this passage is the same as the <i>Zanzis</i> in the Physiciens Tale,
  C 16; and he is no other than Zeuxis the painter. I do not suppose that Chaucer had any special
  reason for assigning to him the saying, but his name was as useful as that of any one else, and
  the medieval method of reference is frequently so casual and light-hearted that there is nothing
  to wonder at. Besides, we are distinctly told (l. 428) that Pandarus was speaking <i>for the
  nonce</i>, <span class="pagenum" id="page488">{488}</span>i.e. quite at random. The real author is
  Ovid: 'Successore nouo uincitur omnis amor;' Remed. Amor. 462.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL460" id="TIVNL460" class="pginternal">460</a>. <i>pleyen raket</i>, play at rackets, knocking the
  ball forwards and backwards; alluding to the rebound of the ball after striking the wall.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL461" id="TIVNL461" class="pginternal">461</a>. <i>Netle in, dokke out</i> means, as Chaucer says,
  first one thing and then another. The words are taken from a charm for curing the sting of a
  nettle, repeated whilst the patient rubs in the juice from a dock-leaf. The usual formula is
  simply, 'in dock, out nettle,' for which see Brockett's Glossary of North-Country Words, s. v.
  <i>dockon</i> (dock); but Chaucer is doubtless correct. He refers to a fuller form of words, given
  in Notes and Queries, 1st Ser. iii. 368<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Nettle in, dock out—Dock in, nettle out;</p>
<p>Nettle in, dock out—Dock rub nettle out.'</p>
</div>
<p>Akermann's Glossary of Wiltshire Words gives a third formula, as follows<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Out 'ettle, in dock—Dock shall ha' a new smock;</p>
<p style="margin-left:2.60em">'Ettle zhan't ha' narrun.'</p>
</div>
<p>i.e. nettle shan't have ne'er one. See also N. and Q. 1st Ser. iii. 205, 368; xi. 92; Athenæum,
  Sept. 12, 1846; Brand, Pop. Antiq. iii. 315.</p>
<p>In the Testament of Love, Bk. i., the present passage is quoted in the following form: 'Ye wete
  wel, lady, eke (quod I) that <i>I haue not playde racket, nettyl in, docke out</i>, and with the
  wethercocke waued;' ed. 1550, fol. cccv. col. 2. This shews that the text is correct.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL462" id="TIVNL462" class="pginternal">462</a>. 'Now ill luck befall her, that may care for thy
  wo.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL481" id="TIVNL481" class="pginternal">481-3</a>. <i>gabbestow</i>, liest thou. Ll. 482, 3 are a
  reproduction of Pandarus' own saying, in Bk. iii. 1625-8.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL493" id="TIVNL493" class="pginternal">493</a>. Deficient in the first foot; read—'I | that
  liv'd' | &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL497" id="TIVNL497" class="pginternal">497</a>. <i>formely</i>; Cm. <i>formaly</i>; for
  <i>formelly</i>, i.e. formally.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL503" id="TIVNL503" class="pginternal">503</a>. From Boethius, Bk. i. Met. 1. 13, 14 (p. 1).</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL506" id="TIVNL506" class="pginternal">506</a>. Troilus speaks as if dead already. 'Well wot I,
  whilst I lived in peace, before thou (death) didst slay me, I would have given (thee) hire;' i.e.
  a bribe, not to attack me.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL520" id="TIVNL520" class="pginternal">520</a>. <i>alambyk</i>, alembic; i.e. a retort, or vessel
  used in distilling; in Cant. Ta. G 794, MS. E. has the pl. <i>alambikes</i>, and most other MSS.
  have <i>alembikes</i>. The word was afterwards split up into <i>a lembick</i> or <i>a limbeck</i>;
  see Macb. i. 7. 67. Chaucer took this from Le Rom. de la Rose, 6406-7<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Je vois maintes fois que tu plores</p>
<p>Cum alambic sus alutel.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#TIVL556" id="TIVNL556" class="pginternal">556</a>. 'Then think I, this would injure her reputation.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL583" id="TIVNL583" class="pginternal">583</a>. 'But if I had so ardent a love, and had thy
  rank.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL588" id="TIVNL588" class="pginternal">588</a>. Cf. the phrase 'a nine days' wonder.' Lat.
  <i>nouendiale sacrum</i>; Livy, i. 31.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL600" id="TIVNL600" class="pginternal">600</a>. 'Audentes Fortuna iuuat;' Æneid. x. 284; 'Fortes
  Fortuna adiuuat'; Terence, Phormio, i. 4. 26.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL602" id="TIVNL602" class="pginternal">602</a>. 'Unhardy is unsely;' Reves Ta. A 4210.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page489">{489}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIVL603" id="TIVNL603" class="pginternal">603</a>. For <i>litel</i>, MS. H. and Thynne have <i>lite</i>.
  It makes no difference, either to the sense or the scansion.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL607" id="TIVNL607" class="pginternal">607</a>. <i>for ferd</i>, for fear (H2. <i>for drede</i>;
  Thynne, <i>for feare</i>). Properly <i>for ferde</i>, as in Ho. Fame, 950; but often shortened to
  <i>for ferd</i>. <i>Ferde</i> or <i>ferd</i> is tolerably common as a sb., but some scribes hardly
  understood it. Hence MSS. Cl. and H. have <i>of-fered</i>, i.e. greatly frightened.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL618" id="TIVNL618" class="pginternal">618</a>. Cf. Kn. Ta. A 1163-8; and the notes.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL622" id="TIVNL622" class="pginternal">622</a>. 'Boldly stake the world on casts of the dice.' Cf.
  Cant. Tales, B 125, C 653, and the notes.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL627" id="TIVNL627" class="pginternal">627</a>. Nearly repeated in Kn. Tale, A 1010.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL630" id="TIVNL630" class="pginternal">630</a>. 'The devil help him that cares about it.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL659" id="TIVNL659" class="pginternal">659-61</a>. From Boccaccio, Fil. iv. st. 78; cf. Æneid. iv.
  188.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL683" id="TIVNL683" class="pginternal">683</a>. 'And expected to please her.' <i>For pitous Ioye</i>
  represents 'pietosa allegrezza,' Fil. iv. st. 80.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL684" id="TIVNL684" class="pginternal">684</a>. 'Dear enough at a mite;' cf. note to L. G. Wom.

<p><a href="#TIVL692" id="TIVNL692" class="pginternal">692</a>. <i>on every syde</i>; 'd'ogni partito;' Fil. iv. 81.
  I suppose it means, literally, 'on every side;' Troy being subject to attacks at various
  points.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL708" id="TIVNL708" class="pginternal">708-14</a>. Certainly genuine; found also in Fil. iv. 84.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL716" id="TIVNL716" class="pginternal">716</a>. Deficient in the first foot.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL735" id="TIVNL735" class="pginternal">735</a>. Dr. Furnivall says that MSS. Cl., H., and others have
  here misplaced a stanza, meaning that ll. 750-6 should have come next, as shewn by Boccaccio's
  text. But only MS. Cm. has such an order, and it is quite certain that the other MSS. are right.
  The order in Boccaccio's text furnishes no real guide, as Chaucer often transposes such order; and
  it is odd that only this <i>one</i> instance should have been noted. It is better to consider the
  order in MS. Cm. as wrong, and to say that it transposes the text by placing ll. 750-6 after l.
  735, and gives a somewhat different version of ll. 750-2.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL736" id="TIVNL736" class="pginternal">736</a>. <i>ounded</i>, waved, wavy; see Ho. Fame, 1386, and
  note. Cf. 'Tear my bright hair,' &amp;c.; Shak. Troilus, iv. 2. 112.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL750" id="TIVNL750" class="pginternal">750</a>. Cf. note to l. 735. MS. Cm., which inserts this
  stanza after l. 735, begins thus<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'The salte teris from hyre eyȝyn tweyn</p>
<p>Out ran, as schour of Aprille ful swythe;</p>
<p>Hyre white brest sche bet, and for the peyne,' &amp;c.</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#TIVL762" id="TIVNL762" class="pginternal">762</a>. This line, giving the name of Criseyde's mother, is
  not in Boccaccio (Fil. iv. stt. 89-93). I do not know where Chaucer found the form <i>Argyve</i>;
  in Statius, Theb. ii. 297, <i>Argia</i> is the name of the wife of Polynices, and Ch. calls her
  <i>Argyve</i>; see Bk. v. l. 1509 below.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL769" id="TIVNL769" class="pginternal">769, 70</a>. <i>by-word</i>, proverb: 'plants without a root
  soon die.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL782" id="TIVNL782" class="pginternal">782</a>. <i>ordre</i>, order. She will pass her life in
  mourning and abstinence, as if she had entered a religious order.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL790" id="TIVNL790" class="pginternal">790</a>. <i>Elysos</i>, Elysium. It looks as if Chaucer was
  thinking of Vergil's 'Elysios ... campos;' Georg. i. 38; for the story of Orpheus and Eurydice
  occurs in Georg. iv. 453-527. Cf. Ovid, Met. x. 1-85.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page490">{490}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIVL829" id="TIVNL829" class="pginternal">829</a>. <i>cause causinge</i>, the primary cause. '<i>Causa
  causans</i>, a primary or original cause; <i>causa causata</i>, a secondary or intermediate

<p><a href="#TIVL831" id="TIVNL831" class="pginternal">831</a>. <i>Wher</i>, short for <i>whether</i>; as in Cant.

<p><a href="#TIVL836" id="TIVNL836" class="pginternal">836</a>. 'Extrema gaudii luctus occupat;' Prov. xiv. 13. See

<p><a href="#TIVL850" id="TIVNL850" class="pginternal">850</a>. <i>resport</i>, regard; see note to l. 86 above.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL865" id="TIVNL865" class="pginternal">865</a>. Compare the similar lines in Kn. Ta. A 1400, 1.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL866" id="TIVNL866" class="pginternal">866</a>. <i>men</i>, weakened form of <i>man</i>, takes a
  sing. verb.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL870" id="TIVNL870" class="pginternal">870</a>. <i>Bi-trent</i>, winds round; see note to iii.
  1231.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL884" id="TIVNL884" class="pginternal">884</a>. <i>into litel</i>, within a little, very nearly.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL887" id="TIVNL887" class="pginternal">887</a>. <i>fawe</i>, gladly; cf. Cant. Ta. D 220.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL907" id="TIVNL907" class="pginternal">907</a>. <i>bane</i>, destruction; see Kn. Ta. A 1097,
  1681.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL927" id="TIVNL927" class="pginternal">927</a>. 'Be to him rather a cause of the <i>flat</i> than of
  the <i>edge</i>,' i.e. of healing rather than of harming. A curious allusion which is fully
  explained by reference to the Squieres Tale, F 156-165. See also note to the same, F 238.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL947" id="TIVNL947" class="pginternal">947-1085</a>. This passage is not in Boccaccio, but some of it
  is in Boethius; see below.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL963" id="TIVNL963" class="pginternal">963-1078</a>. A considerable portion of this passage is
  copied, more or less closely, from Boethius, lib. v. Pr. 2 and Pr. 3. The correspondences are all
  pointed out below. Chaucer's own prose translation should be compared. For example, the word
  <i>wrythen</i> (l. 986) appears in that also (Bk. v. Pr. 3. 15).</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL963" class="pginternal">963-6</a>. 'Quae tamen ille, ab aeterno cuncta prospiciens, prouidentiae
  cernit intuitus, et suis quaeque meritis praedestinata disponit;' Boeth. v. Pr. 2 (end).</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL968" id="TIVNL968" class="pginternal">968</a>. <i>grete clerkes</i>; such as Boethius, Saint
  Augustine, and bishop Bradwardine; see Non. Pr. Ta. B 4431, 2.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL974" id="TIVNL974" class="pginternal">974-80</a>. 'Nam si cuncta prospicit Deus, neque falli ullo
  modo potest, euenire necesse est, quod prouidentia futurum esse praeuiderit. Quare si ab aeterno
  non facta hominum modo, sed etiam consilia uoluntatesque praenoscit, nulla erit arbitrii
  libertas;' Boeth. v. Pr. 3. 981-7 (<i>continued</i>): 'neque enim uel factum aliud ullum, uel
  quaelibet existere poterit uoluntas, nisi quam nescia falli prouidentia diuina praesenserit. Nam
  si res aliorsum, quam prouisae sunt, detorqueri ualent, non iam erit futuri firma praescientia.'
  988-994 (<i>continued</i>): 'sed opinio potius incerta: quod de Deo credere nefas iudico.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL996" id="TIVNL996" class="pginternal">996</a>. I.e. who have received the tonsure.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL997" id="TIVNL997" class="pginternal">997-1001</a>. 'Aiunt enim, non ideo quid esse euenturum,
  quoniam id prouidentia futurum esse prospexerit: sed è contrario potius, quoniam quid futurum est,
  id diuinam prouidentiam latere non posse;' Boeth. v. Pr. 3. 1002-1008 (<i>continued</i>): 'eoque
  modo necessarium hoc in contrariam relabi partem. Neque enim necesse est contingere, quae
  prouidentur; sed necesse esse, quae futura sunt, prouideri.' 1009-1015 <span class="pagenum" id="page491">{491}</span>(<i>continued</i>): 'Quasi uero, quae cuiusque rei caussa sit,
  praescientiane futurorum necessitatis, an futurorum necessitas prouidentiae, laboretur.' 1016-1022
  (<i>continued</i>): 'At nos illud demonstrare nitamur, quoquo modo sese habeat ordo caussarum,
  necessarium esse euentum praescitarum rerum, etiam si praescientia futuris rebus eueniendi
  necessitatem non uideatur inferre.'</p>
<p>(The negative in l. 1016 is remarkable, but Chaucer's prose rendering presents the same form.
  Surely he has taken <i>nitamur</i> as if it were <i>uitamus</i>.)</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1023" id="TIVNL1023" class="pginternal">1023-9</a>. (<i>continued</i>): 'Etenim si quispiam sedeat,
  opinionem quae eum sedere coniectat ueram esse necesse est: atque è conuerso rursus, (1030-6) si
  de quopiam uera sit opinio, quoniam sedet, eum sedere necesse est. In utroque igitur necessitas
  inest: in hoc quidem sedendi, at uerò in altero ueritatis.' 1037-1047 (<i>continued</i>): 'Sed non
  idcirco quisque sedet, quoniam uera est opinio; sed haec potius uera est, quoniam quempiam sedere
  praecessit. Ita cùm caussa ueritatis ex altera parte procedat, inest tamen communis in utraque
  necessitas. Similia de prouidentia futurisque rebus ratiocinari patet.' 1051-78
  (<i>continued</i>): 'Nam etiam si idcirco, quoniam futura sunt, prouidentur; non uero ideo,
  quoniam prouidentur eueniunt: nihilo minus tamen à Deo uel uentura prouideri, uel prouisa euenire
  necesse est: quod ad perimendam arbitrii libertatem solùm satis est. Iam uero quam praeposterum
  est, ut aeternae praescientiae temporalium rerum euentus caussa esse dicatur? Quid est autem aliud
  arbitrari, ideo Deum futura, quoniam sunt euentura, prouidere, quam putare quae olim acciderunt,
  caussam summae illius esse prouidentiae? Ad haec, sicuti cum quid esse scio, id ipsum esse necesse
  est: ita cum quid futurum noui, id ipsum futurum necesse est. Sic fit igitur, ut euentus
  praescitae rei nequeat euitari.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1094" id="TIVNL1094" class="pginternal">1094</a>. <i>ferd</i>, fared; not the pp. of <i>faren</i>
  (l. 1087), but of the weak verb <i>feren</i> (A. S. <i>fēran</i>). The correct pp. of
  <i>faren</i> is <i>faren</i>. See Stratmann.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1105" id="TIVNL1105" class="pginternal">1105</a>. 'A man may offer his neck soon enough when it
  (i. e. his head) must come off.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1136" id="TIVNL1136" class="pginternal">1136</a>. 'Beyond the nature of tears.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1139" id="TIVNL1139" class="pginternal">1139</a>. Myrrha, daughter of Cinyras, king of Cyprus, who
  was changed into a myrrh-tree; Ovid, Met. x. 298. The tree wept tears of myrrh; id. x. 500.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1146" id="TIVNL1146" class="pginternal">1146</a>. <i>hir-e</i> (MS. Cl. <i>here</i>), their, is here
  dissyllabic. <i>unswelle</i>, cease to swell, as in Bk. v. 214.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1147" id="TIVNL1147" class="pginternal">1147</a>. 'All hoarse, and exhausted with shrieking.'
  <i>forshright</i> is the pp. of <i>forshriken</i>, to shriek excessively. Bell wrongly has <i>for
  shright</i>; but <i>shright</i> is not a noun. The Ital. has 'con <i>rotta</i> voce,' with broken
  voice; Fil. iv. st. 116.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1153" id="TIVNL1153" class="pginternal">1153</a>. 'Being always on the point of departing.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1162" id="TIVNL1162" class="pginternal">1162</a>. 'Whether it was sad for him.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1174" id="TIVNL1174" class="pginternal">1174</a>. Cf. 'And <i>bisily</i> gan,' &amp;c.; Prol. A
  301.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page492">{492}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIVL1179" id="TIVNL1179" class="pginternal">1179</a>. <i>preignant</i> (F. <i>preignant</i>,
  <i>pregnant</i>, Cotgrave), catching hold of tightly, hence, forcible; pres. part. of
  <i>prendre</i>, to seize. Quite distinct from <i>pregnant</i> when representing Lat.
  <i>praegnans</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1181" id="TIVNL1181" class="pginternal">1181</a>. <i>woon</i>, hope, resource. This answers to Early
  E. <i>wān</i> (see Stratmann), and is allied to Icel. <i>ván</i>, hope, expectation; cf.
  Icel. <i>væna</i>, to hope for, to ween. The word is monosyllabic, and the long <i>o</i> is
  'open,' as shewn by its riming with <i>noon</i>, <i>goon</i>, from A. S. <i>nān</i>,
  <i>gān</i>. Bell quite fails to explain it, and Morris suggests 'remedy,' without assigning
  any reason. It is common in Rob. of Gloucester, with similar rimes, and does not mean 'custom' or
  'habit' or 'manner,' as suggested in Mr. Wright's Glossary, nor has it any connection with M. E.
  <i>wone</i>, custom, which was dissyllabic, and had a short vowel in the former syllable; but it
  means, as here, 'hope' or 'resource.' For example: 'tho he ne sey other <i>won</i>' = when he saw
  nothing else to be done; Rob. Glouc. ed. Hearne, p. 12; ed. Wright, l. 275. 'And flowe in-to hor
  castles, vor hii nadde other <i>won</i>,' i. e. no other resource; id. p. 19, ed. Hearne, l.
  442. This is one of the rather numerous words in Chaucer that have not been rightly
  understood.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1185" id="TIVNL1185" class="pginternal">1185</a>. <i>twighte</i>, plucked; pt. t. of
  <i>twicchen</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1188" id="TIVNL1188" class="pginternal">1188</a>. 'Where the doom of Minos would assign it a place.'
  Boccaccio here uses the word <i>inferno</i> (Fil. iv. 120) to denote the place where Troilus' soul
  would dwell; which Rossetti explains to mean simply Hades. Chaucer's meaning is the same; he is
  referring to Æneid. vi. 431-3.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1208" id="TIVNL1208" class="pginternal">1208</a>. Atropos is the Fate who cuts the thread of life;
  see note to v. 7.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1237" id="TIVNL1237" class="pginternal">1237</a>. <i>a forlong wey</i>, two minutes and a half, to
  speak exactly; see note to C. T., A 3637.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1241" id="TIVNL1241" class="pginternal">1241</a>. Either <i>slayn</i> is here expanded into
  <i>slayen</i>, or the pause after this word does duty for a syllable, in the scansion.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1242" id="TIVNL1242" class="pginternal">1242</a>. <i>ho</i>, stop, cease; see Kn. Ta. A 1706.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1244" id="TIVNL1244" class="pginternal">1244</a>. <i>ther-e</i> is here made into a dissyllable.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1245" id="TIVNL1245" class="pginternal">1245</a>. <i>morter</i>, mortar. The Century Dict. quotes
  from Dugdale's Hist. of St. Paul's (ed. Ellis), p. 27: 'A <i>mortar</i> was a wide bowl of iron or
  metal; it rested upon a stand or branch, and was filled either with fine oil or wax, which was
  kept burning by means of a broad wick [at funerals or on tombs].' It was named from its similarity
  in shape to the <i>mortar</i> in which things were pounded. I remember the word in common use; it
  came to denote what is now called a <i>night-light</i>, and the word <i>night-light</i> seems to
  have nearly displaced it. In this modern contrivance, the old 'mortar' is sometimes represented by
  a paper casing. The term was frequently applied, not merely to the saucer which held the grease,
  but to the light itself, which sometimes took the shape of a short candle. Cotgrave explains F.
  <i>mortier</i> as 'a kind of small chamber-lamp.' Instead of <i>morter</i>, MS. Cm. has
  <i>percher</i>, which meant a kind of wax candle placed upon a branch or bar called a
  <i>perche</i> (perch).</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1295" id="TIVNL1295" class="pginternal">1295</a>. 'About that (there) is no question.' Cf. l.
  1694.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page493">{493}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIVL1374" id="TIVNL1374" class="pginternal">1374</a>. <i>wether</i>, sheep. I. e. it is advisable
  to give the wolf a limb of a sheep, in order to save the rest.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1377" id="TIVNL1377" class="pginternal">1377</a>. <i>grave</i>, incise, make an impression upon.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1380" id="TIVNL1380" class="pginternal">1380</a>. <i>moble</i> (H., H2. <i>moeble</i>), movable
  property; cf. F. <i>meubles</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1404" id="TIVNL1404" class="pginternal">1404</a>. 'Whilst he is making his divination; and I will
  make him believe.' Ll. 1401-14 are due to a passage in Guido; see allit. Destruction of Troy,
  8101-40.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1406" id="TIVNL1406" class="pginternal">1406</a>. <i>amphibologyes</i>, ambiguities. A more correct
  form is <i>amphiboly</i>, from Gk. <span class="fsn" title="amphibolia">ἀμφιβολία</span>; see New E. Dict.
  The ambiguous character of the old oracular responses is well known.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1411" id="TIVNL1411" class="pginternal">1411</a>. 'When he started away from Delphi for fear.' Cf.
  l. 607.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1422" id="TIVNL1422" class="pginternal">1422</a>. See note to Book i. 463.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1425" id="TIVNL1425" class="pginternal">1425</a>. <i>the selve wit</i>, the same opinion.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1435" id="TIVNL1435" class="pginternal">1435</a>. <i>clere</i>, clear of woe, free, light. MS. H.
  has <i>chere</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1453" id="TIVNL1453" class="pginternal">1453</a>. 'The bear has one opinion, and his leader
  another.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1456" id="TIVNL1456" class="pginternal">1456</a>. Repeated in Kn. Ta. A 2449; see note.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1459" id="TIVNL1459" class="pginternal">1459</a>. 'With eyes like Argus;' i. e. seeing
  everywhere. Argus had a hundred eyes; Ovid, Met. i. 625.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1483" id="TIVNL1483" class="pginternal">1483</a>. <i>fere</i>, frighten, terrify; as in Bk. ii.
  124.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1505" id="TIVNL1505" class="pginternal">1505</a>. 'To lose the substance, for the sake of something
  accidentally representing it;' as when the dog dropped the piece of meat, in his anxiety to get
  the shadow (or reflected image) of it. As to the famous words <i>substance</i> and
  <i>accident</i>, see note to Pard. Ta. C 539.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1525" id="TIVNL1525" class="pginternal">1525</a>. <i>go we</i>, let us go; also written <i>gowe</i>,
  P. Plowm. B. Pr. 226.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1538" id="TIVNL1538" class="pginternal">1538-40</a>. Juno caused Athamas, the husband of Ino, to run
  mad. As Ovid tells the story, Juno descended into hell, and crossed the Styx, in order to persuade
  the fury Tisiphone to haunt Athamas. Hence the mention of the Styx was readily suggested. See
  Ovid, Met. iv. 416-561, esp. l. 434. Styx was not, as Chaucer says, 'the pit of hell,' but a river
  that flowed through it.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1544" id="TIVNL1544" class="pginternal">1544</a>. <i>Satiry and Fauny</i>, Satyri and Fauni, Satyrs
  and Fauns. Chaucer was probably thinking of Ovid, Met. vi. 392-4, where the <i>Fauni</i>,
  <i>Satyri</i>, and <i>Nymphae</i> are described as 'ruricolae, siluarum numina.' For <i>halve
  goddes</i>, we now say <i>demigods</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1548" id="TIVNL1548" class="pginternal">1548</a>. <i>Simois</i>, a river of Troas; Æneid. i.
  100.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1560" id="TIVNL1560" class="pginternal">1560</a>. <i>laye</i>, would lie; subj. The <i>e</i> is
  elided.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1562" id="TIVNL1562" class="pginternal">1562</a>. <i>take</i>, take place, be made. Thynne has <i>be
  take</i>, but <i>be</i> clogs the line, and is not in the MSS.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1584" id="TIVNL1584" class="pginternal">1584</a>. 'Vincit qui patitur;' see Frank. Ta. F 773.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1585" id="TIVNL1585" class="pginternal">1585</a>. 'He who will have what he wants must give up what
  he likes.' Such seems to be the sense intended. <i>Leef</i> means 'dear.' One of Heywood's
  proverbs is—'Nought lay down, nought take up;' and very similar to this is—'Nothing
  venture, nothing have.' For the second <i>leef</i>, MS. H. has <i>lyfe</i>, a reading adopted by
  Bell and Morris. This takes all point out of the saying, and does not seem applicable to the case.
  Ll. 1587 and 1588 repeat the saying in another form, and confirm the reading in the text. Cf.
  Boeth. Bk. ii. Pr. 4. 98.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page494">{494}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TIVL1591" id="TIVNL1591" class="pginternal">1591, 2</a>. <i>Lucina</i>, i. e. Diana, or the moon;
  cf. Kn. Ta. A 2085. 'Before the moon pass out of the sign of Aries beyond that of Leo.' In order
  to this, the moon would have to pass wholly through Taurus, Gemini, Cancer, and Leo, thus
  traversing a distance represented by about 4 signs, or a third part of the whole zodiac: this
  would take up about the third part of 28 days, or more than 9 days. This brings us, as Criseyde
  says, to the 10th day (l. 1595). Such a method of counting is natural enough to those that watch
  the moon's course; and lovers are generally credited with taking a special interest in that
  luminary; cf. l. 1608. In the sequel, a good deal turns upon this 'tenth day.' Cf. ll. 1320, 1328,
  1685; V. 239, 642, 681, 1103, 1206.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1608" id="TIVNL1608" class="pginternal">1608</a>. <i>Cynthia</i>, i. e. Diana, the moon; Ovid,
  Met. ii. 465.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1612" id="TIVNL1612" class="pginternal">1612</a>. 'To lose one opportunity, in order to gain
  another.'</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1620" id="TIVNL1620" class="pginternal">1620</a>. <i>pure</i>, very; as in Kn. Ta. A 1279.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1628" id="TIVNL1628" class="pginternal">1628</a>. 'Who can hold a thing that tries to get away?'</p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:4.00em">'An eel and woman,</p>
<p>A learned poet says, unless by th' tail</p>
<p>And with thy teeth thou hold, will either fail.'</p>
<p style="margin-left:4.55em">The Two Noble Kinsmen, A. iii. sc. 5. l. 49.</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#TIVL1645" id="TIVNL1645" class="pginternal">1645</a>. 'Res est solliciti plena timoris amor;' Ovid, Her.
  i. 12.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1667" id="TIVNL1667" class="pginternal">1667-73</a>. In Boccaccio, a stanza of a similar character
  is assigned to Troilus, not to Criseyde.</p>
<p><a href="#TIVL1677" id="TIVNL1677" class="pginternal">1677</a>. <i>poeplish</i>; Boccaccio (Fil. iv. st. 165) has
  <i>popolesco</i>, which Rossetti translates by 'low-bred.' Florio's Ital. Dict. has:
  '<i>popolesco</i>, popular, of the common people.'</p>
<p class="sp3"><a href="#TIVL1682" id="TIVNL1682" class="pginternal">1682</a>. <i>fórtun-è</i> is trisyllabic.</p>
<h2>BOOK V.</h2>
<p>The following sketch gives a general notion of the relation of this Book to the Filostrato,
  though Chaucer often amplifies and transposes the material in a way that it would be tedious to
  particularise more minutely.</p>
