<p><a href="#TVL3" id="TVNL3" class="pginternal">3</a>. <i>Parcas</i>, Fates; the accusative case, as usual.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL7" id="TVNL7" class="pginternal">7</a>. <i>Lachesis</i>, the Fate that apportions the thread of life;
  often represented with the spindle, though this is properly the attribute of Clotho alone. Clotho
  spins, Lachesis apportions, and Atropos cuts, the thread of life. Atropos has been mentioned
  above; Bk. iv. 1208, 1546. Statius mentions all three in lib. iii. of his Thebaid; Clotho at l.
  556, Lachesis (Lachesim putri uacuantem saecula penso) at l. 642, and Atropos at l. 68.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL8" id="TVNL8" class="pginternal">8</a>. For <i>golden tressed</i>, MS. Harl. 3943 has <i>Auricomus
  tressed</i> (!). Cf. 'Sol auricomus, cingentibus Horis;' Valerius Flaccus, Argonaut. iv. 92.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL12" id="TVNL12" class="pginternal">12</a>, <a href="#TVL13" id="TVNL13" class="pginternal">13</a>. <i>sone of
  Hecuba</i>, Troilus; <i>hir</i>, Criseyde.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL15" id="TVNL15" class="pginternal">15-9</a>. Note that ll. 15, 17 rime on <i>-éde</i>, with close
  <i>e</i>, but ll. 16, 18, 19 rime on <i>-ède</i>, with open <i>e</i>. Cf. Anelida, 299-307.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL22" id="TVNL22" class="pginternal">22-6</a>. Lines 22, 24 rime on <i>-ōre</i>, with long close
  <i>o</i>; ll. 23, 25, 26 on <i>-ŏre</i>, with (original) short open <i>o</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL25" id="TVNL25" class="pginternal">25</a>. <i>crop</i>, shoot, upper part of a tree. <i>more</i>,
  root, still in use in Hants; A. S. <i>more</i>, <i>moru</i>; see P. Plowman, B. xvi. 5, C. xviii.
  21.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL53" id="TVNL53" class="pginternal">53</a>. 'Upon the report of such behaviour of his.'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL65" id="TVNL65" class="pginternal">65</a>. So in Boccaccio: 'Con un falcone in pugno;' Fil. v. st.
  10.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL67" id="TVNL67" class="pginternal">67</a>. A mistranslation. Boccaccio's word is not <i>valle</i>, a
  valley, but <i>vallo</i>, a rampart. The first foot lacks a syllable.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL71" id="TVNL71" class="pginternal">71</a>. Antenor was the Trojan, captured by the Greeks, who was
  restored to Troy in exchange for Thoas and Criseyde.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL88" id="TVNL88" class="pginternal">88</a>. <i>sone of Tydeus</i>, i. e. Diomede, often called
  <i>Tydides</i>; as in Æneid. i. 97, 471, &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL89" id="TVNL89" class="pginternal">89</a>. To know one's creed is very elementary knowledge.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL90" id="TVNL90" class="pginternal">90</a>. <i>by the reyne hir hente</i>; Rossetti thinks Chaucer
  misunderstood <span class="pagenum" id="page496">{496}</span><i>di colei si piglia</i> (Fil. v.
  13), which might mean 'takes hold of her,' but really means 'takes a fancy to her.'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL98" id="TVNL98" class="pginternal">98</a>. This resembles 'to take care of No. 1.'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL101" id="TVNL101" class="pginternal">101</a>. <i>make it tough</i>, raise a difficulty, viz. by
  disparaging Troilus.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL106" id="TVNL106" class="pginternal">106</a>. <i>coude his good</i>, knew what was good for him, knew
  what he was about. Bell says—'understood good manners.'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL128" id="TVNL128" class="pginternal">128</a>. <i>helply</i>; we now say 'helpful,' i.e. serviceable.
  <i>to my might</i>, to the best of my power.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL143" id="TVNL143" class="pginternal">143</a>. <i>O god of love</i>, one and the same god of love.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL151" id="TVNL151" class="pginternal">151</a>. <i>this</i>, contracted form of <i>this is</i>.
  <i>enseled</i>, sealed up.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL158" id="TVNL158" class="pginternal">158</a>. <i>As paramours</i>, as by way of love. Cf. l. 332.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL180" id="TVNL180" class="pginternal">180</a>. See below (l. 530), and Man of Lawes Ta. B 697. We can
  read either <i>brast</i> (burst), or <i>braste</i> (would burst).</p>
<p><a href="#TVL182" id="TVNL182" class="pginternal">182</a>. <i>sye</i>, to sink down; A. S. <i>sīgan</i>;
  see <i>siȝen</i> in Stratmann.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL194" id="TVNL194" class="pginternal">194</a>. <i>mewet</i>, mute; as in the Court of Love, 148.
  <i>Mewet</i>, <i>muwet</i>, or <i>muet</i> is from the O. F. <i>muët</i>, orig. dissyllabic, and
  answering to a Low Lat. diminutive type <i>*mutettum</i>. The E. word is now obsolete, being
  displaced by the simple form <i>mute</i>, borrowed directly from Lat. <i>mutus</i>, which in O. F.
  became <i>mu</i>. <i>Mute</i> is common in Shakespeare. Lydgate has: 'And also clos and
  <i>muët</i> as a stone;' Siege of Thebes, pt. iii. § 8. In Merlin, ed. Wheatley, p. 172, we find
  'stille and <i>mewet</i> as though thei hadde be dombe.'</p>
<p>The <i>-e</i> in <i>mild-e</i> is not elided; the A. S. <i>milde</i> is dissyllabic.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL208" id="TVNL208" class="pginternal">208</a>. <i>Cipryde</i>, i.e. Cypris, or Venus; see note to
  Parl. Foules, 277.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL212" id="TVNL212" class="pginternal">212</a>. The <i>-ie</i> in <i>furie</i> is rapidly slurred over.
  <i>Ixion</i> is accented on the <i>first</i> syllable. Ixion was bound, in hell, to an
  ever-revolving wheel; Georg. iii. 38; Æn. vi. 601.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL249" id="TVNL249" class="pginternal">249</a>. <i>as mete</i>, as (for instance) dream; see l.
  251.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL283" id="TVNL283" class="pginternal">283</a>. 'Although he had sworn (to do so) on forfeit of his
  head.'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL304" id="TVNL304" class="pginternal">304</a>. <i>pálestrál</i>, i.e. games consisting of
  wrestling-matches and similar contests; from Lat. <i>palaestra</i>; see Verg. Æn. iii. 280, 281;
  and G. Douglas, ed. Small, vol. iii. p. 52, l. 24. There is a description of such games, held at a
  funeral, in Statius, Theb. vi., which is imitated by Chaucer in the Knightes Tale; see note to A
  2863. <i>Vigile</i> (l. 305) is the same as Chaucer's <i>liche-wake</i>; see note to A 2958.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL306" id="TVNL306" class="pginternal">306</a>. He means that his steed, sword, and helm are to be
  offered up to Mars, and his shield to Pallas, at his funeral; cf. Kn. Ta. A 2889-2894.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL319" id="TVNL319" class="pginternal">319</a>. <i>Ascaphilo</i>, a transposed form of Ascalaphus, whom
  Proserpine changed into an owl; Ovid, Met. v. 539. So also <i>Adriane</i> for Ariadne. Bell's
  note, that the form of <i>Ascaphilo</i> is Italian, and helps to prove that Chaucer here follows
  Boccaccio is misleading; for Boccaccio does not mention Ascalaphus.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL321" id="TVNL321" class="pginternal">321</a>. Mercury was supposed to convey men's souls to Hades.
  See l. 1827 below, and note.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL332" id="TVNL332" class="pginternal">332</a>. <i>paramours</i>, passionately; an adverb, as usual;
  cf. l. 158.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL345" id="TVNL345" class="pginternal">345</a>. <i>By freendes might</i>, by constraint of their
  relatives.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page497">{497}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TVL350" id="TVNL350" class="pginternal">350</a>. <i>hurt</i>, for <i>hurteth</i>, hurts; present
  tense.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL360" id="TVNL360" class="pginternal">360</a>. On dreams, cf. Non. Pr. Ta. B 4113-4129, 4280-4.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL365" id="TVNL365" class="pginternal">365-8</a>. From Le Rom. de la Rose, 18709-12, q. v.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL379" id="TVNL379" class="pginternal">379</a>. Lit. 'Well is it, concerning dreams, to these old
  wives;' i.e. these old women set a value on dreams.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL387" id="TVNL387" class="pginternal">387</a>. Boccaccio has: 'a te stesso perdona,' i.e. spare
  thyself; Chaucer takes it literally—'forgive thyself.'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL403" id="TVNL403" class="pginternal">403</a>. Sarpedon had been taken prisoner by the Greeks (iv.
  52). Neither Boccaccio nor Chaucer explains how he had got back to Troy. See l. 431.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL409" id="TVNL409" class="pginternal">409</a>. <i>iouken</i>, slumber; cf. P. Plowman, C. xix. 126. It
  was chiefly used as a term in falconry, and applied to hawks. In the Boke of St. Albans, fol. a 6,
  we are told that it is proper to say that 'your hauke <i>Ioukith</i>, and not slepith.' From O. F.
  <i>joquier</i>, <i>jouquier</i>; see Godefroy.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL421" id="TVNL421" class="pginternal">421</a>. <i>of fyne force</i>, by very necessity.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL451" id="TVNL451" class="pginternal">451</a>. I read 'piëtous,' as in MS. H., not 'pitous,' for the
  sake of the metre, as in Bk. iii. 1444; cf. <i>pietee</i>, id. 1033. Perhaps Chaucer was thinking
  of the Ital. <i>pietoso</i>. We also find the spelling <i>pitevous</i>, for which form there is
  sufficient authority; see Wyclif, 2 Tim. iii. 12, Titus ii. 12; Rob. of Glouc. ed. Wright, 5884
  (footnote); cf. Mod. E. <i>piteous</i>. Chaucer's usual word is <i>pitous</i>, as in Cant. Ta. B
  449, 1059, C 298, &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL460" id="TVNL460" class="pginternal">460</a>. <i>For</i>, because; as frequently.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL469" id="TVNL469" class="pginternal">469</a>. 'Fortune intended to glaze his hood still better.' To
  'glaze one's hood' was to furnish a man with a glass hood, a jocular phrase for to mock or expose
  to attack; because a glass hood would be no defence at all. Chaucer himself admirably illustrates
  this saying in a passage which has already occurred above; see Bk. ii. 867.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL478" id="TVNL478" class="pginternal">478</a>. <i>her-e</i> is dissyllabic; as in Ho. Fame, 980, 1014,
  1885, 1912, &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL479" id="TVNL479" class="pginternal">479</a>. <i>congeyen us</i>, bid us take leave, dismiss us.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL484" id="TVNL484" class="pginternal">484</a>. 'Did we come here to fetch light for a fire, and run
  home again?' A man who borrows a light must hurry back before it goes out.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL505" id="TVNL505" class="pginternal">505</a>. <i>Hasel-wode</i>, hazel-wood; an allusion to a popular
  saying, expressive of incredulity. See note to l. 1174 below. Not the same proverb as that in Bk.
  iii. 890.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL541" id="TVNL541" class="pginternal">541</a>. 'O house, formerly called the best of houses.' Bell and
  Morris place the comma after <i>houses</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL552" id="TVNL552" class="pginternal">552</a>. As to kissing the door, see note to Rom. Rose,
  2676.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL601" id="TVNL601" class="pginternal">601</a>. Referring, probably, to Statius, Theb. i.
  12—'Quod saeuae Iunonis opus.' But this refers to the wrath of Juno against Athamas rather
  than against Thebes.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL642" id="TVNL642" class="pginternal">642</a>. 'Wherefore, if, on the tenth night, I fail (to have)
  the guiding of thy bright beams for a single hour,' &amp;c.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL655" id="TVNL655" class="pginternal">655</a>. Here Thynne's reading, <i>Lucina</i>, is obviously
  correct; see Bk. iv. 1591. By the common mistake of writing <i>t</i> for <i>c</i>, it became
  Lutina, and was then changed into <i>Latona</i>. But Latona was Lucina's <i>mother</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL664" id="TVNL664" class="pginternal">664</a>. <i>Pheton</i>, Phaethon; alluding to Ovid, Met. ii. 34,
  47, &amp;c.</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page498">{498}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TVL744" id="TVNL744" class="pginternal">744</a>. Prudence is here represented with <i>three</i> eyes, to
  behold present, past, and future; but Creseyde had but <i>two</i> eyes, and failed to see what was
  to come. Cf. 'rerum fato Prudentia maior;' Georg. i. 416.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL763" id="TVNL763" class="pginternal">763</a>. 'I call it felicity when I have what satisfies me;' cf.
  the parallel passage in Prol. A 338; and Boeth. Bk. iii. Pr. 2. 6-8.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL769" id="TVNL769" class="pginternal">769</a>. <i>knotteles</i>; 'like a thread in which there is no
  knot.'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL784" id="TVNL784" class="pginternal">784</a>. 'Nothing venture, nothing have.'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL805" id="TVNL805" class="pginternal">805</a>. In Lydgate's Siege of Troye, we are told that Diomede
  brought 80 ships with him 'fro Calidonye and Arge;' Bk. ii. ch. 16, in the catalogue of the ships.
  The English alliterative Romance omits this passage. <i>Arge</i> is the town of Argos, ruled over
  by Diomede; Homer, Il. ii. 559. <i>Calidoine</i> is Calydon, in Ætolia, of which city Tydeus,
  father of Diomede, was king; see l. 934, and ll. 1513-5 below.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL806" id="TVNL806" class="pginternal">806</a>. This description seems to be mainly Chaucer's own. It
  occurs again, much amplified, in Lydgate's Siege of Troy, Bk. ii. ch. 15, where it precedes the
  description of Priam. Boccaccio says that she had 'lucent eyes and an angelic face' (Fil. i. st.
  28), with which cf. l. 816. He also describes her as 'Accorta, savia, onesta, e costumata,' which
  Rossetti translates by 'Discerning, wise, honourable, and high-bred' (Fil. i. 11); cf. ll. 820,
  821.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL827" id="TVNL827" class="pginternal">827</a>. Troilus is described by Guido delle Colonne; see the
  translations, in the alliterative Destruction of Troy, ed. Panton and Donaldson, l. 3922, and in
  Lydgate's Siege of Troye, Bk. ii. ch. 16.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL836" id="TVNL836" class="pginternal">836</a>. Troilus was second to Hector in prowess (Bk. ii. 158,
  644), but not in courage (Bk. i. 474).</p>
<p><a href="#TVL837" id="TVNL837" class="pginternal">837</a>. <i>durring don</i>, daring to do, courage; where
  <i>durring</i> is a sb. formed from <i>durren</i>, to dare. So in l. 840, <i>to durre don</i> is
  'to dare to do.' It is quite a mistake to regard <i>durring don</i> as a compound word, as is
  usually done by such as are ignorant of Middle English grammar. Spenser borrowed the phrase, but
  may have misunderstood it. In the Globe edition of Spenser, <i>derring-doe</i> occurs <i>with a
  hyphen</i>, in Shep. Kal. <i>Oct.</i> l. 65, but <i>as two words</i>, in F. Q. ii. 4. 42, vi. 5.
  37. In F. Q. ii. 7. 10, we find 'in <i>der-doing</i> armes,' which I leave to be explained by the
  omniscient critic.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL852" id="TVNL852" class="pginternal">852</a>. See the parallel line, Squi. Ta. F 294; cf. Bk. iii.
  674.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL883" id="TVNL883" class="pginternal">883</a>. <i>as who seyth</i>, so to speak.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL892" id="TVNL892" class="pginternal">892</a>. <i>Manes</i>, the departed spirits or shades of the
  dead. He means that even these will dread the Greeks. The idea that they are the 'gods of pain' is
  taken from Vergil, Æn. vi. 743; cf. Statius, Theb. viii. 84. Boccaccio merely has 'tra' morti in
  inferno'; Fil. vi. st. 16.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL897" id="TVNL897" class="pginternal">897</a>. <i>ambages</i>, ambiguities; adapted from Boccaccio's
  'ambage' (Fil. vi. st. 17), which Ch. has to explain.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL911" id="TVNL911" class="pginternal">911-938</a>. These lines are fairly close to the original.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL934" id="TVNL934" class="pginternal">934</a>. See note above, to l. 805. B. has: 'Di Calidonia e d'
  Argo;' Fil. vi. st. 24.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL937" id="TVNL937" class="pginternal">937</a>. Tydeus, father of Diomede, is one of the chief heroes
  in the Thebaid of Statius, which describes the struggle between Eteocles and <span class="pagenum" id="page499">{499}</span>Polynices (called <i>Polymites</i> in l. 938) for the possession of
  Thebes. Tydeus and Polynices married sisters, the daughters of Adrastus, king of Argos; hence
  their alliance. For the death of Tydeus in battle, see the conclusion of Book viii of the Thebaid.
  See ll. 1480-1501 below.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL971" id="TVNL971" class="pginternal">971</a>. <i>Orcades</i>, the Orkney islands, very remote from
  Rome; Juvenal, Sat. ii. 161. <i>Inde</i>, India, remote from Rome in the other direction; Vergil,
  Æn. vi. 794. Here the point of view is transferred from Rome to Troy.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL975" id="TVNL975" class="pginternal">975</a>. She was a widow; Bk. i. 97. In l. 977, she lies
  boldly.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL992" id="TVNL992" class="pginternal">992</a>. 'When I see what I have never seen yet (viz. Troy
  taken), perhaps I will do what I have never yet done (i. e. think of a second husband).'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1013" id="TVNL1013" class="pginternal">1013</a>. This incident is not in Boccaccio; but it occurs in
  Guido delle Colonne, which Chaucer must therefore have consulted. The alliterative Destruction of
  Troy duly records the circumstance, ll. 8092-4<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'A gloue of that gay gate he belyue,</p>
<p>Drogh hit full dernly the damsell fro;</p>
<p>None seond but hir-selfe, that suffert full well.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#TVL1016" id="TVNL1016" class="pginternal">1016</a>. I. e. Venus was seen as 'the evening-star.'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1018" id="TVNL1018" class="pginternal">1018, 9</a>. <i>Cynthea</i>, i. e. the moon; Bk. iv.
  1608. In Bk. iv. l. 1591, Criseyde had promised to return before the moon passed out of the sign
  Leo. This was now on the point of happening; the moon was leaving Leo, to pass into Virgo.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1020" id="TVNL1020" class="pginternal">1020</a>. <i>Signifer</i>, the 'sign-bearer,' the zodiac.
  'This forseide hevenish zodiak is cleped the cercle of the signes;' Astrolabe, pt. i. § 21. The
  zodiac extended, north and south, to the breadth of 6 degrees on both sides of the ecliptic line,
  thus forming a belt 12 degrees wide. This included numerous bright stars, such as Regulus (<span class="fsn" title="a">α</span> Leonis) and Spica Virginis (<span class="fsn" title="a">α</span> Virginis), here called 'candles.' Chaucer may have found the word
  <i>Signifer</i> in Claudian, In Rufinum, i. 365.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1039" id="TVNL1039" class="pginternal">1039</a>. <i>he wan</i>, he took in battle. Thynne reads
  <i>she</i>; but <i>he</i> is right. Diomede got possession of Troilus' horse, and sent it to
  Criseyde; whereupon she said that Diomede might keep it for himself. Note that Chaucer refers us
  to 'the story' for this incident; by which he means the <i>Historia Troiana</i> of Guido. But
  Guido only goes as far as to say that Diomed sent Troilus' horse to Criseyde; the rest is
  Chaucer's addition. See the allit. Destruction of Troy, ll. 8296-8317; and Lydgate's Siege of
  Troye, Bk. iii. ch. 26, ed. 1557, fol. R 4, back. Cf. Shak. Troilus, v. 5. 1: '<i>Dio.</i> Go, go,
  my servant, take thou Troilus' horse, Present the fair steed to my lady Cressid.' The incidents of
  the 'broche' and 'pensel' are Chaucer's own; see Bk. iii. 1370-2.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1043" id="TVNL1043" class="pginternal">1043</a>. <i>pencel</i>, short for <i>penoncel</i>, a little
  pennon or banner; here it means that Diomede wore a sleeve of hers as a streamer on his helmet or
  arm. This was a common custom; cf. Shak. Troil. v. 2. 69, 169. '<i>Pensell</i>, a lytel baner;'
  Palsgrave; and see P. Plowm. C. xix. 189.</p>

<p><a href="#TVL1114" id="TVNL1114" class="pginternal">1114</a>. <i>noon</i>, noon, mid-day; the time for dinner (see

<p><a href="#TVL1133" id="TVNL1133" class="pginternal">1133</a>. <i>cape</i>, gape; see Miller's Tale, A 3444, 3841

<p><a href="#TVL1140" id="TVNL1140" class="pginternal">1140, 1</a>. <i>yate</i>, i.e. port-cullis. <i>As nought ne
  were</i>, as if there were no special reason for it. I.e. I will make them do it, without telling
  them why.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1151" id="TVNL1151" class="pginternal">1151</a>. Deficient in the first foot; hardly a good line.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1155" id="TVNL1155" class="pginternal">1155</a>. 'Think it not tedious to (have to) wait.'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1162" id="TVNL1162" class="pginternal">1162</a>. <i>fare-cart</i>, cart for provisions; cf. our
  phrase 'to enjoy good <i>fare</i>.' It might mean 'travelling-car,' but that is inapplicable. B.
  has simply 'carro;' Fil. vii. 8.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1163" id="TVNL1163" class="pginternal">1163-9</a>. Cf. Romeo's speech in Rom. v. 1. 1-11.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1174" id="TVNL1174" class="pginternal">1174</a>. 'The happiness which you expect will come out of the
  wood,' i.e. if it comes at all. A jocular form of expressing unlikelihood. There is evidently a
  reference to some popular song or saying; compare the Jeu de Robin in Toynbee's Specimens of Old
  French, p. 224. In the Rom. of the Rose, 7455, we have an allusion to a 'ioly Robin,' who was a
  gay dancer and a minstrel, and the exact opposite of a Jacobin friar. Shakespeare's clown in
  Twelfth Night (iv. 2. 78) sings of a 'jolly Robin' whose lady 'loves another.' And Ophelia sang
  'bonny sweet Robin is all my joy;' Haml. iv. 5. 187.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1176" id="TVNL1176" class="pginternal">1176</a>. Another proverbial saying, <i>ferne yere</i>, last
  year; see <i>fern, fürn</i>, in Stratmann, and cf. A. S. <i>fyrngēarum frōd</i>,
  wise with the experience of past years, Phœnix, 219. Last year's snow will not be seen
  again.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1190" id="TVNL1190" class="pginternal">1190</a>. He persuades himself that the moon is to pass well
  beyond the end of the sign Leo; thus allowing another day.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1222" id="TVNL1222" class="pginternal">1222</a>. <i>by potente</i>, with a stick, or staff with a
  spiked end and crutch-like top; cf. Somp. Ta. D 1776. A <i>potent</i>, in heraldry, is a figure
  resembling the top of a crutch, consisting of a rectangle laid horizontally above a small square.
  See Rom. of the Rose, 368.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1274" id="TVNL1274" class="pginternal">1274</a>. 'Whereas I daily destroy myself by living.'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1313" id="TVNL1313" class="pginternal">1313</a>. <i>rolleth</i>, revolves; see Pard. Ta. C 838; Somn.
  Ta. D 2217.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1335" id="TVNL1335" class="pginternal">1335</a>. 'And for that which is defaced, ye may blame the
  tears.'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1354" id="TVNL1354" class="pginternal">1354</a>. 'I sigh with sorrowful sighs.' MS. Cm. has <i>sikis
  I sike</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1368" id="TVNL1368" class="pginternal">1368</a>. 'I can only say that, being a receptacle for every
  sorrow, I was still alive.' <i>cheste</i>, box; like that of Pandora.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1372" id="TVNL1372" class="pginternal">1372</a>. 'Until I see the contents of your reply.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page501">{501}</span></div>
<p><a href="#TVL1431" id="TVNL1431" class="pginternal">1431</a>. 'Bottomless promises;' i. e. that held

<p><a href="#TVL1450" id="TVNL1450" class="pginternal">1450</a>. <i>Sibille</i>, the Sibyl, the prophetess; not here
  a proper name, but an epithet of Cassandra. Cf. Æneid. vi. 98.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1464" id="TVNL1464" class="pginternal">1464</a>. (Ll. 1457-1512 are not in Boccaccio.) The story of
  Meleager and the Calydonian boar-hunt is told at length in Ovid, Met. viii. 271, &amp;c.; whence
  Chaucer doubtless took it; cf. l. 1469 with Met. viii. 282. The 'mayde,' in l. 1473, was
  Atalanta.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1480" id="TVNL1480" class="pginternal">1480</a>. Chaucer seems to be mistaken here. Tydeus, according
  to one account, was Meleager's brother; and, according to another, his half-brother. He does not
  tell us to what 'olde bokes' he refers.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1483" id="TVNL1483" class="pginternal">1483</a>. <i>moder</i>; his mother Althaea; see Ovid, Met.
  viii. 445.</p>
<p><span class="sc">Latin Lines</span>: Argument of the 12 books of the Thebaid of Statius. These
  lines are placed, in the MSS., after l. 1498, interrupting the connection. I therefore insert them
  after l. 1484, which is certainly their proper place. Ll. 1485-1510 give a loose rendering of
  them. I subjoin an epitome, in a more intelligible form; but suppress many details not mentioned
  in Chaucer.</p>
<p><span class="sc">Book I.</span> Polynices and Tydeus meet, and become allies.</p>
<p>II. Tydeus sets out on an embassy to Eteocles at Thebes, and escapes an ambush by the way (ll.
  1485-1491). He spares Mæon, one of his 50 assailants, and sends him to Thebes with the news,
  whilst he himself returns to Argos instead of proceeding to Thebes (1492-3).</p>
<p>III. Maeon (also called Haemonides, as being the son of Haemon, Bk. iii. l. 42) returns to
  Thebes, and relates how Tydeus had slain 49 men out of 50. At Argos, Amphiaraus, the augur, had
  concealed himself, hoping to delay the war against Thebes, which he prophesied would be
  disastrous; but Capaneus forces him from his retirement, and war is resolved upon (1494).</p>
<p>IV. The seven chiefs set out against Thebes. The army suffers from thirst, but Hypsipyle, a
  Lemnian princess, appears, and shews them a river (1495).</p>
<p>V. Hypsipyle relates the story of 'the furies of Lemnos,' i. e. of the Lemnian women who
  killed all the men in the island except Thoas, her father, whom she saved. (See Leg. of Good
  Women, 1467, and note.) While she is speaking, a snake, sent by Jupiter, kills her infant, named
  Archemorus. The snake is killed by Capaneus (1497, 8).</p>
<p>VI. Description of the obsequies of Archemorus, and of the funeral games (1499).</p>
<p>VII. Description of the temple of Mars (see Knightes Tale). The allies arrive before Thebes,
  and the city is attacked. Amphiaraus is swallowed up by an earthquake (1500).</p>
<p>VIII. Tydeus is slain, after a great slaughter of his enemies (1501).</p>
<p>IX. Hippomedon, after great deeds of valour, is drowned in the river. Death of Parthenopaeus
  (1502, 3).</p>
<p>X. Capaneus is killed by lightning whilst scaling the walls of Thebes (1504, 5).</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page502">{502}</span></div>
<p>XI. Single combat between Eteocles and Polynices; both are slain (1506-8).</p>
<p>XII. Creon forbids the burial of the slain invaders. The wives of the six chieftains seek
  assistance from Theseus, king of Athens (see Knightes Tale). Argia, wife of Polynices, finds and
  burns her husband's body. Theseus slays Creon, and the Thebans open their gates to him
  (1509-10).</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1485" id="TVNL1485" class="pginternal">1485-1491</a>. From the Thebaid, Bk. i (see above).
  <i>felawe</i>, comrade, brother-in-law. <i>Polymites</i>, Polynices. <i>Ethyocles</i>,
  Eteocles.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1492" id="TVNL1492" class="pginternal">1492-8</a>. From the same, Books ii-v. <i>Hemonides</i>,
  Haemonides, i. e. Maeon, son of Haemon. <i>asterte</i>, escaped. <i>fifty</i>; but he only
  slew 49, though attacked by 50. <i>sevene</i>; the seven chieftains, who went to besiege Thebes.
  <i>holy serpent</i>, the snake sent by Jupiter. <i>welle</i>, (apparently) the stream Langia,
  which refreshed the army (end of Bk. iv). <i>The furies</i>, the furious women of Lemnos, who
  killed all the males (but one) in the island.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1499" id="TVNL1499" class="pginternal">1499-1505</a>. From the same, Bks. vi-x. <i>Archimoris</i>,
  Archemorus, infant son of Hypsipyle; honoured by funeral games. <i>Amphiorax</i>, Amphiaraus; see
  Bk. ii. 105, and note to Anelida, 57. <i>Argeyes</i>, Argives, people of Argos. <i>Ypomedon</i>,
  Hippomedon; <i>Parthonope</i>, Parthenopaeus; see note to Anelida, 58. <i>Cappaneus</i>, Capaneus;
  see note to Anelida, 59.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1506" id="TVNL1506" class="pginternal">1506-1512</a>. From the same, Bks. xi, xii. <i>Argyve</i>,
  Argia, wife of Polynices; cf. Bk. iv. l. 762, above. <i>brent</i>, burnt; see Kn. Ta. A 990; but
  Statius says that the Thebans opened their gates to Theseus, who entered in triumph. I find
  nothing about any harm done to the city on this occasion.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1514" id="TVNL1514" class="pginternal">1514</a>. But Tydeus was Meleager's brother; see note to l.
  1480.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1518" id="TVNL1518" class="pginternal">1518</a>. <i>leef</i>, leave it alone. Usually
  <i>leve</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1523" id="TVNL1523" class="pginternal">1523</a>. <i>seestow</i>, seest thou; a general observation,
  <i>not</i> addressed to Cassandra in particular, but to every one at large.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1527" id="TVNL1527" class="pginternal">1527</a>. <i>Alceste</i>, Alcestis; see Leg. of Good Women,
  432.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1528" id="TVNL1528" class="pginternal">1528</a>. <i>but</i>, except, unless. Yet Bell misunderstands
  it.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1530" id="TVNL1530" class="pginternal">1530</a>. <i>housbonde</i>; Admetus, king of Pherae, in
  Thessaly.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1545" id="TVNL1545" class="pginternal">1545</a>. <i>smitted</i>, smutted, disgraced; cf. l. 1546.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1548" id="TVNL1548" class="pginternal">1548</a>. <i>fyn of the paródie</i>, end of the period.
  Chaucer, not being a Greek scholar, has somewhat mistaken the form of the word; but, in MS. H.,
  <i>parodie</i> is duly glossed by 'duracion,' shewing the sense intended. It is from the O. F.
  fem. sb. <i>perióde</i>, or <i>peryóde</i>, of which Littré gives an example in the 14th century:
  '<i>Peryode</i> est le temps et la mesure de la <i>duracion</i> d'une chose;' Oresme, Thèse de
  Meunier. Chaucer, being more familiar with the prefix <i>per-</i> than with the Greek <span class="fsn" title="peri-">περι-</span>, has dropped the <i>i</i>; and the
  confusion between <i>per-</i> and <i>par-</i> is extremely common, because both prefixes were
  denoted, in contracted writing, by the same symbol. We may give up the old attempts at explaining
  the word otherwise, as we know that the glosses are usually due to the author. 'The end of the
  period of Hector's life was nigh at hand.'</p>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page503">{503}</span></div>
<p>Lydgate uses the word in the same sense, having caught it up from the present passage<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'When the <i>paródye</i> of this worthy knyght [Hector]</p>
<p>Aproche shall, without[e] wordes mo,</p>
<p>Into the fyelde playnly if he go.'</p>
<p style="margin-left:3.15em">Siege of Troye, Bk. iii. ch. 27; ed. 1557, fol. R 6.</p>
<p class="stanza" style="margin-left:-0.20em">'And how that he [Ulysses] might[e] not escape</p>
<p>The <i>párodýe</i> that was for hym shape;</p>
<p>For Parchas haue his last[e] <i>terme</i> set,' &amp;c.</p>
<p style="margin-left:10.15em">Id., Bk. v. ch. 38; fol. Dd 3.</p>
</div>
<p>Observe that <i>parodye</i> is here equated to <i>terme</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1558" id="TVNL1558" class="pginternal">1558</a>. From Guido; according to whose account Hector,
  having taken a prisoner, was conveying him through the throng, when Achilles thrust him through
  with a spear in a cowardly manner, stealing up to him unperceived. See allit. Dest. of Troy, ll.
  8649-8660; Lydgate, Siege of Troy, Bk. iii. ch. 27, fol. S 2, back; Shak. Troil. v. 6. 27, 8.
  1.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1634" id="TVNL1634" class="pginternal">1634</a>. <i>kalendes</i>, an introduction to the beginning;
  see note to Bk. ii. 7.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1653" id="TVNL1653" class="pginternal">1653</a>. <i>Lollius</i>; this incident is in the Filostrato,
  viii. st. 8; I do not find it in Guido.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1669" id="TVNL1669" class="pginternal">1669</a>. <i>word and ende</i>, beginning and end; see note to
  Monk. Ta. B 3911; and note to Bk. ii. 1495.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1689" id="TVNL1689" class="pginternal">1689</a>. 'To present your new love with.'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1760" id="TVNL1760" class="pginternal">1760</a>. See note to Book i. 463.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1764" id="TVNL1764" class="pginternal">1764</a>. Here the story practically ends. Beyond this point,
  the lines taken from Boccaccio are less than twenty.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1771" id="TVNL1771" class="pginternal">1771</a>. <i>Dares</i>, i. e. Guido, who professes to
  follow Dares; see note to Book Duch. 1070.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1778" id="TVNL1778" class="pginternal">1778</a>. I. e. Chaucer was beginning to think of his
  Legend of Good Women.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1786" id="TVNL1786" class="pginternal">1786</a>. Here begins the Envoy (interrupted by ll.
  1800-1827). Compare the last three lines of the Filostrato (ix. 8)<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Or va'; ch' io prego Apollo che ti presti</p>
<p>Tanto di grazia ch' ascoltata sii,</p>
<p>E con lieta risposa a me t'invii.'</p>
</div>
<p><a href="#TVL1787" id="TVNL1787" class="pginternal">1787</a>. 'Whereas may God send power to him that wrote thee
  to take part in composing some "comedy," before he die.'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1789" id="TVNL1789" class="pginternal">1789</a>. 'Do not envy any (other) poetry, but be humble.'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1791" id="TVNL1791" class="pginternal">1791</a>. Imitated from the concluding lines of the Thebaid,
  xii. 816<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:3.30em">'nec tu diuinam Æneida tenta,</p>
<p>Sed longe sequere, et <i>uestigia semper adora</i>.'</p>
</div>
<p>The sense is—'And kiss their footsteps, wherever you see Vergil, &amp;c. pass along.' The
  reading <i>space</i> is ridiculous; and, in l. 1792, the names <i>Virgíle</i>, &amp;c., are
  accented on the second syllable. <i>Steppes</i> means 'foot-prints,' Lat. <i>uestigia</i>; see
  Leg. Good Women, 2209.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1792" id="TVNL1792" class="pginternal">1792</a>. An important line. Chaucer, in this poem, has made
  use of Statius (see l. 1485), Ovid (in many places), Vergil (occasionally), and <span class="pagenum" id="page504">{504}</span>Homer (not at first hand). Lucan seems to be mentioned
  only out of respect; but see note to Bk. ii. 167. He is mentioned again in Boethius, Bk. iv. Pr.
  6. 159.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1796" id="TVNL1796" class="pginternal">1796</a>. <i>mismetre</i>, scan wrongly. This shews that
  Chaucer was conscious of his somewhat archaic style, and that there was a danger that some of the
  syllables might be dropped.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1797" id="TVNL1797" class="pginternal">1797</a>. <i>red</i>, read (by a single person), <i>songe</i>,
  read aloud, recited in an intoned voice.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1802" id="TVNL1802" class="pginternal">1802</a>. <i>thousandes</i> is to be taken in the literal
  sense. On one occasion, according to Guido, Troilus slew a thousand men at once. See the allit.
  Destruction of Troy, 9878; Lydgate, Siege of Troy, fol. U 3, back, l. 7.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1806" id="TVNL1806" class="pginternal">1806</a>. So in Guido; see allit. Destr. of Troy, 10302-11;
  Lydgate, Siege of Troye, Bk. iv. ch. 31. Cf. l. 1558, and the note.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1807" id="TVNL1807" class="pginternal">1807-1827</a>. These three stanzas are from Boccaccio's
  <i>Teseide</i>, xi. 1-3, where, however, they refer to Arcita<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Finito Arcita colei nominando</p>
<p>La qual nel mondo più che altro amava,</p>
<p>L'anima lieve se ne gì volando</p>
<p>Vêr la concavità del cielo ottava:</p>
<p>Degli elementi i conuessi lasciando,</p>
<p>Quivi le stelle erratiche ammirava ...</p>
<p>Suoni ascoltando pieni di dolcezza.</p>
<p class="stanza">Quindi si volse in giù a rimirare</p>
<p>Le cose abbandonate, e vide il poco</p>
<p>Globo terreno, a cui d'intorno il mare</p>
<p>Girava ...</p>
<p>Ed ogni cosa da nulla stimare</p>
<p>A respetto del ciel; e in fine al loco</p>
<p>Là dove aveva il corpo suo lasciato</p>
<p>Gli occhi fermò alquanto rivoltato.</p>
<p class="stanza">E fece risa de' pianti dolenti</p>
<p>Della turba lernea; la vanitate</p>
<p>Forte dannando delle umane genti,</p>
<p>Le qua' da tenebrosa cechitate</p>
<p>Mattamente oscurate nelle menti</p>
<p>Seguon del Mondo la falsa beltate:</p>
<p>Lasciando il cielo, quindi se ne gio</p>
<p>Nel loco a cui Mercurio la sortio.'</p>
</div>
<p><i>holownesse</i> translates 'concavità.' For <i>seventh</i>, B. has 'ottava,' eighth. The
  seventh sphere is that of Saturn, from which he might be supposed to observe the motion of Saturn
  and of all the inferior planets. But surely <i>eighth</i> is more correct; else there is no
  special sense in 'holownesse.' The eighth sphere is that of the fixed stars; and by taking up a
  position on the <i>inner</i> or <i>concave</i> surface of this <span class="pagenum" id="page505">{505}</span>sphere, he would see all the planetary spheres revolving within it. (The
  'spheres' were supposed to be concentric shells, like the coats of an onion.) The 'erratic stars,'
  or wandering stars, are the seven planets. As to the music of their spheres, see notes to Parl.
  Foules, ll. 59 and 61.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1810" id="TVNL1810" class="pginternal">1810</a>. <i>in convers leting</i>, leaving behind, on the
  other side. When, for example, he approached the sphere of Mars, it was <i>concave</i> to him;
  after passing beyond it, it appeared <i>convex</i>. Some modern editions of the Teseide read
  <i>connessi</i> (connected parts), but the right reading is <i>conuessi</i> (convex surfaces), for
  which Chaucer substitutes <i>convers</i>. See <i>converse</i> in the New E. Dictionary.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1815" id="TVNL1815" class="pginternal">1815</a>. Cf. Parl. Foules, 57. Boccaccio had in mind Cicero's
  <i>Somnium Scipionis</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1825" id="TVNL1825" class="pginternal">1825</a>. <i>sholden</i>, and we ought; <i>we</i> is
  understood.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1827" id="TVNL1827" class="pginternal">1827</a>. <i>sorted</i>, allotted; Ital. 'sortio.'</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1828" id="TVNL1828" class="pginternal">1828-1837</a>. Chiefly from Il Filostrato, viii. 28, 29.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1838" id="TVNL1838" class="pginternal">1838-1862</a>. These lines are Chaucer's own, and assume a
  higher strain.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1840" id="TVNL1840" class="pginternal">1840</a>. 'This lyf, my sone, is but a chery-feyre.'<br>
<span class="gap" style="width:5em"> </span> Hoccleve, De Regim. Princ. ed. Wright, p.
  47.</p>
<p>See four more similar comparisons in Halliwell's Dict., s. v. <i>Cherry-fair</i>.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1856" id="TVNL1856" class="pginternal">1856</a>. <i>moral Gower.</i> This epithet of Gower has stuck
  to him ever since; he moralises somewhat too much.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1857" id="TVNL1857" class="pginternal">1857</a>. <i>Strode.</i> Concerning this personage, Leland
  discovered the following note in an old catalogue of the worthies of Merton College, Oxford:
  'Radulphus Strode, nobilis poeta fuit et versificavit librum elegiacum vocatum Phantasma
  Radulphi.' In the introduction to his edition of 'Pearl,' p. l., Mr. Gollancz says: 'This Ralph
  Strode is identical with the famous philosopher of that name whose philosophical works hold an
  important place in the history of medieval logic. He was also famous in his time as a
  controversialist with Wiclif, and from Wiclif MSS., still unprinted, it is possible to gain some
  insight into Strode's religious views.' He was, perhaps, related to the philosopher N. Strode, who
  is mentioned at the end of pt. ii. § 40 of the Treatise on the Astrolabe as being the tutor, at
  Oxford, of Chaucer's son Lewis.</p>
<p><a href="#TVL1863" id="TVNL1863" class="pginternal">1863-5</a>. From Dante, Paradiso, xiv. 28-30<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem sp3">
<p style="margin-left:-0.20em">'Quell' uno e due e tre che sempre vive,</p>
<p>E regna sempre in tre e due e uno,</p>
<p>Non circonscritto, e tutto circonscrive.'</p>
</div>
<div><span class="pagenum" id="page506">{506}</span></div>
<h2>ADDITIONAL NOTE TO BOOK III. 674.</h2>
<p>As the curious word <i>voidee</i> has been suppressed in all previous editions, I add some more
  examples of it, for some of which I am indebted to Dr. Murray. It occurs, e.g., in the extremely
  interesting account of the death of James I of Scotland.</p>
<p>'Within an owre the Kyng askid the <i>voidee</i>, and drank, the travers yn the chambure edraw
  [= <i>y-drawe</i>, drawn], and every man depairtid and went to rist': (1400) <span class="sc">Jn.
  Shirley</span>, Dethe of James Stewarde, Kyng of Scotys, p. 13, ed. 1818.</p>
<p>Hence, no doubt, Mr. Rossetti, in his poem of The King's Tragedy, drew the line:—'Then he
  called for the <i>voidee</i>-cup.'</p>
<p>'A <i>voidy</i> of spices': (1548) Hall's Chron. 14 Hen. VIII.</p>
<p>'A <i>voidee</i> of spices': (1577-87) Holinshed's Chron. vol. iii. p. 849.</p>
<p>In A Collection of Ordinances and Regulations for the Royal Household, London, 1790, there are
  several examples of it.</p>
<p>'The Archbishoppe to stand on the Kinges right hand, and the King to make him a becke when hee
  shall take <i>spice and wine</i>. And when the <i>voide</i> is donne, then the King to goe into
  his chamber; and all other estates to goe into their chambers, or where it shall please them,'
  &amp;c.: p. 111; in Articles ordained by King Henry VII.</p>
<p>At p. 113, there are minute directions as to the <i>voidè</i>. The chamberlain and others fetch
  a towel, the cups, and the spice-plates; the king and the bishop take 'spice and wine,' and
  afterwards the lords and people are served 'largely' with spice and wine also; after which the
  cups are removed. At p. 36, we read: 'the bourde <i>avoyded</i> [cleared] when wafyrs come with
  ypocras, or with other swete wynes. The King never taketh a <i>voyd</i> [read <i>voydè</i>] of
  comfites and other spices, but standing.' At p. 121: 'as for the voide on twelfth day at night,
  the King and Queene ought to take it in the halle.' At the Coronation of Queen Anne Boleyn, there
  was a voidè 'of spice-plates and wine'; English Garner, ed. Arber, ii. 50.</p>
<p class="sp3">The <i>voidee</i> was, in fact, a sort of dessert. The word <i>spices</i> included
  many things besides what it now implies. In the Ordinances above-mentioned, there is a list of
  spices, at p. 103. It includes pepper, saffron, ginger, cloves, maces, cinnamon, nutmegs, dates,
  prunes, quinces, comfits, raisins, currants, figs, and even rice. In the North of England, even at
  the present day, it includes sweetmeats, gingerbread, cakes, and dried fruits.</p>

<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_9" id="Nt_9">[9]</a>
<p>See the Romaunt of the Rose (in vol. i.), ll. 5659-5666; and the note to l. 5661. It is also
    tolerably obvious, that Chaucer selected Metre 5 of Book ii. of Boethius for poetical treatment
    in his 'Former Age,' because Jean de Meun had selected for similar treatment the very same
    passage; see Rom. de la Rose, ll. 8395-8406.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_10" id="Nt_10">[10]</a>
<p>There is a copy of this in the British Museum, MS. Addit. 10341.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_11" id="Nt_11">[11]</a>
<p>MS. Harl. 44 (Wülker); <i>not</i> MS. Harl. 43, as in Warton, who has confused this MS. with
    that next mentioned.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_12" id="Nt_12">[12]</a>
<p>MS. Harl. 43 (Wülker); <i>not</i> MS. Harl. 44, as in Warton.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_13" id="Nt_13">[13]</a>
<p>There is a better copy than either of the above in MS. Royal 18 A. xiii. The B. M. Catalogue
    of the Royal MSS., by Casley, erroneously attributes this translation to Lydgate. And there is
    yet a fourth copy, in MS. Sloane 554. The Royal MS. begins, more correctly:—'In
    suffisaunce of cunnyng and of wyt.'</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_14" id="Nt_14">[14]</a>
<p>MS. i. 53.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_15" id="Nt_15">[15]</a>
<p>MS. B. 5. There is yet another MS. in the library of Trinity College, Oxford, no. 75; and
    others in the Bodleian Library (MS. Rawlinson 151), in the Cambridge University Library (Gg. iv.
    18), and in the Phillipps collection (as in note 5 below).</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_16" id="Nt_16">[16]</a>
<p>'The Boke of Comfort, translated into Englesse tonge. Enprented in the exempt Monastery of
    Tavestok in Denshyre, by me, Dan Thomas Rychard, Monke; 1525. 4to.'—Lowndes.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_17" id="Nt_17">[17]</a>
<p>The MS. is now in the collection of Sir Thomas Phillipps; no. 1099.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_18" id="Nt_18">[18]</a>
<p>He here implies that Chaucer's translation was by no means the only one then in existence; a
    remarkable statement.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_19" id="Nt_19">[19]</a>
<p>MS. inserts <i>full</i>, needlessly.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_20" id="Nt_20">[20]</a>
<p><i>Perhaps read</i> In.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_21" id="Nt_21">[21]</a>
<p>MS. neye.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_22" id="Nt_22">[22]</a>
<p>MS. hy<i>m</i>self.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_23" id="Nt_23">[23]</a>
<p>MS. theym self.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_24" id="Nt_24">[24]</a>
<p><i>Printed</i> feldes <i>by</i> Mr. Stewart.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_25" id="Nt_25">[25]</a>
<p>Observe that this line is due to Chaucer's <i>gloss</i>, not to his text.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_26" id="Nt_26">[26]</a>
<p>MS. Thisee (!).</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_27" id="Nt_27">[27]</a>
<p>MS. hem self.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_28" id="Nt_28">[28]</a>
<p><i>Printed</i> thise <i>by</i> Mr. Stewart.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_29" id="Nt_29">[29]</a>
<p>MS. This (giving no sense).</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_30" id="Nt_30">[30]</a>
<p>Mr. Stewart <i>omits</i> thus.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_31" id="Nt_31">[31]</a>
<p>MS. parelous (!). This shews that Walton's text can be corrected by Chaucer's.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_32" id="Nt_32">[32]</a>
<p>Yet we must remember that 'The Former Age' only reproduces a <i>part</i> of this Metre; and
    that it also introduces a passage from Jerome, besides reminiscences of Ovid and of Le Roman de
    la Rose; as shewn in the notes.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_33" id="Nt_33">[33]</a>
<p>Mr. Stewart adds another instance, from Bk. iii. met. 5. 5<span class="wnw">:—</span></p>
<div class="poem">
<p>And that the last ile in the see</p>
<p>That hight Tyle, be thral to thee.</p>
</div>
<p>I hope this was unintentional, for they are poor verses. It is higher praise to say that,
    especially in the Metres, Chaucer's prose often flows well, with a certain melody of its own.
    Mr. Stewart also gives some instances in which he supposes that Chaucer 'actually reproduces the
    original Latin metre;' but they are imperfect and unintended.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_34" id="Nt_34">[34]</a>
<p>Mr. Stewart quotes this as: 'a long unagreable dwellynges;' but 'draweth a-long' is a fair
    translation of 'protrahit.'</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_35" id="Nt_35">[35]</a>
<p>365 is the number of the line; see p. 164 below. I refer to Boethius by the letter 'B.',
    meaning the text as printed in the present volume, giving the <i>line</i> of the text as well as
    the number of the Prose or Metre, so that every passage can easily be found.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_36" id="Nt_36">[36]</a>
<p>The prefixed asterisk marks a <i>doubtful</i> or <i>wrong</i> instance.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_37" id="Nt_37">[37]</a>
<p>I omit the comparison of Bk. iii. ll. 8-14 with Boethius; for the whole stanza is copied from
    the <i>Filostrato</i>, Bk. iii. st. 75. Also, that of l. 373 with B. iii. met. 9. 1; for l. 373
    is copied from the <i>Filostrato</i>, Bk. iii. st. 15.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_38" id="Nt_38">[38]</a>
<p>I omit mention of l. 2839 (compared with B. ii. met. 3. 14); for it is taken from the
    <i>Teseide</i>, Bk. ix, 10, 11.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_39" id="Nt_39">[39]</a>
<p>The three points are: (1) Avarice is insatiable, l. 2321, which answers to 'finem quaerendi
    non inuenit,' quoted as from Seneca, but really from Palladius; see Albertani Brixiensis Liber
    Consolationis, ed. T. Sundby, p. 37: (2) Good and evil are two contraries, l. 2479; compare the
    same, p. 96: (3) Fortune the nurse, l. 2635, translated from 'fortuna usque nunc me fouit'; see
    the same, p. 89.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_40" id="Nt_40">[40]</a>
<p>I have noted a few inaccuracies, chiefly due to confusion of <i>c</i> and <i>t</i> (which are
    written alike), and to abbreviations. At p. 2, l. 13, for 'p<i>ro</i>cede' read
    'p<i>er</i>cede.' At p. 9, l. 28, for 'basilicis' read 'basilius.' At p. 11, l. 32, read
    'auauntede.' At p. 12, l. 10, read 'c<i>on</i>uict'; &amp;c. Cf. note to Bk. v. pr. 6. 82.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_41" id="Nt_41">[41]</a>
<p>Here <i>recte</i> is miswritten for <i>recta</i>, clearly because the scribe was still
    thinking of the latter syllable of the preceding <i>sponte</i>. But observe that Ch. has 'the
    rightes,' a translation of <i>recta</i>. This proves at once that Chaucer did not use <i>this
    particular copy</i> as his original; and of course the peculiar mode in which it is written
    precludes such a supposition. But I believe it to be copied from Chaucer's copy, all the
    same.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_42" id="Nt_42">[42]</a>
<p>This shews how entirely wrong an editor would be who should change the forms into
    <i>Atrides</i> and <i>Agamemnon</i>; unless, indeed, he were to give due notice. For it destroys
    the evidence. Note also, that <i>Agamenon</i> is the usual M. E. form. It appears as
    <i>Agamenoun</i> in Troil. iii. 382.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_43" id="Nt_43">[43]</a>
<p>Hence it is easy to see that when Chaucer's glosses agree, as they sometimes do, with those
    in Notker's Old High German version or in any other version, the agreement is due to the fact
    that both translators had similar <i>Latin</i> glosses before them.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_44" id="Nt_44">[44]</a>
<p>My text has <i>thonder-light</i>, as in the MSS.; but <i>leyte</i> or <i>leyt</i> is better;
    see note to the line (p. <a href="#page422" class="pginternal">422</a>), and see above, p. <a href="#pagexlii" class="pginternal">xlii</a>, l. 8.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_45" id="Nt_45">[45]</a>
<p>There is a later edition by Peiper, said to be the best; but it is out of print, and I failed
    to obtain a copy. But I have also collated the Latin text in the Delphin edition, ed. Valpy,
    1823, and the edition by Renatus Vallinus, 1656; both of these contain useful notes.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_46" id="Nt_46">[46]</a>
<p>Mr. Rossetti has a note, shewing that Prof. Morley's figures are incorrect. He himself
    reckons <i>Troilus</i> as containing 8246 lines, because the number of stanzas in Book V. of Dr.
    Furnivall's print of MS. Harl. 3943 is wrongly given as 268 instead of 267.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_47" id="Nt_47">[47]</a>
<p>For a fuller comparison with this poem, see § <a href="#stro21" class="pginternal">21</a> below; p. <a href="#pagelxv" class="pginternal">lxv</a>.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_48" id="Nt_48">[48]</a>
<p>Lydgate accepts Chaucer's view without question. He says—'And of this syege wrote eke
    Lollius'; Siege of Troye, ed. 1555, fol. B 2, back.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_49" id="Nt_49">[49]</a>
<p>Usually called Guido de Colonna, probably because he was supposed to belong to a famous
    family named Colonna; but his name seems to have been taken from the name of a place (see note 1
    on p. lvi). My quotations from Guido are from MS. Mm. 5. 14, in the Cambridge University
    Library.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_50" id="Nt_50">[50]</a>
<p>He refers to the story of Troy as existing 'in the Latyn and the Frenshe'; Siege of Troye,
    fol. B 1, back; and explains 'the Latyn' as 'Guido.'</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_51" id="Nt_51">[51]</a>
<p>In an Italian work entitled 'Testi Inediti di Storia Trojana,' by E. Gorra, Turin, 1887, a
    passage is quoted at p. 137, from Book XIII of Guido, which says that Terranova, on the S. coast
    of Sicily, was also called 'columpne Herculis,' and Gorra suggests that this was the place
    whence Guido derived his name 'delle Colonne.' At any rate, Guido was much interested in these
    'columns'; see Lydgate, Siege of Troye, fol. M 4. I think <i>Tropæus</i>, from Gk. <span class="fsn" title="tropaia">τροπαῖα</span>, may refer to
    these <i>columnæ</i>; or Guido may have been connected with <i>Tropea</i>, on the W. coast of
    Calabria, less than fifty miles from Messina, where he was a judge.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_52" id="Nt_52">[52]</a>
<p>'Homerus ... fingens multa que non fuerunt, et que fuerunt aliter transformando'; Prologus.
    See the E. translation in the Gest Hystoriale, or alliterative Troy-book, ll. 38-47; Lydgate,
    Siege of Troye, fol. B 2.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_53" id="Nt_53">[53]</a>
<p>See allit. Troy-book, ll. 60-79.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_54" id="Nt_54">[54]</a>
<p>See allit. Troy-book, ll. 3922-34; Lydgate, Siege of Troye, fol. F 3, back.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_55" id="Nt_55">[55]</a>
<p>MS. penatos.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_56" id="Nt_56">[56]</a>
<p>The mention of Escaphilo, i.e. Ascalaphus, in Book V. 319, was perhaps suggested by the
    mention of Ascalaphus by Guido (after Dictys, i. 13, Homer, Il. ii. 512) as being one of the
    Grecian leaders; see allit. Troy-book, l. 4067.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_57" id="Nt_57">[57]</a>
<p>I. e. glove; from Gk. <span class="fsn" title="cheir">χείρ</span>,
    hand, and <span class="fsn" title="thêkê">θήκη</span>, case.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_58" id="Nt_58">[58]</a>
<p>Put for xenium (<span class="fsn" title="xenion">ξένιον</span>),
    a gift, present.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_59" id="Nt_59">[59]</a>
<p>Cf. 'And save hir browes ioyneden y-fere'; Troil. v. 813.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_60" id="Nt_60">[60]</a>
<p><i>Talke</i> is not in the Glossary. As <i>lk</i> is a common way of writing <i>kk</i> (as
    shewn in my paper on 'Ghost-words' for the Phil. Soc.), the word is really <i>takke</i>, a
    variant of <i>take</i>; and the sense is 'let him take.'</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_61" id="Nt_61">[61]</a>
<p>Lydgate began his Troy-book on Oct. 31, 1412, and finished it in 1420; see this shewn in my
    letter to the <i>Academy</i>, May 7, 1892.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_62" id="Nt_62">[62]</a>
<p>Hence it was not written by Sir Hugh Eglintoun, if he died either in 1376 or 1381; see Pref.
    to allit. Troy-book, pp. xvii, xxv.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_63" id="Nt_63">[63]</a>
<p>MS. to disport; <i>but</i> to <i>is needless</i>.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_64" id="Nt_64">[64]</a>
<p>MS. I for; I <i>is needless</i>.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_65" id="Nt_65">[65]</a>
<p>Two false rimes; <i>ye</i> and <i>aweye</i>; <i>dispyt</i> and <i>bright</i> (correctly,
    <i>bright e</i>).</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_66" id="Nt_66">[66]</a>
<p>Not <i>clene</i>, as in the St. John's MS. and in the Phillipps MS.; for Chaucer never rimes
    <i>clene</i> (with open <i>e</i>) with such words as <i>grene</i>, <i>quene</i> (with close
    <i>e</i>); see, on this point, the remarks on my Rime-Index to Troilus, published for the
    Chaucer Society. MS. Harl. 2392 likewise has <i>sheene</i>, a word in which the long <i>e</i> is
    of 'variable' quality.</p>
</div>
<div class="foot">
<a class="fnote pginternal" href="#NtA_67" id="Nt_67">[67]</a>
<p>Some guess that it means 'Tres gentil Chaucer.' But this seems to me very improbable, if not
    stupid.</p>
</div>
